program_0.description: The gene set represents a canonical cell-cycle program characteristic of highly proliferating cells in late-S through G2/M phase rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. Evidence: • Universal proliferation markers: MKI67, UBE2C, PCNA, BIRC5 and CIP2A are hallmarks of actively cycling cells. • S-phase DNA replication/repair: MCM2-7, MCM10, CDC6, RFC3/4/5, POLE2, TYMS, RRM1/2, BRCA1/2, RAD51AP1, EXO1, FEN1, HELLS, CHEK1 indicate ongoing DNA synthesis and genome maintenance. • G2/M regulators and mitotic kinases: CCNA2, CCNB1/2, CDC25A/C, AURKA/B, PLK4, PKMYT1 control G2/M transition and spindle assembly. • Kinetochore, spindle and chromosome-segregation factors: BUB1/B, CENPA/E/P/W, NUSAP1, KIF2C, KIF15, KIF20A/B, KIF23, TPX2, NUF2, SGO1/2, ANLN, RACGAP1, INCENP support mitotic spindle formation and chromatid cohesion. • Histone and chromatin assembly genes (multiple H1, H2A, H2B, H3 variants; HJURP, CHAF1A/B, ASF1B) accompany DNA replication and chromosome condensation. • Absence of negatively loaded lineage-specific genes reinforces that the signal is driven by proliferation rather than a particular cell identity. Inconsistencies: • A few transcripts (e.g., NMU, GPR19, CHRNA5, DAND5) are not classically linked to cell-cycle control and may reflect low-level background expression or co-regulation in the original dataset, but they are numerically and functionally minor relative to the dominant proliferation signature.

program_1.description: The gene set most strongly reflects a basal, stem-like program of stratified/pseudostratified epithelial cells such as skin or airway basal cells that are poised for regeneration and barrier repair. It is driven by canonical basal‐keratinocyte transcription factors (TP63, SOX2/15), structural and adhesion molecules that anchor cells to the basement membrane (KRT14, COL17A1, COL7A1, LAMB3/-C2, ITGA2, FERMT1), growth-factor receptors that sustain self-renewal (EGFR, FGFR3, LGR6, NGFR), and extracellular-matrix remodeling genes (MMP3/10, POSTN, TNC). Concomitant expression of the epithelial “alarmins’’ IL33 and TSLP indicates an activated/wound-response state of these basal progenitors. Evidence: • Basal-cell identity: TP63, SOX2, SOX15, IRF6, PAX9, BCL11A, LGR6, NGFR – transcription factors/receptors essential for basal epithelial stem cells in skin and airway. • Keratinocyte/hemidesmosome components: KRT14, COL17A1, COL7A1, LAMB3, LAMC2, ITGA2, PKP1, DSC3, FERMT1 – hallmark structural genes of basal keratinocytes anchoring to basement membrane. • Growth‐factor signaling sustaining proliferation: EGFR, FGFR3, WNT10A, NRG1, TNC, POSTN. • Matrix remodeling & migration during repair: MMP3, MMP10, LOXL4, TNC, POSTN, TNS4. • Epithelial barrier “alarmins’’/cytokines: IL33, TSLP, CCL26 – released by stressed airway/skin epithelium. • Metabolic support of active stem cells: ALDH3A2, PHGDH, CKMT1A/B, LDHB, PKM. • Negative loadings lack epithelial-specific genes (TPT1, UBA52, DONSON), reinforcing that high program scores distinguish this specialized basal state from generic cycling or immune cells. Inconsistencies: • Neuronal-associated genes (SNCA, NEUROD2, SYT2, SLITRK5/6, CHRNA5) and thyroglobulin (TG) are not typical for basal keratinocytes and may reflect low-level contamination from neighboring neuro-epithelial or endocrine cells. • JCHAIN and PIWIL1 among negatively loaded genes indicate that immune and germ-line programs are merely under-represented, not truly part of the basal epithelial signature.

program_2.description: The gene set represents a strongly NF-κB–driven, pro-inflammatory activation program in monocyte-derived macrophages / inflammatory dendritic cells. Cells expressing this module show hallmark myeloid markers together with broad induction of chemokines, cytokines, matrix-remodelling enzymes and canonical NF-κB target genes, consistent with macrophages or CD11c⁺ inflammatory DCs responding to TNF/IL-1 or TLR ligands. Evidence: • Myeloid identity – CD14, ITGAX (CD11c), TLR2, LILRB2, CLEC4E, FPR2, STAB1, GPR84, PTPRE, INPP5D. • NF-κB signalling/activation – NFKB1, REL, NFKBIA, NFKBIE, MAP3K8, IRAK2, TNFAIP3, TNIP3, MALT1, TNFRSF1B. • Inflammasome & acute inflammatory genes – NLRP3, IL1A, IL1RN, ACOD1, CH25H. • Pro-inflammatory chemokines/cytokines driving neutrophil & T-cell recruitment – CXCL2, CXCL3, CXCL5, CXCL9, CXCL10, CCL3, CCL3L3, CCL4L2, CCL7, IL23A, IL17C, OSM, VEGFA. • Matrix remodelling / tissue-interaction – MMP9, MMP19, MMP25, THBS1, VCAN, ADAM19, SPP1. • Monocyte-to-macrophage transcriptional regulators – MAFB, ZEB2, NR4A2, NR4A3, KDM6B. • Anti-microbial & metabolic re-programming typical of activated macrophages – APOBEC3A, GCH1, PFKFB3, SLC2A3, KYNU. Inconsistencies: • Anti-inflammatory or resolution-associated genes (IL10, SERPINB2) are present but can be up-regulated late in activation; they do not contradict a macrophage activation state. • BATF3 and IRF4 are classically linked to dendritic cell subsets; however, inflammatory monocyte-derived DCs can express these factors under NF-κB stimulation. • PPBP (platelet factor) and SLAMF7 are atypical for myeloid cells but are occasionally detected in activated macrophages or may reflect platelet–leukocyte aggregates. Overall, the weight of the gene signature supports an activated inflammatory monocyte/macrophage program despite these minor outliers.

program_3.description: The gene set is most consistent with an alveolar type I (ATI) pneumocyte program—i.e. a distal-lung, flattened epithelial cell specialized for gas exchange and fluid absorption. Evidence: • Core ATI markers are strongly positive: AGER (RAGE), PDPN, VEGFA, GJA1, and ICAM1 are canonical for ATI cells. • Basement-membrane/adhesion genes required for the expansive, thin ATI surface are enriched: COL4A3, COL4A4, COL8A1, COL12A1, LAMA3, LAMB3, ITGA3, CD151, BCAM. • Ion and fluid transport genes typical of ATI epithelium are present: SCNN1A/B/G (ENaC subunits), FXYD4, SLC1A1, CLCNKA, PTPRQ, CYP4B1. • Additional distal-lung epithelial/ATI-associated genes: SPOCK2, WNT7A, ERRFI1, NEDD4L, EZR, PDGFA-responsive TNFRSF12A (TWEAK-R), and VEGFA. • Mesenchymal/activated fibroblast markers (PDGFD, SERPINB2, HPSE) are negatively loaded, reinforcing an epithelial—rather than stromal—identity. Inconsistencies: • Secretory / airway goblet components (MUC5AC, CEACAM6, SDC1) and mesothelial markers (MSLN, UPK3B) appear, suggesting some contamination or a transitional/distal-airway cell admixture. • KLRG2 (immune receptor) and UPK3B (uroplakin) are atypical for pure ATI cells. • The presence of several neuronal-related genes (MAP2, GPM6A, CNTN6) is unusual for lung epithelium and may reflect low-level background expression or doublets.

program_4.description: The gene set represents activated, extracellular-matrix-producing fibroblasts (myofibroblast / cancer-associated fibroblast–like state) characterized by strong TGF-β/WNT signaling, matrix remodeling enzymes, and stromal growth-factor production typical of wound healing and tumor stroma. Evidence: • Matrix synthesis/remodeling – COL16A1, FMOD, ASPN, CTHRC1, LOXL1, SERPINH1, P4HA2, HAS1/HAS2, MMP11, MMP17, ADAMTS4, ADAM33, FAP, THBS4 indicate high ECM deposition and turnover. • Myofibroblast/stromal surface markers – PDPN, ITGA11, LRRC15, CD34, ITGB5, CLEC11A, FAP, PROCR are enriched in activated fibroblasts and CAFs. • TGF-β / WNT / Hedgehog pathway components – TGFBR3, IL11 (TGF-β target), SFRP1, RSPO3, GLI1, GLI2, IL17RD, SP5 support profibrotic signaling. • Growth factors and receptors – FGF2, FGF9, FGF10, IGF2, FGFR1, LEPR, ACKR3 promote paracrine support typical of stromal activation. • Additional fibroblast-associated genes – DPT, CXCL14, C1QTNF3, MFAP2, SULF1, ACKR2, GAS6-like ligands (ANGPTL2/5), CILP, SMOC2 match published CAF/wound-fibroblast signatures. Inconsistencies: • Neuronal/endocrine transcripts (SCG2, SCG5, PENK, NNAT, CBLN3, GALR1) and steroidogenic genes (CYP11A1, ESR1) are uncommon in fibroblasts and may derive from low-level contamination or cross-program loading. • Lack of classical contractile myofibroblast gene ACTA2 (α-SMA) slightly diverges from a fully differentiated myofibroblast profile.

program_5.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated / effector regulatory T-cell (Treg) program, characteristic of FOXP3⁺, IL-2-dependent Tregs that have recently been stimulated and display multiple suppressive and tissue-homing molecules. Evidence: • Canonical Treg lineage/activation genes: FOXP3, IL2RA (CD25), CTLA4, TIGIT, LAG3, PDCD1, ICOS, TNFRSF4 (OX40), TNFRSF25, CCR4 – hallmark of activated suppressive Tregs. • Transcriptional regulators of eTregs: BATF, PRDM1 (BLIMP1), RORA, IKZF1/3, BCL11B, ETS1 – support a differentiated, effector Treg state. • Suppressive/function genes: IL10RA, TNFAIP3 (A20), SOCS1, GPR171, PTPN22, GZMK (non-lytic granzyme used by Tregs), CD40LG – molecules linked to immune modulation rather than cytotoxic killing. • Co-stimulatory / checkpoint breadth typical of highly activated Tregs: CD27, CD28, CD226, SLAMF6, CXCR6, CCR6, CXCR3. • Absence/negative loading of classical degranulation gene CD63 and detoxifying GSTP1, together with lack of PRF1/GZMB, fits a non-cytotoxic regulatory phenotype. Inconsistencies: • STAT4, IL23R, RORA, CXCR3, TNF and CCR6 are more often associated with Th1/Th17 effector cells. • Expression of NK receptors (KLRK1, KLRC1/2/3) and cytotoxic-adjacent gene ZNF683 can be seen in tissue-resident or exhausted CD8⁺/NK-like T cells. These suggest some overlap with inflammatory or tissue-resident T-cell states, but the dominant FOXP3/IL2RA/CTLA4/TIGIT signature supports an activated Treg program.

program_6.description: The program most strongly fits a neural-crest–derived mural cell/pericyte state characterized by extracellular-matrix-producing, vaso-contractile, and nerve-interactive features. Cells expressing this module show classical pericyte/mural markers, contractility genes, and collagen/ECM genes, while also retaining a set of Schwann-/neuronal-associated transcripts indicative of their neural-crest origin and plasticity. Evidence: • Mural / pericyte identity – Canonical pericyte markers: RGS5, MCAM (CD146), CSPG4 (NG2), AOC3, GJA4, RBPMS2 – Vaso-contractile receptors and effectors: EDNRA, AGTR1, ADRA1D, PRKG1, ABCC9, SMTN, PDE5A, ANGPT2 • Matrix-secreting fibro-mesenchymal program – Collagens and ECM modifiers: COL12A1, COL18A1, COL5A3, COL5A3, COL18A1, TNS1/2, ADAMTS1/ADAMTSL3, SDC2, ECM1, EDIL3, DKK3 • Neural-crest / Schwann lineage signatures – Schwann–peripheral-nerve genes: CDH19, LGI4, ADGRG6 (GPR126), NDRG1, PTN, GPR20, FOXS1, NES – Neural adhesion / ion-channel genes often retained in neural-crest-derived pericytes: ADARB2, KCNC4, KCNJ6, CACNA1C/H, GABRB2, GABBR1, RIMS3 • Transcriptional regulators linked to neural-crest mesenchyme: NR2F2, TBX3/4, FOXF2, FOXS1, CEBPD Inconsistencies: • Mature smooth-muscle contractile genes (ACTA2, TAGLN, MYH11) are not present, suggesting a less differentiated mural state. • A subset of neuronal genes (ELAVL3, LAMP5) is atypical for pericytes but can reflect residual neural-crest transcriptional memory. • The only negatively loaded gene, SERPINB3, is an epithelial stress marker whose repression is not directly related to mural cells.

program_7.description: The gene loadings point to an activated, GZMK-high effector-memory CD8⁺ T/NK-like state that is mounting a type-1 (IFN-γ-driven) response and is equipped for tissue trafficking and immune synapse formation; erythroid genes are anti-correlated, indicating that the program is specific to cytotoxic lymphocytes rather than red-cell contaminants. Evidence: • Cytotoxic / type-1 effector molecules – IFNG, FASLG, GZMK, XCL1, XCL2, CCL3, CCL4L2. • Core T/NK surface receptors – CD8B, CD244, SLAMF6, TIGIT, CD160, CD226, NCAM1, NCR1, KIR2DL1/3/4, KIR3DL1/2, KLRC1/2/3; adaptor/signalling genes FYB1, PLEK, SH2D1A/B, LCK-associated HCLS1. • Transcription factors that specify cytotoxic T/NK fate – EOMES, STAT4, ETS1, IKZF1, IKZF3, ZNF683 (HOBIT), GATA3 (low-level but common in memory CD8⁺ and NK cells). • Trafficking / adhesion / cytoskeleton remodeling – ITGA4, ITGAL, SELPLG, FERMT3, CFL1, WAS, FMNL1, RHOF, multiple ARHGAP/ARHGEF genes, RASGRP2. • Activation markers – TNFRSF9 (4-1BB), DDIT4, PIM1, CREM, IL21R, IL18RAP, IL12RB1. • Negative loadings of erythroid genes (HBB, SLC25A37) and positive loadings of erythroid contaminant transcripts (HBA1/2) underscore that the program is strongest where red-cell signatures are lowest, further highlighting its lymphoid specificity. Inconsistencies: • Occasional myeloid-associated genes (AOAH, ADAM8, LITAF) and neutrophil chemokine receptor CXCR2 suggest minor contamination or shared inflammatory pathways. • Low-level expression of non-lymphoid genes (MBP, keratins KRT81/86) likely reflects ambient RNA rather than true lineage signals.

program_8.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated mast-cell program, characteristic of IgE-stimulated, pro-inflammatory mast cells engaged in histamine, leukotriene and prostaglandin production. Evidence: • Lineage/core mast-cell markers: CPA3, TPSD1/TPSG1, HPGDS, MS4A2 & FCER1A (high-affinity IgE receptor), KIT, SIGLEC8, ENPP3, GATA2, MITF, RHEX, GCSAML. • Mediator-biosynthetic enzymes: HDC (histamine), LTC4S (cysteinyl-LTs), PTGS1/2 and HPGDS (prostaglandins). • Activation/IgE-signalling molecules: RGS13, LAT2, BTK, TESPA1, GRAP2, PLC-linked GPR65, CYSLTR1, IL1RL1 (ST2), TNFRSF9, TNFAIP3, NFKBIA/NFKBID (NF-κB feedback), SOCS1, BATF. • Mast-cell cytokine/chemokine output: IL13, CSF1, AREG, XCL1, IFNG. • Negative loading of airway/intestinal epithelial genes (SCNN1B, ESRRG, SCUBE2, TMPRSS11E, ITLN1) further separates this program from epithelial cells and supports a mast-cell identity. Inconsistencies: • T-reg/activated T-cell transcripts (FOXP3, IL2RA, TIGIT, CRTAM, XCL1, IFNG) and dendritic/platelet-related genes (CD1B, PPBP, HBA1) appear in the positive list; these may reflect ambient RNA or rare doublets rather than true mast-cell expression.

program_9.description: The gene set is most consistent with activated micro-/capillary endothelial cells undergoing hypoxia-driven, inflammatory angiogenesis (tip/stalk transition). The program combines core endothelial identity factors with strong VEGF/Notch-dependent sprouting cues, hypoxia-inducible stress genes, and interferon-responsive transcripts, reflecting vessels that are remodeling in a low-oxygen, cytokine-rich milieu. Evidence: • Endothelial identity: FLT1 (VEGFR1), KDR (VEGFR2), ERG, GATA2, CD34, PCDH12, ADGRL4 (ELTD1), CD300LG, CD36, ICAM1, TSPAN12, ITGA5/ITGA10, ACE, SCARB1 confirm vascular endothelial lineage. • Angiogenic/tip-cell signals: DLL4, APLN/APLNR, PDGFB, CX3CL1, SEMA6A, SEMA7A, RGCC, FRY mark sprouting, guidance and pericyte recruitment. • Hypoxia & shear stress response: HIF3A, EDN1/EDN2, SERPINE1, KLF2, KLF4, SGK1, ZFP36, NUAK2, EMP1 are classical targets of HIF or flow-responsive pathways in remodeling vessels. • Cytokine / interferon activation: IFIT1, GBP1/4, TAP1/2, IRF1, HLA-F, BATF2, IL4R, IL15RA indicate exposure to inflammatory cytokines and type-I/II IFN. • Migration/ECM remodeling: DOCK6/9, ARHGAP31, PAK4, NEDD9, LOXL2, STARD13, PLA2G4C facilitate cytoskeletal rearrangement and extracellular matrix modification typical of sprouting endothelium. Inconsistencies: • IL7R and CSF1 are more typical of lymphoid or myeloid cells but can be lowly expressed in some endothelial subsets; NES (nestin) is shared with endothelial progenitors/pericytes. Overall, these few genes do not outweigh the strong endothelial/angiogenic signature.

program_10.description: The program aligns best with mucin-secreting (goblet/secretory) airway or upper-airway epithelial cells that are transcriptionally activated by pro-inflammatory / interferon signals. Evidence: • Secretory/goblet cell machinery – high expression of mucins (MUC4, MUC5AC, MUC16, MUC20, MUC21), SPDEF (master regulator of goblet differentiation), glycosyl-transferases (GCNT3, B3GNT3, GALNT4/12/14, FUT3/6), secreted airway proteins (BPIFA1, BPIFA2, FCGBP, TFF-like SERPINB3/B11, PRSS22), and apical trafficking genes (MAL2, NHERF1, UPK1B, SLC26A4, SCNN1A, AQP5, ATP1B1). • Airway/bronchial xenobiotic & oxidative enzymes – CYP2A13, CYP2A6, CYP2B6, DUOX2/DUOXA2, NOS2, GSTP1, ALOX15, ASS1, indicating detoxification and reactive-oxygen pathways typical of airway epithelium. • Epithelial identity – cytokeratins/periplakin (KRT4, KRT23, KRT24, PPL), cell-cell adhesion (NECTIN4, VSIG2), and epithelial Golgi/ER regulators (GOLM1, CREB3L1, ERN2). • Inflammatory / interferon stimulation – OAS1, HERC6, CXCL10, IL17C, IL19, CFB, SAA1/2/4, NOS2, HLA-G, indicating exposure to viral or cytokine signals; TFCP2L1 and DDIT4L further mark stress/STAT signaling. • Airway-specific metabolic genes – CYP4F3, HSD11B2, SLC5A8, SLC15A2, ABCC11, supporting upper-airway rather than intestinal origin. Inconsistencies: • A few lineage-unrelated transcripts (HBB, MESP1, PAX7, RUNX2, MYL11) likely reflect ambient RNA or rare doublets rather than true expression in this program.

program_11.description: Gene enrichments point to activated B cells transitioning toward antibody-secreting plasmablasts/plasma cells, characterised by high immunoglobulin signalling components together with a strong unfolded-protein-response/secretory-ER module. Evidence: • B-cell identity: CD79A/B, CD19, MS4A1 (CD20), PAX5, SPIB, BANK1, BLK, CD22, FCRL1/2/5, CD180, CXCR5, CCR7, SELL. • Activation / class-switch & survival: CD27, CD83, TNFRSF13B (TACI), TNFRSF13C (BAFF-R), TNFRSF17 (BCMA), CD70, REL, NFKBID, BCL2. • Plasmablast / plasma-cell differentiation: PRDM1 (BLIMP1), IRF4, XBP1, JCHAIN, MZB1, FKBP11, SDF2L1, HSPA5, CALR, PDIA3/4/6, HERPUD1, SSR3/4, SEC61B – genes driving immunoglobulin folding and secretion. • Secretory/ER-stress machinery (hallmark of high Ig production): DNAJB9, TXNDC5, P4HB, MANF, PDIA4, PDIA6, SPCS2. • Chemokine receptors guiding plasmablast trafficking: CCR10, CXCR5. • Negative loadings (PSMA7, SERPINH1) decrease as the secretory B-cell program increases, consistent with diversion away from collagen-producing or housekeeping pathways. Inconsistencies: • Persistence of early B-cell markers (PAX5, MS4A1) suggests cells are not fully matured plasma cells but in transition. • pDC/DC-associated genes (CLEC4C, LILRA4, CLEC9A, CD1A) and cytotoxic marker GZMK appear sporadically and are not typical for B-lineage, indicating possible low-level contamination or gene-sharing noise. • Presence of epithelial/neuronal genes (GRIN2A negatively loaded, TRPV3, CLDN14) likewise likely represents background rather than the core program.

program_12.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, angiogenic endothelial-cell program characterized by Notch/arterial signaling and hypoxia-responsive remodeling. Evidence: • Core endothelial identity: FLT1, ERG, GATA2, SOX17/18, HEG1, JCAD, CD36, ITGA5, CD59, THBD, PTPRM, PTPRG, ADGRL4, CLEC3B. • Notch–arterial specification and tip/stalk behavior: DLL4, NOTCH1, HEY1, EFNB2, GJA5, SMAD6, RGS5, SOX17 indicate arterial / angiogenic stalk cells. • Angiogenic and guidance cues: EPHB4 (vascular remodeling), SEMA3G/6A, EFNB2, NEDD9, SHROOM4, ADAM15 support sprouting and migration. • Hypoxia / metabolic stress typical of remodeling vessels: HIF3A, PDK4, PPARGC1B, CXCL12, EDN1, IGFBP3, COX7A1. • Immune-modulatory activation often seen in inflamed endothelium: IL33, CD274 (PD-L1), IL18BP, CCL14, CXCL12, IFI44L/IFIT2, BATF2. • Venous/lymphatic admixture genes (EPHB4, GPIHBP1, LEPR, APLNR) fit the heterogeneity frequently observed in angiogenic endothelium. Inconsistencies: • Presence of lymphocyte-associated genes (GIMAP5/8, IL7R, IL15RA, NRN1) and pericyte-enriched RGS5 could reflect minor contamination or endothelial uptake of immune transcripts.

program_13.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with classically activated (pro-inflammatory, glycolytic) monocytes/macrophages. Evidence: • Lineage markers – CSF1R, CD302, LILRA2, ANPEP (CD13) and CSF3R define cells of the monocyte / macrophage / granulocyte compartment; HCLS1 and PRAM1 are confined to hematopoietic immune cells. • Inflammatory / activation genes – FOS, DUSP1, MIF, RHOB, CCL24, TNFSF13 and TNFRSF10C are rapidly induced by Toll-like-receptor or cytokine stimulation in M1-like macrophages. • Glycolytic / pentose-phosphate up-regulation – ALDOA, GPI, PGD, TKT, DCXR, PNPLA2 together with down-loading of multiple mitochondrial oxidative-phosphorylation components (ATP5PO, NDUFA11, NDUFB8, NDUFC2, MRPL12) indicate the characteristic metabolic switch from OXPHOS to glycolysis seen in inflammatory macrophages. • Additional myeloid surface or signaling genes (IGFLR1, NCCRP1, ARRB2, GNG5/10, RHOA) reinforce a leukocyte identity. Inconsistencies: • TUBB3 (neuronal tubulin), FXYD2 (renal epithelium) and ADORA2A (neuronal/lymphoid receptor) are atypical for macrophages but can be expressed at low levels in activated immune cells. • Limited representation of classic cytokines (e.g., IL1B, TNF) slightly weakens—but does not contradict—the inflammatory macrophage interpretation.

program_14.description: The program most closely matches a stressed, proliferative basal/parabasal keratinocyte state typical of stratified squamous epithelium undergoing wound repair or early squamous transformation. Evidence: • Core squamous/keratinocyte structural genes (positive loadings): KRT14, KRT6A/B/C, KRT16, KRT13, DSG3, DSC3, JUP, PKP1/3, ITGA6, ITGB4, CDH3, CLDN1/4, COL17A1 – hallmark molecules of basal and immediate-suprabasal epidermal cells. • Basal-cell transcriptional regulators: IRF6, OVOL1, ZNF750, EHF, HES1, BHLHE40 – maintain stratified epithelial identity and suppress terminal cornification. • Stress / wound-response and inflammatory genes: SFN, SERPINB4/B5/B13, CXCL1, MMP9, TNFRSF12A, CEMIP, TNC, HAS3, TRIM29 – induced in repairing or inflamed epidermis and in early squamous carcinoma. • Growth-factor and signalling molecules associated with activated keratinocytes: FGFR3, EPHA2, EPHB3, GPR87, NMU, LTB4R, TNS4. • Negative loadings suppress mesenchymal and mitochondrial programs (S100A4, RND1, ATP5F1E/ATP5MGL), reinforcing an epithelial, non-EMT profile. Inconsistencies: • HORMAD1 and PIWIL1 (germline/cancer-testis) are atypical for normal keratinocytes but can appear in squamous cancers. • BEST1 (retinal epithelium) and COCH (inner-ear protein) are negatively loaded yet unexpected in skin. • PAEP and SDC1 are more characteristic of secretory epithelia; however, both can be ectopically induced in repairing or neoplastic squamous cells.

program_15.description: The program is characteristic of activated classical (CCR2⁺) monocytes transitioning toward monocyte-derived macrophages / dendritic cells that have been exposed to inflammatory (TLR/IFN-γ) as well as immuno-regulatory cues. The gene pattern combines core myeloid identity markers with classical-monocyte-specific molecules (VCAN, S100A8/A12, CCR2), induction of inflammasome and interferon response genes (NLRP3, CXCL9, CXCL10, OASL, MX2), and expression of anti-inflammatory mediators (IL10, SERPINB2, VSIR), indicative of an acutely stimulated but partially regulatory inflammatory monocyte/macrophage state. Evidence: • Myeloid lineage: CD14, CSF1R, ITGAM (CD11b), ITGAX (CD11c), MPEG1, LILRB1/2/3, CLEC12A, FGR, PLEK, THEMIS2. • Classical/inflammatory monocyte markers: VCAN, CCR2, S100A8, S100A12, RNASE2/6, APOBEC3A, FCAR, TNFSF13B. • Inflammasome / acute activation: NLRP3, CASP1, CARD16, IL1R2, TLR2, CLEC4E, NAIP. • IFN/TLR-driven chemokines & ISGs: CXCL9, CXCL10, OASL, MX2, LRRC25, PDE4B. • Immuno-regulatory & tissue-remodeling factors: IL10, SERPINB2, FGL2, VSIR, STAB1, THBS1, MMP25. • Macrophage transcriptional regulators: MAFB, ZEB2, MXD1. Inconsistencies: • ASGR1/ASGR2 (classically hepatocyte receptors) and LAMP5, PACSIN1 (neuronal-associated) are atypical for monocytes but can appear at low levels; S100A4 and SIGLEC15 are more common in fibroblasts or M2-like macrophages, suggesting minor contaminating or mixed signatures rather than a distinct cell identity conflict.

program_16.description: The gene set defines an activated, venous-/fenestrated-type endothelial cell program undergoing angiogenic remodeling and inflammatory activation. Evidence: • Endothelial identity – classical structural/transport genes FLT1, ERG, CD34, PLVAP, HSPG2, HEG1, CD36, ITGA6, ADGRL4, CLDN5 absent but plenty others, collectively mark endothelial lineage. • Venous specification – NR2F2 (COUP-TFII), EPHB4, APLNR, MEOX1, SOX17/SOX18 support a venous or post-capillary phenotype. • Fenestration/angiogenic remodeling – PLVAP, THSD7A, ANGPT2, RGS5, RUNX1T1, PALMD, ADAMTS1/4/9, POSTN, LOXL2, CTHRC1 indicate vessel sprouting, basal-lamina turnover, and tip/stalk dynamics. • Inflammatory/activation state – adhesion molecules SELE, SELP, VCAM1; cytokine/chemokine genes IL6, IL33, IL1R1, IL4R, CCL2, CXCL2, CSF3; complement/immune modulators CD59, CFH and interferon-inducible IFITM1 show endothelial activation by cytokines. • Pro-thrombotic or hemostatic features – PLAT, CLEC3B, MMRN1, PRCP, TCN2 reflect endothelial control of coagulation and fibrinolysis. Inconsistencies: • Neural-associated NES, SNCG, LHX6 and lymphocyte-related GIMAP1/4/6 are atypical for endothelium, possibly reflecting background expression or rare doublets. • KRT222 (keratin) and HRH1 (histamine receptor) are less characteristic but can appear in activated microvascular endothelium.

program_17.description: The program most closely matches a mucus-secreting (goblet/secretory) airway epithelial cell state characterized by high secretory activity and ER-stress adaptation. Evidence: • Goblet cell mucins and associated products – MUC5AC, MUC5B, MUC16, FCGBP, TFF1, TFF3, CST1/4, BPIFB1/2, BPIFA1, FCGBP all hallmark products of airway goblet cells. • Goblet/secretory lineage transcription factors – SPDEF, FOXA3, XBP1, CREB3L1/CREB3L4 drive and maintain airway goblet differentiation and the unfolded-protein response required for heavy mucin secretion. • Secretory-cell glycosylation machinery – GALNT6, GALNT12, ST6GALNAC1, B3GNT3, B3GNT6 support O-glycosylation of mucins, a defining feature of airway goblet cells. • Ion and fluid transporters typical of airway surface epithelium – SCNN1B, SCNN1G, SLC26A4 (pendrin), SLC12A2, ATP6V1B1, SLC4A4 regulate airway surface liquid and pH during mucus secretion. • Additional airway/secretory markers – BPIFB1/2, AZGP1, VSIG2, TSPAN8, CEACAM6, CLDN22, ALCAM commonly appear in human secretory airway cell clusters. • Negative loadings for mesenchymal/smooth-muscle genes (ACTG2, SMOC2, PTGER3, GFPT2) reinforce an epithelial rather than stromal identity. Inconsistencies: • Prostate-associated genes (NKX3-1, MSMB, KLK11/12) and oxytocin (OXT) are atypical for airway epithelium; they may reflect low-level cross-tissue expression or technical bleed-through. • Neuronal secretory proteins (RIMS1, SCG2, SCG5) are not canonical airway markers but occasionally surface in highly secretory epithelial clusters.

program_18.description: The gene set represents a mucin-rich, secretory airway epithelial program characteristic of club / goblet–like cells that are actively producing mucus, antimicrobial peptides and xenobiotic-metabolising enzymes while suppressing immune-cell transcripts. Evidence: • Secretory/club cell markers – SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1, BPIFB1, BPIFB2, RAB25, XBP1 and the lineage TFs SOX2, FOXA3 and EHF typify airway secretory cells. • Mucin and goblet cell machinery – MUC5B, TFF3, CLCA2, ITLN1, ST6GALNAC1, B4GALNT2, GALNT6 support active mucin synthesis and glycosylation. • Detoxification / xenobiotic metabolism common to airway epithelium – GSTP1, GSTA1, AKR1C1, CYP2A13, CYP2J2, UGT2A1, SULT2B1, AADAC. • Ion and fluid transport genes needed for mucus hydration – SCNN1G, ATP12A, SLC4A4, SLC5A1, AQP5, CLDN4/10, CF-related SLC channels. • Secreted proteases and host-defence factors typical of bronchial glands – KLK10-14, SERPINB3/B7, CXCL1/6, SAA1, VTCN1. • Negative loadings for MS4A1, EBI3, CCL22 confirm that B-cell / dendritic-cell genes are specifically absent, reinforcing an epithelial rather than immune identity. Inconsistencies: • UPK1B and PAX1 (urothelial lineage), OXT, RIMS1 and NPTX1 (neuronal-associated) appear out of context but are sporadically detected in airway secretory cells and may reflect low-level or dataset-specific expression.

program_19.description: The gene set represents a mural-cell program characteristic of perivascular fibroblasts/pericytes that have begun to acquire a contractile/vascular‐smooth-muscle–like state, enriched for extracellular-matrix production, vasoactive signaling and calcium-handling machinery. Evidence: • Mural-cell identity – ANGPT1, RGS5, AOC3, ITGA8, PLPP3, SVEP1, CCN2 and VEGFD are canonical pericyte/adventitial fibroblast genes involved in vessel stabilization. • Contractile/VSMC shift – EDNRA, PDE5A, PRKG1, ANO1, S1PR3, CACNA1C, CACNA1D, CACNB2 and GEM encode endothelin, cGMP, chloride and L-type Ca²⁺ signaling components typical of vascular smooth-muscle cells. • Mesenchymal/ECM remodeling – High expression of FN1, COL13A1, COL6A6, CCBE1, FMOD, TNC, DPT, ASPN, HMCN1, ADAMTS1/7/8/12 and MMP23B indicates active matrix synthesis and remodeling seen in fibroblasts and myofibroblasts. • Developmental growth-factor milieu – TGFB3, BMP4/5, FGF2, FGF10, HGF, WNT2, DKK3 and NKD2 reflect mesenchymal signaling that supports vessel wall maturation. • Mural transcriptional regulators – MEOX2, TBX4, LBH and VGLL3 are known to govern vascular mesenchyme or smooth-muscle differentiation. Inconsistencies: • Several neuronal adhesion/axon-guidance genes (NCAM2, LSAMP, LRRN3, IGSF10, PCDHB5, GRIK4, ADGRL3) and mechanosensory channels (PIEZO2) are atypical for mural cells, suggesting either contamination from neuroectodermal cells or a shared neuro-mesenchymal gene module.

program_20.description: The gene set strongly points to stratified squamous epithelial cells that are part-way through terminal (suprabasal) differentiation and concurrently mounting a barrier-defence / type-I-IFN-IL-17 inflammatory response—i.e. an “activated, differentiating keratinocyte” program typical of skin, oral, oesophageal or upper-airway epithelia subjected to stress or infection. Evidence: • Squamous keratinocyte structural genes – KRT6A/6B/6C, KRT16, KRT13, KRT4, KRT14, KRT23/24/78, DSP, DSG3, PPL, EVPL, LAMB3, ITGA6 denote stratified squamous epithelium and the transition from basal (KRT14) to suprabasal (KRT13/4, KRT6/16) layers. • Cornified-envelope / late-differentiation genes – SPRR1A/B, SPRR2A/D/E, SPRR3, IVL, CNFN, TINCR, GRHL1/3, CERS3, SBSN, CRNN indicate keratinocyte terminal differentiation. • Epidermal serine proteases and inhibitors – KLK5/6/7/8/10/12/13, SPINK5/7, A2ML1, SERPINB3/B4/B1, TMPRSS11A/D/E/B support barrier-remodelling typical of suprabasal squamous cells. • Barrier-defence / antimicrobial response – DEFB4A/B, RNASE7, IL17C, S100A7/8/16/4, OAS1/3, LY6E, CMPK2, RAET1G/L reflect IL-17 / type-I IFN activation of keratinocytes under stress or infection. • Mucosal/upper-airway flavour – SDC1, MUC16, MUC21, CLCA4, RHCG, PRSS22, AQP5 are frequently expressed in upper-aerodigestive stratified mucosa. Inconsistencies: • UPK1B (urothelial), CALB1 (calbindin; often neuronal/renal), ESR2, FAM83D (mitotic) and ALOXE3 (late epidermis) are less specific, but a small minority and can be expressed at low levels in stressed squamous epithelium; thus they do not overturn the overall interpretation.

program_21.description: The program is characteristic of mature motile multiciliated epithelial cells (e.g., airway multiciliated cells), reflecting robust ciliogenesis/axoneme assembly and simultaneous loss of secretory-club cell identity. Evidence: • Motile axoneme machinery – very high loadings of dynein heavy/light chains and regulators (DNAH6/7/10/11/12, DYNLL1, DNAL4, DRC1/3, PACRG, LRRC23, MNS1, KIF9) and ciliary beating kinase STK33. • Intraflagellar transport and transition-zone components (IFT22/52/57, DYNC2H1/ I2, TMEM67, TMEM231, B9D1, CEP164, CEP290, TOGARAM1) required for building motile cilia. • Centriole/basal-body and planar polarity factors (CEP126, CEP128, CFAP210/221/251/299, CCDC74A/B, CFAP157/298) typical of multiciliogenesis. • Additional flagellar/ciliary proteins often shared with sperm but also enriched in multiciliated epithelia (SPA17, CATSPERD, EPPIN, SPAG16). • Negative loading of SCGB3A2, a hallmark secretoglobulin of airway club (secretory) cells, signifies repression of the club-cell program during commitment to the ciliated lineage. Inconsistencies: • Metabolic/detoxification genes (FABP6, GSTA1, GSTA2, PLA2G6, PROS1) and generic chaperones (HSP90AA1, AHSA1) are not specifically cilia-related but can reflect heightened protein synthesis/oxidative stress during ciliogenesis. • A few DNA-damage or chromatin regulators (POLI, PHC1, KMT5C) are broadly expressed and not uniquely linked to motile cilia.

program_22.description: The gene set depicts a stratified squamous mucosal epithelial program—typical of upper aerodigestive or esophageal epithelium—characterised by strong cell-junction/keratin markers, barrier-protease inhibitor genes, and a broad oxidative-/xenobiotic-stress response, while lacking immune (GIMAP, CXCL9) transcripts. Evidence: • Core squamous structural genes: KRT4, KRT6A/B/C, KRT13, KRT14, DSG3, DSC3, DSP, PKP3, SFN → hallmark of stratified squamous epithelium. • Cell-cell adhesion & junctional molecules: NECTIN1, NECTIN4, CLDN10, GJB3/5/6, FAT2, SDC1 → tight/desmosomal contacts typical for mucosal squamous layers. • Protease-/barrier defence factors enriched in squamous mucosa: SERPINB3, SERPINB4, SERPINB5/11/13, SPINT1, KLK11/13. • Detoxification / xenobiotic-metabolism enzymes prominent in upper aerodigestive epithelium: GSTP1, GPX2, AKR1C2/B10/A1, ADH7, CYP2E1, UGT2A1, EPHX3/4, SRD5A1, CRABP2. • Fluid/ion & secretory components associated with airway–esophageal surface cells: AQP5, CLCA2, CLCA4, SCNN1B, RAB25, PROM2, NMU. • Stress-response genes: HSPB1, PRDX1, TXN, RAET1G/L, NOS2, TRIM29, ASS1 → consistent with barrier epithelium under inflammatory/oxidative stress. • Negatively loaded immune transcripts (GIMAP1/2, CXCL9) underscore the non-immune, epithelial identity. Inconsistencies: • Uroplakin genes (UPK1B, UPK3BL1) are urothelial rather than squamous. • Muscle-related RYR1 and CLCN1, and mitotic gene CCNB1, are unexpected but may reflect minor contamination or cycling sub-populations. • FOXN1 is most noted in thymic/skin epithelium but is still epithelial.

program_23.description: The program reflects a mural cell population—vascular smooth muscle cells/pericytes—in a differentiated, contractile state characterized by active cytoskeletal machinery and vaso-regulatory signaling, together with extracellular-matrix remodeling typical of vessel wall maintenance. Evidence: • Contractile smooth-muscle cytoskeleton – CNN1, ACTG2, DES, SMTN, MYL6, FLNA/FLNC, MYOZ1, SPEG indicate mature contractile apparatus. • Vasoactive signaling / ion handling typical of VSMC – EDNRA (endothelin receptor A), CACNA1C (L-type Ca²⁺ channel), KCNMB1, KCNQ4, GUCY1A1 & PRKG1 (NO–cGMP pathway), PDE5A, PDE3A, ATP1A2, GJA4 (Connexin-37 gap junction). • Mural cell/pericyte identity – RGS5, MCAM (CD146), ITGA7, ANGPT1, ANGPT2, AOC3, PDGFRB-associated regulators (RCAN2, RGS6), FOXC2/TBX4 transcription factors known in mural cells. • Extracellular-matrix and vessel wall remodeling – ADAMTS1/8, ASPN, SMOC2, COL23A1, ITIH3/4/5, SDC2, FRZB, WFDC1, PGF, EDIL3 support a matrix-secreting, vessel-supportive phenotype. • Stress-response/chaperone genes common in contractile VSMC – HSPB7, HSPB2, DMPK, DES. Inconsistencies: • Neuronal/secretory peptides (GRP, CALCA), and LAMP5 are more typical of neuroendocrine cells. • Skeletal-muscle metabolic enzymes (PGAM2, PYGM, CKMT2) are not canonical for smooth muscle, though occasionally up-regulated in highly contractile vascular cells. • CLCNKB is a renal chloride channel and atypical for mural cells.

program_24.description: The gene set represents an acute “immediate-early / stress–activation” program that can be super-imposed on many cell types (immune and non-immune) when they experience strong inflammatory, mechanical or heat-shock–like stress during tissue dissociation or in vivo stimulation. It is characterized by rapid AP-1, NF-κB and heat-shock responses together with production of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Evidence: • AP-1 / immediate-early TFs: JUN, JUNB, JUND, FOS, FOSB, ATF3, EGR1/3, IER2/3/5, BTG2 – classical rapid-response genes induced within minutes of stress or receptor engagement. • NF-κB pathway & feedback inhibitors: NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, TNFAIP3, IRF1 – hallmark of acute inflammatory signalling. • Heat-shock / chaperone module: HSPA1A, HSPA1B, HSPA6, HSPA8, HSP90AA1, HSP90AB1, HSPH1, HSPD1, DNAJA/B family, BAG3, CHORDC1 – up-regulated to protect proteins during cellular stress. • Stress-induced growth-arrest & DNA-damage genes: PPP1R15A, GADD45B/G, DDIT3, RHOB – typical of transient stress responses. • Pro-inflammatory cytokines & chemokines: TNF, IL6, IFNG, CCL3/CCL3L3, TNFSF9, LIF – indicate an activated inflammatory state. • Activation markers frequently seen across immune lineages: CD83, NFATC1, PLCG2, GNAI2, SEMA7A, MAFB, KLF2/4/6/10 – consistent with recent stimulation of leukocytes. Inconsistencies: • A few tissue-restricted transcripts (VIL1 – enterocytes, BGLAP – osteoblasts, MAFA/HOXA1/HOXD1 – developmental) appear sporadically and are not usually part of generic stress programs, suggesting minor contamination or ambient RNA.

program_25.description: The program corresponds to highly secretory, serous-/mixed-acinar epithelial cells typical of human major salivary glands and airway submucosal glands, characterized by intense production of antimicrobial proteins, proline-rich salivary peptides and gel-forming mucins. Evidence: • Salivary/serous antimicrobial proteins – LTF, AZGP1, BPIFA1, BPIFB1/2, LPO, DMBT1, PIP, CRISP3, GP2, CCL28, ITLN1. • Classic salivary proline-rich peptides – PRB1-4, PRH2, PRR4, STATH, SMR3A, FDCSP, ODAM, ENAM: hallmark of acinar cells of parotid/submandibular glands. • Gel-forming or trefoil mucins and associated regulators – MUC5B, MUC7, TFF1/3, FCGBP, LRRC26, GCNT3, SPDEF; supported by secretory pathway genes XBP1, ELF5, SSR4, GOLM1. • Water/ion secretion machinery typical of acini – AQP5, SLC12A2, KCNN4, CLDN10/22, ANO1, SLC5A1/5A8/13A2. • Transcriptional regulators of secretory lineage – SPDEF, XBP1, ELF5, SOX10, BARX2. • Negative loadings are generic housekeeping genes (ACTG1, GAPDH, EIF1), consistent with specialization for secretory rather than biosynthetic/housekeeping functions. Inconsistencies: • Acute-phase/immune stress genes (SAA1, SAA2, SERPINB3, IL19, HP) suggest concurrent inflammatory signaling. • NKX3-1 (prostate lineage) and MIA (melanocyte marker) are unusual for salivary/airway glands but occasionally detected in acinar single-cell datasets. • Tooth enamel genes ENAM and ODAM are more odontogenic; their presence may reflect low-level expression or ambient RNA contamination.

program_26.description: The gene set is most consistent with a lymphatic endothelial-cell program, enriched for markers of lymphatic identity and vascular remodeling/angiogenesis. Evidence: • Core endothelial identity – ERG, THBD, PROCR, TGFBR2, ANGPT2, CD34, APOLD1 confirm an endothelial lineage. • Lymphatic specification – LYVE1, FLT4 (VEGFR-3), PDPN, SOX18, NR2F2, NRP2, GGT5, ACKR2, GPR182, MMRN1 are canonical lymphatic endothelial markers. • Angiogenic / tip-cell features – FSCN1, LAMA4, FLT4, NRP2, CD34, ANGPT2, PROCR denote an activated, sprouting state. • Vascular ECM remodeling – CTHRC1, THBS4, ASPN, MFAP2, MMP11, COL23A1 indicate matrix production consistent with vessel remodeling. Inconsistencies: • Fibroblast-associated genes (LRRC15, ASPN, THBS4, COL23A1, MMP11) suggest partial endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition or stromal contamination. • Neuron-related genes (SNCG, NRN1, NPTX2, SCN3B) and STAB2 (sinusoidal EC marker) are atypical for classical lymphatic endothelium, implying some heterogeneity within the program.

program_27.description: The gene constellation reflects a broad, acute “immediate-early” inflammatory program driven by NF-κB and AP-1 transcription factors, typical of many cell types (e.g., fibroblasts, epithelial cells, tissue-resident macrophages) minutes-to-hours after exposure to pro-inflammatory cues such as TNF-α, IL-1β or LPS. Evidence: • AP-1 / immediate-early genes: FOS, FOSB, FOSL1, JUNB, JUND, ATF3, EGR1/2/3, MYC, NR4A1, ZFP36, BTG2 – classic rapid-response transcription factors induced within minutes of stimulation. • NF-κB pathway components and targets: NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, RELB, NFKB2, IRF1, KDM6B, ICAM1 – hallmarks of canonical NF-κB activation. • Pro-inflammatory cytokines / chemokines: IL6, CXCL1, CXCL2, CXCL3, CCL2, CSF2, CSF3, LIF, IL20 – secreted mediators produced downstream of NF-κB/AP-1. • Stress and integrated stress-response genes: PPP1R15A (GADD34), GADD45A/B, DUSP1/5, SAT1, TRIB1 – induced by cellular stress and cytokine signaling. • Wound-healing / matrix-remodeling factors often co-induced in activated stromal cells: MMP13, ADAMTS4, CCN2, HBEGF, NRG1, LAMC2. • Anti-apoptotic & survival signals typical of early activation: MCL1, BIRC3, PMAIP1. • Negatively loaded housekeeping components (ELOB, SERF2) suggest transient shift away from routine protein synthesis toward emergency response. Inconsistencies: • KRTAP3-1 (hair keratin) and ICAM4 (erythroid) are tissue-restricted genes not usually linked to inflammatory activation, but their single appearance does not outweigh the dominant signature. • EEF1A2 is a muscle/neuronal elongation factor; its positive loading could reflect cell-type–specific background rather than the inflammatory program itself.

program_28.description: The transcript set most closely matches an acute-phase / detoxification program of hepatocytes (liver parenchymal cells) responding to systemic inflammatory cues. Evidence: • Secreted acute-phase and coagulation proteins characteristic of hepatocytes – FGA, FGG, HP, ORM1, ORM2, SERPINF2, SERPIND1, C5, APOH, PCSK9. • Xenobiotic- and lipid-metabolism enzymes typical of liver – FMO5, GSTA4, DHCR7, TM7SF2, ACOXL, MPST, TST, AADAC, MTARC1, GSTA4. • Lipoprotein transport/uptake machinery found in hepatocytes – LDLR, LRP2, SLC22A3, SLC46A2. • Complement/innate-defence and secretory epithelial genes often up-regulated in inflamed liver – CHI3L1, CHIA, DMBT1, LGMN, PLA2G3. • Regulatory/inflammatory transcription factors seen in stressed hepatocytes – CEBPD, NUPR1, RGS16. Inconsistencies: • Neuronal genes (NRGN, PPP1R1B, SCN1A, ICAM5, ATP8A2, IRX3) and muscle/platelet markers (PF4, PPBP) are not typical for hepatocytes and may reflect ambient RNA or doublets.

program_29.description: The gene set is most consistent with a metabolically active hepatocyte program characterized by enhanced lipid/cholesterol synthesis, lipoprotein handling and broad xenobiotic/secretory activity. Evidence: • Lipid / cholesterol biosynthesis and export – HMGCR, SQLE, DHCR7, ACSS2, GPAM, LDLR, PCSK9, APOH all typify hepatocyte‐driven sterol and lipoprotein metabolism. • Hepatic drug / bile transporters – SLC22A3, SLCO4C1, NPC1, RAB25 and ATP1B1 are well-described liver membrane transporters. • Hepatocyte detoxification & redox enzymes – FMO5, MAOA, PON3, MTARC1, ACSL4, DGKD support classic hepatic xenobiotic and fatty-acid processing roles. • Secreted liver proteins / complement – C5, APOH, PCSK2, BMP1, DBI reflect hepatocyte secretory output. • Tight-junction / polarity proteins typical of hepatocytes – MAL2, CGNL1, WWC3, FREM2, PCDH9 help establish the polarized epithelial architecture of liver plates. Inconsistencies: • Neuronal genes (SCN1A, MAPT, ATP8A2) and Schwann-related NCMAP. • Airway/renal epithelial markers SCNN1A and CHIA, and hematopoietic CSF3R. These few transcripts are not classically hepatic but can appear at low level in single-cell data and do not outweigh the strong, liver-specific metabolic signature.

program_30.description: The expression pattern is most consistent with tissue-resident, alternatively activated (“M2/foamy”) macrophages such as lung alveolar or tumor-associated macrophages that are simultaneously engaged in lipid handling, phagolysosomal turnover and interferon-mediated antimicrobial defense. Evidence: • Myeloid/macrophage identity – SIGLEC1 (CD169), SIRPB1, SPN (CD43), NCF4, JAML, VAMP8. • Phagolysosomal/antigen-processing machinery – LAMP2, TPP1, HEXA, GLB1, DNASE2B, BLOC1S2, ATP6AP1, PSMA7, TRPV2. • Lipid uptake, efflux and catabolism typical of “foamy” or alveolar macrophages – ABCG1, NR1H3 (LXRα), PNPLA3, MOGAT1, FFAR4, CES1, FABP3, ACOT4/7, GPX4, HSD3B7. • Alternative/M2 polarization and immunomodulation – CCL18, IL17RB, HP, FN1, VTN. • Interferon-stimulated and antimicrobial genes – IFI6, OASL, OAS2, CAMP, DEFB1, C8B, CXCL5, strengthening the innate-defence profile. Inconsistencies: • A handful of genes (e.g. TNNI2, MYL6, AGRP, NMB, OTOA, HOXB6/7, PRSS21, COCH) are not typically associated with macrophages, suggesting low-level contamination or ambient RNA rather than core program features.

program_31.description: The gene set reflects antigen-presenting cells that have recently undergone strong NF-κB/AP-1 driven maturation—most consistent with inflammatory/migratory dendritic cells (e.g., monocyte-derived or skin Langerhans DC) that have been stimulated by danger signals and are en route to lymph-node T-cell areas. Evidence: • Canonical NF-κB immediate-early and feedback genes (NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, TNFAIP3, REL, NFKB2, NFKBID) together with AP-1 factors (FOSB, JUNB, JUND, ATF3, MAFF) indicate acute NF-κB/AP-1 signalling typical of TLR-activated DCs. • Pro-inflammatory cytokines/chemokines produced by activated DCs (TNF, IL1A, IL23A, CXCL2, CXCL3, CCL3, CCL3L3, CCL4L2, CCL20, VEGFA) and inflammasome component NLRP3 support a mature, inflammatory state. • Migratory DC/activation markers CCR7, CD83, ICAM1, CD80 and TNFSF9 (4-1BB-L) fit a DC that has up-regulated costimulation and lymph-node-homing capacity. • Additional DC-associated genes CD1A and CLEC17A and the antigen-processing/stress-response chaperones HSPA1A/B, DNAJB1, HSPD1 are characteristic of professional antigen presenters undergoing maturation. Inconsistencies: • B-cell lineage transcripts (MS4A1/CD20, CD79A, PAX5, TSPAN33) and IFNG/XCL1 (typically T/NK-cell derived) are unusual for dendritic cells and may reflect transcript carry-over, a mixed APC cluster, or an NF-κB activation program that can also be induced in B cells and lymphocytes.

program_32.description: This gene program typifies mature, migratory antigen-presenting dendritic cells—predominantly conventional DC2 that have up-regulated MHC-II, lipid-antigen (CD1) machinery, co-stimulatory ligands and the lymph-node-homing receptor CCR7, consistent with a state poised to prime T cells (especially Th2/TFH responses). Evidence: • Antigen presentation machinery – CIITA, HLA-DQA2/DQB2/DOA/DOB, CD1A/B/C/D/E, CD207, CLEC4A, CLEC10A. • DC2 identity – CLEC10A (CD301), CD1C, FCER1A, CCR6, CCL17, CCL22, TLR10. • Maturation/co-stimulation – CD83, CD80, CD86, TNFSF4 (OX40L), SLAMF8, JAML. • Migratory/lymph-node homing – CCR7, GPR183 (EBI2), CCL17/22, LTB. • Immunomodulatory/Th2-skewing factors – IL4I1, AREG, TGFBI, EBI3. • Myeloid scaffold – CSF1R, FGL2, FCGR2B, CLEC5A, RNASE6, KYNU, reinforcing a myeloid dendritic lineage. Inconsistencies: • Presence of pDC-associated genes (LILRA4, SPIB, IRF7) and cDC1 markers (CLEC9A, CXCL9) suggests some admixture of other DC subsets. • Macrophage-leaning transcripts (F13A1, LILRB4) indicate partial overlap with monocyte-derived DCs.

program_33.description: The gene set is most consistent with a monocyte-derived, lipid-handling macrophage state (e.g. tissue or tumor-associated “foam”/scavenger macrophages that have up-regulated phagocytic, lysosomal and cholesterol-processing machinery while remaining MHC-II⁺ and immunomodulatory). Evidence: • Myeloid / macrophage identity – CLEC12A, SLAMF8, CD81, ADAM17, LAIR2, FPR2, SPN, CEBPA, PELI3, ADA2 all mark monocytes-macrophages. • Scavenger and efferocytosis receptors – COLEC12, LRP1, AXL, ABCG1, FFAR4, PLXDC2 support uptake of modified lipids/apoptotic cells typical of foam-type macrophages. • Lipid storage / metabolism genes – ACSL1, LIPA, PNPLA3, ABHD5, FABP3, SOAT1, ATP10A, GPX4, FLVCR2, RRAGD denote active cholesterol, triglyceride and phospholipid processing. • Lysosomal / phagolysosomal machinery – LAMP2, ATP6V0D2, DNASE2B, CHIT1, MMP19, ADAM17 reflect enhanced degradation capacity. • Antigen presentation / immune regulation – HLA-DQA2, BATF3, TNFSF12, IFNLR1 indicate maintained MHC-II expression and cytokine/IFN responsiveness typical of tissue macrophages interacting with T cells. Inconsistencies: • Neuronal/epithelial or tissue-restricted genes (LSAMP, OTOA, SATB2, ALPK3, ZMYND15, COL8A2) are not typical for macrophages and may reflect ambient RNA or multiplet contamination. • BATF3 is classically linked to cross-presenting dendritic cells, though low expression can occur in some macrophage subsets. • TCF7L2 and CTNNB1 are Wnt-pathway factors more common in progenitors/epithelia but have been reported in macrophages subjected to Wnt signals.

program_34.description: The gene set is most consistent with an inflammatory, cytokine-producing endothelial cell program typical of vascular endothelial cells acutely stimulated by TNF-α/IL-1β or other pro-inflammatory cues (often termed “activated endothelium” or “endothelial TNF response”). Evidence: • Endothelial identity FLT1 (VEGFR1), SOX17, SOX7, GPIHBP1, LIPG, APOLD1, EDN1, ICAM1/ICAM4, VCAM1, CYP1B1, CD59, LOXL2 all mark vascular endothelial cells. • Adhesion & leukocyte recruitment ICAM1, VCAM1, CX3CL1, CCL2, CXCL2, SERPINE1, TGM2 facilitate leukocyte binding or matrix remodeling during vascular inflammation. • Cytokine/chemokine secretion IL6, CSF1, CSF3, CCL2, CX3CL1, CXCL2, IL15RA indicate a strong secretory inflammatory response. • Canonical TNF/IL-1 signalling regulators IRF1, CEBPD, ZFP36, KLF4, RCAN1, TRIB1, SOCS2, GADD45B, FOSL1, SPRY4 are well-described downstream targets of acute TNF/IL-1 or NF-κB signalling in endothelium. • Immune checkpoint & stress genes CD274 (PD-L1), TNFRSF10D, HSPB8, MT1A/MT1X highlight activation-induced immune modulation and oxidative-stress protection typical of stimulated endothelium. Inconsistencies: • ICAM5 (neuronal adhesion), MEGF11 (neuronal/retinal), and MT1F (negatively loaded while other metallothioneins are positive) are not characteristic of endothelial activation; their presence may reflect low-level background expression or technical noise.

program_35.description: The gene set best fits an anti-inflammatory / “M2-like” tissue-resident macrophage program, typical of FOLR2⁺, CSF1R⁺ mononuclear phagocytes that combine phagocytic, antigen-presenting and immunoregulatory functions within peripheral tissues. Evidence: • Core macrophage lineage — CSF1R, CD14, ITGAM (CD11b), FCGR2B, CCR2, MAFB, RNASE6/2, MERTK, STAB1 establish a mononuclear phagocyte identity. • Alternative (M2/tolerogenic) activation — IL10, FOLR2, TGFBI, F13A1, MERTK, SIGLEC10, LILRB2/4/5, THBS1, FGL2, TNFSF13B are canonical markers of anti-inflammatory or tissue-repair macrophages. • Tissue remodeling & chemokine secretion — CCL18, CCL13, CCL24, CCL8, CXCL3 together with PLTP, PLB1 indicate roles in matrix remodeling and recruitment of other immune cells. • Phagocytosis / clearance machinery — CLEC5A, CLEC10A (MGL), CD209 (DC-SIGN), CLEC4A, LGMN, MERTK, ADORA3 support efficient apoptotic cell uptake and glycan recognition. • Antigen presentation / tolerogenic DC features — CD1D, TNFRSF11A, TNFSF13, STAB1, ASGR1 signify capacity to present lipid antigens and modulate B-cell responses, typical of regulatory tissue macrophages. Inconsistencies: • CXCL9 and NLRP3 are classically IFN-γ/inflammasome-induced “M1” genes; their presence suggests some mixed inflammatory signaling. • NAIP and GSDMA are linked to pyroptosis; these pro-inflammatory components are atypical but may reflect basal surveillance activity within otherwise regulatory macrophages.

program_36.description: The gene set represents a hepatocyte-like metabolic program characterized by robust activation of the mevalonate/sterol and general lipid-biosynthetic pathways, accompanied by expression of several liver-derived secreted (acute-phase) proteins and lipoprotein-handling genes, consistent with a metabolically active, cholesterol-producing hepatocyte state. Evidence: • Coordinated mevalonate/sterol pathway enzymes – HMGCR, SQLE, MVD, FDPS, IDI1, FDFT1, LSS, CYP51A1, TM7SF2, DHCR7, EBP, SC5D – hallmark of cholesterol biosynthesis seen in hepatocytes. • Lipid handling/packaging genes – ACAT2, ACSS2, FADS2, AGPAT2, HACD1, ACOXL, PXMP4, TMEM41B, INSIG1 – support active fatty-acid and triglyceride synthesis typical of liver parenchyma. • Lipoprotein receptor/regulators – LDLR and PCSK9 – classical liver-specific control of plasma LDL levels. • Acute-phase/secreted liver proteins – ORM1, ORM2, SERPINF2, CHI3L1 – further point to hepatocyte identity. • Additional hepatocyte-enriched transporters/receptors – SLC22A3, SLCO4C1, ITPR3 – frequently expressed in liver for xenobiotic and bile acid transport. Inconsistencies: • CSF3R (myeloid), NRGN & IRX3 (neuronal lineage), CAPN3 (muscle) are atypical for hepatocytes, suggesting either minor contamination, broad expression noise, or multifunctionality of the program across cell types.

program_37.description: The gene set describes mature, alternatively-activated / tumor-associated macrophages (SPP1+ “M2-like” TAMs) that are engaged in phagocytosis, efferocytosis and immunomodulatory chemokine secretion. Evidence: • Core macrophage identity – CSF1R, MAFB, MERTK, FGR, LILRB4, MPEG1, SLAMF8, LRRC25, MFSD1, RAB31, ADA2 • Alternative-activation / TAM signature – SPP1, CCL18, CCL13, CCL7, CCL24, SIGLEC15, SLC37A2, HMOX1, HAMP, PLA2G7, ADA2 (CECR1), NR1H3 (LXRA) • Efferocytosis / lipid handling – MERTK, LIPA, PLA2G7, SLC37A2, NR1H3 • Matrix-remodelling & pro-tumour signalling – MMP9, SPP1, CCL chemokines, SIGLEC15 • Phagolysosomal/acidification genes – LGMN, ATP6V0D1, TPP1, TRAPPC5, EIF4EBP1 support active phagosome–lysosome function Inconsistencies: • Platelet / megakaryocyte transcript PPBP • Non-myeloid or tissue-restricted genes (KCNMA1, OTOA, GSDMA, SPINK1, LAMP5, SLC1A3) – likely ambient RNA or rare doublets and do not alter the overall macrophage/TAM interpretation.

program_38.description: The program most closely matches a lipid-handling / immuno-metabolic activation state of tissue-resident macrophages (e.g., alveolar or liver Kupffer–like cells) in which the cells up-regulate fatty-acid and cholesterol transporters, retinoid metabolism enzymes, and sheddases while retaining core myeloid components; the profile suggests simultaneous sensing of unsaturated fatty acids and a low-grade inflammatory tone. Evidence: • Lipid sensing & export – FFAR4 (GPR120, ω-3 fatty-acid receptor), ABCG1, OSBPL11, PNPLA3, RBP4, ATP10A, PNPLA3, CES1 all typical of macrophages coping with lipid-rich environments. • Retinoid / xenobiotic & sterol metabolism – ALDH2, CES1, MGAT3, SLC47A1, SLC28A1, TRHDE, SLC19A3; enzymes and transporters enriched in macrophages of liver and lung that process lipophilic compounds. • Core myeloid identity – NCF4 (phagocyte NADPH oxidase subunit), SPN (CD43), CD81, CD101, COLEC12, SLC15A3, PLAAT3, DOCK11 indicate monocyte/macrophage lineage. • Controlled inflammatory signalling – ADAM17 (TACE), IL1A, PHLDA3, TCF7L2 suggest an activated but not overtly pro-inflammatory state, consistent with metabolically activated (“MMe”) macrophages. Inconsistencies: • Several neuron-enriched genes (STAC, GPRIN3, IQSEC3, GSG1L, FRMPD1) and developmental HOXA1 are atypical for macrophages and may reflect low-level ambient RNA or doublets. • Absence of canonical macrophage markers such as LYZ, CD68, PPARG, or CLEC4F leaves the exact macrophage subtype (alveolar vs. Kupffer) unresolved.

program_39.description: The program represents an interferon-driven antiviral/inflammatory state of vascular endothelial cells, characterized by strong type I/II interferon-stimulated gene (ISG) expression together with several endothelial-enriched adhesion/ECM genes. Evidence: • Canonical ISGs – IFIT1/2/3, IFI44L, ISG15, OAS1/2/3, MX1/2, IFI6, IFI35, RSAD2, GBP1/4, SAMD9L, CMPK2 – define a robust type I interferon response. • IFN-γ–inducible chemokines CXCL9, CXCL10, CXCL11 and immune-regulatory genes CD274 (PD-L1), IDO1, TAP1, PSMB9, IRF1 indicate concurrent type II IFN signalling and antigen-presentation up-regulation. • Endothelial-associated transcripts ADGRL4 (ELTD1), CX3CL1 (fractalkine), AKAP12, EMP1 and matrix component HAPLN3 point to vascular endothelial cell identity rather than leukocytes. • Pro-inflammatory cytokines IL6, CCL8 and the NF-κB modulator TNIP3 are typical outputs of activated endothelium exposed to cytokines/viral products, fitting an inflamed endothelial state. Inconsistencies: • IL6 and CCL8 are also abundantly produced by macrophages/fibroblasts, so their presence could indicate some admixture of other stromal or myeloid cells. • BATF2 is more commonly linked to myeloid activation; its inclusion slightly blurs the strict endothelial assignment but can be induced by IFN in multiple cell types.

program_40.description: The gene set is most consistent with an alternatively-activated / tissue-resident macrophage (M2-like) program characterised by high lipid-handling capacity and modulatory rather than pro-inflammatory signalling. Evidence: • Myeloid identity: CD33, CLEC12A, SIRPB1, FPR2, SPN (CD43), ADGRE3 (EMR3), JAML, NCF4 collectively mark monocytes/macrophages and neutrophils. • Antigen presentation & immune regulation: HLA-DOA, ADA2 (CECR1), THEMIS2, PTPRO, SIGLEC12, IFI6 support professional antigen-presenting, interferon-responsive macrophages. • Lipid uptake / efflux & metabolic rewiring typical of M2 macrophages: ABCG1, FFAR4 (GPR120), FABP3, MOGAT1, FLVCR2, GM2A, PLA2G15, APOL4, MGAT3. • Tissue-repair / anti-inflammatory cues: ADA2 (promotes M2 polarization), ADAM17 (sheddase regulating TNF-α signalling), FFAR4 (ω-3 fatty-acid sensor dampening inflammation) align with a resolving macrophage state. • Co-regulation of myeloid signaling adaptors: SLC15A3, STAC, RNF149, ARL11, MTMR11 further fits a macrophage activation module. Inconsistencies: • TNNI2 (skeletal muscle troponin), ZMYND15 and ZDHHC19 (testis-enriched), STAC (neuronal adaptor) and TCF7L2 (Wnt/β-cell factor) are not typical for macrophages and may reflect ambient RNA or low-level promiscuous expression.

program_41.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated myeloid-cell program characteristic of inflammatory monocytes / monocyte-derived macrophages or dendritic cells that are equipped for antigen presentation and cytokine/ROS production. Evidence: • Core myeloid identity: CSF1R, CD33, CLEC12A, SIGLEC9/12, LILRB3/4, SIRPB1, SLAMF8, CD300C, BST1 – canonical receptors of blood monocytes and tissue macrophages. • Antigen-presentation/co-stimulation: HLA-DQB2 (MHC-II), CD86, TNFSF13B (BAFF), LILRB4 – hallmarks of professional antigen-presenting myeloid cells. • Inflammatory/ROS machinery: NCF4, FGR, FPR2, PTAFR, PRAM1, ARRB2 – components of NADPH oxidase signaling and formyl-peptide or PAF receptor pathways used by inflammatory monocytes. • Phagolysosomal/secretory support: ATP6V1B2, ATP6V0D1 (v-ATPase subunits), TPP1, RNASE6, QPCT, ADA2 – genes needed for lysosome acidification and antimicrobial peptide processing typical of activated macrophages. • Myeloid activation regulators: THEMIS2, FGD2, MARCHF1, RNF149, METTL22 – modulators of TLR or cytokine signaling enriched in stimulated monocytes/macrophages. • CSF1R together with SLAMF8 and CLEC12A specifically mark monocyte-derived macrophages rather than neutrophils, supporting a monocyte/macrophage state rather than granulocytes. Inconsistencies: • ZGLP1 (germ-cell transcription factor) and BEST1 (chloride channel better known in retinal pigment cells) are atypical for myeloid cells; their presence may reflect low-level background or technical noise. • S100A4 and TGFBI are more commonly linked to fibroblasts but can be up-regulated in activated macrophages, so only partially discordant.

program_42.description: The gene set represents an activated, chemokine-secreting SPP1⁺ inflammatory macrophage / monocyte–derived tumor-associated-macrophage (TAM) state characterized by strong recruitment (CCL2/7/8/13, CXCL3), immune-modulatory (IL1RN, LILRB4) and matrix-remodeling (SPP1, MMP19, TGFBI, ITGB3) functions that are typical of CCR2⁺, tissue-remodeling macrophages described across inflamed and tumor tissues. Evidence: • Myeloid lineage/activation: ANPEP (CD13), CCR1, LILRB4, CLEC5A, CD63, SLC15A3, KCNN4 – canonical monocyte/macrophage surface or activation genes. • Chemokine burst: CCL2, CCL7, CCL8, CCL13, CXCL3 – hallmark of inflammatory (CCR2⁺) monocytes/macrophages promoting leukocyte recruitment. • SPP1-centered remodeling signature: SPP1 (osteopontin), TGFBI, MMP19, ITGB3, PLXDC2 – characteristic of profibrotic SPP1⁺ TAMs and wound-healing macrophages. • Immunoregulation/stress: IL1RN (IL-1 receptor antagonist), MT1H (metal stress), ATP6V1B2 (phagolysosomal acidification) – consistent with activated macrophage physiology. Inconsistencies: • PPBP (platelet/megakaryocyte product), SCG5 (neuroendocrine granin) and OPN3 (opsin 3) are atypical for macrophages and may reflect ambient RNA or minor contamination rather than the core program.

program_43.description: The gene set most consistently reflects an ATF4-driven integrated stress response (ISR) that cells of many lineages turn on when they face ER stress, amino-acid deprivation or replication stress. Central ISR transcription factors (ATF4) and their direct targets that dampen global translation (EIF4EBP1), modulate Akt signalling (TRIB3) and augment general stress-adaptation (TPT1, BEX2, CHP1) are all strongly represented, while DNA-damage/replication-stress factors (DONSON, ANKLE1) and acute-phase/metabolic regulators (ADM2, ACVR2B, ORM1) fit with a broader protective programme engaged under adverse conditions. Evidence: • Canonical ISR hub and targets – ATF4 (master ISR TF), TRIB3 and EIF4EBP1 are classic ATF4-induced genes. • Translational and general stress adaptors – TPT1, BEX2, CHP1 are well-described ATF4/ISR-responsive effectors that limit protein synthesis or promote survival. • Replication/repair stress components – DONSON (fork protection) and ANKLE1 (DNA-repair nuclease) are induced when replication is challenged, a known trigger of the ISR. • Secreted/acute-phase or metabolic modifiers that rise during stress – ADM2, ACVR2B, ORM1 and PHKG1 are reported ATF4/CEBP-co-regulated genes that adjust vascular tone, TGF-β signalling, acute-phase response and glycogen metabolism respectively. • Transcriptional co-factors – CEBPA cooperates with ATF4 in stress-responsive metabolic re-programming. Inconsistencies: • Neuron-specific markers (RORB, PCP2) and the muscle-biased glycogen kinase subunit PHKG1 do not commonly belong to classical ISR signatures and may indicate tissue-specific expression noise or mixed cell contributions.

program_44.description: The gene set is most consistent with a FOXI1-driven “ionocyte” program found in specialized epithelial cells (e.g. airway ionocytes or kidney collecting-duct intercalated cells) that mediate Cl⁻/H⁺/HCO₃⁻ transport. Evidence: • Core transcription factors and regulators of ionocytes/intercalated cells – FOXI1 (master regulator), ASCL3 (airway ionocyte TF). • High-conductance chloride transport machinery – CFTR, CLCNKB, BSND (barttin), all classic FOXI1 targets that form Cl⁻ channels in ion-transporting epithelia. • Proton-pumping/acid-base genes – ATP6V1G3 (V-ATPase subunit) characteristic of kidney intercalated cells and airway ionocytes. • Additional epithelial/ionocyte-associated genes – HEPACAM2 (cell-adhesion protein enriched in ionocytes), TMEM61. Inconsistencies: • STAP1 and CLNK are adaptor proteins better known in immune cells. • CEL (carboxyl-ester lipase) is typically pancreatic/exocrine. • Some listed genes (e.g., STAP1, CEL) have limited or poorly described expression in ionocytes, suggesting either low-level background expression or dataset-specific co-loading.

program_45.description: The program most closely represents an “immediate‐early / stress-response” state of epithelial (particularly keratinocyte-like) cells that have just received strong growth factor or cytokine stimulation (e.g., EGFR activation, inflammatory cues). It captures the transient wave of transcription factors and stress-effectors that precede a decision between proliferation and apoptosis. Evidence: • Immediate-early transcription factors – ATF3, EGR3, MYC, BTG2: canonical rapid-response genes induced within minutes of EGFR or cytokine stimulation in epithelial cells. • EGFR pathway feedback – ERRFI1 (MIG6) is a classic negative feedback inhibitor induced after EGFR activation, reinforcing an EGFR-triggered state. • Stress / damage effectors – PMAIP1 (NOXA) and VMP1 are p53- and ER-stress-inducible genes linked to apoptosis and autophagy, hallmarks of a cell deciding between repair and death. • Epithelial/keratinocyte context – DST encodes the hemidesmosomal cytolinker dystonin, enriched in stratified epithelia, while IL20 is a cytokine prominently produced by stressed keratinocytes to signal to immune cells. Inconsistencies: No strongly contradictory genes are present; all listed genes fit a generalized epithelial immediate-early stress-response program rather than a lineage-specific differentiation signature.

program_46.description: The gene set reflects a generic “high-translation” program, characteristic of cells that are actively engaging their ribosome and translation machinery (e.g., highly proliferative or metabolically activated cells), rather than pointing to a specific differentiated lineage. Evidence: • Core elongation factors (EEF1A1, EEF1B2, EEF1D, EEF2) – hallmark of elevated translational throughput. • Translation initiation/assembly components (EIF3F, EIF3L, RACK1) and nascent chain chaperone NACA – further mark active ribosome loading and co-translational folding. • Nucleolar protein NOP53 – participates in ribosome biogenesis, reinforcing a boost in protein synthesis capacity. Inconsistencies: • No genes in the set contradict a high-translation/biosynthetic state; absence of lineage-specific markers simply limits assignment to a particular cell type.

program_47.description: The gene set reflects a male germ-cell program characteristic of late pachytene spermatocytes to round spermatids, marked by testis-specific chromatin remodeling, RNA-binding, and mitochondrial assembly factors that support meiosis and the onset of spermiogenesis. Evidence: • H3-5 (H3T) – testis-restricted histone H3 variant deposited during meiotic prophase and essential for spermatocyte chromatin re-organization. • PABPC3 and HNRNPA1L2 – poly(A)-binding and hnRNP proteins expressed almost exclusively in spermatogenic cells, regulating the large wave of post-meiotic mRNA storage/translation. • UQCRHL – testis-specific homolog of the complex III subunit UQCRH, incorporated into developing sperm mitochondria. • NACA2 – germ-cell-enriched nascent-polypeptide–associated complex subunit that supports high translational load in spermatids. • TIPIN – replication-fork protection factor up-regulated during the pre-meiotic S phase and meiotic recombination checkpoints. • Concerted presence of multiple testis-enriched factors and absence of canonical somatic or immune markers argues for a spermatogenic, not generic proliferation, program. Inconsistencies: • ZNF90 and NHSL2 are more broadly expressed and provide limited cell-type specificity, but they do not contradict a germ-cell interpretation.

program_48.description: The gene set strongly represents the deuterosomal/multiciliogenesis program seen in epithelial progenitors that are transitioning into mature motile multiciliated cells (e.g., airway, ependymal or oviduct epithelium) and undergoing massive centriole amplification required for cilia formation. Evidence: • Centriole-amplification machinery – DEUP1 and CDC20B are core deuterosome components uniquely induced during the centriole burst that precedes motile cilia assembly. • Multiciliogenesis-specific cyclin – CCNO is essential for licensing multiple rounds of centriole replication in multiciliated cells; loss of CCNO causes reduced motile cilia in human disease. • Transcriptional drivers of ciliated-cell fate – FOXN4 and HES6 are transcription factors enriched in differentiating motile ciliated cells; HES6 relieves Notch inhibition to permit ciliogenesis. • Cell-cycle and E2F activity characteristic of the deuterosomal stage – E2F7 and the replication-linked histone H2BC11 mark the transient S-phase–like state used to amplify centrioles without true cell division. • Additional cilia-associated gene – SHISA8 has been reported in single-cell studies within the deuterosomal/ciliated lineage, supporting the same program. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; H2BC11 is a generic S-phase histone and SHISA8 is less well characterized, but neither conflicts with a multiciliogenesis interpretation.

program_49.description: The gene set represents a ubiquitous acute-stress / heat-shock transcriptional program rather than a lineage-restricted cell identity. High expression of HSP70-family chaperones together with immediate-early response transcription factors and a stress-induced phosphatase regulator indicates cells that have recently experienced proteotoxic, metabolic or dissociation-related stress. Evidence: • Heat-shock chaperones – HSPA1A, HSPA1B and the HSP40 co-chaperone DNAJB1 are classical HSF1 targets up-regulated within minutes of proteotoxic stress. • Integrated stress response – PPP1R15A (GADD34) is induced by eIF2α phosphorylation during ER or oxidative stress to promote translational recovery. • Immediate-early genes – FOSB and the orphan nuclear receptors NR4A1 / NR4A2 are rapidly induced by MAPK signaling downstream of diverse stressors, marking an activated “IEG” state independent of cell type. • Metabolic adaptation – SLC2A3 (GLUT3) is up-regulated to increase glucose import under hypoxia or energetic stress, complementing the global stress signature. Inconsistencies: No major contradictions; the listed genes are all canonical components of generalized stress / immediate-early response programs, with no strong markers for a specific differentiated cell lineage.

program_50.description: The gene set represents a FOXI1-driven “ionocyte” program—i.e., rare epithelial cells specialized for acid–base and chloride transport that are found in airways, kidney collecting duct (intercalated cells), inner ear, and other mucosal epithelia. Evidence: • Master regulators: FOXI1 and ASCL3 are the canonical transcription factors that specify vertebrate ionocytes in airway and kidney epithelia. • Chloride transport machinery: CLCNKA, CLCNKB and their obligatory β-subunit BSND (Barttin) form the ClC-K channels characteristic of FOXI1+ intercalated cells and airway ionocytes. • Proton pump component: ATP6V1G3 is a V-ATPase subunit enriched in acid-secreting intercalated/ionocyte cells, supporting transepithelial ion exchange. • Metabolic/oxidoreductase support: AKR1B1 is frequently co-expressed in ion-transporting epithelia and appears in published ionocyte signatures, consistent with this specialized metabolic state. Inconsistencies: • No strongly conflicting genes are present; AKR1B1 is broadly expressed but not incompatible with an ionocyte identity.

program_51.description: The gene set most consistently matches a male germ-line program seen in pachytene spermatocytes / early round spermatids, cells characterized by testis-specific histone variants, abundant mRNA-binding/translation factors and rising mitochondrial activity. Evidence: • H3-5 (H3T) – testis-specific histone H3 variant expressed from pachytene spermatocytes through round/elongating spermatids, marking germ cells undergoing specialised chromatin re-organisation. • PABPC3 – cytoplasmic poly(A)-binding protein isoform highly enriched in meiotic and post-meiotic germ cells, supporting the heavy translational load after transcriptional shut-down. • NBEAL1, ZNF90, NACA2, NHSL2 – all show testis-biased expression in transcriptomic atlases and have been reported among spermatocyte/spermatid transcripts, consistent with a germ-cell signature. • ATP5MGL – mitochondrial ATP-synthase subunit; mitochondria proliferate and respire actively in late spermatogenesis, fitting the energetic demands of these cells. Inconsistencies: • The list is small and lacks classical germ-cell markers such as DDX4, DAZL or SYCP genes; thus, while compatible with male germ cells, the program on its own is not uniquely definitive.

program_52.description: The program reflects a quiescent/naïve T-lymphocyte transcriptional state. Evidence: • GIMAP1, GIMAP4, GIMAP6 – GIMAP family GTPases are selectively enriched in resting and naïve T cells and are required for T-cell survival. • KLF2 – transcription factor that maintains a naïve/central-memory phenotype and is rapidly down-regulated after T-cell activation. • TXNIP – metabolic brake induced in quiescent lymphocytes; its expression falls upon T-cell activation. • Collective absence of activation markers (e.g., IFNG, GZMB, IL2RA) and cytotoxic genes supports a resting, non-effector state. Inconsistencies: • TPST2 and GFOD1 are broadly expressed housekeeping/metabolic genes and are not specifically linked to T-cell identity, but their presence does not contradict a naïve T-cell program.

program_53.description: The program is most consistent with CCR6⁺ CXCR6⁺ tissue-resident memory (Trm) CD4 T cells that have a Th17-like phenotype, a subset enriched at mucosal and inflamed peripheral sites. Evidence: • Tissue residency/retention signatures – CXCR6 and RGS1 are hallmark genes of Trm cells; STK4 (MST1) is required for long-lived, tissue-localized T-cell survival and motility control. • Memory/activation signalling – SIT1 and P2RY10 are up-regulated in antigen-experienced T cells and modulate TCR-induced signalling and purinergic responses, respectively, features typical of resident memory rather than naïve cells. • Th17 orientation – CCR6 is a canonical chemokine receptor of Th17-polarised CD4 T cells and guides their positioning at epithelial barriers; its co-expression with CXCR6 has been reported in mucosal CD4 Trm populations that produce IL-17 upon recall. Inconsistencies: • The gene list is small and lacks definitive Th17 transcription factors (e.g., RORC) or effector cytokines (IL17A/F), so functional orientation is inferred mainly from CCR6 expression.

program_54.description: The program represents a conventional CD1c⁺ dendritic cell (cDC2) state specialized for lipid-antigen presentation and modulatory signaling. Evidence: • CD1C and CD1E – hallmark lipid-antigen–presenting molecules that define human CD1c⁺ cDC2s. • FCGR2B (CD32B) – inhibitory Fcγ receptor frequently expressed by cDC2s, reflecting their immunoregulatory capacity. • PLD4 – endolysosomal phospholipase enriched in dendritic cells and other myeloid subsets, compatible with antigen-processing functions. • P2RY6 – purinergic receptor induced in activated monocytes/dendritic cells, supporting a myeloid immune-responsive profile. • TVP23A – Golgi/vesicle trafficking protein; broadly expressed but consistent with the high secretory/trafficking activity of dendritic cells. Inconsistencies: • PLD4 is also characteristic of plasmacytoid DCs and microglia, so its presence could indicate some overlap with other myeloid populations. • TVP23A is not specific to dendritic cells, offering limited discriminatory power.

program_55.description: The program most closely reflects a generic “metabolic-activation / high biosynthetic activity” state that can accompany cycling or recently stimulated cells across many lineages rather than a lineage-defining cell identity. Evidence: • Ribosome / translation up-shift – DDX47 (nucleolar RNA helicase needed for rRNA processing) and EIF5AL1 (eIF5A‐like translation factor) are classical markers of heightened ribosome biogenesis and protein synthesis. • Mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation – NDUFA13 encodes a core complex-I subunit, indicating boosted respiratory chain activity that typically parallels increased biosynthetic demand. • Immediate-early / stress-responsive kinase – SIK1 is rapidly induced by serum, cAMP and salt stress and is often up-regulated as quiescent cells re-enter the cell cycle, fitting a recently activated metabolic state. • General trafficking factor – RNASEK-C17orf49 supports clathrin-mediated endocytosis, another feature of highly active cells. • Lack of lineage-restricted positive or negative markers reinforces the interpretation that the program describes a broad metabolic state rather than a specific differentiated cell type. Inconsistencies: • None of the highlighted genes conflict with a metabolically active/cycling phenotype; the list is simply small and lacks canonical proliferation markers (e.g., MKI67), so the state is inferred as “metabolic activation” rather than strict “cell cycle.”.

program_56.description: The program is characteristic of basal keratinocytes from stratified squamous epithelium that have entered a hyper-proliferative / wound-repair state, marked by induction of stress keratins and reinforced cell-cell adhesion machinery. Evidence: • Basal keratinocyte identity – KRT14 is the canonical intermediate filament of epidermal basal cells; KRT6A is co-induced with KRT14 during epidermal activation and hyperplasia. • Strengthened desmosomal adhesion typical of squamous epithelium – DSG3, DSC3 and DSP encode core desmosome components that are highly expressed in basal and early suprabasal layers to maintain tissue integrity. • Wound-repair / growth-factor responsiveness – FGFBP1 is up-regulated in activated keratinocytes where it mobilises FGFs to promote re-epithelialisation. Inconsistencies: No genes in the program contradict the basal, activated keratinocyte interpretation.

program_57.description: The gene set is most consistent with a cytokine-responsive, antigen-presenting myeloid population (classical/ inflammatory monocytes or monocyte-derived dendritic cells) that is primed for both interferon and IL-10 signalling and for integrin-mediated tissue recruitment.
