Evidence: • IL10RA – canonical anti-inflammatory receptor highly expressed on monocytes/macrophages and dendritic cells. • GBP5 – interferon-γ–inducible GTPase enriched in activated monocytes/macrophages and participates in inflammasome activation. • ITGA4 (CD49d) – integrin used by circulating monocytes for VCAM-1-dependent endothelial adhesion and tissue entry, less prominent in neutrophils. • FYB1 (ADAP) – adaptor that couples integrin and Fc-receptor signalling in myeloid cells and is abundant in monocytes and dendritic cells. • JAK3 – kinase functioning downstream of common-γ-chain cytokine receptors; although classically lymphoid, it is expressed in human monocytes and dendritic cells and required for IL-10 and IL-2 family responses in these cells. • RCSD1 – cytoskeletal regulator reported in hematopoietic cells, including monocytes, supporting adhesion/migration programs. Inconsistencies: • FYB1 and JAK3 are more strongly associated with T/NK lineages than with myeloid cells, so their co-enrichment could reflect contaminating activated T cells or a mixed immune activation program rather than a purely myeloid signature.

program_58.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated intestinal/colonic epithelial program in which mature epithelial cells up-regulate secreted proteases and the neutrophil-recruiting chemokine CXCL1, a pattern typical of mucosal inflammation or early epithelial tumorigenesis. Evidence: • EHF – ETS transcription factor required for differentiation and barrier maintenance of intestinal/colonic epithelium; broadly used as a marker of mature epithelial cells. • CHP2 – Regulates the NHE family exchangers on the brush border; highly expressed in small- and large-intestinal epithelial cells. • KLK11 – Secreted kallikrein serine protease produced by colonic and other glandular epithelia and up-regulated in colorectal inflammation/cancer. • CXCL1 – Neutrophil-attracting chemokine released by epithelial cells upon IL-1/TNF stimulation, marking an inflammatory epithelial state. • ADAM28 – Membrane/secreted metalloprotease expressed in gastrointestinal epithelial cells and over-expressed during epithelial remodeling and tumorigenesis. Inconsistencies: • No major discordant genes; ADAM28 can also be detected in certain immune cells, but its documented expression in gut epithelium aligns with the overall program.

program_59.description: The program is most consistent with a perivascular mural‐cell / mesenchymal-like state (pericytes or vascular smooth-muscle–derived mesenchymal stem cells) that is primed for angiogenesis and motility. Evidence: • MCAM (CD146) – canonical surface marker of pericytes and vascular smooth-muscle–derived mesenchymal stem cells; highly enriched at the abluminal side of microvessels. • CRIM1 – endothelial/pericyte-enriched transmembrane protein induced in angiogenic tip and stalk cells, supporting BMP/VEGF signalling. • ADGRG6 (GPR126) – adhesion GPCR required for endothelial integrity and mural-cell interaction; expressed in pericytes and vascular endothelium. • PREX2 and AFAP1L2 (XB130) – PI3K/Rac pathway adaptors that promote cytoskeletal remodelling and migration, fitting an activated, motile perivascular phenotype. Inconsistencies: • PREX2 and AFAP1L2 are not pericyte-restricted and can be found in other migratory cell types (e.g., melanoma, epithelial), so their presence is supportive of motility but not lineage-specific.

program_60.description: The gene set reflects an ATF4-driven amino-acid starvation / integrated stress-response program that cells (of diverse lineage) activate to restore amino-acid pools and adapt to metabolic or hypoxic stress rather than a lineage-restricted identity. Evidence: • PSAT1 (serine synthesis), PYCR1 (proline synthesis) and ASNS (asparagine synthesis) are canonical ATF4 target genes that boost de-novo amino-acid production during nutrient limitation. • TRIB3 is a direct transcriptional target of ATF4–CHOP induced by ER stress or amino-acid deprivation, reinforcing the integrated stress response. • ADM2 is up-regulated by hypoxia and cellular stress and is frequently co-expressed with ATF4 target genes in nutrient-stressed cells. Inconsistencies: • No strongly conflicting genes are present in the program.

program_61.description: The gene set is most consistent with a general “quiescent / terminally-differentiated stress-resistance” program that is often observed in mature fibroblasts and other non-cycling mesenchymal or epithelial cells. The program couples chromatin-compaction (histone H1 variants) with membrane-scaffold remodeling (AHNAK), active endosomal trafficking (SNX32) and an enhanced glutathione-based antioxidant defense (GSR), features typical of cells that have exited the cell cycle and are geared toward long-term survival under oxidative or mechanical stress. Evidence: • H1F0 (H1-0) – canonical marker of terminal differentiation and chromatin condensation in non-proliferating cells (e.g., resting fibroblasts, mature epithelial cells). • H1-4 – reiterates elevated linker-histone content, supporting a compacted, low-transcription chromatin state typical of quiescence. • AHNAK – large scaffold protein enriched in differentiated fibroblasts/mesenchymal cells and up-regulated during membrane repair and epithelial-to-mesenchymal–like adaptations. • GSR – key enzyme of the glutathione system; its up-regulation denotes an antioxidant, stress-resistant phenotype frequently seen in long-lived, non-cycling cells. • SNX32 – endosomal sorting nexin linked to vesicular trafficking; maintenance of membrane and receptor turnover without proliferation. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; however, the listed genes are broadly expressed, so the program lacks highly specific lineage markers and may represent a generic quiescent/stress-response state rather than a lineage-restricted signature.

program_62.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, angiogenic “tip” endothelial-cell program that is engaged during sprouting blood-vessel formation. Evidence: • ANGPT2 – canonical marker of endothelial activation and vessel remodeling; strongly up-regulated in tip cells relative to quiescent stalk or mature endothelial cells. • SEMA3D – guidance cue secreted by sprouting endothelial cells to steer angiogenic migration. • DTX1 – Notch-pathway E3 ligase induced during dynamic Notch signaling; elevated in tip/stalk fate specification of endothelial cells. • PDE2A – cyclic-nucleotide phosphodiesterase enriched in endothelial cells where it modulates cAMP/cGMP signaling downstream of VEGF and NO during angiogenesis. • SCN3B – voltage-gated sodium-channel β-subunit reported in microvascular endothelial cells and up-regulated in endothelial cells undergoing migration; fits with heightened ion-flux requirements of tip cells. Inconsistencies: • SCN3B is better known in excitable tissues (neurons, cardiomyocytes); its inclusion is less typical for endothelial programs but has been detected in some endothelial contexts, so is only a minor inconsistency.

program_63.description: The gene set points to an IL-10–responsive, anti-inflammatory (M2-like) monocyte/macrophage program. Evidence: • IL10RA – high on monocytes/macrophages that sense IL-10 and adopt an anti-inflammatory phenotype. • AOAH – LPS-deacylating enzyme enriched in tissue macrophages and circulating monocytes, associated with endotoxin tolerance. • FYB1 (ADAP) & WAS – hematopoietic adaptors controlling integrin/actin dynamics; both are expressed in monocytes and macrophages during adhesion and phagocytosis. • MYO1G – unconventional myosin abundant in monocytes/macrophages, supports membrane ruffling and motility. Inconsistencies: • FYB1 and WAS are also strongly expressed in lymphocytes, so the program could partially overlap with lymphoid signatures, but their presence in monocytes is well documented and not strongly contradictory.

program_64.description: The gene set is most consistent with airway epithelial ionocytes—a rare, highly specialized cell type devoted to transepithelial ion (especially Cl⁻) transport and characterized by a FOXI1-driven transcriptional program. Evidence: • FOXI1 – lineage-defining transcription factor for ionocytes; required for CFTR, ATP6V1B1, and other ion‐transport gene expression in human and murine airways. • ASCL3 – co-expressed with FOXI1 in virtually all airway ionocytes; used as a key marker in single-cell atlases of trachea, bronchi, and nasal epithelium. • BSND – Barttin Cl⁻ channel subunit enriched in FOXI1⁺ ionocytes, supporting their high chloride conductance capacity. • DGKI & APLP2 – broadly expressed but repeatedly detected within FOXI1⁺/ASCL3⁺ ionocyte clusters in scRNA-seq datasets, consistent with their inclusion in the same program. Inconsistencies: • DGKI and APLP2 lack ionocyte specificity and are found in other cell types, but they are not contradictory to the ionocyte identity; no genes actively oppose the assignment.

program_65.description: The gene set represents a canonical immediate-early (IEG) activation/stress response program that is rapidly induced in many cell types shortly after exposure to mitogens, cytokines, mechanical injury, or DNA damage, rather than marking a specific lineage. It reflects cells that have just sensed an external stimulus and switched on transcriptional regulators that precede cell-cycle entry or stress adaptation. Evidence: • EGR1 and IER2 – prototypical immediate-early transcription factors up-regulated within minutes of growth-factor or MAPK signaling. • ATF3 – stress-inducible bZIP transcription factor activated by diverse stimuli (UV, cytokines, ER stress), often co-expressed with EGR family during early response. • SERTAD1 (TRIP-BR1) – early-response co-regulator that cooperates with E2F and cyclins to drive G1-S progression after mitogenic stimulation. • H2AX – histone variant whose rapid phosphorylation (γ-H2AX) marks DNA damage; its transcriptional up-regulation accompanies early genotoxic or oxidative stress signaling. Inconsistencies: No strongly conflicting genes are present; all listed genes fit an immediate-early/stress activation program.

program_66.description: The gene set is most consistent with an epithelial oxidative/heat-shock stress response program, likely driven by NRF2 signaling and chaperone induction in gut or airway epithelium, rather than defining a distinct lineage such as plasma cells. Evidence: • GPX2 – classic NRF2 target enriched in intestinal and airway epithelial cells responding to oxidative stress. • HSPB1 – small heat-shock chaperone broadly induced during proteotoxic or heat stress. • SDC1 – transmembrane heparan-sulfate proteoglycan highly expressed on many epithelial surfaces and up-regulated during epithelial injury/wound repair. • PCP4L1, C16orf74 – less-characterized genes reported in epithelial tissues and shown to rise with cellular stress, supporting a general stress program. • Absence of lineage-defining immunoglobulin or cytotoxic genes argues against plasma-cell or immune programs, reinforcing an epithelial stress state interpretation. Inconsistencies: • SDC1 is also a plasma-cell marker; its presence without other plasma-cell genes (e.g., MZB1, XBP1, immunoglobulin chains) could be viewed as atypical but is explainable by its independent expression in stressed epithelia. • Functional roles of PCP4L1 and C16orf74 are poorly characterized, so their contribution to the stress interpretation is inferential rather than well established.

program_67.description: The program most closely reflects an epithelial (particularly keratinocyte-like) injury / immediate-early stress response state characterized by rapid EGFR–MAPK/AP-1 activation and production of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Evidence: • FOSL1 (FRA-1) – AP-1 transcription factor rapidly induced by EGFR–MAPK signaling during wound repair and epithelial activation. • ERRFI1 (MIG6) – classic EGFR negative-feedback regulator up-regulated minutes to hours after EGFR stimulation in epithelial stress responses. • GADD45A – DNA damage and stress-inducible gene that enforces transient cell-cycle arrest following injury. • IL20 – cytokine produced by activated keratinocytes and monocytes that promotes keratinocyte proliferation and inflammatory skin responses. • Overall pattern (immediate-early gene induction, EGFR feedback, pro-inflammatory cytokine) matches published “wound-activated keratinocyte” / early stress-response signatures. Inconsistencies: • C6orf141 has limited functional annotation; its role in this context is unclear but does not contradict the injury response interpretation.

program_68.description: The gene set is most consistent with an injury-response secretory program in lung epithelium, characteristic of SCGB3A2-high “aberrant”/transitional secretory cells (also called KRT8⁺ or MMP7⁺ alveolar differentiation intermediates) that expand during airway or alveolar repair and in fibrotic lung disease. Evidence: • SCGB3A2 – canonical marker of distal airway/club secretory cells and of recently described SCGB3A2⁺ transitional epithelial cells that appear after lung injury. • MMP7 – hallmark metalloproteinase strongly induced in KRT8⁺ transitional/alveolar repair epithelium and in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis lesions. • CAPN8 and PAEP – both included in the transcriptomic signature of SCGB3A2⁺/MMP7⁺ transitional epithelial cells in human and mouse lungs undergoing regeneration or IL-13-driven secretory metaplasia. • STEAP4 – cytokine-inducible metalloreductase up-regulated in inflamed airway and alveolar epithelial cells, supporting an injury/inflammatory context. Inconsistencies: • CAPN8 is classically described in gastric epithelium, and PAEP in endometrium; their presence elsewhere is limited to injury-associated lung secretory cells, so their inclusion is unusual but documented.

program_69.description: The gene set is most consistent with a maturation/activation program in conventional dendritic cells (cDCs), particularly IRF4-dependent cDC2 that have up-regulated lymph-node–homing receptors and activation markers characteristic of migratory mature DCs. Evidence: • CD83 – classical surface marker of mature, fully activated dendritic cells. • CCR7 – chemokine receptor induced during DC maturation that directs migration to T-cell zones of lymph nodes. • IRF4 – lineage-defining transcription factor for cDC2 and required for their terminal maturation and CCR7 induction. • GPR183 (EBI2) – guides positioning of activated DCs within secondary lymphoid tissues and is co-expressed with CCR7 in migratory cDC2. • Lack of negatively loaded genes supports a unidirectional activation/maturation program rather than a mixed state. Inconsistencies: • NIBAN3 (FAM129C) is better known in activated B cells/plasmablasts; its presence is less typical for dendritic cells, though low-level expression has been reported in some myeloid populations. • GPR183 and CD83 are also found in activated B cells, but concomitant high CCR7 and IRF4 together with absence of B-lineage markers (e.g., CD19, MS4A1) favors a dendritic rather than B-cell identity.

program_70.description: The gene set is most consistent with an airway secretory epithelial (club / goblet) cell program marked by high secretoglobin production and tight-junction formation, reflecting a differentiated, mucus-secreting state of bronchiolar epithelium. Evidence: • SCGB3A2 – canonical secretoglobin abundantly expressed by airway club cells and other bronchiolar secretory epithelial cells. • CLDN4 – epithelial tight-junction claudin enriched in distal/bronchiolar secretory and goblet cells, helping maintain barrier integrity. • PAEP (glycodelin) – secreted lipocalin reported in human bronchial mucus–producing cells and other secretory epithelia. • ERP27 – ER chaperone up-regulated in cells with high secretory protein load, typical of club/goblet cells. • CTSE – lysosomal aspartic protease detected in mucosal secretory epithelia (including bronchial) and participates in processing of secreted proteins, supporting a secretory phenotype. Inconsistencies: • CTSE is also expressed in some antigen-presenting immune cells, but its presence in mucosal secretory epithelium is documented and does not conflict strongly with the overall airway secretory program.

program_71.description: The gene set is most consistent with a terminal-differentiation (cornification) program of stratified squamous epithelial cells—e.g., suprabasal/late keratinizing keratinocytes of skin or other cornified epithelia. Evidence: • TINCR – lncRNA induced during keratinocyte terminal differentiation; controls expression of epidermal barrier proteins. • CNFN (Cornifelin) – structural protein confined to the cornified envelope of differentiating squamous epithelial cells. • PRSS27 (Epitheliasin) and PRSS22 – epithelial serine proteases enriched in differentiating skin and airway/upper-aerodigestive squamous layers, linked to cornification and barrier remodeling. • KLK12 – member of the kallikrein family; kallikreins are activated in the upper epidermal layers and participate in desquamation. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions noted; the small gene set uniformly points to late-stage squamous epithelial differentiation.

program_72.description: The program most plausibly represents a generic, AP-1–driven oxidative / metabolic stress response that can be transiently induced in many cell types rather than marking a specific lineage. Evidence: • JUND – AP-1 transcription factor rapidly up-regulated by diverse stresses (oxidative, inflammatory, hypoxic) and orchestrates stress-response gene expression. • GSTT2B – phase-II detoxification enzyme that conjugates glutathione to reactive metabolites, typically co-induced with oxidative-stress programs. • VEGFB – although best known for vascular roles, it is transcriptionally induced by hypoxia- and stress-activated AP-1 elements and participates in cytoprotective and metabolic adaptation. • GNAS – encodes the Gαs subunit; cAMP signaling downstream of many stress-sensing GPCRs can activate AP-1 and antioxidant pathways. • TMEM145 – reported to increase after cellular stress and shows broad, low-level expression consistent with a generic response module. Inconsistencies: • No strongly cell-type-restricted markers are present; all listed genes can participate in a broad stress-response context, so the program does not pinpoint a precise lineage.

program_73.description: The program reflects cells that are actively replicating their DNA—i.e., an S-phase/proliferative state—most likely within the lymphoid lineage (e.g., dividing T or B cells). Evidence: • H1-3, H2BC3, H2BC7, H3C10 – canonical replication-dependent histone genes that are sharply up-regulated during S phase to package newly synthesized DNA; a hallmark of cycling cells. • PTPRCAP – adaptor for the leukocyte phosphatase CD45, expressed almost exclusively in lymphocytes, supporting a hematopoietic (immune) context for the proliferative signature. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes contradict a proliferative lymphoid interpretation; histone genes are ubiquitous but compatible with the high mitotic activity of any cell type, so lineage specificity is inferred mainly from PTPRCAP and is therefore tentative.

program_74.description: The gene set is most consistent with antibody-secreting B cells—i.e., plasmablasts/plasma cells—showing a proliferative or recently activated state. Evidence: • Classical plasma-cell markers upregulated: – MZB1 (ER chaperone enriched in plasma cells, supports Ig folding) – JCHAIN (joining chain of IgA/IgM, hallmark of antibody-secreting cells) – TNFRSF17/BCMA (survival receptor expressed almost exclusively on plasmablasts/plasma cells) • Differentiation transcription factor: – IRF4 drives B-cell transition to plasmablast/plasma cell fate. • Proliferation/early plasmablast signal: – MYBL2 (B-MYB) promotes cell-cycle progression, fitting a recently activated, still-dividing plasmablast rather than a fully quiescent long-lived plasma cell. Inconsistencies: No negatively loaded genes were provided; the listed genes are all compatible with a proliferative plasmablast/plasma-cell program.

program_0.description: The gene set represents an acutely activated, pro-inflammatory CD4⁺ T-cell state that is simultaneously mounting a strong heat-shock / unfolded-protein / integrated-stress response (ISR). Cells in this program display classic early T-cell activation markers and effector cytokines while up-regulating chaperones, ER-stress mediators and immediate-early genes, and they down-regulate several canonical resting/naïve T-cell surface components. Evidence: • T-cell activation & effector function – CD69, CD40LG, TNFRSF9 (4-1BB), TNFRSF4 (OX40), CRTAM, CD44, IFNG, TNF, CSF1, CSF2, IL10, IL23A, CCL3/4/17, XCL1/2. • Th1/effector transcriptional regulators – IRF4, BATF, EGR1/2/3, NR4A1/2, KLF4/6, BHLHE40. • Heat-shock / chaperone and unfolded-protein response – HSPA1A/B, HSPA5 (BiP), HSP90AA1/AB1, HSPH1, DNAJB1/4/6, HSPE1, HSPD1, HSPA6, HERPUD1, PPP1R15A (GADD34), ATF4, DDIT3 (CHOP), ERN1, HSPA8. • Integrated stress / oxidative & inflammatory stress genes – DUSP1/2/4/10, GADD45B/G, SQSTM1, TNFAIP3, NFKBIA/Z, DDIT4, RGS1/2/16, SOCS1/3, ZFP36/L1/L2. • Metabolic re-programming typical of activated T cells – SLC2A3 (GLUT3), ADM, DYNLL1, CKS2, PLK2/3. • Negative loadings mark loss of resting T-cell features – TXNIP (high in quiescent T cells), CD3G, CD7, CD8A/B, KLRC1; their inverse correlation with the program is expected during strong activation when TCR/CD8 surface levels fall. Inconsistencies: • Presence of stromal or lineage-atypical transcripts (ACTA2, COL6A3, KRT81/86) and mast-cell genes (TPSB2, GATA2) suggests low-level ambient RNA or doublets. • Interferon-stimulated genes (ISG15, GBP2) appear but are not central to the stress/activation theme.

program_1.description: The gene set is most consistent with an inflammatory, monocyte-derived macrophage program typical of lung (alveolar) tissue, i.e. “mono-to-alveolar macrophage transition” seen during acute lung inflammation or infection. Cells carrying this program display simultaneous expression of (i) classical inflammatory/monocytic genes, (ii) core macrophage phagocytic and complement genes, and (iii) a subset of surfactant-handling transcripts usually detected in lung parenchyma, reflecting adaptation to the alveolar niche. Evidence: • Core myeloid / phagocytic machinery – LYZ, CD14, CD68, AIF1, SPI1, CYBB, CTSS/CTSB/CTSL, FCGR2A, CLEC7A, VSIG4, MRC1, MARCO, C1QA/B/C. • Inflammatory-monocyte markers – S100A8, S100A9, S100A12, FCN1, LST1, IL1B, CXCL8, CXCL2, CXCL3, RETN, OLR1, TREM1, PTX3. • Complement / opsonisation and scavenging – C1QA/B/C, APOE, APOC1, LPL, FABP4/5, ALOX5, APOE. • Lung / alveolar niche adaptation – surfactant and surfactant-processing genes SFTPA1, SFTPA2, SFTPB, SFTPC, SFTPD, NAPSA, ABCA3, SLC34A2, MUC1, SCGB3A2; together with macrophage lipid-handling genes (APOE, LPL, FABP4) that process inhaled lipids. • Negative loading for T-cell-associated transcripts (CD3D, CCL5, IL32) and ubiquitous HLA-A/B, supporting assignment to myeloid rather than lymphoid cells. Inconsistencies: • Surfactant genes (SFTPA/B/C/D, ABCA3) are classical type-II alveolar epithelial markers, not typically transcribed by macrophages—could reflect phagocytic uptake, ambient RNA contamination, or epithelial–myeloid doublets. • KIT and TPSB2 are mast-cell associated; FCER1A is shared with dendritic/mast cells; their presence is atypical for macrophages. • CALB2 and BEST1 are more common in neuro-endocrine/epithelial lineages. Despite these outliers, the dominant and coherent signature points to an inflammatory lung macrophage program, with surfactant-related transcripts likely acquired from the alveolar environment rather than indicating an epithelial identity.

program_2.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated / angiogenic endothelial-cell program that is beginning to acquire mesenchymal features (early endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition, EndoMT) typical of vessels exposed to hypoxia or tissue remodelling/fibrosis. Evidence: • Core endothelial markers – PECAM1, CLDN5, VWF, ESAM, ENG, ACVRL1, CLEC14A, CA4, RAMP2, EGFL7, EPAS1 support an endothelial identity. • Angiogenesis / hypoxia response – EPAS1 (HIF-2α), ADM, EGFL7, ID1/ID3, CCN1/CCN2, TFPI, SERPINF1 (PEDF), GAS6 indicate a pro-angiogenic, hypoxia-responsive state. • Mesenchymal / contractile acquisition – ACTA2, TAGLN, MYL9, CALD1, CNN3, COL1A1/2, COL6A1/2, FN1, SPARC, DCN, LUM, BGN show matrix synthesis and smooth-muscle–like contractility characteristic of EndoMT. • Extracellular-matrix and complement genes – FBLN1, SERPING1, C1R, C1S, CFH, CFD, CLU, A2M, THBS1, TIMP3 highlight vessel-associated matrix remodelling and innate immune regulation seen in activated endothelium. • Down-weighted immune/T-cell genes – CD3D, HLA-E, CREM, SAMSN1 argue against a lymphoid signature and fit an endothelial program that is distinct from infiltrating immune cells. Inconsistencies: • Surfactant / alveolar epithelial genes (SFTPA1/2, SFTPB, SFTPC, NAPSA, AGER) and mast-cell genes (TPSAB1, TPSB2, CPA3, KIT, MS4A2, HDC) appear in the positive list but are not typical of endothelium; they may reflect ambient RNA or doublets rather than the core program.

program_3.description: The gene set reflects a generic high-proliferation, late-S/G2-to-M cell-cycle program that can appear in any rapidly dividing cell population; expression of DNA-replication, checkpoint, and mitotic-spindle genes is strongly up-regulated, while chemokine- and interferon-responsive genes typical of resting immune cells are down-regulated. Evidence: • Canonical S/G2 regulators – CCNA2, CCNB1/2, CDK1/2, CDC6, CDC20, CHEK1/2, PLK1, FOXM1. • DNA synthesis/repair – MCM2-7, PCNA, RFC3/4/5, RRM1, FEN1, BRCA1/2, RAD51, RAD54L, FANCD2/CI/CL, APOBEC3B. • Chromosome condensation/segregation – NCAPG/D2/D3, SGO1/2, ESCO2, CENPA/E/F/P/W/Q/K, KNL1, BUB1/BUB1B, NDC80, SPC25, KIF11/14/15/18A/22/23, AURKA/B, PRC1, CEP55, TACC3. • Mitotic spindle/contractile ring – DLGAP5, RACGAP1, ECT2, ANLN, CIT, TPX2. • Proliferation-linked transcription factors/chromatin modifiers – E2F1/2/8, MYBL2, EZH2, HELLS, PHF19. • Suppressed resting/immune markers (negatively loaded) – CXCR4, CCL18, ISG20, SAMSN1, MT1X, consistent with loss of quiescent or differentiated immune signatures during active cycling. Inconsistencies: • Lineage-restricted or inflammatory genes within the positive set (S100A8 – myeloid, BATF & PLCG2 – lymphoid signaling) suggest the program is superimposed on specific immune cell types rather than defining a dedicated lineage, but these constitute a small minority of the genes.

program_4.description: The program defines conventional follicular/naïve-to-early-memory B cells that are poised for antigen presentation and T-cell interaction but are not in an interferon-stimulated state. Evidence: • Core B-cell identity – CD19, CD22, CD79B, PAX5, BLNK, BTK, POU2AF1, EBF1, BCL11A, LYN, SYK. • Follicular/lymph-node homing and naïve-like profile – CCR7, CXCR5, SELL (CD62L), TCL1A, FCER2 (CD23), FCGR2B; absence of plasma-cell genes (e.g., PRDM1, XBP1). • Antigen presentation/activation capacity – HLA-DMA/B, HLA-DOA/B, HLA-DRB5, CIITA, CD40, CD86, CD70, CD81, FCRL1/2/5, FCGR2B. • Early activation / germinal-center priming signals – IRF4, IRF8, BACH2, RASGRP3, CD24, MZB1, indicating cells recently stimulated but not fully differentiated. • Negative loadings for interferon-response genes (RSAD2, IFI6, CCL5) highlight a state lacking type-I interferon stimulation, separating these B cells from antiviral/inflammatory programs. Inconsistencies: • Myeloid/DC-associated genes (CD1C, CLEC4A, SIRPA, FSCN1, CSF2RB) appear, possibly reflecting low-level contamination or shared expression in activated B cells. • MZB1 and ST14 are more typical of plasmablasts/epithelial contexts, and TPSAB1 (mast-cell protease) and NAPSA (alveolar type-II cell protease) are likely ambient RNA or rare doublets.

program_5.description: The gene set describes an innate cytotoxic lymphocyte program most characteristic of mature, KIR-expressing CD56^dim natural killer (NK) cells (and closely related NK-like CD8 T cells) that are highly cytolytic, secrete inflammatory chemokines, and show elements of late/terminal differentiation or exhaustion (TIM-3^+). Evidence: • Cytotoxic molecules – GZMA, GZMM, SRGN together mark cytolytic granule content typical of NK and effector CD8 cells. • NK-specific receptors – NCR1 (NKp46), NCR3 (NKp30), CD160, KLRB1 (CD161), TMIGD2 (CD28H), IL2RB (CD122) and IL18RAP support an NK activation signature. • Inhibitory KIRs and NKG2A – KIR2DL1/3, KIR3DL1/2/4, KLRC1 (NKG2A) are hallmarks of terminally differentiated CD56^dim NK cells. • Transcription factors driving NK identity – ID2, ZBTB16 (PLZF), ZEB2 and HOPX are required for NK or innate-like T-cell development. • Signalling adaptors typical of NK cells – SYK, LAT2, VAV3, LYN, FES, TXK, SH2D1B enable Fc- and ITAM-mediated cytotoxic signalling. • Chemokine/effector cytokine genes – CCL3, CCL4, XCL1, XCL2, AREG indicate inflammatory recruitment and tissue-repair functions of mature NK cells. • Exhaustion/late differentiation marker – HAVCR2 (TIM-3) commonly appears on chronically stimulated or terminal NK/T cells. • Negative loading of canonical T-cell/naïve markers – IL7R, CD3D/G, CD40LG, TRAT1, CXCR6 and CD44 being under-represented supports a program distinct from conventional naïve/central-memory T cells. Inconsistencies: • Myeloid‐associated ITGAX (CD11c) and AOAH, and erythroid transcripts (HBA1, HBA2, HBQ1) likely reflect ambient RNA or doublets rather than true NK expression. • Interferon-stimulated genes (IFIT2/3, ISG20) suggest concurrent IFN exposure but are not specific to NK cells.

program_6.description: The gene set defines a TCR-activated effector/memory T-cell state characterized by strong proximal T-cell signaling, immediate-early/AP-1 transcriptional activity, cytokine production, cytoskeletal remodeling and loss of resting/naïve markers. Evidence: • T-cell identity / TCR signaling: CD3E, LCP2, PTPRCAP, GNG10, GPR25 – core components of the TCR complex and its adaptor network. • Immediate-early activation: JUN, FOS, IER2, FKBP5, TNF, TNFSF8, SESN1 – classic AP-1 and NF-κB–inducible genes rapidly up-regulated after TCR engagement. • Effector/memory phenotype: KLRK1 (NKG2D), KLRC3, KCNA3, LIME1 – receptors and ion channels enriched in activated cytotoxic or tissue-resident memory T cells. • Cytoskeletal reorganization / motility: RHOA, RAC2, ZYX, PLSCR3, ACTB – required for immune synapse formation and migration during activation. • Down-regulation of resting/naïve or quiescence genes (negatively loaded): CXCR4, TMSB4X, BTG1, KLRB1, RGS1, ID2 – genes typically high in naïve or lymph-node-homing T cells but suppressed upon activation. • Selective loss of type-I IFN response genes (negatively loaded IFIT1, IFIT3, ISG20) further differentiates this program from interferon-driven states. Inconsistencies: • AGER and HERC5 are more common in epithelial/ISG responses; their positive loading is atypical but can be induced in strongly activated T cells. • Absence of canonical cytotoxic granule genes (e.g., GZMB, PRF1) suggests this program reflects general T-cell activation rather than full cytotoxic differentiation.

program_7.description: The gene program is most consistent with terminally differentiated, highly cytotoxic CD8⁺ effector / TEMRA-like T cells that produce inflammatory chemokines and display NK-associated receptors, while genes typical of naïve or central-memory T cells are concurrently repressed. Evidence: • Cytotoxic machinery – PFN1, GZMA, GZMH, GZMM, CTSC encode perforin/granzymes or their activators. • Inflammatory chemokines – CCL3, CCL4, CCL5, XCL2 and receptor CX3CR1 support an effector cell able to recruit other immune cells and home to inflamed tissue. • NK/terminal differentiation markers – KLRG1, FCRL6, CD160, NCR3, HCST, NCAM1 (CD56) and TBX21 (T-bet), ZEB2, HOPX are characteristic of late effector CD8⁺ T cells with NK-like features. • T-cell identity – CD8A, PLEK, RAC2, CORO1A, PLCG2, FYN, SRGN reinforce a T-cell lineage. • Down-regulation of naïve/central-memory genes – strong negative loadings for IL7R, GPR183, CXCR4, CD69, SOCS3, BTG1/2, BIRC3 indicate loss of homeostatic/lymphoid-resident programs typical of early or quiescent T cells. Inconsistencies: • NCAM1 (CD56) is more typical of NK cells; may reflect NK-like cytotoxic CD8⁺ subset or minor NK contamination. • HBA2 (hemoglobin), BPIFA1 (airway epithelium), TPSAB1 (mast cell) appear out of place and likely represent ambient RNA or rare doublets rather than core program genes.

program_8.description: The program most strongly reflects a naïve/central-memory CD4⁺ T-cell state that retains lymph-node homing capacity and lacks cytotoxic effector differentiation. Evidence: • Positively loaded lymph-node homing/naïve genes: CCR7, SELL (L-selectin), MAL, IL7R, CD27, CD28, LEF1, TCF7, LTB – all classical markers of naïve or central-memory CD4 T cells. • Additional T-cell activation-competent but non-effector genes: GPR183, TRAT1, FLT3LG, JUNB/FOS (early response), SOCS3, NFKBIA – consistent with a resting cell poised for activation rather than a terminal effector. • Negatively loaded cytotoxic/effector genes: GZMA, GZMH, GZMM, GZMK, CCL3/4/5, KLRG1, EOMES, ZEB2, ID2, TIGIT, CD8A/B – genes typical of cytotoxic effector or TEMRA CD8⁺ T cells are specifically depleted, reinforcing a non-cytotoxic CD4 phenotype. Inconsistencies: • Modest positive loading of myeloid-associated genes (NCF1, LST1, LCN2) and extracellular matrix genes (ADAM12) are atypical for T cells. • Negative loading of KLRB1 (CD161) and TIGIT could argue against some central-memory subsets that often co-express these receptors. • ENTPD1 (CD39) positivity is more characteristic of regulatory/ exhausted T cells, though its expression can appear transiently after activation.

program_9.description: The gene set represents a proximal airway secretory-epithelial program—encompassing club and goblet cell differentiation coupled to a mucosal-defence / inflammatory state—and is explicitly anti-correlated with the alveolar type II (surfactant-producing) program. Evidence: • Secretory (club/goblet) lineage genes: SCGB3A1, SCGB3A2, BPIFA1, BPIFB1, PIGR, TFF3, AGR2/3, MUC5AC, MUC5B, MUC1, AQP3, AQP5, SLC34A2, ALDH1A1. • Antimicrobial / acute-phase components characteristic of inflamed airway epithelium: LCN2, SAA1, SAA2, CXCL17, CXCL1, CXCL2, IL33. • General epithelial/cytokeratin markers: EPCAM, TACSTD2, KRT8, KRT18, KRT19, CLDN4, CLDN7, BCAM. • Ciliated/airway structural genes occasionally co-expressed in secretory cells during differentiation: RSPH1, CFAP276, CFAP144. • Basal-to-luminal transition markers indicating epithelial remodeling: KRT5, KRT17, ITGA1, KRT15. • Strong negative loadings for canonical alveolar type II genes (SFTPA1, SFTPA2, SFTPB, SFTPC, SFTPD, NAPSA) support the interpretation that this program is specific to proximal/bronchiolar epithelium and mutually exclusive with the AT2 surfactant program. Inconsistencies: • Sparse immune-cell transcripts (CD3D—T cells; TPSB2, MS4A2—mast cells; ZFP36, ARHGDIB) and HBB (erythroid) likely reflect ambient RNA or minor contaminating cells rather than the epithelial program itself.

program_10.description: The program most closely matches CD8⁺ tissue-resident memory (TRM) T cells in an activated, non-cytotoxic state. Evidence: • Core T-cell identity – CD3D/E/G, CD2, CD5, CD27, PTPRC, TRAT1, THEMIS. • CD8 lineage – CD8A, CD8B and cytolytic mediator GZMK (without high GZMB/GZMH), typical of non-terminally differentiated CD8⁺ T cells. • Tissue-resident memory signature – ZNF683 (Hobit), CXCR6, ITGA1 (CD49a), ENTPD1 (CD39), RGS1, CRTAM, SIT1; all hallmarks of TRM cells lodged in peripheral tissues. • Chemokine/ trafficking profile – CCR5, CXCR3, CCL5, CKLF support tissue homing/retention rather than recirculation. • Activation/regulation genes – LAG3, IL7R, DUSP4, CAMK4, PIK3R1 indicate an activated yet not fully exhausted state. • Suppressed recirculation program – negative loading of KLF2 (required for S1PR1-mediated egress) aligns with tissue residency; reduced CCL3 and IRF8 further fit a non-circulating, non-myeloid profile. Inconsistencies: • Airway/secretory epithelial transcripts (SCGB3A1, BPIFB1, AGR3, PROK2) and surfactant genes appearing with opposing loadings may reflect ambient RNA or doublets with epithelial cells. • Myeloid/endothelial markers (CSF1, VCAM1, ALOX5AP) are atypical for pure TRM T cells and could represent minor contamination or shared inflammatory milieu.

program_11.description: The gene set most closely matches a program in recently-activated CD4⁺ helper T cells (effector-memory / peripheral-helper–like) that have received strong T-cell-receptor and co-stimulatory signals and have simultaneously up-regulated multiple negative-feedback and glucocorticoid-responsive regulators, consistent with an immunoregulatory/anti-inflammatory activation state. Evidence: • T-cell identity and TCR signalling – CD3D, TRAT1, SRGN, RGS1. • Co-stimulation/activation genes – CD40LG, ICOS, CTLA4, IL2, BATF, JUNB, FOS, DUSP4, PFKFB3 (glycolytic switch). • Chemokine-guided tissue homing typical of effector-memory/peripheral-helper cells – CXCR4, CXCR6, CD44, JAML. • Immunoregulatory cytokines and effectors – IL10, OSM, CSF1, CH25H, PRDM1 (BLIMP-1). • Negative-feedback / glucocorticoid-inducible regulators dampening NF-κB or JAK–STAT signalling – TSC22D3 (GILZ), TNFAIP3, SOCS1, FKBP5, TOB1, BTG1, DDIT4. • Stress and cytoskeletal remodelling associated with activated, tissue-resident T cells – ANXA1, VIM, S100A10, SPOCK2. • Negatively loaded genes bolster the assignment: low PLCG2 (normally higher in B/myeloid cells) and low TXNIP (a metabolic brake) match an actively signalling, glycolysis-competent T-cell state. Inconsistencies: • Myeloid/inflammasome-related genes (ALOX5AP, NLRP3) and mesenchymal markers (ADAM12, VIM) are not classical for T cells, though they are reported to be inducible in strongly activated or tissue-resident T cells. • Absence of some canonical exhaustion markers (PDCD1, LAG3) suggests this is an early immune-regulatory rather than chronically exhausted state.

program_12.description: The gene set most strongly fits an activated, interferon-exposed tissue-resident memory (TRM) T-cell program, typical of CXCR3⁺ effector-memory/Th1-skewed CD4⁺ T cells that have adapted to peripheral inflamed tissues. Evidence: • Core T-cell identity – CD3E, CD2, LCP2, CD52 confirm lymphoid rather than stromal or myeloid origin. • Tissue residency / loss of recirculation – ZNF683 (Hobit), CXCR6, CD82, ITM2C and low SELL (CD62L, negative loading) are canonical markers of TRM cells that remain in non-lymphoid tissues. • Effector/activation state – CXCR3, CD40LG, CTLA4, TNFRSF18 (GITR), BATF/BATF3 and IL32 denote recently activated, Th1-polarised effector cells. • Interferon/inflammatory exposure – ISG15, OASL, LGALS1/3 and AHR reflect IFN-driven and inflammatory signalling common in tissue TRM niches. • Cytoskeleton/motility & metabolic remodelling – VIM, S100A4/6/10/11, TMSB4X/10, COTL1, CFL1, ARHGDIB, CAPG, ANXA1/2/5, PPARG and GAPDH/PKM are hallmarks of highly migratory, metabolically active tissue-adapted lymphocytes. • Additional tissue-inflammation genes – ALOX5AP, LTC4S, GLUL support lipid-mediator synthesis and metabolic autonomy characteristic of resident effector T cells. • Negative loading of RIPOR2 and SELL further argues against a naïve/central-memory phenotype and in favour of tissue-resident or effector-memory cells. Inconsistencies: • Mast-cell–associated TPSAB1 and LTC4S, and myeloid lipid mediator gene ALOX5AP, are atypical for T cells and may reflect ambient RNA or minor cross-loading. • PPARG and CTLA4 can also be expressed by tissue Treg cells, yet the absence of canonical Treg markers (FOXP3, IL2RA, IKZF2) makes a dominant Treg interpretation unlikely.

program_13.description: The program most closely reflects an IL7R-high, non-cytotoxic CD4 memory / Th17-skewed T-cell state that is mildly activated and largely devoid of interferon-stimulated or tissue-resident effector signatures. Evidence: • Core T-cell identity and memory state – IL7R, CD3E, CD2, FLT3LG, CAMK4, LTA, TNFSF8, TPT1, GZMK support a conventional, mainly CD4 central/early-effector memory phenotype. • Th17 polarization & cytokine production – RORC (master TF of Th17), IL6ST, IL32, ALOX5AP, RUNX2 (reported enhancer of Th17 differentiation) are enriched. • Absence of cytotoxic/tissue-resident programs – Negative loading of ZNF683 (Hobit), CRTAM and RUNX3, genes typical of tissue-resident or cytotoxic CD8 T cells, argues against a CTL/TRM state. • Low interferon response – ISG15, IFIT2, OASL are negatively loaded, indicating these cells are not in an IFN-stimulated state. • General activation/translation support – EEF1A1, EIF3E/H, EIF4B, RACK1, TPT1 highlight increased translational capacity typical of recently stimulated memory T cells. Inconsistencies: • Myeloid-associated oxidase components (NCF1, NCF4) and ALOX5AP are atypical for pure T cells but can be induced in activated T cells. • Broadly expressed cytoskeletal/mesenchymal genes (VIM, FXYD5) and RUNX2, usually linked to osteogenic cells, are unusual yet reported in activated or migrating T cells. • Hemoglobin genes (HBA2, HBB) in the negatively loaded set likely represent ambient RNA rather than true biological signal.

program_14.description: The gene set reflects an activated, tissue-adapted CD4⁺ regulatory T-cell state (FOXP3⁺ “effector”/tissue Tregs that co-express the Th17-associated factor RORC), typical of barrier tissues such as gut or inflamed mucosa. Evidence: • Core T-cell identity – high CD3E, CD3G, CD2, CD4, CD5, CD6, TRAT1, IL7R. • Regulatory T-cell program – FOXP3, IL2RA (CD25), CTLA4, TNFRSF4 (OX40), TNFRSF25, ICOS, CD82, CCR2; low CCL5 (negative loading) fits non-cytotoxic Tregs. • Effector/tissue adaptation – PPARG, CXCR6, CXCR3, BATF, MAF, IL32, CD40LG, TNF, RUNX2, SPOCK2; these factors are enriched in “effector” or tissue-resident Tregs found in visceral fat and gut. • Th17-skewing within Tregs – RORC together with BATF, IL23-responsive genes (e.g., DUSP16) mark RORγt⁺ Tregs described in intestinal lamina propria. • Activation/adhesion/remodelling genes (VIM, ADAM19, ADAM12, CAPG, COTL1, NCF1) are up, consistent with motile, cytokine-producing Tregs in inflamed tissue. • Negative loading of CCL5 and absence of cytotoxic genes (GZMB, PRF1) argue against cytotoxic CD8⁺ or Th1 effector bias, supporting a regulatory phenotype. Inconsistencies: • VIM, ADAM12/19, HPGD and NCF1 are more common in mesenchymal or myeloid cells, though they can appear in activated T cells; their presence slightly blurs lineage specificity. • PPARG and RUNX2 are not universal Treg markers and may indicate a mixed tissue-remodelling program or contaminating stromal signal.

program_15.description: Gene expression strongly points to connective-tissue / mucosal mast cells that are actively engaged in eicosanoid and prostaglandin metabolism—i.e. an “activated mast-cell” program. Evidence: • Mast-cell signature proteases – TPSAB1 (tryptase) and CPA3 – are highly restricted to mast cells and define their lineage. • RGS13 is a mast-cell-enriched regulator of FcεRI signaling, further anchoring the mast-cell identity. • LTC4S, HPGD and ACSL4 encode key enzymes for leukotriene C₄ synthesis and prostaglandin turnover, typical of mast-cell activation/mediator production. • TMEM176B and VWA5A are expressed in myeloid/secretory immune cells, consistent with mast-cell physiology. Inconsistencies: • GLUL (glutamine synthetase) and VWA5A are not canonical mast-cell markers and are more broadly expressed, but their presence does not contradict a mast-cell program; they may reflect metabolic rewiring rather than lineage specificity.

program_16.description: The program most closely fits a mature, steady-state luminal secretory epithelium of the prostate/seminal-vesicle lineage. Evidence: • MSMB (β-microseminoprotein) – signature secreted product of prostate/seminal-vesicle luminal cells. • AGR2 – ER chaperone strongly enriched in highly secretory prostate epithelium and co-expressed with MSMB. • ALDH1A1 – retinoid-metabolizing enzyme found in prostate luminal/progenitor cells and other glandular epithelia. • SCGB3A1 and CAPS – small secreted/secretoglobin proteins characteristic of mucosal glandular epithelium, consistent with a secretory luminal state. • GSTA1 – detoxification enzyme often co-expressed in prostate and other glandular epithelia with high secretory output. • Negative loading of ZFP36 – reduced immediate-early / inflammatory-stress response, compatible with a quiescent, homeostatic epithelial state. Inconsistencies: • SCGB3A1 and CFAP276 are more commonly reported in airway secretory or ciliated cells, and GSTA1 is classically hepatic; their presence may reflect low-level, shared secretory/ciliary gene expression or minor contamination.

program_17.description: The gene set points to a program characteristic of mature, connective-tissue mast cells undergoing, or poised for, degranulation and lipid-mediator synthesis. Evidence: • Canonical mast-cell granule proteases: TPSAB1 (tryptase α/β) and CPA3 are restricted to mast cells and define their identity. • Mast-cell signaling/regulation: RGS13 is highly enriched in mast cells where it dampens GPCR signaling after activation. • Lipid-mediator synthesis typical of activated mast cells: LTC4S catalyzes leukotriene C₄ production from arachidonic acid. • Additional mast-cell–associated or lysosomal genes: VWA5A and LAPTM4A are expressed in secretory granule/lysosomal compartments; DUSP6 and HPGD participate in MAPK feedback and prostaglandin turnover seen after mast-cell activation. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes conflict with a mast-cell identity; some (VWA5A, DUSP6, LAPTM4A, HPGD) are not mast-cell-specific but are compatible with their physiology and do not contradict the assignment.

program_18.description: The gene set is most consistent with a classical/steady-state macrophage or monocyte program characterized by high complement production and oxidative-burst machinery, indicative of phagocytic innate immune cells poised for microbial killing and tissue surveillance. Evidence: • C1QA, C1QB – Complement C1q subunits abundantly secreted by tissue macrophages and circulating monocytes to initiate the classical complement cascade. • SPI1 (PU.1) – Lineage-defining transcription factor required for monocyte–macrophage differentiation and maintenance. • NCF2 – p67phox component of the NADPH oxidase complex that supports the respiratory burst in macrophages and neutrophils. • CSTA (Cystatin A) – Cysteine protease inhibitor enriched in monocytes/macrophages, linked to regulation of lysosomal cathepsins during phagocytosis. • GPX1, ALDH2 – Enzymes that detoxify reactive oxygen species and aldehydes generated during oxidative burst and inflammatory metabolism, commonly up-regulated in activated macrophages. Inconsistencies: • None evident; all listed genes align with macrophage/monocyte identity and function.

program_19.description: The gene set reflects a generic, highly proliferative cellular state—specifically the S-phase of the cell cycle—rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. The coordinated up-regulation of multiple replication-dependent histone genes (H1 linker histones and H2A core histones) is a hallmark of DNA synthesis, required for rapid nucleosome assembly as newly replicated DNA is packaged. Evidence: • H1-3, H1-4, H1-5, H1-2 – replication-dependent linker histone H1 genes whose transcription peaks in S-phase to meet chromatin assembly demand. • H2AC6, H2AC14, H2AC16 – canonical H2A histone genes likewise transcribed mainly during S-phase for new nucleosome formation. • Concerted induction of multiple histone family members is a well-established signature of cells actively undergoing DNA replication. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes and no contradictory markers are present, so the program is internally consistent with an S-phase proliferation signature.

program_20.description: The program is most consistent with the transcriptional profile of AXL⁺/SIGLEC6⁺ “transitional” dendritic cells (also called AS-DCs), a plasmacytoid-like dendritic-cell subset primed for type I-interferon signaling. Evidence: • IRF7 – master regulator of type I IFN production; highly enriched in plasmacytoid and AXL⁺ transitional DCs. • JCHAIN and SOX4 – co-expressed in AS-DCs and pDCs (rare in classical DCs or monocytes); JCHAIN marks the pDC/AS-DC branch identified by Villani et al., and SOX4 is a key transcription factor for this lineage. • GAS6 – ligand for the AXL receptor that typifies this DC subset; GAS6 production is part of the tolerogenic, interferon-competent AS-DC program. • PPP1R14B – expressed in myeloid-lineage cells, including DCs, and up-regulated in interferon-stimulated states. • APP – broadly expressed secreted/vesicular protein; detected in single-cell profiles of AS-DCs and pDCs and linked to IFN responses. Inconsistencies: • APP and PPP1R14B are not unique to AS-DCs and are expressed in many other cell types, so they provide limited lineage specificity. • Classic surface markers of AS-DCs (AXL, SIGLEC6, IL3RA) are not present in the provided gene list, reducing specificity, but the available genes collectively align best with the transitional/AXL⁺ DC identity.

program_21.description: The gene set most closely matches a generic “house-keeping” program that supports basal RNA processing, vesicle trafficking and mitochondrial ATP production rather than a lineage-restricted cell identity; it is therefore expected to be active at low to moderate levels in many viable, non-cycling cells across tissues. Evidence: • RNA processing / RNA-binding – HNRNPA1L2 (heterogeneous nuclear RNP), ZNF90 (zinc-finger transcription/RNA-binding factor), NACA2 (nascent-polypeptide associated complex subunit‐like) all encode proteins that chaperone nascent transcripts or regulate transcription. • Vesicle/cytoskeletal organization – NBEAL1 (BEACH-domain protein linked to membrane trafficking) and NHSL2 (NHS-like scaffolding protein that binds actin) provide generic secretory and structural support. • Basal energy production – ATP5MGL encodes a subunit of mitochondrial ATP synthase, a core component of oxidative phosphorylation typical of metabolically active but non-specialized cells. Inconsistencies: • No clear inconsistencies; all listed genes are broadly expressed “maintenance” genes rather than markers of a specific differentiated lineage or activation state.

program_22.description: The gene set is most consistent with an NF-κB–driven activation program in peripheral lymphocytes, particularly mature/activated B cells, that is accompanied by cytoskeletal remodeling and endoplasmic-reticulum stress adaptation. Evidence: • Lymphocyte identity/activation – REL (c-Rel, a canonical NF-κB subunit required for antigen-driven B-cell proliferation and cytokine production); LY9/CD229 (SLAM-family immune‐synapse receptor enriched on B and T cells); CD55 (complement-regulatory protein highly expressed on circulating B cells and up-regulated after activation). • Cytoskeletal immune-synapse remodeling – EZR (ezrin, links plasma membrane to F-actin and is recruited to B-cell receptor microclusters during activation). • Stress-adaptation/activation-coupled transcription – HERPUD1 (UPR component induced by ER stress that rises during intense immunoglobulin synthesis in activated B cells); KDM4B (histone demethylase induced by inflammatory cues that promotes NF-κB target-gene expression). Inconsistencies: • No classic, B-cell–restricted surface markers (e.g., CD19, MS4A1) appear in the list, and EZR and HERPUD1 are not lymphoid-specific, so the program may also be shared with activated T/NK cells or other cell types undergoing NF-κB signaling and ER stress.

program_23.description: The gene set represents an NF-κB–driven acute inflammatory activation program typical of stimulated innate immune cells, especially monocytes / macrophages, characterized by robust production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, lipid-metabolizing enzymes and early-response stress genes. Evidence: • Cytokine/chemokine induction (classical NF-κB targets): CXCL8 (IL-8) and IL1B are hallmark products of activated monocytes/macrophages during early inflammatory responses. • Immediate-early NF-κB response genes: IER3 is rapidly induced by TNF-α/IL-1 and LPS in myeloid cells; SOD2 is likewise up-regulated by NF-κB to buffer oxidative stress generated during activation. • Innate immunity lipid mediator enzyme: PLA2G2A is strongly induced by IL-1/TLR signalling in macrophages, supplying arachidonic acid for eicosanoid synthesis. • Additional NF-κB–inducible extracellular matrix–associated gene: MGP can be up-regulated by IL-1β in vascular and myeloid cells during inflammation. Inconsistencies: • MGP is better known for roles in cartilage/vascular cells and is not a canonical monocyte marker, though its inducibility by IL-1 explains its presence. • No classical macrophage lineage markers (e.g., CD68, LYZ) appear, so the program may reflect a general NF-κB inflammatory state rather than a strictly myeloid identity.

program_24.description: The gene set is most consistent with an inflamed, post-capillary/venular endothelial cell program characterized by chemokine secretion and a strong oxidative-/metal-stress response. Evidence: • ACKR1 (DARC) – canonical marker of venular endothelial cells that bind/shape chemokine gradients. • CCL2 – potent monocyte-attracting chemokine released by activated endothelial cells during leukocyte recruitment. • NAMPT – stress-inducible enzyme/cytokine up-regulated in endothelial cells under inflammatory and hypoxic conditions. • MT2A, MT1X – metallothioneins strongly induced in endothelial cells upon oxidative or heavy-metal stress, often concurrent with inflammatory signaling. • Co-occurrence of ACKR1 with CCL2/NAMPT and metallothioneins points to an endothelial, not myeloid, source undergoing inflammatory activation. Inconsistencies: • Metallothioneins and CCL2 can also be produced by myeloid cells, but absence of core myeloid markers (e.g., LYZ, CD68, ITGAM) favors an endothelial interpretation.

program_25.description: The program most closely matches an activated/migratory cytotoxic lymphocyte (CD8⁺ T cell or NK cell) state that is simultaneously up-regulating interferon-responsive antigen-presentation machinery and actin-cytoskeleton remodeling required for target-cell engagement and chemokine release. Evidence: • CCL5 – prototypic chemokine secreted at high levels by activated CD8⁺ T cells and NK cells to recruit additional effector leukocytes. • HLA-B – IFN-I/II–inducible MHC class I molecule; up-regulation is common in activated cytotoxic lymphocytes and facilitates cross-presentation to neighboring cells. • PFN1, CFL1, ACTB – core actin regulators whose coordinated induction accompanies immune-synapse formation and rapid motility of cytotoxic lymphocytes during target seeking. Inconsistencies: • PFN1, ACTB and CFL1 are ubiquitous housekeeping genes, so their presence alone is not lymphocyte-specific. • Classic cytotoxic effector transcripts (e.g., GZMB, PRF1, NKG7) are absent, weakening—but not excluding—the cytotoxic lymphocyte interpretation.

program_26.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, pro-inflammatory monocyte / macrophage program characterized by leukotriene synthesis and immune-modulatory cytokine release. Evidence: • ALOX5AP encodes FLAP, a key co-factor for 5-lipoxygenase and a canonical marker of leukotriene-producing myeloid cells (monocytes, macrophages, neutrophils). • IL32 is a cytokine induced in activated monocytes/macrophages downstream of TNF-α and IFN-γ and amplifies inflammatory signaling. • LGALS1 (Galectin-1) is up-regulated in activated macrophages where it modulates T-cell responses and cytokine secretion. • TMSB4X is abundant in monocytes and supports actin remodeling during phagocytosis and migration, typical of activated myeloid cells. • CD52, although classically associated with lymphocytes, is also expressed on a subset of circulating “CD52^hi” inflammatory monocytes described in human blood. Inconsistencies: • CD52 is more strongly associated with T and B lymphocytes than with myeloid cells; its high loading could reflect some lymphocyte contamination or a mixed leukocyte activation program.

program_27.description: The program reflects conventional αβ T lymphocytes, most consistent with naïve/central-memory CD4⁺ T cells that retain homeostatic IL-7 responsiveness yet show low-level pro-inflammatory priming. Evidence: • T-cell receptor complex genes CD3D and the adhesion/coreceptor CD2 are hallmarks of all mature T cells. • IL7R (CD127) is highly expressed on naïve and central-memory CD4⁺ T cells and is down-regulated on most effector cytotoxic T cells, pointing to a non-cytotoxic, homeostatic phenotype. • IL32, an inducible cytokine commonly produced by activated or memory CD4⁺ T cells, suggests mild inflammatory priming rather than full effector differentiation. • ANXA1 is enriched in activated or memory helper T cells and supports the presence of an immune-regulatory, non-cytotoxic T-cell state. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes align with a naïve/central-memory helper T-cell program.

program_28.description: The gene set points to a vascular endothelial cell program, skewed toward an angiogenic/activated state. Evidence: • EGFL7 – secreted factor highly enriched in sprouting and tumor-associated endothelial cells, driving angiogenesis. • PECAM1 (CD31) – canonical surface marker of vascular endothelial cells and a component of endothelial junctions. • ETS2 – ETS-family transcription factor that, together with ETS1, regulates many endothelial-specific genes during vessel formation. • NHERF2 – scaffold that interacts with VEGFR2 and regulates endothelial barrier and signaling responses. • APP – up-regulated in endothelial cells exposed to shear stress and during neovascularization, supporting an activated vascular phenotype. Inconsistencies: No substantial contradictions; all listed genes can be accommodated within an activated/angiogenic endothelial context.

program_29.description: The program represents an acute NF-κB–driven activation response typical of innate immune cells such as monocytes/macrophages (and, to a lesser extent, other antigen-presenting cells) that have recently encountered inflammatory or toll-like receptor stimuli. Evidence: • REL (c-Rel) – canonical NF-κB transcription factor rapidly induced after TLR/IL-1 signaling in macrophages, driving pro-inflammatory gene expression. • NFKBID (IκBNS) – inducible IκB family member that modulates NF-κB target genes following LPS stimulation in macrophages and dendritic cells. • KDM6B (JMJD3) – histone H3K27 demethylase whose expression is NF-κB-dependent; essential for classically activated (M1) macrophage polarization. • NR4A3 – immediate-early nuclear receptor up-regulated in activated monocytes/macrophages and linked to NF-κB signaling and cytokine production. • Coordinated up-regulation of multiple NF-κB targets without opposing (negatively loaded) anti-inflammatory genes is consistent with an early pro-inflammatory state. Inconsistencies: • REL and NFKBID are also abundant in activated B/T lymphocytes, so the program could, in principle, be shared with lymphoid activation states. • ARL5B is a vesicular trafficking GTPase with no direct link to NF-κB signaling, suggesting a more generic up-regulation of membrane dynamics rather than inflammation per se.

program_30.description: The gene set reflects a Type I/II interferon–induced antiviral program coupled to enhanced autophagy-lysosomal activity, a state commonly detected in epithelial and innate immune cells responding to viral infection. Evidence: • IFITM1 – classical interferon-stimulated gene that restricts viral entry, marking an interferon-activated antiviral state. • GABARAP and ATP6V0C – core autophagy and lysosomal acidification components, respectively; interferon signaling is known to stimulate autophagosome formation and lysosomal degradation as part of host defense. • EEF1G – translation-elongation factor often up-regulated during interferon responses to support synthesis of antiviral effectors. • GRINA (LFG1) – anti-apoptotic/stress-protection protein induced by interferon and ER stress, helping cells survive during antiviral defense. Inconsistencies: No strongly discordant genes are present in this limited list.

program_31.description: The five genes up-weighted in this program do not converge on a single lineage-defining marker set; instead they point to a broad, housekeeping/metabolic state that many cell types adopt when maintaining cytoskeletal dynamics, glycoprotein synthesis and glycogen turnover. Such a transcriptomic pattern is therefore most consistent with a generic “basal metabolic/secretory” program rather than a distinct, lineage-restricted cell identity. Evidence: • HNRNPH1 – ubiquitous RNA-binding protein that supports constitutive and alternative pre-mRNA splicing in virtually all cell types. • CDC42SE1 – effector of the small GTPase CDC42 that regulates actin remodeling and membrane dynamics, processes required across diverse cell populations. • B4GALT1 – Golgi β-1,4-galactosyltransferase essential for N- and O-linked glycoprotein synthesis; expression is common to many metabolically active or secretory cells. • PHKG1 – catalytic γ-subunit of phosphorylase kinase that initiates glycogen breakdown, indicating generic energy-mobilizing activity rather than a lineage-specific trait. • C1orf56 – poorly characterized but reported as broadly expressed; no evidence for strict lineage restriction. Inconsistencies: No clear lineage-specific or state-specific markers (e.g., immune, epithelial, neuronal, muscle) appear, and no negatively loaded genes refine the interpretation, underscoring the nonspecific, housekeeping nature of the program.

program_32.description: The gene set represents an acute cellular stress / immediate-early response program that can be transiently activated in many cell types upon MAPK signaling, heat shock, oxidative stress or inflammatory cues, rather than a lineage-restricted identity. Evidence: • DUSP1 and GADD45B – classical MAPK pathway–inducible phosphatase and DNA-damage/oxidative-stress mediator, rapidly up-regulated within minutes of stress. • HSP90AA1 and BAG3 – molecular chaperone and co-chaperone induced by heat shock/unfolded-protein stress to refold or clear damaged proteins. • RHOB – small GTPase whose expression rises after genotoxic or cytokine stress and participates in cytoskeletal remodeling during damage responses. Inconsistencies: • No prominent inconsistencies; all listed genes are concordant with a generalized stress-response state.

program_33.description: The gene set reflects a generic, acute cellular stress/heat-shock response program rather than a lineage-specific identity; it captures cells that have recently experienced proteotoxic or other environmental stress and have activated chaperone-mediated cytoprotection and immediate-early transcriptional responses. Evidence: • HSPA1A (HSP70) and HSPB1 (HSP27) are canonical heat-shock proteins transcriptionally induced by HSF1 to refold or triage misfolded proteins during proteotoxic stress. • BAG3 partners with HSP70/HSC70 to promote selective autophagy of damaged proteins and is a hallmark of the heat-shock/proteostasis response. • RHOB is rapidly up-regulated by UV, heat, and genotoxic stress and modulates actin cytoskeleton and stress-induced apoptosis. • EGR1 is an immediate-early gene activated within minutes of diverse stresses (heat, hypoxia, oxidative stress) and coordinates downstream adaptive transcription. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes were provided; no major inconsistencies detected.

program_34.description: The gene set is most consistent with an NF-κB–driven, pro-inflammatory activation program in monocytes/macrophages (classically referred to as “M1-like” inflammatory macrophages) characterized by high chemokine production and enhanced survival signaling. Evidence: • CXCL8 (IL-8) – hallmark chemokine secreted by activated monocytes/macrophages to recruit neutrophils. • CXCL16 – chemokine/scavenger receptor up-regulated in inflammatory macrophages and dendritic cells, promoting T-cell recruitment. • PLAUR – urokinase receptor induced by LPS/TNF-α in monocytes/macrophages, facilitating pericellular proteolysis and cell migration during inflammation. • BCL2A1 – anti-apoptotic gene directly induced by NF-κB in activated myeloid cells, supporting survival amid inflammatory stress. • C15orf48 (NMES1) – strongly induced by IFN-γ or TLR ligands in macrophages, marking classical activation. Inconsistencies: No clear contradictions; all listed genes fit an NF-κB–dependent inflammatory myeloid activation signature.

program_35.description: The program most closely matches an activated/effector Th17 (RORγt⁺ CCR6⁺) CD4⁺ T-cell state that produces the chemokine CCL20 and expresses immunomodulatory molecules typical of tissue-infiltrating Th17 cells. Evidence: • RORC (encoding RORγt) – lineage-defining transcription factor required for Th17 differentiation. • CCR6 and its ligand CCL20 – canonical receptor/chemokine pair highly enriched in human and mouse Th17 cells and used to isolate circulating and tissue Th17 populations. • IL4I1 – oxidase induced during Th17 polarization and detected in RORγt⁺ effector T cells, contributing to local immunomodulation. • TNFRSF25 (DR3) – costimulatory death-receptor super-family member up-regulated on activated effector Th17 (and Treg) cells, enhancing IL-17 responses in inflammation. Inconsistencies: • IL4I1 and TNFRSF25 are also expressed by certain antigen-presenting cells or Treg/Th2 subsets, but their co-occurrence with RORC, CCR6 and CCL20 collectively favors a Th17 assignment.

program_36.description: The gene set most strongly matches a tissue-resident cytotoxic lymphocyte program—characteristic of CD8⁺ tissue-resident memory T cells (TRM) and related NK-like innate lymphocytes—marked by HOBIT (ZNF683)–driven residency and NKG2 receptor expression, with one keratin gene (KRT86) likely reflecting ambient RNA or doublets rather than the core program. Evidence: • ZNF683 (HOBIT) – master transcription factor that enforces tissue residency in CD8⁺ TRM and some tissue-resident NK cells. • KLRC1 (NKG2A) & KLRC2 (NKG2C) – inhibitory/activating C-type lectin receptors expressed on NK cells and TRM-like cytotoxic T cells, supporting an NK/effector cytotoxic phenotype. • CD63 – tetraspanin up-regulated during granule exocytosis in activated cytotoxic T and NK cells, fitting an effector cytotoxic state. Inconsistencies: • KRT86 – hair follicle keratin; not typically expressed in lymphocytes, suggesting contamination or a doublet rather than a feature of the core program.

program_37.description: The program most closely fits a naïve/resting T-cell (and related innate lymphoid cell) state characterized by dependence on IL-7 and IL-6–family cytokine signaling, basal protein-synthesis activity, and absence of the phagocyte NADPH-oxidase machinery. Evidence: • IL7R⁺ – hallmark receptor of naïve and memory T cells and many ILCs; essential for lymphoid survival and homeostasis. • IL6ST (gp130)⁺ – shared signal-transducing subunit for IL-6 family cytokines, broadly up-regulated in lymphocytes, reinforcing a cytokine-responsive lymphoid phenotype. • CYBA⁻ – CYBA encodes the p22^phox subunit of the NADPH oxidase complex highly expressed in neutrophils/monocytes; its depletion supports a non-myeloid, lymphoid identity. • TPT1⁺ and EEF1A1⁺ – ubiquitous translation/elongation factors indicating basal protein-synthesis capacity typical of viable but non-activated (quiescent) lymphocytes rather than highly proliferative or effector cells. Inconsistencies: • IL6ST is not strictly T-cell specific and can be found in many tissues; however, in conjunction with strong IL7R expression and CYBA depletion, the overall signature still favors a naïve/resting lymphoid cell identity.

program_38.description: The gene set is most consistent with a quiescent naïve/central-memory T-cell program. Evidence: • LEF1 – lineage-defining WNT-responsive transcription factor highly expressed in naïve CD4⁺ and CD8⁺ T cells and central memory T cells, but down-regulated in effector states. • SELL (CD62L) – lymph-node-homing receptor characteristic of naïve and central-memory T cells; lost on effector/effector-memory subsets. • TMEM123 and SH3YL1 – repeatedly found enriched in scRNA-seq naïve/early-memory T-cell clusters and low in differentiated cytotoxic T cells, supporting a resting T-cell phenotype. • Absence of cytotoxic/activation markers (e.g., GZMB, PRF1, IFNG) further points to a non-effector, resting T-cell state. Inconsistencies: • FHIT and SH3YL1 are not T-cell-specific and are expressed more broadly, but they do not contradict a naïve/central-memory T-cell identity.

program_39.description: The gene set strongly reflects an activated regulatory T-cell (Treg) program. Evidence: • FOXP3 – lineage-defining transcription factor for regulatory T cells. • IL2RA (CD25) – constitutively high on Tregs and further up-regulated upon activation. • TNFRSF4 (OX40) – co-stimulatory receptor induced on activated/effector Tregs. • RTKN2 – Rho-GTPase effector enriched in CD4⁺ T cells and required for Treg survival and suppressive function. • TBC1D4 – expressed in resting and activated CD4⁺ T cells, including Tregs, and linked to IL-2 signaling, consistent with IL2RA elevation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are compatible with an activated Treg identity.

program_40.description: The program reflects a generic S-phase/proliferation signature rather than a lineage-restricted cell type: cells actively synthesizing DNA up-regulate replication-dependent core histone genes (H2A and H2B variants) to package newly replicated chromatin. Evidence: • H2AC6, H2AC11, H2AC16 – replication-dependent H2A genes whose mRNA levels peak during S phase to supply histone proteins for newly synthesized DNA. • H2BC4, H2BC7 – replication-dependent H2B genes co-regulated with H2A genes and similarly maximally expressed in proliferating cells. • Concerted up-regulation of multiple replication-coupled histone genes is a canonical hallmark of cycling cells in single-cell RNA-seq datasets. Inconsistencies: No obvious inconsistencies; all detected genes align with an S-phase histone expression program.

program_41.description: The gene set represents a canonical type I interferon–stimulated gene (ISG) program reflecting cells in an antiviral/interferon-activated state rather than a specific lineage; it can be induced in virtually any nucleated cell exposed to IFN-α/β. Evidence: • IFI6, IFI44L – Classical ISGs up-regulated upon IFN-α/β signaling, mediating antiviral defense. • ISG15 – Ubiquitin-like modifier strongly induced by type I IFNs; marks cells mounting antiviral responses. • MX1 – Dynamin-like GTPase that blocks viral replication; hallmark of interferon activation. • OAS3 – 2´-5´-oligoadenylate synthetase family member activated by type I IFNs to trigger RNase L–mediated viral RNA degradation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are core ISGs consistent with an interferon-responsive cellular state.

program_42.description: The program most closely reflects an alternatively-activated (M2/repair) macrophage state characterized by PPARG-driven lipid handling and Galectin-3/S100 family–mediated tissue-repair functions. Evidence: • PPARG – master transcription factor for lipid uptake and oxidative metabolism in M2 macrophages; its activation is required for IL-4–induced alternative polarization. • LGALS3 (Galectin-3) – highly expressed in wound-healing and profibrotic macrophages, promoting phagocytosis and extracellular matrix remodeling. • S100A10 & S100A11 – components of the Annexin A2/S100A10 complex enriched in anti-inflammatory macrophages, facilitating plasmin generation and tissue repair. • S100A6 – calcium-binding protein up-regulated during macrophage activation and stress responses, frequently co-expressed with other S100 family members in M2 cells. Inconsistencies: • PPARG and S100A10 are also abundant in adipocytes and certain stromal cells, so without additional lineage markers the program could partially overlap with adipogenic or fibroblast signatures; however, the concurrent presence of LGALS3 and multiple S100 proteins is more typical of macrophages than of adipocytes.

program_43.description: The program is characteristic of lung alveolar type II (AT2) epithelial cells in a surfactant-producing, homeostatic/secretory state. Evidence: • Surfactant genes SFTPC, SFTPA1 and SFTPB are canonical markers uniquely and abundantly expressed by AT2 cells, encoding core components of pulmonary surfactant. • NAPSA (napsin A) is an aspartic protease highly enriched in AT2 cells where it processes surfactant proteins. • PGC (pepsinogen C) is co-expressed with NAPSA in AT2 cells and lung adenocarcinoma of AT2 origin, reflecting the proteolytic machinery linked to surfactant maturation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes align with an AT2 surfactant program.

program_44.description: The gene program strongly reflects mature alveolar type II (AT2) epithelial cells in the lung that are actively producing pulmonary surfactant. Evidence: • Surfactant proteins – SFTPA1, SFTPA2, and SFTPB are hallmark secreted components of pulmonary surfactant and are highly enriched in AT2 cells. • NAPSA (Napsin A) is a lysosomal aspartic protease required for processing pro-SFTPB to its active form and is routinely used as an immunohistochemical marker of AT2 cells. • SERPINA1 (α1-antitrypsin) is expressed in AT2 cells where it counters neutrophil elastase, preserving alveolar integrity. Inconsistencies: • SERPINA1 is classically abundant in hepatocytes; however, its documented expression in AT2 cells aligns with the overall program, so no major discordant genes are present.

program_0.description: This gene program is most consistent with an activated cytotoxic lymphocyte state—i.e. CD8⁺ T cells / NK cells that are producing granzymes, perforin and multiple chemokines in response to inflammatory / interferon cues. Evidence: • Cytotoxic effector machinery: PRF1, GNLY, NKG7, GZMB/GZMA/GZMH/GZMM, FGFBP2, CTSW support CD8⁺ T or NK cell cytotoxicity. • T-cell/NK identity genes: CD3D/E/G, CD2, CD7, CD247, IL2RG, CD8A, KLRD1, KLRB1, KLRF1, CLEC2B, RHOH, LCP2, ZEB2, ETS1 indicate TCR-bearing cytotoxic lymphocytes. • Activation / trafficking signals: CCL3, CCL4, CCL5, CXCR4, CD69, ITGAX, SELPLG, GPR183 mark recently activated, tissue-homing lymphocytes. • Interferon / inflammatory response: ISG15, IFI6, IFI16, OAS1/2, APOBEC3G, ISG20, IRAK3, TNFAIP3, IL1B demonstrate exposure to type-I/II IFN and NF-κB signalling—typical of activated effector T/NK cells in inflamed tissues. • Broad leukocyte markers with low metabolic genes: PTPRC, CORO1A, LCP1 are high, while metabolic genes (NNMT, NPC2, DBI, PPP1R1C) are specifically repressed, matching lymphocyte rather than parenchymal programs. Inconsistencies: • Numerous myeloid genes (CD14, FCGR3A, CD163, MRC1, CSF1R, VCAN, S100A12, CLEC4E, TREM1/2) and a few B-cell/plasma genes (CD79A, JCHAIN, MZB1) appear, suggesting some contamination, doublets or that the program was extracted across mixed immune populations. • Macrophage lipid-handling genes (FABP4, AQP9, OLR1) are atypical for pure cytotoxic lymphocytes. • SPI1 (PU.1) and IRF8 are myeloid-lineage transcription factors not usually expressed in mature T/NK cells. Overall, despite these myeloid-associated transcripts, the dominant and functionally coherent signature is that of highly activated cytotoxic T/NK cells engaged in inflammatory responses.

program_1.description: The gene pattern points to vascular endothelial cells that are undergoing, or have recently undergone, endothelial-to-mesenchymal activation/transition (EndMT), acquiring a myofibroblast-like, extracellular-matrix-producing phenotype often seen in fibrotic or wound-healing settings. Evidence: • Classical endothelial genes retained: PECAM1, VWF, ENG, ACVRL1, CD93, HEG1, ACKR1, RAMP2/3 – indicate an endothelial lineage origin. • Strong induction of mesenchymal / myofibroblast genes: ACTA2, TAGLN, TPM1/2, SERPINH1, CCN1/2, AEBP1, PRSS23, FBLN5, THBS1 – hallmarks of EndMT‐derived myofibroblasts. • Abundant ECM-remodelling and collagen genes: COL1A1/1A2/3A1/5A1/6A1-3, FN1, VCAN, ELN, SPARC, SERPINF1, MMP2, MMP14, TIMP2, PCOLCE – typical of fibroblast-like matrix producers. • Pro-angiogenic / hypoxia-responsive factors (DDIT4, EPAS1, CXCL14, IL6, PTX3) and vascular guidance cues (SLIT2, SEMA3C, EGFL7) further fit an activated endothelial–mesenchymal state. • Negative loading of canonical alveolar type-II epithelial markers (SLC34A2, LPCAT1, SFTPD, SFTA2) and AQP3/1 underscores that the program is specific to mesenchymalising endothelial cells rather than epithelial cells. Inconsistencies: • Low-level epithelial/basal genes (KRT15, KRT17, MUC4, MUC5B) and immune genes (CD79A, JCHAIN) are present but weak; they may reflect ambient RNA or rare doublets rather than the core program.

program_2.description: The gene set describes airway epithelial cells that are engaged in the motile‐cilia differentiation program (FOXJ1⁺/RFX3⁺ ciliogenesis) and simultaneously repressing an alveolar/secretory (SLC34A2⁺/SFTA2⁺) signature, consistent with mature or maturing multiciliated airway cells. Evidence: • Motile cilia structural genes: DNAH5/7/9/10/11/12, DNAAF1/3/4, CFAP43/44/45/53/95, RSPH1/4A/9, TEKT2, MNS1, IFT22/25/27/172, DYNC2H1 – core components of axoneme, dynein arms and intraflagellar transport required for motility. • Ciliogenesis transcription factors/regulators: FOXJ1, RFX3, SOX2, HES1, NEK5/10, STK33 – canonical drivers of multiciliogenesis. • Airway ciliated cell surface/adhesion genes: CDHR3, CDHR4, LRRC46, CFAP126, BPIFB1 – enriched in respiratory multiciliated cells. • Suppressed alveolar/secretory programme: negative loadings for SLC34A2, SFTA2, LAMP3, AZGP1, NOTUM, APOA1 and PLA2G1B, all characteristic of alveolar type II or club/secretory cells, indicating a mutually exclusive state. Inconsistencies: • Secretory/goblet cell products (MUC4, MUC20, CEACAM5, SCGB3A2) appear positively loaded, suggesting some cells may be transitional or mixed secretory–ciliated phenotypes. • GNLY (cytotoxic lymphocyte marker) and HLA-DOB (antigen presentation) are unexpected in epithelial cells but are few and do not dominate the signature.

program_3.description: The gene set represents a generic “cycling-cell” program marking cells that are in late S-phase through G2/M, independent of lineage. The overwhelming enrichment for DNA-replication factors, mitotic kinases, centromere/kinetochore components and chromosome-segregation proteins typifies actively dividing cells rather than a differentiated lineage-specific state.
