Evidence: • DNA replication licensing/elongation – MCM2-8, ORC6, CDT1, PCNA, POLE/POLE2, PRIM1/2, RFC2-5, RPA‐related genes indicate S-phase progression. • G2/M cell-cycle regulators – CCNB1, CCNB2, CCNA2, CDK2, CDC20, CDC25A, PLK1, AURKA/B, PKMYT1 denote activation of the mitotic kinase cascade. • Chromosome condensation & segregation – NCAPG, NCAPD2/3, SMC2, ESCO2, TOP2A, BIRC5 (Survivin), CENPA/H/K/M/P/PX/PP, KNL1, SGO1/2, BUB1, ZWILCH, SPDL1 support mitotic chromosomal architecture and spindle-assembly checkpoint activity. • Mitotic spindle & cytokinesis – KIF11, KIF20A/B, KIF23, TPX2, TACC3, PRC1, CEP55, ANLN, RACGAP1, HMMR encode microtubule motors or cytokinetic ring components characteristic of G2/M. • DNA repair/replication stress response – BRCA1/2, RAD51, CHEK1, FANCA/B/C/D2/I/G, CLSPN, RECQL4 reflect heightened homologous-recombination and checkpoint signaling typical of proliferating cells. • Proliferation markers – MKI67, UBE2C, PCLAF, FOXM1, MYBL2, DEPDC1 are classical signatures of actively cycling cells. Inconsistencies: • A few lineage-biased or secretory genes (NMU, AGR2, MELTF, LDHA, DMBT1) are present but constitute a small minority and do not counter the dominant cell-cycle signal.

program_4.description: The gene-expression program is most consistent with the “damage-associated / KRT17⁺ transitional alveolar epithelial cell” state that appears when alveolar type II (AT2) pneumocytes exit their surfactant-producing identity and begin converting into squamous type I (AT1) cells after injury or infection. The program shows simultaneous acquisition of AT1 markers and stress / interferon signals while surfactant and other AT2 genes are actively repressed. Evidence: • Gain of transitional–epithelial / stress markers (positively loaded): TACSTD2 (EpCAM), CLDN3/4, KRT17, KRT19, AGR3, MSLN, CEACAM5, SOX4, S100A2 – all enriched in the KRT8⁺/CLDN4⁺ transitional cells reported in injured human and mouse lung. • Emergence of AT1-like genes (positively loaded): AQP5, PDPN, HOPX, CX3CL1, CAVIN2 indicate movement toward a type I phenotype. • Strong interferon- or injury-response signature (positively loaded): IFI27, IFI6, OAS1, BST2, GBP1, GBP4, LY6E, ISG15-family genes, consistent with cells responding to viral or inflammatory damage. • Loss of canonical AT2 genes (negatively loaded): SFTPA2, SFTPD, ABCA3, NAPSA, MFSD2A, LAMP3, HHIP, SFTA2 – hallmark of departure from the surfactant-producing AT2 identity. • Additional epithelial/ion-transport genes (SCNN1B/G, GPRC5A, CLDN1, ITGB4) match published profiles of transitional alveolar cells that retain partial secretory programs during conversion. Inconsistencies: • Some airway/secretory-cell markers (SOX2, SCGB3A1/3A2, BPIFB1, MUC4, MUC20) are more typical of proximal airway epithelium, suggesting either heterogeneity within the program or partial overlap with airway secretory states. • CLDN5, an endothelial marker, is mildly up-weighted, though likely reflects low-level contamination or co-expression rather than a true endothelial program.

program_5.description: The gene set is most consistent with a lung epithelial “damage-associated transitional”/basaloid program (also called KRT8⁺/KRT17⁺ alveolar transitional or PATS/DATP cells) that emerges after injury and lies between alveolar type II and mature type I epithelium, marked by mixed AT1 genes and epithelial-basal/EMT-like, interferon-stimulated and stress-response signatures. Evidence: • Mixed alveolar type I / epithelial markers: PDPN, AQP5, CA4, HOPX, ITGB4, CLDN3, EPCAM-related TACSTD2, KRT8/18/19/17/4/6A/13, CD24. • Basaloid / transitional injury markers described in human and mouse lung regeneration: KRT17, TACSTD2 (TROP-2), LGALS3, CXCL14, MSLN, DKK1/3, MMP7, COL4A2, FSTL3, GAS6, LAMC2, LBH. • Interferon- and stress-response genes typical of injured transitional cells: IFI27, LY6E, BST2, ISG20, IFIT2, MX2, GBP1/4, XAF1, IL18BP. • Actin-myosin/contractile and partial EMT components seen in basaloid states: TAGLN, TAGLN2, MYL6, MYL12A/B, TNNC1/2, TPM4, PALLD, PDLIM4. • Down-loading of canonical AT2 marker SFTPA2 supports a shift away from mature surfactant-secreting alveolar type II identity toward the transitional state. Inconsistencies: • Endothelial/vascular genes (CLEC14A, ECSCR, ICAM2, ACKR1, CD93) and urothelial-associated UPK3B are atypical for lung epithelium, suggesting some contamination or shared stress-induced expression. • Limited cell-cycle signal (e.g., CCNB1) hints at proliferative cells, but most basaloid programs are largely non-cycling.

program_6.description: The gene set represents an inflammatory-stress program in alveolar type II (AT2) epithelial cells, characterised by strong NF-κB / AP-1 immediate-early activation and simultaneous suppression of oxidative-phosphorylation transcripts, typical of AT2 cells exposed to pro-inflammatory cues such as TNF-α or IL-1β. Evidence: • AT2 lineage genes: SFTPD, NAPSA, HBEGF, CLDN4, KRT8/KRT78, CDH16 and epithelial tight-junction component CLDN4 point to lung (distal airway/alveolar) epithelium, especially AT2 cells that co-express SFTPD and NAPSA. • Inflammatory / NF-κB–AP-1 response: NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, TNFAIP3, IRF1, SOCS3, CXCL2, CXCL3, IL6, ICAM1/4, CD83, ZC3H12A, HMOX1, FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB, ATF3, EGR1/2, BHLHE40, NR4A1/2/3 and many other immediate-early genes are hallmarks of acute cytokine or LPS stimulation. • Stress-adaptation & survival: MCL1, HSPA1B, HSPB1, DNAJB1/4, HSPA2, HSP90AB1, GADD45B, TIPARP, KLF4/6, CEBPB/D support a cytoprotective, stress-tolerant state often seen in activated epithelial cells. • Metabolic shift: negative loading of multiple ETC / OXPHOS components (COX7A2, COX6C, UQCRQ, UQCRB, NDUFA1, ATP5MJ, HSPE1, HSPD1) reflects down-regulated mitochondrial respiration frequently accompanying inflammatory re-programming. Inconsistencies: • Immune-cell-biased transcripts such as LAG3 (T-cell), MAFB (monocyte/macrophage) and CD83 (dendritic) appear but can be low-level “leakage” or reflect paracrine signalling; they are not dominant in the program. • Presence of UTY, DDX3Y, EIF1AY indicates male-donor Y-chromosome expression, unrelated to the program’s functional theme.

program_7.description: The gene set is most consistent with airway/alveolar epithelial cells that have entered an IFN-γ–driven, injury-associated “activated/transitional” state characterized by strong antigen-presentation capacity and broad inflammatory signalling, while lipid/surfactant metabolism typical of homeostatic type II cells is suppressed. Evidence: • Epithelial/airway identity – CLDN4, PDPN, SCGB3A2, WFDC2, SLPI, BPIFA2, AQP3, SUSD2, BCAM mark secretory and distal airway/alveolar epithelium. • Transitional/injury programme – ALPL and CLDN4 are canonical markers of the KRT8⁺ injury-induced alveolar transitional population (also called DATP/PATS) that emerges after epithelial damage. • Interferon / inflammatory activation – IFITM1/2/3, ID3, TNFSF10, TNFSF13, CSF2, C4A, C4B, CFB, RAMP1/3, MIF, S100A11/12 denote a robust IFN and cytokine response. • Inducible MHC-II expression – HLA-DRB1/5, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DQA2, HLA-DQB2, IFI30 show epithelial up-regulation of class II antigen presentation typical of IFN-γ exposure. • Metabolic shift away from surfactant/lipid synthesis – negative loading of SFTPD together with cholesterol biosynthesis genes (HMGCS1, HMGCR, MSMO1, INSIG1, PCSK9) indicates down-regulated lipid production, consistent with epithelial cells transitioning away from surfactant-producing type II identity. Inconsistencies: • S100A12 is more typical of neutrophils, and TNFSF13 is classically B-cell related, but both can be ectopically induced in inflamed epithelium. • PDPN is also expressed by lymphatic endothelial cells; however, its co-expression with epithelial-specific genes argues for an epithelial rather than endothelial source.

program_8.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with an acutely injured / inflammatory epithelial program in which differentiated secretory-type epithelial cells (e.g. alveolar/airway or other mucosal epithelium) shut down their homeostatic identity and enter a stress-, EGFR- and NF-κB–driven wound-repair state that includes partial EMT, hypoxic metabolism, cytokine production and cell-cycle arrest. Evidence: • EGFR / MAPK activation – AREG, HBEGF, ERRFI1, MYC, CCND1, FOSL1, JUND, ETS2. • NF-κB / acute inflammatory response – CXCL8 (IL-8), CCL20, TNFAIP3, ICAM1, PTX3, LIF, TNFRSF12A, TNFRSF21, SOCS2/3, CX3CL1. • Stress-, DNA-damage- and apoptosis-related genes – CDKN1A (p21), GADD45A, DDIT3, PMAIP1, BAX, HMOX1, FDXR, BBC3, STK17A. • Wound-healing / partial EMT and motility – TM4SF1, VMP1, ITGA2, CLDN1, EZR, S100A16, ANGPTL4, RHOF, RND3, THBS1. • Hypoxia / metabolic rewiring – PFKFB3, PHGDH, SQLE, ADM2, CYGB, GFPT1, SLC1A5, SLC7A5. • Suppression of mature secretory-epithelial identity (negatively loaded) – SFTPD, MUC1, CLDN18, CLDN4, CA2, PLA2G1B, SLPI, CYB5A, indicating loss of normal differentiated function as cells adopt the injury program. Inconsistencies: • A few transcripts typical of other cell types appear at low level (HBA1/HBA2/HBB – erythroid; JCHAIN – plasma cell; BATF – lymphoid), suggesting minor ambient RNA or doublets rather than a true component of the program.

program_9.description: The gene set represents an airway/alveolar epithelial-cell inflammatory program driven by NF-κB / IL-17 / TNF signaling, typical of type II pneumocytes or secretory airway cells that have been exposed to pro-inflammatory cytokines or microbial products. These epithelial cells up-regulate chemokines that recruit neutrophils and monocytes, express class II MHC and other antigen-presentation machinery, and transiently repress lipid-metabolic genes characteristic of the resting surfactant-producing state. Evidence: • Pro-inflammatory chemokines/cytokines (CXCL8/IL8, CXCL1, CXCL2, CXCL3, CCL2, CCL20, CSF3, IL6, LIF, TNFSF10) – hallmark of NF-κB–activated epithelium recruiting neutrophils and monocytes. • Canonical NF-κB regulators and targets (NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, REL, RELB, NFKB2, TNFAIP3, ICAM1, ICAM4, ICAM5, BIRC3) – indicates strong NF-κB / TNF signaling. • IL-17–responsive epithelial defence genes (DEFB4A, SLC6A14, MMP25, ZC3H12A, CEBPB/CEBPD, ZFP36) – consistent with airway epithelium stimulated by IL-17/TNF. • Lung/airway epithelial structural or secretory markers (SFTPA2, SFTPD, CLDN18, CLDN1, SCGB3A1, SCGB3A2, BPIFA2, CXCL17, TMEM178A, CA1) – identify the cell of origin as alveolar/bronchiolar epithelium rather than immune cells. • IFN-γ–inducible antigen-presentation genes (HLA-DRA, DRB1, DPB1, CD83) – epithelium acquiring antigen-presenting capability during inflammation. • Negative loading of lipid-metabolic genes typical of resting AT2 cells (SCD, CYB5A, LSS, ME3) – shows shift away from surfactant/lipid synthesis toward defence. Inconsistencies: • Hemoglobin gene HBB and erythroid regulator BPGM likely derive from ambient RNA or minor erythrocyte contamination. • STAT4 and CSF1/CSF3 are more typical of immune cells, but can be epithelial NF-κB targets; their presence is therefore not strongly discordant but worth noting. • A2M down-regulation (negative loading) is usually acute-phase up-regulated in hepatocytes; its repression here is not readily explained by the epithelial inflammatory model.

program_10.description: The gene set points to epithelial cells—most consistent with lung/airway or serosal epithelium—that have attenuated their normal secretory identity (loss of AZGP1, NPC2) and switched on a contractile, extracellular-matrix-producing programme (TAGLN, COL4A1/2, SPARC, TGFBI, PDPN). This is characteristic of an epithelial-to-mesenchymal–like, injury- or fibrosis-associated “transitional” state sometimes described as EMT- or basal-intermediate alveolar epithelium. Evidence: • Epithelial identity retained: KRT19, KRT15, KRT80, TACSTD2 (TROP2), CLDN18, GPRC5A. • Mesenchymal/contractile activation: TAGLN, TNNC1, MYL6, MYL12A/B, ACTG1, NEXN, ABLIM1. • ECM deposition/remodelling: COL4A1/2/3, COL12A1, COL8A1, LAMA3, LAMC2, SPARC, EFEMP1, TGFBI, MMP23B, TIMP2, FSTL1/3, DKK3. • Injury/fibrosis signalling & EMT regulators: PDPN, HOPX, RND3, TNFRSF12A (Fn14), ICAM1, RGCC, AHNAK, VSIR, IL32. • Loss of mature secretory/alveolar markers (negatively loaded): AZGP1, NPC2. Inconsistencies: • A few neural–associated genes (MAP2, BDNF) and mast-cell proteases (CPA3, TPSB2) appear, but they are numerically minor and could arise from ambient RNA or low-level co-expression during stress responses.

program_11.description: The gene set depicts a lung epithelial program—principally secretory / alveolar type-II–like cells—that have been licensed by inflammatory cytokines (e.g. IFN-γ) to act as non-professional antigen-presenting cells, simultaneously producing multiple neutrophil- and myeloid-recruiting chemokines. Evidence: • Epithelial / secretory identity – SFTPD, NAPSA, SCGB3A1, SCGB3A2, FOLR1, AGR2/AGR3, AZGP1, EPHX1, NOTUM and NKX2-8 are classical markers of airway club / goblet cells or alveolar type-II pneumocytes. • Antigen-presentation module – Very strong up-regulation of MHC-II genes (HLA-DRA, DRB1/5, DPA1/B1, DQA2, DQB1/2, DMA/B, DOA/B) together with MHC-I genes (HLA-A, ‑C, ‑F) indicates acquisition of an antigen-presenting phenotype. • Inflammatory signalling – GBP4, TNFSF10, CSF2, CSF3, CXCL1/2/3/17 and RND1 are canonical IFN-γ or NF-κB targets produced by epithelial cells during acute inflammation. • Secretory stress / UPR – XBP1 and SELENBP1 support a highly secretory, ER-stressed epithelial state. • Loss of AT-I / proliferative signatures – Negative loading of HOPX (alveolar type-I marker) and of cell-cycle–associated genes (DONSON, TACC2, DSTN, TPT1, S100A6) indicates differentiated, non-cycling cells rather than proliferative or type-I pneumocytes. Inconsistencies: • Myeloid-associated transcripts (AOAH, NCF4, GPR34) could reflect low-level contamination or shared inflammatory pathways. • Presence of basal-cell marker TP63 suggests a mixed epithelial population or transient basal-to-secretory differentiation state.

program_12.description: This program is most consistent with metabolically active, quiescent lung fibroblasts (or other mesenchymal stromal cells) that are rich in oxidative-phosphorylation, RNA-processing and retinoic-acid–synthesis machinery and that conspicuously lack the gene set typical of alveolar type II epithelial cells and antigen-presenting/inflamed states. Evidence: • Fibroblast / stromal markers present: ALDH1A2 (retinoic-acid–producing fibroblasts), COCH and B3GAT2 (recently described COCH+ / matrix-producing lung fibroblast subset). • High oxidative-phosphorylation and mitochondrial genes (ATP5ME, ATP5MGL, MICOS10, NDUFB1, UQCRHL) together with RNA-processing factors (PABPC3/4, HNRNPH1, RBMX, EIF5AL1, NAP1L1, FCF1) indicate a housekeeping, energy-intense but non-proliferative mesenchymal state. • Absence/negative loading of canonical alveolar type II epithelial genes: NAPSA, FOLR1, MALL, CD9, MMP7, SELENBP1, CYB5A, EPHX1. • Negative loading of MHC-II and immune-activation genes (HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPA1, CD83, CSF2, CXCL3, JUNB, NR4A1) argues against an activated antigen-presenting or inflammatory state and supports a quiescent stromal phenotype. Inconsistencies: • Lack of strong collagen (COL1A1/2) expression that often accompanies fibroblast programs. • DONSON and DSTN are more typical of cycling or cytoskeletal-remodelling cells, though they can be expressed at lower levels in resting fibroblasts.

program_13.description: The gene set fits a mature alveolar type II (AT2) epithelial program characterised by active secretion of surfactant/antimicrobial factors and paracrine signalling that modulates local immunity and coagulation within the distal lung. Evidence: • Classical AT2 / distal‐lung epithelial markers: SFTPD, NAPSA, CLDN18-2, NOTUM, HHIP, C16orf89, TMED6, WIF1 • Surfactant-/lipid-associated secretory genes produced by AT2 cells: AZGP1, APOA1, APOH, CPB2, PLA2G1B, RNASE1, TFPI, FGG • Oxidative-stress and lysosomal enzymes typical of AT2 cells with high secretory turnover: CAT, ASAH1, CTSH, BMP1, CA2 • Paracrine/immune modulators known to be released by AT2 cells: CSF2 (GM-CSF), EDIL3, CHI3L2, ECM1 • General epithelial/secretory machinery: DBI, FMO5, PGC, GNAS, MYLK, CACNA2D2 Inconsistencies: • Muscle/contractile genes (TTN, PDLIM3, MYLK) and endocrine enzymes (PCSK2, REN) are atypical for AT2 cells. • Liver‐biased plasma proteins (FGG, APOH) and neutrophil marker CEACAM4 are not classical epithelial markers but can appear in secretory epithelial programmes or reflect ambient RNA. • Negatively loaded metallothionein gene MT1E suggests the programme is not a generic oxidative-stress response, which would ordinarily up-regulate MT1 genes.

program_14.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mature, metabolically active alveolar type II (AT2) epithelial cell program in human lung, characterized by surfactant production and lipid/sterol-handling functions. Evidence: • Surfactant / AT2 identity – SFTPA2, SFTPD, NAPSA, HHIP, C16orf89, TMEM213 are canonical markers of human AT2 cells. • Lipid / sterol metabolism typical of AT2 cells – CD36, CES1, CES3, APOA1, AZGP1, CYB5A, ALDH2, NPC2 support the high lipid-processing demand of surfactant synthesis. • Secretory / protease components enriched in AT2 – PGC and AK1 (peptidase/kinase enriched in secretory epithelia), SELENBP1, LGI3, CRYM. • Transcriptional activation but low proliferation – immediate-early genes FOS, CEBPD are up, while negative loading of SPIN1 (pro-proliferative chromatin reader) and SH3BP4 (nutrient-sensing endosomal protein) suggests a differentiated, non-cycling state. Inconsistencies: • AQP1 (vascular/endothelial) and CA1/CA2 (erythroid/AT1-biased) are atypical for pure AT2 cells. • CYP17A1 (steroidogenic enzyme) and CORIN (cardiac convertase) are not usually expressed in lung epithelium. • The panel lacks hallmark AT2 transcripts SFTPC and SLC34A2, so assignment rests on other surfactant genes.

program_15.description: The gene set is most consistent with an airway sub-mucosal gland/secretory epithelial program, encompassing both mucous (MUC5B-high) and serous (LTF-, WFDC2-, AZGP1-high) acinar cells that are activated by inflammatory or oxidative stress. Evidence: • Mucous secretory identity – MUC5B, BPIFB1, PRR4, DMBT1, SPINK5 encode major gel-forming mucins and associated mucous-cell products typical of airway gland and goblet cells. • Serous gland components – LTF, WFDC2 (HE4), AZGP1, LCN2, DEFB1, SERPINA1/ SERPIND1 code for antimicrobial peptides and protease inhibitors enriched in serous acinar cells. • Airway/respiratory epithelial markers – CXCL17, CHI3L1, ABCA3, ALPL, AQP1 and SLC5A8 are expressed in distal airway or alveolar secretory epithelia and up-regulated during epithelial injury. • Injury / oxidative-stress metabolism – HMOX1, LDHA, NNMT, S100A11, HMGCS2 and heat-shock chaperone HSPA8 indicate an activated, stress-responsive state typical of inflamed airway epithelium. • Overall coherence – the co-expression of mucins, antimicrobial/antiprotease factors and surfactant-processing machinery fits the phenotype of sub-mucosal gland cells that supply protective secretions to the airway lumen. Inconsistencies: • ABCA3 and ALPL are classically strongest in alveolar type II cells, suggesting some overlap with distal alveolar programs. • AQP1 is mainly endothelial; PPP1R1B and RASGRF1 are neuroendocrine/neuronal genes; HMGCS2 is best known for hepatic/intestinal ketogenesis. • Only one negatively loaded gene (DSTN, an actin-depolymerizing protein) is present, offering limited information on suppressed pathways.

program_16.description: The gene loadings describe a generic “high-translation / ribosome biogenesis” program that marks cells in a metabolically active or proliferative state rather than a specific lineage identity. The program is driven by broad up-regulation of ribosomal proteins, translation-elongation factors and energy-production genes, while canonical, lineage-specific differentiation markers (e.g., surfactant genes of alveolar type II epithelial cells) are concurrently suppressed. Evidence: • Strong positive loadings of core translational machinery and ribosome-associated genes (RACK1, FAU, NACA, UBA52, EEF1A1/EEF1B2/EEF1D, EEF2, NOP53, TPT1) are hallmarks of ribosome biogenesis and active protein synthesis seen in cycling or stressed cells across tissues. • Enhanced metabolic support for translation (SLC25A5, ATP5MC2 – mitochondrial ATP transport/synthesis; TKT – pentose-phosphate pathway) fits a high biosynthetic state. • Negative loadings of mature, lineage-defining secretory/structural genes (SFTPA2, SFTPD – alveolar type II; SELENBP1, STC1, SFRP5 – alveolar type I; PGC – gastric chief cell; PDLIM3 – contractile cells) indicate that differentiated functions are dialed down when the translation program is high, consistent with a “dedifferentiated/proliferative” condition rather than a specific mature cell type. Inconsistencies: • A1BG and IGBP1 are plasma or immune-related proteins whose inclusion is not strictly tied to translation; they contribute little mechanistic information but do not contradict the overall high-translation signature.

program_17.description: The program represents hepatocytes that have entered an acute-phase/inflammatory secretory state, characterized by high production of plasma acute-phase proteins and activation of endoplasmic-reticulum (ER) chaperone machinery to handle the increased secretory load. Evidence: • Canonical liver acute-phase plasma proteins: HP, ORM1, ORM2, FGA, FGG are classically synthesized and secreted by hepatocytes during the acute-phase response. • Secretory/ER stress machinery: AGR2, CALR, FKBP11, MANF encode ER-resident foldases or chaperones induced when secretory throughput is high, a hallmark of acute-phase hepatocytes. • Additional inflammation-induced secreted factors elevated in injured liver: DMBT1, CHI3L1, S100A9, NME1 further support an inflammatory acute-phase program. Inconsistencies: • S100A9 is more typical of neutrophils/monocytes, and CHI3L1 is widely expressed by macrophages and stromal cells; their presence may reflect paracrine uptake or minor contamination, but both are reported to be inducible in hepatocytes during systemic inflammation.

program_18.description: The gene set reflects an ATF4-driven integrated stress response (ISR) characteristic of cells experiencing amino-acid deprivation or related metabolic stress, rather than a lineage-specific cell identity. Evidence: • Core ISR transcription factor and downstream effectors – ATF4 together with its canonical targets TRIB3, NUPR1 and ASNS indicate activation of the amino-acid starvation/ER‐stress pathway. • Amino-acid supply and redox adaptation – SLC7A11 (cystine-glutamate antiporter) and SLC6A9 (glycine transporter) promote import of sulfur and one-carbon substrates, while MTHFD2 and PSAT1 support serine/one-carbon biosynthesis, all well-known ATF4 targets during nutrient stress. • Translational re-programming – EIF4EBP1 (mTOR-regulated translation repressor), EIF1, XPOT and SARS1 (serine-tRNA synthetase) denote the characteristic ISR shift toward selective translation of stress-response mRNAs while globally restraining protein synthesis. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; housekeeping translation factors (EIF1, XPOT, SARS1) are ubiquitous but frequently retained or even up-regulated during ISR to maintain selective protein synthesis.

program_19.description: The gene set most closely matches an inflamed, mucus-secreting airway/other mucosal secretory epithelial cell (goblet/club-like) program, characterised by high production of antimicrobial and barrier-protective secreted proteins. Evidence: • Goblet / secretory cell products – BPIFB1 (LPLUNC1), WFDC2 (HE4), TFF3 and SCGB3A1 are classical secreted proteins highly enriched in airway and other mucosal goblet or club cells. • Antimicrobial / acute-phase factors – LCN2 and BPIFB1 provide bacteriostatic activity, fitting an epithelial response to inflammation. • Detoxification / antioxidant enzymes typical of secretory epithelia – GSTA1 and CP are induced in epithelial cells exposed to inhaled or luminal oxidants. • Additional secretory / membrane proteins frequently up-regulated in activated epithelial cells – TMEM45A, TSPAN8 and MDK are reported in metaplastic or injury-stimulated airway and gut secretory epithelia. Inconsistencies: • CP is classically hepatocyte-derived but is also inducible in wounded airway epithelium; its presence therefore only partially diverges from the secretory epithelial theme.

program_20.description: The gene set reflects a generalized “Oxidative Phosphorylation (OXPHOS)/high-mitochondrial-respiration” program, characteristic of cells relying on mitochondrial ATP production (e.g., metabolically active, oxygen-rich epithelial, muscle, or memory immune cells). Evidence: • Multiple ATP synthase subunits (ATP5F1E, ATP5ME, ATP5MK) → concerted up-regulation of complex V, a core feature of OXPHOS. • COX7C (complex IV), NDUFB1 (complex I), UQCR11 (complex III) → simultaneous induction of complexes I, III and IV indicates coordinated assembly of the entire electron-transport chain. • POLR2L (RNA-pol II) and TMA7 (translation machinery) → housekeeping factors often co-induced with high bioenergetic demand to sustain protein/RNA synthesis driven by mitochondrial ATP. • Absence of negatively loaded glycolytic or stress genes supports a shift toward oxidative, rather than glycolytic, metabolism. Inconsistencies: • SFTA2 is a surfactant-associated, ER/Golgi protein enriched in lung epithelium and not directly involved in the respiratory chain, so its presence is not readily explained by an OXPHOS program, though it can be co-regulated in secretory epithelia with high energy needs.

program_21.description: The gene set is most consistent with an “acute-phase / interferon-stimulated inflammatory monocyte–macrophage” program, characterised by simultaneous induction of classical acute-phase secreted proteins, interferon-response genes and ER/secretory‐pathway chaperones that support high secretory load. Evidence: • Acute-phase proteins (HP, SAA1, SERPINA1) – typically liver-derived but repeatedly reported as strongly up-regulated in inflammatory monocytes/macrophages in sepsis, IBD and COVID-19 single-cell datasets (“SAA⁺/HP⁺ inflammatory macrophages”). • Myeloid inflammatory markers (S100A9, PI3) – abundant in neutrophils/monocytes and in the above “acute-phase macrophage” state. • Interferon-stimulated gene (IFITM3) – fits an antiviral, pro-inflammatory macrophage program frequently co-expressed with SAA1/HP modules. • ER/secretory pathway components (CALR, SDF2L1, SEC61G) – support high-level synthesis and secretion of acute-phase proteins seen in this macrophage subset. Inconsistencies: • Acute-phase proteins are classically hepatocyte products; their presence could also fit a hepatocyte acute-phase response, but the concurrent myeloid markers (S100A9, PI3) and interferon gene (IFITM3) favour an inflammatory monocyte/macrophage origin over hepatocytes.

program_22.description: The gene set most closely fits an activated fibroblast / myofibroblast program characterized by extracellular-matrix production and acquisition of smooth-muscle–like contractility, typical of wound healing, fibrosis, or stromal remodeling states. Evidence: • Matrix synthesis: COL1A2, FN1 and DCN are core components of type I collagen and fibronectin-rich ECM produced by fibroblasts during tissue repair. • Fibroblast / stromal identity: CFD (adipsin) and RGCC are commonly expressed in interstitial fibroblasts undergoing proliferative or inflammatory activation. • Myofibroblast contractility: ACTA2 (α-SMA) and FHL1 mark fibroblasts that have adopted smooth-muscle–like properties, a hallmark of myofibroblasts. Inconsistencies: • GYPC is an erythroid membrane protein and is not typical of fibroblasts; its presence likely reflects ambient erythrocyte RNA contamination rather than the core program.

program_23.description: The gene set outlines a proliferative, protein-synthesis–intense state of ALDH1A2-positive mesenchymal/fibroblast cells that are actively replicating DNA and producing retinoic acid, while lacking immediate-early stress–response signatures. Evidence: • ALDH1A2 – canonical retinoic-acid–synthesising enzyme enriched in stromal/fibroblast lineages (cardiac, lung, intestinal subepithelial fibroblasts). • DONSON – replication-fork protector strongly expressed during S-phase, marking cells in active DNA replication. • RACK1, EEF1B2, EEF1D, UBA52 – ribosomal/elongation factors that rise with high translational demand typical of cycling cells. • Negative loading of FOS (immediate-early activation gene) and RNASE1 (endothelial/activated macrophage marker) supports a fibroblast identity in a basal, non-stress state rather than an activated endothelial or inflammatory program. Inconsistencies: • Translation-related genes are ubiquitously expressed and could represent a generic high-biosynthesis program rather than fibroblast-specific activity. • ALDH1A2 is not universal to all fibroblast subsets; its presence narrows the interpretation to retinoic-acid–producing stromal cells, which may not account for every context in which the other genes appear.

program_24.description: The program reflects an IFN-γ–activated professional antigen-presenting cell (APC) state—typical of dendritic cells, macrophages, or B cells undergoing up-regulation of MHC class II molecules to present peptide antigens. Evidence: • Strong enrichment of classical MHC class II genes (HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DRB5, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DQA1, HLA-DQB1) is the canonical signature of professional APCs and is further boosted upon IFN-γ stimulation. • CALHM6 (FAM26F) is an interferon-inducible membrane channel up-regulated in activated macrophages and dendritic cells, supporting an activated/inflammatory APC state. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes were provided; no clear inconsistencies detected.

program_25.description: The gene set represents a canonical micro-vascular endothelial cell program characterized by tight-junction formation and pro-angiogenic signaling, consistent with capillary/venous endothelial cells that maintain vascular barrier integrity and respond to vaso-active peptides. Evidence: • Endothelial identity – PECAM1 (CD31) and CLDN5 are hallmark endothelial adhesion and tight-junction genes. • Barrier / tight junction specialization – CLDN5 is the principal claudin of continuous capillaries, especially in blood–brain and lung barriers. • Vaso-active peptide reception – RAMP2 forms the adrenomedullin/CALCRL receptor complex, enriched in endothelial cells regulating permeability and angiogenesis. • Angiogenic / extracellular matrix remodeling – SPARC is secreted by activated endothelium during vessel sprouting and matrix turnover. • Transport and signaling typical of endothelium – SLCO2A1 (prostaglandin transporter), GNG11 (G-protein γ subunit), and VAMP5 (vesicular trafficking) are all preferentially expressed in endothelial cells, supporting signal transduction and vesicle fusion required for vascular function. Inconsistencies: • NPDC1 is better known in neuronal contexts; however, low-level expression has been reported in endothelial cells, so its presence is only mildly discordant.

program_26.description: The program most closely reflects alveolar type II (AT2) epithelial cells that have recently sensed stress- or cytokine-mediated stimulation, manifesting a canonical immediate-early (AP-1) response. Evidence: • AT2 lineage marker – NAPSA (Napsin A) is highly and selectively expressed in lung alveolar type II pneumocytes. • Immediate-early/AP-1 activation – JUN, FOS, JUNB (AP-1 transcription factors), IER2, DUSP1, GADD45B and NR4A1 are classic rapid-response genes induced within minutes of MAPK, cytokine or injury signals, denoting an acutely activated cellular state. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; all listed genes fit an activated AT2 profile, though the absence of additional surfactant genes (e.g., SFTPA/B/C) slightly weakens—but does not contradict—the AT2 assignment.

program_27.description: The gene set represents an unfolded-protein-response/ER-stress program typical of highly secretory cells experiencing increased protein-folding load (e.g., plasma cells, hepatocytes, activated secretory epithelia). Evidence: • Core UPR chaperones and translocon components – HSPA5/BiP, HSP90B1/GRP94, SDF2L1, PPIB and SEC61G – are canonical targets of ATF6/XBP1 pathways that expand ER folding capacity. • SERPINA1 (α1-antitrypsin) and MYDGF encode secreted proteins whose expression rises with secretory demand and is strongly coupled to XBP1 activity in hepatocytes and plasma cells. • IFITM3, although best known as an interferon-stimulated gene, is also induced by ER stress and traffics through the secretory pathway, fitting a broader stress/secretory state rather than a full antiviral program (other ISGs are absent). Inconsistencies: • Lack of additional interferon-stimulated genes (e.g., ISG15, MX1) suggests the program is not a classic antiviral response; IFITM3’s presence alone could reflect secondary induction during ER stress.

program_28.description: The program most closely matches an airway/alveolar epithelial cell (club / type II–like) that is undergoing an IFN-γ– or cytokine-driven “antigen-presenting” state, i.e. an epithelial cell up-regulating MHC class II molecules while retaining surfactant/secretory functions. Evidence: • Airway/alveolar epithelial identity – SFTPD (surfactant protein D) and AADAC are characteristic of club and type II alveolar epithelial cells. – TPPP3 is enriched in differentiated airway epithelial cells with stable microtubules/cilia. • Antigen-presentation / IFN-γ response – HLA-DRA and HLA-DPB1 are canonical MHC class II genes induced in epithelial cells by inflammatory cytokines. • Stress/hormone-responsive epithelium – TSC22D1 is a glucocorticoid-inducible transcriptional regulator commonly up-regulated in stressed epithelial cells. – UBB (ubiquitin-B) rises with cellular stress and protein-turnover demands, fitting an activated state. Inconsistencies: • Classical surfactant genes (SFTPA, SFTPB, SFTPC) typical of mature type II cells are not present, suggesting the program reflects a subset of airway/club cells or a partial type II signature rather than fully mature AT2 cells.

program_29.description: The gene set delineates a metallothionein-driven oxidative/metal stress program most often observed in inflammatory monocytes–macrophages (but also inducible in other cell types) exposed to heavy metals, reactive oxygen species, or pro-inflammatory cytokines. Evidence: • Metallothionein core (MT1E, MT1X, MT2A, MT1G, MT1F, MT1H) – classical zinc/copper-binding, ROS-scavenging genes highly induced in LPS- or cytokine-stimulated monocytes/macrophages and during heavy-metal detoxification. • EIF4EBP1 – an mTOR-regulated translation inhibitor whose induction accompanies cellular stress responses and is co-expressed with metallothioneins in activated myeloid cells. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes fit a canonical metallothionein stress response signature.

program_30.description: The program is most consistent with a mature, mucosal-lining gastrointestinal epithelial state—seen in gastric surface (pit) cells and upper-villus/colonic absorptive or weakly secretory cells—characterized by active retinoic-acid metabolism, glycoprotein (mucin) sialylation and multiple apical transporters. Evidence: • ALDH1A1 – retinoic-acid–producing enzyme strongly enriched in stomach, duodenum and colonic villus-tip/absorptive epithelial cells. • ST6GALNAC1 – mucin-type α2,6-sialyltransferase abundant in gastric surface mucous cells and intestinal goblet/secretory epithelium. • CLIC6 – chloride channel with highest expression in stomach and gallbladder epithelia, supporting fluid/ion secretion at the luminal surface. • ABCC5 – apical multidrug/organic anion exporter enriched in intestinal and gastric epithelia, indicative of barrier and detoxification functions. • MFSD4A – solute carrier preferentially expressed in small-intestinal epithelium, supporting nutrient/solute handling. • GRHL1 – epithelial transcription factor driving barrier maturation in digestive tract epithelia. Inconsistencies: • Classic markers that would pin the program to a single specialized epithelial subtype (e.g., MUC2/TFF3 for goblet cells, ATP4A for parietal cells, or BEST4/OTOP2 for intestinal ionocytes) are absent, so the signature may represent a generalized mature mucosal‐epithelial transport/secretory program rather than one highly specific lineage.

program_31.description: The program reflects a lipid-metabolic state dominated by activation of the mevalonate/cholesterol-biosynthetic pathway, a signature commonly seen in highly proliferative epithelial or cancer-like cells that require de-novo sterol synthesis to support membrane expansion and growth‐factor signalling. Evidence: • HMGCS1, MVD, MSMO1, EBP, ACAT2 – sequential enzymes of the mevalonate pathway / cholesterol biosynthesis, typically co-induced by the master regulator SREBP2 during proliferation or oncogenic signalling. • Concerted up-regulation of multiple steps in this pathway is a canonical “cholesterol biosynthesis” transcriptional module observed in dividing epithelial cells, activated immune cells, and many tumors. • FGFBP1 encodes a secreted carrier that mobilises FGF1/2 and is often co-expressed in proliferative, wound-healing or tumor contexts, fitting the growth-associated metabolic program. Inconsistencies: • None pronounced; FGFBP1 is not a sterol-pathway enzyme but is frequently co-regulated with proliferative / metabolic genes, so its presence is compatible rather than conflicting.

program_32.description: The gene collection is most consistent with a TGF-β–driven myofibroblast program—i.e., fibroblasts that have acquired contractile, extracellular-matrix-remodeling features typical of wound healing and fibrosis. Evidence: • ACTA2 (α-smooth-muscle actin) – canonical marker of myofibroblasts; induced by TGF-β. • FN1 (fibronectin) – major extracellular-matrix component secreted by activated fibroblasts and myofibroblasts. • RGCC (RGC-32) – up-regulated by TGF-β/SMAD signaling in fibroblasts during fibrosis. • FHL1 – LIM-domain protein enriched in contractile and mechanically stressed mesenchymal cells, including myofibroblasts. • CRYAB (αB-crystallin) – small heat-shock protein elevated in stressed, contractile mesenchymal cells and reported in fibrotic lesions. • RARRES2 (Chemerin) – cytokine/adipokine secreted by dermal and pulmonary fibroblasts; rises during tissue remodeling and inflammation. Inconsistencies: • FHL1 and CRYAB are better known in skeletal muscle and lens/astrocytes, respectively, but both have documented up-regulation in fibrotic myofibroblasts, so the mismatch is minor.

program_33.description: The gene set most consistently points to a hepatocyte-like drug/xenobiotic-metabolism program, typical of pericentral (zone 3) liver parenchymal cells that are specialized for cytochrome-P450-mediated detoxification. Evidence: • CYP2B6 – canonical cytochrome-P450 enzyme enriched in pericentral hepatocytes and a hallmark of xenobiotic clearance. • HSD17B6 – NAD-dependent oxidoreductase involved in steroid/retinoid metabolism, likewise hepatocyte-enriched and co-expressed with P450 genes in zone 3. • SELENBP1 – selenium-binding protein implicated in hepatic oxidative-stress and sulfur compound catabolism, showing high basal liver expression. • BCAM – laminin receptor present on hepatocyte plasma membranes and up-regulated in liver injury/regeneration, compatible with a hepatic epithelial context. • SUSD2 – transmembrane protein detected in several epithelial tissues including liver biliary/hepatocyte lineages and up-regulated in regenerating liver. • RNASE1 – secreted endoribonuclease produced by hepatocytes as well as endothelial cells; its presence fits a secretory, enzyme-rich hepatic micro-environment. Inconsistencies: • RNASE1 and BCAM are more classically associated with vascular endothelial cells, and SUSD2 is better known in stromal/perivascular niches, so their co-loading may reflect minor endothelial/stromal contamination or a mixed cell doublet rather than pure hepatocytes.

program_34.description: The gene set is most consistent with a basal airway (and more generally stratified) epithelial-stem / progenitor program, i.e. the keratin-5⁺/TP63⁺ basal cells that anchor the epithelium to the basement membrane and provide a reservoir for renewal while maintaining a modest, constitutive antiviral readiness. Evidence: • ITGB4 – integrin β4 forming the α6β4 hemidesmosome complex, a canonical marker of basal epithelial cells in trachea, bronchus, epidermis and limbal epithelium. • CYP4B1 – cytochrome P450 isoform highly enriched in lung and upper-airway epithelial cells (basal and club), involved in xenobiotic metabolism characteristic of barrier epithelia. • CRIP1 / CRIP2 – LIM-domain proteins strongly expressed in airway and epidermal basal layers, linked to cytoskeletal organization and wound-responsive basal cell states. • CD24 – surface glycoprotein marking epithelial progenitors, including airway basal cells, and facilitating epithelial cell adhesion/renewal. • BST2 (tetherin) – an interferon-inducible barrier protein frequently up-regulated in airway epithelium, reflecting the low-level antiviral surveillance typical of basal cells exposed to pathogens. Inconsistencies: • BST2’s interferon inducibility could also arise from transient antiviral signalling rather than a constitutive basal program, but its expression is frequently noted in basal epithelial scRNA-seq clusters, so this is a minor discrepancy.

program_35.description: The program reflects an interferon-stimulated, antigen-presenting endothelial cell state—i.e., endothelial cells that have been exposed to type I/II interferons and have up-regulated MHC-I molecules and classical antiviral genes. Evidence: • Endothelial identity – CLEC14A is an endothelial-restricted C-type lectin highly expressed in blood vessel endothelium. • Interferon response – IFI27 and BST2 (tetherin) are canonical type I interferon-stimulated genes induced during viral sensing. • Enhanced antigen presentation – HLA-A, HLA-C and non-classical HLA-E are MHC-I molecules whose coordinated up-regulation is a hallmark of interferon signaling and equips cells for CD8⁺ T-cell recognition. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes are compatible with an interferon-activated endothelial profile.

program_36.description: The gene set represents a type I interferon–stimulated activation program most often seen in myeloid immune cells (monocytes, macrophages, dendritic cells) but also inducible in many nucleated cells during an antiviral response. Evidence: • BST2 (tetherin) – canonical interferon-stimulated gene that restricts viral particle release. • HLA-A & HLA-C – MHC-I molecules whose transcription is up-regulated by type I IFN to enhance antigen presentation to CD8⁺ T cells. • IL32 – pro-inflammatory cytokine induced in IFN-activated NK, T, and myeloid cells, amplifying antiviral signaling. • MARCKSL1 – cytoskeletal regulator enriched in activated macrophages; expression increases after IFN or TLR stimulation. • CRIP1 – abundantly expressed in monocytes/macrophages and reported among interferon-responsive transcripts. Inconsistencies: • No clear inconsistencies; all listed genes are compatible with a generalized interferon-driven antiviral activation state, although the absence of additional classical ISGs (e.g., ISG15, OAS family) slightly limits the breadth of the signature.

program_37.description: The program is most consistent with an airway epithelial basal-/progenitor-cell state characterized by active WNT/β-catenin signaling and cytoskeletal remodeling, accompanied by broad translational activity and a clear exclusion of alveolar type II identity. Evidence: • CTNNB1 (β-catenin) — core effector of canonical WNT signaling that maintains airway basal stem-cell self-renewal. • DSTN — actin-depolymerizing factor enriched in motile, remodeling basal/progenitor epithelia. • PABPC1 and NBEAL1 — proteins involved in mRNA translation and vesicle/Golgi trafficking, respectively, fitting the high biosynthetic demand of proliferative basal cells. • NAPSA is strongly repressed; Napsin A is a hallmark of alveolar type II pneumocytes, so its negative loading supports a non-AT2, proximal airway identity. Inconsistencies: • Gene set is small and largely ubiquitous (e.g., PABPC1), so resolution is limited; no major contradictions but lack of classical basal markers (KRT5, TP63) slightly weakens the assignment.

program_38.description: The program is most consistent with a barrier-forming epithelial state, such as differentiated squamous/epidermal or other tight-junction–rich epithelial cells that are reorganising their cortical actin and plasma-membrane microdomains. Evidence: • CLDN1 – core tight-junction protein indispensable for epidermal/other epithelial barrier integrity. • SFN (14-3-3σ) – keratinocyte-restricted checkpoint protein induced during stratified epithelial differentiation and stress. • EZR – apical actin–membrane linker abundant in microvilli of polarised epithelial layers. • TM4SF1 – tetraspanin-like protein enriched in several epithelial barriers and up-regulated during epithelial maturation and repair. • CAVIN1 – caveolae structural component that, together with caveolins, regulates membrane organisation in surface epithelia. • EDN1 – paracrine peptide secreted by keratinocytes/other epithelia to modulate vascular tone and pigmentation, fitting an epithelial barrier with signalling capacity. Inconsistencies: • TM4SF1, CAVIN1 and EDN1 are also found in endothelial cells, yet canonical endothelial markers (e.g. PECAM1, VWF, CLDN5, KDR) are absent, favouring an epithelial rather than endothelial interpretation.

program_39.description: The program reflects a universal cellular stress/heat-shock response rather than a specific lineage, characterized by concerted induction of HSP70- and HSP90-family chaperones that buffer proteotoxic or ER stress. Evidence: • HSPA1A, HSPA6 – classic inducible HSP70 genes rapidly up-regulated upon heat, oxidative, or proteotoxic stress. • HSP90AA1 – cytosolic HSP90 isoform whose expression rises during the heat-shock response to stabilize mis-folded proteins. • DNAJA1 – HSP40 co-chaperone that partners with HSP70s to refold damaged proteins. • HSPA8 – constitutive HSC70 that is often further elevated in stressed cells to augment chaperone capacity. • HSPA5 (BiP/GRP78) – ER-resident chaperone and canonical unfolded protein response (UPR) marker, indicating engagement of ER stress pathways alongside the cytosolic heat-shock program. Inconsistencies: No negatively loaded or lineage-specific genes are present that conflict with a generic stress response interpretation.

program_40.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated stratified-squamous epithelial (keratinocyte) program seen at the wound edge: cells that retain epithelial/cornified-envelope features yet up-regulate migratory and injury-response molecules. Evidence: • SCEL (Sciellin) and SFN (14-3-3-σ) – classical components of the cornified envelope and late epidermal/stratified-epithelial differentiation. • EZR and PDLIM2 – cytoskeleton/actin-linker proteins that stabilize epithelial cell shape and junctions. • TM4SF1 – tetraspan membrane protein induced in basal/migratory keratinocytes and other epithelia during wound repair and in progenitor-like states. • TNFRSF12A (Fn14) – TWEAK receptor strongly up-regulated in injured epidermis, driving keratinocyte proliferation, migration and inflammatory signaling. Inconsistencies: • TM4SF1 is also prominent in angiogenic endothelial cells, so its presence could reflect a mixed epithelial–vascular signal, though it is reported in wound-edge keratinocytes as well.

program_41.description: The program represents a robust type I interferon–stimulated gene (ISG) response, characteristic of cells that have sensed viral infection or have been exposed to IFN-α/β, rather than a specific lineage; it denotes an antiviral activated state that can be super-imposed on many immune or parenchymal cell types. Evidence: • ISG15, IFI6, IFI44L – classic ISGs whose transcription is rapidly induced by IFN-α/β signaling and whose protein products restrict viral replication. • MX1 – dynamin-like GTPase that blocks influenza and other RNA viruses, canonically up-regulated in interferon responses. • IFIT1, IFIT3 – members of the IFIT family that bind 5′-triphosphate viral RNA and inhibit viral translation, hallmark markers of a type I interferon program. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes were provided; no contradictions detected.

program_42.description: The program represents a metallothionein-driven metal-ion detoxification and oxidative-stress response state that can be induced in many cell types (e.g., epithelial, immune, or stromal cells) rather than a lineage-specific identity. Evidence: • Strong positive loading of MT1A, MT1E, MT1F, MT1G, MT1X and MT2A – canonical metallothioneins that bind Zn²⁺/Cu²⁺ and are rapidly up-regulated by heavy metals, reactive oxygen species, TNF, IL-1 and other stress signals, marking a generic cellular stress–protection program. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes coherently encode metallothioneins associated with the described stress-response state.

program_43.description: The gene set is most consistent with a secretory-epithelial cell that has activated an interferon-stimulated, stress-response program accompanied by actin-cytoskeleton remodeling. Evidence: • IFITM3 – prototypic interferon-stimulated, antiviral membrane protein marking an IFN-responsive state. • PFN1 and CFL1 – core actin-binding factors whose concerted up-regulation is typical of cytoskeletal re-organization triggered by inflammatory or stress signals. • S100A11 – calcium-binding protein induced in inflamed or wounded epithelia and linked to motility and membrane repair. • AGR2 – ER chaperone highly enriched in secretory/goblet and other mucus-producing epithelia, anchoring the program to a secretory-epithelial lineage. Inconsistencies: • AGR2 can be suppressed by strong interferon signaling in some contexts, so its co-expression with IFITM3 is somewhat unusual but has been reported in partially activated secretory cells during moderate antiviral responses.

program_44.description: The gene set points to a generic simple-/luminal-epithelial program, characteristic of EpCAM (TACSTD2)–positive epithelial cells that rely on the KRT8/KRT18 intermediate-filament network; such a profile is commonly seen in undifferentiated or transitional epithelial progenitors (e.g., KRT8+ alveolar differentiation intermediates, biliary/hepatic progenitors, or many carcinoma cells). Evidence: • KRT8 and KRT18 – obligate keratin pair defining simple and luminal epithelia; strongly induced in epithelial progenitors and transitional states. • TACSTD2 (EpCAM/TROP2) – trans-membrane glycoprotein broadly marking viable epithelial cells and epithelial stem/progenitor compartments; often co-expressed with KRT8/18. • ANXA1 – calcium-dependent phospholipid-binding protein enriched at apical membranes of secretory/simple epithelia and up-regulated during epithelial regeneration. • UBC – ubiquitin gene ubiquitously expressed but typically high in metabolically active, proliferative cells, consistent with progenitor or tumor epithelia. Inconsistencies: • None of the positive genes contradict an epithelial identity; UBC is a generic housekeeping gene but not inconsistent.

program_45.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with a bronchiolar secretory (club / early goblet–like) epithelial program: cells that secrete secretoglobins and other protective factors in the conducting airways, but that are distinct from alveolar type II pneumocytes. Evidence: • SCGB3A1 – prototypic secretoglobin abundantly expressed by airway club cells and early goblet cells but low in alveolar epithelium. • TSPAN8 and TMEM45A – enriched in mucus-producing and other secretory epithelial cells of lung and intestine; reported markers of goblet/club differentiation. • APOD – secreted apolipoprotein detected in airway secretory epithelium, often co-expressed with secretoglobins during club-cell maturation. • Negative loading of SFTPD – surfactant protein D is a hallmark of alveolar type II cells; its suppression argues against an AT2 identity and supports a non-alveolar, bronchiolar secretory state. Inconsistencies: • SFTPD can be produced at low levels by some proximal secretory cells, so strong negative loading may under-represent that minor overlap. Apart from this, few genes contradict the club/goblet secretory interpretation.

program_46.description: The gene set is most consistent with a germ-cell / cancer-testis (CTA)–like program, i.e. a transcriptional state in which somatic or malignant cells aberrantly express genes normally restricted to male germ cells and testis. Evidence: • CTAG2 encodes a classic cancer-testis antigen, normally silent in adult somatic tissues and activated in germ cells and a wide range of tumours. • TMEM238 shows strong testis-enriched expression in GTEx and other datasets, clustering with multiple CTA genes. • CD81, although broadly expressed, is a tetraspanin implicated in sperm–egg fusion and reported on germ cells alongside other tetraspanins (e.g., CD9). • GNAS is an imprinted locus with high expression in germ cells and testicular tissue, fitting the germline signature. • BRI3, while more ubiquitous, is expressed in human testis and is frequently co-up-regulated with CTA genes in cancers displaying germ-cell programs. Inconsistencies: • BRI3 and CD81 are not germ-cell restricted and can be expressed in many cell types, so their presence alone does not define a CTA program; however, their co-expression with CTAG2 and TMEM238 suggests they participate in a broader, mixed membrane/germline module rather than contradict the interpretation.

program_47.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mature, granulocytic (neutrophil) program biased toward tissue-deployed/activated neutrophils that carry coagulation- and matrix-modifying enzymes. Evidence: • CEACAM4 – virtually restricted to human neutrophils and stored in specific granules; strong marker of the lineage. • CTSH – lysosomal/azurophilic protease highly expressed in myeloid cells, especially neutrophils and monocytes, supporting a granule/lysosome-rich state. • CPB2 (TAFI) – although classically liver-derived, CPB2 mRNA and protein are detected in neutrophil secondary granules and are released to modulate fibrinolysis at sites of inflammation. • CA2 – cytosolic carbonic anhydrase present in neutrophils, where it helps regulate intracellular pH during the respiratory burst. • Collective presence of CEACAM4, CTSH, CPB2 and CA2 aligns with a neutrophil program specialized for extracellular matrix remodeling and clot regulation often seen in tissue-infiltrating or inflammation-associated neutrophils. Inconsistencies: • WIF1 is more typical of mesenchymal/fibroblast lineages; its inclusion suggests either modest contamination or that these neutrophils up-regulate Wnt-inhibitory signals in specific inflammatory contexts.

program_48.description: The program most closely matches an epithelial injury-/stress-response state, in which tight-junction–bearing epithelial cells activate cytoprotective heat-shock and ubiquitin pathways while initiating early wound-repair and proliferation signals. Evidence: • CLDN4 – canonical tight-junction claudin enriched in differentiated epithelial layers, confirming epithelial identity. • HSPB1 (HSP27) and UBC – classical immediate-early stress genes that buffer protein folding and drive ubiquitin-mediated proteostasis during cellular stress. • H3-3B – replacement histone variant incorporated during active transcription and cell-cycle entry, consistent with repair-associated proliferation. • CCN1 (CYR61) – matricellular factor induced by tissue damage that promotes epithelial restitution, angiogenic signaling and extracellular-matrix remodeling. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes are provided; no clear contradictions detected.

program_49.description: The gene set is most consistent with an injury-induced, reparative mucosal/airway epithelial program—similar to the “reactive secretory” or pre-alveolar type-1 transitional (PATS/ADI) state seen after epithelial damage, characterized by innate-defence secreted factors and extracellular-matrix remodeling. Evidence: • DMBT1 and CHI3L1 – canonical secreted pattern-recognition/innate-defence proteins strongly up-regulated in wounded or inflamed airway and intestinal epithelium and in PATS cells. • NPC2 and DBI – lipid-binding/transport proteins enriched in surfactant-producing type-II alveolar cells and maintained in their transitional injury-repair state. • TNC – extracellular-matrix glycoprotein induced in epithelial cells during wound healing and tissue remodeling, aligning with a reparative program. Inconsistencies: • TNC is more classically produced by activated fibroblasts, and CHI3L1 can be expressed by macrophages, so without additional epithelial markers the assignment to epithelial rather than stromal/immune cells is less definitive. • DBI is broadly expressed, providing limited cell-type specificity.

program_50.description: The program most closely reflects an inflammatory/acute-phase state of lung mucosal epithelium, particularly alveolar type II (AT2) or secretory airway cells that have up-regulated innate-immune and interferon-stimulated genes. Evidence: • AT2 / mucosal epithelial identity – DMBT1 is a scavenger-receptor glycoprotein highly expressed by AT2 and other airway secretory epithelial cells. – SERPINA1 transcripts are abundant in AT2 pneumocytes and secretory airway cells and increase during lung injury. • Acute-phase / tissue-remodelling response – CHI3L1 (YKL-40) is released by stressed epithelial cells and promotes tissue repair and remodeling in the lung. – FGA (fibrinogen-α) is induced in lung epithelium during injury and contributes to provisional extracellular matrix. • Antiviral / interferon stimulation – IFITM3 is a canonical interferon-stimulated gene up-regulated in epithelial cells during viral challenge, fitting an inflamed epithelial state that co-expresses the above acute-phase factors. Inconsistencies: • FGA is classically a hepatocyte product and may reflect low-level ambient RNA; however its induction has been documented in injured lung epithelium, so its presence is not wholly discordant.

program_51.description: The program is most consistent with a pulmonary venous endothelial-cell identity that is executing an anticoagulant/ECM-remodelling secretory state. Evidence: • CPB2 (Carboxypeptidase B2/TAFI) – strongly enriched in lung venous endothelial cells and contributes to regulation of fibrinolysis. • TFPI – classical endothelial anticoagulant that inhibits the tissue-factor pathway; highly expressed in venous endothelium. • HHIP – lung-specific venous endothelial marker that modulates Hedgehog signalling during airway–vascular patterning. • CTSH – lysosomal cathepsin detected in endothelial cells and up-regulated during vascular remodelling. • CHI3L2 – secreted chitinase-like protein reported in activated lung endothelial cells and other stromal populations, fitting an ECM-remodelling/secretory profile. Inconsistencies: • CHI3L2 and CTSH are better known in macrophages/chondrocytes; their presence suggests either endothelial activation or minor contamination by stromal/immune cells.

program_52.description: The program represents a canonical mast-cell transcriptional signature, characteristic of mature, granule-rich connective-tissue mast cells that express high levels of tryptases and carboxypeptidase A3 and rely on KIT signaling. Evidence: • Mast-cell‐restricted proteases TPSAB1 and TPSB2 (α/β-tryptases) are classical markers of differentiated mast cells. • CPA3 encodes carboxypeptidase A3, another granule enzyme almost exclusive to mast cells. • KIT (CD117) is the stem-cell-factor receptor indispensable for mast-cell development, survival and activation. • GLUL (glutamine synthetase) has documented expression in mast cells and supports glutamine metabolism needed for histamine and nucleotide synthesis, fitting an activated or metabolically prepared mast-cell state. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes contradict a mast-cell identity; GLUL is not mast-cell specific but is compatible with their metabolic requirements.

program_53.description: The gene set reflects an activated antigen-presenting program characteristic of tissue-resident, CXCL17-producing macrophages (e.g., airway/alveolar or other mucosal macrophages) that are poised for MHC class II–mediated T-cell stimulation. Evidence: • HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB5, HLA-DQA1 – core MHC class II molecules; high expression marks professional antigen-presenting cells such as macrophages and dendritic cells in an immune-active state. • NPC2 – lysosomal cholesterol-binding protein enriched in macrophages and dendritic cells, supporting endo-lysosomal antigen processing required for MHC II presentation. • CXCL17 – chemokine predominantly secreted by lung and other mucosal macrophages; recruits myeloid cells and is up-regulated during macrophage activation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent given the current gene lists.

program_54.description: This gene set most closely reflects a generic “high-translation” cellular program—cells with up-regulated ribosome/translation-associated factors and concomitant suppression of the alveolar type II (AT2) surfactant gene SFTPA2, suggesting a state of heightened protein synthesis that is anticorrelated with AT2 differentiation. Evidence: • Up-regulated core translation machinery: FAU (ribosomal protein S30/ubiquitin), UBA52 (RPL40/ubiquitin), RACK1 (ribosome-associated scaffold), and EEF1D (translation elongation factor) collectively mark increased ribosome abundance and peptide-elongation activity. • Down-regulated SFTPA2 is a canonical marker of differentiated AT2 epithelial cells; its negative loading supports that this program is expressed in cells lacking—or actively down-regulating—AT2 identity, consistent with a broad, nonspecialized translational state. Inconsistencies: • No additional surfactant or epithelial markers are present to refine the pulmonary context, so the negative SFTPA2 association could also simply reflect dilution of an AT2 signature rather than an active suppression specific to lung epithelium.

program_55.description: The program reflects an acutely-activated, pro-inflammatory innate immune state most compatible with interferon- and cytokine-stimulated monocytes/macrophages. Evidence: • SAA1 & SAA2 – classical IL-1/TNF-inducible acute-phase proteins that are strongly up-regulated in activated tissue monocytes/macrophages in inflamed lesions, in addition to hepatocytes. • MIF – constitutively expressed and released by monocytes/macrophages, acting in an autocrine loop to amplify TNF/IL-1 production. • IFITM2 – interferon-stimulated transmembrane protein induced by type I/II IFNs, a hallmark of viral-sensing or interferon-primed myeloid cells. • S100A11 – calcium-binding protein enriched in inflammatory myeloid cells and linked to cytokine secretion and cell motility. Collectively these genes denote an innate immune cell experiencing simultaneous IFN signaling and acute-phase cytokine exposure. Inconsistencies: • Absence of canonical macrophage structural markers (e.g., LYZ, CD68, CSF1R) leaves open the possibility that other cell types (e.g., inflammatory fibroblasts or hepatocytes) could contribute; however, the overall gene combination is most parsimoniously explained by an activated monocyte/macrophage state.

program_56.description: The gene combination points to an epithelial injury-response / wound-healing program, typical of basal-like or “repairing” epithelial cells that have begun a partial epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) to support migration and matrix remodeling. Evidence: • KRT17 – basal keratin induced in activated keratinocytes, airway basal cells, and other epithelia during wound repair and partial EMT. • MMP7 – secreted matrix metalloproteinase that degrades extracellular matrix; strongly up-regulated in repairing intestinal, airway and renal epithelia and during early EMT. • MARCKSL1 – actin-binding protein promoting membrane ruffling and cell motility in migrating/invasive epithelial cells. • S100A11 – calcium-binding protein elevated in proliferating, regenerating and EMT-like epithelial states, facilitating motility and matrix interaction. • PDLIM4 – cytoskeletal adaptor that links actin to signaling complexes; up-regulated in motile/invasive epithelial and cancer cells, supporting a remodeling phenotype. Inconsistencies: • Classical EMT transcription factors (e.g., SNAI1/2, TWIST1) and mesenchymal markers (e.g., VIM, COL1A1) are not present; thus the program represents a partial, not full, EMT.

program_57.description: The program reflects an acutely-injured, pro-inflammatory epithelial state most consistent with kidney proximal tubule cells mounting an acute-phase/repair response. Evidence: • Proximal-tubule identity – PDZK1IP1 is a brush-border protein highly enriched in renal proximal tubule epithelium. • Epithelial injury/repair markers – LCN2 (NGAL) and MMP7 are classical genes induced in damaged tubules and during Wnt-driven epithelial regeneration. • Acute-phase secretory response – SAA1 and PI3 (Elafin) are inducible, secreted proteins produced by epithelial cells under IL-1/TNF signaling, signalling a local inflammatory milieu. Together these genes outline a proximal-tubule epithelial cell that has sensed injury and activated an acute-phase, matrix-remodelling program. Inconsistencies: • SAA1 is more classically hepatocyte-derived; however its inducible expression in inflamed epithelia, including kidney, is documented, so inconsistency is limited.

program_0.description: This program typifies airway epithelial cells that have switched from a secretory/club- or alveolar-like identity to a stratified squamous, keratinising state characteristic of squamous metaplasia. Evidence: • Cornified envelope / keratinisation genes up-regulated: SPRR1A/B, SPRR2A/D/E/F, SPRR3, IVL, SCEL, PPL, TINCR, CALML5, KRT6B/C, KRT13, KRT16, KRT78, KRT4, DSG3, DSC2, LAMB3. • Squamous differentiation transcriptional regulators up: GRHL1/3, KLF4, HOPX, PITX1, VGLL1. • Barrier-associated proteases & inhibitors up: KLK7/8/10/12/13, TMPRSS11A/B/D/E, SPINK5/7, SERPINB1/5. • Stress-inflammatory keratinocyte markers up: S100A7/8/9/11/12/14/16, IL1RN, CXCL1/6, BCL2A1. • Secretory / club / AT2 markers down: SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1, ALDH1A1, SFTPD, ALOX15, MUC16, HPCAL1, EPAS1. • Loss of MHC class-I antigen presentation genes (HLA-B, HLA-C, B2M, CD74) common in keratinising epithelium. Inconsistencies: • A few secretory or alveolar-biased genes remain up (MUC21, SLC34A2, VWF, CALB1), and macrophage-associated MERTK is present, suggesting some mixed or transitional expression.

program_1.description: The gene set represents a strong G2/M-phase cell-cycle program characteristic of actively dividing basal/squamous epithelial cells such as proliferative keratinocytes. The dominance of canonical mitotic regulators (e.g., CDK1–CCNB1/2, AURKA/B, PLK1), together with epithelial adhesion/keratin genes (DSG3, DSC2/3, COL17A1, KRT6C), points to an epithelial lineage that is currently in a highly proliferative state rather than a lineage-specific functional program. Evidence: • Cell-cycle machinery – CDK1, CCNB1/2, CCNA2, CDC20, UBE2C, BIRC5, PLK1, TPX2, AURKA/B, BUB1/BUB1B, TTK, NUSAP1, TOP2A, MCM2-7, PCNA, RRM2, TK1: hallmark G2/M and S-phase genes. • Mitotic spindle/kinetochore components – KIF11, KIF20A/B, KIF23, KIF2C, CENPA/P/W, NDC80, CENPF, CENPE, NUF2, SPC24/25, KNL1, HJURP: definitive for cells in mitosis. • Epithelial/basal keratinocyte markers – DSG3, DSC2, DSC3, COL17A1, KRT6C, CD109: support squamous epithelial origin. • Desmosome/caveolae genes – CAV1, CAVIN1/3, FLNA: frequently found in basal epithelial cells undergoing remodeling during division. • Transcriptional drivers of proliferation – FOXM1, MYBL2, E2F2/7: reinforce a cycling state. Inconsistencies: • A handful of context-dependent genes (e.g., NMU, THBD, CA2) are not classical keratinocyte markers but are low in number and can be variably expressed; they do not outweigh the dominant epithelial G2/M signature.

program_2.description: The gene set reflects a motile-ciliogenesis program characteristic of fully differentiated multiciliated epithelial cells (e.g., airway or oviduct epithelium). Strong up-regulation of the FOXJ1 transcriptional network and numerous axonemal dynein, radial spoke, intraflagellar-transport and basal-body components indicates active assembly/maintenance of motile cilia, while concurrent expression of epithelial markers (EPCAM, EZR, PROM1) and suppression of secretory/absorptive genes (TSPAN8, RNASE1) further support an epithelial, multiciliated state. Evidence: • Ciliogenesis transcriptional driver: FOXJ1, MAP3K19, AKNA • Axonemal dynein heavy/light chains: DNAH1/3/7/9/10/11/12, DNAL1, DYNLRB2, DYNC2H1, DYNC2I1 • Radial-spoke / nexin–dynein regulatory complex: RSPH4A, DRC1, DRC3, CCDC65, CFAP43/45/47/53/58, BBOF1 • Intraflagellar transport & basal-body proteins: IFT88, IFT81, TTC21A, CC2D2A, TCTN1/2, CEP126, CROCC, BBS5, ALMS1 • Transition-zone / centrosome components: DAW1, LCA5/LCA5L, CCDC40, CCDC30, CCDC157 • Epithelial identity: EPCAM, EZR, PROM1, CLDN3, AKAP14; suppression of secretory/enterocyte genes TSPAN8, RNASE1 (negative loadings) Inconsistencies: • BEST4, ABCB11, HSD17B13 – typically intestinal/hepatic; may represent low-level ambient RNA or rare doublets • MUC16, MUC5B – mucin genes more common in secretory cells, but low expression in ciliated cells can occur • VIM – mesenchymal marker occasionally induced by stress or dissociation.

program_3.description: The gene set reflects a stratified squamous epithelial-differentiation program typical of basal/suprabasal cells undergoing non-keratinised squamous maturation (e.g. airway or oesophageal-type metaplasia). It is enriched for desmosomal, keratin, and TP63-controlled genes characteristic of squamous layers, while genes that define columnar/secretory goblet or club cells are selectively repressed. Evidence: • Squamous-structural genes: TP63, KRT13/4/19/8, DSG3, DSC2/3, PKP1, PERP, SPRR1B, SERPINB3/B4/B13, CLCA2 – canonical markers of stratified squamous epithelium. • Basal-layer adhesion/ECM: ITGA6, ITGB4, CD44, TACSTD2, ITM2B, LAD1 support a basal epithelial identity. • Calcium-binding & barrier genes: CALML3/5, S100A11, CSTB/CSTA, ALOX15, CERS3 – linked to squamous barrier formation and cornified envelope assembly. • Airway/upper-GI squamous markers: LGR6, CLCA4, AKR1B10, FGFR3, SERPINB5 align with mucosal squamous differentiation seen in airway metaplasia. • Negative loading of secretory cell genes (MUC1, MUC5AC, TFF3, PIGR, BPIFA1, WFDC2, CXCL6, CD74) underscores repression of columnar/goblet programs, reinforcing a squamous, non-secretory state. Inconsistencies: • AQP5 (type I alveolar/secretory) and S100A8 (myeloid-stress) are atypical but can be induced in stressed squamous epithelium. • Modest immune/stress genes (PYCARD, CXCL14, TGFB1, GAS6) suggest concurrent inflammatory signalling rather than a distinct cell identity.

program_4.description: The gene set is most consistent with an airway/upper-airway secretory (goblet-like) epithelial program in an activated, mucous-hypersecreting state typical of goblet-cell differentiation or goblet metaplasia during airway inflammation. Evidence: • Mucin core proteins characteristic of goblet cells – MUC1, MUC4, MUC5AC, MUC16, MUC20, MUC21, MUC4, FCGBP, TFF1. • Airway innate-defence secreted factors – BPIFA1, BPIFB1 (PLUNC family), LCN2, SLPI, DEFB4A, RNASE1/4, S100A4/6, LGALS3, PIGR, CEACAM5/6, CEACAM7, CEACAM5; these are highly expressed in inflamed bronchial goblet epithelium. • Other goblet-/secretory-cell enzymes and transporters – GCNT3 (core 2 O-glycan branching in mucins), ANPEP, AZGP1, AQP5, SLC34A2, LPCAT1, ALDH1A1; many are reported in secretory or metaplastic airway epithelium. • Mesothelial/epithelial-secretory markers up-regulated in goblet metaplasia – MSLN, PSCA, WFDC2, CST3, CP. • Negative loading of club-cell and ciliated-cell markers (SCGB1A1, CXCL14, KRT8, TMPRSS11D) supports a shift away from normal club/ciliated epithelium toward mucus-secreting goblet fate. Inconsistencies: • Presence of FBP1, ASS1, MSMB and MESP1—which are better known in hepatic, renal, prostate or developmental contexts—suggests some cross-program contamination. • Lack of classic surfactant genes (SFTPA/B/C/D) that normally accompany SLC34A2 and LPCAT1 in alveolar type-2 cells indicates the program is not a pure AT2 signature. • ALPL and SERPINA1 are more typical of other epithelial or mesenchymal states but may reflect stress-induced expression.

program_5.description: The program reflects a highly differentiated mucous/secretory airway epithelial (goblet-like/club-like) state characterized by robust production and processing of gel-forming mucins, anti-microbial peptides and other secreted factors, together with repression of generic stress/basal epithelial genes. Evidence: • Goblet cell mucin machinery – MUC5AC, MUC5B, MUC13, TFF1, TFF3, FCGBP, AGR2, AGR3, DMBT1, MMP7 support a mucin-secreting phenotype. • Airway-restricted secreted proteins – BPIFB1, BPIFB2, BPIFA1, PIGR, CXCL17, CXCL6, LTF, LCN2, WFDC2, SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1 typify upper and lower respiratory secretory epithelium. • ER/secretory pathway reinforcement – XBP1, CP, STARD10, RAP1GAP, NUCB2, RAMP1 highlight the increased secretory load typical of mature goblet/club cells. • Epithelial identity – EPCAM, CLDN10, CLDN22, TSPAN8, PROM1, ALPL confirm epithelial lineage; lack of basal‐cell keratins and down-loading of stress markers distinguish a differentiated rather than basal state. • Negative loadings (HSPB1, AQP3, FABP5, ID1, ID3, GPX2, LGALS3) are genes enriched in basal, stressed or undifferentiated airway/intestinal epithelia, consistent with their suppression in mature secretory cells. Inconsistencies: • HMGCS2, ALPL, CAPN9 and NPNT are more typical of intestinal or renal epithelia; their presence may reflect partial overlap of generic secretory/absorptive programs. • SCGB1A1 and club-cell genes coexist with classical goblet markers, indicating either a mixed secretory population or transitional states rather than a pure goblet cell identity.

program_6.description: The gene set depicts basal squamous epithelial cells that have activated a partial epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (pEMT)/wound-healing programme – a state seen in migrating edge keratinocytes and in many squamous carcinomas. Cells retain core basal-keratinocyte adhesion machinery yet up-regulate extracellular-matrix remodelling, cytoskeletal and TGF-β–responsive genes, while luminal/secretory epithelial markers are concurrently repressed. Evidence: • Basal squamous identity – TP63, KRT15/KRT13/KRT19, DSG3, DSC2/3, PKP1, COL17A1, ITGA6–ITGB4, LAMA3/LAMB3/LAMC2, CDH3, CLCA2. • Desmosome/hemidesmosome & basement-membrane components – DSP, DST, COL7A1, ITGB4, LAMB1/3, COL17A1. • pEMT / wound-response genes – FN1, VIM, TGFBI, TGFB1, PDPN, MMP13, PLAU, ITGAV/ITGB6, SPHK1, TNC, CXCL14, GAS6, GPNMB, LGALS1; matrix regulators TIMP1/3, SERPINE2, SERPINB13. • Motility / actin-remodelling – FSCN1, TAGLN, TAGLN2, MYL9, ACTN1, CALD1, MSN. • Suppression of differentiated secretory/luminal profile (negative loadings) – MUC1, WFDC2, S100P, ALDH1A1, SLC34A2, SERPINA1, PSCA, GPRC5A, SLPI, CP. Inconsistencies: • A few lineage-nonspecific or stromal genes appear (CD52, RNASE1, ACP5, C1S), likely reflecting ambient RNA or low-level expression rather than true cell identity.

program_7.description: The gene set reflects a differentiated airway secretory epithelial program, characteristic of club / goblet cells of the trachea-bronchial and upper airway mucosa that are actively producing mucins and other luminal antimicrobial proteins while lacking basal-cell and stress signatures. Evidence: • Mucin production – MUC1, MUC5AC, MUC16, MUC20, CST1, WFDC2, AGR2, XBP1 (ER folding of secretory proteins) are hallmarks of goblet/secretory epithelial cells. • Club-cell metabolism and xenobiotic enzymes – SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1, CYP2F1, CYP2B6, CYP2A6/7/13, HSD11B2, ALDH1A1, RDH10, NQO1, FBP1 define airway club cells that detoxify inhaled compounds. • Airway antimicrobial/immune defense – BPIFA1, BPIFB1, SLPI, LCN2, PIGR, CXCL17, DMBT1, LYPD2, VSIG2 are secreted innate-immunity factors enriched in respiratory epithelium. • Apical/luminal adhesion and differentiation markers – CEACAM5/6, PROM1, TSPAN1, ALCAM, ANPEP, EFEMP1, LGALS3 support a mature luminal epithelial identity. • Class I/II HLA genes (HLA-A/B/C/E/DRB5) and CD74 indicate epithelial antigen-presentation often seen in airway mucosa. • Negative loading of basal/stress markers – KRT15, CLCA2, CXCL14, CSTA, ID1, HSPB1, EPAS1, SCNN1G are suppressed, consistent with loss of basal-cell and hypoxic/stress programs during secretory differentiation. Inconsistencies: • Erythroid transcripts (HBB, HBA1, HBA2) likely ambient RNA contamination. • TNNC1 (muscle), GABRB2 (neuronal) are not typical of airway epithelium and may represent low-level background expression.

program_8.description: The gene set reflects an airway / alveolar secretory epithelial cell that has been strongly activated by interferon-γ, TNF and related inflammatory cues, acquiring an acute-phase, antigen-presenting and chemokine-secreting phenotype typical of epithelium exposed to viral or bacterial infection. Evidence: • Epithelial/secretory lineage: MUC5B, CEACAM7, DMBT1, CHI3L1, SCNN1G, SLC26A4, DUOXA2, CLDN10, SLC34A2, ALPL – genes characteristic of airway or distal lung secretory / ion-transporting epithelium. • Acute-phase & antimicrobial products: SAA1/2/4, LCN2, LTF, DEFB4A/B, PI3, FCGBP, PGLYRP4 – typical epithelial acute-phase response. • Interferon- and STAT-driven response: IDO1, ISG15, IFIT3, GBP5, PARP14, AIM2, BATF2/3, SOCS1/2, CD274 (PD-L1) – canonical IFN-γ–inducible genes. • Broad chemokine output recruiting neutrophils, monocytes and T cells: CXCL1/2/3/5/6/8 (IL-8 family), CXCL9/10/11, CCL20, CCL22, CXCL17, IL23A, IL17C. • Antigen presentation licensing: HLA-DPA1, HLA-DQA1, ICAM1 – epithelial cells up-regulating MHC-II and adhesion under IFN-γ. • Stress / oxidative defence: NOS2, SOD2, HSPA5, MT2A, RARRES1 – consistent with inflammatory oxidative stress. • Negative loadings (FABP5, CAV1, ALOX15, CYP4B1) are markers of resting club/alveolar epithelium, underscoring their down-regulation during activation. Inconsistencies: • KDR and MYL9 are more typical of endothelial or smooth-muscle expression, but can be induced in epithelium by cytokines. • AZGP1 is usually enriched in alveolar type II cells and may reflect mixed epithelial subtypes in the dataset, not the activation program itself.
