program_9.description: The program reflects an interferon-γ–licensed, highly antigen-presenting myeloid population—i.e., inflammatory / mature dendritic cells or M1-like macrophages—characterized by very high MHC-II expression, a broad interferon-stimulated gene (ISG) signature, and production of T-cell-recruiting chemokines (CXCL9/10/11) alongside immunomodulators such as IDO1 and NOS2. Evidence: • Antigen presentation: coordinated up-regulation of CIITA together with multiple MHC-II genes (HLA-DRA, DRB1, DPA1, DPB1, DQA1, DQB1, CD74) and MHC-I genes (HLA-A, ‑B, ‑C) is typical of activated dendritic cells / macrophages. • Interferon response: strong enrichment for classic ISGs (ISG15, IFI6, IFI27, IFI35, IFIT1/2/3, IFITM1/3, OAS1/3/L, MX1/2, RSAD2, BST2, GBP1-5, STAT1, PARP14, EPSTI1, XAF1) indicates recent IFN-γ/IFN-α signaling. • Inflammatory chemokines and cytokine signaling: CXCL9, CXCL10, CXCL11, TNFSF10 (TRAIL), CSF3 and IL32 are hallmarks of IFN-γ–activated myeloid cells that attract and activate T cells and neutrophils. • Maturation/activation markers for dendritic cells: LAMP3, CD83, IL4I1, BATF2 and IDO1 are well-described in mature, migratory DCs found in inflamed tissues and lymph nodes. • Myeloid lineage genes: HCK, AIF1, C1QA, SRGN, CD63, CD52 and ACP5 support a macrophage/DC identity. • Negative loadings for broadly expressed cytoskeletal genes (VIM, COTL1) are consistent with reduced motility/cytoskeletal remodeling seen after DC maturation. Inconsistencies: • Epithelial/secretory genes such as MUC5B, MMP7, SLC26A4, STATH and HAPLN3 are not canonical for myeloid cells and may represent low-level ambient RNA or mixed cell states. • Serum amyloid genes (SAA1/2/4) are chiefly hepatic but can be induced in other cells during inflammation; their presence is compatible but not specific.

program_10.description: The gene set is most consistent with an inflamed, mucus-secretory (goblet-like) epithelial program that has switched to glycolytic metabolism and is experiencing an interferon-driven stress response. Evidence: • Secretory/goblet machinery – CST1, MUC16, GALNT4 and LRRC26 are classic, highly expressed components of mucus-producing airway/intestinal epithelial cells; SERPINE2 and MMP28 reflect the ECM remodeling often accompanying goblet cell metaplasia. • Interferon/inflammatory stimulation – IFI6, IFITM1, IFITM3, HLA-DRB5 and CFB are canonical type-I/II interferon-inducible or antigen-presentation genes up-regulated in epithelial cells exposed to cytokines. • Glycolytic shift / hypoxia-like metabolism – Strong enrichment of glycolytic enzymes (ALDOA, PKM, TPI1, GAPDH, ASS1) together with negative loading of mitochondrial ETC / ribosomal genes (NDUFA11, MICOS10, MRPL23, MRPL12) indicates a metabolic switch from oxidative phosphorylation to glycolysis typical of inflamed epithelium. • Stress-adaptation modules – GABARAP (autophagy), LGALS3, AHNAK, S100A6 and MIF are broadly induced during epithelial stress, wound repair or cytokine exposure, fitting an activated, injury-responsive epithelial state. Inconsistencies: • Myeloid-associated genes such as LGALS3, CEBPD and ALOX15 are more typical of macrophages but can be induced in epithelial cells under inflammation; their presence slightly blurs the purely epithelial assignment. • Absence of classic goblet markers MUC2/MUC5AC or SPDEF means the program may represent a partial or early secretory transition rather than a fully differentiated goblet cell.

program_11.description: The program reflects a basal/squamous epithelial state that is shifting toward a motile, wound- or EMT-like phenotype: cells express classic basal keratinocyte and desmosomal genes (TP63, KRT16, ITGA6, DSG/DSC family) together with stress-responsive, extracellular-matrix remodelling and invasion genes (FSCN1, TNC, TGFB1, MMP28, THBS1) while actively repressing columnar/secretory epithelium markers (PIGR, TFF3). The accompanying up-regulation of glycolytic enzymes (GAPDH, LDHA/B, PKM, ENO1) and histones indicates high metabolic and proliferative activity typical of repairing or early-tumorigenic squamous cells. Evidence: • Basal/squamous identity – TP63, KRT16, ITGA6, CDH3, LGALS7/7B, SERPINB5, CLCA2, DSG3, DSC2/3, DSP, LAD1. • Cell-junction/hemidesmosome reinforcement – DSG3, DSC2/3, DSP, ITGA6, LAD1. • Motility/partial EMT & matrix remodelling – FSCN1, TNC, TGFB1, THBS1, MMP28, TIMP1, SERPINE2, PLAT, GPNMB. • Proliferation/metabolic re‐programming – CENPW, H1-3/4, H3C10 plus glycolytic genes GAPDH, LDHA/B, PKM, ENO1, ALDOA, TPI1. • Negative loading of secretory/columnar markers – PIGR, TFF3, VMO1, TMSB10 indicates loss of glandular/goblet features, supporting a squamous program. Inconsistencies: • S100A8 and GBP6 are typically myeloid/interferon-inducible genes. • AQP5 and CST1 are more characteristic of secretory epithelia. • CA2 is abundant in some glandular cells. These genes are few relative to the strong basal/squamous and EMT signature and may reflect microenvironmental signals or moderate contamination.

program_12.description: The gene constellation is most consistent with airway secretory (club/goblet) epithelial cells that have been acutely activated by pro-inflammatory cytokines (e.g., TNF-α / IL-1β), leading to a strong NF-κB/AP-1–driven response characterized by chemokine release and acute-phase proteins while some homeostatic club-cell genes are repressed. Evidence: • Secretory airway epithelial identity – SCGB1A1 (club-cell marker), MUC5B and AGR2 (goblet/secretory mucins), SFTPD (surfactant protein), B3GNT6, CLDN4/10 (tight-junction proteins enriched in airway epithelium). • Classic NF-κB / AP-1 immediate-early activation – FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB, ATF3, EGR1/2/3, NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, TNFAIP3, IER2/3; accompanied by stress-responsive phosphatases DUSP1/2/5 and CHOP pathway gene PPP1R15A. • Cytokine / chemokine burst characteristic of TNF / IL-1–stimulated epithelium – CXCL1/2/3/5/8, CXCL17, CSF1, CSF3, ICAM1, AREG, HBEGF, PTGS2, SOCS3, PLAU/PLAUR, EDN1. • Acute-phase & oxidative-stress proteins – SAA1, SAA2, GDF15, SLC6A14/20, SAT1, MAFF, GADD45B. • Negative loading of steady-state club-cell genes – FABP5 and ALDH3A1 decrease, fitting a switch from quiescent maintenance toward inflammatory activation. Inconsistencies: No major contradictions; the small number of negatively loaded genes (FABP5, ALDH3A1) align with repression of homeostatic club-cell functions rather than disputing the epithelial inflammatory program.

program_13.description: The gene set reflects a metabolically-active epithelial program dominated by oxidative phosphorylation and mitochondrial ribosome/translation components, indicative of epithelial cells in a high-energy, mildly proliferative state rather than a canonical stress- or immune-responsive phenotype. Evidence: • OXPHOS/mitochondrial biogenesis – numerous electron-transport and mitochondrial ribosomal genes (NDUFA11/13/9/7, ETFB, MRPL23/12/53, MRPS17, SLIRP, FMC1, TSFM) point to enhanced oxidative phosphorylation. • Proteostasis and bulk translation – proteasome subunits (PSMA1/2/4), translation factors (EIF4A1, EEF1E1, SRP19, EMG1) and RNA-pol II subunits (POLR2J/L) support globally elevated protein synthesis. • Epithelial identity – FGF7 (keratinocyte growth factor), FXYD3 and ATP1B1 (Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase β-subunit, enriched in epithelia), plus CRIP1 and CKLF, are typical of epithelial lineages. • Cell-cycle/replication support – CENPS and MPHOSPH9 hint at some proliferative activity without a full mitotic signature. • Negative loadings (LGALS3, ASS1, AKR1C2, B4GALT1) are genes often higher in glycolytic, inflammatory, or detoxification states, underscoring the shift toward an OXPHOS-centric epithelial program. Inconsistencies: • Absence of hallmark proliferation markers (e.g., MKI67) tempers the interpretation of an actively dividing state. • INSR and CKLF are broadly expressed across tissues, not strictly epithelial, and thus add limited lineage specificity.

program_14.description: The gene set is most consistent with a secretory/ductal epithelial program that has switched into an interferon-stimulated, injury-responsive state often seen in mucosal glands or airway/duct epithelia. Cells expressing it display core epithelial/secretory markers (KRT7, CLDN7, PSCA, AQP3/5, PIP, AZGP1, TCN1), enhanced lysosomal–autophagy and glycolytic genes, up-regulation of class-I antigen-presentation and interferon-response genes (IFITM1, LY6E, OAS1, HLA-C), and concurrent suppression of homeostatic club-cell and metallothionein oxidative-stress programs (SCGB1A1, MT1/2 family), indicating a stressed, antiviral ductal/serous epithelial state rather than a quiescent secretory cell. Evidence: • Epithelial / secretory identity – KRT7, CLDN7, AQP3, AQP5, PSCA, PIP, AZGP1, TCN1, GALNT4. • Secretory/lysosomal machinery – CTSD, CST3, SQSTM1, GABARAP, ATP6V0C, TIMP2, PNPLA2. • Interferon / antiviral activation – IFITM1, LY6E, OAS1, CFB, HLA-C, LGALS3. • Metabolic re-programming toward glycolysis – PKM, ALDOA, BCAT1, ASS1. • Negative loadings mark loss of homeostatic club-cell and metal-stress genes – SCGB1A1, CXCL14, and multiple MT1/2 isoforms, plus reduced oxidative-phosphorylation components (MICOS10, NDUFA11, EFHD1). Inconsistencies: • S100A4 (often fibroblast-associated) and EFHD2 (immune-cell enriched) are atypical for epithelial cells but can rise in stressed epithelia. • LGALS3 and CFB are also expressed by macrophages, yet their co-occurrence with strong epithelial markers suggests paracrine induction or low-level immune contamination.

program_15.description: The gene set is most consistent with airway secretory (club / early goblet) epithelial cells mounting a xenobiotic-detoxification and oxidative-stress response. Evidence: • Secretory/club cell identity – SCGB1A1 (classic club-cell secretoglobin), HEY1 (Notch target required for club-cell fate), CYP4B1 / CYP26A1, AADAC, ALDH3A1, FMO2 and MGST1 (lung-enriched phase-I/II detox enzymes typical of club cells), plus simple-epithelium keratins KRT8/18/19. • Mucus-producing/goblet bias – CST1, SERPINB3/B7, NTS and AQP5 are all up-regulated during the club-to-goblet transition. • Oxidative-stress / metal-handling program – MT1 family genes (MT1X/E/M/F/G/H), MT2A, PRDX1, TXN and CYBA, fitting the high-ROS environment of conducting airways. • General epithelial rather than immune/mesenchymal – negative loading of TMSB10, S100A4, SAT1 and B2M, which are abundant in fibroblasts, migratory cells or immune cells, supports an epithelial-specific program. Inconsistencies: • SERPINF1, IGFBP5 and MFAP2 are more typical of fibroblasts/ECM-secreting cells. • CD74 (MHC-II chaperone) is normally immune-restricted but can be induced in stressed epithelium; its presence is atypical yet occasionally reported in inflamed airway epithelium.

program_16.description: The gene set reflects a mature luminal/secretory epithelial program characterized by strong anti-oxidant and xenobiotic-detoxifying activity, typical of surface mucosal epithelia such as airway secretory cells or superficial urothelial “umbrella” cells. Evidence: • Epithelial identity – KRT18, KRT4, CTNNA1, ANXA2 and LGALS3 are canonical epithelial/luminal cytoskeletal and adhesion genes. • Secretory/apical features – AQP5 (water channel on apical membranes of mucosal glands and airway surface), WFDC2 (secretory whey-acidic protein of distal airway & gland epithelium), and UPK1B (urothelial/umbrella cell surface protein) point to differentiated surface-facing cells that handle fluid and protein secretion. • Detoxification/oxidative-stress module – GSTP1, NQO1, PRDX1, TXN, ALDH1A1, ALDH3A1, SELENBP1 and S100A6 are classic phase-I/II metabolic or redox buffering enzymes highly expressed in barrier epithelia exposed to xenobiotics (airway, bladder, ocular surface). • Differentiated, non-proliferative state – Negative loading of generic translational/proliferative genes (TPT1, TMSB10, EEF1A1, UBA52, EIF3L) and stromal/basal-cell ligands (FGF7, CXCL14, DMBT1) supports a terminally differentiated luminal compartment rather than basal or mesenchymal cells. Inconsistencies: • UPK1B is bladder-biased, whereas AQP5 and WFDC2 are airway/salivary gland biased, so the exact tissue source cannot be resolved from this gene subset alone. • Absence of hallmark club-cell genes (e.g., SCGB1A1) or urothelial KRT20 leaves some ambiguity regarding the precise epithelial subtype.

program_17.description: The gene signature is most consistent with a stratified-squamous epithelial/keratinocyte differentiation program (e.g., epidermal or mucosal suprabasal cells) rather than a secretory glandular epithelium. Evidence: • Keratinocyte / squamous markers – LGALS7, CALML3, SERPINB13, CLCA2, CLCA4 and TMEM40 are all highly enriched in suprabasal epidermal or other stratified-squamous epithelia. • Barrier and water-handling genes – AQP3 and CD9 are characteristic of differentiated, surface-exposed squamous layers that regulate hydration and cell–cell adhesion. • Stress/heat-shock component – HSPB1 is up-regulated in terminally differentiating keratinocytes that experience mechanical or osmotic stress in the outer layers. • Anti-secretory bias – Key genes typical of secretory/glandular epithelium (PIGR, VMO1, CP) are negatively loaded, reinforcing that the program represents a non-secretory, barrier epithelium. Inconsistencies: • HSPB1 and CD9 are not exclusive to squamous cells and can appear in other stressed or activated cell types. • AQP3 can also be expressed in some glandular epithelia, although its highest levels are in epidermal keratinocytes.

program_18.description: The gene set is most consistent with a differentiated secretory/absorptive intestinal (largely colonic) epithelial program that is simultaneously engaged in innate-immune defense, a state often seen in inflamed gut mucosa or infection. Evidence: • CEACAM5, CEACAM6 – classic apical markers of mature colon enterocytes/goblet cells and up-regulated in colonic inflammation and cancer. • MUC4, PI3 (elafin) – secreted mucin and protease inhibitor produced by mucus-secreting intestinal/airway epithelial cells during barrier defense. • DUOX2 + DUOXA2 – H₂O₂-generating oxidase complex strongly induced in intestinal epithelium by microbes and IFN-γ, hallmark of “antimicrobial enterocyte” state. • LCN2 – antimicrobial lipocalin highly secreted by inflamed gut epithelium and Paneth-like cells. • CD55 – complement-regulatory glycoprotein abundantly displayed on the luminal surface of intestinal epithelial cells. • C15orf48 (NMES1) and BCAT1 – genes frequently up-regulated in inflammatory bowel epithelium and metabolically active colonocytes, respectively. Inconsistencies: • LYNX1 is better known as a neuronal cholinergic modulator; its epithelial expression is limited, making it a weak fit with the overall intestinal program.

program_19.description: The program represents an acute “immediate-early” stress/activation state, driven by MAPK/AP-1 signaling and typically seen minutes–hours after cells (of many lineages) encounter pro-inflammatory cytokines, growth factors, tissue dissociation, or other stressors. Evidence: • Canonical immediate-early transcription factors FOS, ATF3, EGR1, MAFF and NR4A1 are hallmark AP-1/MAPK targets induced within minutes of stimulation. • Stress-responsive phosphatase and feedback regulators PPP1R15A (GADD34), DUSP1 and GADD45B provide negative feedback on MAPK and eIF2α pathways, characteristic of early stress responses. • Secreted early response genes CXCL8 (IL-8) and AREG are classical downstream products of AP-1 activation, released rapidly by many cell types after inflammatory or growth-factor cues. Inconsistencies: None obvious, as all listed genes fit a coherent immediate-early/stress-activation signature.

program_20.description: The gene set is most consistent with a KRT7⁺/LGALS3⁺ transitional alveolar epithelial program that appears during lung injury or development as alveolar type II cells convert into mature, AQP5-rich type I cells; the program couples epithelial identity with heightened glycolytic metabolism. Evidence: • Epithelial identity/transition – KRT7 is strongly induced in “KRT8/KRT7⁺ transitional” alveolar epithelial cells but absent from mature ATI/ATII macrophages. • Alveolar lineage – AQP5 is a canonical marker of alveolar type I cells and rises as transitional cells commit to the ATI fate. • Injury-associated intermediate state – LGALS3 is repeatedly noted in the same KRT7⁺ transitional population during lung repair and fibrosis. • High glycolytic flux – PKM and ALDOA are core glycolytic enzymes up-regulated in metabolically active, proliferative epithelial cells during regeneration. • Stress-detox pathways – AKR1C2, expressed in many epithelial tissues, is induced during oxidative/steroid stress accompanying epithelial remodeling. Inconsistencies: • LGALS3 is also abundant in macrophages, but the simultaneous presence of keratin (KRT7) and AQP5 strongly favors an epithelial, not immune, origin.

program_21.description: The program most strongly matches an activated fibroblast / stromal-mesenchymal state characterized by caveolae biogenesis, cytoskeletal remodeling and immune-modulatory secretory activity. Evidence: • Caveolae scaffold genes CAV1 and CAVIN1 are canonical markers of fibroblasts and other mesenchymal cells and are up-regulated when these cells become mechanically active. • Cytoskeletal/contractile regulators FLNA and CALD1 support actin cross-linking and tension generation, features of stressed or myofibroblast-like states. • LGALS1 (Galectin-1) is a well-known secreted lectin produced by activated fibroblasts that modulates extracellular matrix organization and local immune suppression. • Complement component C1S is synthesized by dermal and lung fibroblasts as part of their immune-surveillance and wound-healing functions. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes are clearly contradictory, although CAV1 and FLNA are also expressed in endothelial and smooth-muscle cells; absence of endothelial-specific genes (e.g., PECAM1, VWF) argues against a vascular endothelial identity.

program_22.description: The program most closely reflects squamous epithelial cells (e.g., keratinocytes or squamous-cell carcinoma cells) that have undergone a hypoxia- or inflammation-driven metabolic shift toward high glycolysis and extracellular-matrix remodeling, a state commonly seen in invasive or highly activated squamous epithelia. Evidence: • Metabolic re-wiring: ENO1, LDHA and TPI1 are core glycolytic enzymes up-regulated by HIF-1α and characteristic of the Warburg-type glycolytic program found in hypoxic or rapidly proliferating epithelial tumors. • Squamous epithelial identity/activation: SERPINB4 (also known as SCC antigen 2) is selectively expressed in differentiated or malignant squamous epithelia and is strongly induced by hypoxia and inflammatory cytokines. • Invasion / protease balance: PLAT (tissue plasminogen activator) promotes pericellular matrix degradation, while SERPINE2 counter-regulates plasmin activity; co-expression of both is typical of epithelial cells or tumors that remodel their surrounding matrix during invasion or wound repair. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes were supplied, so no internal contradictions can be evaluated.

program_23.description: The gene set reflects terminally differentiating suprabasal epidermal keratinocytes that are assembling the cornified envelope and simultaneously mounting a retinoic-acid / interferon-induced stress response. Evidence: • Keratinocyte structural maturation – PKP1 (desmosomal plaque protein enriched in stratified epithelia) and TGM1 (transglutaminase that cross-links cornified envelope proteins) are canonical markers of late epidermal differentiation. • Retinoid-responsive keratinocyte genes – CRABP2 (retinoic-acid binding protein) and RAET1L/ULBP6 (retinoic-acid early transcript family) support a retinoic-acid-driven differentiation program. • Interferon-/stress-induced component in epithelia – GBP6 is an interferon-stimulated guanylate-binding protein often up-regulated in keratinocytes during innate immune activation, consistent with RAET1L (NKG2D ligand) expression under epithelial stress. Inconsistencies: • No strongly discordant genes; GBP6 is more broadly interferon-responsive but is documented in keratinocytes during viral or cytokine exposure, so it is compatible with a stressed epidermal state.

program_24.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with a generic oxidative-/cytoskeletal-stress state that can be adopted by many cell types, characterized by up-regulation of redox buffering and actin-remodeling factors while global protein synthesis is dampened. Evidence: • Oxidative stress buffering – TXN (thioredoxin) is a canonical antioxidant that is rapidly induced when reactive oxygen species rise. • Actin–cytoskeleton remodeling – GSN (gelsolin) and S100A6 both bind Ca²⁺ and modulate actin filament dynamics, functions typically heightened during stress-induced shape change or motility. • Stress-linked translation down-shift – Negative loading of EEF1A1 (core elongation factor) and TPT1 (a translation regulator/anti-apoptotic protein) points to reduced global protein synthesis, a well-described arm of the integrated stress response. Inconsistencies: • No lineage-defining markers are present; therefore the program is state-specific rather than cell-type-specific and could coexist with diverse cellular identities.

program_25.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated/angiogenic vascular endothelial program that incorporates cytoskeletal and adhesion changes typical of endothelial cells responding to shear-stress or sprouting cues. Evidence: • Endothelial identity – RNASE1 is a highly selective marker of blood-vessel endothelial cells and is strongly induced by shear stress. • Angiogenic/adhesion component – EMP2 promotes integrin-mediated adhesion and angiogenesis in endothelial monolayers. • Contractile/cytoskeletal shift – MYL9 encodes myosin regulatory light chain 9, whose up-regulation in endothelial cells accompanies stress-fiber formation during migration or partial endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition. • Metal-ion & metabolic support – SLC39A8 (ZIP8) is up-regulated in endothelium to import Zn2+/Mn2+ during angiogenesis and inflammatory activation. • Hippo/YAP signaling modulation – WWC2, a Hippo pathway scaffold, is expressed in endothelium and regulates barrier integrity and sprouting. Inconsistencies: • MYL9 is classically abundant in vascular smooth-muscle cells; its presence here is best explained by the well-described induction of contractile genes in activated or transitioning endothelial cells, but it could also indicate minor mural-cell contamination.

program_26.description: The gene set is most consistent with a metabolically active, TP63-positive basal/squamous epithelial cell state characterized by high glycolytic flux—typical of proliferating basal keratinocytes or squamous epithelial progenitors. Evidence: • TP63 – master regulator of basal and squamous epithelial identity; marks undifferentiated keratinocytes and airway basal stem cells. • ENO1, TPI1, LDHA – core glycolytic enzymes whose concerted up-regulation denotes a “Warburg-like” high-glycolysis metabolic program frequently seen in dividing epithelial progenitors and squamous carcinomas. • SLC25A5 (ANT2) – mitochondrial ADP/ATP carrier enriched in rapidly proliferating, glycolysis-biased cells to shuttle ATP/ADP across the mitochondrial membrane. Inconsistencies: No notable genes in the list conflict with a glycolytic, TP63-positive basal epithelial program.

program_0.description: The gene set is most consistent with an “inflammatory-activated myofibroblast” program—i.e., fibroblasts that have up-regulated classic extracellular-matrix genes but are simultaneously responding to pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1/TNF) and cellular stress. Evidence: • Fibroblast / myofibroblast identity – Structural matrix genes: COL1A1/2, COL3A1, COL6A1/2/3, ELN, DCN, BGN, LUM, PCOLCE – Contractile/activated marker: ACTA2 (α-SMA) – Fibroblast-enriched regulators: CCDC80, IGFBP4/6, SFRP2, SERPING1, SERPINH1 • Inflammatory activation (NF-κB / AP-1, IL-1/TNF stimulation) – Cytokines/chemokines: IL1A, IL1B, IL6, IL10, TNF, IL23A, CXCL1/2/3/8, CCL2/3/4/19 – NF-κB targets/inhibitors: NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, TNFAIP3, BCL2A1, ICAM1 – Immediate-early/AP-1 genes: FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUND, ATF3, EGR1/2/3/4, NR4A1/2 – Stress-response chaperones: HSPA1A/B, HSP90AA1/AB1, HSPH1, DNAJ family, BAG3 • Cellular stress / UPR component – HSPA5, HSPD1, DDIT3, PPP1R15A, MLKL, HMOX1 indicate oxidative and ER stress accompanying activation. • Negative loadings fit the model – Suppressed genes (SPP1, AREG, CHI3L1, AIF1) are typically higher in alternative macrophages or epithelial cells, not fibroblasts, supporting a fibroblast-specific program. Inconsistencies: • Presence of some immune-cell markers (CYBB, CSF3R, FCAR, CD22, CD52, GNLY) and MBP may reflect low-level contamination or rare doublets rather than core program genes. • Heat-shock genes are ubiquitous and do not on their own define fibroblasts, but their co-expression with ECM and cytokine modules supports a general stress response rather than contradicting the assignment.

program_1.description: The gene set represents a strongly NF-κB–driven, pro-inflammatory activation program characteristic of circulating classical monocytes differentiating toward M1-like / inflammatory macrophages or monocyte-derived dendritic cells after acute TLR/LPS stimulation. Evidence: • Core NF-κB–responsive cytokines/chemokines: IL1B, IL6, IL23A, CXCL1/2/3/8, CCL20, TNFAIP2/3, NFKBIA, NFKB1, REL, MAP3K8, IRAK2. • Monocyte/macrophage lineage markers: LYZ, FCN1, ITGAX (CD11c), ANPEP (CD13), CD14, CD44, VCAN, OLR1, CCRL2, TREM1. • M1/inflammatory macrophage genes: NOS-pathway cofactor KYNU, inducible glycolysis switch PFKFB3, NAMPT, SLC2A3 (GLUT3), OSM, SERPINB2, PTGS2, NLRP3, S100A8/A9, PLAUR, MMP9. • Anti-apoptotic and stress-response genes typical of LPS-activated monocytes: BCL2A1, MCL1, CFLAR, DDIT4, SOD2, VEGFA, HBEGF. • Negative loading of tissue-resident/anti-inflammatory (“M2-like”) or homeostatic macrophage genes: CD163, MS4A6A, STAB1, F13A1, LYVE1, TSC22D3, TXNIP, GPX1, DAB2, CAPG. Their suppression is expected during an acute M1 shift. Inconsistencies: • CCR7 (positive) and its ligand CCL19 (negative) suggest partial overlap with mature inflammatory dendritic cells. • Presence of neutrophil granule genes ELANE and MMP8 (if expressed) and airway-epithelial genes BPIFA1/BPIFB1 may indicate minor contamination or co-regulation rather than the core monocyte program.

program_2.description: The gene set reflects a TREM2⁺, APOE⁺ lipid-handling (foamy) macrophage program typical of alternatively activated, tissue-resident macrophages found in lipid-rich or remodeling environments such as adipose tissue, atherosclerotic plaque, tumor stroma or healing wounds; monocyte-associated genes are concurrently repressed, indicating a differentiated resident state rather than an inflammatory monocyte profile. Evidence: • Lipid uptake / metabolism signature: APOE, APOC1, APOC2, LPL, PLIN2, PPARG, ABCG1, CYP27A1, NR1H3, FABP4/5, ANGPTL4 – hallmark of foamy, lipid-associated macrophages. • TREM2-dependent resident macrophage module: TREM2, MSR1, LGALS3, CD9, CD63, CD81, LAMP1, CTSB/L, ATP6V1F – seen in adipose and tumor-associated lipid-laden macrophages and microglia-like cells. • M2 / immunoregulatory markers: MRC1 (CD206), CCL18, VSIG4, SIGLEC1, ALOX5AP, CXCL16, CSF1 – consistent with alternatively activated, tissue-repair phenotype. • Enhanced lysosome / osteoclast-like remodeling machinery: CTSK, CTSC, LGMN, DCSTAMP, ATP6V0D2, ACP2, MMP7/19, SPP1 – supports active phagolysosomal digestion and matrix remodeling common in foamy/osteoclast-like macrophages. • Negative loading of classical monocyte / inflammatory DC genes: FCN1, FPR1, LST1, CLEC9A, SRGN, LYZ, MNDA – indicates suppression of circulating-monocyte identity and inflammatory programs. Inconsistencies: • Presence of IL6, CXCL1, CXCL5, CCL2 suggests some pro-inflammatory cytokine production. • IL7R (lymphoid), AGRP, OTOA, GLDN and a few other tissue-restricted transcripts are atypical for macrophages and may reflect low-level ambient RNA or mis-assignment.

program_3.description: The gene set represents a tissue-resident, alternatively activated (M2-like) macrophage program typified by LYVE1⁺/MRC1⁺/FOLR2⁺/CD163⁺ macrophages that engage in phagocytosis, iron and lipid handling, immune-suppressive signaling and vascular/homeostatic support, while expressly lacking the FCN1/S100A8/S100A9 inflammatory-monocyte signature. Evidence: • Core resident‐macrophage receptors – MRC1 (CD206), CD163, FOLR2, SIGLEC1, MSR1, VSIG4, STAB1, CSF1R, CD209, LYVE1, TREM2, MERTK, CLEC10A, MS4A4A denote non-migratory, phagocytic tissue macrophages. • M2/alternative-activation & wound-repair markers – CCL18, CCL13, IL13RA1, ALOX5AP, IGF1, MAF, GAS6, TGFBI, NR1H3, APOE, SLC40A1, F13A1, PDGFC support an anti-inflammatory, reparative state. • Lipid/iron metabolism & lysosomal genes – APOE, LIPA, LAMP1, NPC2, CTSB/L/Z, PLTP, SCD, GPX1, FTL/FTH1, IDH1, GLUL, A2M reflect cholesterol handling and oxidative stress control typical of resident macrophages. • Endothelial/vascular association – LYVE1, ALCAM, NRP1, ECM1, ITGB5, MMP14, FN1 align with perivascular “LYVE1⁺ macrophages” described in lung, heart and adipose tissue. • Negative load of inflammatory-monocyte genes – FCN1, S100A8, S100A9, LST1, COTL1, CD48 underscores exclusion of classical FCN1⁺/S100A8⁺ pro-inflammatory monocytes. Inconsistencies: • Interferon-stimulated genes (IFI27, IFIT1, IFIT3) suggest some concomitant IFN signaling not typical of classical M2 macrophages. • Low-level T-cell/lymphoid markers (IL2RA, CD28, KCNA3) and neuronal-associated transcripts (SCN9A, SLC12A5) are atypical and may reflect ambient RNA or doublets.

program_4.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, angiogenic lung endothelial-cell program that is beginning a partial endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndMT), characterized by strong endothelial identity, hypoxia/angiogenic signalling and de-novo extracellular-matrix production, while anti-angiogenic THBS1 is suppressed. Evidence: • Core endothelial identity – CLDN5, PECAM1, VWF, CDH5, ESAM, ENG, PTPRB, ACVRL1, NOTCH4, EPAS1, CLEC14A, RAMP2/CALCRL, ECSCR. • Angiogenic / hypoxic response – EPAS1 (HIF-2α), ID1/ID3, RAMP2, CALCRL, VEGF-associated EGFL7, TFPI, PLA2G2A; negative loading of THBS1 (anti-angiogenic) supports pro-angiogenic state. • EndMT / mesenchymal shift – induction of ACTA2, TAGLN, MYL9, TPM1/2, COL1A1/1A2/3A1/6A1/6A2, FN1, SPARC, LUM, DCN, TIMP3, MMP2, SERPINF1, CCN1/2, AEBP1, indicating extracellular-matrix synthesis and smooth-muscle–like contractile machinery. • Vascular basement-membrane and pericyte interaction genes – CAV1/2, CAVIN1/2/3, HSPG2, LAMB2, COL4A1 (implicit in COL4 genes), BCAM, ENG, supporting vessel-wall remodelling. • Suppressed anti-angiogenic gene – THBS1 is negatively loaded, fitting an angiogenic activation program. Inconsistencies: • Alveolar epithelial markers (SFTPA1, SFTPA2, SFTA2, NAPSA, SLC34A2, AGER) suggest some epithelial transcript contamination or a mixed cell population. • Cytotoxic / immune transcripts (GNLY, GZMA/H, CCL3/4/5, CD247) point to minor T-cell or NK-cell signal bleed-through. • Presence of smooth-muscle genes could alternatively indicate pericyte admixture rather than true EndMT.

program_5.description: The gene set describes a conventional dendritic-cell program most consistent with human CD1c⁺/FCER1A⁺ cDC2 (sometimes termed cDC3 when they co-express macrophage genes) in a tissue-resident, immunoregulatory state characterized by high MHC-II presentation capacity and low inflammatory-monocyte signature. Evidence: • Antigen presentation machinery – strong enrichment of MHC-II genes (HLA-DMA, ‑DMB, ‑DRB5, ‑DQA2, ‑DQB2) together with CIITA, CD80 and CD276 indicates professional APCs. • Canonical cDC2 markers – FCER1A, CLEC10A (CD301), CD1C, CD1A/B/E, CCR6, FCGR2B, CD9 and ALCAM align with established CD1c⁺ dendritic cells. • Tissue-resident / tolerogenic bias – MRC1 (CD206), FOLR2, TREM2, AXL, GAS6, IGF1, CXCL12, SERPINF1, ALOX15 and SELENOP are typical of anti-inflammatory, tissue DC/macrophage programs. • Migratory / chemokine receptor profile – CXCR4, GPR34, GPR183 and P2RY14 are found in tissue-migratory DCs. • Negative loading of inflammatory-monocyte genes – S100A8, S100A9, S100A12, FCN1, VCAN, FPR2, CTSS and CSTA are hallmarks of classical and inflammatory monocytes; their inverse association underscores that the program is distinct from those cells. Inconsistencies: • Macrophage-associated genes such as TREM2, ALOX5AP and SERPINF1 could signify partial monocyte-to-DC differentiation (cDC3) rather than “pure” cDC2. • Absence of some classical cDC2 transcription factors (e.g., IRF4) and presence of platelet-derived growth factor PDGFB and stromal genes (COL9A2) are peripheral to a dendritic-cell identity but do not outweigh the dominant cDC2 signature.

program_6.description: The program reflects an injured / regenerative lung epithelial state dominated by KRT8⁺/KRT17⁺ transitional alveolar epithelial cells that arise from type II pneumocytes and acquire mixed airway-secretory features while beginning to express some type I markers. These cells appear during alveolar repair and fibrosis and are distinct from macrophages, which are actively excluded in this program. Evidence: • Transitional AT2→AT1 identity – Concurrent surfactant/type II genes (SFTPA1/2, SFTPD, SFTA2, ABCA3, NAPSA) and emerging type I markers (AGER, HOPX, CLDN4) together with high KRT8, KRT17, KRT18, KRT19 and TACSTD2, a signature described for “KRT8⁺/CLDN4⁺ pre-alveolar type-1 transitional cells (PATS)”. • Airway/secretory & injury response traits – Club/secretory genes SCGB3A1, SCGB3A2, MUC1, BPIFA1/BPIFB1, PIGR, LCN2, CXCL17, MMP10 and mucin MUC5B indicate acquisition of airway-like secretory programs typical of injured alveolar epithelium. – Stress-response and proliferation genes CCND1, ID1, SFN, SERPINB3, NNMT further support a repair phenotype. • Epithelial lineage and adhesion markers – High EPCAM, ELF3, TSPAN1, FXYD3, CLDN7, CD24, BCAM underscore epithelial origin. • Negative loading of macrophage genes – Classical macrophage markers CD163, CD68, IL1R2 are negatively weighted, confirming the program is epithelial rather than myeloid. Inconsistencies: • Sporadic ciliated-cell genes (RSPH1, CFAP276, CFAP144) and mast-cell products (TPSB2, CPA3), plus erythroid transcripts (HBA1/2, HBB), likely reflect ambient RNA or minor contamination rather than core program features.

program_7.description: This gene program is the canonical S-phase/G2-M cell-cycle proliferation module, marking cells that are actively replicating DNA, assembling the mitotic spindle and undergoing chromosome segregation; its negative loadings suggest that this cycling state is mutually exclusive with terminally differentiated myeloid (granulocyte/monocyte) cells. Evidence: • Core proliferation markers – MKI67, PCNA, FOXM1, UBE2C, BIRC5 – universally up-regulated in dividing cells. • DNA replication/S-phase machinery – MCM2-7, ORC6, CDT1, RFC4, RRM1/2, TYMS, TK1, DHFR, PRIM1, LIG1, GMNN, DNMT1. • G2-M cyclins and kinases – CCNA2, CCNB1/2, CDK1, PLK1, AURKA/B, PKMYT1. • Mitotic spindle/kinetochore complexes – KIF11/14/15/20B/23, TPX2, NDC80, NUF2, SPC25, CENP family members (CENPA-U), BUB1/BUB1B, MAD2L1, SGO1/2, TOP2A, PRC1, ANLN. • Chromatin/histone assembly – H2AX, H2AZ1/2, H4C3, ASF1B, UHRF1, HELLS. • Negative loadings (ACSL1, LYZ, S100A12, CLEC4E, CSF3R, FCAR) are hallmark genes of mature neutrophils/monocytes, highlighting their depletion when the proliferation program is active. Inconsistencies: • A few positively loaded immune genes (FCGR2B, CLEC10A) are not classical cell-cycle factors, suggesting mild cell-type–specific noise. • Stress-response gene HSPB1 is not directly linked to cell division but can rise during rapid proliferation.

program_8.description: The gene set is most consistent with a classical (CD14++ CCR2+) inflammatory monocyte program marked by strong alarmin expression and early antimicrobial activation, coupled with reduced antigen-presentation and CD16‐associated features. Evidence: • Classical/inflammatory monocyte core – CD14, CCR2, FCN1, VCAN, VSIR, CLEC4E/D, CD36, CTSS, CEBPD, GMFG, RETN and high S100A8/S100A9/S100A12 are canonical for CD14++ CCR2+ monocytes that dominate acute inflammatory responses. • Antimicrobial/degranulation profile – ELANE, RNASE2/3, PADI4, FPR1/2, CSF3R, NAIP, NLRP12, SERPINB1/B10, MPO-related pathways (ELANE) reflect early granule release and inflammasome readiness typical of activated inflammatory monocytes. • Down-regulation of non-classical/APC signatures – Negative loading of FCGR3A (CD16), MS4A7, BLNK, CALHM6 and multiple MHC-II genes (HLA-DMA, HLA-DOA) indicates suppression of the CD16+ patrolling or antigen-presenting monocyte program, reinforcing a classical identity. Inconsistencies: • Neutrophil/eosinophil granule genes (ELANE, RNASE3) and the cytotoxic marker NKG7 suggest minor neutrophil/eosinophil contamination or shared myeloid activation modules. • FLT3 and BLNK (usually in dendritic progenitors/B cells) and low-level ISG15 (interferon-response) in the negative set are not typical for classical monocytes but are low enough not to override the dominant signature.

program_9.description: The program fits classical plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) in a partially activated / interferon-primed state, characterized by their lineage-defining transcription factors, BDCA2/ILT7 surface receptors, high secretory capacity and class-II antigen-presentation machinery, while showing suppression of monocyte/macrophage genes. Evidence: • Lineage markers of pDCs – CLEC4C (BDCA2), LILRA4 (ILT7), TCF4 (E2-2), SPIB, IRF7/8, BCL11A, BLNK, PTPRS. • Secretory/ER stress genes common in pDCs – JCHAIN, MZB1, DERL3, SEL1L3, UGCG, SERPINF1, TXNDC5. • Interferon/activation components – IRF7, IDO1, CXCR3, CXCR4, CCR7, GZMB, TRAF4, WDFY4. • Antigen-presentation and migratory genes – HLA-DMA, HLA-DMB, SELL, GPR183, XCR1, CD24. • Negative loading of monocyte/macrophage core set (FTL, FTH1, AIF1, TYROBP, FCN1, S100A8, FCER1G, LILRA1) rules out classical monocytes and underscores pDC specificity. Inconsistencies: • PTCRA and RUNX2 are atypical for pDCs (more common in early T-cell or osteogenic programs). • XCR1 is classically cDC1-associated, though low-level expression can appear in activated pDCs. • BLK and POU2AF1 are B-cell genes but are variably expressed in human pDCs and thus not contradictory.

program_10.description: The gene set defines an inflammatory, interferon-stimulated monocyte / macrophage state (M1-like, CD14⁺/FCGR3A⁺), characterized by heightened antimicrobial, Fc-receptor and complement activity and concurrent down-regulation of markers of alternatively-activated (M2/resident) macrophages. Evidence: • Core monocyte / macrophage identity: CD14, FCGR1A (CD64), FCGR3A, TYROBP, LST1, FCN1, CTSS, C5AR1, LILRB1/2, VSIR, AIF1, CFD, PECAM1. • Pro-inflammatory / interferon response genes: IFITM1/2/3, APOBEC3A, WARS1, TNFSF10, CASP5, DDIT4, NAMPT, RIPOR2, SAT1. • Chemotaxis and microbial-sensing repertoire typical of recruited inflammatory monocytes: CCR2, CX3CR1, FPR1/2, CLEC4E, COTL1, S100A9, LTA4H. • Complement / Fc-effector machinery: FCGR3A/B, FCER1G, CFD, CFP, C5AR1. • Suppression of M2 / tissue-resident programs (negatively loaded): MRC1 (CD206), CD9, ALCAM, VIM, DAB2, ALOX15, FABP5, RGCC, ALOX5AP. Inconsistencies: • Neutrophil-biased transcripts (FCGR3B, CEACAM3) and epithelial/goblet cell genes (SCGB3A2, ITLN1, ZG16B, VMO1) appear in the positive list, suggesting minor cross-cell contamination or shared inflammatory transcripts rather than true lineage identity. • Endothelial-associated PECAM1 and progenitor marker FLT3 are present but can occasionally be expressed in activated monocytes; their inclusion is not central to the program.

program_11.description: The program most closely matches mature, migratory (CCR7⁺ LAMP3⁺) conventional dendritic cells, particularly the IRF4-dependent cDC2/LAMP3 subset that has reached lymph-node–draining tissues and displays an immunoregulatory phenotype. Evidence: • Migration / maturation signature – CCR7, LAMP3, FSCN1, CD83, CD40, CD80, CCL19 and the lymph-node‐homing chemokines CCL17 & CCL22 are hallmarks of mature, tissue-emigrating DCs. • Antigen-presentation machinery – High expression of multiple MHC-II chains (HLA-DQA2, DRB5, DQB2, DOB) and CD1 family members (CD1A/B/C/E) together with CD207 (Langerin) is typical of professional APCs and enriched in cDC2-derived LAMP3⁺ DCs. • Lineage-defining TFs – IRF4, SPIB, RUNX3, ZBTB46, ID2 and BCL11A drive/corroborate cDC lineage and maturation. • T-cell–modulatory / tolerogenic factors – IDO1, IL4I1, AXL, SERPINF1 and REL together with chemokines above are characteristic of regulatory LAMP3⁺ DCs observed in inflamed tissue and tumour micro-environments. • Down-weighting of monocyte / immature myeloid genes – Negative loadings for S100A6, S100A4, FTL, FCER1G, CTSS and PSAP match the loss of monocytic and lysosomal signatures during DC maturation. Inconsistencies: • Classical T-cell genes (CTLA4, TNFRSF4/OX40, TNFRSF9/4-1BB, TNFRSF18/GITR, TOX, CD5, IL7R) and the B-cell gene CD79A are atypical for DCs and may reflect low-level ambient RNA or doublets. • CXCL9, GBP1 and other interferon-response genes suggest a concurrent IFN stimulus but are not specific for migratory DCs.

program_12.description: The gene set reflects a strongly NF-κB–driven, classically activated (M1-like) inflammatory program typical of monocytes / macrophages that have encountered microbial or TNF/IL-1 signals, characterized by massive production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, matrix-remodelling enzymes and the canonical negative-feedback regulators of the NF-κB pathway. Evidence: • Cytokines/chemokines: IL1A, IL1B, IL6, IL23A, TNF, CXCL1/2/3/5/8, CCL3/3L3/4/4L2, CCL20, CSF3, OSM – hallmark secretory profile of activated myeloid cells. • NF-κB signalling core: NFKB1, REL, NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, TNFAIP3, TNIP1/3, IRAK2, TRAF1, LITAF, KDM6B – classic LPS/TLR-induced cascade. • Myeloid / monocyte markers: TREM1, OLR1, GPR84, ICAM1, CD44, AQP9, PLEK, CCRL2, SLAMF1/7 – enriched in inflammatory monocytes/macrophages. • Effector and stress genes: PTGS2, MMP9/10/19, SPHK1, SOD2, FTH1, G0S2, PPP1R15A, HCAR3 – typical of oxidative, metabolic and matrix-remodelling responses seen in M1 cells. • Anti-inflammatory feedback: IL1RN, IL10, TNFAIP6, BIRC3, C15orf48 – consistent with late-phase NF-κB feedback found in activated macrophages. • Negative loadings of TXNIP, ZFP36L2 and CST3 (genes that restrain or mark quiescent myeloid cells) further point to a shift toward a highly activated state. Inconsistencies: • Epithelial/secretory genes (MUC5B, BPIFA1, BPIFB1, KRT17, ZP3, MSMB) and T-cell–associated receptors (TNFRSF4/9/18, LRRC32) appear sporadically and are not typical of macrophages, suggesting minor contamination or that the program was de-convoluted across multiple cell types rather than a pure lineage signature.

program_13.description: The gene set reflects an activated cytotoxic CD8⁺ T-cell / NK-like effector program, characteristic of peripheral or tissue-resident cytotoxic lymphocytes engaged in target-cell killing and inflammatory cytokine production. Evidence: • Cytotoxic effector molecules – GNLY, PRF1, GZMA/B/H/K/M, CTSW, NKG7, FGFBP2, CST7 indicate perforin/granzyme-mediated killing typical of CD8⁺ T and NK cells. • T-cell receptor and signalling components – CD3D/E/G, CD247, CD2, CD7, ZAP70, LCK, LAT, ITK, RASGRP1, SKAP1 support a T-lineage identity. • CD8 lineage markers – CD8A, CD8B, CD96, CD6, CD27 together with the Th1/Tc1 transcription factor TBX21 and cytokine IFNG denote activated CD8⁺ cytotoxic T cells. • NK receptors and aids – KLRD1 (CD94), KLRF1, KLRG1, NCR3, S1PR5 highlight NK-like features often up-regulated in terminally differentiated effector CD8⁺ T cells. • Chemokines/chemokine receptors driving cytotoxic trafficking – CCL3, CCL4, CCL5, XCL1/2, CXCR4, CCL21 promote recruitment to inflamed tissues. • Low ferritin genes (negative load of FTL, FTH1) fit the iron-poor metabolic profile of lymphocytes compared with myeloid cells. Inconsistencies: • B-cell genes (MS4A1/CD20, CD79A, CD22, BANK1, TNFRSF13C) and mast-cell markers (TPSAB1, TPSB2, CPA3, GATA2) are atypical for cytotoxic T/NK cells and may reflect ambient RNA or doublets. • Stromal/ECM genes (MGP, FBLN1, SPOCK2) are not typically expressed by lymphocytes.

program_14.description: The gene set reflects classically activated (M1-like) inflammatory monocytes / macrophages experiencing a strong type I/II interferon response and up-regulating antigen-presentation machinery. Evidence: • Interferon-stimulated genes: IFITM1/2/3, IFIT1-3, OAS1/2/3, ISG15, RSAD2, MX1, USP18, STAT1, IRF1, EIF2AK2, PARP9/14, DDX60, SAMD9L indicate robust type I/II IFN signaling. • Pro-inflammatory chemokines CXCL9, CXCL10, CXCL11 and cytokine-related genes TNFSF10, TNFSF13B, IL27, EBI3 typify IFN-γ–licensed (M1) myeloid cells. • Antigen presentation: strong MHC-I components (HLA-A/B/C/E, TAP1, PSMB9, PSME2, B2M) and immunoproteasome genes reflect IFN-driven enhancement of cross-presentation. • Myeloid/monocyte markers: FCGR3A (CD16), FCGR1A (CD64), LILRB1, LST1, AIF1, CTSS, CD48, CD52, CFP/LAP3, CST3, SLAMF7/8 confirm monocyte-macrophage identity. • Negative loading of MRC1 (CD206) together with down-weighted VIM and CALM1 fits repression of alternative (M2) macrophage programs during classical activation. Inconsistencies: • SERPINA1 and FGL2 are more typical of tissue (e.g., liver) or regulatory macrophages but are also inducible by IFN, so only mildly discordant. • FCER1G is shared with dendritic cells, yet is frequently co-expressed in inflammatory monocytes.

program_15.description: Gene loading points to conventional type-2 dendritic cells (cDC2; CD1c⁺ FCER1A⁺ DCs) in an activated / antigen-presenting state that is distinct from monocytes. Evidence: • Core cDC2 identity – FCER1A, CD1C, CD1A/E, CLEC10A, CCR6, IRF4, LSP1 and ZBTB46 are canonical for CD1c⁺ cDC2. • Dendritic-cell lineage factors – BTLA, CADM1, AXL, JAML, CPVL and SERPINF1 are enriched in classical DCs or AXL⁺ pre-/migratory DCs but not in monocytes. • Antigen presentation machinery – broad up-regulation of HLA-D (DQA2, DQB2, DMA, DMB, DOB, DOA, DRB5), B2M, CD69 and CCR6 indicates mature DCs ready for T-cell interaction. • Negative loadings mark exclusion of monocytes – FTH1, FTL, C5AR1, S100A4/A6 and PSAP are typical of monocytes/macrophages and are down-weighted, underscoring a DC rather than monocyte program. Inconsistencies: • A few cDC1-leaning genes (CLEC9A, XCR1) and the Langerhans marker CD207 suggest minor overlap with other DC subsets. • Low-level epithelial/other transcripts (KRT15, CLDN1, COL9A2, GHRL) could reflect ambient RNA or rare contaminating cells.

program_16.description: The program most strongly marks classical monocyte / macrophage‐lineage cells that have initiated an early inflammatory-phagocytic response (e.g. TLR- or LPS-stimulated CD14⁺ monocytes). Evidence: • Myeloid identity – SPI1 (PU.1), CD14, LILRB1, CYBB, NCF1, PTPRCAP, CST3 and TNFSF13 are hallmark genes of blood monocytes and macrophages. • Phagocytosis / oxidative burst – CYBB and NCF1 encode the catalytic and regulatory subunits of the NADPH oxidase; MAN2B1, PSAP, GNPTG and PSMA6/PSMB10 indicate active lysosome- and proteasome-mediated degradation. • Early inflammatory activation – FOS, DUSP1, IER2, ZFP36/ZFP36L2, RHOB and TXNIP are rapid-response genes induced by TLR or cytokine stimulation. • Metabolic / stress re-programming – EIF4EBP3, TXNIP, SEPHS2 and multiple histone H1/H2 variants reflect chromatin and translational remodeling that accompanies acute activation, while negative loading of mitochondrial ETC genes (NDUFB8, NDUFC2) is consistent with the glycolytic shift of activated monocytes. • Immune effector support – IFITM1 (innate antiviral), PSMB10 (immunoproteasome), TNFSF13 (APRIL) and CYBB together outline a cell prepared for antigen processing and antimicrobial functions. Inconsistencies: • GIMAP5 (lymphocyte survival factor) and KLF2 (typically higher in quiescent endothelial or non-classical monocytes) are less characteristic of acutely activated classical monocytes. • The down-weighted actin regulator TMSB4X is usually abundant in resting leukocytes, but its negative loading is still compatible with activation-driven cytoskeletal remodeling rather than being contradictory.

program_17.description: The gene set represents an activated fibroblast / cancer-associated fibroblast (CAF) program characterized by extracellular-matrix (ECM) production, cytoskeletal re-organization and wound-healing/remodeling functions. Evidence: • ECM synthesis and remodeling – COL3A1, COL6A2, FN1, LUM, FBLN1, PCOLCE, CCDC80, C1S denote fibroblast-derived interstitial matrix and complement secretion typical of stromal cells. • Fibroblast/CAF markers – NNMT, CCDC80, PLA2G2A, IGFBP6 and DEPP1 are repeatedly enriched in single-cell profiles of CAFs in tumors and activated dermal/organ fibroblasts during repair. • Cytoskeletal and contractile machinery – VIM, TAGLN2, PDLIM1, CFL1, TMSB4X/10, ANXA2, S100A10, HSPB1 support actin remodeling and stress-fiber formation found in motile, matrix-depositing fibroblasts/myofibroblasts. • Cell–matrix/adhesion molecules – CD9, EMP1/3, CRIP1/2, CAVIN3 facilitate adhesion, migration and caveolae signaling in stromal cells. • Secretory/transport components – AQP3, CAVIN3, PLA2G2A reflect enhanced secretory activity of activated fibroblasts during tissue remodeling. Inconsistencies: • CLDN7 and AQP3 are more typical of epithelial cells, and their presence suggests either partial epithelial–mesenchymal transition or contaminating epithelial transcripts. • The gene list lacks classical smooth-muscle myofibroblast markers (e.g., ACTA2, TAGLN1), indicating a fibroblast activation state short of full myofibroblast differentiation.

program_18.description: The gene set is most consistent with a generic “proliferation/replication” program that marks cells in S-phase and/or a metabolically active cycling state rather than a lineage-restricted cell identity. Evidence: • S-phase / DNA-replication genes – TIPIN (replication-fork protection) and the replication-coupled histone variant H3-5 rise during S-phase. • Chromatin/RNA processing factors required in dividing cells – HNRNPA1L2 (pre-mRNA processing), NACA2 (nascent-polypeptide–associated complex) and ZNF90 (transcription factor). • Mitochondrial oxidative-phosphorylation subunits – ATP5MGL (ATP synthase) and UQCRHL (complex III) are typically co-induced with cell-cycle programs to meet increased ATP demand. • Additional housekeeping/vesicle or cytoskeletal regulators often up in growing cells – NBEAL1 and NHSL2. • Net direction: all genes are positively loaded and there are no negatively loaded (repressed) lineage markers, supporting the idea of a broad, cell-cycle-linked metabolic program rather than a specific differentiated state. Inconsistencies: • BEST1 is classically enriched in retinal pigment epithelium or certain glia rather than universally in cycling cells, and its inclusion may reflect cell-type–specific expression in the dataset rather than the proliferation program itself. • ZNF90’s function is not tightly linked to cell cycle, so its positive loading is less explanatory for an S-phase signature.

program_19.description: The gene set is most consistent with a conventional type 1 dendritic cell (cDC1) program characteristic of cross-presenting, MHC-II–competent antigen-presenting cells in a relatively quiescent state. Evidence: • CLEC9A and CADM1 – gold-standard surface markers of human cDC1 that mediate dead-cell sensing and cellular adhesion, respectively. • DNASE1L3 and CLNK – selectively enriched in cDC1 and required for DNA handling and signaling downstream of cytokine receptors in this subset. • HLA-DOB – non-classical MHC-II molecule, reinforcing a professional antigen-presenting phenotype. • CST3 – cystatin C; broadly expressed in myeloid APCs, including cDC1, and linked to antigen processing. Inconsistencies: • S100B is classically associated with neural/astrocytic cells; its presence may reflect tissue-specific expression or minor contamination. • C1orf54 has limited functional annotation and provides little discriminatory power.

program_20.description: The gene set represents a robust type I interferon–stimulated antiviral response program that can be activated in many cell types (immune and parenchymal) upon viral sensing. Evidence: • Canonical interferon-stimulated genes: IFIT1, IFIT3, MX1, IFI6, IFI44L and HERC5 are well-established direct targets of IFN-α/β signaling via STAT1/2–IRF9, mediating viral RNA recognition, translation inhibition and ubiquitin-like ISGylation. • Additional inflammatory/IFN-responsive genes: GRN (progranulin, induced by inflammatory cytokines including IFNs) and GMPR (up-regulated in IFN-γ– and type I IFN-driven metabolic remodeling) reinforce an activated antiviral/inflammatory state. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes fit within an interferon-induced activation program, although GRN and GMPR are less strictly ISG-restricted and could reflect broader inflammatory signaling.

program_21.description: The gene set denotes a mesenchymal, fibroblast-like program characteristic of activated/wound-healing fibroblasts or cells that have undergone epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT), marked by cytoskeletal rearrangement, cell-surface annexin complexes, and extracellular-matrix (ECM) remodeling capacity. Evidence: • VIM and FN1 – canonical mesenchymal and fibroblast markers; vimentin filaments and fibronectin production are central to motile, matrix-depositing stromal cells. • ANXA2–S100A10 heterotetramer – localizes plasminogen activation on the cell surface, a hallmark of invasive, ECM-remodeling fibroblasts and EMT states. • ANXA1 – glucocorticoid-inducible annexin enriched in activated stromal cells and up-regulated during EMT and tissue repair. • EMP1 – promotes integrin/FAK signaling and motility in migrating fibroblasts and EMT-converted epithelial cells. • CRIP1 – LIM-domain protein elevated in fibroblasts and mesenchymal stem cells, supports β-catenin–driven mesenchymal gene expression. Inconsistencies: • ANXA1 is more classically linked to myeloid cells, but its reported up-regulation in activated fibroblasts and EMT limits the conflict. No other clear contradictions within the listed genes.

program_22.description: The gene set reflects cells undergoing an endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress / unfolded-protein-response (UPR) program, a state common in highly secretory cells or in any cell type experiencing acute protein-folding burden. Evidence: • Core ER chaperones & folding enzymes up-regulated in the UPR: HSPA5 (BiP/GRP78), CALR (calreticulin), PDIA3 (ERp57), HSP90B1 (GRP94), SDF2L1, MANF, and HYOU1 (GRP170) are canonical target genes of the ATF6, IRE1–XBP1, and PERK arms of the UPR, induced to expand ER folding capacity and resolve misfolded proteins. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes were provided; no conflicts detected.

program_23.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with a mature, CD16⁺ monocyte / tissue macrophage program, reflecting phagocytic, lysosome-rich myeloid cells rather than epithelial or stromal populations. Evidence: • Core macrophage/monocyte markers are positively loaded ─ CD68 (pan-macrophage lysosomal protein), MS4A7 (myeloid membrane protein), FCGR3A/CD16A (non-classical CD16⁺ monocytes and tissue macrophages), and PSAP (lysosomal prosaposin enriched in phagocytes). • Absence of epithelial- or fibroblast-associated growth factors (AREG, ADAM19 are negatively loaded) supports a myeloid identity and argues against epithelial, mesenchymal, or reparative stromal programs. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes strongly contradict a myeloid/macrophage identity; AREG can be produced by some macrophage subsets during wound repair, but its negative loading here simply indicates the profiled cells are not in that amphiregulin-secreting reparative state.

program_24.description: The gene set reflects an alternatively-activated (M2-like), tissue-resident macrophage program characterized by high scavenger-receptor activity and complement inhibition, typical of anti-inflammatory macrophages such as Kupffer or alveolar macrophages. Evidence: • MRC1 (CD206) – canonical marker of M2/tissue-resident macrophages engaged in mannose-rich pathogen clearance. • VSIG4 (CRIg) – complement receptor uniquely enriched in liver and alveolar resident macrophages, mediating complement inhibition and anti-inflammatory signaling. • MSR1 (CD204) – scavenger receptor up-regulated during alternative activation and efferocytosis. • ALOX5AP – lipid-metabolism enzyme supporting leukotriene synthesis in resident macrophages, often co-expressed with MRC1/MSR1 during tissue repair. • ALCAM (CD166) – adhesion/antigen-presentation molecule expressed on macrophages and facilitating tissue retention; frequently co-expressed with VSIG4+ Kupffer cells. • LGALS2 negatively loaded – Galectin-2 is linked to pro-inflammatory (M1) macrophages and T cells; its depletion aligns with an anti-inflammatory M2 profile. Inconsistencies: • ALCAM is not exclusive to macrophages (also on endothelial and epithelial cells). • ALOX5AP can be high in neutrophils; however, combined presence of MRC1, VSIG4 and MSR1 strongly favors an M2 macrophage interpretation.

program_25.description: The program most closely reflects an immediate-early “acute activation / stress-response” state that many cell types enter within minutes of stimulation, characterized by rapid AP-1 transcription factor induction and engagement of autophagy-lysosome machinery, while actin-sequestering components are concurrently dampened. Evidence: • FOS together with DUSP1 and ZFP36L2 – classic immediate-early genes induced by MAPK/JNK signaling after mitogen, cytokine or T-cell-receptor stimulation, marking the first wave of cellular activation. • GABARAP (autophagosome expansion) and ATP6V0C (v-ATPase proton channel for lysosomal acidification) point to heightened autophagy-lysosome activity frequently linked to stress adaptation and rapid protein/organelle turnover that accompanies acute activation. • TMSB4X is negatively loaded; this actin-monomer sequestering protein is often down-regulated or redistributed during activation to permit cytoskeletal remodeling, fitting an activated rather than resting cell state. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes strongly contradict an acute activation / stress-response program; the set is small but internally coherent.

program_26.description: The gene set is most consistent with a generic, stimulus-induced “autophagy / early-stress” program rather than a particular lineage: cells that have recently sensed stress (e.g. nutrient limitation, cytokine or danger signals) up-regulate early-response transcription factors and components of the autophagy–lysosome pathway to remodel metabolism and degrade cytoplasmic material. Evidence: • Autophagy / lysosome machinery – GABARAP (ATG8 family protein required for autophagosome elongation) and ATP6V0C (V-ATPase subunit c that acidifies lysosomes and autophagosomes) rise together when autophagic flux is enhanced. • Immediate-early stress transcription – JUNB (AP-1 complex) and RHOB (stress-inducible small GTPase) are classical rapid-early genes induced by MAPK or inflammatory signalling and are frequently co-expressed during starvation- or cytokine-driven autophagy. • Metabolic adaptation – NME2 (nucleoside diphosphate kinase sustaining nucleotide pools) and RBKS (ribokinase for ribose phosphorylation) support increased nucleotide and sugar turnover that accompanies autophagy-dependent recycling. Inconsistencies: • No strong lineage-restricted markers appear; therefore the program is not specific to a defined cell type (e.g. T cell, macrophage, neuron). • Some canonical autophagy genes (e.g. ATG5, MAP1LC3B, SQSTM1) and lysosomal hydrolases are absent; thus the signature captures only a core subset of the pathway.

program_27.description: The gene set represents a canonical mature, resting peripheral B-cell identity program (naïve or memory B cells, pre–plasma cell differentiation). Evidence: • MS4A1 (CD20), CD79A and CD22 – core components of the B-cell receptor complex and classical surface markers of mature B cells; expression is lost or markedly reduced in plasma cells. • BANK1 and FCMR – B-cell–specific signalling adaptors/receptors enriched in resting naïve and memory B cells rather than in germinal-center or plasma cells. • LY9 (SLAMF3) – SLAM-family receptor present on mature B cells, reinforcing a lymphoid but non-plasma identity. • No plasma-cell genes (e.g., PRDM1, XBP1, SDC1) or germinal-center activation markers (e.g., AICDA, BCL6) appear, supporting a resting peripheral state. Inconsistencies: • LY9 is also found on T/NK cells, but its co-expression with multiple B-cell–specific genes makes this a minor concern.

program_28.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, pro-angiogenic monocyte / macrophage state characterized by high glycolytic demand and enhanced survival signaling. Evidence: • SERPINB2 (PAI-2) – strongly induced in inflammatory or tissue-remodeling macrophages; used as a marker of activated human monocytes/macrophages. • PROK2 (BV8) – secreted by myeloid cells; promotes angiogenesis and is up-regulated in tumor-associated or wound-healing macrophages. • MCL1 – essential for prolonged survival of short-lived myeloid cells (monocytes, macrophages, neutrophils) during activation. • SLC2A3 (GLUT3) – high-affinity glucose transporter up-regulated in glycolytically active, LPS-stimulated monocytes/macrophages. • CD55 – complement-regulatory protein highly expressed on circulating and tissue macrophages to protect them from complement-mediated lysis. • CYP1B1 – AhR-responsive P450 enzyme expressed in macrophages and induced by inflammatory cues, contributing to redox and lipid-metabolism changes seen in activated macrophages. Inconsistencies: • No clear contradictions; all listed genes are compatible with an activated myeloid (monocyte/macrophage) program, though SLC2A3 and CYP1B1 can also be expressed in other cell types (neurons, endothelial cells), making them less specific.

program_29.description: This program represents a generic oxidative-/metal-stress response rather than a lineage-restricted cell identity; the concerted up-regulation of multiple metallothionein isoforms (MT1A, MT1E, MT1F, MT1G, MT1X, MT2A) is characteristic of cells experiencing elevated intracellular Zn2+/Cu2+ levels, reactive oxygen species, or pro-inflammatory cytokine signaling. Evidence: • MT1A, MT1E, MT1F, MT1G, MT1X, MT2A all encode cysteine-rich metallothioneins that bind Zn2+ and other heavy metals, scavenge free radicals, and are transcriptionally induced by MTF-1 in response to metal excess, oxidative stress, glucocorticoids, and IL-6/TNF-α. • Coordinated induction of multiple MT1 isoforms together with MT2A is a canonical gene signature observed across diverse cell types (epithelial, immune, stromal) subjected to metal overload or oxidative/inflammatory stress in single-cell and bulk RNA-seq datasets. Inconsistencies: • None apparent—the entire positive gene set is coherently linked to the metal/oxidative stress program, and no negatively loaded genes were provided.

program_30.description: The program reflects an anti-inflammatory, tissue-resident (M2-like) macrophage state typified by FOLR2⁺/MRC1⁺ cells such as liver Kupffer cells or similar lipid-handling macrophages that co-express hepatically enriched acute-phase and lipid-transfer genes. Evidence: • FOLR2 and MRC1 (CD206) – canonical markers of M2-polarised, tissue-resident macrophages found in liver, placenta and tumor microenvironments. • PLTP – lipid-transfer enzyme up-regulated in Kupffer cells and other lipid-scavenging macrophages. • A2M – acute-phase protease inhibitor produced by Kupffer cells; frequently co-expressed with MRC1 in homeostatic hepatic macrophages. • SELENOP – selenium-transport protein highly expressed in liver but also reported in Kupffer and other resident macrophages, fitting a liver-associated macrophage signature when seen together with FOLR2/MRC1/PLTP/A2M. Inconsistencies: • SELENOP, A2M and PLTP are also abundant in hepatocytes; their presence without classical macrophage genes (e.g., CD68, LYZ) could indicate some hepatocyte RNA contamination or a hepatocyte-adjacent macrophage subset.

program_31.description: The gene set best fits a lipid-sensing, oxidative-burst–competent macrophage / microglial program characteristic of alternatively activated (M2-like) phagocytes that are adapting their redox and fatty-acid metabolism. Evidence: • CYBB (gp91-phox) – NADPH-oxidase catalytic subunit restricted to professional phagocytes (monocytes, macrophages, microglia), conferring respiratory-burst capacity. • ABHD5 (CGI-58) – co-activator of ATGL-mediated lipolysis; up-regulated in lipid-handling macrophages and microglia during alternative activation. • FFAR4 (GPR120) – ω-3 fatty-acid receptor that drives anti-inflammatory, M2-like polarization in macrophages and microglia. • TXNIP – redox/glucose-responsive gene induced in monocytes/macrophages under oxidative or metabolic stress, modulating inflammasome activity. • KCNA3 (Kv1.3) – voltage-gated K⁺ channel enriching activated macrophages/microglia and regulating their membrane potential and cytokine release. Inconsistencies: • KCNA3 is also abundant in effector memory T cells, and the program lacks canonical myeloid markers (e.g., LYZ, CD68), so low-level T-cell contamination cannot be fully excluded.

program_32.description: The gene set represents a generic actin-cytoskeleton remodeling and contractility program characteristic of cells that are actively spreading or migrating (e.g., mesenchymal-like fibroblasts, motile epithelial cells, or activated immune cells), rather than a lineage-restricted signature. Evidence: • ACTB (β-actin) – core structural component of actin filaments; uniformly up-regulated during lamellipodia/filopodia formation and cell spreading. • PFN1 (Profilin-1) and CFL1 (Cofilin-1) – key regulators of actin polymerization–depolymerization cycles that drive membrane protrusion and retraction in migrating cells. • MYL6 (Myosin light chain 6) – component of non-muscle myosin II; its phosphorylation increases actomyosin contractility needed for cell motility and stress-fiber tension. • SH3BGRL3 – adaptor protein that binds actin and promotes Rac1-dependent membrane ruffling; reported up-regulated in invasive and EMT-like states. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes were provided, and all listed positives fit the cytoskeletal/motility program, so no major inconsistencies are evident.

program_33.description: The gene set is most consistent with an alternatively-activated / pro-resolving (“M2-like”) macrophage program engaged in tissue repair and extracellular-matrix remodeling. Evidence: • IL1R2 – decoy IL-1 receptor highly induced in anti-inflammatory monocytes/macrophages, dampening IL-1 signaling during resolution phases. • MFGE8 – secreted efferocytosis ligand produced by M2 macrophages to clear apoptotic cells and promote wound healing. • ALOX15B – 15-lipoxygenase isoform that generates specialized pro-resolving lipid mediators; enriched in alternatively activated macrophages. • ADAMTS2 – procollagen N-peptidase involved in collagen maturation; up-regulated in wound-healing macrophages during matrix remodeling. • FKBP5 – glucocorticoid-responsive chaperone; glucocorticoids are potent drivers of M2 polarization, and FKBP5 is frequently elevated in such macrophages. Inconsistencies: • ADAMTS2 is also expressed by fibroblasts; however, its co-expression with the macrophage-specific anti-inflammatory genes above is most parsimoniously explained by a tissue-remodeling macrophage state rather than a fibroblast identity.

program_34.description: The gene set suggests a generic “activated fibroblast / stromal wound-response” program marked by cytoskeletal remodeling, membrane repair and immune-modulatory secreted factors that are typically up-regulated in fibroblasts undergoing activation during tissue injury, fibrosis or within the tumour micro-environment. Evidence: • LGALS1 – secreted galectin widely used as a marker of activated or cancer-associated fibroblasts, participates in ECM remodelling and immune suppression. • ANXA2 and ANXA1 – annexins that promote membrane trafficking, fibrinolysis and cell migration; both are characteristically induced in wound-activated or myofibroblast-like stromal cells. • S100A6 – Ca²⁺-binding protein up-regulated in mechanically stressed or proliferating fibroblasts and in myofibroblast differentiation. • CRIP1 – zinc-binding protein enriched in mesenchymal stromal cells and tissue fibroblasts, frequently co-expressed with LGALS1 in activated stromal states. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; the annexins and S100A6 can also be expressed in epithelial or myeloid cells, but their joint enrichment with LGALS1 and CRIP1 most parsimoniously fits an activated fibroblast program.

program_35.description: The gene set points to lipid-metabolizing, tissue-resident macrophages—most classically alveolar or other lipid-laden macrophage subsets—characterized by high apolipoprotein production and fatty-acid handling, together with a stress-responsive transcriptional tone. Evidence: • APOE and APOC1 – apolipoproteins abundantly produced by alveolar and other lipid-associated macrophages to mediate cholesterol efflux and surfactant/lipid recycling. • FABP4 – fatty-acid–binding protein highly enriched in alveolar macrophages and lipid-handling TAM/LAM populations; rarely seen outside macrophages except in adipocytes. • NUPR1 – stress-inducible transcription factor up-regulated in activated/inflammatory macrophages exposed to metabolic or oxidative stress. • S100A13 – calcium-binding protein expressed in macrophages and endothelial cells, linked to secretion and stress responses, fitting a macrophage activation program. • Co-enrichment of all four lipid-metabolism genes (APOE, APOC1, FABP4, S100A13) with a macrophage stress gene (NUPR1) aligns with resident, lipid-loaded macrophage states reported in lung and metabolic tissues. Inconsistencies: • FABP4 is also a hallmark of mature adipocytes, but the simultaneous presence of macrophage-specific apolipoproteins (APOE/APOC1) favors a macrophage rather than adipocyte identity. No other strong contradictions are present in this limited gene list.

program_36.description: The program most consistently fits an activated, tissue-resident regulatory/effector CD4⁺ T-cell state (often termed “tissue-repair Tregs/Th-like Tregs”), characterised by production of the epidermal growth factor ligand amphiregulin and expression of immunomodulatory decoy cytokine receptors. Evidence: • AREG – hallmark product of tissue-repair Tregs and other type-2/Th-like T cells that promote epithelial regeneration. • IL1R2 – decoy IL-1 receptor highly induced in activated Tregs, allowing them to neutralise pro-inflammatory IL-1 signals. • IL18R1 – expressed by Th1-skewed or tissue-resident Tregs and other effector T cells, conferring responsiveness to IL-18. • GSTM3 – detoxification/oxidative-stress enzyme up-regulated in metabolically active, recently activated lymphocytes. • PSAP negatively loaded – lysosomal/secretory protein abundant in myeloid cells; its relative depletion is compatible with a lymphoid (T-cell) rather than macrophage identity. Inconsistencies: • IL18R1 is also common in NK/ILC1 and Th1 cells, so its presence could indicate a non-Treg effector subset; broader marker panels (e.g., FOXP3, CD56) would be needed to rule this out.

program_37.description: The program is most consistent with an activated, tissue-resident “repair” T-regulatory (Treg) cell state typified by secretion of Amphiregulin and expression of immunomodulatory molecules that dampen prostaglandin and collagen-mediated signaling. Evidence: • AREG – hallmark effector cytokine of tissue-repairing Tregs and ILC2s; highly induced after T-cell activation in barrier tissues. • LAIR2 – soluble decoy receptor released by activated CD4⁺ T cells (particularly Tregs) to modulate collagen‐LAIR1 signaling and limit inflammation. • HPGD – enzyme that degrades PGE₂; selectively up-regulated in anti-inflammatory/Treg programs to curb eicosanoid-driven inflammation during resolution. • SAP30 – component of the FOXP3 repressor complex that enforces the Treg transcriptional program. • KLF9 – glucocorticoid- and stress-responsive transcription factor enriched in activated Tregs and other immunomodulatory lymphocytes. Inconsistencies: • AREG and HPGD are also expressed by some epithelial and macrophage populations, and SAP30 is ubiquitously nuclear, so these genes are not exclusively Treg-specific; thus other pro-repair immune or epithelial cells could contribute part of the signal.

program_38.description: The gene set represents an interferon-stimulated inflammatory monocyte/macrophage state. Evidence: • IFITM2, IFITM3 – canonical type I interferon-stimulated genes induced during viral sensing in myeloid cells. • LST1 – selectively expressed in monocytes, macrophages and dendritic cells, up-regulated by inflammatory cytokines. • ICAM2 – leukocyte adhesion molecule enriched on circulating and tissue macrophages, facilitating immune cell–endothelium interactions during inflammation. • ARHGAP29 – Rho-GTPase–regulating protein controlling actin remodeling and migration in macrophages, often co-induced with inflammatory programs. Inconsistencies: • None apparent given the small, uniformly myeloid/interferon-related gene set.

program_39.description: The gene set is most compatible with a metabolic/energy-mobilisation programme characteristic of mature skeletal-muscle fibres preparing for contraction, marked by high oxidative phosphorylation and glycogenolysis activity. Evidence: • PHKG1 – muscle-specific γ-catalytic subunit of phosphorylase kinase; activates glycogen phosphorylase to liberate glucose-1-phosphate during muscle contraction. • ATP5PO – core peripheral-stalk component of mitochondrial ATP synthase complex V; up-regulation reflects elevated oxidative phosphorylation typical of energy-demanding myofibres. • BLOC1S1 and NBEAL1 – vesicle/lysosome-related trafficking proteins; muscle fibres increase vesicular turnover (e.g., autophagy, sarcoplasmic reticulum trafficking) under high metabolic load. • Concordant presence of multiple organelle/energy-homeostasis genes with absence of immune or epithelial markers supports a myocytic metabolic state rather than another lineage. Inconsistencies: • Canonical structural muscle genes (e.g., MYH1/7, ACTA1, TNNT) are not represented, and BLOC1S1/NBEAL1 are not muscle-restricted, leaving some ambiguity about a purely myofibre identity.

program_40.description: The gene set reflects an immediate-early activation program present in many cell types that have just been stimulated by growth factors, stress signals, or pathogens. Hallmarks include strong AP-1 transcriptional activity (JUN), other rapid-response transcription factors (IER2), chromatin re-organization associated with cell-cycle entry (H1-4), and coordinated up-regulation of endo-lysosomal proton-pump components (ATP6V0C, RNASEK) that support receptor recycling and signal transduction. Evidence: • JUN and IER2 are classic immediate-early genes induced within minutes of MAPK/AP-1 activation after cytokine or mitogen stimulation. • H1-4 (linker histone H1.4) is up-regulated when quiescent cells re-enter the cell cycle, indicating early proliferative or stress-response chromatin remodeling. • ATP6V0C (V-ATPase V0 subunit) and RNASEK (membrane co-factor for V-ATPase assembly) rise when cells boost endosomal/lysosomal acidification to facilitate receptor internalization and signaling, a common feature of recently activated cells. Inconsistencies: • No obvious cell-type-specific markers are present; the program therefore describes a transient activation state rather than a lineage-defining profile.

program_41.description: The program represents activation of the unfolded-protein response (UPR) in the endoplasmic reticulum, a stress‐induced state common to highly secretory or otherwise stressed cells rather than a lineage-defining cell type. Evidence: • HSP90B1 (GRP94/gp96) – ER-resident HSP90 chaperone induced by UPR to assist folding of nascent secretory proteins. • CALR – canonical ER calcium-binding lectin chaperone up-regulated during ER stress. • PDIA4 and PDIA3 – protein-disulfide isomerases that catalyze disulfide bond formation/rearrangement; transcriptionally enhanced by ATF6/XBP1 arms of the UPR. • NUCB2 – Ca²⁺/golgi-associated protein that accompanies high secretory flux and is co-induced with ER chaperones under stress. Inconsistencies: none evident; all listed genes are classical components or companions of the ER protein-folding and quality-control machinery.

program_42.description: The gene signature is most consistent with mature, CCR7-positive conventional dendritic cells (cDCs) that have acquired a migratory, partly immuno-regulatory phenotype characteristic of cells leaving peripheral tissues and homing to lymph nodes. Evidence: • CCR7 and its ligand CCL19 are canonical markers of mature cDCs that up-regulate this chemokine axis to enter afferent lymphatics and the T-cell zone of lymph nodes. • FSCN1 (fascin) is strongly induced during dendritic-cell maturation, where it reorganizes actin bundles to facilitate membrane protrusions and motility. • EBI3 encodes the p28/EBI3 subunit used in IL-27 and IL-35, cytokines secreted by activated or tolerogenic DCs to modulate T-cell responses. • IL4I1 is an L-phenylalanine oxidase up-regulated in activated/regulatory dendritic cells and macrophages, contributing to suppression of T-cell proliferation. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes were provided, and none of the positive genes conflict with a mature migratory dendritic-cell identity.

program_43.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, lipid-processing, lysosomal-enriched macrophage/microglial state frequently referred to as “disease-associated” or “foamy” phagocytes that emerge in chronically inflamed or neuro-degenerating tissue.
