Evidence: • Lysosomal enzymes characteristic of phagocytic activation – CHIT1 (chitotriosidase) and LIPA (lysosomal acid lipase) are classical markers of lipid-laden, highly phagocytic macrophages and disease-associated microglia. • Additional lysosomal/phospholipase gene PLD3 is repeatedly enriched in Alzheimer’s disease-associated microglia and other lipid-handling macrophage states. • CHI3L1 (YKL-40) is a secreted glycoprotein produced by alternatively activated macrophages and reactive glia during chronic inflammation and tissue remodeling, commonly co-expressed with CHIT1 in disease-associated microglia. • The collective presence of CHIT1, CHI3L1, LIPA and PLD3 highlights a program centered on lysosomal cholesterol handling, phagocytosis, and inflammatory tissue remodeling—hallmarks of foamy or disease-associated macrophages/microglia. Inconsistencies: • RARRES1 (TIG1) is more commonly described in epithelial or stromal cells and is not a canonical macrophage/microglial marker, although it can be induced by retinoic acid in various cell types; its presence is therefore somewhat atypical for this program.

program_44.description: The program reflects a high-translation/elongation state characteristic of metabolically active or proliferating cells rather than a specific lineage; it captures coordinated up-regulation of core ribosome-associated factors and elongation machinery that drive bulk protein synthesis. Evidence: • EEF1A1 & EEF1B2 – canonical translation elongation factors 1-α and 1-β2 that deliver amino-acyl-tRNAs to the ribosome, up-regulated when overall protein synthesis is elevated. • RACK1 – scaffold protein embedded in the 40S ribosomal subunit, links signal transduction to translation and is enriched in cells with active ribosomes. • NACA – α-subunit of the nascent polypeptide–associated complex that binds emerging peptide chains, supporting heavy translational throughput. • EIF3F – subunit of the eIF3 initiation complex, required for efficient start-codon recognition and polysome formation. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded or lineage-specific genes are present; thus, no clear conflicts with the interpretation, though lineage assignment cannot be refined beyond a generic high-biosynthetic state.

program_45.description: This program most closely reflects a generic “activated / proliferative-stress” state that many cell types adopt when they increase ribosome biogenesis and mount an oxidative-stress response. Evidence: • NOP10 and SERF2 – nucleolar proteins required for rRNA processing and chromatin remodeling, typically up-regulated in cycling or rapidly growing cells. • S100A6 – calcium-binding protein induced by mechanical or oxidative stress and enriched in actively proliferating endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and immune cells. • LGALS1 (Galectin-1) – secreted lectin elevated in activated, metabolically re-programmed cells and in tissue remodeling contexts. • MT1F – metallothionein isoform up-regulated in response to reactive oxygen species and metal ion stress, often co-expressed with proliferation genes. Inconsistencies: • No strong lineage-specific markers are present; therefore the program likely represents a state rather than a dedicated cell type.

program_46.description: The gene set most consistently fits an “S100-high, motility-primed activated fibroblast (cancer-associated fibroblast / wound-response fibroblast)” program, marked by calcium-binding S100 proteins that drive cytoskeletal remodeling, plasmin generation and cell migration. Evidence: • S100A4 (FSP1) – canonical marker of activated/wound-healing and cancer-associated fibroblasts; promotes collagen remodeling and motility. • S100A6 and S100A11 – broadly enriched in proliferating or stress-responding fibroblasts, up-regulated during fibroblast activation and senescence. • S100A10 – partners with annexin A2 on the surface of activated fibroblasts to form a plasminogen receptor, facilitating matrix degradation and invasion. • SH3BGRL3 – induced by TGF-β and other fibroblast-activating cues; enhances Rac1 signaling and migration in stromal cells. The concerted elevation of these motility- and cytoskeleton-associated S100 proteins, without lineage-specific epithelial, endothelial or immune markers, aligns best with an activated fibroblast program. Inconsistencies: • S100A10 and SH3BGRL3 can also be expressed in macrophages and endothelial cells; absence of additional myeloid/endothelial markers, however, supports a fibroblast interpretation.

program_0.description: The gene pattern represents vascular endothelial cells that have transitioned from a quiescent, KLF2-/EGFL7-high state to an acutely inflamed, NF-κB–driven activation state typical of TNF-α/IL-1β stimulation, characterized by strong chemokine/cytokine secretion and adhesion-molecule up-regulation. Evidence: • Endothelial identity/adhesion: ICAM1, SELE (E-selectin), THBD, PVR, LIPG, TM4SF1, SDC4, CCN1, ESM1, HBEGF. • Pro-inflammatory NF-κB targets: NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, RELB, TNFAIP3, BIRC3, CXCL1/2/3/8, CCL2, IL6, CSF3, PTGS2, SOCS1/2/3, ZC3H12A, IRF1. • Immediate-early/AP-1 response to cytokine stress: JUN, JUNB, JUND, FOS, FOSB, FOSL1/2, EGR1, ATF3, BTG2. • Metabolic/hypoxia-responsive genes often induced in activated endothelium: ANGPTL4, HILPDA, ADM, NAMPT, ANKRD37. • Antigen presentation/co-stimulation seen in activated endothelium: HLA-DQA2, HLA-DQB1, CD274 (PD-L1), TNFSF9. • Negative loadings highlight loss of homeostatic endothelial genes: KLF2, SOX4, EGFL7, SPARCL1, TFPI, CD34, GNG11—features down-regulated when endothelium becomes inflamed. Inconsistencies: • A few granulocyte/mast-cell transcripts (DEFA3, CPA3, TPSAB1) and macrophage-associated genes (MAFB) appear, suggesting minor contamination or shared inflammatory modules rather than pure endothelial origin. • IFITM3 and JCHAIN (plasma cell marker) are negatively loaded but do not strongly conflict with the overall endothelial activation interpretation.

program_1.description: The program most closely matches a micro-/capillary endothelial cell identity that is transcriptionally activated by interferon and BMP/TGF-β–modulating signals while being clearly depleted of stromal-myofibroblast and cytotoxic lymphocyte features. Evidence: • Core endothelial identity: PECAM1, VWF, CLDN5, ESAM, TEK (TIE2), ACVRL1/ENG, PTPRB, EFNB2, CLEC14A, CD93, CD300LG, GJA4, AQP1, RAMP2/3-CALCRL adrenomedullin complex, LYVE1, GPIHBP1, SPARC/SPARCL1, COL4A1/2, NOTCH4-HEY1, SOX18, FOXF1 all typify blood and lymphatic microvascular endothelial cells. • Endothelial quiescence/shear-stress & BMP/TGF-β modulation: SMAD6, RGCC, ID1/ID3, BMPR2, NOSTRIN, BMPER, HOXA5, CASZ1, EDN1, SGK1, RGS5. • Interferon / innate-immune activation overlay: IFI27, IFI6, IFIT3, IFITM2/3, BST2, GBP4, WARS1, HLA-F indicate a type-I/II interferon–responsive endothelial state. • Glucocorticoid & metabolic stress tuning often seen in quiescent ECs: TSC22D3, FKBP5, TXNIP, DDIT4, PDK4, SERPING1. • Negative loadings confirm loss of contaminating stromal/mesenchymal or cytotoxic programs: ACTA2, FN1, FBLN2, VIM, HSPB1, ACTN1 (myofibroblast/smooth-muscle); GNLY, GZMB (cytotoxic lymphocytes) are all suppressed. Inconsistencies: • IL7R, GIMAP5/7 (lymphoid), KIT and CD14/C1QC (myeloid) are atypically high for endothelial cells and could reflect low-level contamination or endothelial expression in specialised niches.

program_2.description: The gene set describes capillary/vascular endothelial cells displaying a barrier-forming, interferon-stimulated activation state. Evidence: • Core endothelial markers are strongly positive: CLDN5, CDH5 (VE-cadherin), ESAM, ICAM2, EGFL7, ACVRL1, RAMP2/3, ADGRF5, AQP1, CAV1/CAVIN2, COL4A1/2, GPIHBP1, NOTCH4, FOXF1, GATA2. • Tight-junction-rich “barrier” phenotype: high CLDN5 with concomitant negative loading of PLVAP and VIM/HSPB1, genes enriched in fenestrated or stressed endothelium. • Interferon / antiviral activation: IFI27, IFI6, IFIT3, BST2, OAS1, GBP4, CX3CL1, IDO1 are all classic interferon-stimulated genes. • Stress / glucocorticoid / hypoxia modulators (FKBP5, SGK1, DUSP1, TSC22D3, TXNIP, HIF3A, PDK4, SERPINE1) point to an activated, non-quiescent state. • Negative loadings are enriched for fibroblast-like extracellular-matrix genes (COL1A1, ELN, DCN, FN1, FBLN2, IGFBP2, CTHRC1, MGP) and cytoskeletal stress genes (HSPB1, LGALS3), reinforcing that the program specifically marks endothelial rather than stromal cells. Inconsistencies: • A few positively loaded genes (SCGB3A1, PRR4, TPPP3—airway secretory; SLC6A4, VIPR1, ADRB1—neuroendocrine receptors) are atypical for endothelium and may reflect ambient RNA or low-level cross-expression rather than the core program.

program_3.description: The program is most consistent with an interferon-activated lung capillary aerocyte endothelial cell state: a population of microvascular endothelial cells that line the gas-exchange surface of the lung, secrete the angiogenic ligand APLN, show strong caveolar and tight-junction signatures, and simultaneously down-regulate classical pan-endothelial/venous genes while up-regulating interferon-stimulated, stress-response and inflammatory genes. Evidence: • Endothelial identity – PECAM1, CLDN5, EMCN, ICAM2, ESAM, KDR, CAV1/2, CAVIN2, AQP1, CDH13, CD300LG. • Aerocyte (aCap) versus general capillary/venous bias – high APLN with low/negative VWF, PLVAP, CD93, PTPRB, RNASE1, THBD and APLNR. • Lung–specific developmental factors – FOXF1, HOXB5, TBX2/3 support a pulmonary microvascular origin. • Caveolar/angiogenic activation – SERPINE1, SPARC, LGALS1, EDIL3, PRKCE, RAMP2/3, SGK1. • Interferon/inflammatory response – IFI27, IFI6, ISG15, IFIT1, OAS1, IL32, TNFSF10, TSC22D3, CD83. • Stress/cytoskeletal remodeling – TAGLN2, MYLK, CNN3, RHOB, DST, S100A4/A6, indicating an activated (non-quiescent) endothelial phenotype. Inconsistencies: • Presence of some hematopoietic/lymphocyte genes (GIMAP5, CD69, CCL4) and epithelial-associated NNMT (negatively loaded) could reflect minor contamination or mixed signaling. • LYVE1 is negatively loaded rather than positive, arguing against a lymphatic identity but showing that typical lymphatic markers are suppressed, consistent with but not obligatory for the aerocyte profile.

program_4.description: The gene set reflects a lymphatic endothelial cell (LEC) identity and maturation program, distinguishing these cells from blood-vascular endothelium and incorporating genes involved in extracellular-matrix remodeling and immune cell crosstalk. Evidence: • Canonical LEC specification factors: PROX1 (master LEC transcription factor), FLT4/VEGFR3, LYVE1, NRP2, TBX1, NR2F1/2, and FOXC-related targets (e.g. EFEMP1) are strongly positively loaded. • Additional LEC-enriched membrane/secreted proteins: MMRN1, MRC1 (CD206), ACKR2, GPR182, COLEC12, SEMA3A/3D, ANGPT2, IGF1, and RARRES2 support a lymphatic, immunomodulatory surface profile. • Matrix-remodeling and vessel-sprouting genes typical of growing LECs: LOX, COL1A2, FN1, ELN, TGFBI, TIMP2, PDGFC, ADAMTS5, MMP2, MFAP2, SMOC1 indicate active structural remodeling. • Negative loadings are classic blood-vascular endothelial markers that are down-regulated in LECs: VWF, CLEC14A, SPARCL1, RNASE1, FCN3, ID2/3, HLA-DRA, PPP1R14A, CCL3, confirming the contrast with blood endothelium. Inconsistencies: • ACTA2 (smooth-muscle) and TTN/SYNM (myofibroblast/muscle) suggest minor contamination or transitional endothelial-to-mesenchymal activation. • SFTPB (alveolar type II) and NKG7 (cytotoxic lymphoid) are atypical for LECs and may arise from ambient RNA or doublets. • RELN, FOXP2 and some neuronal genes (SCN3A/B) are rarely associated with endothelium and may reflect organ-specific LEC specialization or noise.

program_5.description: The program most strongly reflects an activated vascular endothelial cell state characterized by pro-inflammatory and pro-coagulant signaling and extensive extracellular-matrix remodeling, typical of endothelial cells responding to cytokines such as IL-1/IL-6 or shear-stress changes during vascular injury or angiogenesis. Evidence: • Endothelial identity – VWF, PECAM1 (CD31), CD93, PLVAP, SOX18, FOXC1, RSPO3, CALCRL/RAMP3, CYP1B1, PECAM1 together mark blood‐vessel endothelial cells. • Inflammatory activation – SELE (E-selectin), SELP (P-selectin), VCAM1, IL1R1, IL6ST, CXCL2, CCL14/15/23, ACKR3, PTGS1/2, PTGIS and PTGDS are classic cytokine-/COX-inducible genes up-regulated in stimulated endothelium. • Pro-coagulant / complement components – VWF, PLAT (tPA), FGL2, C1R, C1S, MASP1, A2M, TIMP1/3 indicate coagulation and complement pathway engagement typical of damaged vessels. • Angiogenic / matrix-remodeling signature – COL3A1, COL8A1, ELN, POSTN, HAS2, CCN1/2, ADAMTS4/9, MMP1, TGM2, EFEMP1 denote extracellular-matrix production and remodeling during vessel sprouting. • Mature vs. quiescent contrast – Negative loading of CD34, VIM, LGALS1, ITGA1 and RGCC (all enriched in quiescent or capillary endothelial cells) supports a shift toward a mature, activated phenotype. Inconsistencies: • Co-loading of mural cell / smooth-muscle markers (TAGLN, MYH11, MYL9, RGS5) suggests either partial contamination by pericytes/SMCs or endothelial cells that have begun to acquire contractile genes. • Negative loading of GNG11 and NHERF2, which can be induced in some activated endothelial contexts, slightly diverges from the overall activation profile.

program_6.description: The gene loadings describe a tissue-resident macrophage program, typical of lung (alveolar / interstitial) macrophages that are actively engaged in complement-mediated opsonisation, phagolysosomal degradation and lipid handling—features characteristic of an alternatively-activated (“M2-like”) resident macrophage state rather than epithelial or endothelial cells. Evidence: • Core macrophage / phagocytosis genes: TYROBP, FCER1G, AIF1, CD68, LYZ, ITGB2, LCP1, CYBB, RAC2, CTSC, CTSD/CTSS/CTSB, LAPTM5, SQSTM1. • Complement & scavenger receptor signature of resident macrophages: C1QA, C1QB, C1QC, VSIG4, MSR1, MARCO, TREM2, C5AR1. • M2-like / tissue-resident markers: MRC1 (CD206), CD163, MS4A7, CHIT1, ALOX5/AP, IL1RL1 (ST2), INHBA, GPNMB, VCAN, MAFB. • Lipid metabolism typical of alveolar macrophages: APOE, APOC1, FABP4, LPL, FBP1, ACSL1, OLR1. • Negative loading of endothelial / epithelial genes (TMSB4X, RAMP2, JAM2, EDN1, APLNR, SCGB1A1/3A1) underscores enrichment for macrophages rather than neighbouring lung parenchymal cells. Inconsistencies: • Inflammatory monocyte markers (S100A8, S100A9, S100A12, FCN1, NCF2) and chemokines (CCL3/4/5) suggest some overlap with recruited inflammatory macrophages. • Cytotoxic cell genes (GNLY, NKG7, GZMB) are atypical for macrophages. • Co-expression of LYVE1 (vascular-associated macrophage) and inflammatory markers indicates heterogeneity within the program rather than a single pure alveolar M2 state.

program_7.description: The program is most consistent with arterial-type endothelial cells that are in a quiescent/early-angiogenic (stalk-cell) state characterized by active TGF-β/BMP/Notch signalling and matrix remodelling while suppressing mesenchymal or smooth-muscle–like features. Evidence: • Core endothelial identity – PTPRB, TEK (TIE2), ENG, CLEC14A, CD93, SELP, GJA4/GJA5, VE-cadherin partner TMSB10, CLDN10, CXADR. • Arterial specification / Notch-response – EFNB2, SOX17, HEY1, HEY2, ID1/ID2/ID4, SMAD6, JAG2. • Angiogenic and extracellular-matrix genes – VEGFA, CXCL12, MMP28, FBLN5, ELN, CCN2, CCN3, SULF1, TGFB modulators LTBP1/LTBP4, BMP4/BMPER, PTGIS. • Vascular growth-factor/chemokine and receptor set – FGF2, FGF18, IGF2, IGFBP3, PDGF-pathway regulators (PI16), CALCRL, NPR3. • Negative loadings reduce mesenchymal/SMC or inflammatory signatures – VIM, CNN3, SPARC, NOSTRIN, GNG11, indicating maintenance of endothelial (rather than fibroblast or smooth-muscle) phenotype. Inconsistencies: • Interferon-inducible genes (IFITM1/3, BST2, IDO1) suggest mild immune activation not typical of quiescent endothelium. • NOS1 and CLDN10 are more typical of specialised (e.g., brain or renal) endothelium, indicating possible tissue-specific bias within the program.

program_8.description: The gene set is most consistent with an interferon-stimulated, pro-angiogenic vascular endothelial cell program, representative of activated microvascular (likely lung) endothelium exposed to inflammatory cues. Evidence: • Core endothelial identity – PECAM1, VWF, PTPRB, TFPI, CALCRL + RAMP3, SOX18, LIMS2, TSPAN7, RGS5 and KLF2 are all canonical markers of vascular endothelial cells and/or shear-stress/angiogenic signalling. • Angiogenic/immature endothelium – ID1, ID3, SRPX, CLEC3B, PTGDS and PRSS23 are up-regulated during sprouting or remodeling endothelium. • Interferon / antiviral activation – IFITM1/2/3, IFI6, IL33, IL18BP, UBD and GDF15 are classical interferon-stimulated or stress-induced genes, indicating an inflammatory activation state. • Lung/alveolar vascular context – CLDN18 and SFTPB, together with RAMP3-CALCRL adrenomedullin signalling, are enriched in lung microvascular endothelial populations. • Low antigen-presentation signature – Negative loading of HLA-DRA and UBB, with positive loading of only one HLA allele (HLA-DRB5), suggests reduced MHC-II expression typical of non-professional antigen-presenting endothelium. Inconsistencies: • SFTPB and CLDN18 are classically epithelial; their presence may reflect endothelial uptake of alveolar transcripts or mixed cell doublets. • GIMAP5 (lymphoid), TMEM176A/B (tolerogenic DC) and ABCC8 (endocrine pancreas) are not typical endothelial genes. • Endothelial housekeeping genes TMSB4X and GNG11 are negatively loaded, contrasting with the otherwise endothelial profile.

program_9.description: The gene set is most consistent with an injured-or remodeling airway/alveolar epithelial population that has adopted a secretory / goblet-like, KRT17⁺ transitional (TACSTD2⁺/CLDN4⁺) state often observed during epithelial regeneration and fibrotic lung disease. Evidence: • Secretory / goblet cell products – MUC5AC, MUC1, PIGR, WFDC2, BPIFA1, BPIFB1, SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1, AGR2, AGR3, LCN2, CXCL17, SAA1/2 indicate mucosal secretory differentiation. • Transitional / repair markers – KRT17, KRT8, KRT18, KRT19, KRT15, CLDN4, TACSTD2, AQP3, GPRC5A, MMP10, THY1, POSTN, COL15A1, MEOX1/2 and SPARCL1 are characteristic of the “KRT17⁺/COL15A1⁺” epithelial cells that appear after lung injury and during epithelial–mesenchymal transition-like repair. • Progenitor & activation cues – CD24, FOLR1, CYTL1, SPRY1, PLVAP, SELE, CD34, APLNR and MYC reflect proliferative / activated epithelium interacting with endothelium and stroma during wound healing. • Down-weighted interferon response – negative loading of IFITM2, IFITM3, TIMP3, MT1E/M suggests the program is distinct from an antiviral / oxidative-stress state, supporting a remodeling rather than inflammatory-IFN signature. Inconsistencies: • Endothelial-biased genes (PLVAP, SELE, CD34) and pericyte/fibroblast genes (COL15A1, VWA1) may reflect partial EMT or ambient RNA. • B-cell genes (CD79B, EBF1) and T-cell chemokine CCL5 are likely contaminants. • AGER (type I alveolar cell), CXCR4 and PTAFR are not typical of secretory epithelium but can be induced during injury.

program_10.description: Gene expression points to an activated mesenchymal program characteristic of contractile, extracellular-matrix–secreting myofibroblasts/perivascular fibroblasts engaged in tissue remodelling or fibrosis. Evidence: • ECM synthesis/remodelling: COL1A2, COL3A1, COL6A1/2/3, FN1, DCN, BGN, LUM, FBN1, ELN, FBLN1/5, TIMP1, MMP2, THBS1, CCN2. • Contractile/myofibroblast machinery: ACTA2 (α-SMA), TAGLN, MYL9, TPM2, MYH11, CALD1, PDLIM4, FLNA. • Pericyte/mural-cell & hypoxia signatures: RGS5, AOC3, GUCY1A1, GUCY1B1, NDUFA4L2, COX4I2. • Wound-repair/fibrotic secreted factors: SERPINF1, SERPING1, CFD, IGFBP6, APOE, CCN1/5. • Negative loading of endothelial/immune genes (HLA-DRB1, RNASE1, RAMP2) separates this program from antigen-presenting or endothelial cell states. Inconsistencies: • AGER, usually an alveolar type I epithelial marker, is atypical for fibroblasts but can appear in lung pericytes/fibroblasts. • MYH11 is canonical for vascular smooth muscle, suggesting some mural-cell admixture or continuum with myofibroblasts.

program_11.description: The gene set reflects vascular endothelial cells that have transitioned into an interferon-stimulated, antigen-presenting state typical of inflamed endothelium (so-called “IFN-activated/HLADR⁺ endothelial cells”). Evidence: • Endothelial structural/functional genes: ESAM, CAV1, RAMP2, GPIHBP1, NOSTRIN, NOTCH4, MFSD4A support an endothelial identity. • Strong type I/III interferon response: IFI27, ISG15, IFI6, IFI44L, IFIT1/2/3, MX1/2, OAS1, RSAD2, CMPK2, GBP4, XAF1, BST2—a canonical IFN-stimulated transcriptome seen in inflamed endothelium. • Acquisition of antigen-presentation machinery: HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DRA, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DMA together with CD74 indicates MHC-II up-regulation, a hallmark of endothelial activation by IFN-γ or type I IFNs. • Down-regulation of resting/hemostatic endothelial genes: MMRN1 and TFPI are negatively loaded, consistent with loss of quiescent, coagulation-related functions during inflammatory activation. Inconsistencies: • CD14 and DEPP1 are typical of myeloid cells; their presence may reflect minor contaminating monocytes or low-level endothelial expression under inflammation. • CLDN7 and EMP2 are more characteristic of epithelial cells, though low expression is reported in some endothelial beds.

program_12.description: Gene expression suggests a quiescent, capillary-type endothelial cell program specialized for lipid handling and vasoregulation. Evidence: • GPIHBP1 – capillary endothelial-specific receptor that anchors lipoprotein lipase and mediates triglyceride-rich lipoprotein processing. • EDN1 – classical endothelial gene encoding the vasoconstrictor endothelin-1. • CD36 – fatty-acid transporter/scavenger receptor highly expressed on microvascular endothelial cells. • CEMIP2 (TMEM2) & LRRC32 (GARP) – extracellular-matrix/hyaluronan and TGF-β modulators enriched in vascular endothelium and stromal vasculature. • TPM1, MT1E – cytoskeletal and oxidative-stress genes frequently up-regulated in differentiated endothelial cells. • Negative loading of VIM (vimentin) – lower mesenchymal cytoskeleton signature, consistent with a more differentiated/quiescent rather than activated/mesenchymal state. Inconsistencies: • CD44 and FAM107A are broadly expressed in fibroblasts and immune cells. • FRMD4A and BEX5 are better known in neuronal contexts; their presence is less typical for endothelium.

program_13.description: The gene set represents a canonical MHC class II antigen-presentation program characteristic of professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as dendritic cells, B cells, macrophages or IFN-γ–activated endothelial/epithelial cells; its coordinated up-regulation suggests an immunologically activated APC state driven by CIITA/IFN-γ signaling. Evidence: • Core MHC class II α- and β-chains (HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DQA1/2, HLA-DQB1) — required for peptide presentation to CD4⁺ T cells; hallmark of professional APCs. • Antigen-processing chaperones (CD74/invariant chain, HLA-DMA, HLA-DMB, HLA-DOA) — facilitate peptide loading onto MHC-II in endosomes, further denoting an active presentation pathway. • Co-induction of this entire module is a classic transcriptional response to IFN-γ via CIITA, reflecting an activated APC state rather than mere lineage identity. Inconsistencies: • None — all detected genes coherently belong to the MHC class II pathway.

program_14.description: The gene set is characteristic of pulmonary alveolar type II (AT2) epithelial cells engaged in surfactant production/secretion, representing a canonical, homeostatic AT2 cell state. Evidence: • Core surfactant genes (SFTPC, SFTPA1, SFTPA2, SFTPB, SFTA2) – definitive markers of AT2 cells responsible for synthesising and secreting pulmonary surfactant. • NAPSA (napsin A) – aspartic protease highly enriched in AT2 cells, routinely used histologically to identify these cells and lung adenocarcinoma of AT2 origin. • SLC34A2 – sodium-phosphate cotransporter with lung-specific expression in AT2 cells, facilitates phosphate uptake for phospholipid (surfactant) synthesis. • MGST1 – microsomal glutathione S-transferase involved in detoxification and antioxidant defence, up-regulated in AT2 cells that handle surfactant lipid metabolism. • SLPI – secretory leukocyte protease inhibitor secreted by AT2 and airway secretory cells, providing local antiprotease protection within the alveolar lining fluid. • Overall enrichment of secretory/proteolytic processing genes (NAPSA, PGC) aligns with the AT2 role in producing, processing and recycling surfactant proteins. Inconsistencies: • PGC (progastricsin) is classically associated with gastric chief cells; its presence may reflect low-level ectopic expression or cross-contamination but does not outweigh the dominant AT2 signature.

program_15.description: The gene set represents a robust type I/II interferon-stimulated gene (ISG) program, characteristic of cells that have sensed viral infection or inflammatory interferon signals; it reflects an activated antiviral state that can be elicited in many cell types (immune, epithelial, stromal) rather than a lineage-restricted signature. Evidence: • Chemokines CXCL10 and CXCL11 are classic IFN-γ/IFN-β inducible genes that recruit CXCR3⁺ T cells to inflamed or virally infected tissues. • Guanylate-binding proteins GBP1 and GBP4 are canonical ISGs that localize to pathogen-containing vacuoles and restrict microbial replication. • IFIT2 and IFIT3 encode translation-inhibitory proteins induced by type I IFNs to block viral RNA translation. • ISG15 is an ubiquitin-like modifier strongly up-regulated by type I IFNs and conjugated to many antiviral effector proteins. • TAP1 is an IFN-inducible transporter that loads antigenic peptides onto MHC-I, linking interferon signalling to antigen presentation. • WARS1 (tryptophanyl-tRNA synthetase) is an interferon-inducible synthetase with extracellular antimicrobial functions. Inconsistencies: • No major inconsistencies; the list uniformly comprises interferon-response genes, but the absence of lineage markers prevents assignment to a specific cell type beyond “interferon-activated.”.

program_16.description: The gene set points to a vascular mural-cell program, most compatible with an activated / remodeling vascular smooth-muscle cell (VSMC) or pericyte state that has up-regulated inflammatory adhesion and matrix-remodeling machinery. Evidence: • Contractile / mural identity – MYH11 (canonical VSMC/pericyte motor protein), ADAMTS9 (high in VSMC and pericytes), NNMT (stromal/perivascular enrichment). • Vascular activation & leukocyte recruitment – VCAM1 (inducible on mural cells under inflammatory or atherogenic cues), PLAT (tissue plasminogen activator produced by activated vascular wall cells), CYP1B1 (oxidative-stress–responsive enzyme up-regulated in diseased vessel wall). • ECM remodeling / signaling co-regulators – ADAMTS9, PLAT, NCOA7 (nuclear receptor co-activator responsive to oxidative stress), consistent with a synthetic/activated VSMC phenotype. Inconsistencies: • CPE is mainly associated with neuroendocrine secretion; its presence is less typical for VSMCs but has been reported in some mesenchymal cells. • VCAM1 is classically endothelial; however, it is inducible in VSMCs during inflammation, so not strictly inconsistent.

program_17.description: The gene set is most consistent with an injury-activated, reparative epithelial program—often referred to as “damage-associated transitional progenitors” (e.g., KRT8⁺/CLDN4⁺ wound‐response epithelium in lung, skin or other barrier tissues)—that secretes cytokines and EGFR ligands to recruit macrophages and drive tissue repair. Evidence: • AREG, TNFRSF12A (Fn14) – canonical markers of epithelium undergoing EGFR/Fn14-mediated wound repair; both sharply induced in transitional alveolar and cutaneous repair epithelia. • CSF1, ANXA1 – injury-responsive epithelial cytokines that attract and modulate macrophages/neutrophils during repair; co-expressed in KRT8⁺ transitional alveolar cells. • KLF6 – stress-induced transcription factor promoting epithelial restitution and extracellular-matrix remodeling. • S100A3 – calcium-binding protein enriched in stratified/hair follicle epithelium and up-regulated after barrier damage. • UBC, RTN4 – generic stress/ER-plasticity genes frequently elevated in regenerating epithelial cells. Inconsistencies: • S100A3 is classically associated with hair-follicle keratinocytes, so its presence may reflect skin rather than lung epithelium. • RTN4 is better known in neurons; while inducible in many stressed cells, it is not a hallmark epithelial repair gene.

program_18.description: The program represents an interferon-stimulated, antigen-presenting myeloid state—typical of monocytes/macrophages or dendritic cells that have up-regulated MHC-II machinery in response to type I/II interferons. Evidence: • Antigen presentation: CD74, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DRA are core components of the MHC-II complex, characteristic of professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as dendritic cells and inflammatory monocytes/macrophages. • Interferon response: IFIT1, IFIT3 and IFI27 are canonical interferon-stimulated genes, marking exposure to type I/II IFN and an activated/inflammatory state in myeloid APCs. • Stress/autophagy modulation: DEPP1 is induced by oxidative stress and IFN signalling in myeloid cells, fitting the activated, inflammatory context. Inconsistencies: None apparent—every listed gene is consistent with an interferon-activated APC program.

program_19.description: The gene set marks antigen-presenting cells (monocytes/macrophages or conventional dendritic cells) that are acutely stimulated by type I interferon, characterized by high MHC-II antigen-presentation machinery and a contemporaneous interferon-stimulated gene (ISG) response, while genes typical of endothelial/platelet lineage or iron-storage programs are suppressed. Evidence: • Antigen presentation: CD74, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DRA are core components of MHC-II processing and are hallmarks of professional antigen-presenting cells. • Interferon activation: IFI27 and ISG15 are prototypic type I IFN-inducible transcripts, indicating current interferon signaling in these APCs. • Negative association: MMRN1 (endothelial/megakaryocyte granule protein) and FTH1 (ferritin heavy chain, abundant in iron-handling or oxidative-stress programs) are down-weighted, reinforcing that the program is specific to interferon-activated APCs and not endothelial/platelet or iron-storage-focused cells. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; the limited gene list is cohesive, though the presence of only two ISGs (IFI27, ISG15) provides modest rather than comprehensive evidence of a full interferon response.

program_20.description: The gene set is most consistent with an “IL-33⁺ inflammatory/remodeling fibroblast” program—i.e., tissue-resident fibroblasts that have been activated to secrete the alarmin IL-33, remodel extracellular matrix, and modulate coagulation/growth‐factor signalling during wound repair or chronic inflammation. Evidence: • IL33 – canonical alarmin highly expressed by activated stromal fibroblasts in inflamed or fibrotic tissues (lung, synovium, skin). • MMP28 and SULF1 – matrix metalloproteinase and heparan-sulfate endosulfatase frequently up-regulated in fibroblasts undergoing extracellular-matrix remodeling/fibrosis. • F2R (PAR1) and CLIC3 – coagulation- and chloride-channel genes induced in myofibroblasts; PAR1 mediates thrombin-driven fibroblast activation. • IGF2 – growth factor secreted by stromal fibroblasts to support tissue repair and epithelial proliferation. • KCTD12 – reported in mesenchymal stromal cells and up-regulated during TGF-β/IL-1–driven fibroblast activation, fitting a broad fibroblast activation profile. Inconsistencies: • KCTD12 is better known for neuronal roles, but its documented expression in activated mesenchyme lessens the conflict; otherwise, the gene set shows little contradiction to an activated fibroblast program.

program_21.description: The gene set most closely matches a capillary / micro-vascular endothelial program characteristic of angiogenic or tip/stalk-like endothelial cells. Evidence: • Classical endothelial markers: EMCN (endomucin, highly enriched in capillary ECs), RAMP2 (adrenomedullin-receptor component broadly expressed in ECs), and TSPAN12 (supports Norrin/Wnt signalling in vascular ECs). • Pro-angiogenic / motility genes: S100A4 (FSP1; up-regulated in activated, migrating ECs and during endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition), RAMP2 (required for angiogenic signalling), and EMCN (up-regulated in sprouting ECs). • Wnt/BMP modulators found in specialized endothelial sub-types: SOSTDC1 (secreted BMP antagonist expressed in subsets of lung, cardiac and tumor-associated microvascular ECs and linked to vascular patterning), TSPAN12 (ligand modulator in Wnt/Norrin endothelial pathways). • General cytoskeletal component associated with dynamic cells: TUBA1A (α-tubulin isoform enriched in proliferative/migratory states). Inconsistencies: • S100A3 is best known from hair follicle keratinocytes; its presence is not typical for endothelium and may reflect low-level or context-specific expression. • S100A4 is also a fibroblast marker; while it fits an activated/migratory EC phenotype, it could indicate some admixture or endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition rather than pure endothelial identity.

program_22.description: The gene set reflects an epithelial–mesenchymal transition (EMT)/pro-migratory stress program, typical of epithelial cancer cells or wounded epithelial cells acquiring mesenchymal, cytoskeletal-reorganizing and survival features while suppressing pro-apoptotic signaling. Evidence: • Mesenchymal cytoskeleton: VIM (vimentin) and ANXA2/S100A10 complex are canonical EMT genes that reorganize actin and promote cell motility. • Stress-survival chaperone: HSPB1 (Hsp27) is induced by heat-shock and EMT, stabilizing cytoskeleton and protecting against apoptosis. • Invasion/metastasis marker: SNCG is frequently up-regulated in invasive carcinomas and enhances cell motility, aligning with an EMT state. • Suppressed apoptosis: Negative loading of TNFSF10 (TRAIL) is consistent with reduced pro-apoptotic signaling in cells selecting for survival during EMT. Inconsistencies: • SNCG is classically neuronal; its presence is atypical for normal mesenchymal/fibroblast cells, but its known up-regulation in metastatic epithelial tumors mitigates this conflict.

program_23.description: The gene set points to hepatocytes that have activated a p53-associated stress/senescence program: the cytochrome P450 gene CYP3A5 anchors the profile to liver parenchymal cells, while concurrent induction of SERPINE1, CDKN2B and BBC3 together with other stress-responsive genes (S100A6, CD83) is characteristic of hepatocyte injury leading to cell-cycle arrest, pro-apoptotic priming and a modest senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP). Evidence: • Hepatocyte identity – CYP3A5 is a hallmark phase-I drug-metabolising enzyme highly enriched in mature hepatocytes. • Senescence/cell-cycle arrest – CDKN2B (p15^INK4b) and BBC3 (PUMA) are canonical p53 targets that enforce growth arrest and apoptosis during DNA-damage or oxidative stress in hepatocytes. • SASP / injury response – SERPINE1 (PAI-1) and S100A6 are well-described components of the hepatocyte SASP and are induced by TGF-β or p53 during liver injury; both accumulate in stressed or senescent liver cells. • Immune-modulatory facet – CD83, while best known in activated dendritic cells, is up-regulated in damaged or cytokine-stimulated hepatocytes and forms part of the inflammatory milieu generated by senescent cells. Inconsistencies: • CD83 is more typical of activated dendritic/B cells and is only sporadically reported in hepatocytes, so its presence may reflect paracrine signalling contamination or mixed cell states.

program_24.description: The gene set reflects a broad interferon-stimulated antiviral program characteristic of cells recently exposed to type I/II interferons—commonly seen in professional antigen-presenting cells (e.g., dendritic cells, macrophages) and, under inflammatory conditions, in endothelial or other parenchymal cells. Evidence: • Canonical interferon-stimulated genes: BST2 (tetherin), IFIT1, and OAS1 are classic ISGs induced by type I IFNs and restrict viral replication. • Antigen presentation machinery: HLA-DRB1 (MHC-II β-chain) is up-regulated by IFN-γ and marks activated antigen-presenting cells. • Stress/IFN-linked accessory genes: DEPP1 (autophagy regulator induced by oxidative/IFN stress) and RAMP2 (reported to be up-regulated in endothelial cells after cytokine stimulation), both compatible with an interferon-driven inflammatory state. Inconsistencies: • RAMP2 is most abundant in vascular endothelium and not a classical ISG, possibly indicating endothelial contribution or a mixed cell-type signature rather than pure APC identity. • DEPP1 is primarily noted for autophagy regulation and is not uniformly linked to interferon responses, suggesting some pathway heterogeneity.

program_25.description: The gene set is most consistent with an extracellular-matrix–secreting interstitial fibroblast / stromal cell program (often termed “matrix fibroblast” or “adventitial fibroblast”), reflecting a quiescent, non-myofibroblastic state enriched for ECM structural proteins, secreted regulators of matrix organization, and complement factor production. Evidence: • ECM core proteins – DCN (decorin) and CCDC80 are canonical fibrillar-collagen-associated proteoglycans/adhesion molecules highly expressed in interstitial fibroblasts. • Matrix‐modifying secreted factors – SERPINF1 (PEDF) and IGFBP6 are classical fibroblast-derived secreted proteins that regulate collagen deposition and growth-factor availability. • Stromal complement/adipokine signature – CFD (adipsin) is produced by fibroblasts and adipose stromal cells, marking adventitial fibroblasts that interface with immune cells. • General stromal stress-response/oxidoreductase – MGST1 is broadly expressed in mesenchymal cells and supports detoxification in matrix-rich stromal niches. Inconsistencies: • No strong inconsistencies; absence of myofibroblast markers (e.g., ACTA2, TAGLN) simply indicates a non-contractile fibroblast state rather than contradicting the assignment.

program_26.description: The gene set is most consistent with a junction/adhesion-focused endothelial cell program characteristic of relatively quiescent, barrier-forming vascular endothelial cells. Evidence: • Endothelial junction markers – JAM2 (tight-junction adhesion molecule) and CTNNAL1 (adherens-junction scaffold) are classical venous/vascular endothelial genes. • Membrane organizer TSPAN7 is enriched in brain and microvascular endothelial cells and promotes endothelial sprouting and barrier integrity. • PLK2 is inducible by shear stress in endothelial cells and participates in vascular remodeling, fitting an endothelial context. • Negative loading of S100A6, a calcium-binding protein that is up-regulated in activated or stressed endothelial/fibroblast states, supports a comparatively quiescent barrier phenotype. Inconsistencies: • CYYR1 is best known for expression in endocrine tissues and is not a standard endothelial marker. • PLK2 can also mark cycling cells, which could imply some proliferative activity rather than full quiescence.

program_27.description: The gene set represents a contractile smooth-muscle / myofibroblast program, characteristic of vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) or fibroblasts that have adopted a smooth-muscle–like (ACTA2⁺) state. Evidence: • ACTA2 (α-smooth-muscle actin), TPM2 (tropomyosin 2) and MYL9 (myosin light-chain 9) form the core contractile apparatus that defines VSMCs and activated myofibroblasts. • CRIP1/CRP1 is a LIM-domain protein enriched in vascular smooth muscle, promoting actin filament organization during smooth-muscle differentiation. • ACTB encodes β-actin, a ubiquitous but essential cytoskeletal component that is highly expressed in cells with augmented contractile machinery, reinforcing the structural program. Inconsistencies: • ACTB is broadly expressed and alone is not specific to smooth muscle; however, in the context of the other contractile genes it is not discordant.

program_28.description: The gene set is most compatible with a vascular endothelial-cell program characterized by cytoskeletal remodeling and secretion of proteases/complement regulators. Evidence: • ACTN1 – actin-binding protein enriched in endothelial and other contractile cytoskeletal structures; required for maintenance of endothelial junctions. • PRCP – endothelial and macrophage lysosomal/secreted serine carboxypeptidase that modulates the kallikrein–kinin system and blood-pressure control, a canonical endothelial product. • CFI – complement factor I, synthesized by endothelial cells (as well as liver and myeloid cells) to regulate local complement activation on the vascular surface. • DUSP23 – phosphatase induced by MAPK signaling and oxidative stress in endothelial cells, linked to barrier regulation. • TMEM273 (ILDR2) – transmembrane protein reported in endothelial and immune interfaces, implicated in vascular immune regulation. Inconsistencies: • ACTN1 is also highly expressed in megakaryocytes/platelets, so its presence is not uniquely endothelial. • DUSP23 is broadly expressed and not specific to any single lineage, reducing the overall specificity of the program.

program_29.description: The gene set most consistently reflects vascular endothelial cells in a mildly activated / stress-responsive state. Evidence: • Endothelial identity & remodeling – PRSS23 and ADAM15 are enriched in blood- and lymphatic-vessel endothelial cells and are up-regulated during endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition and angiogenic remodeling. • Complement protection on the vessel surface – CD59 is a GPI-anchored inhibitor of the membrane-attack complex that is constitutively expressed by endothelial cells to prevent complement-mediated damage. • Oxidative-stress defense typical of shear-exposed endothelium – NQO1 is a canonical NRF2 target induced in endothelial cells under sheer-related oxidative stress. • Endothelial secretory function – TCN2 (transcobalamin II) is secreted by vascular endothelium and macrophages and is detected in single-cell profiles of capillary and venous endothelial subsets. Inconsistencies: • The listed genes are not entirely endothelial-restricted (e.g., CD59, NQO1, TCN2 are also present in various hematopoietic and parenchymal cells); however, their combined presence with the endothelial-biased PRSS23 and ADAM15 and the absence of lineage-specific markers for other cell types favors an endothelial interpretation.

program_30.description: The gene set is most consistent with a lung alveolar epithelial program dominated by type I pneumocyte identity but retaining some type II/precursor features—characteristic of the AT2-to-AT1 transitional state observed during alveolar differentiation or repair. Evidence: • AT1 markers – AGER and HOPX are canonical, high-level transcripts of mature type I pneumocytes. • Transitional/alveolar regeneration marker – GPRC5A is strongly up-regulated in AT2→AT1 intermediate cells and in injury-induced “alveolar differentiation intermediates.” • Residual surfactant gene – SFTPB, while a classic type II marker, is often still expressed in AT2-derived cells that are converting toward an AT1 fate. • General epithelial/structural support – LMO7 is enriched in lung epithelial cells and increases during cytoskeletal remodeling that accompanies AT1 cell spreading. Inconsistencies: • SFTPB is largely absent from fully differentiated AT1 cells; its presence indicates the program is not a pure AT1 signature but a mixed or transitional state. • LMO7 lacks strict cell-type specificity, so its inclusion provides limited discriminatory power.

program_31.description: The program is most consistent with a KRT8-high transitional alveolar epithelial state (often termed “alveolar differentiation intermediate” or “damage-associated transient progenitor”) that appears during the conversion of type II to type I alveolar epithelial cells after lung injury. Evidence: • AGER (RAGE) – canonical marker of mature alveolar type I (AT1) cells, indicating alveolar epithelial lineage. • KRT8, KRT18, KRT7 – cytokeratins enriched in simple epithelia and specifically up-regulated in KRT8⁺ transitional/repair epithelial cells that emerge between AT2 and AT1 states. • TACSTD2 (EPCAM) – epithelial adhesion molecule retained by progenitor-like alveolar cells and lost in fully mature AT1 cells, supporting an intermediate/progenitor rather than terminally differentiated identity. Inconsistencies: No clear discordant genes are present in this limited list.

program_32.description: The gene set reflects an immediate-early, stress-induced activation program that is agnostic to lineage but is commonly seen in many cell types shortly after acute stimulation, tissue dissociation, or hypoxic stress. Evidence: • JUN – canonical AP-1 immediate-early transcription factor induced within minutes of MAPK signaling. • DUSP1 – MAPK phosphatase rapidly up-regulated to provide negative feedback during cellular stress or LPS/IL-1 stimulation. • NR4A1 – orphan nuclear receptor whose transcription spikes after calcium/TCR or growth-factor signaling, marking early activation. • KLF2 – stress-responsive Kruppel-like factor maintained in the earliest phase of activation and shear/hypoxia responses. • ANKRD37 – direct HIF-1α target induced by hypoxia, fitting a general stress response milieu. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; absence of other classical IEGs (e.g., FOS, EGR1) slightly narrows the signature but does not conflict with an immediate-early stress program.

program_33.description: The gene set points to a professional antigen-presenting immune cell, most consistent with an MHC-II–high macrophage or dendritic‐cell–like state that is actively engaged in antigen processing and migration, rather than an endothelial lineage. Evidence: • Antigen presentation: CD74 (invariant chain) and HLA-DPB1 are core MHC-II components, a hallmark of macrophages, dendritic cells and B cells. • Myeloid/activation cues: TMSB4X supports actin remodeling required for motility and phagocytosis in activated macrophages/DCs. • Tissue-interaction signal: APLNR is reported on subsets of tissue and tumor-associated macrophages that interact with the apelin-rich vasculature, fitting a specialized macrophage/DC subset rather than B cells. • Non-endothelial signature: TFPI, abundant in endothelial cells, is negatively loaded, arguing against an endothelial identity and aligning with an immune cell. Inconsistencies: • APLNR is more classically linked to endothelial and pericyte cells; its strong positive loading may indicate either a vascular-associated macrophage subset or modest cross-contamination with endothelial transcripts.

program_34.description: The program is most consistent with vascular endothelial cells that have been exposed to interferon (particularly IFN-γ) and have adopted an antigen-presenting, inflamed state. Evidence: • Endothelial identity – AQP1 (aquaporin-1) and CAVIN2/SDPR are canonical markers of capillary/venous endothelial cells and caveolae formation. • Interferon response – IFI27 is a prototypic type I/II interferon-stimulated gene, indicating recent cytokine exposure. • MHC-II up-regulation – HLA-DRB1 and HLA-DPA1 are MHC class II molecules that endothelial cells inducibly express after IFN-γ stimulation, enabling antigen presentation to CD4⁺ T cells. Inconsistencies: No major conflicts; while HLA-II genes are also expressed by professional antigen-presenting cells, those cells do not typically co-express endothelial-specific markers such as AQP1 and CAVIN2.

program_35.description: The program is most consistent with an activated, inflammation-associated fibroblast state characterized by robust extracellular matrix (matrisome) production coupled to local complement synthesis. Evidence: • ECM/matrisome genes FN1 (fibronectin), FBLN2 (fibulin-2) and BGN (biglycan) are canonical markers of tissue-remodeling fibroblasts. • Complement factors CFH and CFD are frequently up-regulated by inflammatory fibroblasts and stromal cells to modulate innate immune responses at sites of tissue injury. • The concurrent enrichment of structural matrix components (FN1, BGN, FBLN2) with complement regulators (CFH, CFD) matches transcriptomic signatures described for “inflammatory” or “complement-producing” fibroblast subsets in wound healing, fibrosis and arthritic synovium. Inconsistencies: • CFD (“adipsin”) is classically high in adipocytes; however, several studies report its induction in activated fibroblasts, so this is only a minor potential inconsistency.

program_36.description: The gene set typifies differentiated secretory epithelial cells of the conducting airway, particularly club (Clara) and related goblet/serous cells engaged in mucosal secretion. Evidence: • SCGB1A1 and SCGB3A1 – canonical, highly abundant secretoglobins that define mouse and human airway club cells. • BPIFB1 – PLUNC family protein restricted to airway goblet/serous cells and submucosal gland ducts, marking mucosal secretion. • MSMB – small secreted protein enriched in several mucosal gland epithelia, including tracheobronchial serous cells. • ELF3 – epithelial-specific ETS transcription factor that promotes secretory differentiation of airway epithelium and is up-regulated in club/goblet cells. Inconsistencies: • MSMB is classically associated with prostate epithelium and is less frequently reported in airway tissue, so its presence may reflect a broader secretory program rather than airway exclusivity.

program_37.description: The gene set is most consistent with an airway/secretory epithelial cell program acutely exposed to glucocorticoids or other stress-inflammatory cues, characterised by induction of classical glucocorticoid-response genes and simultaneous production of chemokines that recruit immune cells. Evidence: • FKBP5 and ZBTB16 – well-validated, immediate glucocorticoid-receptor (GR) target genes, indicating active GR signaling. • SCGB3A1 – secretoglobin highly enriched in lung/airway club (secretory) epithelial cells, pointing to an epithelial origin. • CCL20 and CCL4L2 – NF-κB–inducible chemokines secreted by epithelial cells after inflammatory or stress stimuli, attracting CCR6+ and CCR5+ leukocytes, respectively; their co-expression with FKBP5/ZBTB16 fits a “GR-modulated inflammatory response” state in epithelium. Inconsistencies: • ZBTB16 is better known for expression in innate-like lymphocytes (NKT/MAIT/ILC); however, its strong induction by glucocorticoids can account for its presence here despite the epithelial context.

program_38.description: The program most closely reflects an activated cytotoxic lymphocyte state—i.e., T- or NK-cells that have recently received antigenic stimulation, up-regulated early activation markers, and are secreting chemokines to recruit additional immune effectors. Evidence: • GNLY – cytolytic granule protein characteristic of cytotoxic T cells and NK cells. • CD69 – canonical early activation marker on T and NK cells; also enriched on tissue-resident/effector-memory subsets. • CCL3 and CCL4 – MIP-1α/β chemokines released by activated cytotoxic lymphocytes to attract additional T, NK, and myeloid cells. • CXCR4 – chemokine receptor expressed on memory/activated T cells and many NK cells, supporting chemotaxis and tissue retention. Inconsistencies: • No major inconsistencies; the list lacks some classic cytotoxic genes (e.g., GZMB, PRF1), but none of the observed genes contradict the activated cytotoxic lymphocyte interpretation.

program_39.description: The program most closely matches a monocyte-derived “fibrocyte” or ECM-producing inflammatory macrophage state, i.e. CD14⁺ myeloid cells beginning to secrete basement-membrane collagen while down-regulating more generic housekeeping / cystatin C genes. Evidence: • CD14 (strong positive) – canonical surface marker of classical monocytes/macrophages; retained in early fibrocytes. • COL4A2 (positive) – type IV collagen gene; up-regulated when monocytes transition to fibrocytes and begin extracellular-matrix production. • TCIM/C8orf4 (positive) – Wnt-responsive transcriptional co-activator reported to rise during monocyte activation and differentiation. • CST3 (negative) – cystatin C is usually abundant in resting macrophages; its repression aligns with a shift away from a homeostatic macrophage profile toward an ECM-producing phenotype. • FAU (negative) – ribosomal fusion protein; lower expression is commonly seen during exit from a proliferative, protein-synthesis-rich state toward a more specialized extracellular-matrix-secreting fate. Inconsistencies: • COL4A2 is also made by endothelial and mural cells, so without additional endothelial markers its presence alone is not fully specific to fibrocytes. • TCIM is broadly induced in several activated immune and epithelial contexts, providing limited cell-type specificity.

program_40.description: The gene set represents a ubiquitous acute cellular stress/heat-shock response state rather than a lineage-specific cell type; cells expressing this program are mounting a chaperone-mediated response to proteotoxic or other environmental stresses. Evidence: • HSPA1B (HSP70) and DNAJB1 (HSP40 family) – canonical inducible heat-shock chaperones that refold damaged proteins and are hallmarks of the heat-shock response. • JUN – an immediate-early AP-1 transcription factor rapidly induced by diverse stresses (heat, oxidative, cytokine) and drives transcription of stress-response genes. • UBC – encodes poly-ubiquitin; its up-regulation supplies ubiquitin for tagging misfolded proteins for proteasomal degradation during stress. • RHOB – GTPase up-regulated by DNA damage and stress, involved in actin cytoskeleton remodeling and cell survival signaling. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes are broadly consistent with a generic stress/heat-shock program and are not contradictory to this interpretation.

program_41.description: The gene set is most consistent with an IL-33–high, perivascular/adventitial fibroblast program displaying extracellular-matrix production and a mild interferon-stimulated state. Evidence: • Canonical perivascular/adventitial fibroblast / stromal ECM genes – MGP, HSPG2 (Perlecan) and ENPP2 (Autotaxin) are all enriched in vascular-associated fibroblasts that line the vessel adventitia and contribute basement-membrane components. • IL33 is a hallmark cytokine of “IL-33⁺ adventitial fibroblasts” described in lung, skin and gut, positioning these cells as tissue-resident immune sentinels. • IFITM1 signifies an interferon-responsive activation state that is frequently induced in stromal cells during inflammation and complements the IL-33 alarmin profile. Inconsistencies: No clear contradictions; IFITM1 is also expressed by endothelial cells, but its presence is compatible with an interferon-activated fibroblast phenotype.

program_42.description: The gene set best fits a generic proteotoxic/heat-shock stress response program that can be activated in many cell types rather than a lineage-defining signature. Evidence: • HSP90AA1 and HSPH1 encode major cytosolic heat-shock chaperones induced upon elevated temperature and other protein-damaging stresses. • INTS6 (Integrator complex) and HEXIM1 (P-TEFb inhibitor) are part of the transcription-pausing machinery that is rapidly up-regulated during acute stress to globally dampen mRNA elongation and allow preferential expression of stress-response genes. • The list lacks canonical, mutually reinforcing lineage markers; the four genes above are ubiquitously inducible and collectively constitute a well-described heat-shock/proteostasis module. Inconsistencies: • MAFB is a transcription factor characteristic of monocyte/macrophage differentiation and is not a core component of classical heat-shock pathways; its presence may reflect cell-type composition or an unrelated differentiation cue rather than the stress program itself.

program_0.description: The programme most closely matches the “KRT8+/TACSTD2+ alveolar epithelial transitional cell” that appears during lung injury and regeneration, i.e. an epithelial progenitor derived from alveolar type II (AT2) cells as they convert toward type I (AT1) fate. Evidence: • Lung-epithelial identity – NKX2-1 (TTF-1), EPCAM, CDH1, CLDN3/4/18, OCLN, KRT7/8/18/19, TACSTD2/TROP2, TM4SF1. • AT2 ancestry – ABCA3, LPCAT1, ALOX15B, SLC22A31, SFT-cofactor gene ITGB6, SCGB1A1 and PIGR (secretory/club and surfactant-processing genes frequently retained in transitioning AT2 cells). • Early AT1/transition markers – AGER, CLDN18, EPCAMlow/CLDN4high pattern, together with KRT8, S100A2, S100A14, AGR2/3 and YAP1, a set repeatedly reported for damage-associated transient progenitors (DATPs/KRT8+ cells). • Regenerative/remodelling signalling – YAP1, CCND1, ID1/4, EPAS1, EGFR, MET, ITGA3/B6, suggesting a proliferative, matrix-remodelling state typical of regenerating epithelium. • Negative loading of immune/hematopoietic genes (TMSB4X, FTH1, CD52, DOK1, CTSZ, GLIPR1) further supports a non-immune, epithelial programme. Inconsistencies: • Presence of SCGB1A1 (airway club), GKN2 and MSLN (gastric/mesothelial), and erythroid genes HBA2/HBB/HBA1, plus macrophage marker FOLR2, indicate minor contamination or shared stress responses rather than core features of the transitional alveolar epithelium.

program_1.description: The program represents a generic, highly proliferative cell-cycle state encompassing both S phase (DNA synthesis) and G2/M phase (mitosis) that can be activated in virtually any dividing cell type. Evidence: • S-phase/DNA replication genes – TYMS, RRM1/2, PCNA, MCM2-8, DHFR, FEN1, RFC3-5, PRIM1, CDT1, GMNN, BRCA1/2, RAD51, CHEK1 indicate active DNA synthesis and replication licensing. • G2/M regulators – CCNA2, CCNB1/2, CDK1/2, WEE1, PKMYT1, UBE2C, CDC20, BUB1/B, MAD2L1, TTK drive entry into and progression through mitosis. • Mitotic spindle/segregation components – AURKA/B, KIF11, KIF14/18A/20B/23, TPX2, NUSAP1, CENP family, NUF2, SPC25, PRC1, RACGAP1 ensure chromosome alignment and cytokinesis. • Proliferation markers – MKI67, TOP2A, BIRC5 (Survivin), PCLAF, MELK, EZH2 are classical hallmarks of actively cycling cells across tissues. • DNA repair and chromatin assembly factors – HELLS, UHRF1, CHAF1A/B, DNMT1, ASF1B support replication-coupled chromatin remodeling typical of dividing cells. Inconsistencies: No major gene sets conflict with a cycling program; occasional metabolic genes (PHGDH, IDH2) or structural genes (LMNB1) are commonly up-regulated during proliferation and are not contradictory.

program_2.description: The gene set describes MHC-II–high, interferon-stimulated tissue macrophages/monocytes that are primed for antigen presentation and complement-mediated clearance (often termed “APC-like” or “interferon-activated” macrophages). Evidence: • Antigen presentation machinery – strong positive loading of CD74 and virtually the entire HLA class II locus (HLA-DRA, ‑DRB1, ‑DPB1, ‑DQA1/2, ‑DQB1/2, ‑DMA) together with β-2-microglobulin, HLA-A/B/C/E. • Core macrophage markers – C1QA/B/C, MARCO, VSIG4, AIF1, FCGR3A (CD16), CD14, SRGN, CTSC/CTSS, LGALS3, APOE and MS4A4A identify mature tissue macrophages rather than dendritic cells or neutrophils. • Complement and scavenger/receptor-mediated clearance – SERPING1, CFD, C8B, C1QC, VSIG4, MARCO support a phagocytic/complement mode typical of resident or alternatively activated macrophages. • Interferon/immune activation – IFIT3, IFI27, GBP5, CXCL9, CXCL11, CAMP and JUN denote recent type I/II IFN signalling and an inflammatory stimulus. • Lipid-handling genes associated with alveolar or other tissue-resident macrophages (FABP4/5, ALDH1A1, APOE, FOLR2/3) also load positively, consistent with resident macrophage identity. • Negative loadings remove dendritic-cell genes (FCER1A, CLEC10A), SPP1/VCAN-hi scar-associated macrophage markers, and antioxidant-stress genes (HMOX1, SLC7A11, GCLM), sharpening the distinction toward the APC/IFN-activated macrophage phenotype. Inconsistencies: • CDH1 (E-cadherin) is more typical of epithelial cells, though low-level expression has been reported in some macrophage subsets. • Presence of TIMD4 and FOLR2 (usually enriched in quiescent resident macrophages) alongside strong IFN-response genes suggests a mixture of homeostatic and activated signatures. • S100A4 and VIM are cytoskeletal genes broadly expressed in mesenchymal cells and may reflect general motility rather than a macrophage-specific program.

program_3.description: The gene set represents an activated, phagocytic myeloid program characteristic of circulating or recently‐recruited inflammatory monocytes/macrophages that are engaged in antigen presentation, oxidative burst and chemokine secretion rather than cell-cycle progression. Evidence: • Core myeloid identity – CD14, FCGR3A (CD16), LST1, AIF1, COTL1, ITGAM, CORO1A, CYBA/CYBB and the complement genes C1QA/B/C. • Antigen processing/presentation – high MHC-II complex (HLA-DRA, HLA-DQA2, HLA-DRB5), CD74 and B2M. • Phagolysosomal & oxidative machinery – CTSB/L/S, CTSD, LYZ, RNASE2/6, SRGN, GRN, TYMP together with NADPH-oxidase subunits CYBA/CYBB and Fc-receptor chain FCER1G. • Inflammatory chemokines/cytokines – CCL4, CCL15, CCL18, CCL23, CXCL11, CAMP and interferon-stimulated genes ISG15, IFI27, LY6E, GBP1. • Motility/cytoskeletal re-organisation fitting recent recruitment – CFL1, PFN1, TAGLN2, ACTB, ACTG1, TMSB4X, RAC1. • Tissue-homing receptor CXCR4 and cell-cycle/translation genes (FAU, NPM1, CCNB1IP1, multiple EIFs) are negatively loaded, supporting a non-proliferative, peripheral rather than marrow-resident state. Inconsistencies: • Concurrent expression of FCN1 and S100A8/A9 (classical blood monocyte) with MARCO and FABP4 (more typical of alveolar/resident macrophages) suggests a mixture of monocyte and tissue-resident signatures. • Platelet-associated PPBP is unusually high and may reflect ambient platelet RNA. • Alveolar macrophage markers PLIN2, MFGE8 and ALOX15B are negatively loaded, arguing against a fully differentiated alveolar macrophage identity.

program_4.description: The gene set depicts a classically activated (NF-κB–driven) inflammatory monocyte / monocyte-derived dendritic-cell state, similar to human peripheral blood CD14⁺ monocytes stimulated through TLR2/4. Cells in this program up-regulate a broad chemokine and cytokine arsenal, co-stimulatory molecules and antigen-presentation genes, while neutrophil-associated transcripts are specifically down-regulated. Evidence: • Pro-inflammatory chemokines highly expressed: CCL3, CCL3L3, CCL4, CCL20, CXCL1, CXCL2, CXCL3, CXCL5, CXCL8, CXCL10, CXCL11 – characteristic output of LPS-activated monocytes. • Cytokine and inflammasome genes: IL1A, IL1B, IL6, TNF, IL23A, IL27, NLRP3, IL1RN, PTGS2; together define classical (M1-like) activation. • NF-κB pathway components and negative feedback regulators: NFKB1, NFKB2, RELB, IKBKE, NFKBIA, NFKBIE, TNFAIP3, TNIP1/3 – indicates active NF-κB signalling. • Monocyte/macrophage identity: CD14, FCN1, CYBB, HCK, VCAN, MARCO, FFAR2, LILRA1/5, ITGB8, PLAUR. • Antigen presentation / co-stimulation: HLA-DQA2, CD80, CD83, CD274 (PD-L1), SLAMF1 – typical of monocyte-derived DCs engaging T cells. • Negative load of neutrophil markers (CEACAM8, LTB4R) and stress gene TXNIP supports selective activation of monocytes rather than neutrophils. Inconsistencies: • IL7R, BATF, RASGRP1 (T-cell associated), LILRA4 (plasmacytoid DC), and NKG7 (cytotoxic lymphoid) suggest minor cross-contamination or ambient RNA. • SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1 (airway epithelial/club cell) and ZP3 (oocyte-specific) transcripts are unexpected in myeloid cells and may represent low-level background expression.

program_5.description: The gene set reflects an activated, contractile fibroblast / myofibroblast program typical of stromal cells engaged in tissue repair or fibrotic remodeling. High expression of extracellular-matrix structural genes and remodeling enzymes is coupled with smooth-muscle–like contractile machinery, a profile classically seen in wound-healing fibroblasts, scar-forming myofibroblasts and many cancer-associated fibroblasts (myCAFs). Evidence: • Extracellular matrix production – major fibrillar collagens and proteoglycans (COL1A1, COL1A2, COL3A1, COL6A1-3, DCN, LUM, BGN, VCAN, FBN1, SPARC, SPARCL1) and matrix-associated factors (MFAP4/5, PCOLCE, PRELP). • Matrix remodeling and TGF-β signalling components characteristic of activated fibroblasts (MMP2, TIMP3, SERPINE1, CCN1, CCN2, LTBP4, FSTL1, RARRES1/2). • Contractile/myofibroblast cytoskeleton (ACTA2, MYH11, MYL9, TAGLN, TPM1, TPM2, CNN3, CRIP2, VCL) indicating acquisition of smooth-muscle–like tension-generating capacity. • Growth-factor and IGF-axis modulators enriched in stromal cells (IGFBP4/5/6/7, FGF7, FGF10, ACVRL1, BMPR2). • Caveolins and adhesion molecules (CAV1, CAVIN1/3, PALLD, CSRP1, BCAM) that support a contractile, matrix-interacting phenotype. • Negatively loaded genes include metabolic (FBP1) or interferon-responsive (IFI6) transcripts, further distinguishing this program from epithelial or immune states. Inconsistencies: • A small subset of myeloid- or mast-associated transcripts (S100A8, S100A12, CHIT1, TPSAB1) and lymphoid activation markers (CD69, IL2RA) appear, likely reflecting minor contamination or ambient RNA rather than the core fibroblast program.

program_6.description: The gene set is most consistent with vascular endothelial cells in an activated/angiogenic state that is beginning to acquire mesenchymal characteristics (partial endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition, EndMT). Evidence: • Endothelial identity – classical endothelial markers VWF, PECAM1, CLDN5, ESAM, FLT1, EGFL7, TM4SF1, PROCR, TFPI, CD93, CLEC14A, ADGRF5, RAMP2/3, ACVRL1 all load positively. • Angiogenic / hypoxia response – EPAS1 (HIF-2α), SERPINE1, VEGF-coreceptor NRP1 (via FLT1), EGFL7, CCN1/2, ID1/3, PTGDS, NQO1, CA4, IL32 and RAMP2/ CALCRL (adrenomedullin axis) indicate an actively remodeling, pro-angiogenic endothelium. • Mesenchymal acquisition – smooth-muscle/pericyte–associated genes ACTA2, TAGLN, MYL9, TPM1/2, CNN3, CALD1, COL3A1, COL6A2 and SPARC suggest partial EndMT or vessel stabilization program. • Extracellular matrix/remodeling – SPARCL1, TIMP3, MGP, HSPG2, EFEMP1, ADAMTS1, LTBP4 support matrix production typical of activated or transitioning endothelium. • Low oxidative phosphorylation – negative loading of mitochondrial genes ATP5F1C, TEFM, PPM1M fits reduced OXPHOS often seen in glycolytic, angiogenic endothelial cells. Inconsistencies: • S100A8 (myeloid), GIMAP7 (T-cell), KRT8 & S100A2 (epithelial), MSMB (prostate epithelium) and CTSK (osteoclast/fibroblast) are atypical for endothelium; they may reflect ambient RNA or low-level contamination rather than the core program.

program_7.description: The gene set defines an activated cytotoxic lymphocyte program characteristic of mature effector CD8⁺ T cells and cytotoxic NK/NKT cells, marked by high expression of perforin- and granzyme-mediated killing machinery, T-cell receptor signaling components, and killer lectin-like receptors, with concurrent suppression of HOXB6/HOXB7 typical of early hematopoietic progenitors. Evidence: • Cytotoxic effector molecules: GNLY, PRF1, GZMB, GZMA, GZMH, GZMM, CTSW, NKG7, FGFBP2 → hallmark proteins of CTL/NK granule-mediated cytotoxicity. • T-cell/NK activation and signaling: CD3D, CD247, CD2, CD7, LCK, FYN, SKAP1, PTPN7, RHOH, TRAF3IP3, ETS1 → components of TCR/CD3 and downstream signaling. • Killer lectin-like/NK markers: KLRD1 (CD94), KLRF1, KLRB1, CST7 → surface receptors and inhibitors enriched in NK and cytotoxic T subsets. • Chemokine and activation genes: CCL5, IL32, ISG20, DDIT4, ACAP1 → produced by activated effector T/NK cells to recruit other immune cells. • Broad leukocyte/lymphocyte genes: PTPRC, CORO1A, RAC2, DUSP2 confirm hematopoietic origin. • Negative loadings: HOXB6, HOXB7 (stem/progenitor transcription factors) are down-regulated, consistent with a mature differentiated cytotoxic state. Inconsistencies: • TPSAB1 and MS4A2 (mast-cell/basophil tryptase and FcεRIβ) and S100A12 (myeloid) suggest minor contamination or ambient RNA not typical of cytotoxic T/NK cells. • A2M (plasma protein) is atypical for lymphocytes but occasionally detected intracellularly; likely nonspecific.

program_8.description: The program most closely matches an IgE/FcεRI-stimulated mast-cell state: canonical mast-cell identity genes (KIT, GATA2, TPSAB1/2, MS4A2, RGS13) are highly expressed together with a broad set of immediate-early response factors (FOS, JUNB, ATF3, NR4A1/2/3, DUSP1/2/4, EGR2/3) and pro-inflammatory mediators (AREG, HBEGF, CXCL2/3, OSM, IL10), indicating recent, acute activation; housekeeping/cytoskeletal genes typical of quiescent cells (TMSB4X, PFN1, CRIP1, FABP4) are concurrently down-regulated. Evidence: • Mast-cell identity: KIT (SCF receptor), TPSAB1 & TPSB2 (tryptases), MS4A2 (FcεRI β-chain), GATA2 (mast-cell lineage TF), RGS13 (selectively restrains IgE signalling in mast cells). • Activation/immediate-early genes: FOS, JUNB, FOSB, ATF3, KLF4, NR4A1/2/3, DUSP1/2/4, SOCS3, TNFAIP3, IER3, CREM, EGR2/3—classic markers of rapid MAPK/NF-κB signalling after FcεRI cross-linking. • Secreted cytokines/chemokines and growth factors typical of activated mast cells: AREG, EREG, HBEGF, CXCL2, CXCL3, OSM, IL10, ANGPTL4. • Survival and signalling modulators used by activated mast cells: MCL1, CXCR4, RCAN1, RGS1/2, NLRP3. • Negative loadings (TMSB4X, PFN1, CRIP1, FABP4) mark reduced expression of generic cytoskeletal/adipocyte-associated genes, consistent with a shift away from a resting or stromal program. Inconsistencies: • NLRP3, CH25H and INSIG1 are more often highlighted in macrophage activation programs, though mast cells can express these during lipid-mediated signalling. • The program lacks strong expression of canonical basophil markers (e.g., CCR3, IL4), suggesting the signature is predominantly mast-cell rather than basophil despite partial overlap.

program_9.description: The gene set captures an acute, NF-κB/AP-1-driven inflammatory “immediate-early” program typical of recently activated monocyte-macrophage lineage cells (e.g., TLR or TNF/IL-1–stimulated macrophages). Evidence: • Canonical immediate-early transcription factors—FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB, JUND, ATF3, EGR1/2/3, NR4A1/2, KLF2/4/6, DUSP1/2, BTG2—mark rapid primary-response activation seen minutes to hours after macrophage stimulation. • NF-κB negative-feedback regulators (NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, SOCS3, PPP1R15A, TSC22D3) indicate NF-κB pathway engagement typical of inflammatory macrophages. • Myeloid/monocytic activation genes—CEBPB (lineage TF), CH25H (IFN-inducible cholesterol 25-hydroxylase), CXCL2, CXCL3, OSM, AREG, HBEGF, INHBA, THBS1, MMP19, RGCC—encode chemokines, cytokines and matrix-remodelling factors secreted by activated macrophages. • Surface/activation markers CD69 and CD83 are rapidly induced in activated monocytes/macrophages and dendritic cells. • Down-weighting of APOC1, a gene enriched in homeostatic, lipid-handling macrophages, is consistent with a shift from resting to activated state. Inconsistencies: • CLDN1 (tight-junction protein) and THBD & KLF2 (often endothelial) are less typical for macrophages, suggesting either cross-cell-type sharing of the immediate-early module or mixed cell populations. • Lack of classic macrophage structural markers (e.g., CD14, LILRB, MSR1) indicates this is a state-specific rather than lineage-defining program.

program_10.description: The gene set represents an interferon-activated, cytotoxic effector CD8⁺ T-cell state (effector/effector-memory T lymphocytes engaged in anti-viral or anti-tumor responses). Evidence: • T-cell identity: CD3D, CD3E, CD3G, CD2, PTPRC, CD48, IL2RG, FYN all define T-lineage cells. • Cytotoxic effector machinery: GZMB, CST7, SERPINB9, TNFSF10, PRDM1, RUNX3, CCL5 encode granzymes, perforin regulators, death-ligands and transcription factors driving terminal effector CD8⁺ differentiation. • Interferon/activation signature: ISG20, IFITM3, CXCL10, IL32, ETV7, BIRC3 reflect type-I/II IFN stimulation typical of recently activated, pathogen- or tumor-reactive T cells. • Lymphocyte survival/trafficking and signaling: GIMAP7, CORO1A, STIM2, ACAP1 support activated T-cell function and migration. Inconsistencies: • WFDC2 and OCIAD2 are mainly described in epithelial contexts; their presence is atypical for T cells but could reflect low-level or ambient RNA contamination. • CLEC2D is usually an NK-cell ligand rather than a T-cell marker, yet low expression can occur in activated lymphocytes.

program_11.description: The gene set reflects an alternatively-activated / immunoregulatory tissue macrophage program characterized by high lysosomal-phagocytic activity, lipid and iron handling, and secretion of M2-associated chemokines. Evidence: • Core macrophage identity – C1QA, C1QC, CD68, CYBA, MS4A6A, LGMN, CAPG mark professional phagocytes. • Enhanced lysosome / phagolysosome function – multiple cathepsins (CTSD, CTSL, CTSB, CTSK), CTSA, PSAP, NPC2, LIPA, ASAH1, PLA2G7 cooperate in lipid and protein degradation. • Lipid-handling, LXR axis – APOE, PLTP, NR1H3 (LXRα), GPNMB, MGST1 support cholesterol efflux and oxidative-stress protection typical of M2 and tissue-resident macrophages. • Iron / heme metabolism – HMOX1 (heme oxygenase-1) and HAMP (hepcidin) are up-regulated during iron recycling by macrophages. • Immunoregulatory chemokines – CCL18, CCL23, CCL13, CCL2, CCL7 are signature transcripts of alternatively activated (IL-4/IL-10) or tumor-associated macrophages. • Tolerogenic regulators – TMEM176A/B, PLXNC1 and ORM1 are enriched in suppressive macrophage/DC states. Inconsistencies: • AGRP (neuronal appetite peptide) appears among negatively loaded genes, suggesting it is simply low in macrophages rather than informative for this program. • Limited representation of pro-inflammatory (M1) cytokines (e.g., IL1B, TNF) fits the M2 interpretation but their complete absence should be noted.

program_12.description: The gene set reflects a classical/inflammatory monocyte-to-early-macrophage activation program (often termed “VCAN/FCN1 inflammatory monocytes”). Cells running this program display strong chemotactic and inflammasome activity (CCR5, CCL13, GPR183, NLRP3), Fc-receptor‐mediated innate sensing, and extracellular-matrix interaction, while lacking lipid-handling and complement genes typical of tissue-resident or anti-inflammatory (FABP4+, C1QA+) macrophages. Evidence: • Classical/inflammatory monocyte core: FCN1, VCAN, CLEC5A, CORO1A, SIGLEC10, FCGR2B, ANXA6. • Chemotaxis & chemokine receptors: CCR5, CMKLR1, GPR183 (EBI2), CCL13 promote migration to inflamed tissue. • Inflammasome/innate activation: NLRP3, IL1R2, PLA2G7, SPHK1, PRKCB support IL-1 signaling and eicosanoid production. • Lipid handling & scavenging typical of activated monocytes: APOE, NPC2, SP P1 (osteopontin) but absence of FABP4 (negatively loaded). • Down-weighted resident/M2 signature: strong negative loadings for FABP4 and C1QA, markers of alveolar and other tissue-resident macrophages, underline a non-resident, pro-inflammatory state. Inconsistencies: • Endothelial/fibroblast-associated transcripts (RNASE1, SDC2, CLEC11A) and the tolerogenic-DC gene TMEM176B appear, suggesting some ambient RNA or minor contamination.

program_13.description: The gene set reflects an acutely TLR/cytokine-activated, pro-inflammatory classical (FCN1⁺/CD14⁺) monocyte / macrophage state that is shifting away from a homeostatic, C1QA/B⁺ tissue-resident macrophage profile. Evidence: • Pro-inflammatory chemo-cytokines and inflammasome components up: CXCL2, CXCL3, CCL2, OSM, AREG, EREG, NLRP3, PTGS2, IL10, TNFAIP3 → hallmark of LPS/TNF-stimulated monocytes. • Immediate-early response / stress-response TFs up: EGR1, IER3, BTG1, CREM, MXD1, DUSP2/4, BASP1 → typical of rapid monocyte activation. • Classical circulating-monocyte markers up: FCN1, CD300E, SAMSN1, GPR183, APOE, NPC2 → consistent with non-tissue-resident myeloid cells. • Homeostatic/resident macrophage genes down: C1QA, C1QB, TYROBP, APOC1, FABP4, ACP5, HLA-DRB5 → indicates loss of an M2-like, phagocytic or microglia-like program during acute activation. Inconsistencies: • IL10 and MCL1 (positive) provide anti-apoptotic/anti-inflammatory feedback rather than pro-inflammatory drive. • APOE (positive) and TXNIP, NUPR1 (negative) can also be expressed in resident macrophages, adding minor ambiguity but not overturning the overall activation signature.

program_14.description: The gene set is most consistent with an interferon-stimulated, inflammatory fibroblast/mesenchymal program such as the “iCAF” or CXCR4⁺ inflammatory stromal state observed in wound healing and many tumours. Evidence: • Type I/III interferon response – classical ISGs (ISG15, RSAD2/VIPERIN, IFI44L) together with CXCR4, EIF4EBP3 and RND3, all well-documented interferon-inducible transcripts. • Fibroblast / mesenchymal identity – INHBA (Activin-A, hallmark of inflammatory CAFs), SPRY1 (quiescent and activated fibroblasts), NEXN and LIMS2 (actin-binding, focal-adhesion proteins abundant in stromal cells), COCH and HPGD (stromal-extracellular matrix and eicosanoid-metabolism genes), PLIN2 (lipid-droplet protein enriched in lipid-laden fibroblasts and CAFs). • Broad stress/secretory machinery – up-regulation of translation and proteostasis components (PABPC1/4, EIF2S2, PSMA7, GABARAP, DYNC1I2) fits the high secretory output typical of inflammatory fibroblasts. Inconsistencies: • EVI2B is primarily a leukocyte marker and fits less well with a fibroblast state. • The program lacks several canonical fibroblast structural ECM genes (e.g., COL1A1, COL3A1), suggesting either a partial fibroblast signature or a state shared with other interferon-responsive cells.

program_15.description: The gene set is most consistent with airway secretory epithelial (club / goblet) cells that are undergoing an inflammatory-acute-phase response, a state frequently observed after viral or toxic injury to the bronchial epithelium. Evidence: • Secretory / airway epithelial identity – SCGB1A1 (club-cell secretoglobin), BPIFB1 and WFDC2 (airway antimicrobial secreted proteins), TPPP3 and KRT17 (stress-induced airway keratins), TSPAN1 and RARRES1 (epithelial surface proteins). • Acute-phase / innate-immune activation – LCN2, SAA1, SAA2, GSTP1, BIRC3 and ISG20 are classical epithelial acute-phase or interferon-stimulated genes induced by cytokines. • Chemokine/cytokine signalling typical of inflamed epithelium – IL32, CCL5, LTB, ECE1 and DOK1 are produced by airway epithelium to recruit or interact with immune cells. • Proliferation / repair components – CDK4, SMARCAD1, PSMC6, MALSU1 suggest a reparative or stress-proliferative state often seen after epithelial injury. • Down-regulation of DRAM2 (negative loading) fits suppression of autophagy observed in acute epithelial inflammation.
