Inconsistencies: • The T-cell receptor component CD3D and the lymphocyte chemokine CCL5 are classically T-cell genes; their high positive loading could reflect epithelial–lymphocyte doublets or ectopic expression, so they do not cleanly fit an epithelial program.

program_16.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with a lipid-handling, lysosome-enriched program of tissue-resident macrophages (e.g. alveolar, adipose or microglial “lipid-associated”/foam-cell-like states) that are non-proliferative and display heightened antimicrobial and scavenger activity. Evidence: • Core myeloid markers – TYROBP, LILRB4, LYZ, CD48, CAMP support a macrophage identity. • Lipid uptake/efflux and foam-cell genes – APOC1, APOC2, ABCA1, SCD, LRP1 indicate active cholesterol trafficking typical of lipid-laden tissue macrophages. • Lysosomal / phagolysosomal machinery – PSAP, CTSD, GM2A, SLC29A3, TFRC underscore enhanced catabolism of internalised material, a hallmark of resident or disease-associated macrophages. • Stress / activation factors – NUPR1, TIMP2, AOC3 align with an activated, tissue-remodeling macrophage state. • Negative loading of PTMA (a proliferation-linked histone chaperone) supports a differentiated, low-cycling phenotype. Inconsistencies: • ITLN1 (intestinal/airway epithelium), CAVIN4 (muscle), PKD2L1 and KCNJ5 (sensory/neuroendocrine) are atypical for macrophages and may reflect low-level ambient RNA, doublets or broader tissue-specific signals.

program_17.description: The gene set mirrors an acute NF-κB/AP-1–driven inflammatory activation program characteristic of classical peripheral‐blood monocytes / inflammatory macrophages exposed to LPS or related danger signals. Evidence: • Monocyte lineage markers: FCN1, FCAR (CD89), CEBPB, GPR183 are highly expressed in classical human monocytes. • Pro-inflammatory chemokines: CXCL2 and CXCL3 are canonical NF-κB targets secreted by activated monocytes to recruit neutrophils. • Immediate-early NF-κB/AP-1 response genes: NFKBIA, IER3, PPP1R15A, DUSP2, FOSL1, MAFF, NR4A2, ZC3H12A, RCAN1 indicate recent pathway activation. • Matrix-remodelling / migration genes typical of activated macrophages: MMP19, RGCC, AKR1C1, CYP1B1. • Stress-response / cytokine-regulated genes often induced by LPS: SAT1, MT1X, PHLDA1, EMP1, HES4/HEY1 (Notch-interferon cross-talk). Inconsistencies: • LMNA (nuclear lamina), TMEM217, SMIM3 are generic structural genes and not specific to monocytes. • CYP1B1 and EMP1 are expressed in several cell types, so their presence is not uniquely informative.

program_18.description: The gene set is most consistent with an alveolar / lipid-handling macrophage program that is modestly interferon-stimulated. Cells expressing this program show the canonical fatty-acid– and acute-phase–associated genes described for human lung-resident (alveolar) macrophages, together with broad antigen-presentation machinery, while simultaneously lacking the extracellular-matrix and VCAN-high profile typical of interstitial / tissue-remodeling macrophages or fibroblasts. Evidence: • Alveolar-macrophage, lipid and acute-phase signature: FABP4, SERPINA1, HP, ALDH2, MGST3, PSAP – all enriched in human alveolar macrophages and scarce in other myeloid subsets. • Core myeloid / antigen-presentation markers: CD74, FCER1G, MCEMP1, CAMP, CD59, CD52, C8B indicate a professional phagocyte with Fc-receptor and complement activity. • Interferon-responsive activation: LY6E and IFI27 mark moderate IFN stimulation, a state frequently observed in lung macrophages exposed to viral or inflammatory cues. • Negative loading of interstitial / mesenchymal genes: VCAN, SDC2, ANTXR2, AKR1C1 and the stromal/ECM gene OTOA are repressed, fitting the distinction between VCAN-high interstitial macrophages and FABP4-high alveolar macrophages. • Endothelial and inhibitory Fc receptor genes low: RNASE1 (endothelial) and FCGR2B (inhibitory FcγR) are under-represented, further separating this program from endothelial cells and from alternative macrophage subtypes that up-regulate FCGR2B. Inconsistencies: • S100A4 is more typical of fibroblasts or motile mesenchymal cells but can be induced in activated macrophages. • CD52 is classically a lymphocyte marker; however, low-level expression is documented in lung macrophages. • Suppression of FCGR2B contradicts its usual presence in many macrophage subsets, suggesting either selective down-regulation or mixture with another population.

program_19.description: The gene set is most consistent with an inflammatory/activated vascular endothelial (or closely related perivascular) program: cells that maintain core endothelial/pericytic identity while up-regulating stress and immune–interaction genes. A minority of strongly T-cell-specific transcripts are present and are likely ambient RNA or doublet contamination rather than true co-expression. Evidence: • Endothelial / perivascular identity – CLU, MGP, RAMP2, BCAM, PRSS23, OCIAD2, CRIP2, CD59 and C1RL are all well-described endothelial or pericyte transcripts involved in vascular integrity, matrix regulation and complement control. • Stress / inflammatory activation – IL32, LTB, FKBP11, DEPP1 and CCND2 rise in endothelial cells exposed to cytokines and drive autophagy, NF-κB signalling and limited proliferation typical of an “activated” state. • House-keeping / cytoskeletal support typical of endothelial cells – EZR, SPTBN1, SMAGP, UBTF, CAPS. • Negative loading of IL15 fits with endothelial cells that are not acting as strong IL-15 trans-presenters, distinguishing them from myeloid or stromal subsets. Inconsistencies: • Classical T-cell–restricted genes CD3D, CD2 and GIMAP7 (and to a lesser extent LTB) are not expected in endothelial cells; their co-loading most likely reflects ambient T-cell RNA or occasional endothelial–T-cell doublets rather than true expression in the vascular compartment.

program_20.description: The gene signature represents cells in a strong type-I/III interferon–stimulated antiviral state rather than a distinct lineage; the program is typical of many cell types acutely sensing viral nucleic acids or responding to exogenous IFN. Evidence: • Canonical interferon-stimulated genes highly up-regulated: ISG15, MX1, IFIT1/2/3, IFI6, IFI44L, IFI35, RSAD2, USP18, CMPK2, LY6E, GBP4, HERC5, EPSTI1, XAF1, ETV7 – textbook markers of the IFN response across epithelial, immune and stromal cells. • Chemokine CXCL11 (an IFN-γ/IFN-β inducible gene) fits an antiviral, immune-recruiting state. • Transcription factors CEBPB and ETV7 are themselves IFN-inducible and help propagate interferon-driven transcriptional programs. • Negative loading of DONSON, a DNA-replication fork protector, is consistent with the interferon-associated cell-cycle slowdown that accompanies antiviral defense. Inconsistencies: • PTPRN2 (neuronal/endocrine vesicle protein), HESX1 (pituitary development factor) and NEXN (muscle/actin-binding protein) are not classical ISGs; their positive loading may reflect cell-type–specific background expression rather than the interferon state itself.

program_21.description: The gene program represents activated mast cells, likely in an IL-33/ST2–responsive state characterized by degranulation‐associated proteases and early activation markers. Evidence: • Mast-cell–defining granule proteases: TPSAB1, TPSB2, CPA3 are uniquely abundant in tissue and peripheral mast cells. • Stem-cell-factor receptor KIT (CD117) is a canonical surface marker required for mast-cell development/survival. • IL1RL1 (ST2), together with CD69, LTB and IL32, denotes IL-33–induced early activation and cytokine production typical of stimulated mast cells in allergy or type-2 inflammation. • Anti-apoptotic/inflammatory regulators (BIRC3, CASP8, HDAC7) and trafficking genes (ACAP1, LAPTM4A, DTNBP1) are up-regulated in activated mast cells undergoing granule mobilization. Inconsistencies: • T-cell markers CD2 and CD7 are not typical of mast cells and may reflect low-level ambient RNA or minor T-cell contamination. • CSAD and CCHCR1 lack clear mast-cell specificity but do not contradict the overall program.

program_22.description: The gene signature is most consistent with an activated, lipid-handling macrophage program typified by TREM2⁺/APOE⁺/SPP1⁺ “lipid-associated” or “disease-associated” macrophages (LAM/DAM) seen in atherosclerotic lesions, obese adipose tissue, tumors and neuro-degenerative brain, characterized by enhanced phagocytosis, lysosomal activity and cholesterol processing while lacking the FABP4-high profile of homeostatic tissue-resident macrophages. Evidence: • Lipid handling / lysosomal genes: APOE, NPC2, LIPA, LGMN, MCOLN3, ATP6V0D2 – hallmark of cholesterol-loaded, lysosome-rich macrophages. • TREM2 pathway: TREM2 together with APOE and LIPA defines LAM/DAM populations that sense lipids and debris. • Phagocytic/osteoclast-like activation: SPP1 (osteopontin), CHIT1, CHI3L1, PLA2G7, MATK, CAMK1 promote matrix remodeling and engulfment; ATP6V0D2 is an osteoclast fusion/acidification gene frequently co-expressed in these macrophages. • Immune-regulatory receptors: FCGR2B, CD48, TMEM176B support a myeloid identity with dampened inflammatory signaling typical of LAM/DAM. • Negative loading of FABP4 argues against homeostatic adipose or alveolar macrophages, reinforcing a disease-associated state. Inconsistencies: • OTOA (inner-ear structural gene) and SDC2 (often fibroblast-associated) are atypical for macrophages but appear infrequently in single-cell datasets and may represent ambient RNA or low-level expression.

program_23.description: The gene set is most consistent with an AXL⁺/MSR1⁺ monocyte-derived macrophage or dendritic-cell program that has adopted a phagocytic, interferon-responsive and generally tolerogenic/anti-inflammatory state. Evidence: • Macrophage/phagocytosis markers – MSR1 (scavenger receptor CD204), FGD2, CDC42, CDC42SE1 and RASGEF1B all promote actin remodeling and particle uptake typical of macrophages and monocyte-derived DCs. • AXL⁺ tolerogenic myeloid state – AXL together with its sheddase ADAM17 defines the well-described AXL⁺ DC/macrophage subset associated with immune regulation and efferocytosis. • Interferon / antiviral response – APOBEC3C and RASGEF1B are classic type-I-IFN-inducible genes frequently up-regulated in antiviral, anti-inflammatory macrophages. • Active secretory and glycosylation machinery – B4GALT1, B3GNT7, ATP1B1 and PHKG1 support high membrane turnover and secretion characteristic of activated myeloid cells. • β-catenin signaling – CTNNB1 activation has been linked to tolerogenic functions in AXL⁺ DCs, fitting the regulatory phenotype. Inconsistencies: • Several genes (EIF5A, HNRNPH1, MTA2, CHP1) are housekeeping or broadly expressed and add little cell-type specificity. • BRSK1 (neuronal kinase) and IAH1 are atypical for myeloid cells and may represent background or dataset-specific artifacts rather than true functional elements of this program.

program_24.description: The gene set reflects a metabolic/anti-inflammatory program typical of alternatively activated (M2-like) or iron-recycling macrophages that rely on oxidative phosphorylation and reactive-oxygen-species detoxification rather than on pro-inflammatory signalling. Evidence: • Oxidative phosphorylation / mitochondrial respiration: ATP5F1E, ATP5ME, UQCR11 (ATP-synthase & complex III subunits), BDH1 (mitochondrial ketone-body enzyme), GPX1 (mitochondrial ROS scavenger) all rise together, indicating high OXPHOS activity. • Iron handling / anti-oxidant defence: FTL, FTH1 (ferritin chains) store red-ox active iron; GPX1 and CSTB further buffer oxidative stress—features of iron-recycling macrophages. • M2 / tissue-resident macrophage markers: CD163L1 (CD163 family scavenger receptor), FOLR3 (folate receptor enriched in resident macrophages), APOC2 (lipid-handling protein released by M2 macrophages) are positively loaded, while classical inflammatory genes B2M, ANXA1 and the stress-inducible phosphatase DUSP1 are negatively loaded, consistent with a non-inflammatory macrophage state. • Anti-proliferative or differentiation-linked regulators (PRDM6) appear with the oxidative module, matching the typically quiescent, metabolically active profile of resident macrophages. Inconsistencies: • PRDM6 is better known for smooth-muscle/pericyte differentiation, not macrophages. • DONSON (DNA-replication fork factor) suggests some proliferative activity that is not a hallmark of mature tissue-resident macrophages. • ACVR2B is broadly expressed and not specific to macrophages, so its presence is not informative for this program.

program_25.description: The gene set most closely matches adipose-derived mesenchymal stromal / pre-adipocyte (fibro-adipogenic) cells that are beginning to acquire an adipocyte-like, secretory program while retaining fibroblast‐ECM and mild interferon/VGLL3 activation signatures. Evidence: • Adipocyte-related lipid/retinoid handling: FABP4 and RBP4 are canonical adipokines enriched in mature and pre-adipocytes; C8B is an adipose-secreted complement component. • Preadipocyte / mesenchymal fibroblast factors: IGF1, FGF10, ITIH5, PCOLCE2 and HOXB6 are characteristic of adipose stromal fibroblasts that support adipogenesis and lay down ECM. • Secretory/IFN-stimulated fibroblast signature: IFI27 (type-I IFN target) and VGLL3 (transcription co-factor up-regulated in interferon-responsive fibroblasts) fit a subset of adipose or dermal fibroblasts exposed to cytokine signals. • Ion-channel and signaling genes seen in adipose stroma: KCNAB1 and NALCN transcripts have been reported in adipose-derived mesenchymal cells, consistent with stromal origin. Inconsistencies: • SKAP1 is primarily a T-cell adaptor protein and is atypical for stromal cells. • NALCN and KCNAB1 are better known for neuronal excitability, though low-level expression is documented in diverse stromal populations.

program_26.description: The gene set represents an acute heat-shock/proteotoxic-stress program, typical of cells that have recently activated HSF1-dependent chaperone machinery to stabilize or refold misfolded proteins; it reflects a transient stress state rather than a specific lineage. Evidence: • Canonical inducible HSP70 family members (HSPA1A, HSPA1B, HSPA6) and the major HSF1 targets HSP90AA1 / HSP90AB1 and HSPH1 signify classical heat-shock response activation. • Co-chaperones DNAJB1 (HSP40), HSPE1 (HSP10), and FKBP4 coordinate ATP-dependent folding with HSP70/HSP90, further indicating a concerted chaperone response. • HSPB1 (HSP27) and SERPINH1 (HSP47) are stress-inducible small/ER chaperones that prevent protein aggregation during thermal or oxidative insult, reinforcing a global proteostasis program. Inconsistencies: No obvious discordant genes; all listed factors participate in molecular chaperoning and are up-regulated during heat-shock or related stress conditions.

program_27.description: The gene set is most consistent with a contractile, extracellular-matrix-remodeling stromal cell state—classically termed an “activated myofibroblast” or perivascular smooth-muscle-like fibroblast—characterized by α-smooth-muscle actin expression and high production of matricellular proteins (CTGF/CCN2, CYR61/CCN1, SERPINF1) and matrix regulators (MGP, FBLN1, IGFBPs). Evidence: • Contractile machinery: ACTA2 (α-SMA) and CNN3 are hallmark genes of myofibroblasts and vascular smooth-muscle/pericyte lineages. • Matricellular activation: CCN2/CTGF and CCN1/CYR61 are classic indicators of activated fibroblasts driving ECM deposition and remodeling. • Matrix components/regulators: MGP and FBLN1 are abundantly expressed in vascular smooth muscle, pericytes, and fibrogenic fibroblasts, supporting a perivascular, ECM-focused phenotype. • Secreted growth-factor modulators: IGFBP4 and IGFBP6, along with SERPINF1 (PEDF), are widely produced by stromal fibroblasts undergoing activation, enhancing matrix organization and cell–matrix signaling. Inconsistencies: No strongly discordant genes are present; all listed genes align with an activated myofibroblast/perivascular stromal program.

program_28.description: The gene set is most consistent with an adipogenic program characteristic of differentiating or mature white adipocytes / adipocyte-biased mesenchymal stromal cells, reflecting active lipid synthesis, IGF-1–driven growth signaling and prostaglandin-regulated metabolic activity. Evidence: • Lipid metabolism & adipogenesis – SCD (key desaturase for triglyceride biosynthesis), GPD1 (glycerol backbone production), IGF1 (autocrine/paracrine driver of adipocyte differentiation). • Prostaglandin-linked lipolysis control – PTGER3 is the PGE2 receptor that modulates cAMP and lipolytic tone in adipocytes. • ECM remodeling typical of expanding adipose tissue – TGM2 cross-links extracellular matrix proteins during adipocyte hypertrophy. • Adipose/mesenchymal stromal markers – NTRK3 and CA2 are reported in marrow- and muscle-derived adipogenic progenitors; ENPP3 expression rises during adipocyte differentiation. • Ion-channel / metabolic support – KCNAB1 (K+ channel β-subunit) and CA2 (pH buffering) facilitate the high metabolic activity of lipid-filled cells. Inconsistencies: • ENPP3 is also a basophil/mast-cell antigen. • CA2 is widely expressed (e.g., osteoclasts, renal tubule). • KCNAB1 and NTRK3 have prominent neuronal expression. These genes, however, are reported in adipose or stromal compartments as well, so they do not outweigh the overall adipogenic signature.

program_29.description: The program represents a metallothionein-driven metal-ion/oxidative-stress response that can be transiently activated in many cell types (e.g., epithelial, immune or hepatic cells) when intracellular Zn²⁺/Cu⁺ and reactive oxygen species rise; it is marked by strong induction of multiple MT1/MT2 isoforms together with the zinc exporter SLC30A1. Evidence: • MT1X, MT1E, MT1G, MT1F, MT1M, MT1H, MT1A and MT2A encode metallothioneins whose transcription is directly activated by the metal-responsive transcription factor MTF-1 during zinc, cadmium or oxidative stress, and they sequester excess metal ions while scavenging reactive oxygen species. • SLC30A1 (ZnT1) is an MTF-1 target that exports Zn²⁺ out of the cytosol, complementing metallothioneins in restoring metal homeostasis. • The concerted up-regulation of eight MT isoforms plus ZnT1 constitutes a well-described “metallothionein stress” signature seen across multiple single-cell studies in cells exposed to heavy metals, hypoxia or inflammatory cytokines. Inconsistencies: No clear inconsistencies; all detected genes fit a coherent metal-responsive cytoprotective program.

program_30.description: The gene set represents a SREBP-driven sterol-lipogenic program, i.e. cells in a metabolic state of active de-novo cholesterol and unsaturated fatty-acid synthesis rather than a specific lineage; such a program is commonly induced by low intracellular sterol levels, proliferative cues, or differentiation events that require membrane biogenesis. Evidence: • Core cholesterol pathway enzymes: MSMO1, SQLE, DHCR7, EBP and ERG28 catalyze sequential steps from lanosterol to cholesterol, marking activation of the canonical sterol biosynthetic pathway. • Up-stream acetyl-CoA utilization: ACAT2 converts acetyl-CoA/acetate into acetoacetyl-CoA and esterifies cholesterol, supporting bulk sterol production and storage. • SREBP transcriptional control: INSIG1 is a feedback regulator transcriptionally induced by SREBP; its co-induction with the enzymes above is a hallmark of SREBP1/2 activation. • Fatty-acid desaturation linkage: FADS1 encodes Δ5-desaturase, coupling cholesterol synthesis with unsaturated fatty-acid generation, a coordinated response mediated by SREBP1/2 and needed for membrane fluidity during cell growth. Inconsistencies: None apparent; all listed genes coherently belong to the SREBP-regulated cholesterol/fatty-acid biosynthetic axis.

program_31.description: The program reflects an interferon-stimulated, pro-inflammatory T-cell state, most consistent with activated/effector (likely CD8⁺) memory T cells that are producing chemokines and survival factors in response to viral or inflammatory cues. Evidence: • T-cell identity – core T-cell receptor complex genes CD3D and CD2 are strongly expressed. • Effector/chemokine output – CCL5 (RANTES) is a hallmark of activated cytotoxic and effector-memory T cells that recruit additional immune cells. • Cytokine/activation markers – IL32 is induced upon T-cell activation and promotes Th1-type inflammation; BIRC3 is an NF-κB–inducible anti-apoptotic gene that supports survival of activated T cells. • Interferon response – ISG20 and the interferon-responsive gene OCIAD2 indicate exposure to type-I/II interferons, a common signature of virus-responsive effector T cells. Inconsistencies: • No clear cytotoxic granule genes (e.g., GZMB, PRF1) appear, so the program may capture a broader activated T-cell population rather than fully cytolytic cells. Overall, the gene set coherently points to interferon-exposed, pro-inflammatory activated T cells.

program_32.description: The program is characteristic of airway secretory epithelial cells—particularly goblet/club-cell-like cells—engaged in an innate-defence / injury-response state, marked by high production of antimicrobial and anti-protease secreted proteins. Evidence: • Secretory airway markers – WFDC2 (HE4) and BPIFB1 (PLUNC) are canonical proteins secreted by large-airway goblet and club cells. • Secretoglobin family – SCGB3A1 (UGRP2) is enriched in non-ciliated secretory (club) epithelium and increases during airway differentiation and repair. • Innate immune secreted factors – LCN2 (lipocalin-2) sequesters bacterial siderophores; MDK (midkine) is an injury-induced growth factor; both rise in inflamed or regenerating airway epithelium. • Retinoic-acid–responsive epithelial gene – RARRES1 is up-regulated during epithelial differentiation and is retinoid-inducible, consistent with airway epithelial maturation programs. • General vesicle/actin remodeling component – FCHSD2 participates in endocytosis and is highly expressed in secretory epithelia, supporting an active secretory machinery. Inconsistencies: • MDK and RARRES1 are not strictly airway-restricted and can appear in stromal or tumor contexts; their presence may reflect a broader injury or proliferative response rather than a pure resting secretory phenotype. • LCN2 is also produced by neutrophils, so its elevation could in part reflect contaminating immune transcripts, although it is known to be inducible in airway epithelium.

program_33.description: The gene set is most consistent with a “testis-enriched housekeeping” program that typifies male germ cells in mid-to-late spermatogenesis (late pachytene spermatocytes through round spermatids), reflecting the switch to germ-cell-specific paralogs of generic RNA-binding, translational and mitochondrial genes. Evidence: • PABPC3 – testis-specific paralog of the cytoplasmic poly-A–binding protein, highly expressed in spermatocytes/spermatids and commonly used as a marker of post-meiotic germ cells. • UQCRHL – testis-enriched component of mitochondrial complex III required for sperm mitochondrial activity. • ZNF90 – zinc-finger TF with predominant testicular expression according to GTEx/HPA, up-regulated during spermatogenic maturation. • NBEAL1, NHSL2, CCDC88C – all display testis-biased expression; CCDC88C transcripts rise in germ cells after meiosis, and NBEAL1/NHSL2 are among “testis-enhanced” genes in large transcriptomic surveys. • Collectively, the list is dominated by genes whose highest expression is in testis and whose known functions (RNA handling, mitochondrial respiration, cytoskeletal remodeling) align with the metabolic and translational surge in maturing germ cells. Inconsistencies: • No strongly conflicting genes; however, several (e.g., CCDC88C, NBEAL1) are also expressed in brain and other tissues, so ubiquity rather than exclusivity must be kept in mind.

program_34.description: The program most closely matches an “early T-cell activation” state driven by acute T-cell-receptor (TCR) / Ca²⁺–NFAT signalling, typified by the NR4A immediate-early transcription factors and accompanied by inducible cytokine/chemokine genes that appear shortly after stimulation. Evidence: • NR4A2 and NR4A3 – rapidly induced orphan nuclear receptors that are classic NFAT targets and hallmarks of freshly TCR-stimulated or pre-exhausted T cells (both conventional and regulatory). • RCAN1 – calcineurin/NFAT-responsive gene induced within minutes of TCR signalling, reinforcing the Ca²⁺-dependent activation context. • BTG1 – immediate-early antiproliferative gene up-regulated in lymphocytes immediately after activation. • AREG – growth factor produced by activated CD4⁺ effector and regulatory T cells during tissue inflammation and repair. • CXCL3 – chemokine that can be released by activated T cells to recruit myeloid cells to inflamed sites. Inconsistencies: • CXCL3 and AREG are also expressed by myeloid or epithelial cells, so their presence could reflect a broader inflammatory response rather than a purely T-cell signature. • Lack of canonical T-cell structural genes (e.g., CD3, CD4/8) means the program alone cannot unambiguously assign lineage without additional markers.

program_35.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated myeloid‐lineage cell (monocyte / macrophage or dendritic cell) that is up-regulating vesicle acidification, autophagy, and proteasome pathways—features typical of cells engaged in phagocytosis and antigen processing, accompanied by secretion of the B-cell-stimulatory cytokine APRIL (TNFSF13). Evidence: • Vesicle acidification / phagolysosome formation: ATP6V0C (V-ATPase V0 subunit) is required for lysosomal acidification, a hallmark of professional phagocytes. • Autophagy machinery: GABARAP promotes autophagosome expansion and fusion with lysosomes; RNASEK facilitates endocytic trafficking—both enriched in activated macrophages/dendritic cells. • Proteasome activity: PSMA6 supports heightened proteasomal degradation during antigen processing. • Myeloid cytokine production: TNFSF13 (APRIL) is classically secreted by monocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, and dendritic cells to support B-cell and plasma-cell survival, marking an activated myeloid state. • Metabolic/proliferative support: NME2 supplies nucleoside diphosphates for high energy demand typical of activated innate immune cells. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes align with generalized proteostatic and secretory activation seen in myeloid cells, though the program lacks highly specific lineage markers (e.g., CD14, ITGAX), so broader proteostasis activation in other cell types cannot be fully excluded.

program_36.description: The gene set reflects a generic cytoprotective heat-shock / proteotoxic-stress response that can be transiently activated in virtually any cell type rather than marking a specific lineage. Evidence: • HSPA1A (HSP70), DNAJB1 and DNAJA4 (HSP40 family) – canonical inducible heat-shock proteins that refold mis-folded polypeptides and are transcriptionally up-regulated after heat, oxidative or proteasome stress. • HSPE1 (HSP10) – cochaperone partnering with HSP60 but likewise induced by heat shock to assist protein folding. • BAG3 – HSP70 cofactor that redirects damaged proteins to macro-autophagy, a hallmark of the stress-induced chaperone-assisted selective autophagy pathway. • CSTB (cystatin B) – stress-responsive cysteine-protease inhibitor that protects cells from lysosomal cathepsin-mediated damage during proteotoxic conditions. Inconsistencies: No clear lineage-specific or contradictory markers are present; all listed genes align with a generalized stress–response program.

program_37.description: The gene set defines a mature secretory airway epithelial (club/Clara) cell program, highlighting cells specialized for mucosal secretion and immune defense in the bronchiolar epithelium. Evidence: • SCGB1A1 (uteroglobin/CC10) – canonical marker of club cells in the conducting airways. • SCGB3A1 – paralog of SCGB1A1, highly enriched in club and other secretory airway epithelial cells. • BPIFB1 (LPLUNC1) and WFDC2 (HE4) – secreted innate-immune proteins produced by goblet/club airway epithelial cells. • PIGR – polymeric Ig receptor that transports IgA/IgM across secretory epithelia, typical of airway secretory cells. • KRT19 – intermediate filament protein broadly marking epithelial lineage, including airway secretory populations. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes align with an airway secretory (club) epithelial identity.

program_38.description: The gene set represents an activated mast-cell transcriptional program. Evidence: • Mast-cell–specific proteases – TPSAB1, TPSB2 (tryptases) and CPA3 (carboxypeptidase A3) – are signature granule constituents found almost uniquely in connective-tissue and mucosal mast cells. • MS4A2 encodes the β-chain of the high-affinity IgE receptor (FcεRI), a hallmark surface complex of mast cells (and basophils, but basophils lack tryptases). • CD69, an early activation/retention marker up-regulated after FcεRI engagement, supports an activated or tissue-resident mast-cell state. • LAPTM4A, a lysosomal membrane protein, is enriched in cells with prominent secretory granules such as mast cells, aligning with the degranulation/secretory phenotype. Inconsistencies: No major genes in the list contradict a mast-cell identity; all positively loaded genes are compatible with this cell type and its activated state.

program_39.description: The program is most consistent with an acutely activated / stress-responsive monocyte–macrophage state, characterized by simultaneous induction of integrated-stress, oxidative-stress and LPS-responsive genes that temper or adapt ongoing inflammation. Evidence: • ZC3H12A (MCPIP1) – canonical early-response RNase strongly induced by LPS in monocytes/macrophages to dampen pro-inflammatory mRNA; widely used marker of activated myeloid cells. • PPP1R15A (GADD34) – hallmark target of the integrated stress response (eIF2α pathway) frequently up-regulated in macrophages encountering ER stress or TLR ligands. • MAFF – small-Maf transcription factor partnering with NRF2 during oxidative-stress programs activated in macrophages exposed to reactive oxygen species. • ADM – vasoactive peptide whose transcription is driven by HIF1A and inflammatory cytokines in hypoxic or cytokine-stimulated macrophages. • ABL2 – cytoskeletal kinase whose expression/activity rises in migrating or activated macrophages, supporting chemotaxis and phagocytosis. Inconsistencies: • Gene set is small and not exclusively myeloid; ABL2 and PPP1R15A are expressed in several lineages, so the program could theoretically appear in other stressed cell types lacking monocyte markers.

program_40.description: The gene set typifies a secretory, perivascular fibroblast / adventitial stromal cell program that supports tissue repair and angiogenesis through IGF-1, Wnt–R-spondin and prostaglandin signalling. Evidence: • IGF1 – hallmark transcript of “IGF1+ fibroblasts” and adventitial/perivascular stromal cells that supply trophic cues to parenchyma and endothelium. • RSPO3 – potent Wnt agonist selectively produced by vascular-associated fibroblasts and endothelial tip cells, driving stem-cell niche maintenance and vascular growth. • ITIH5 – extracellular-matrix protein secreted by quiescent to early-activated fibroblasts; enriched in vascular adventitia and tumor-associated stroma. • AKAP12 – cytoskeletal scaffold prominent in pericytes, smooth-muscle–like fibroblasts and scar-associated stromal cells; linked to endothelial interaction and barrier support. • PTGER3 – prostaglandin E2 receptor expressed in smooth-muscle/fibroblast lineages, mediating vasodilatory and wound-healing signals. Inconsistencies: • None obvious; all listed genes are compatible with a vascular-associated fibroblast state, though PTGER3 and AKAP12 are also found in some smooth-muscle cells and endothelium.

program_41.description: The program reflects a generic Type I interferon–stimulated (antiviral) activation state that can be super-imposed on many immune and non-immune cell types rather than defining a specific lineage. Evidence: • IFIT1, IFIT2 – classical interferon-stimulated genes that inhibit viral translation and replication. • ISG15 – ubiquitin-like modifier highly induced by IFN-α/β, marks proteins for antiviral effector functions. • APOBEC3A – cytidine deaminase whose expression is driven by Type I IFN and restricts viral DNA. • TNFSF10 (TRAIL) – up-regulated after interferon signaling and mediates cytotoxic/apoptotic antiviral responses. Inconsistencies: • No notable inconsistencies; all listed genes are coherent with a Type I interferon response program.

program_42.description: The program is most consistent with an interferon-stimulated, pro-inflammatory monocyte/macrophage state, i.e. an early innate immune activation profile that couples antiviral defense (IFITM1, RNASEK) with cytokine production (MIF) and some lipid-handling capacity (APOC4-APOC2). Evidence: • IFITM1 – canonical type I/II interferon-stimulated gene widely used to mark antiviral activation in monocytes and macrophages. • RNASEK – interferon-responsive endosomal protein required for virus entry; up-regulated in interferon-treated myeloid cells. • MIF – cytokine abundantly produced by activated monocytes/macrophages, driving inflammatory responses. • APOC4-APOC2 – apolipoprotein locus expressed in lipid-laden or foam macrophages and up-regulated in inflammatory myeloid cells exposed to modified lipids. • NME2 – housekeeping/proliferation-associated kinase whose higher expression is common in metabolically active, cytokine-secreting myeloid cells. Inconsistencies: • APOC4-APOC2 is also liver-enriched and could reflect ambient hepatocyte RNA rather than true myeloid expression. • NME2 is ubiquitous and not specific to immune cells, so its presence is supportive but not diagnostic.

program_43.description: The program most closely matches a mature/activated mast-cell transcriptional state, characterized by high expression of granule tryptases and NF-κB–responsive survival genes. Evidence: • Mast-cell granule enzymes – TPSAB1 and TPSB2 code for α/β-tryptases, the canonical and highly specific markers of tissue mast cells. • Pro-survival, NF-κB target – BIRC3 (cIAP2) is rapidly induced downstream of IgE-FcεRI engagement in activated mast cells, supporting their survival during degranulation. • Membrane remodeling – CAVIN2 (SDPR) participates in caveolae formation and has been reported to increase during mast-cell degranulation, consistent with an activated state. • General RNA-binding/housekeeping factor – RO60 (TROVE2) is broadly expressed but is also detected in mast cells, providing generic transcript stability. Inconsistencies: • CAVIN2 is more classically an endothelial/smooth-muscle marker, so its strong loading is somewhat atypical for mast cells. • RO60 is ubiquitous and not cell-type specific, adding little discriminatory power.

program_44.description: The gene set represents a generic “high–protein-synthesis / growth” transcriptional program seen in many cell types that are metabolically active or preparing for proliferation, rather than marking a specific lineage. Evidence: • EEF1A1, EEF2, EIF4B – core translation elongation/ initiation factors whose coordinated up-regulation is a hallmark of cells with elevated ribosome activity and protein production. • NOP53 – nucleolar protein required for ribosome biogenesis; up-regulated when rRNA processing and ribosome assembly are high. • CCNG1 – p53-responsive cyclin that rises during growth-factor–driven cell-cycle re-entry or mild stress, consistent with cells gearing up for division in parallel with increased translation. Inconsistencies: • No clear inconsistencies; the listed genes all converge on translation and growth control but do not specify a unique cell lineage.

program_45.description: The gene set is most consistent with a differentiated, secretory mucosal epithelial program such as airway/bronchiolar club (secretory) cells or other Ig-transporting glandular epithelia. Evidence: • KRT19 – intermediate filament typical of simple epithelia and bronchiolar/ductal secretory cells, absent from mesenchyme or immune lineages. • PIGR – polymeric Ig receptor uniquely expressed by mucosal epithelial cells to transcytose IgA/IgM across the apical surface, defining barrier epithelium engaged in immune surveillance. • SCGB3A1 – secretoglobin highly enriched in airway club cells and other secretory epithelia, marking a mature secretory state. • FXYD3 – regulator of Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase abundantly expressed in gastric, colonic, and airway epithelium, supporting ion-transport functions of secretory cells. • MDK – secreted growth factor up-regulated in regenerating or developing epithelia, fitting with a reparative/activated facet of secretory epithelial cells. Inconsistencies: No strongly discordant genes; MDK is more broadly pro-growth but is often induced in regenerating epithelium rather than contradicting an epithelial identity.

program_46.description: The gene combination most closely reflects a generic “house-keeping”/basal metabolic program characteristic of broadly active, non-specialised cells rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. The genes encode core components of chromatin (H3-5), nascent-chain chaperoning (NACA2), transcriptional regulation (ZNF90), actin/cytoskeletal signalling (NHSL2), and mitochondrial electron transport (UQCRHL), together suggesting a program that supports fundamental functions such as chromatin packaging, protein synthesis/folding, and oxidative phosphorylation. Evidence: • H3-5 – replication-dependent histone H3 variant, marks active chromatin assembly during S-phase and general nucleosome turnover. • NACA2 – subunit of the nascent polypeptide-associated complex; ensures correct folding of newly synthesised proteins, a core translational support function. • ZNF90 – C2H2 zinc-finger transcription factor, representative of broad transcriptional regulation rather than lineage-restricted markers. • UQCRHL – component of complex III of the mitochondrial respiratory chain, indicating oxidative phosphorylation activity typical of metabolically active cells. • NHSL2 – NHS-like protein involved in actin remodelling; widely expressed and linked to basic cytoskeletal dynamics. Inconsistencies: No clear lineage-specific markers are present, and no negatively loaded genes are supplied; therefore, no internal inconsistencies with the generic house-keeping interpretation are evident.

program_47.description: Gene composition points to a canonical type I interferon-stimulated (antiviral) transcriptional program that can be activated in many immune or parenchymal cell types rather than to a specific lineage. Evidence: • Classical interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs): ISG15, IFI44L, IFIT2 are hallmark targets of the STAT1/STAT2–IRF9 pathway downstream of IFN-α/β signaling. • Concerted up-regulation of several independent ISGs argues for a coordinated interferon response rather than isolated gene activation. Inconsistencies: • NEXN (actin-binding protein enriched in striated muscle) and HESX1 (homeobox factor involved in pituitary development) are not typical ISGs and have no well-described roles in interferon signaling, suggesting either cell-type-specific co-expression or noise in the loading of this program.

program_0.description: The gene set is most consistent with a lung alveolar epithelial cell undergoing an epithelial-to-mesenchymal–like transition (EMT) that characterises the “transitional/ KRT8⁺” injury-response state described in fibrotic or regenerating lung. These cells still express surfactant and ion-transport genes typical of type II/early type I alveolar epithelium yet have up-regulated mesenchymal, extracellular-matrix and stress–response programmes while down-regulating classical epithelial cytokeratins and EpCAM. Evidence: • Residual alveolar epithelial identity – SFTPC, SFTPB, SFTPD, SLC34A2 (AT2); AGER, HOPX (early AT1). • EMT / mesenchymal activation – VIM, FN1, ACTA2, TAGLN, COL1A1/2, COL6A1/2, SPARC, LGALS1, S100A4, MMP2, MMP28, IGFBP7, RARRES1/2, CXCL14. • Matrix-remodelling & myofibroblast-like contractile genes – MYL9, TPM1/2, CALD1, CRIP2, FHL1. • Stress / inflammatory response typical of transitional cells – FOS, DUSP1, SOCS3, IFI27, IFITM1/2, HLA-E, CCL2, GDF15. • Loss of epithelial/basal markers (negatively loaded) – TACSTD2 (EpCAM), KRT19, KRT5, S100A2, ITM2B, ADH7, indicating partial loss of epithelial polarity consistent with EMT. Inconsistencies: • Presence of leukocyte genes (PTPRC, CD68, LAPTM5, FCER1G, C1QA/B) and endothelial-associated genes (EGFL7, ACKR1) suggests some ambient RNA or doublet contamination rather than true expression in the transitional epithelial cells.

program_1.description: The gene set is most consistent with an airway/bronchiolar secretory epithelial program encompassing club and goblet cells, with some extension toward alveolar type II–like surfactant production. Cells expressing this program are non-basal, highly secretory, produce mucins, antimicrobial peptides and surfactant proteins, and lack the basal-cell keratin KRT5. Evidence: • Goblet-cell module – MUC5AC, MUC5B, MUC1, MUC4, MUC16, TFF3, SPDEF, AGR2/AGR3, GALNT6 support mucus-producing goblet identity. • Club-cell module – SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1, SCGB3A2, CYP2F1, BPIFA1/BPIFB1, LCN2, PIGR, CCNO mark bronchiolar club/secretory cells. • Surfactant/AT2 tilt – SFTPB, SFTPC, SFTPD, CLDN3/4/7, PIGR, EPC-like genes (GOLM1, XBP1) indicate overlap with alveolar type II–like secretory function. • Secretory/ER stress machinery – XBP1, ERN2, CREB3L1, SPDEF, SELENBP1 reflect high secretory load. • Immune-modulatory secretions – CXCL1, CXCL6, CXCL8, CXCL17, DEFB1, LTF show chemokine/antimicrobial output typical of airway secretory epithelium. • Negative loading of basal markers – KRT5, S100A2 and the absence of other basal genes underline a non-basal state. Inconsistencies: • HOPX (type I alveolar) and MSLN/FOLR1 (mesothelial/serous markers) suggest a minor alveolar‐transitional or serous component. • Presence of some myeloid-associated genes (ARHGDIB, ITGB2, LYZ) may reflect ambient RNA or low-level inflammatory cell contamination rather than true epithelial expression.

program_2.description: The gene set defines a generic high-proliferation, G2/M–enriched cell-cycle program that marks cells actively progressing through late S phase, mitosis and cytokinesis, a state seen in cycling progenitors, tumor cells and any rapidly dividing population regardless of lineage. Evidence: • Mitotic spindle/kinetochore: AURKB, PLK1, BIRC5, KIF11, KIF20A/B, NUSAP1, CENPA/B/F/P/W, NDC80, SPC24/25, ZWINT/ZWILCH, BUB1/BUB1B – core regulators of chromosome alignment and segregation. • Cyclins, CDKs and checkpoints: CCNA2, CCNB1/2, CCNE2, CDK1, CDKN3, CDC20, CDC25B, CHEK1 – drive G2/M transition and anaphase onset. • DNA replication/repair: MCM2-7, PCNA, RFC3/4, ORC6, TYMS, RRM2, TOP2A, BRCA1/2, RAD51, FANCA/D2/I – hallmark of late-S–phase DNA synthesis and damage tolerance. • Proliferation markers: MKI67, FOXM1, MYBL2, HELLS, EZH2, UBE2C – widely used indicators of dividing cells. • Cytokinesis/abscission: PRC1, RACGAP1, CEP55, KIF23, ANLN, CIT – complete the proliferative signature. • Negatively loaded POSTN (extracellular matrix) suggests suppression of differentiation/ECM programs during active cycling. Inconsistencies: • Moderate expression of immune genes (HLA-B, B2M, IFI27) and housekeeping PABPC1 are not specific to proliferation, but their low number and load do not conflict with the overall cell-cycle identity. • No lineage-defining markers (e.g., epithelial, immune, stromal) are present, indicating this program is state-specific rather than cell-type-specific.

program_3.description: The gene set is most consistent with a basal-squamous epithelial program that has activated a wound-healing / partial epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) state. Cells expressing this program keep core basal-keratinocyte markers (KRT5/14/15/17, COL17A1) but up-regulate extracellular-matrix and EMT-related genes (POSTN, LOXL4, THSD4, SERPINF1, AXL, PDPN) while down-regulating tight-junction/secretory genes (CLDN7, TFF3, CLCA2, CXCL17). This profile matches activated basal cells found during tissue repair or in basal-like carcinomas where epithelial identity is retained yet mesenchymal remodeling genes are induced. Evidence: • Basal-keratinocyte identity (positively loaded): KRT5, KRT14, KRT15, KRT17, COL17A1, LAMB3, DST. • Stem/early squamous markers: KRT15, DLK2, TP63 target DKK3, BCAM. • EMT / matrix remodeling (positive): POSTN, LOXL4, THSD4, CCN2, MMP10, PDPN, AXL, LGALS1/LGALS3BP, LTBP4, AEBP1, MYL9. • Wound-response / stress (positive): IFITM3, DUSP1, CH25H, G0S2, IL1R2. • Loss of epithelial barrier & secretory genes (negatively loaded): CLDN7, TSPAN1, NHERF1, TFF3, CLCA2, CXCL17, FAM3D. • Reduced differentiation / detoxification genes (negative): GSTP1, AKR1C3, SAT1, MT1X/MT2A, SERPINB3, indicating departure from mature luminal state. Inconsistencies: • A few classical stress-keratins (KRT6A) and squamous differentiation genes (FGFBP1) are negatively loaded, suggesting these particular late-wound markers are suppressed. • Fibroblast-enriched ECM genes (SERPINF1, POSTN) are strongly positive, which could reflect either epithelial EMT or contaminating fibroblast signals. • Metallothioneins (MT1X/MT2A) and ANXA1/2, often induced by stress, are negatively loaded, which is atypical for some EMT models.

program_4.description: The program reflects epithelial cells that have engaged an acute, NF-κB/AP-1–driven inflammatory-stress response, as seen in airway or alveolar secretory/Type II epithelium exposed to pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, TNF-α) or bacterial products. Evidence: • Canonical immediate-early / stress TFs (FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB, JUND, ATF3, EGR1/2/3, NR4A1/2, IER2/3, DUSP1/2/5/6, ZFP36, NFKBIZ, SOCS3, TNFAIP3, CDKN1A) indicate rapid NF-κB / MAPK activation in stimulated cells. • Secreted inflammatory mediators and acute-phase genes (CXCL1/2/3/8, CXCR4, IL32, LCN2, SAA1/2, HBEGF, AREG, EDN1, GDF15, ICAM1, CCN1/2) typify cytokine-producing, inflamed epithelium. • Epithelial/secretory structural markers (MUC4, CLDN4, AGR3, TM4SF1, EZR, VIM, SFTPB) support an epithelial origin, particularly secretory or alveolar Type II cells. • Down-loading of GLUL (glutamine synthetase) together with up-loading of stress genes is characteristic of Type II pneumocytes transitioning from a homeostatic to an injured/inflammatory state. • Enrichment of oxidative-stress and apoptosis modulators (SOD2, PMAIP1, RHOB, GADD45B/G) further corroborates a damage-response program. Inconsistencies: • Low-level erythroid transcripts (HBB, HBA2) and myeloid-associated genes (LYZ, S100A9, APOC1, HCST) may derive from ambient RNA or minor contaminating cells. • CFAP and RSPH ciliogenesis genes suggest a small contribution from ciliated epithelium rather than secretory/Type II cells. • Negative loading of the broadly expressed PABPC1 and MT1X is not readily explained by this state and may reflect technical variation.

program_5.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with an activated airway secretory (club) epithelial-cell program, characterised by mucin/chemokine secretion, Notch-driven secretory fate, and strong xenobiotic-detoxification and anti-protease activity, while basal-cell keratins are specifically repressed. Evidence: • Club/secretory epithelial markers: SCGB1A1, CYP2F1, CYP2A13, ALDH1A1, CLDN10, CLDN4, AGR2, MUC15/16, CLCA2, CLDN7 and UPK1B are all enriched in human airway club or other secretory epithelial cells. • Notch-dependent secretory fate: NOTCH3, HES1, HES4 and ELF3 are classical drivers of club/goblet differentiation from basal progenitors. • Anti-protease and mucosal defense genes typical of airway secretory cells: SERPINB1/B2/B3/B4/B7, SLPI-like FAM3B/FAM3D, LTF, CXCL17, CXCL1, CXCL6, MDK. • Xenobiotic and oxidative-stress enzymes abundant in club cells: GSTP1, GSTA1, MGST1, CYP4B1, FMO5, MT1G/MT1H/MT2A, AKR1C3, DEGS2, SULT2B1. • Suppressed basal-cell identity: negative loadings for KRT15 and KRT17 (hallmark basal keratins), plus repression of BCAM and MYL9, indicate loss of basal features and support a differentiated secretory state. Inconsistencies: • Immune-related transcripts (HLA-DRA, ISG20, POU2AF1, FYB2, B2M) hint at low-level interferon or antigen-presentation signalling not strictly specific to epithelial club cells. • HOPX, normally an alveolar type-I marker, is negatively loaded but could reflect mixed epithelial populations in the dataset.

program_6.description: The gene set reflects mucosal secretory epithelial cells—typical of airway/upper-airway goblet- or club-like epithelium—that are acutely activated by pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1/TNF/IL-17, IFN-γ). The program combines strong secretory/goblet identity markers with a broad NF-κB/acute-phase response, chemokine burst and MHC-II up-regulation, fitting the “inflamed secretory epithelial” state described during respiratory infection or chronic airway inflammation. Evidence: • Secretory / goblet / airway epithelial identity – Mucins and secretoglobins: MUC1, MUC4, MUC5B, MUC16, BPIFA1, FCGBP, ZG16B, PIP – Ion/transport genes characteristic of airway secretory cells: SLC34A2, SLC26A4, SLC4A4 – Keratins linked to suprabasal/repairing epithelium: KRT6A, KRT16; stem/secretory marker PROM1 • Acute-phase & antimicrobial proteins produced by inflamed epithelium – SAA1/2, LCN2, CHI3L1, LTF, CP, HP, PI3, SAT1 • Cytokine/chemokine storm typical of IL-17 / IL-1 / TNF stimulation – CXCL1/2/3/6/8, CCL2, CCL20, CSF3, PTGES • Tissue-remodelling and barrier repair genes – MMP1/7/10, ADAMTS1, ADAMTSL4, TGM2, TIMP1, HAS3, STC1, CCN1 • NF-κB / stress-response transcriptional regulators – TNFAIP2, TNFAIP3, SOCS3, ZFP36, CEBPD, ATF3, KLF6, MAFF, DUSP2/5 • Interferon-γ–induced antigen presentation machinery – HLA-DRB1, HLA-DQA1, CD74, IDO1, IFITM1/3, WARS1 Inconsistencies: • HBB (hemoglobin β) is usually erythroid, occasionally ectopically expressed in epithelium but not canonical. • HCST (DNAM-1 adaptor) is more typical of NK/immune cells, though low epithelial expression has been reported. Overall, the vast majority of genes align with an inflamed airway secretory epithelial program, and the few outliers do not outweigh this interpretation.

program_7.description: The gene set reflects a Notch-high, luminal/secretory differentiation program of mucosal (e.g. airway or other non-keratinised) epithelium: cells have exited the basal (KRT15/17⁺) compartment and are adopting a suprabasal–secretory state characterised by EPCAM/TACSTD2, tight-junction protein CLDN7, luminal keratins (KRT8/18/19, KRT4/13) and secretion/defence genes (CXCL17, LTF, FAM3D, DPP4) together with xenobiotic-metabolising enzymes (CYP4B1, SULT2B1, UGT2A1). Concomitant enrichment of NOTCH3 and its targets HES1/4/6 supports Notch-driven commitment to the secretory lineage, while detoxification and SERPINB family members indicate barrier and inflammatory-modulatory functions typical of airway/other mucosal secretory epithelial cells. Evidence: • Luminal/epithelial identity – TACSTD2 (EPCAM), CLDN7, TSPAN1, CD9, LY6D, UPK1B, EMP2; luminal keratins KRT8/18/19 and suprabasal keratins KRT4/13. • Secretory/antimicrobial repertoire – CXCL17, LTF, FAM3D, DPP4, MDK, AZGP1, SPON2. • Xenobiotic & redox enzymes typical of airway secretory cells – CYP4B1, SULT2B1, UGT2A1, AKR1C3, GSTP1, MGST1, EPHX1, HPGD. • Notch signalling & differentiation drivers – NOTCH3 together with HES1, HES4, HES6, SOX4, CCND1. • Barrier-protective SERPINB family – SERPINB1/3/4/7/10/13 supportive of mucosal epithelium. • Negative loadings mark loss of basal/interferon programs – basal keratins KRT15/17, basal-associated SPRY1, LGALS1, ZFP36L2 and interferon-response IFITM3 are all anti-correlated. Inconsistencies: • TNNT3 (muscle troponin) and UPK1B (classical urothelial protein) are uncommon in airway epithelium, though low-level expression can occur in transitional/suprabasal cells. • Absence of classical secretory marker SCGB1A1 limits precise assignment to canonical club cells, suggesting a more general luminal/secretory mucosal program rather than a single cell subtype.

program_8.description: The gene set most strongly matches an interferon-γ–activated antigen-presenting myeloid population (inflammatory monocytes / macrophages or dendritic cells) characterized by high MHC class II expression, robust interferon-stimulated gene induction and acute-phase inflammatory mediators, with a concomitant reduction in the housekeeping translation factor EEF2. Evidence: • Antigen presentation: very strong enrichment of MHC-II components and their chaperone (HLA-DRA/DRB1/DPA1/DPB1/DQA1/DQB1, HLA-DMA/DMB/DOA, CD74) together with class-I molecules (HLA-A/B/C/E/F, B2M) typical of professional APCs. • Myeloid lineage / phagocyte genes: LYZ, AIF1, ARHGDIB, GMFG, COTL1, LAPTM5, SRGN, S100A9, LCN2, S100A11, CORO1A support monocyte–macrophage identity. • Interferon and inflammatory activation: STAT1, ISG15, IFI27, IFI6, IFITM1, IFITM3, GBP1, EPSTI1, NCOA7, IDO1, CXCL1, IL32, SAA1/2, AREG denote IFN-stimulated, pro-inflammatory state. • Translational down-modulation: negative loading of EEF2 is consistent with global translation repression seen in IFN-activated myeloid cells. Inconsistencies: • T-cell markers (CD3D, CD7, CD52, ACAP1, LTB) suggest low-level T-cell contamination or doublets. • Endothelial/epithelial transcripts (VWF, EGFL7, TM4SF1, MUC4, SLC34A2, MMP7) are not typical of myeloid cells and may reflect ambient RNA or mixed populations.

program_9.description: The gene set is most compatible with a fibroblast-like (general mesenchymal stromal) cell in a homeostatic, signaling-competent state characterized by active Wnt/β-catenin, Rho-family GTPase–driven cytoskeletal remodeling and insulin-responsive metabolism rather than proliferation. Evidence: • Wnt/β-catenin axis – CTNNB1 (β-catenin) is central to Wnt signalling widely used by fibroblasts for matrix remodelling and migration. • Rho-GTPase cytoskeletal program – CDC42, CDC42SE1 and the RAC1 GEF DOCK5 coordinate lamellipodia/filopodia formation typical of motile mesenchymal cells. • Cell-surface polarity/adhesion proteins – ATP1B1 (Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase β1) and the adhesion-related receptor PTPRS are enriched in fibroblasts and other stromal cells maintaining membrane polarity and cell-matrix contacts. • Secretory/Golgi and glycosylation machinery – B4GALT1 and GOLIM4 support glycoprotein processing, fitting fibroblast secretory activity. • Insulin/circadian metabolic responsiveness – INSR, PER2 and the glycogen-regulatory kinase subunit PHKG1 reflect insulin- and clock-regulated metabolism observed in cultured fibroblasts. • Chromatin/miRNA regulators (SET, CBX6, TNRC6B) and ubiquitous RNA-binding protein HNRNPH1 indicate epigenetic and post-transcriptional control typical of non-dividing, metabolically active stromal cells. Inconsistencies: • PHKG1 is classically skeletal-muscle enriched. • PTPRS shows highest expression in neurons. • PAQR7 (membrane progesterone receptor) is better known in reproductive tissues. These few genes are not incompatible with a fibroblast program (they are expressed at low levels in multiple cell types) but are less specifically supportive of the assignment.

program_10.description: The gene set represents professional antigen-presenting cells—most plausibly macrophages or dendritic cells—driven into an inflammatory, acute-phase state that is characterized by very high MHC class II antigen-presentation capacity. Evidence: • Antigen presentation: HLA-DRA, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DQA1, HLA-DQB1 together with CD74 form the canonical MHC class II complex expressed by macrophages and dendritic cells. • Inflammatory/acute-phase activation: LCN2 (lipocalin-2) and SAA1 (serum amyloid A1) are inducible by IL-1/IL-6/TNF or LPS and are commonly up-regulated in activated macrophages and inflammatory dendritic cells. Inconsistencies: • LCN2 and SAA1 are also produced by neutrophils or epithelial cells; however, their co-expression with a full MHC-II module and absence of neutrophil-specific genes (e.g., MPO, ELANE) favors an interpretation of inflamed APCs rather than neutrophils or epithelium.

program_11.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mesenchymal‐activation / partial epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) program frequently observed in cancer-associated fibroblasts or epithelial tumour cells that have adopted fibroblast-like, migratory properties. Evidence: • Core mesenchymal/EMT markers – S100A4 (FSP1) and CSRP2 drive actin remodelling and motility; FABP5 supports lipid metabolism typical of migratory mesenchymal cells. • CA12 is a HIF-1–inducible carbonic anhydrase up-regulated in hypoxic, invasive carcinomas and CAFs to regulate extracellular pH during invasion. • PRKAR2B (PKA-RIIβ) enhances cAMP signalling that promotes cytoskeletal re-organisation and migration in activated fibroblasts. • Re-expression of developmental transcription factors SIX3 and PAX7 fits with the well-described re-awakening of embryonic gene programs during EMT and tumour-associated fibroblast activation. • ASRGL1, a metabolic enzyme over-expressed in several solid tumours, supports the notion of a tumour-associated, metabolically flexible mesenchymal state. Inconsistencies: • PAX7 is classically a skeletal muscle satellite-cell marker, and SIX3 a forebrain/eye field factor; their presence is atypical for fibroblasts and likely reflects aberrant, developmentally-reprogrammed expression rather than lineage identity. • CA12 is more commonly associated with epithelial rather than mesenchymal cells, but its hypoxia-responsive nature can explain its coexistence with mesenchymal markers in invasive tumours.

program_12.description: The gene set is most consistent with a basal stratified-epithelial progenitor/keratinocyte program that is simultaneously activating a wound-healing/ECM-remodelling (“partial EMT”) response. Evidence: • Basal epithelial identity – KRT15, KRT17 and BCAM are hallmark markers of basal cells in epidermis, airway and other stratified epithelia, and are up-regulated during proliferation and repair. • Secreted wound/ECM factors – LOXL4 (cross-links collagen/elastin), SERPINF1 (PEDF, anti-angiogenic), SERPINE2 (protease inhibitor) and IGFBP2/IGFBP6 (IGF modulators) are classically induced in epithelial cells during injury or partial EMT, supporting matrix remodelling and growth-factor sequestration. • Co-occurrence of basal keratins with ECM-remodelling secreted proteins is a recognised signature of proliferative, wound-responsive keratinocytes. Inconsistencies: • SERPINF1 and LOXL4 are more typically abundant in fibroblasts; their presence might indicate paracrine signals or a small fibroblast contribution, but such genes can also be induced in epithelial cells under stress/EMT conditions.

program_13.description: The gene combination is most consistent with an activated / inflammatory fibroblast program—i.e. interstitial or stromal fibroblasts that have been stimulated by cytokines (including type-I IFN) and are secreting extracellular-matrix modulators and complement components rather than the structural collagens typical of quiescent fibroblasts. Evidence: • TIMP1 – classic fibroblast-secreted inhibitor of matrix metalloproteinases, strongly induced in activated or wound-healing fibroblasts. • C1S – complement serine-protease transcribed by mesenchymal stromal cells and “inflammatory fibroblasts” in lung, skin and synovium. • APOD – apolipoprotein abundantly produced by adventitial and dermal fibroblasts and up-regulated during fibroblast activation. • MT1M – stress-response metallothionein frequently co-expressed with TIMP1/APOD in activated fibroblasts exposed to oxidative or cytokine stress. • IFITM2 – interferon-stimulated gene indicating cytokine (IFN) exposure, a hallmark of the “inflammatory” fibroblast subtype. Inconsistencies: • Only a single canonical interferon-stimulated gene (IFITM2) is present, so IFN signaling is suggested but not strongly supported. • Absence of structural ECM genes (e.g., COL1A1, COL3A1, FN1) or myofibroblast markers (ACTA2) means the program represents a secretory/inflammatory state rather than the full myofibroblast phenotype.

program_14.description: The gene set represents an interferon-induced antigen-presentation program characteristic of activated professional antigen-presenting cells (e.g., dendritic cells, macrophages, B cells), marked by strong up-regulation of both MHC class II machinery and a type I interferon response gene. Evidence: • MHC class II complex: HLA-DRA, HLA-DPB1 and the invariant chain CD74 are core components of the class II antigen-presentation pathway, uniformly up-regulated upon APC activation. • MHC class I support: B2M encodes β-2-microglobulin, required for stable surface expression of all class I molecules, often co-induced with class II in activated APCs. • Interferon stimulation: IFI27 is a canonical type I interferon-stimulated gene, indicating exposure to IFN-α/β, a common trigger for heightened antigen-presentation capacity. Inconsistencies: • No apparent discordant genes in the current list.

program_15.description: The program is most consistent with an inflammatory, interferon-stimulated fibroblast / stromal cell state that is simultaneously engaged in extracellular-matrix remodeling and complement production. Evidence: • IFITM3 – classical interferon-stimulated gene, marking cells exposed to type-I/II IFN during viral or inflammatory challenge. • MMP10 and CTSB – lysosomal / secreted proteases up-regulated in activated fibroblasts and other stromal cells during wound repair and matrix turnover. • C1R – complement component synthesized extra-hepatically by dermal and pulmonary fibroblasts, fitting a stromal innate-immune role. • Co-occurrence of IFITM3 (antiviral) with MMP10/CTSB (matrix remodeling) and C1R (complement) typifies “activated fibroblast” gene signatures reported in inflamed lung, skin and tumor stroma. • CYP24A1 – vitamin-D-catabolic P450 that is inducible by inflammatory cytokines in fibroblasts and epithelial-derived stromal cells, aligning with an activated stromal phenotype. Inconsistencies: • CYP24A1 is most abundant in renal/other epithelial cells, so its presence may reflect epithelial contamination or a vitamin-D–responsive subset rather than all activated fibroblasts.

program_16.description: The gene set is most consistent with a broad “β-catenin / Wnt-activated progenitor-like” program that can be seen in many epithelial or mesenchymal stem/progenitor populations rather than a highly lineage-restricted cell type. Evidence: • CTNNB1 (β-catenin) – core effector of canonical Wnt signalling and adherens-junction integrity, commonly elevated in stem/progenitor cells when the pathway is active. • H3-3B – replication-independent histone variant enriched in transcriptionally active, undifferentiated or cycling cells, and frequently up-regulated downstream of Wnt/β-catenin. • KCNJ2 – inward-rectifier K⁺ channel whose expression is promoted by Wnt/β-catenin in several progenitor contexts and contributes to the hyper-polarised membrane potential typical of immature cells. • PAQR7 – membrane progesterone receptor whose transcription can be induced by Wnt and which is expressed in diverse epithelial progenitors; progesterone signalling often intersects with Wnt to maintain stemness. • C1orf56 – broadly expressed but reported to rise in proliferative states, fitting a general progenitor signature. Inconsistencies: • Absence of several canonical Wnt target genes (e.g., AXIN2, MYC, CCND1) makes the programme less definitive for strong Wnt activation. • KCNJ2 is classically high in excitable cells (cardiomyocytes/neurons), so its inclusion may reflect a mixed or less lineage-specific pattern. • PAQR7 is hormone-responsive and not universally linked to stemness, suggesting additional regulatory inputs beyond Wnt.

program_0.description: The gene set most strongly matches a lung alveolar-capillary “barrier/repair” program that is seen in epithelial and endothelial cells at the gas-exchange interface during tissue homeostasis or regeneration. It combines (i) alveolar type II surfactant and KRT8⁺ transitional epithelial markers, (ii) capillary endothelial/angiogenic genes, and (iii) extracellular-matrix and smooth-muscle genes associated with remodeling, while genes typical of myeloid/immune cells are negatively weighted. Evidence: • Alveolar type II / transitional epithelium – SFTPA1, SFTPA2, SFTPB, SFTPC, ABCA3, NAPSA, SLC34A2, MUC1, TACSTD2, KRT8/18/19, LAMP3, AGR2. • Alveolar type I / barrier components – AGER, CAV1, CAV2, CAVIN1/2, CLDN7. • Capillary endothelial identity – PECAM1, VWF, CLDN5, ESAM, EGFL7, RAMP2, RAMP3, TMEM100, ICAM2, EPAS1, IGFBP7. • Angiogenesis / hypoxia & vascular signaling – RAMP2/3, CALCRL, EPAS1, IGFBP4/7, EGFL7. • Matrix remodeling & contractile Mesenchyme (repair) – ACTA2, TAGLN, MYL9, COL6A2, DCN, BGN, SERPINH1, TIMP3, MMP2, CCN1/2. • Stress / injury response typical of regenerating alveolus – IFI27, IFITM3, CXCL17, SAA1, LCN2. • Negative loadings are myeloid/antigen-presentation genes (TYROBP, HLA-DPB1, IRF7), supporting an epithelial/endothelial—not immune—program. Inconsistencies: • Strong endothelial markers (PECAM1, VWF) are not normally co-expressed with high surfactant genes in pure epithelial cells, suggesting either mixed cell contributions or doublets. • Airway club-cell genes (SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1/3A2, VIPR1) and mast-cell genes (TPSB2, TPSAB1) appear but are not core to an alveolar barrier cell, indicating some contamination. • Smooth-muscle–associated ACTA2/TAGLN expression is higher than expected for classical epithelium/endothelium and may reflect stromal cells captured in the same program.

program_1.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mature, tissue-resident, MHC II-high macrophage program typified by anti-inflammatory / alternative (M2-like) activation and active lipid handling, as seen in alveolar or other resident macrophage populations rather than circulating inflammatory monocytes. Evidence: • Macrophage lineage & phagocytosis: C1QA/B/C, MARCO, CTSC, TREM1, CHIT1, LGALS3, SERPING1, CYBA • Strong antigen presentation: broad up-regulation of HLA-DRA, ‑DRB1/5, ‑DQA1/2, ‑DPA1/B1, ‑DMA/B, B2M, CD74 • Lipid metabolism typical of foamy/resident macrophages: APOE, APOC1, LPL, FABP4/5, FABP3, GPD1, FBP1, NNMT, ACOT7 • Alternative/M2 or tissue-repair factors: CCL18, CCL17, IGF1, INHBA, FOLR1, CFD, ADTRP, SERPINF1 • Negative loading of classical monocyte / inflammatory genes: FCN1, CD14, VCAN, CCL2, SPP1, HMOX1, IL1RN, NKG7 underscores shift away from blood-derived inflammatory states. Inconsistencies: • Presence of some pro-inflammatory or neutrophil-linked genes (TREM1, IL1A, CXCL5, CAMP, PPBP) that are less typical of resident M2 macrophages. • Fibroblast-associated markers (FN1, S100A4) appear at low levels, suggesting minor contamination or extracellular matrix remodeling activity.

program_2.description: This gene set reflects a classical, acute NF-κB / AP-1–driven inflammatory activation program in human monocytes-macrophages (so-called “M1-like” or LPS/TNF-stimulated state), characterised by strong induction of immediate-early transcription factors, pro-inflammatory cytokines/chemokines, and stress-response genes, together with concurrent suppression of homeostatic, complement-rich macrophage transcripts. Evidence: • Immediate-early/AP-1/NF-κB factors (FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB, ATF3, NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, DUSP1/2, EGR1/3, NR4A1/2/3, BTG1/2) – canonical markers of rapid inflammatory signalling. • Pro-inflammatory cytokines/chemokines (IL1A, IL1B, IL6, TNF, TNFAIP3/6, CXCL1/2/3/8/10, CCL3/4/20, CXCL2, CXCL8) – hallmarks of M1-polarised monocytes. • Monocyte/macrophage lineage and activation markers (CD14, FCN1, LYZ, VCAN, C5AR1, OLR1, NLRP3, PTGS2, PLAUR, THBS1, CLEC10A) enriched in circulating/inflammatory monocytes. • Stress-response / glycolytic shift genes (HIF1A, SLC2A3, NAMPT, VEGFA, DDIT4, SOD2) consistent with metabolic re-programming seen after LPS stimulation. • Anti-inflammatory brake genes induced by strong TLR/NF-κB signalling (SOCS3, IL10, GADD45B, PPP1R15A) typical of feedback regulation in activated monocytes. • Negative loadings include complement genes (C1QA/B/C), lipid-handling genes (APOC1, FABP4/5), MARCO and other transcripts characteristic of resting or tissue-resident macrophages, indicating their repression during the inflammatory switch. Inconsistencies: • T-cell receptor–associated genes (CD247, CD8A/B, ZAP70, KLRB1) and platelet chemokine PPBP suggest minor contamination or a shared immediate-early signature across lymphoid cells. • Anti-apoptotic BCL2A1 appears in the negatively loaded list; it is often induced, not repressed, in inflammatory monocytes, so its down-weighting may reflect dataset-specific regulation.

program_3.description: The gene set defines an infiltrating, pro-inflammatory classical monocyte / monocyte-derived macrophage program characterized by high expression of S100A8/A9/A12-bearing “FCN1⁺” inflammatory genes and concurrent repression of the C1QA/B/C–APOE–MARCO module typical of mature, tissue-resident (MRC1⁺/FABP4⁺) macrophages. Cells scoring highly for this program therefore represent recently recruited, inflammatory monocytes or early monocyte-derived macrophages rather than long-lived, resident macrophages. Evidence: • Positive loadings – inflammatory monocyte module – S100A8, S100A9, S100A12, VCAN, FCN1, LILRB2, CD14, IL1R2, CSF3R, LGALS2: canonical markers of circulating/classical (CD14⁺) inflammatory monocytes. – AIF1, TNFRSF1B, TIMP1, IFITM3, CEBPB, BIRC3, RETN, HAMP: inducible inflammatory or acute-phase genes up-regulated during monocyte activation. – CYBB, MPO-related AZU1, RNASE2, PADI4: oxidative and granule proteins enriched in recently recruited myeloid cells. • Negative loadings – resident macrophage module (down-regulated in this program) – C1QA, C1QB, C1QC, APOE, APOC1, MARCO, MRC1, FABP4, SERPING1, TYROBP, LGALS3: signature genes of long-lived tissue-resident macrophages such as alveolar, Kupffer, and interstitial macrophages. – CD68, CTSD, LGMN, CTSA: lysosomal molecules characteristic of mature phagocytes that are comparatively lower in newly infiltrating monocytes. Inconsistencies: • FOLR2, CLEC10A, CCL17 – more typical of anti-inflammatory/M2 or tissue-resident macrophages. • Low-level lymphoid transcripts (CD3D, CD79B) and alveolar epithelial marker AGER may indicate ambient RNA or multiplet contamination. • Neutrophil granule gene AZU1 and chromatin modifier PADI4 suggest some overlap with immature neutrophils, though these can be transiently expressed in inflammatory monocytes.

program_4.description: The gene pattern reflects an immunoregulatory, “M2-like” tissue-resident macrophage state (e.g. LYVE1+/FOLR2+/MERTK+ perivascular or interstitial macrophages) characterized by high scavenging/efferocytic and anti-inflammatory activity and by a concomitant down-regulation of classical antigen-presentation and pro-inflammatory modules. Evidence: • Resident/M2 identity – CD163, MERTK, MAFB, STAB1, FOLR2, SIGLEC10, GAS6, NR1H3, IL10, AREG, ADORA3, LYVE1, F13A1, HMOX1, SELENOP, SLC40A1, HAMP: genes linked to scavenging of hemoglobin, efferocytosis, iron handling, and anti-inflammatory signaling typical of alternatively activated macrophages. • Perivascular / tissue-resident signature – LYVE1, AGER, FBLN5, FGL2, LGMN, PLTP, ENPP2, ADAMTS2/DEC1: enriched in capillary‐associated macrophages found in lung, heart, and adipose tissue. • Chemokine and remodeling factors typical of resolving macrophages – CCL2, CCL13, TIMP4, MMP2, ADM, HTRA1. • Suppressed antigen presentation / inflammatory drive (negative loadings) – strong down-weighting of HLA-DRA, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DRB5, CD74, TREM1, C1QA/B, MARCO, ALOX5AP, SERPINA1, APOE/C1, FABP4/5 indicates the program is anti-inflammatory and non–classically activated. Inconsistencies: • FLT3 and TMEM176A/B are more typical of tolerogenic dendritic cells, not macrophages. • Presence of S100B and AREG is atypical but reported at low levels in some tissue macrophage subsets.

program_5.description: The gene set describes a generic G2/M-phase cell-cycle program characteristic of rapidly proliferating cells, irrespective of lineage (e.g., dividing epithelial, immune, or tumor cells). Evidence: • Mitotic kinases and regulators – CDK1, CCNB1/2, AURKA/B, PLK1, BUB1, PKMYT1, PRC1, RACGAP1 mark G2/M transition, spindle assembly, and cytokinesis. • DNA replication/repair factors – MCM5/7, CDT1, ORC6, RRM1/2, TYMS, DHFR, FANCI, BRCA1, RAD51AP1 reflect S-phase completion and genome integrity checks preceding mitosis. • Chromosome condensation & segregation proteins – TOP2A, SMC2/4, NCAPG/D2, CENPA/F/M/P/U/W, NDC80, KNL1, CENPE support chromosomal architecture and kinetochore function. • Proliferation markers – MKI67, UBE2C, BIRC5, PCLAF, PCNA, TK1 are canonical markers of actively cycling cells. • Down-regulated lineage gene – C1QB (classical macrophage complement component) is negatively loaded, consistent with loss of differentiated macrophage identity during cell-cycle entry rather than contradicting a proliferation signature. Inconsistencies: No substantial subsets conflict with a generic mitotic cell-cycle program; the lone negatively loaded macrophage gene (C1QB) simply indicates that non-cycling, differentiated macrophages are under-represented in this program rather than challenging the proliferative interpretation.

program_6.description: The gene set depicts an activated, cytotoxic CD8⁺ T-cell (and CD94⁺/CD161⁺ NK-like T-cell) program that is simultaneously experiencing a strong type I interferon (ISG) response, typical of antiviral effector/memory CD8⁺ T lymphocytes. Evidence: • Cytotoxic effector machinery – PRF1, GZMB, GZMA, GZMH, GNLY, NKG7, FGFBP2, CTSW, CST7 indicate perforin/granzyme-mediated killing. • T-cell identity – CD3D/E/G, CD2, CD7, CD247, LCK, PTPRCAP confirm TCR-bearing lymphocytes. • CD8⁺ / NK-like features – CD8A, KLRD1 (CD94), KLRB1 (CD161), CD96 support a CD8⁺ cytotoxic or CD8⁺NK-T phenotype. • Activation / effector chemokines – CCL5, CCL4, CXCL10, CD69 denote recent activation and tissue recruitment. • Interferon-stimulated genes – ISG15, MX1, MX2, IFIT1/2, OAS2/3, RSAD2, STAT1, IRF7, EIF2AK2, XAF1 show a robust type I IFN transcriptional response often seen in viral infection. • Memory / persistence markers – IL7R, HOPX, RORA, ETS1 suggest an effector-memory or tissue-resident subset rather than naïve cells. Inconsistencies: • A few ISGs (OAS1, IFIT3, SAMD9L) are negatively loaded, implying heterogeneous or stage-specific IFN signaling within the program. • VIM, FTH1, CTSD (typically higher in myeloid or stressed epithelial cells) are negatively loaded, but their down-regulation is compatible with a lymphoid-restricted signature rather than conflicting.

program_7.description: The program represents an alternatively-activated, lipid-laden macrophage/TAM (SPP1⁺, APOE⁺, C1QC⁺) state characterized by heightened lysosomal and lipid-handling activity and concomitant suppression of MHC-II antigen presentation. Evidence: • Lysosome/Phagolysosome genes – CTSD, CTSB, CTSL, LGMN, IFI30, ATP6V1F, CD63 support an active degradative/engulfment phenotype typical of tissue macrophages. • Lipid uptake/processing – APOE, FABP4, FABP5, CD36, CYP27A1, MGLL, ANGPTL4, PLA2G7, NPC2 indicate foam-cell–like, cholesterol-handling macrophages frequently observed in tumors and atherosclerotic lesions. • SPP1, GPNMB, MARCO, LGALS3, C1QC are canonical markers of the SPP1⁺/TREM2⁺ disease-associated or tumor-associated macrophage subset. • M2/TAM chemokines/cytokine regulators – CCL18, CCL2, CCL7, CCL13, IL1RN, CHI3L1, CHIT1 denote an alternatively-activated, immunoregulatory state. • Negative loading of HLA-DRA and CD74 together with positive LILRB4, FCER1G reflects down-regulated MHC-II antigen presentation, a hallmark of TAM/DAM programs. Inconsistencies: • ISG15 (interferon response) and FOS (immediate-early gene, negatively loaded) suggest minor activation states not central to an M2/TAM phenotype. • FCER2 (typically B-cell) and OTOA are likely low-level contamination or technical noise rather than true macrophage markers.

program_8.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with a TREM2⁺, lipid-associated/foam‐like macrophage state that has heightened lipid uptake, lysosomal activity and extracellular-matrix remodelling—features described for “lipid-associated macrophages” (LAM) in adipose tissue, atherosclerotic plaques and tumours. Evidence: • Lipid handling & catabolism – high FABP4, FABP5, LPL, CD36, LIPA, MGLL, PLA2G7, SCARB2 point to active uptake and hydrolysis of lipids characteristic of foam/LAM macrophages. • TREM2-associated LAM module – TREM2, CD9, SPP1, LPL, LIPA, FABP5, MS4A6E, HCST collectively mark the TREM2⁺ LAM/DAM programs described in obesity and neurodegeneration. • Phagocytic/lysosomal and actin remodelling genes – GSN, EVL, ITGB2, CD63, LSP1, SCARB2, SYTL1 support an activated, phagocytic macrophage phenotype. • Extracellular matrix remodelling & wound response – MMP7, MMP9, TIMP1, CHI3L1, COL6A3, FN1, COL22A1, SDC2 indicate tissue-remodelling behaviour typical of lipid-laden macrophages in diseased tissues. • Pro-inflammatory regulation – CEBPB, IL1RN, SLAMF7, RGCC, CCL24 reflect an activated inflammatory state. • Negative loadings – repression of CD163 and ALOX5AP, markers of tissue-resident, anti-inflammatory macrophages, further supports a shift toward an activated lipid-associated phenotype rather than a homeostatic M2-like state. Inconsistencies: • TACSTD2 (EpCAM) and COL22A1 are more typical of epithelial/mesenchymal cells and may reflect engulfed material or ambient RNA rather than true macrophage expression. • MATK and SPOCD1 are not commonly highlighted in LAM signatures, though they do not contradict the macrophage identity.

program_9.description: The gene pattern most closely matches a lipid-handling, anti-inflammatory (“foam-cell/M2-like”) macrophage state, characterized by high expression of fatty-acid uptake and lysosomal cholesterol-processing genes together with mediators of tissue remodeling and cytokine dampening, and simultaneous repression of classical inflammatory/MHC-II macrophage genes. Evidence: • Lipid uptake & processing – strong up-regulation of CD36, FABP4, FABP5 and LIPA, genes classically induced when macrophages accumulate lipids and form foam cells. • Anti-inflammatory/resolution factors – IL1RN, TIMP1, GDF15 and RGS2 are well-known products of alternatively activated or resolving macrophages. • General macrophage identity – FCMR and MS4A6E are expressed in monocytic/macrophage lineages. • Cytoskeletal/house-keeping support – ACTB, CFL1, PFN1, GAPDH, CALM3 reinforce that the program is not cell-cycle specific but reflects an active metabolic state. • Repression of classically activated/resident signatures – MARCO, ALOX5AP, MCEMP1, HLA-DPA1 and SERPINA1 (markers of pro-inflammatory, antigen-presenting or resident macrophages) as well as ACP5 (osteoclast) are negatively loaded, consistent with a switch away from a pro-inflammatory/MHC-II phenotype.
