Inconsistencies: • MFAP5 (stromal), SELENOP (hepatocyte-enriched) and the down-regulation of APOE (often elevated in foam cells) are somewhat atypical for foam-cell macrophages, but do not outweigh the dominant lipid-handling and anti-inflammatory macrophage signature.

program_10.description: The program reflects an activated, cytotoxic T-cell state—most consistent with CD8⁺ effector T lymphocytes that have up-regulated granule-mediated killing machinery and early activation genes. Evidence: • T-cell identity: CD3D, CD3E and CD7 encode components/co-receptors of the T-cell receptor complex, distinguishing T cells from CD3⁻ NK cells. • Cytotoxic machinery: GNLY (granulysin), NKG7, GZMM and CST7 (cystatin F) are canonical constituents or regulators of lytic granules in cytotoxic CD8 T cells and NK cells. • Activation/effector markers: CD69 (early activation), IL32 (pro-inflammatory cytokine often induced in activated T and NK cells) and IFITM1 (interferon-stimulated gene up-regulated upon activation) indicate recent T-cell activation and engagement in immune responses. Inconsistencies: • Classical CD8A/B, perforin (PRF1) or granzymes A/B are not present, so the program may represent a subset or an intermediate activation state rather than the full canonical CD8 cytotoxic signature.

program_11.description: The program is most consistent with an activated cytotoxic T-cell (CD8⁺ effector/effector-memory, often tissue-resident) or closely related NK-like state, characterized by chemokine secretion, cytotoxic granule machinery and early activation/residency markers. Evidence: • Cytotoxic granule module – NKG7 and CST7 are hallmark components of cytotoxic lymphocytes (CD8⁺ T cells and NK cells). • T/NK lineage markers – CD7 and ACAP1 are broadly expressed in T cells (especially CD8⁺) and NK cells. • Activation/tissue-residency – CD69 is an early activation antigen and canonical marker of tissue-resident memory T cells (Trm); IFITM1 is rapidly induced by interferon signaling during activation. • Effector chemokine – CCL5 (RANTES) is abundantly produced by activated CD8⁺ T cells and NK cells to recruit additional immune effectors. Inconsistencies: • Classic cytotoxic effectors (GZMB, PRF1, GNLY) are not listed, which slightly weakens—but does not contradict—the cytotoxic T/NK interpretation.

program_12.description: The gene program represents an acutely-activated, pro-inflammatory myeloid state (e.g., monocytes/macrophages exposed to TLR/TNF-α stimuli), characterized by rapid AP-1 transcription factor induction and secretion of neutrophil- and T-cell-recruiting chemokines. Evidence: • Immediate-early AP-1 genes FOS, JUNB, and FOSB are classical markers of recent stimulation in myeloid cells. • TNFAIP3 (A20) is an NF-κB-inducible negative feedback regulator, up-regulated minutes after TNF-α/LPS exposure. • Chemokines CXCL8 (IL-8) and CXCL1 (GRO-α) are hallmark neutrophil attractants released by activated monocytes/macrophages. • CCL3 (MIP-1α) is a pro-inflammatory chemokine that recruits additional monocytes and T cells, typical of activated macrophage programs. Inconsistencies: None apparent—all listed genes align with an early pro-inflammatory myeloid activation signature.

program_13.description: The gene set is most consistent with an interferon-stimulated, pro-inflammatory lymphoid state typical of recently activated T or NK cells, characterized by high antiviral/IFN-responsive transcripts and concomitant low expression of myeloid/osteoclast iron-handling genes. Evidence: • IFITM1 – canonical interferon-stimulated gene strongly induced in activated T and NK cells during antiviral responses. • IL32 – cytokine produced by activated T cells and NK cells that amplifies TNF/IL-1–driven inflammation. • CLIC3 – reported to rise during lymphocyte activation and vesicular trafficking associated with cytotoxic granule release. • ACP5 (osteoclast/TRAP) – low expression argues against osteoclasts or dendritic/macrophage lineage; fits lymphoid identity. • FTH1 – ferritin heavy chain enriched in macrophage/iron-handling cells; its negative loading is compatible with a non-myeloid, lymphoid population. Inconsistencies: • CLIC3 is not a classic lymphoid marker and is also seen in some epithelial and myeloid contexts. • IL32 can be expressed by monocytes, so its presence alone is not exclusive to lymphoid cells.

program_14.description: The program represents a metallothionein-driven metal-ion/oxidative-stress response state that can be adopted by many cell types when exposed to elevated Zn²⁺/Cu²⁺, heavy metals, or reactive oxygen species rather than defining a specific lineage. Evidence: • Strong positive loading of five classical metallothionein genes—MT1X, MT2A, MT1G, MT1F, MT1E—whose coordinated up-regulation is a well-described signature of MTF-1/NRF2-mediated detoxification and antioxidant programs across diverse epithelial, stromal and immune cells. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; no negatively loaded genes provided.

program_0.description: The program corresponds to an airway secretory–goblet cell state that has undergone type-2/inflammatory stimulation, characterised by massive mucin production, antimicrobial/chemokine secretion and loss of the ciliated‐cell transcriptional signature. Evidence: • Goblet/secretory identity – high expression of canonical regulators and products (MUC5AC, MUC5B, SPDEF, FOXA3, AGR2, TFF1/TFF3, CLCA4, BPIFB1/2, BPIFA1, SCGB1A1/3A1, PIGR). • Airway localisation – airway-restricted xenobiotic enzymes (CYP2F1, CYP2A13), ion/fluid transporters (CFTR, SCNN1B/G, SLC12A2, AQP5) and secretoglobin genes. • Inflammatory/type-2 activation – strong chemokine/cytokine set (CXCL8, CXCL6, CXCL2/3/10, CXCL17, IL19, TNFSF10), hypoxia/VEGF module (EPAS1, VEGFA), and antimicrobial peptides/protease inhibitors (SLPI, WFDC2, DEFB1, SERPINB3/B4). • Loss of ciliated program – negative loading of cilia/axoneme genes (RSPH1, CFAP276) and redox enzymes (PRDX5, GPX4) fits replacement of ciliated cells by mucus secretory cells seen in goblet cell metaplasia. Inconsistencies: • Basal-cell keratins (KRT5/6/15/17) and MHC-II genes (HLA-DRA/DRB5, CD74) appear, likely reflecting minor basal/transitional cells or cytokine-induced antigen-presentation rather than true goblet identity. • JCHAIN and XBP1 are plasma-cell genes but can be induced in highly secretory epithelia; their presence may indicate low-level plasma-cell contamination.

program_1.description: The gene set is most consistent with airway (bronchial) basal/secretory epithelial cells that have been acutely stimulated and are mounting a wound-healing / pro-inflammatory, partly epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT-like) response. Evidence: • Airway/basal epithelial identity – TP63, KRT5, KRT14, KRT6A, KRT15, KRT17, DSC3, CLDN10, CD44, PKP1; secretory/club cell genes SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1, BPIFB1, BPIFA1, MUC5B, PIGR, BPIFB1. • Early-response / stress activation – immediate-early genes FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB, EGR1/2/3, NR4A1, MYC, ATF3, BTG1/2, DUSP2. • Pro-inflammatory chemokines and cytokine signalling – CXCL8 (IL-8), CXCL2, CXCL3, CCL5, AREG, HBEGF, EDN1, EPAS1. • Wound repair / EMT-like and extracellular-matrix remodelling – AXL, POSTN, TNC, COL7A1, TAGLN, CNN1, DCN, PLAUR, MMP10, HAS3. • Suppressed oxidative/metabolic genes (negatively loaded COX6A1, PRDX5, GSTP1, FTH1) are typical of the metabolic shift seen during acute epithelial activation. Inconsistencies: • Erythroid transcripts (HBA1, HBA2, HBB, GYPC) and mast-cell/plasma-cell markers (TPSB2, JCHAIN) likely represent ambient RNA contamination. • Myeloid genes LYZ, LTF, S100A8, S100A9 are present but few, suggesting minor immune RNA carry-over rather than a true mixed cell program.

program_2.description: The program most closely matches alveolar type II epithelial cells that have entered an injury- or repair-associated transitional state characterized by inflammatory activation and partial epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT). Evidence: • Core AT2 identity – high surfactant machinery (SFTPA1/2, SFTPB, SFTPC, SFTPD), lipid-handling/processing genes (ABCA3, LPCAT1, FASN), and AT2-enriched transporters (SLC34A2, NAPSA), all under the lung epithelial TF NKX2-1. • Early AT1 / transitional markers – HOPX and AGER together with ICAM1 and CLDN18, consistent with AT2→AT1 differentiation seen during repair. • Injury / inflammatory activation – immediate-early response genes (FOS, DUSP1, ZFP36), cytokine and chemokine genes (CCL2, IL32, LGALS1, TREM1), complement inhibitor SERPING1, and stress genes IFI6, ID1, GADD45B. • Partial EMT / contractile program – mesenchymal and smooth-muscle–like genes VIM, TAGLN, ACTA2, MYL9, CNN1, CALD1, COL6A1, DCN, MMP7/28, SERPINH1, indicating cytoskeletal remodeling and matrix interaction typical of epithelial cells undergoing EMT during wound healing. • Additional lung epithelial surface molecules (GPRC5A, EPCAM paralogue CPM, TM4SF1, AQP4/1) further support an epithelial origin. Inconsistencies: • Strong smooth-muscle genes (ACTA2, MYL9, CNN1) could instead indicate contaminating pericytes or myofibroblasts rather than true EMT. • Negative loading of ubiquitous epithelial marker CD24 and interferon-stimulated gene ISG15 is unexpected for a typical inflamed epithelium.

program_3.description: The program is most consistent with a non-ciliated, secretory airway (club/goblet) epithelial state that is concurrently experiencing an interferon-driven inflammatory response; it is enriched for xenobiotic-metabolizing and mucin/secretory genes while genes required for motile ciliogenesis are suppressed. Evidence: • Secretory/club cell and mucin genes positively loaded – MUC1, MUC16, CLDN7, WFDC2 (HE4), SCGB2A1, PIGR, DUOX2, FMO3, ALDH1A1/ALDH3A1, CYP2A13, CYP24A1, ABCA12, CEACAM5, TSPAN1 support a secretory epithelial identity typical of airway club/goblet cells that handle xenobiotics. • Interferon/inflammatory activation – HLA-A/B/C, IFI16, MX1, IDO1, CDKN2A, LGALS3 indicate an up-regulated type-I IFN/MHC-I antigen-presentation program often seen during viral challenge of airway epithelium. • General epithelial/metabolic support – GAPDH, ALDOA, PRDX1, TXN, S100 family, ANXA1/2/3/11, CYBA, ASS1 reflect high metabolic and redox activity typical of secretory cells. • Negative loading of motile cilia genes – CFAP144, CFAP276, CFAP70, DNAAF1, CETN2, DYNLRB2, DYNLT2B, DYNLL1 together with MS4A8 and AGR3 (markers of ciliated/tuft cells) shows the program is expressed when ciliogenesis is comparatively low, reinforcing a non-ciliated secretory state. Inconsistencies: • Developmental/neuro-mesodermal TFs (PAX7, MESP1, FOXG1, SIX3, FEZF1, VGLL1) appear among positively loaded genes and are not typical of mature airway secretory cells. • Negative loading of immediate-early/stress genes (FOS, DUSP1) and immune cytotoxic genes (GNLY, SRGN) does not neatly align with the principal secretory epithelial interpretation.

program_4.description: The gene set typifies airway secretory/club epithelium that has been acutely activated by injury- or cytokine-mediated stress, displaying an EGFR/MAPK immediate-early response coupled to hypoxia/angiogenic and pro-inflammatory signalling—hallmarks of a wound-healing, mucous-producing state rather than a resting epithelial cell. Evidence: • Secretory/club cell identity – SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1, BPIFB1, CYP2F1, GPRC5A, CLCA2, MUC5B, LTF, CEACAM6 and KRT17/6A are canonical markers of bronchial secretory and goblet lineage. • Immediate-early EGFR/MAPK activation – classic rapid-response genes FOSB, JUN, JUNB, FOSL1, EGR1/2/3, ATF3, BTG1/2, IER5, DUSP5/6, SOCS3, NR4A1/3 and ERRFI1 indicate acute transcriptional activation downstream of EGFR, TNF or IL-1. • Pro-inflammatory chemokine output – CXCL8, CXCL2/3/6, CCL20, CSF3, CXCR4 and PLAUR signify epithelial recruitment of neutrophils and monocytes after damage. • Wound-healing & hypoxia response – AREG, HBEGF, VEGFA, EPAS1 (HIF-2α), ADM, EDN1, THBS1, TNC, PLAU and FGFR1/3 support tissue repair, angiogenesis and extracellular-matrix remodelling. • Survival and stress adaptation – MCL1, GDF15, HES1, XBP1 and unfolded-protein-response genes highlight adaptation to oxidative and ER stress. • Down-regulation of lipid biosynthesis – negative loading of FDFT1 (cholesterol synthesis) and CFD is consistent with metabolic shift during acute epithelial activation. Inconsistencies: • MAFB (macrophage), SERPINB9 (cytotoxic lymphocytes) and PRDM1 (plasma cells) are atypical for epithelium but can be low-level or reflect ambient RNA. • Absence of classic basal (KRT5/14) or alveolar (SFTPA/B/C) markers confirms the program is not basal or AT2, yet presence of stress keratins KRT6/17 may blur strict lineage assignment.

program_5.description: The program most closely matches lung alveolar epithelial cells—primarily type II pneumocytes that are transitioning toward an activated/repair state characterized by mixed AT2-AT1 features and induction of stress and antigen-presentation pathways. Evidence: • Lineage / surfactant genes (AT2): NKX2-1, SFTPA1, SFTA2, NAPSA, MGST1, SERPINA1, FOLR1, TMEM35B support alveolar type II identity. • AT1 / transitional markers: AGER, HOPX, CAV1, CCN1, WIF1, MMP28 indicate partial AT1 gene induction typical of AT2→AT1 differentiation after injury. • Antigen presentation: CD74, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DRB5, C4B and IFN-stimulated genes (IFITM1/3, IFI6) show inflammatory activation of AT2 cells, a well-described response to cytokine exposure. • Immediate-early / stress response: FOS, DUSP1, IER2, ZFP36, HSPA1A/B, HSPB1, SESN1, MIF denote recent stress signalling. • Secretory/vesicle trafficking genes (GABARAP, ATP6V0C, SYT8, TRAPPC5) fit the high secretory activity of surfactant-producing AT2 cells. • Negatively loaded epithelial genes (FXYD3, CD24) are normally enriched in steady-state airway/glandular epithelia, consistent with their relative down-regulation in alveolar cells. Inconsistencies: • MUC12 (intestinal mucin), CLEC11A (hematopoietic factor), TNNI2 (muscle contractile), PNMA2 (neuronal antigen) and OMG (negatively loaded CNS gene) are atypical for lung epithelium and may derive from low-level contamination or shared ubiquitous transcripts. • CCNA1 suggests cell-cycle entry, yet most classic proliferation markers are absent, implying either low-level cycling or noise.

program_6.description: The gene set represents an NF-κB / AP-1–driven “immediate early” inflammatory-stress program most prominently seen in activated airway/alveolar epithelial cells. Cells up-regulate rapid-response transcription factors, cytokines and tight-junction/epithelial genes while repressing oxidative-phosphorylation and homeostatic metabolic genes, a signature characteristic of epithelium acutely stimulated by TNF-α / IL-1β or mechanical dissociation. Evidence: • Immediate-early / AP-1 factors: JUN, JUNB, JUND, FOS, FOSB, ATF3, EGR1, IER2/5, BTG2 underline a classic rapid-response module. • NF-κB pathway targets and inhibitors: NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, SOCS3, GDF15, CXCL2/3, CCL4/5/20, IL6, CSF3—hallmarks of pro-inflammatory epithelial activation. • Stress-adaptation genes: DUSP1/2, GADD45A/B, PPP1R15A, HSPA1A/B, ZFP36, RHOB reflect acute cellular stress. • Epithelial identity: TACSTD2 (TROP2), CLDN3/4, ELF3, OVOL1, GPRC5A, AREG, AGER, NPNT support an airway/alveolar epithelial source. • Metabolic shift: positive glycolytic LDHA and negative OXPHOS components (COX6A1, ATP5F1E) plus loss of ALDH1A1 indicate suppression of mitochondrial respiration typical of acute inflammatory activation. Inconsistencies: • Immune cell genes (PTPRC, NKG7, CTSW) and endothelial/fibroblast markers (CLDN5, LUM) appear sporadically and may reflect doublets or low-level contamination rather than the core epithelial stress program.

program_7.description: The gene set describes an epithelial-cell inflammatory response program typical of “DUOX2⁺/SAA⁺ inflamed secretory enterocytes or airway secretory cells” seen in mucosal tissues during active infection or inflammatory bowel disease. Cells bearing this program retain secretory/goblet features but are strongly stimulated by NF-κB and interferon, producing acute-phase proteins, chemokines and antimicrobial factors while ciliated-cell genes are repressed. Evidence: • Secretory/goblet/enterocyte markers – MUC1, MUC13, FCGBP, ZG16B, DUOX2/DUOXA2, SLC26A4, SLC5A1, GALNT5/14 indicate a non-ciliated mucosal epithelial lineage. • Acute-phase & antimicrobial proteins – SAA1/2/4, LCN2, PI3, DEFB4A, S100A8/A9, LYZ show strong epithelial innate-immune activation. • Interferon / JAK–STAT genes – IDO1, CXCL10, ISG20, IFI16, IFI27, GBP1, MX1, MX2, OASL, UBD mark an IFN-stimulated state. • NF-κB/inflammatory regulators – ZC3H12A, IKBKE, TNFAIP2, TNIP3, BATF/BATF2/BATF3, RELB underline cytokine-driven activation. • Chemokines & cytokines – CCL20, CCL2, CCL4, CSF3, IL32, IL19, PTGES support recruitment of immune cells. • MHC up-regulation – HLA-B, HLA-DQA2, HLA-DRB5 reflects epithelial antigen-presentation during inflammation. • Negative loadings for motile-cilia genes (DNAH12, CFAP70, CFAP46) further point to a secretory rather than ciliated epithelial identity. Inconsistencies: • Low-level immune cell transcripts (CD7, GNLY, HCST, LTB) and hemoglobin (HBA1) suggest minor contamination or shared interferon signature. • Basal/keratinocyte genes (KRT6A, KRT14) and muscle-related PAX7 are atypical for gut/airway epithelium but could arise from stressed epithelial differentiation programs or ambient RNA.

program_8.description: This transcriptional program best fits an inflamed lung-alveolar niche characterized by surfactant-producing alveolar type II (AT2) epithelial cells that are spatially coupled to, and transcriptionally intermixed with, activated/resident alveolar macrophages. It captures simultaneous up-regulation of canonical AT2 surfactant-metabolism genes and myeloid complement, scavenger-receptor and chemokine genes, indicating epithelial–immune crosstalk during local injury or infection; airway-secretory markers (ALDH1A1, CD24) are specifically depleted, consistent with a distal-alveolus, not airway, setting. Evidence: • AT2 / surfactant production – Classic surfactant genes: SFTPC, SFTPA1/2, SFTPB, SFTPD, LPCAT1, NAPSA, ADGRF5, TPPP3, CST6. • Lipid handling & epithelial regulators typical of AT2 cells under stress/repair – FABP4, PLIN2, APOE, APOC1, SERPINA1, PGC, NNMT, WIF1. • Resident/activated alveolar macrophage signature – Complement & phagocytic genes: C1QA/B/C, FCER1G, TYROBP, VSIG4, MARCO, CD68, AIF1, LST1, ARHGDIB. – Inflammatory chemokines/cytokines: CCL2, CCL3, CCL4/4L2, CCL5, IL1B, IL32, TREM1, OSMR. • General myeloid activation / antigen presentation – HLA-DPB1, RELB, BIRC3, NAMPT, SRGN, LYZ, GMFG. • Depletion of proximal-airway/secretory markers – Negative loadings for ALDH1A1 and CD24 support a distal (alveolar) rather than airway identity. Inconsistencies: • Smooth-muscle/endothelial transcripts (ACTA2, CALD1, CLDN5, EGFL7) and NK-cell granule gene NKG7 are atypical for AT2 or macrophages, suggesting minor contamination or ambient RNA. • Presence of S100A8/A9 (often neutrophil) may reflect infiltrating granulocytes or generalized inflammatory RNA background.

program_9.description: The gene set depicts a mature, motile-ciliated epithelial cell program—typical of airway or ependymal ciliated cells—characterised by active axonemal assembly/maintenance, high mitochondrial energy production and detoxification capacity, while showing low expression of immune-presentation genes. Evidence: • Ciliogenesis / axoneme: CFAP276, CFAP144, RSPH1, DYNLL1, DYNLRB2, TUBB4B, TUBA1A and MORN5 encode structural or motor components of motile cilia. • Energy demand: ATP5IF1, ATP5F1E, NDUFB2 and AK1 support elevated oxidative phosphorylation required for continuous ciliary beating. • Detoxification / oxidative-stress defence typical of airway epithelia: GSTP1, GSTA1, GSTA2, GPX4, PRDX5, ALDH1A1, CYP4B1, HGD. • Ion/fluid regulation associated with ciliated airway cells: FXYD1. • Negative loading of HLA-B, CD74, IFITM1 and FTL indicates reduced antigen-presentation/interferon response, fitting differentiated epithelial—not immune—cells. Inconsistencies: • Secretory/club markers ALDH1A1, CYP4B1 and TFF3, and complement gene C1R, are more typical of non-ciliated secretory or immune programs; their presence may reflect low-level co-expression in a subset or mixed epithelial population.

program_10.description: The gene set most closely matches an IL-17/IL-1–induced “inflammatory secretory epithelial” program that is seen in airway and intestinal goblet/club cells during mucosal inflammation. Cells expressing this program are secretory epithelial cells that up-regulate antimicrobial peptides, chemokines, and acute-phase reactants to recruit neutrophils and bolster barrier defense. Evidence: • Antimicrobial/acute-phase genes (LCN2, SAA2, DEFB4A, NOS2) – canonical IL-17/IL-1 targets produced by epithelial cells to limit bacterial growth. • Neutrophil-recruiting and ‑expanding factors (CCL20, CSF3) – hallmarks of IL-17–driven mucosal responses. • Secretory/goblet cell genes (ZG16B, ATP12A, SLC26A4) – enriched in airway and colonic goblet/club cells that secrete mucus and bicarbonate. • Epithelial transporters up-regulated during inflammation (SLC5A8, ATP10B) – support metabolic and pH changes in activated secretory cells. • Immune-modulatory enzymes (IDO1, C15orf48) – commonly induced in inflamed epithelial barriers by IFN-γ/IL-1. Inconsistencies: • No strong contradictions; all listed genes have documented expression in inflamed mucosal epithelium, though IDO1 is also expressed by myeloid cells and SLC5A8 is most abundant in colon rather than airway.

program_11.description: The program represents a robust MHC class II antigen-presentation module characteristic of professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs)—such as dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells—in an activated state. Evidence: • Core MHC-II α/β chains: HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DQA1, HLA-DQB1, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1 encode the peptide-binding heterodimers essential for presenting exogenous antigens to CD4⁺ T cells. • Antigen-processing chaperones: CD74 (invariant chain) guides MHC-II folding and peptide loading; HLA-DMA and HLA-DMB catalyze CLIP removal and peptide exchange. • Accessory molecules: HLA-DOA modulates HLA-DM activity, fine-tuning peptide selection. Collectively, this gene set marks cells transcriptionally primed for high‐level antigen presentation. Inconsistencies: • None detected—every gene reinforces an MHC-II antigen-presentation program.

program_12.description: The gene set is most consistent with a motile-ciliated epithelial program – typical of airway or ependymal multiciliated cells – that is enriched for mitochondrial energy control and protein-folding modules used to support ciliary assembly and beating. Evidence: • CFAP144 – canonical motile-cilium structural/assembly gene; strongly marks multiciliated epithelial cells. • ATP5IF1 & AK1 – regulators of mitochondrial ATP production/adenylate balance, required for the high energy demand of ciliary beating. • PFDN5 & SERF2 – chaperone/co-chaperone components that assist folding of cytoskeletal and ciliary proteins. • CES1 – carboxylesterase expressed in airway epithelial cells, reflecting xenobiotic metabolism often co-expressed with ciliary genes in lung epithelium. • C1R – complement component produced by airway/epithelial cells, consistent with barrier epithelium initiating innate immune defense. Inconsistencies: • None overt; CES1 and C1R are not cilium-specific but are compatible with an airway epithelial context that combines ciliation with detoxification and complement production.

program_13.description: Enrichment for PDGFA together with β-catenin (CTNNB1), the CDC42 effector CDC42SE1 and several spliceosome-associated factors (HNRNPH1, SRSF6, PPP1CB) points to an activated, migratory fibroblast / stromal cell state that is simultaneously engaging PDGF- and WNT-driven signalling and a high level of mRNA-processing activity, features that accompany fibroblast activation during wound healing and tissue remodelling. Evidence: • PDGFA – canonical autocrine/paracrine growth factor secreted by activated fibroblasts and mesenchymal stromal cells to drive proliferation and matrix remodelling. • CTNNB1 (β-catenin) – central effector of WNT signalling; WNT–β-catenin activation supports fibroblast proliferation and myofibroblast differentiation. • CDC42SE1 – downstream effector of the Rho GTPase CDC42, promotes actin reorganisation and cell motility typical of activated/migratory fibroblasts. • HNRNPH1, SRSF6, PPP1CB – core components/regulators of the spliceosome; activated fibroblasts up-regulate RNA-processing machinery to sustain high biosynthetic demand. Inconsistencies: • Classic fibroblast structural genes (e.g. COL1A1, COL3A1, ACTA2, LUM) are absent, so the program lacks unequivocal matrix-production signatures. • All positively loaded genes are broadly expressed “house-keeping” or signalling genes; hence they could, in principle, arise from other proliferative cell types rather than being strictly fibroblast-specific.

program_14.description: The gene pattern points to a detoxification / iron-handling program typical of hepatocytes or other parenchymal cells specialized for xenobiotic metabolism, accompanied by a clear exclusion of erythroid cells. Evidence: • Xenobiotic–metabolism enzymes up: CES1 (major hepatic/monocytic carboxyl-esterase) and GSTP1 (phase-II glutathione-S-transferase enriched in liver and other metabolically active parenchyma). • Iron-storage gene up: FTH1, a hallmark of hepatocytes and macrophage-like cells that buffer intracellular iron released from heme. • Erythroid transcripts strongly down: HBA1, HBA2, HBB, indicating that the program is active in non-erythroid cells and may be involved in processing, rather than synthesising, heme/hemoglobin. Inconsistencies: • CFAP144 is usually associated with motile cilia (e.g., airway or ependymal epithelium) and is not a canonical hepatocyte marker, suggesting either low-level contamination from ciliated epithelial cells or that the factor captures a mixed signal rather than a pure hepatocyte signature.

program_15.description: The gene set is most consistent with a metabolically active hepatocyte‐like program, in which liver parenchymal cells up-regulate oxidative-phosphorylation machinery together with secreted acute-phase/xenobiotic-metabolising proteins. Evidence: • Liver-restricted secretory / acute-phase genes – CES1 (major hepatic carboxyl-esterase involved in xenobiotic and lipid metabolism) and C1R (complement C1r, classically synthesized by hepatocytes). • High-energy mitochondrial module – UQCR11 (complex III), ATP5IF1 (ATP-synthase regulator), AK1 (adenylate kinase), and SERF2 all rise during intensified oxidative phosphorylation; hepatocytes are among the most OXPHOS-dependent somatic cells, fitting the co-induction of these genes with CES1/C1R. Inconsistencies: • Classical hepatocyte hallmark transcripts such as ALB, APOA1, TF, or multiple cytochrome P450s are absent from the positive list; this could reflect partial capture of the program or a mixed epithelial population rather than fully mature hepatocytes.

program_16.description: The gene set represents a TNF-/NF-κB–driven pro-inflammatory activation program that can be induced in many stromal or parenchymal cells (e.g., endothelial cells, fibroblasts, epithelial cells) upon exposure to cytokines such as TNF-α or IL-1β. Evidence: • NF-κB signaling core – RELB and BCL3 are canonical components of the alternative and classical NF-κB pathways, respectively, marking pathway activation. • Cytokine/chemokine production – CCL2 (MCP-1) is a hallmark NF-κB target that recruits monocytes, while SOCS2 modulates cytokine signaling feedback. • Adhesion/immune cell recruitment – ICAM1 is a well-known NF-κB-inducible adhesion molecule up-regulated on activated endothelial, epithelial and stromal cells to facilitate leukocyte binding. • Metabolic support of inflammation – NAMPT is up-regulated by NF-κB and supplies NAD⁺ to sustain high glycolytic flux during inflammatory activation. Inconsistencies: • No major inconsistencies observed; the entire positively loaded set coherently fits an NF-κB–mediated inflammatory response signature.

program_17.description: The gene set is most consistent with an alveolar type I (AT1) epithelial cell program in the lung, capturing features of mature gas‐exchanging epithelium with some overlap into distal airway/secretory biology. Evidence: • Core AT1 markers – HOPX and CPM are canonical, high-confidence markers of mature AT1 cells; MGP and GPC3 are also reported in fetal and adult AT1 epithelium. • Stress-detox/oxidative genes often enriched in AT1 – MGST1 is up-regulated in AT1 cells, which experience high oxidative load from inspired air. • Secreted/ECM components found in AT1 – MGP (matrix Gla protein) and GPC3 (cell-surface proteoglycan) contribute to the specialized extracellular interface of the alveolar wall. Inconsistencies: • SCGB3A2 is classically a club/airway secretory cell product; its presence suggests low-level contamination or a minor mixed distal airway signature. • MGST1 is not exclusive to AT1 cells and can be expressed by other epithelial or macrophage populations, but it is nevertheless compatible with an oxidative-stress-adapted alveolar epithelium.

program_18.description: The program is best interpreted as a low-complexity “ankyrin-repeat module” that appears most prominently in myeloid-lineage cells (monocytes / immature neutrophils) but is not, by itself, a definitive marker of any classical activation state; rather, it likely tags cells in which a small set of poorly-characterised ankyrin-repeat genes and the scaffold protein AHI1 are co-up-regulated, perhaps during early differentiation or stress responses. Evidence: • ANKRD36B / ANKRD36C – transcripts reported to be enriched in peripheral blood leukocytes and to rise during THP-1 monocyte-to-macrophage differentiation. • ANKRD36 family members and AHI1 show coordinated expression in bulk myeloid RNA-seq datasets (e.g. BLUEPRINT), supporting a myeloid bias. • AHI1 – although best known for neuronal roles, it is expressed in hematopoietic progenitors and regulates neutrophil chemotaxis, fitting a myeloid context. • ANKRD18A / ANKRD18B – low-information ankyrin-repeat genes that co-cluster with ANKRD36 transcripts in single-cell datasets of bone-marrow–derived cells, again suggesting myeloid co-regulation. Inconsistencies: • Absence of canonical myeloid structural or activation markers (LYZ, CSF1R, S100A8/A9, MPO, etc.) limits confidence and implies the module reflects a narrow transcriptional facet rather than a full cell-identity program. • AHI1 is also prominent in neuronal and ciliated epithelial cells; without accompanying ciliogenesis or neurogenic genes, its presence here is somewhat atypical.

program_19.description: The gene set reflects an epithelial cell state characterized by activation of an NRF2-driven antioxidant / xenobiotic-detoxification program. Evidence: • Core NRF2 targets for phase I/II detoxification and reactive-oxygen protection: NQO1, GPX2, AKR1C2, AKR1B10. • Iron-sequestration and oxidative-stress buffering: FTL, commonly co-induced with NRF2 signaling in stressed epithelia. • GPX2 and AKR1B10 are preferentially expressed in mucosal or airway/hepatic epithelia, where NRF2-mediated oxidative stress defenses are frequently engaged. Inconsistencies: • No obvious conflicting genes; all listed transcripts fit an NRF2-regulated antioxidant/detoxification response.

program_20.description: The program most consistent with these transcripts represents a generic oxidative-stress / redox-detoxification state that many cell types (especially epithelium and macrophages) adopt when intracellular reactive oxygen species are elevated. Evidence: • Antioxidant enzymes – PRDX1 and TXN encode central thiol-based peroxide-scavenging proteins that are transcriptionally up-regulated during oxidative stress. • Aldehyde detoxification – ALDH3A1 oxidizes toxic lipid- and xenobiotic-derived aldehydes generated by ROS, and is a canonical NRF2-responsive gene in stress-protected epithelia. • Stress-responsive calcium-binding protein – S100A6 is induced by ROS and participates in redox-sensitive signaling and cytoskeletal remodeling observed in stressed cells. • Galectin associated with damage and inflammation – LGALS3 (Galectin-3) is up-regulated in multiple cell types after oxidative injury, promoting clearance of damaged proteins and modulation of inflammatory responses. Inconsistencies: • The gene list lacks other hallmark NRF2 targets (e.g., NQO1, HMOX1); thus while strongly suggestive of an oxidative-stress response, the program may reflect only a partial activation or an alternative redox regulatory pathway.

program_21.description: The program is most consistent with an inflamed airway secretory (club/goblet-like) epithelial cell state, characterized by secretoglobin production, high CEACAM expression, extracellular-matrix interaction, and chemokine release. Evidence: • Secretory/club cell genes – SCGB3A1 (secretoglobin family, enriched in bronchiolar club and mucous cells) and CEACAM6 (surface adhesion molecule abundant in airway secretory and goblet cells). • Epithelial identity – S100A14 (calcium-binding protein broadly expressed in differentiating airway epithelium and epithelial tumors). • Inflammatory activation – CXCL2 (neutrophil-recruiting chemokine produced by airway epithelium during infection or injury). • Matrix interaction typical of airway epithelium – NPNT (nephronectin; secreted ECM protein expressed by lung epithelial cells and involved in epithelial–basement-membrane contacts). Inconsistencies: • None apparent with the genes provided.

program_22.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mucosal secretory epithelial program—typical of airway, nasal, or other glandular surface epithelia—engaged in an innate-immune/antimicrobial response and early wound-repair state. Evidence: • Secretory epithelial identity – KRT7 encodes keratin 7, a hallmark of simple and glandular epithelia, including airway and other mucosal surfaces. • Antimicrobial/innate-immune activation – SLPI (Secretory Leukocyte Peptidase Inhibitor) is strongly induced in airway and other mucosal epithelia to inhibit neutrophil proteases and provide antimicrobial activity. – LTF (Lactotransferrin) is an iron-binding antimicrobial protein secreted by mucosal epithelia and neutrophils during infection. – CXCL3 is a chemokine released by epithelial cells to recruit neutrophils and other leukocytes during inflammation. • Wound-repair / cytoskeletal remodeling – RHOV, a Rho family GTPase, is up-regulated in migrating or repairing epithelial cells, supporting cytoskeletal reorganization and barrier restoration. Inconsistencies: • No clear contradictory genes are present in this limited list.

program_23.description: The gene set represents a canonical “cholesterol / mevalonate-pathway activation” program, typical of cells that are building new membranes—e.g., proliferating tumor cells, activated lymphocytes, or other rapidly dividing states—rather than a lineage-specific identity. Evidence: • HMGCS1 and DHCR7 – core enzymes in the mevalonate and late cholesterol-synthetic steps, respectively. • MSMO1 and CYP51A1 – sterol‐modifying enzymes acting mid-pathway to convert lanosterol toward cholesterol. • INSIG1 – ER sterol-sensor that regulates SREBP processing and thus up-scales the entire cholesterol biosynthetic module. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes coherently participate in de novo cholesterol synthesis and its regulation.

program_24.description: The gene set represents a lipogenic / sterol-biosynthetic program most characteristic of hepatocytes (or other cells in a strongly anabolic, SREBP-driven state) that are actively synthesising cholesterol and unsaturated fatty acids for membrane and lipoprotein production. Evidence: • Cholesterol-biosynthesis core: HMGCS1 (mevalonate pathway), DHCR7 (final cholesterol-synthesis step), INSIG1 (regulator of SREBP processing), and LDLR (uptake of exogenous LDL to complement endogenous synthesis) are classic targets of SREBP2 and are highly expressed in metabolically active hepatocytes. • Fatty-acid desaturation: SCD encodes stearoyl-CoA desaturase, another SREBP target essential for generating mono-unsaturated fatty acids, a hallmark of hepatic lipogenesis. • Co-induction of these genes as a module is widely reported in liver under insulin/feeding conditions or in proliferating cells that need bulk membrane synthesis. Inconsistencies: No negatively loaded genes are present; no clear conflicts with a lipogenic, SREBP-activated hepatic state were identified.

program_25.description: The gene set is most consistent with stratified squamous epithelial cells—specifically basal keratinocytes that have entered an “activated / early-differentiation” state typical of wound repair or squamous metaplasia, where stress-inducible and suprabasal keratins are turned on alongside canonical basal markers. Evidence: • Basal keratinocyte identity – KRT14 is a core marker of basal cells in epidermis, oral mucosa, airway and other stratified epithelia. • Activation / stress response – KRT6A is a hyper-proliferative keratin rapidly induced in basal cells after injury and during squamous metaplasia. • Early differentiation toward suprabasal layer – KRT13 is characteristic of non-keratinized suprabasal cells (oral, esophageal epithelium) and is often co-expressed transiently with KRT14/KRT6A during the basal-to-suprabasal transition. • Immediate-early signaling – SIK1 is a CREB-responsive kinase induced by calcium or stress in keratinocytes and linked to initiation of terminal differentiation programs. • General translational support – EIF5AL1 encodes a translation factor that rises in metabolically active, proliferative epithelial cells, fitting the activated basal state. Inconsistencies: No strong contradictions; the simultaneous presence of both basal (KRT14) and suprabasal (KRT13) keratins could appear discordant but is well documented in transitional or reparative squamous epithelium, so it supports rather than contradicts the proposed state.

program_26.description: This program represents a canonical type I/III interferon-stimulated gene (ISG) response that can be super-imposed on many immune and non-immune cell types during viral sensing or other pattern-recognition-receptor activation; it reflects an antiviral, pro-inflammatory cell state rather than a lineage-defining signature. Evidence: • ISG15, IFIT2, IFI44L – prototypic ISGs induced by STAT1/STAT2–IRF9 signaling downstream of IFN-α/β and IFN-λ. • OAS3 – 2′-5′-oligoadenylate synthetase family member activated by double-stranded RNA, hallmark of antiviral interferon response. • EPSTI1 – interferon-inducible adaptor up-regulated in macrophages, dendritic cells, and epithelial cells upon viral mimetics, reinforcing IFN signaling. Inconsistencies: • No notable gene contradicts an interferon response; the list is uniformly composed of ISGs.

program_0.description: The gene set defines a PDGFRA⁺, TCF21⁺, ITGA8⁺ extracellular-matrix–producing fibroblast population typical of lung/perivascular “alveolar/adventitial” fibroblasts that support epithelial and vascular remodeling but are not yet contractile myofibroblasts. Evidence: • Fibroblast core FN1, LUM, COL6A5/6A6/7A1, COL13A1, ELN, FBLN5, MFAP4, CCN1/2, MMP2, TIMP3/4, SERPINE1, FAP → abundant interstitial ECM synthesis/remodeling. • Lineage/identity PDGFRA, TCF21, ITGA8, LMCD1, MEOX2, RSPO1/2/4, WNT2, BMP4/5, FGFR4, FGF7 → markers of lung alveolar/adventitial fibroblasts that drive WNT- and BMP-mediated epithelial maturation. • Lung/perivascular bias ALDH1A1, CYP4B1, HSD11B1, FMO2, PTGDS, VEGFD, ANGPT1, NRP1/2, KDR, EDNRA → genes enriched in pulmonary mesenchyme and vascular niche. • Non-myofibroblast state absence of ACTA2, TAGLN, MYH11 together with presence of PDGFRA and MYH10 indicates pre-contractile fibroblasts rather than smooth-muscle–like myofibroblasts. • Negative loadings depletion of S100A11, IFITM3, MRC1, LGALS3 (epithelial/macrophage markers) underscores mesenchymal rather than immune or epithelial identity. Inconsistencies: • Low-level expression of TMEM119, CD14, CD8A and KDR suggests a minor contribution of microglial/immune or endothelial transcripts. • Presence of EDNRA and smooth-muscle associated transcripts (NEBL, FHOD1) hints at partial pericyte/vSMC features, but lack of canonical contractile genes argues these are secondary or reflect transitional states.

program_1.description: The gene set is most consistent with perivascular mural cells (pericytes / vascular smooth-muscle–like cells) in an activated, angiogenic and hypoxia-responsive state, producing basement-membrane/ECM components and exhibiting Rho-GTPase-driven motility while down-weighting generic fibroblast signatures. Evidence: • Canonical mural-cell markers – RGS5, RBPMS, NR2F2 (COUP-TFII), KCNJ8, LMOD1, LPL and APOE are all strongly enriched in pericytes and vascular smooth muscle but not in endothelial or parenchymal fibroblasts. • Cytoskeletal / contractile and Rho-GTPase regulators typical of mural cells – ACTN4, MYH9, FLNA, VASP, ARHGAP6/10/18/24/42, ARHGEF7/17, PREX2, DOCK6, TNS1/2 support a motile, contractile phenotype. • Basement-membrane and ECM-remodelling genes – COL18A1, COL21A1, COL5A3, SPARC, ADAMTS9, ADAMTSL3, MMP15, PLOD1, NID1, LAMB1, EDIL3 indicate active matrix production typical of vessel-associated fibro-muscular cells. • Angiogenic / hypoxia or Notch–TGFβ signalling components – EPAS1 (HIF-2α), TEAD1, ETV1/5, HEYL, HES4, TGFB2, BMPER, PLXND1, EDNRB, SEMA5A/6D are hallmarks of pericytes engaged in vessel remodelling. • Junctional / adhesion molecules found at the abluminal face of microvessels – ESAM, TJP1, CDH6, CDH19, CADM1, ITGA10, FAT1, OBSCN, support a perivascular localisation. • Negative loadings for typical interstitial fibroblast genes – LUM, MGP, CFD, S100A4, ANXA1 – highlight that the program is distinct from generic stromal fibroblasts. Inconsistencies: • Presence of CD4 and low-level ISG15/IFIT3 suggests minor contaminating T-cell / interferon signal. • Absence of classical contractile SMC genes such as ACTA2 and MYH11 indicates a less-differentiated or pericytic rather than fully smooth-muscle phenotype.

program_2.description: The gene set typifies endothelial cells that have been acutely stimulated by pro-inflammatory cytokines (e.g. TNF-α / IL-1β), entering a classical NF-κB–driven “inflamed endothelium” or early endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndMT) state characterized by strong cytokine/chemokine release, stress–response chaperones and adhesion/matrix-remodelling molecules, while canonical interferon-stimulated or myeloid acute-phase genes are suppressed. Evidence: • Endothelial lineage / flow-responsive factors – PROX1, EFNB2, ANGPTL4, KLF2, KLF4, VCAM1, ICAM1, THBS1, TFPI2. • NF-κB / AP-1 immediate-early activation – NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, REL, RELB, TNFAIP3, JUN, JUNB, FOS, FOSL1/2, ATF3, IRF1, STAT3. • Secreted inflammatory mediators – IL6, CXCL1/2/3/6/8/10, CCL2, CCL19, CCL20, CSF3, PTGS2, SERPINE1, PLAU/R, ADM. • Adhesion & matrix dynamics – VCAM1, ICAM1, MMP19, ADAMTS1/4/9, HAS1/2, THBS1, PLAUR. • Cellular stress/chaperone program – HSPA1A/B/L, HSP90AA1/AB1, HSPH1, DNAJB1/4, SQSTM1, GADD45A/B/G. • Negative loadings (CST3, IFITM3, LCN2, SAA2) mark reduced acute-phase/myeloid signatures, reinforcing endothelial—not myeloid—identity. Inconsistencies: • Fibroblast-associated genes (HAS1/2, CHI3L1/2, SNAI1) suggest partial EndMT or stromal admixture. • Immune markers LAG3 and CD83 are unusual for endothelium and may reflect low-level contamination or paracrine uptake. • Absence of classical endothelial transcripts such as PECAM1 or VWF could indicate either technical dropout or mixed vascular–stromal populations.

program_3.description: The gene set depicts a differentiated, contractile vascular mural-cell program characteristic of vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs)/pericytes that have adopted a fully contractile phenotype and are NOT in an extracellular-matrix–producing (synthetic/fibroblastic) state. Evidence: • Contractile cytoskeleton / smooth-muscle regulators: TPM1, CNN1, LMOD1, ACTG2, SMTN, MYL6, MYLK, MYOCD, DES, CAP2, CFL2, ACTN1/4, TAG smoorth (?)** ensure contractile assembly. • Excitation–contraction coupling genes typical of mature VSMCs: KCNMA1, KCNMB1, KCNA5, CACNB??, PLN, CASQ2, CAMK2G, CALM2, JPH2. • Additional mural/vascular genes: RGS5, ESAM, AOC3, ANGPT2, EDNRB, PDGFA, TM4SF1, CAV1/2, SORBS1/2, EPAS1, FOXC2. • Transcription factors driving contractile VSMC fate: MYOCD, MEF2C, HEY2, FOXS1, ID4. • Suppression of fibroblast/“synthetic” ECM program (negative loadings): COL1A2, COL6A3, LUM, SERPINF1, MFAP5, EFEMP1, MMP2, NNMT are all canonical fibroblast / synthetic VSMC genes, indicating the program is inversely related to extracellular-matrix production. Inconsistencies: • Presence of several cardiomyocyte-enriched genes (TNNT2, TNNC1, MYOM1/2, CKMT2, CASQ2) suggests partial overlap with cardiac muscle transcriptional modules. • Low-level epithelial/keratin genes (KRT15, KRT17) and melanocyte marker TYRP1 are atypical for mural cells. • Neuronal-associated transcripts (NTRK2/3, ADCY5) are not classical VSMC markers. Taken together, the dominant signal supports a contractile VSMC/pericyte state, with some admixture of striated-muscle and non-mural transcripts likely arising from shared cytoskeletal modules or background noise in the single-cell data.

program_4.description: The gene set is most consistent with a leptin-receptor–positive, CXCL12-abundant reticular (CAR) mesenchymal stromal / fibroblast program that typifies the bone-marrow and perivascular niche, characterised by high extracellular-matrix production and secretion of haematopoietic-supportive cytokines while lacking endothelial or epithelial signatures. Evidence: • Core stromal/MSC identity – high expression of COL6A1/2, COL5A1/2, COL12A1, COL14A1, COL15A1, ELN, VCAN, LUM, POSTN, THBS4, MFAP2, ASPN, OGN, FBLN2, SERPINF1, ABI3BP, PDGFRL and MMP2 marks matrix-producing fibroblasts. • Bone-marrow CAR-cell markers – LEPR, CXCL12, IGF1, CFD, PI16, IGFBP4/6, CXCL14 and DPP4-independent PI16 are all characteristic of LEPR+ CAR cells that support haematopoiesis. • Perivascular/adventitial MSC features – PDGFRL, ABCA8/10, CD200, CNTFR, CFH, SFRP2/SFRP4, WNT5A and BMP modulators (BMP4, DIO2, DIO3) align with quiescent vascular-wall fibroblasts. • Secreted niche factors – IL34, CCL11, CXCL12, IGF1, PENK, INHBA, FGF7 and ANGPTL6 illustrate a trophic, immune-modulatory state rather than contractile or proliferative activity. • Negative loading of endothelial/pericyte and epithelial genes – depletion of RGS5, TM4SF1, AQP1, MYLK, ACTN1 (vascular/pericyte), and keratins KRT8/18/15, CLDN1 (epithelial) rules out endothelial or epithelial programs, reinforcing fibroblast identity. Inconsistencies: • TNC, RGS5 and EDIL3 appear in the negatively loaded list even though they can be expressed by activated fibroblasts/pericytes. • S100A4 and CTSK are more typical of myofibroblasts or osteogenic cells, suggesting some heterogeneity within the program. • Presence of ANGPTL7 and CRABP1 is often linked to ocular or tendon fibroblasts rather than bone-marrow stroma, indicating possible tissue-specific variation.

program_5.description: The program is most consistent with an interferon-stimulated, antigen-presenting blood/venular endothelial cell state (sometimes termed “inflamed endothelium” or HEV-like endothelium), characterised by strong vascular core genes, up-regulation of leukocyte-recruiting and MHC class II molecules, and suppression of extracellular-matrix genes typical of fibroblasts. Evidence: • Endothelial identity – CLDN5, PECAM1, CDH5, VWF, ESAM, ENG, TIE1, ROBO4, PTPRB, ACVRL1, RASIP1, EPAS1, ERG. • Venular / inflamed features – ACKR1 (DARC), VCAM1, ICAM2, S1PR1, CLEC14A, CX3CL1, CCL14/19/23, EDN1, POSTN. • Antigen presentation – HLA-DRA, ‑DRB1/5, ‑DPA1/B1, HLA-A/B/C/E, B2M, CD74-like partners, IFNGR1. • Interferon/innate activation – STAT1, RSAD2, OAS1/3, IFIT2, MX2, GBP1/4, IL32, BST2. • Negative loadings highlight non-fibroblast nature – depletion of fibroblast ECM genes COL1A2, COL6A2, COL15A1, SPARC, DPT, SERPING1, CFD. Inconsistencies: • Macrophage/scavenger‐associated genes (C1QA/B, MARCO, MRC1, CD163) and the lymphatic marker PROX1/CCL21 appear, suggesting some admixture with lymphatic endothelial or myeloid signatures. • A few strong interferon‐stimulated genes (IFI27, IFIT1) could also derive from neighbouring immune cells rather than endothelium.

program_6.description: The gene set is most consistent with lung‐resident (alveolar) macrophages that are transcriptionally active in antigen presentation and immunoregulatory (M2-skewed) functions, with a concomitant mild inflammatory/acute-phase response. Evidence: • Core macrophage / myeloid identity – TYROBP, FCER1G, C1QA/B/C, CD68, LST1, LAPTM5, CTSD/CTSS, CYBB/CYBA, MS4A7, SPI1. • Alveolar-macrophage specialization – MARCO, PPARG, FABP4, APOC1, VSIG4, MRC1 (CD206), CD163, OLR1, SPP1, ACP5; all enriched in lung-resident macrophages that recycle lipids and surfactant. • Surfactant / lipid-handling milieu – ALOX5/AP, SCD, LYZ together with high complement genes (C1QA/B/C) support surfactant turnover characteristic of alveolar macrophages. • Antigen-presentation program – broad up-regulation of HLA class II genes (HLA-DRA/B1/B5/DPB1/DQA1/DMB, etc.), CD52, CD37, PTPRC, indicating professional APC activity. • M2 / immunoregulatory bias – CCL18, IL1R2, PPARG, CD163, AREG, GDF15 are hallmarks of alternatively activated macrophages. • Mild inflammatory activation – IL1B, CXCL8, CCL3/4, TREM1, S100A8/A9/A12, HMOX1 suggest an ongoing but not highly cytotoxic inflammatory response. Inconsistencies: • Surfactant genes (SFTPC, SFTPA1/2, SFTPB) and epithelial markers (CLDN18, AGR3) are epithelial, likely ambient RNA or macrophage-epithelial doublets. • GZMB (cytotoxic lymphoid), TPSAB1/CPA3 (mast cell), and JCHAIN (plasma cell) point to minor contamination. • Strong S100A8/A9/A12 and TREM1 are more typical of inflammatory monocytes than classic M2 alveolar macrophages, indicating mixed or transitioning states.

program_7.description: The gene set defines a population of highly activated, cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CD8⁺>NK-like) that have recently received T-cell-receptor stimulation and display a tissue-resident/effector-memory phenotype. Evidence: • Cytotoxic machinery – NKG7, PRF1, GZMB, GZMA, GZMH, GNLY, CTSW, CST7 mark CD8⁺ T and NK cell–mediated killing. • T-cell identity/signalling – CD3D/E, CD247, CD2, CD7, LCK, IL2RG, PTPRC (CD45) confirm lymphoid, TCR-bearing cells. • Effector chemokines/cytokines – CCL3, CCL4, CCL5, XCL2, IFNG, IL32 are produced by activated type-1 cytotoxic T cells to recruit additional immune cells. • Activation & tissue-residency – CD69, HLA-DRA/B/DP, HLA-DQA/B, HLA-DRB5, HOPX, AREG, CXCR4 are induced after recent antigen encounter and are typical of tissue-resident/effector-memory CD8⁺ T cells. • NK‐associated receptors – KLRD1 (CD94), FCGR3A (CD16), TYROBP, FCER1G give the subset an NK-like transcriptional flavour often seen in cytotoxic effector T cells. • Negative loading of stromal/ECM genes (SPARCL1, COL6A2, TIMP3, SERPING1, ANXA2) underscores that the program is enriched in lymphocytes rather than resident stromal cells. Inconsistencies: • Mast-cell proteases (TPSAB1, TPSB2, CPA3) and arachidonate genes (ALOX5, ALOX5AP) are atypical for T cells. • Myeloid-associated S100A8/A9 and LST1, and plasma-cell genes JCHAIN, MZB1 suggest a small amount of non-T-cell signal mixing with the program. • Broad HLA class-II expression is uncommon but can occur on strongly activated human T cells; its presence may partly reflect contaminating antigen-presenting cells.

program_8.description: The gene set is most consistent with a vascular-adventitial / perivascular fibroblast (PI16⁺, CD34⁺) program characteristic of mesenchymal stromal cells that secrete large amounts of extracellular matrix and paracrine factors during tissue remodeling and fibrotic or reparative states. Evidence: • Canonical adventitial-fibroblast markers: PI16, CD34, ACKR3 (CXCR7), PDGFRL, PRRX1, LEPR, PROCR, SEMA3C, C1QTNF3. • Extensive matrix production/remodeling genes: FBN1, ELN, TNXB, COL3A1, COL12A1, COL14A1, VCAN, MFAP5, PCOLCE2, OMD, OGN, ADAMTS5/6/16, HTRA1/3, SFRP2/4, RSPO3, NOX4. • Secreted growth-factor and adipogenic regulators typical of stromal progenitors: IGF1, IGF2, IGFBP4/5/6, WNT10B, BMP7, MEDAG, DPP4, RBP4. • Perivascular signaling molecules: NPR1, PTGIS, RAMP2, BDKRB2, ACE, THBD, CALCRL. • Fibroblast activation / motility factors: S100A4/A10/A11, SERPINF1, GPNMB, IL18, TNFSF10. • Negatively loaded endothelial/myeloid genes (CAV1, AQP1, CSRP1, EDNRB, AGER, LYZ) argue against an endothelial or immune identity and support a selective fibroblast program. Inconsistencies: • Muscle-associated genes TNNT3 and FHOD3, and lymphoid marker CD70, appear but are few and could reflect minor contamination or low-level expression in activated stromal cells rather than a true myogenic or immune state.

program_9.description: The program most closely matches distal lung alveolar type II (AT2) epithelial cells that are transitioning toward an injury-activated, KRT8-high “intermediate” state (often termed AT2-to-AT1 transitional or PATS cells), characterized by high surfactant production together with epithelial-stress and innate-immune response genes and concomitant repression of mesenchymal markers. Evidence: • Core AT2 identity – high expression of multiple surfactant genes (SFTPA1/2, SFTPB, SFTPC, SFTPD, SFTA2), the AT2 enzymes/transporters LPCAT1, NAPSA, SLC34A2, and alveolar markers AGER, HOPX, ITGB6. • Transitional/KRT8-high signature – enrichment of KRT8, KRT17, KRT19, CLDN4, TACSTD2, EPCAM and HOPX, features described for injured AT2 cells converting to AT1. • Secretory/club overlap typical of distal airway–alveolar interface cells – presence of SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1, SCGB3A2, MUC1, WFDC2, CXCL17, AGR2/AGR3. • Injury / inflammatory activation – induction of SLPI, LCN2, SAA1/2, HLA-DRA, IRF7, CXCL6, GDF15, DDIT4, TRIB3, indicating epithelial response to cytokine or pathogen exposure. • Epithelial bias reinforced by negative loading of mesenchymal genes VIM, COL6A2, RGS5, IGFBP7. Inconsistencies: • Low-level inclusion of macrophage or granulocyte-associated genes (MRC1, CSF3R) and dendritic marker LAMP3; likely reflect mild contamination or paracrine‐induced expression. • Goblet/upper-airway marker BPIFB1 and metabolic genes such as RBP4 are atypical for alveolar epithelium but can be up-regulated in stressed distal epithelial cells.

program_10.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, inflammatory/​interferon-responsive fibroblast program frequently observed in stromal or cancer-associated fibroblasts (so-called “iCAFs”). The program is enriched for secreted complement components, serpins, extracellular-matrix regulators and IFN-stimulated genes, while showing reduced expression of the oxidative-phosphorylation gene ATP5PO, fitting the glycolytic, cytokine-rich state of iCAFs. Evidence: • Fibroblast / stromal core – SERPINF1, EFEMP1, MFAP2, ISLR, CCN5, RARRES1, CD248, PROCR, VCAM1, PRG4, WT1: typical of tissue fibroblasts and activated stromal cells. • Secretory complement & serpin module – CFB, CFI, SERPING1, SERPINA3, TIMP1: hallmark of inflammatory CAFs that modulate complement and protease activity. • IFN / inflammatory response – IFITM1, IFITM2, IFITM3, LY6E, TNFSF13, MIF: indicates interferon-driven inflammatory activation seen in iCAFs. • Metabolic/oxidative shift – sole negatively loaded gene ATP5PO (mitochondrial ATP synthase) suggests down-regulated OXPHOS, matching the glycolytic bias of inflammatory fibroblasts. • ECM remodeling & secreted factors – CLEC3B, GPX3, SERPINF1, EFEMP1, MFAP2 support a matrix-modifying, pro-angiogenic fibroblast phenotype. Inconsistencies: • Neuronal-associated genes CALB2 and TUBB3 are atypical for fibroblasts, though they can appear in some mesenchymal cells undergoing stress or EMT. • GABARAP and GRINA are broadly expressed autophagy/vesicle genes and do not specifically point to fibroblasts but are not contradictory.

program_11.description: The program is most consistent with a quiescent, fibro-adipogenic stromal / adventitial fibroblast state that is rich in extracellular-matrix and IGF-binding proteins while lacking a contractile (myofibroblast) cytoskeletal signature. Evidence: • Fibroblast-secreted matrix proteins: MFAP5, FBLN2, CCDC80, CST3, GSN and SCARA5 are canonical fibroblast/adventitial fibroblast genes involved in micro-fibril assembly and matrix remodeling. • IGF axis typical of fibro-adipogenic stromal cells: IGFBP4 and IGFBP6 are hallmark IGF-binding proteins highly expressed by quiescent fibroblasts that modulate local growth-factor availability. • Adipogenic-stromal markers: CFD (adipsin) and MGST1 are enriched in fibro-adipogenic progenitors found in adipose tissue and skeletal muscle. • Low contractility: Negative loading of ACTN1, an actin cross-linking/contractile gene, supports a non-myofibroblast, quiescent stromal phenotype. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes strongly contradict a fibro-adipogenic stromal identity; SCARA5 and CFD can also be expressed in hepatocytes or adipocytes respectively, but both are documented in fibro-adipogenic stromal populations.

program_12.description: The gene set best matches an early pro-inflammatory activation program characteristic of monocytes/macrophages that have recently encountered innate immune stimuli (e.g., LPS/TNF). It reflects rapid, transcription-driven stress and cytokine responses rather than a lineage-defining signature. Evidence: • Classic immediate-early/stress regulators – ZFP36 (TTP) and DUSP1 dampen MAPK/NF-κB signalling after acute stimulation. • Canonical inflammatory macrophage TF – CEBPB mediates LPS/TNF-induced cytokine gene transcription. • Chemokine/cytokine output – CCL2 recruits additional monocytes; ADM (adrenomedullin) is secreted by activated macrophages and controls vascular tone during inflammation. • LPS-responsive genes – LITAF (LPS-induced TNF-α factor) and DEPP1 (oxidative-stress/autophagy regulator) are up-regulated in activated macrophages. • Matrix remodelling enzyme – MMP19 is produced by inflammatory macrophages to remodel extracellular matrix during tissue infiltration. Inconsistencies: • LMNA is a ubiquitous structural gene, not activation-specific. • SAT1 and MMP19 are also induced in stressed fibroblasts/epithelial cells, indicating the program could appear in other cell types under inflammatory stress.

program_13.description: Gene expression points to an activated, secretory fibroblast / myofibroblast state that synthesises extracellular-matrix proteins while autonomously producing and regulating complement components—an “inflammatory/complement-secreting” fibroblast phenotype reported in synovium, lung, skin and perivascular stroma. Evidence: • ECM & fibroblast identity – FBLN2 (fibulin-2), MATN2 (matrilin-2), MYOC (myocilin) and APOD are well-described products of stromal fibroblasts and myofibroblasts engaged in matrix assembly or remodelling. • Complement synthesis – C1R and C1S (classical pathway proteases) together with CFH (alternative pathway regulator) and CLU (clusterin, complement inhibitor/chaperone) mark fibroblast subsets that secrete complement proteins during tissue injury or inflammation. • Coordinated presence of both ECM and complement genes, and absence of lineage-specific markers for immune, epithelial, or hepatocyte cells, is characteristic of the “complement-producing” fibroblast state seen across multiple tissues. Inconsistencies: No clear contradictions; all listed genes align with a secretory, complement-producing fibroblast program.

program_14.description: The gene set most closely matches an acute-phase/hepatocyte transcriptional program, i.e. mature liver epithelial cells that are responding to inflammatory cues. Evidence: • Core liver/acute-phase products – HP (Haptoglobin) and CFB (Complement factor B) are canonical secretory proteins made predominantly by hepatocytes during an inflammatory response. • Hepatocyte xenobiotic-metabolising enzyme – AADAC is highly enriched in hepatocytes and hepatocyte‐derived cell lines. • Epithelial junction component – CLDN1 is expressed in hepatocytes and bile-duct epithelium, consistent with liver epithelial identity. • Co-expressed stress/injury response genes – TFPI2 (tissue factor pathway inhibitor 2) is induced in inflamed or fibrotic liver tissue, supporting an activated state rather than a quiescent hepatocyte. Inconsistencies: • WT1 (classically mesothelial/podocyte) and DMKN (skin/airway epithelium) are not typical of mature hepatocytes; their presence could reflect a small progenitor/mesothelial contaminant or injury-associated dedifferentiation. • TFPI2 is more typical of stromal or endothelial cells than hepatocytes, again suggesting some cross-lineage activation.

program_15.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, extracellular-matrix–remodelling fibroblast program (e.g., wound/dermal fibroblasts or inflammatory cancer-associated fibroblasts) that simultaneously secretes chemokines to recruit immune cells. Evidence: • ECM/remodelling genes – DPT, ASPN, LTBP2 and F13A1 are canonical products of activated dermal or stromal fibroblasts and are up-regulated during fibrosis, wound repair and cancer-associated fibroblast activation. • Chemokine/immune-recruiting genes – CXCL14 and CCL11 are well-described fibroblast-derived chemokines that attract monocytes, dendritic cells and eosinophils, fitting an “inflammatory” fibroblast state. • Stromal surface/adhesion marker – TSPAN8 is reported on mesenchymal stromal cells and certain activated fibroblast subsets, supporting a fibroblast identity. Inconsistencies: • TSPAN8 is also found on some epithelial and cancer cells, and F13A1 can be expressed by macrophages, but their co-occurrence with the strong fibroblast ECM/chemokine signature argues they still fit within a fibroblast program rather than indicating a different cell type.

program_16.description: The program represents an extracellular-matrix–remodeling, “activated” fibroblast / myofibroblast state such as those seen in wound healing, tissue fibrosis, and many cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs). Evidence: • Structural collagens COL1A1, COL1A2, COL3A1 and COL6A3 are hallmark transcripts of fibroblasts undergoing matrix deposition and scar formation. • FAP encodes Fibroblast Activation Protein, a membrane serine protease specifically up-regulated in activated fibroblasts and CAFs. • CTHRC1 is induced in profibrotic/myofibroblast cells and promotes collagen matrix remodeling. • MMP11 (Stromelysin-3) is a matrix-degrading enzyme enriched in activated fibroblasts within remodeling or tumor stroma. Inconsistencies: No negatively loaded or discordant genes are present, so the gene set is uniformly consistent with an activated fibroblast program.

program_17.description: The gene set points to a SERPINF1⁺/IGFBP4⁺ secretory–antioxidant fibroblast program, i.e. a stromal fibroblast state involved in extracellular-matrix regulation and oxidative-stress defense that is typical of remodeling or fibrotic tissue and is distinct from perivascular (AOC3⁺) fibroblasts/pericytes. Evidence: • IGFBP4 and SERPINF1 are well-established markers of interstitial/remodeling fibroblasts across lung, skin and adipose tissue. • S100A10 (plasminogen activation) and MGST1 (glutathione-dependent detoxification) are up-regulated in activated fibroblasts coping with matrix turnover and oxidative stress. • FTL (ferritin light chain) is induced in fibroblasts under iron/oxidative load, complementing the antioxidant theme. • AOC3, a surface amine oxidase enriched in pericytes and vascular fibroblasts, is negatively loaded, supporting a non-perivascular fibroblast identity. Inconsistencies: • FTL and S100A10 can also be expressed by macrophages; however, the absence of core myeloid genes (e.g., LYZ, CD68, CSF1R) makes a dominant macrophage program unlikely.

program_18.description: The program most closely matches a contractile vascular smooth muscle / pericyte state, characterized by actomyosin contractility, response to vaso-active peptides and secretion of extracellular-matrix components. Evidence: • Contractility genes – MYLK (myosin light-chain kinase) and PDLIM3 (actin/Z-disk–associated protein) are core markers of contractile smooth-muscle and pericyte phenotypes. • Vasoactive receptor machinery – RAMP1 forms the CGRP receptor complex that modulates vascular tone in smooth-muscle and pericytes. • Oxidative stress and energy support – SOD3 (extracellular superoxide dismutase) and CKB (creatine kinase B) are enriched in vascular wall cells to buffer reactive oxygen species and supply ATP for contraction. • Basement-membrane component – COL4A5 is synthesized by mural cells and deposited in the vascular basement membrane, fitting a perivascular identity. Inconsistencies: • CKB is also abundant in neurons and other energy-demanding cells, and COL4A5 is expressed in some epithelial lineages, so their presence is not exclusively vascular.

program_19.description: The program represents an activated fibroblast / myofibroblast state (e.g., wound-healing or cancer-associated fibroblast) characterized by intensive deposition and remodeling of interstitial extracellular matrix. Evidence: • COL1A1, COL1A2, COL3A1 – major fibrillar collagens synthesized almost exclusively by fibroblasts undergoing matrix production. • COL6A1, COL6A3 – collagen VI chains enriched in stromal fibroblasts and myofibroblasts, supporting tissue remodeling. • MMP11 (stromelysin-3) – matrix metalloproteinase secreted by activated fibroblasts in fibrotic and tumor stroma, coordinating collagen turnover. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are congruent with an activated fibroblast ECM program.

program_20.description: The gene module most closely matches an immune-activated fibroblastic reticular cell (FRC) / lymphoid-stromal program typical of T-cell-zone stromal cells in lymph nodes and other secondary lymphoid tissues, which attract and sustain lymphocytes through CCL19, VCAM1–mediated adhesion, and BAFF (TNFSF13B) secretion. Evidence: • CCL19 – canonical chemokine of T-zone FRCs that recruits CCR7+ naïve/central-memory T cells and dendritic cells. • VCAM1 – adhesion molecule up-regulated on lymphoid stromal and endothelial cells during immune activation, facilitating lymphocyte retention; commonly co-expressed with CCL19 in FRCs. • TNFSF13B (BAFF) – survival factor for B cells produced by lymph-node stromal cells, especially FRCs, during inflammatory signaling. • RBP5 – retinol-binding protein enriched in mesenchymal/stromal lineages that regulate retinoid metabolism, consistent with the mesenchymal origin of FRCs. • ADRA2A – α2-adrenergic receptor detected in several mesenchymal stromal populations and implicated in neuro-immune regulation of lymph-node stromal cells. Inconsistencies: • Classical FRC markers such as PDPN, COL1A1/2, and CCL21 are not present in the limited gene list, and VCAM1 can also be expressed by activated endothelial cells, leaving a minor ambiguity between stromal and endothelial activation states.

program_21.description: The gene set is most consistent with a neuro-inflammatory, “A1”-type reactive astrocyte program—an astrocyte state induced by microglia-derived factors and characterized by secretion of complement regulators, acute-phase serine protease inhibitors, and lipocalins. Evidence: • SERPING1 – canonical A1 astrocyte marker; complement C1 inhibitor strongly up-regulated in neurotoxic reactive astrocytes in mouse and human brains. • SERPINA3 – acute-phase serpin highly induced in inflammatory, STAT3-dependent reactive astrocytes and in Alzheimer’s disease astrocyte clusters. • APOD – lipocalin secreted by reactive astrocytes; elevated in multiple neuro-degenerative conditions. • RNASE4 – included in the original Liddelow et al. A1 astrocyte signature; enriched in neuroinflammatory astrocyte subsets in single-cell datasets. • PRELP – extracellular matrix/lectican-binding protein up-regulated in scar-forming and inflammatory astrocytes after CNS injury. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; all listed genes have documented induction in reactive astrocytes, though PRELP is also produced by fibroblasts in other tissues.

program_22.description: The gene set most closely matches a TGF-β–responsive, cytoskeleton/adhesion-remodeling program in tissue-resident or infiltrating monocytes/macrophages. Evidence: • ARHGDIB (RhoGDI2) – leukocyte-restricted factor that modulates Rho GTPases during macrophage chemotaxis and phagocytosis. • TGFB1I1 (HIC-5) – classic TGF-β–inducible LIM protein that localizes to focal adhesions in activated macrophages and supports integrin-mediated adhesion. • CRIP2 – LIM-domain co-activator cooperating with SRF in actin and smooth-muscle–like gene expression; up-regulated in macrophages during cytoskeletal rearrangement. • HACD4 – enzyme in very-long-chain fatty-acid elongation, supplying membrane lipids needed for active membrane remodeling in phagocytes. • NNMT negatively loaded – enzyme strongly expressed in stromal fibroblasts and some epithelial cells but low in myeloid cells, reinforcing an immune (rather than fibroblastic) identity. Inconsistencies: • CRIP2 is also found in vascular smooth-muscle and endothelial cells, and HACD4 shows broad expression, so their presence is not exclusively myeloid.

program_23.description: Gene-loadings point to a stromal fibroblast program characteristic of quiescent-to-moderately activated, immune-modulatory fibroblasts (e.g., “ps20/WFDC1-high” fibroblasts seen in lung, prostate and gut stroma) in which Notch signalling is engaged and the metabolically active NNMT-high CAF state is suppressed. Evidence: • WFDC1 (ps20) – a canonical, widely used marker of tissue fibroblasts and stromal cells, scarcely expressed in immune or epithelial lineages. • CRIP2 – LIM-domain factor enriched in mesenchymal cells (fibroblasts, smooth-muscle–like cells) and involved in SRF-dependent cytoskeletal/ECM gene regulation. • HES4 – Notch-responsive transcription factor up-regulated in stromal progenitors and fibroblasts during homeostatic or developmental signalling. • ARHGDIB – although classically described in leukocytes, it is detectable in cytokine-exposed fibroblasts and contributes to Rho-GTPase control of motility, fitting an immune-modulatory stromal phenotype. • NNMT (negative loading) – NNMT is a hallmark of metabolically reprogrammed, highly activated CAFs; its under-representation supports a more quiescent/physiologic fibroblast state rather than an NNMT-high CAF subtype. Inconsistencies: • ARHGDIB is most abundant in hematopoietic cells, so its strong positive loading is somewhat atypical for fibroblasts and could reflect either low-level immune contamination or a specialised fibroblast subset co-opting this gene.

program_24.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, podoplanin-positive inflammatory fibroblast (often termed iCAF or “inflammatory/stromal” fibroblast) that is producing complement and other acute-phase mediators in response to cytokine or hypoxic stress. Evidence: • PDPN – canonical surface marker of tissue fibroblasts, fibroblastic reticular cells and many cancer-associated fibroblasts. • PLA2G2A – highly induced in inflammatory intestinal and tumor-associated fibroblasts; encodes a secreted phospholipase involved in lipid mediator production. • CFB – complement factor B; produced by iCAFs and other stromal cells to amplify local complement activation during inflammation. • HP – haptoglobin; although classically hepatic, it is up-regulated in cytokine-stimulated fibroblasts and contributes to local acute-phase responses. • CA12 – hypoxia/HIF-regulated carbonic anhydrase expressed in stromal cells within low-oxygen, inflamed or tumor tissues, supporting extracellular pH control. Inconsistencies: • CA12 and HP are more frequently associated with epithelial or hepatic cells, respectively; their presence implies a strong stimulus (hypoxia or IL-6 family cytokines) rather than baseline fibroblast identity.

program_25.description: The gene set is characteristic of serosal mesothelial cells in a secretory/lubricating state. Evidence: • Classical mesothelial identity markers: MSLN (mesothelin) and UPK3B are highly and selectively expressed by pleural, pericardial and peritoneal mesothelium. • CALB2 (calretinin) is a routine immunohistochemical marker used to distinguish mesothelioma from carcinomas, reflecting strong endogenous expression in mesothelial cells. • ITLN1 encodes intelectin-1 (omentin), a secreted lectin abundantly produced by peritoneal and pleural mesothelium. • PRG4 (lubricin) is secreted by serosal and synovial surfaces to reduce friction, fitting the lubricating, secretory phenotype of activated mesothelial layers. Inconsistencies: • CALB2 is also expressed in certain neuronal subtypes, and PRG4 in synovial fibroblasts; however, the concurrent presence of multiple mesothelial-specific markers (MSLN, UPK3B, ITLN1) strongly supports a mesothelial cell identity over these alternative sources.

program_26.description: The gene set typifies fibroblastic reticular / lymphoid stromal cells in a homeostatic, immunoregulatory state that organizes T-cell zones in secondary lymphoid organs. Evidence: • CCL19 – canonical chemokine secreted by T-zone fibroblastic reticular cells (FRCs) to attract CCR7⁺ naïve T cells and dendritic cells. • CXCL12 – stromal-derived factor that guides lymphocyte and progenitor trafficking, enriched in lymph node and bone-marrow stromal subsets. • VCAM1 – adhesion molecule on FRCs that promotes lymphocyte and dendritic-cell retention within lymphoid tissue. • TMEM176A / TMEM176B – transmembrane proteins highly expressed by lymphoid stromal cells and tolerogenic antigen-presenting cells, linked to regulation of local immune activation. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; no negatively loaded genes were supplied.

program_27.description: The gene set is most consistent with an epithelial, hepatocyte-like program, likely reflecting hepatocytes (or hepatocyte-derived tumor / regenerating hepatocyte states) that preserve tight-junction features and show heightened metabolic/acute-phase activity, with a hint of developmental or progenitor re-activation (WT1). Evidence: • Hepatocyte/acute-phase identity – HP (haptoglobin) is produced almost exclusively by liver hepatocytes and is a canonical acute-phase protein. • Hepatic tight junction/epithelial component – CLDN1 is a tight-junction claudin enriched in liver epithelium and up-regulated in hepatocytes and hepatocellular carcinoma. • High glycolytic–metabolic activity typical of regenerating or malignant hepatocytes – HK2 is a glycolytic enzyme frequently elevated in proliferative hepatocytes and hepatocellular carcinoma. • Developmental/progenitor facet – WT1 is re-expressed in hepatic progenitors and in regenerating or malignant hepatocytes, consistent with a non-quiescent hepatocyte state. • General endomembrane-trafficking support – SNX10 is broadly expressed and participates in vesicle sorting; such genes often accompany metabolically active secretory cells like hepatocytes. Inconsistencies: • WT1 is not found in fully mature, quiescent hepatocytes; its presence implies a progenitor, regenerative, or neoplastic context rather than normal adult liver parenchyma. • SNX10 lacks liver specificity and is broadly expressed, so it contributes limited discriminatory power for a hepatocyte program.

program_28.description: The program most closely matches a tissue-resident, perivascular/mesenchymal fibroblast state that secretes multiple WNT modulators (RSPO3, SFRP1) and shows a stress-responsive, metal-handling signature (FTL, MT1G) typical of stromal fibroblasts engaged in vascular niche support. Evidence: • RSPO3 – hallmark secreted enhancer of WNT signalling produced by perivascular fibroblasts, vascular leptomeningeal cells and intestinal telocyte-like stromal cells that support neighbouring stem or endothelial cells. • SFRP1 – secreted WNT antagonist co-expressed with RSPO3 in many stromal fibroblast subsets, reinforcing a WNT-modulating secretome. • RARRES1 – classical fibroblast/tissue-stromal marker enriched in adventitial and cancer-associated fibroblasts, rarely expressed in endothelial or immune cells. • FTL and MT1G – ferritin light chain and metallothionein gene up-regulation reflects iron/metal handling and oxidative-stress buffering frequently observed in activated fibroblasts within vascular niches. Inconsistencies: No major contradictions; RSPO3 can also be found in endothelial tip cells, but concurrent high RARRES1 and SFRP1 favour a fibroblast rather than endothelial identity.

program_29.description: The program represents a broad “type I interferon-stimulated” transcriptional state—an antiviral response that can be induced in many immune and non-immune cell types upon exposure to IFN-α/β (and, to a lesser extent, IFN-λ). Evidence: • ISG15, IFIT3, IFI6, IFI44L, MX1 – classical interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) rapidly up-regulated after type I IFN signaling and widely used as markers of viral sensing/antiviral defense. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes coherently fit an interferon response program, and no negatively loaded genes contradict this state.

program_0.description: The gene set represents a generic, highly proliferative cell-cycle program marking cells that are in late S phase through G2/M and actively undergoing mitosis, independent of a specific lineage. Evidence: • Core G2/M regulators: CCNB1, CCNB2, CDK activators CDC20 and CDCA3, mitotic kinases PLK1, AURKA, TTK, NEK2, MELK. • Kinetochore/centromere assembly: CENPA, CENPE, CENPF, CENPN, NDC80 complex (NDC80, SPC24, SPC25), KNL1, BUB1/BUB1B, SGO1/2. • Spindle and cytokinesis factors: KIF11, KIF23, KIF20A/B, KIF4A, KIF2C, ANLN, CEP55, RACGAP1, PRC1, GAS2L3, INCENP. • DNA replication / S-phase machinery: MCM2-7, PCNA, RFC2/3/4, CDC45, GINS1/2/4, ORC1/6, CDT1, GMNN, RRM1, DHFR, BRCA1/2, RAD51, FANCD2/FANCI/FANCA/B — hallmark of S-phase commitment. • Transcriptional drivers of proliferation: FOXM1, MYBL2, E2F1/2/7/8. • Histones & chromatin assembly: multiple H1, H2A.Z, H2AX variants, CHAF1A/B, HELLS, DNMT1, EZH2 reflecting DNA packaging after replication. • Negatively loaded immediate-early / quiescence-linked genes (JUN, SPRY1, MARCKSL1) underscore the shift away from stress-response or differentiation programs toward cell-cycle progression. Inconsistencies: • A few lineage-specific or signaling genes (NMU, IL17RB, APOLD1) are not classically tied to the cell cycle; likely passenger transcripts or sample-specific expression rather than drivers of the program.

program_1.description: The gene set represents a motile multiciliated epithelial-cell program characteristic of fully differentiated, FOXJ1-driven ciliated cells such as those lining the respiratory tract or oviduct.
