The program is dominated by transcripts encoding axonemal dynein arms, radial spoke and central apparatus components, intraflagellar-transport machinery and basal-body factors, while genes typical of squamous, secretory or basal states are simultaneously repressed. Evidence: • Motile ciliary structural genes – outer/inner dynein arms (DNAH5, DNAH11, DNAH9, DNAI1/2/4, DNALI1, DNAAF1/3/4/11), radial spoke/central pair proteins (RSPH1/4A/9, CFAP43/44/54/65, HYDIN, NME5), tektins (TEKT1/2). • Ciliogenesis regulators – transcription factors FOXJ1 and RFX3; kinases NEK5, NEK10, STK33; basal-body proteins CEP126, CCP110, LRRC46, BBOF1. • Intraflagellar transport/transition-zone genes – IFT25, IFT57, DYNC2I1, TMEM67, TMEM231, NPHP1, ARL3. • Additional airway/oviduct ciliated-cell markers – PIERCE1, AGR3, CDHR3, PROM1, CAPSL. • Negative loading of non-ciliated or basal/squamous genes (KRT13, FGFBP1, FTL, PIWIL1) supports a shift away from alternative epithelial or progenitor states. Inconsistencies: • Goblet/secretory marker MUC5AC and mucin-related PRR4. • BEST4 (intestinal epithelium), COL1A1 (mesenchyme), HBB/HBA (erythroid), and immune genes (CD3D, CD74, HLA-B/DRB5) likely reflect minor contamination or ambient RNA rather than the core program.

program_2.description: The gene set describes a differentiated mucin-secreting (goblet/secretory) epithelial program typical of large-airway (and other mucosal) epithelium undergoing goblet-cell differentiation and heightened secretory output, accompanied by an unfolded-protein-response signature; basal-cell (KRT5⁺) features are specifically down-regulated. Evidence: • Goblet/secretory lineage markers – MUC5AC, MUC5B, MUC1, MUC16, MUC13, CEACAM5, CEACAM6, FCGBP, TFF1, TFF3, BPIFA1/BPIFB1/BPIFB2, SCGB3A1/SCGB2A1, SPDEF (master TF for goblet differentiation), CLDN3/22, TSPAN8. • Secretory-pathway/ER stress components needed for high mucin synthesis – XBP1, ERN2 (IRE1β), SSR4, FKBP11, SDF2L1, MANF, CREB3L1. • Metabolic and glycosylation genes supporting mucin production – FUT3, FUT6, B3GNT3/6, GALNT6, ST3GAL4, GMDS. • Goblet-cell-associated cytokines/defense factors – CXCL6, IL6, IDO1, DUOX2, BPIFA2, DEFB4A. • Basal-cell genes are negatively loaded – KRT5, S100A2 and the basal-cell-enriched regulator RGS16, indicating suppression of the basal state in favor of a luminal secretory identity. Inconsistencies: • A few multiciliated lineage/axonemal genes (CCNO, CDC20B, DNAAF4, CFAP65) and endothelial/immune transcripts (KDR, SLAMF7, HLA-DQA1) appear, suggesting either minor contamination or co-expression during airway remodeling.

program_3.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated fibroblast / myofibroblast program typical of wound-healing or cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) and, when detected in epithelial cells, corresponds to an epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT). The program features strong expression of cytoskeletal contractile genes, abundant extracellular-matrix and matrix-remodelling factors, inflammatory and complement components, and a reciprocal repression of epithelial markers. Evidence: • Mesenchymal cytoskeleton / myofibroblast: ACTA2, TAGLN, MYL9, MYH11, TPM1/2, CALD1, MYLK – classic α-SMA-positive contractile fibroblast signature. • Core fibroblast / ECM genes: DCN, COL1A2, COL6A1/2, FN1, SPARC, FBLN1/2/5, AEBP1, LTBP1, PCOLCE, MFAP4 – abundant collagen, fibulin and matricellular proteins. • Matrix remodelling and inhibition: MMP2, TIMP1/2/3, SERPINE1, ADAMTS1/9, THBS1 – hallmarks of tissue-remodelling fibroblasts and CAFs. • Inflammatory & secretory factors: IL6, CCL2, CSF1, CXCL14, CXCL3, GAS6, ICAM1, LGALS1 – “secretory” activated fibroblast phenotype. • Complement / innate immunity: SERPING1, C1R, C1S, C1QA/B, CFD, CFI – fibroblasts are major non-hepatic sources of complement components. • EMT/mesenchymal markers: VIM, SFRP1/2, DKK3, FOXC1, SOX9, RARRES2 together with repression of epithelial genes below. • Negative loading of epithelial genes: KRT19, TACSTD2 (EpCAM/Trop-2), AQP3, ALDH3A1, PERP, CD9 – matches loss of epithelial identity in EMT or absence of these genes in fibroblasts. Inconsistencies: • Endothelial-associated genes (CLDN5, EGFL7, ACKR1, PLXDC1, RAMP2) and pericyte markers (CAV1, ENG) are present, suggesting some vascular stromal contamination or transcriptional overlap with perivascular fibroblasts. • A few immune cell genes (TREM2, FCER1G, CD68) appear, but are low-level and can be produced by inflammatory fibroblasts.

program_4.description: The gene set describes a mature, non-basal secretory epithelial program characteristic of airway “club/goblet‐like” cells that are rich in mucin production, glycosyl- and xenobiotic-metabolising enzymes and display an active endoplasmic reticulum stress/secretory response, while basal-cell markers are repressed. Evidence: • Secretory/goblet machinery – MUC16, LGALS3, CEACAM5, CEACAM6, CLDN3, CLDN4, SLC44A4, FUT2/3/6, B3GNT3/7, B4GALT5, QSOX1, ERN2 and CREB3L1 mark high mucin synthesis, glycosylation and ER-stress typical of mucus-secreting airway epithelium. • Xenobiotic metabolism typical of club cells – CYP2F1, CYP2B6, CYP2C18, CYP3A5, FMO5, GSTP1, GSTA1 and HMOX1 are classical detoxification genes induced in human club (Clara) cells. • General luminal/secretory epithelial markers – KRT8, KRT23, EPCAM-associated partners (NECTIN4, TACSTD2 family: MSLN, PSCA), TMPRSS2, LGALS3, ANXA1, PLAC8 and GDF15; absence of basal keratins. • Secretory vesicle/trafficking genes – RAB11FIP1, SYTL2, BICDL2, GABRP, MDK support active secretion. • Negative loadings for basal markers – BCAM, KRT15 and the stromal gene MGP confirm repression of basal-cell / mesenchymal identity. Inconsistencies: • UPK1B and PSCA are best known in urothelial/gastric epithelium, and SCEL/SPRR1B/2A/3 are more typical of squamous differentiation; their presence may reflect low-level expression or a broader stress-induced epithelial programme rather than pure airway lineage.

program_5.description: The gene set is characteristic of cells that have just received a strong growth-factor/MAPK stimulus—classically seen in wounded or growth-factor-exposed basal epithelial/keratinocyte-like cells—triggering an “immediate early” AP-1/EGR response program that promotes survival, motility and extracellular-matrix remodeling while dampening oxidative phosphorylation genes. Evidence: • Immediate–early transcription factors driven by MAPK/EGF signalling (JUN, JUNB, FOS, FOSB, ATF3, EGR1/2/3, IER2/3, NR4A1) are strongly positively loaded. • Feedback regulators of MAPK/RTK pathways (DUSP2/6, SPRY1, ERRFI1, SOCS1/3, TRIB1) and cell-cycle/survival effectors (CDKN1A, MCL1, BIRC3, BTG1/2) match a rapid activation and cytoprotective state. • Wound-response / activated basal-epithelial genes (KRT17, LAMC2, DST, TAGLN, TM4SF1, CCN1, CCN2, MMP10, CTSV, IGFBP5, ANGPTL4) support an epithelial origin undergoing repair and matrix reshaping. • Stress-induced metabolic shift is reflected by positive TXNIP and repression (negative load) of oxidative-phosphorylation components COX7C and NDUFV2. • Down-regulation of NF-κB inflammatory targets (TNFAIP3, CXCL8, CCL20, DUSP1) in the negatively loaded list is consistent with an early growth-factor–dominated response rather than a full inflammatory program. Inconsistencies: • Scattered lymphocyte markers (CD3D, CD52, PTPRC, CCL5) and macrophage-associated MAFB/HCAR3 could indicate minor immune-cell contamination or co-expression not typical for epithelial cells. • The presence of smooth-muscle/fibroblast gene TAGLN and pericyte marker TM4SF1 suggests that the program may also be activated in other mesenchymal wound-responsive cells, not exclusively keratinocytes.

program_6.description: The program matches an epithelial “wound-response / partial EMT” state—seen in injured or inflamed epithelia (e.g., airway, gut, skin) that have transiently activated stress, YAP/TAZ and TGF-β signalling, extracellular-matrix remodelling and survival pathways while down-shifting mitochondrial respiration. Evidence: • Epithelial identity with basal/repair bias – KRT17, LAMC2, DST, EMP1, TM4SF1, EPCAM-independent cytokeratins (ACTB/ACTG1) • Partial EMT / matrix remodelling – MMP10, MMP13, PLAUR, SERPINE1, TAGLN, THBS1, ICAM1, ANXA1/2, CTSV, SERPINB5 • Injury / immediate-early response TFs – FOSB, EGR2, EGR3, ETS2, IER3, NR4A3, TRIB1, KLF6, PER2, LBH, MAFF • YAP/TAZ- and growth-factor-driven repair signals – WWTR1 (TAZ), AREG, HBEGF, EDN1, TNFRSF12A, EPHA2, PTGS2, CCND1 • Pro-survival / stress adaptation – MCL1, BIRC3, CDKN1A, SGK1, BTG1, STK17A, ANKRD37 (hypoxia) • Negative loading of oxidative-phosphorylation genes (COX7C, NDUFV2) supports the glycolytic shift typical of stressed/repairing epithelia. Inconsistencies: • S100A10 is negatively loaded although it is often up-regulated during EMT. • Absence of classic mesenchymal collagens (e.g., COL1A1) indicates the transition is partial rather than full EMT.

program_7.description: The program is most consistent with a differentiated airway secretory (club/goblet) epithelial cell state characterized by high xenobiotic-metabolizing capacity and mucin/ion-secreting functions, while lacking basal-cell and interferon response features. Evidence: • Club/secretory cell hallmark genes – SCGB1A1, PLAC8, ALDH1A1, CYP2F1, CYP2B6, CYP2A13, CYP4B1, SULT2B1, FMO3/5, UGT2A1 and GSTA1 reflect the classic detoxification profile of airway club cells. • Secretory/goblet products and surface molecules – MUC16, MUC15, MUC20, TSPAN8, ALCAM, LGALS3, MDK, CFTR and ATP12A support a mucus-rich, ion-transporting epithelium. • Luminal keratins – strong KRT8, KRT19 and KRT4 with simultaneous negative loading of basal keratin KRT15 indicate suprabasal differentiation. • Additional epithelial/secretory regulators – ELF5, EPAS1, CCNO, KLF6, INSIG1 and SERPINB family members are all reported in mature airway secretory populations. • Negative loading of IFITM3 suggests absence of an interferon-stimulated antiviral program, compatible with a homeostatic rather than inflamed state. Inconsistencies: • Sporadic genes such as TNNT3, MB and CA8 are not typical of airway epithelium and may represent ambient RNA or rare co-expression. • CCNO is more linked to deuterosomal/ciliated precursors but can transiently appear in secretory–ciliated transitional cells. • Vacuolar ATPase subunits (ATP6V0A4, ATP6V1B1) are better known in renal intercalated cells yet are occasionally expressed in airway secretory cells involved in pH regulation.

program_8.description: The program most closely matches an inflammation-primed alveolar type II (AT2) epithelial cell state that has up-regulated secretory, mucin/antimicrobial and antigen-presentation pathways—an “immune-activated AT2” phenotype described in injured or fibrotic lung. Evidence: • Core AT2 / surfactant machinery – SFTPC, SFTPB, SFTA2, NAPSA, SLC34A2, BBOX1 indicate a type II alveolar lineage. • Secretory and ER stress genes – XBP1, SSR4, KDELR3, ERP27, CTSC, TCN1 support high protein-secretion capacity typical of activated AT2 cells. • Mucin / secretoglobin genes – MUC5B, MUC1, SCGB3A1, SCGB3A2, FCGBP, ZG16B mark a mucus-rich secretory shift reported in AT2 cells after injury. • Antimicrobial/innate-defence factors – BPIFB1, BPIFA1, DEFB1, LTF, RNASE1/4, SAA1/2/4, PI3, AZGP1, CXCL6, CCL28 reflect a barrier-defence response. • Antigen-presentation and cytokine genes – HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DQA1, CD74, IL6, EPSTI1 corroborate interferon-γ/NF-κB driven immune activation of epithelium. • Negative loadings of ADH7, ALDH3A1, EPAS1 and CCND1 show suppression of detoxification, hypoxia-response and proliferation programs, consistent with a non-proliferative, stress-responding AT2 state. Inconsistencies: • Goblet/club cell markers (MUC5B, BPIFB1, SCGB3A1) are classically proximal-airway and are uncommon in steady-state AT2 cells, suggesting either mixed secretory phenotypes or sampling of distal airway epithelium. • KDR (VEGFR2) and PROM1 are not canonical AT2 markers and may reflect minor endothelial/progenitor contamination or signal sharing.

program_9.description: The gene set reflects a broad oxidative-phosphorylation (OXPHOS) / oxidative-stress program that emerges when cells boost mitochondrial respiration and mount an acute stress response, a state commonly seen in metabolically active, stressed epithelial or tumor cells. Evidence: • Mitochondrial electron-transport chain and ATP-synthase subunits up-regulated (NDUFA1/7/13, NDUFV2, UQCR11/Q, COX6A1/6B1/6C/7A2/7B/7C, ATP5F1E, ATP5MF, ATP5ME, ATP5MK, MICOS10, TOMM7) → hallmark of heightened OXPHOS. • Mitochondrial translation/assembly components (MRPL33, FMC1, SLIRP) and general translation factors (EEF1G, EEF2, H3-5) → support increased mitochondrial protein synthesis. • Oxidative-/heat-stress and antioxidant genes (GPX2, OSGIN1, MT1X, S100A6, HSPA1B, HSPB1, ZFP36, BHLHE40, SIK1, RHOB) → indicate an acute stress response coupled to reactive-oxygen species handling. • Metabolic/ER stress markers (TMEM258, ACOT1/2, ALDH3A1, PLSCR3) and pro-survival factor DIABLO further fit a stress-adapted, high-metabolism state. • Negative loading of Ca²⁺/calcineurin signalling components (CALM1, PPP3CA) and APOE suggests a shift away from canonical Ca²⁺ signalling and lipid transport typical of unstressed cells. Inconsistencies: • Germ-cell–related genes (HORMAD1, SYCE1L) and lens protein CRYBB2 are atypical for a generic oxidative-stress program and may reflect tumour-specific ectopic expression. • CES1 and APOE (down-regulated) are classically hepatocyte/macrophage genes rather than epithelial stress markers.

program_10.description: The gene set is most consistent with a KRT8⁺/KRT19⁺ transitional alveolar-airway epithelial cell state that emerges after epithelial injury and lies between mature secretory/AT2 cells and terminally differentiated AT1 cells. These “damage-associated transitional progenitors” (also called KRT8⁺ alveolar progenitors or CLDN4⁺ transitional cells) show strong epithelial identity, tight-junction reinforcement, Notch signalling, stress-response and xenobiotic-metabolism modules, while lacking the interferon/inflammatory program. Evidence: • Transitional‐alveolar markers – CLDN4, KRT8, KRT19, UPK1B, LGALS3, GDF15, HSPB1, ANXA1: core signature reported for KRT8⁺/CLDN4⁺ alveolar progenitors in mouse and human lungs after injury. • Notch / progenitor signalling – HES1, HES4, NOTCH3, BHLHE40, ELF3/ELF5: characteristic of undifferentiated epithelial intermediates. • Epithelial junction/adhesion genes – NECTIN4, TJP3, CLDN4, GSN, SPON2: reinforce tight and adherens junctions seen in regenerating epithelium. • Xenobiotic- and oxidative-stress enzymes – GSTP1, MGST1, CYP2C18, CYP3A5, CYP4B1, CYP4F3, SULT2B1, ABCG2, DEGS2: detoxification profile typical of airway/alveolar epithelium exposed to environmental insults. • Secretory/goblet‐associated or mucin genes – MUC16, GABRP, MDK: often co-expressed in regenerating airway/alveolar epithelium. • Negative loadings (IFITM1, IFITM3, IL1R2, MMP10, PHLDA1) indicate repression of interferon and inflammatory programs, fitting a non-immune, epithelial repair state. Inconsistencies: • ZNF750, CALML3, CALML5 – more typical of stratified squamous/epidermal differentiation. • UPK1B is classically urothelial, though it is also reported in alveolar transitional cells. • GABRP is enriched in airway secretory cells, suggesting some overlap with proximal airway programs.

program_11.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated/wound-responsive basal epithelial (keratinocyte or airway basal) cell state that is mounting an alarmin-rich inflammatory program and initiating extracellular-matrix remodelling. Evidence: • Basal epithelial identity – KRT15, KRT17, COL17A1, LAMB3, BCAM, PDPN, SPINK5 and hemidesmosome component DST mark basal keratinocytes and airway basal cells. • Loss of differentiated-luminal signature – negative loading of KRT8, CLDN4, LGALS3, CLCA4, UPK1B and GSTP1 indicates repression of mature luminal/secretory epithelial genes. • Wound / stress activation – strong AP-1 components (JUN, JUNB, FOSB), immediate-early regulators (EGR2, TSC22D1, ZFP36L2), and interferon-induced IFITM1. • Alarmin and type-2 skewing cytokines – IL33, TSLP, IL1R2, CH25H are typical of epithelial “sentinel” cells that alert immune cells after damage. • ECM remodelling & partial EMT – CCN1, CCN2 (CTGF), TGFBI, SERPINF1, MMP10, THSD4, EFEMP1, SPINK5, DKK3 and PDPN support matrix deposition and tissue repair. • Notch/Delta components DLL1, DLK2 and down-regulated NOTCH3 fit dynamic Notch signalling seen during basal-cell activation. Inconsistencies: • TREM2 (usually myeloid), NTRK2 (neuronal receptor) and GPC3/GGT1 (liver/kidney associated) are atypical but can appear at low levels in stressed epithelia. • Several fibroblast-enriched genes (SERPINE2, THSD4) are present, implying some epithelial–mesenchymal transition but slightly blur the pure basal-epithelial profile.

program_12.description: The gene set represents a strongly activated, “classical/M1-like” inflammatory monocyte-macrophage state characterized by acute-phase, chemokine, and antigen-presentation signatures while showing concurrent loss of epithelial transcripts. Evidence: • Inflammatory myeloid core: S100A8, S100A9, SAA1, SAA2, CXCL8, CXCL1/2/3/5, CCL2, CCL20, CSF3, PTGS2 and IL6 are prototypical products of activated inflammatory monocytes/neutrophils/macrophages. • Antigen presentation & interferon response: HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, ICAM1, CXCL10, IFITM2/3 support IFN-γ–induced, MHC-II–high macrophage activation. • Matrix-remodeling/immune effector genes typical of M1 macrophages: TIMP1, PLAU, NAMPT, LDHA, SOD2, CTSB, CHI3L1/2. • Metabolic-stress and glycolytic shift consistent with M1 polarization: LDHA, NAMPT, SOD2, MT2A. • Negative load of epithelial genes (KRT19, PRSS23, NTS, ADH1C, UGT2A1) indicates these transcripts drop as the inflammatory myeloid program dominates, distinguishing it from an epithelial identity. Inconsistencies: • BATF3 (classically linked to cross-presenting dendritic cells) and SERPINB4/DEFB1 (often epithelial) are present but can be up-regulated in inflamed myeloid cells; their inclusion is minor relative to the predominant macrophage signature.

program_13.description: The gene set captures a pro-inflammatory, antigen-presenting classical monocyte / macrophage state (sometimes referred to as “MHC-II-high inflammatory monocytes”), characterized by strong expression of class II HLA molecules, canonical myeloid signaling adaptors, complement components and multiple cytokines/chemokines indicative of an activated phenotype. Evidence: • Antigen presentation – very high loadings of MHC-II genes (HLA-DRA, ‑DRB1, ‑DPA1, ‑DPB1, ‑DQA1, ‑DQB1, HLA-DMA/B) together with CD74 partners (CTSS) mark professional antigen-presenting myeloid cells. • Core myeloid identity – TYROBP, FCER1G, LST1, ARHGDIB, AIF1, C1QA/B/C, CTSS, COTL1, SRGN, LAPTM5, GMFG, CD14 and FCGR2A are enriched in monocytes/macrophages. • Inflammatory activation – IL1B, PTGS2 (COX-2), BCL2A1, CCL3, CCL4, CCL5, PLAUR, ALOX5AP, LRRK2, CALHM6 and C15orf48 (ACOD1) are up-regulated upon NF-κB / TLR stimulation in classical monocytes. • Chemokine receptor pattern – CXCR4 and RGS1/RGS10 are typical of circulating inflammatory monocytes that traffic to tissues. • Phagolysosomal / complement genes – CST3, NPC2, FTL, C1QA/B/C support a phagocytic macrophage profile. Inconsistencies: • Low-level T-cell transcripts (CD3D, CD7) and endothelial/erythroid-associated ACKR1, as well as PRR4 (tear protein) are atypical for monocytes and may reflect ambient RNA or doublets rather than the core program.

program_14.description: The program is most consistent with a “reactive / transitional alveolar type II (AT2) epithelial cell” state—AT2 cells that have up-regulated stress- and injury-response genes and begun acquiring early alveolar type I (AT1) features during AT2→AT1 differentiation. Evidence: • Core AT2 identity – strong enrichment of canonical surfactant and AT2-restricted genes (SFTPA1, SFTPA2, SFTPB, SFTPC, SFTPD, NAPSA, LPCAT1, SLC34A2, ADGRF5/GPR116, FOLR1, NKX2-1, CYP4B1). • Early AT1 acquisition – HOPX, CAV1, CAV2, AQP4, CYB5A, ICAM1 are typical of AT1 cells or AT2→AT1 intermediates, indicating transition. • Injury / reactive signature – inflammatory and acute-phase genes IL6, SAA1, SOCS2, ICAM1, TFPI, CLU plus stress/ECM genes VIM, TAGLN2, MYL9, TNNC1, MGP and ANXA3 match previously described “damage-associated transitional progenitors” (DATPs/PATS). • Negative loadings (PRSS23, S100A2, AQP3) are characteristic of airway/basal epithelium and are appropriately suppressed, supporting a distal-alveolar, not airway, identity. Inconsistencies: • A few vascular/mesenchymal-leaning genes (MGP, PMP22) are present; these are commonly up-regulated in transitional AT2 cells but could also reflect minor endothelial contamination. • Absence of some hallmark transitional markers such as KRT8 or KRT17, though transitional programs vary across datasets.

program_15.description: The gene set best fits an epithelium-derived “acute inflammatory/IL-17–TNF response” program, characteristic of barrier epithelial (skin or airway) cells that have been strongly activated by microbial or cytokine stimuli, as seen in psoriatic‐like keratinocytes or infected airway epithelium. Evidence: • Antimicrobial/alarmin genes typical of activated barrier epithelium – S100A8, S100A9, S100A12, DEFB4A, SERPINB4, SPRR2A. • Neutrophil- and T-cell-recruiting chemokines and cytokines – CXCL5, CXCL6, CXCL11, CCL20, CSF3, IL36G, IL32, TNFAIP2. • Acute-phase/innate immunity genes frequently induced in inflamed epithelium – SAA1, SAA2, SAA4, SERPINA1, CFB, PLAU, MMP7, LOX, PLAT. • Epithelial barrier/secretory components – CLDN10, DUOXA2, BPIFB4, KLK10, CHI3L1, CHI3L2, PDZK1IP1, STC1. • Tryptophan-catabolic enzymes up-regulated by inflammatory cytokines (IDO1, KYNU) reinforcing an IFN/IL-17 signature. • ER-stress and oxidative-stress chaperones seen in highly stimulated epithelium – HSPA5, CALR, SOD2. Inconsistencies: • A few myeloid-biased transcripts (LYN, CYBA, SLC39A8) could reflect minor immune contamination or paracrine signalling rather than epithelial origin.

program_16.description: The gene set best matches a differentiated airway secretory epithelial (goblet/club or inflamed alveolar type II–like) program that is actively mounting an innate-immune response rather than cycling. Cells bearing this program express multiple airway-specific secreted proteins and mucins together with ER-stress/secretory and antimicrobial genes, while genes linked to proliferation and immediate-early activation are repressed. Evidence: • Airway secretory identity – BPIFA1 (SPLUNC1), BPIFB1 (LPLUNC1), MUC1, SLC34A2, DUOX2, MMP7, ANXA3 and CA2 are characteristic of bronchiolar/alveolar type II epithelium and goblet/club cells. • High secretory/ER load – XBP1, SCD, STARD4, TMSB10/TMSB4X and CITED4 support a metabolically active secretory state. • Innate-immune/inflammatory response – PI3 (elafin), SERPINB1, CXCL6, CFB, LGALS3, ISG20, IL32, IDO1, SAT1, SOCS2, TNIP3, TGM2 and DUOX2 indicate interferon, complement and antimicrobial activation typical of inflamed airway epithelium. • Stress-adaptation genes – S100A6, S100A9, CSTB, MT1G, DEPP1, RARRES1 mark oxidative and cytokine stress. • Quiescent/non-cycling status – proliferation and immediate-early regulators (CCND1, JUN, CCN1, CCN2, BTG2, ZFP36L1/L2, TSC22D1) are negatively loaded, consistent with differentiated rather than dividing cells. Inconsistencies: • Myeloid markers CD68, S100A9 and IDO1 could reflect low-level macrophage gene contamination or doublets. • Squamous-associated SPRR2A/SPRR3 and keratin-related SPINK5 (negatively loaded) suggest some overlap with epithelial keratinization programs. • CA2 and MMP7 are more typical of alveolar type I/II cells, indicating the program may span multiple airway epithelial subtypes rather than a single, pure lineage.

program_17.description: The gene set most strongly matches an alveolar epithelial type I (AT1)–like program, reflecting squamous lung epithelial cells that are flattening, forming tight junctions and caveolae, and experiencing cytoskeletal/ECM remodelling often seen during AT2→AT1 differentiation or mechanical stretch. Evidence: • Canonical AT1 markers: AGER (RAGE), CAV1, CAVIN1, EMP2, HOPX, CLIC5, PMP22, APOD – all highly enriched in mature AT1 cells. • Additional alveolar-epithelial/secretory genes that rise early during AT2→AT1 conversion: SFTPD, LPCAT1, FOLR1, ANGPTL4, APOE. • Genes for cell-contact, barrier formation and caveolae: ICAM1, CGN, SCEL, S100A10, ANXA3, CAV1/-IN1, TSPAN13. • Cytoskeletal and ECM-remodelling genes typical of the stretched, thin AT1 morphology: MYL9, TNNC1, LIMCH1, FHL1, PDLIM3, FBLN5, COL4A2, RGCC. • Stress and lipid-handling genes frequently up-regulated in differentiating or mechanically loaded AT1 cells: DDIT3, RRAD, IL32, APOE, APOD, ANGPTL4. • Negative loading of STARD5 (a lipid-transfer protein up-regulated in ER-stressed or secretory AT2 cells) is consistent with the shift away from a fully secretory AT2 state. Inconsistencies: • Presence of some muscle/neuronal genes (HPCAL1, DPYSL2, DAGLB, TNNC1, FHL1) not typical of AT1 cells. • UPK3B (mesothelial marker) and ADGRE2 (myeloid) are out of place. • Retention of several AT2-biased genes (LPCAT1, SFTPD, FOLR1) suggests the program may represent an intermediate rather than fully mature AT1 identity.

program_18.description: The gene set reflects an activated/wound-response squamous epithelial (keratinocyte) state characterized by robust inflammatory signaling and extracellular-matrix remodeling, typical of epidermal or other stratified epithelia undergoing stress, repair, or early malignant transformation. Evidence: • Squamous structural/activation markers – KRT6A, KRT6B, KRT13, KRT24, SPRR1B, SPRR2A and DSG/DSC family genes are hallmarks of suprabasal or hyperproliferative keratinocytes seen in wound edge epidermis and inflamed squamous mucosa. • Keratinocyte-derived inflammatory mediators – IL36G, IL1RN, S100A8, S100A9, S100A12, TNC, FGFBP1 and PLAUR are strongly up-regulated in injured or psoriatic epidermis and drive neutrophil recruitment and matrix remodeling. • Matrix-remodeling/EMT genes – MMP1, CEMIP, TNC, ECM1, DKK1, FST and SERPINE2 support a repair-like program that loosens epithelial adhesion and remodels collagen. • Stress-response/proliferation genes – AQP3, AKR1B10, TXNDC17, DUSP7, CREB5 and SLC7A5 are induced in metabolically active, proliferating keratinocytes. • Negative loading of airway secretory marker SCGB1A1 and hepatocyte marker SERPINA1 argues against respiratory or hepatic identity, supporting a keratinocyte-specific program. Inconsistencies: • Myeloid-associated receptors/ligands (TREM2, LTB4R) and strong calgranulin expression can also arise from infiltrating neutrophils/monocytes; their presence may indicate contaminating immune transcripts or paracrine signaling rather than pure epithelial origin. • GAL (neuropeptide) and HLA-DRB5 (MHC-II) are not typical of keratinocytes but can be induced under inflammatory conditions.

program_19.description: The gene set denotes an inflammatory, complement-secreting, matrix-remodeling fibroblast program (often termed “inflammatory/immune CAF” or wound-activated fibroblast). These fibroblasts up-regulate extracellular-matrix genes, hyaluronan metabolism, complement components and a broad innate-immune response, while epithelial/neuroendocrine markers are concomitantly repressed. Evidence: • Fibroblast / matrix remodeling: COL6A2, COL17A1, LOXL1, ADAMTS1, MMP1, MMP10, TGM1, HAS3, CEMIP, SERPINE2, SERPINF1, MGP, PDPN, ICAM1 – classical fibroblast and ECM-modifying genes. • Hyaluronan-rich inflammatory CAF signature: HAS3 + CEMIP (hyaluronan synthesis & degradation), CCL2, PTGES, IL1R2, LTB4R/LTB4R2, CHI3L1 – matches published iCAF profiles. • Complement production: C1R, C1S, SERPING1 – hallmark of immune-active fibroblasts in wounds and tumours. • Innate-immune / interferon response: IFITM1/2/3, STING1, S100A8, S100A9, PLA2G2A, BPIFB4, MIF – supports an antiviral / inflammatory fibroblast state. • Antigen presentation capacity: HLA-DPA1, HLA-DOA. • Down-regulation of epithelial / neuroendocrine genes: negative loading of KRT19, NTS, ANXA1 further separates this program from epithelial cells. Inconsistencies: • S100A8/A9 and HP are classically myeloid‐enriched and may reflect gene sharing or minor myeloid contamination. • Strong interferon-stimulated genes (IFITM1-3, STING1) are not universal to all fibroblasts and suggest an added antiviral stress response layered onto the fibroblast program.

program_20.description: The program represents differentiated stratified squamous epithelial cells—such as suprabasal airway, oral or esophageal epithelium—engaged in barrier maturation and oxidative-/inflammatory-stress responses. Evidence: • Squamous differentiation genes: ZNF750 (master regulator), KRT4, KRT13, KRT16, KRT24, SPRR1B/2A/2D/3, SCEL, CLCA2/4 – hallmark of late/suprabasal layers of stratified epithelia. • Epithelial junction/barrier components: CLDN4, AQP3, LY6D, CALML3, ECM1 support an intact tight-junction–rich epithelium. • Detoxification/oxidative-stress enzymes typical of barrier surfaces exposed to xenobiotics: GSTP1, GPX2, AKR1C2/3, AKR1B10, ALDH3A1, ALDH3B2, ACOT1. • Innate-immune/alarmin repertoire seen in mucosal squamous layers: DEFB1, CXCL14, IL1RN, RAET1L, GPR15LG, SERPINB4/B1, APOBEC3A. • Additional epithelial or keratinocyte markers: CLCA2, RHOV, CYBA, CTSC, ANO1, PLAT corroborate an activated barrier epithelium. Inconsistencies: • UPK1B and UPK3BL1 are urothelial-enriched; their presence may reflect low-level urothelial or pan-stratified-epithelial expression. • KRT8 is typical of simple rather than stratified epithelium but can be retained in some basal/suprabasal airway cells. • Generic stress genes (HSPB1, TMSB10) and myeloid-associated CYBA are not specific but fit an oxidative-stress milieu.

program_21.description: The gene set is most consistent with antigen-presenting myeloid cells (classical monocytes / tissue macrophages or dendritic cells) that have been exposed to an interferon-rich, inflammatory milieu, resulting in robust up-regulation of MHC class II machinery and other immune-activation genes. Evidence: • Professional antigen presentation: very strong enrichment for MHC-II genes (HLA-DRA, DRB1, DPA1, DPB1, DQA1/2, DQB1, DMA, DMB, DOA, DRB5) together with the invariant chain CD74 and β2-microglobulin (B2M). • Myeloid identity: CD14, LST1, C1QC, AIF1, CYBA, MS4A6A, ACKR1 and TMEM176B are characteristic of monocytes, macrophages and some dendritic-cell subsets. • Inflammatory / IFN response: LY6E, IFI27, UBD, EPSTI1, SAA1/2 and CFB are classical interferon- or acute-phase–induced genes frequently seen in activated myeloid cells. • Additional antigen-handling / phagocyte markers: C1QC, CYBA and TMEM176B support a phagocytic, antigen-processing role. Inconsistencies: • Epithelial or secretory-cell genes (BPIFA1, MUC4, MMP7, LTF, DMBT1, CCL26) and the B-cell marker CD79A are atypical for myeloid cells and may reflect ambient RNA contamination, low-level co-expression in inflamed tissue, or a minor mixed cell population within the same program.

program_22.description: The gene set describes activated, wound-healing / inflammatory basal-type squamous epithelial (keratinocyte) cells that are proliferating and remodeling their surrounding matrix. Evidence: • Basal-layer keratinocyte identity – KRT5, KRT14, COL17A1, S100A2 are canonical markers of stratified epithelium basal cells. • Wound or “stress” activation of squamous epithelium – induction of KRT6A and KRT13, both strongly up-regulated in repairing epidermis and early squamous carcinogenesis. • Matrix remodeling / invasion program – MMP1, ADAMTS1, TIMP1, COL4A1, COL6A2, PLA2G2A and CA2 support basement-membrane breakdown and extracellular-matrix turnover typical of wound repair. • Inflammatory signaling – PTGS2 (COX-2), CCL2, CHI3L1, ANGPTL2, SOCS2, DKK1 and FST reflect cytokine/chemokine release and modulation of WNT/TGF-β pathways during tissue repair. • Proliferation & glycolytic shift – CCNA1, LDHA, ENO1, TUBA1C, TUBB6, MT2A indicate cell-cycle entry and metabolic adaptation of regenerating keratinocytes. • Negative loadings (ADH1C, ID3, IER2) mark differentiated/metabolic or quiescent states that are suppressed in an activated basal population. Inconsistencies: • S100A9 and FYB1 are myeloid/hematopoietic, suggesting minor immune contamination. • CLDN11 is classically oligodendrocyte-associated, and HP (haptoglobin) is hepatic; their presence is atypical for keratinocytes and may reflect paracrine uptake or low-level ectopic expression.

program_23.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with injured lung alveolar epithelial cells that have entered the KRT8-high “damage-associated transitional progenitor” (DATP/PATS) state observed after infection or toxic injury. These epithelial cells up-regulate junctional/keratin genes and a p53-, interferon- and wound-healing program while down-regulating the basal-cell keratin KRT15. Evidence: • Epithelial identity: KRT8, KRT18, KRT19, KRT6A, CLDN4, OCLN, TACSTD2 (EpCAM), TM4SF1, CD9, ANXA1/2 – canonical cytokeratins and tight-junction/adhesion genes of simple epithelia. • Transitional injury state markers described in mouse and human lung DATP/PATS cells: high KRT8, CLDN4, TACSTD2, SFN, RHOV, IGFBP3, TM4SF1, PLAUR, GADD45A. • Inflammatory / interferon response: ISG20, OASL, APOBEC3A, CXCL8, CLCF1, SERPINB1/B2/B5/B9, PLAU – typical of epithelial cells exposed to viral or cytokine stimuli. • Wound-healing and stress/P53 signalling: GADD45A, DUSP5, PHLDA2, PRDM1, KLF6, PIM1, TACC2. • Negative loading of basal-cell marker KRT15 supports loss of basal identity and transition into the KRT8-high reparative state. Inconsistencies: • PRDM1 and TPPP are not commonly highlighted in lung DATP signatures, though they have been reported in some stressed epithelia. • CHST6 and ATP6V0A4 are more characteristic of corneal and renal epithelia, respectively, but can be ectopically induced during generalized epithelial stress.

program_24.description: The program most closely matches an interferon-activated effector / memory T-cell state—often referred to as CCR5⁺ Th1/Tc1 or tissue-resident–like memory T cells—characterised by strong chemokine production (CCL3/4/5), immunoproteasome induction and expression of canonical T-cell signalling components. Evidence: • T-cell identity: CD3D, CD7, PTPRC, CD52, CORO1A, EVL, TMSB4X confirm a lymphoid (T-cell) lineage. • Effector / memory bias: RUNX3 and HOPX (memory/TRM lineage factors), HCST (DAP10), SRGN, TYMP and ICAM1 are typical of activated cytotoxic or Th1-skewed T cells. • Th1/Tc1 chemokine secretion: strong positive loading of CCL3, CCL4 and CCL5 together with IL32 and CXCR4 denotes a CCR5-associated, pro-inflammatory effector program that recruits additional immune cells. • IFN-γ / antigen-presentation response: EPSTI1, PSMB9, PSME2, HLA-DPB1 and HLA-E are classical interferon-stimulated or immunoproteasome genes up-regulated during antigen-experienced T-cell activation. • Metabolic/remodelling support: SLC2A3 (GLUT3) for high glucose uptake and RGS1/16, SELENOK, CREM adjust signalling thresholds during sustained activation. Inconsistencies: • A small subset of myeloid or tissue genes (APOC1, SERPINA1, SFTPD, ANXA3, GGT1, MT1M) are atypical for T cells and may reflect ambient RNA or doublets with macrophage/alveolar epithelial cells rather than true expression in this program.

program_25.description: The gene set most consistently reflects a Type I/II interferon-driven “antigen-presentation/antiviral” activation program that can be super-imposed on many cell types rather than defining a specific lineage. Evidence: • Interferon-stimulated genes: IFI27, LY6E, SAT1, LGALS3 – classical ISGs induced by IFN-α/β or IFN-γ. • Antigen-presentation machinery: strong up-regulation of MHC class I genes (HLA-A, HLA-C, HLA-E, B2M) plus class II component HLA-DPA1, fitting an interferon-γ response that boosts both classes. • Immune activation markers: CD48 and GIMAP7 (T-cell/NK activation), LGALS3 (macrophage/DC activation), DHRS9 (tolerogenic/activated DC), CD63 (lysosomal trafficking needed for peptide loading). • Global repression of housekeeping/translation genes (negative loadings: EEF1A1, EEF1B2, HNRNPA1, NACA, TPT1, FTL) is typical of an interferon response that switches cells from protein synthesis to defense functions. Inconsistencies: • Endothelial-biased genes (CLDN5, ADTRP) and developmental genes (SIX3, DLX5, STATH) point to contributions from multiple lineages, underscoring that the program is a state, not a pure cell-identity signature.

program_26.description: The gene constellation most closely reflects a generic, growth-factor/MAPK–driven “immediate-early activation” program that can be super-imposed on many stromal or immune cells rather than a lineage-defining signature. Key signalling (MAP2K2, PLCG2, GNAS), AP-1 transcriptional (JUND), chemokine/angiogenic (ACKR3, VEGFB) and chromatin-remodelling (multiple replication-dependent histones) genes together indicate cells that have recently sensed VEGF/CXCL12 or similar cues and are mounting a rapid transcriptional, vesicle-trafficking and proliferative response. Evidence: • MAPK / AP-1 axis – JUND, MAP2K2, PLCG2, GNAS and IER5L are classical immediate-early genes induced minutes after receptor tyrosine-kinase or GPCR stimulation. • Chemokine / angiogenic stimulation – VEGFB and the atypical chemokine receptor ACKR3 (CXCR7) are up-regulated during CXCL12- or VEGF-mediated cell activation. • Early cell-cycle entry / chromatin remodelling – induction of replication-dependent histones (H2AC12, H2AC20, H4C5, H1-4) together with trafficking factors CDV3, RAB11FIP3, RAB12 suggests cells preparing for S-phase. • Stress-responsive growth modulators – TPT1, CITED4, PPP1R14B, TMEM158 and ZFPM1 are commonly elevated in cells undergoing rapid growth or recovery from stress. • Mesenchymal bias but not lineage-specific – TFs FOXD1 and MEIS3, and tetraspanin CD81, are enriched in fibroblast-like stromal cells that often produce or respond to angiogenic factors. Inconsistencies: • PLCG2 and CD81 are also abundant in B-lineage cells, yet hallmark B-cell genes (CD79A/B, MS4A1, PAX5) are absent, arguing against a B-cell program. • Core endothelial markers (PECAM1, VWF, KDR/FLT1) are missing, so the signature is unlikely to represent a dedicated endothelial state despite its pro-angiogenic elements.

program_27.description: The gene set represents a robust type I/II interferon-stimulated gene (ISG) program, indicative of cells that are acutely responding to viral infection or other interferon-inducing stimuli; it is a state that can be super-imposed on many immune and non-immune cell types rather than defining a specific lineage. Evidence: • Canonical ISGs: ISG15, IFI27, IFI6, IFI44L, MX1/2, OAS1, IFIT1/2/3, RSAD2, BST2, GBP1/4 and CXCL10 are classic targets of type I IFN signaling and mediate antiviral defense. • JAK–STAT pathway activation: STAT1 and PARP14 (STAT co-regulator) are central transducers of interferon signaling. • Antigen presentation components: PSMB9 and B2M are up-regulated by IFN-γ, enhancing MHC class I processing. • Immune-modulatory enzymes/cytokines: IDO1 (tryptophan catabolism) and TNFSF13B/BAFF (B-cell survival factor) are inducible by interferons and TLR signaling, fitting an inflammatory milieu. • Additional interferon-responsive or co-regulated genes: EPSTI1, XAF1, PLAAT4, CMPK2, WARS1, STXBP3 all rise after IFN exposure in multiple cell types. Inconsistencies: No strong contradictions; the few less-characterized genes (e.g. TP73, CABCOCO1) can also be interferon-inducible in published datasets, so they do not conflict with an interferon response interpretation.

program_28.description: The gene set reflects an interferon-γ–activated antigen-presenting cell program, typical of inflammatory dendritic cells or classically (M1-like) activated macrophages, characterized by heightened MHC class II assembly, immunoproteasome formation, and secretion of CXCR3-binding chemokines that recruit effector T cells. Evidence: • MHC class II antigen presentation: HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DQA1, HLA-DMA and the invariant chain CD74 are hallmarks of professional APCs. • IFN-γ–induced immunoproteasome components: PSMB8, PSMB9 and PSME2 optimize peptide processing for MHC class I/II during inflammatory activation. • Broad interferon-stimulated gene signature: IFI27, LY6E, ISG15, EPSTI1 and PLAAT4 are canonical ISGs up-regulated after IFN-γ/IFN-α exposure. • T-cell-recruiting chemokines: CXCL9 and CXCL11 are classic IFN-γ–responsive chemokines secreted by activated APCs. • Immune-regulatory/enzyme mediators: IDO1 (tryptophan catabolism) and TNFSF10/TRAIL (pro-apoptotic ligand) are strongly induced in IFN-γ–stimulated dendritic cells/macrophages. • Presence of HLA-A further supports a general up-regulation of antigen-presentation machinery. Inconsistencies: • FXYD3 is more commonly associated with epithelial cells and some cancers rather than myeloid APCs. • PLAAT4 is less specifically linked to myeloid cells, though it is interferon-responsive, which partly mitigates the discrepancy.

program_29.description: The program reflects a stress-activated, highly proliferative basal/-wound keratinocyte (epithelial) state characterized by strong chaperone expression, elevated translational machinery and MYC-driven growth, with concurrent repression of a germ-cell–specific kinase. Evidence: • Epithelial/keratinocyte identity – KRT17 (basal, hyper-proliferative and wound-induced keratin). • Proliferative drive – MYC, TRIB1, TUBB4B, EIF1, GTF2B support increased transcription, translation and cytoskeletal remodeling typical of dividing keratinocytes. • Cell-stress/UPR signature – HSPA5 (BiP/GRP78), HSP90B1 (GRP94), HSP90AA1/AB1, HSPA8, HSPD1, DNAJA1 indicate robust heat-shock and unfolded-protein-response activity often triggered during epithelial injury or rapid growth. • Membrane/exosome remodeling seen in activated keratinocytes – CD9. • Negative loading of STK31, a germ-cell–restricted kinase, underscores that this program is not related to germline differentiation but to somatic epithelial cells. Inconsistencies: • No major inconsistencies; the gene set lacks some classic basal keratins (e.g., KRT5/14), but KRT17 plus the chaperone-rich, MYC-high profile is sufficient to support a stress-proliferative keratinocyte state.

program_30.description: The program represents an epithelial “acute-phase / injury-response” state characterized by robust secretion of antimicrobial, complement and matrix-remodeling proteins that are typically induced in intestinal, respiratory or other mucosal epithelia after inflammatory or wounding stimuli. Evidence: • Acute-phase markers – SAA1, SAA2, CFB and CLU are classical acute-phase reactants transcriptionally up-regulated in epithelial cells exposed to IL-1/IL-6, TNF or microbial products. • Injury-associated matrix remodeling – MMP7 is a hallmark of wound-repair epithelium in gut and lung and co-occurs with SAA1/2 in “injury-responsive” colonocytes. • Antimicrobial secretory products – LTF (lactoferrin) and CHI3L2 encode secreted antimicrobial/lectin-like proteins frequently induced in inflamed mucosa. • Retinoic-acid / differentiation response – RARRES1 is a retinoic-acid–responsive epithelial gene whose expression rises during regeneration and epithelial stress. • Additional secreted stress proteins – MIA and CLU further support a generalized secretory stress program. Inconsistencies: • MIA and CHI3L2 are better known for expression in chondrocytes/cartilage; their presence suggests either broader stress-induced expression or minor mesenchymal contamination, but they do not contradict an overall acute-phase secretory profile.

program_31.description: The gene set is most consistent with pulmonary alveolar epithelial type II (AT2) cells that retain their canonical surfactant-secreting program while beginning transition toward an AT1 fate, i.e. an AT2-to-AT1 intermediate involved in alveolar repair. Evidence: • Surfactant machinery of AT2 cells – SFTPB and SFTPC (core surfactant proteins), CYB5A (lipid desaturation for surfactant), and FOLR1 (well-described AT2 marker). • Protease‐inhibitory/secretory profile typical of AT2 cells – SERPINA1. • Transitional/early AT1 signature – HOPX, an early AT1 transcription factor that rises as AT2 cells differentiate. • Additional epithelial secretory gene – RNASE1, reported in alveolar epithelial populations and up-regulated during epithelial stress or remodeling. Inconsistencies: • RNASE1 is also enriched in vascular endothelial cells, and its presence could reflect minor endothelial contamination rather than pure AT2 origin. • No strong AT1 markers such as AGER or PDPN are present, so the AT1-transition inference relies mainly on HOPX and remains provisional.

program_32.description: The gene set is most consistent with a generalized growth-factor/insulin–WNT signalling program operating in metabolically active, structurally plastic cells rather than a lineage-restricted signature. High expression of INSR and downstream phosphatase PPP1CB points to insulin/IGF pathway engagement, while CTNNB1 and CDC42SE1 support concurrent WNT–β-catenin signalling and actin-cytoskeleton remodelling. House-keeping genes involved in RNA processing (HNRNPH1) and protein glycosylation/secretory traffic (B4GALT1, C1orf56) round out a profile typical of cells preparing for, or actively undergoing, growth and environmental response rather than a quiescent state. Evidence: • INSR + PPP1CB – key receptor and effector in insulin/IGF signalling; PPP1CB regulates glycogen synthase and other insulin-responsive targets. • CTNNB1 – central WNT/β-catenin component; cooperates with growth-factor pathways to drive proliferation and epithelial remodelling. • CDC42SE1 – effector of CDC42 controlling actin dynamics, cell polarity and motility, processes frequently activated downstream of growth-factor cues. • B4GALT1 & C1orf56 – enzymes linked to N-glycosylation and secretory pathway expansion, common in cells with elevated anabolic demand. • HNRNPH1 – splicing factor up-regulated in cells with high transcriptional throughput. Inconsistencies: • Absence of lineage-defining markers (e.g., ALB for hepatocytes, ADIPOQ for adipocytes, EPCAM for epithelial cells) makes precise cell-type attribution uncertain. • Lack of classical proliferation genes (MKI67, PCNA) suggests the program reflects signalling readiness rather than full cell-cycle entry.

program_33.description: The program reflects professional antigen-presenting myeloid cells—macrophages / dendritic cells—displaying a high MHC class II, activated state. Evidence: • HLA-DRA, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1 and CD74 encode the core MHC-II antigen-presentation machinery that is selectively up-regulated in professional APCs. • AIF1 (Iba1) is a hallmark of activated macrophages and microglia, supporting a myeloid rather than B-cell identity. • CST3 (cystatin C) is highly expressed in monocytes, macrophages and microglia, further anchoring the program in the myeloid lineage. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes were provided; no clear contradictions detected.

program_34.description: The gene combination is most compatible with a lipid-handling, metabolically active macrophage (or microglia‐like) state that is mounting a xenobiotic/oxidative-stress response while sustaining high biosynthetic and protein-folding activity. Evidence: • APOC1 – classical marker of lipid-rich tissue macrophages, microglia and foam cells, linked to cholesterol handling. • CYP1B1 – cytochrome P450 enzyme induced by xenobiotics and reactive oxygen species in macrophages and microglia. • RAB3IP – vesicle-trafficking GEF that facilitates exocytic/endocytic turnover during phagolysosomal lipid processing. • CCT2 (chaperonin) and CNOT2 (CCR4-NOT complex) – housekeeping components that rise with increased protein synthesis and turnover typical of activated macrophages. • MDM2 – p53 regulator up-regulated in proliferating or stress-exposed immune cells, consistent with an activated/stressed macrophage program. Inconsistencies: • The set lacks canonical myeloid surface genes (e.g., CD68, CSF1R, ITGAM) and lipid-laden macrophage markers such as APOE or LPL, so the assignment rests on a limited, mostly metabolic signature rather than a full macrophage transcriptome.

program_35.description: The gene set is most consistent with a bronchiolar club (Clara) cell–like secretory epithelial program, marked by high SCGB1A1 and supporting genes involved in vesicle trafficking and luminal acidification, reflecting an active secretory state. Evidence: • SCGB1A1 (CC10/CCSP) – canonical, high-level marker of airway club cells. • TMEM213 – repeatedly co-expressed with SCGB1A1 in single-cell atlases of human and mouse airways, used to demarcate club/secretory epithelial clusters. • ATP6V1B1 – V-ATPase subunit enriched in secretory epithelia (airway and kidney), supporting vesicle acidification required for protein secretion. • RIMS1 and PPP1R9A (neurabin-1) – regulators of vesicle docking/exocytosis and actin remodeling; although classically neuronal, both appear in secretory epithelial cells in scRNA-seq datasets, fitting an active secretory program. • FYB2 – adaptor implicated in cytoskeletal signaling and vesicle dynamics, aligning with a secretory phenotype. Inconsistencies: • RIMS1 and PPP1R9A are best known for neuronal expression, and FYB2 is more typical of hematopoietic cells; their presence could indicate low-level contamination or broader expression of vesicle-handling genes beyond classic club cells.

program_36.description: The gene loadings point to a mature, luminal/secretory epithelial program—typical of simple columnar or cuboidal epithelia such as airway club/secretory cells—accompanied by suppression of a basal-cell/wound-response signature. Evidence: • Positively loaded – CLDN4 encodes a tight-junction claudin enriched in differentiated luminal epithelia, including distal airway and other secretory ducts. – KRT8 is the hallmark intermediate filament of simple (non-stratified) epithelial cells and is absent from basal progenitors. – GSTP1 is highly expressed in detoxifying, xenobiotic-metabolising secretory epithelial cells (e.g., airway club cells, biliary epithelium). • Negatively loaded – KRT15 marks basal progenitor cells in stratified/airway epithelium; its down-loading indicates loss of a basal state. – BCAM (CD239) is enriched in basal and adhesion-remodeling states and falls as cells polarise apically. – MMP10 is induced during epithelial injury and extracellular-matrix remodeling; its suppression is consistent with a quiescent, differentiated surface epithelium. Inconsistencies: • No strong contradictions; the small gene set is internally consistent, though GSTP1 is not exclusive to airway epithelia and can be expressed in other detoxifying epithelia (e.g., liver, gastrointestinal tract).

program_37.description: The gene set points to an “acute inflammatory-stress activation” program frequently seen in recently stimulated immune cells (e.g., macrophages or T lymphocytes) characterized by rapid induction of immediate-early transcription factors, mRNA-destabilizing proteins, enhanced autophagy, and a shift toward higher metabolic/translation activity. Evidence: • BHLHE40 – immediate-early transcription factor induced by TCR, TLR and hypoxia signals; required for IFN-γ production in Th1 cells and for IL-1/TLR-driven macrophage activation. • ZFP36 – RNA-binding protein rapidly induced by TNF/LPS; regulates inflammatory cytokine mRNA decay in activated macrophages and T cells. • GABARAP – core autophagy protein whose expression rises during immune-cell activation and stress, supporting vesicle trafficking and cytokine secretion. • NDUFA13 & EEF1G – subunits of mitochondrial complex I and the translation elongation complex, respectively; their coordinated up-regulation reflects the metabolic and biosynthetic boost that accompanies immune activation. • Overall co-expression of immediate-early (BHLHE40, ZFP36) plus metabolic/translation (NDUFA13, EEF1G) and autophagy (GABARAP) genes is a well-described hallmark of early inflammatory or stress responses in myeloid and lymphoid cells. Inconsistencies: • NBEAL1 is better studied in neural/glial contexts and lipid vesicle biology; its role in classic immune activation is less established, making it a potential outlier in this program.

program_38.description: This program most closely reflects basal epithelial (KRT5⁺) cells in S-phase, i.e., a proliferative basal-cell state characterized by high expression of replication-dependent histone genes. Evidence: • Cell-type marker – KRT5 is a canonical keratin of basal cells in stratified epithelia (skin, airway, prostate, mammary, etc.). • S-phase/proliferation signature – Coordinated up-regulation of replication-dependent histone genes (H1-3, H1-4, H2AC11, H2AC20) is a well-established hallmark of cells actively synthesizing DNA. • The combination of a basal epithelial structural marker (KRT5) with an S-phase histone burst supports a “proliferating basal epithelial cell” state. Inconsistencies: • PLCG2 is predominantly expressed in hematopoietic lineages (B cells, myeloid cells, microglia) and is not typical of basal epithelia, suggesting either low-level contaminating signal or a rare basal subset that engages PLCG2-mediated signaling.

program_39.description: The program most closely matches an alternatively-activated, tissue-remodeling (M2-like) macrophage/TAM state, characterised by strong oxidative-stress control and secretion of extracellular-matrix-modifying and acute-phase proteins typical of wound healing and tumour microenvironments. Evidence: • CHI3L1 (YKL-40) – hallmark secreted glycoprotein of M2 macrophages and tumour-associated macrophages that promotes fibrosis and angiogenesis. • HP (Haptoglobin) – acute-phase protein induced by IL-6/STAT3 in activated monocytes–macrophages, scavenges haemoglobin during tissue injury. • SOD2 – mitochondrial ROS-detoxifying enzyme up-regulated in phagocytically active or cytokine-stimulated macrophages. • MMP1 and ADAMTS1 – macrophage-secreted collagenase and ADAMTS protease that degrade/remodel extracellular matrix during repair and tumour invasion; both are enriched in M2/TAM transcriptional signatures. • Combination of oxidative-stress gene (SOD2), acute-phase reactant (HP) and multiple ECM proteases (MMP1, ADAMTS1, CHI3L1) typifies a wound-healing/remodelling macrophage program rather than a classical (M1) inflammatory state. Inconsistencies: • Absence of core myeloid markers (e.g., CD68, LYZ) means the program could, in principle, also arise in activated fibroblasts that share MMP1/ADAMTS1 expression. • No canonical M2 cytokines (IL10, MRC1) are present, so the call relies on ECM- and stress-related genes rather than lineage-defining markers.

program_40.description: The gene set is most consistent with a motile, multiciliated airway (respiratory) epithelial cell program, reflecting both ciliogenesis and the characteristic xenobiotic-detoxification capacity of mature airway epithelium. Evidence: • Motile cilia core: FOXJ1 (master transcription factor for motile ciliogenesis) and CFAP157 (axonemal component) are hallmark markers of multiciliated epithelial cells in the trachea and bronchi. • Airway-specific secretory/ciliated marker: AGR3 is enriched in airway epithelial cells, particularly ciliated and goblet subsets. • Detoxification enzymes typical of airway epithelium: GSTA2 (glutathione S-transferase) and ALDH3B1 (aldehyde dehydrogenase) support a respiratory epithelial identity that encounters and neutralizes inhaled xenobiotics. Inconsistencies: • None notable—while GSTA2 and ALDH3B1 are also expressed in liver and other tissues, their co-expression with FOXJ1-driven ciliogenesis genes in the same program is commonly observed in airway epithelial cells and does not conflict with the assigned state.

program_41.description: The gene set best fits a striated-muscle program, marking skeletal/cardiac myocytes that are mobilising glycogen and remodelling their cytoskeleton under the control of β-catenin signalling. Evidence: • PHKG1 – muscle-specific catalytic subunit of phosphorylase kinase; activates glycogen phosphorylase during contraction, a hallmark of skeletal and cardiac myocytes. • CTNNB1 (β-catenin) – key effector of Wnt signalling and component of adherens junctions; required for myogenic and cardiomyocyte differentiation/proliferation. • CDC42SE1 – effector of the Rho-GTPase CDC42; promotes actin re-organisation and filopodia formation during myoblast fusion and muscle fibre remodelling. • B4GALT1 – Golgi β-1,4-galactosyltransferase; contributes to glycosylation of membrane proteins such as dystroglycan in muscle and is expressed in striated-muscle tissues. • C1orf56/LRRC75A – limited data, but GTEx and other atlases report appreciable expression in skeletal muscle, aligning with the above muscle-biased genes. Inconsistencies: • CTNNB1 and B4GALT1 are not muscle-restricted and are expressed in many cell types, so their presence alone is not definitive for muscle identity.

program_42.description: The program represents a ubiquitous “core translational/house-keeping” state characterized by elevated protein synthesis and mRNA processing rather than a lineage-restricted cell identity. Evidence: • EEF1A1 and EEF2 – canonical elongation factors required for ribosomal translocation and tRNA delivery, hallmarks of cells with high translational output. • RACK1 – 40S ribosomal scaffold that enhances translation initiation and integrates signaling to the ribosome. • BTF3 – general transcription factor that also stabilizes nascent polypeptides, supporting global protein production. • HNRNPA1 – abundant RNA-binding protein driving pre-mRNA splicing and mRNA export, coordinating with increased translation demand. Inconsistencies: No prominent lineage-specific or contradictory markers are present; the gene set uniformly supports a generic high-translation program.

program_43.description: The gene set represents an NF-κB–driven acute inflammatory activation program, typical of innate immune cells such as monocytes/macrophages (e.g., after LPS or TNF stimulation) and occasionally adopted by other stromal cells exposed to strong pro-inflammatory cues. Evidence: • NF-κB pathway: NFKBIA (IκBα) is a canonical immediate-early NF-κB target that both signals and regulates pathway activation. • Acute-phase/innate transcription factor: CEBPD is rapidly induced during macrophage activation, enhancing expression of inflammatory mediators. • Cytokines/chemokines characteristic of activated monocytes/macrophages: IL6 (pleiotropic inflammatory cytokine), CCL2/MCP-1 (monocyte chemoattractant), and CXCL3/GRO-γ (neutrophil-recruiting chemokine) are classic NF-κB-responsive genes produced upon Toll-like receptor or TNF signaling. Inconsistencies: • No negatively loaded genes are provided, and all listed genes coherently fit an NF-κB–mediated inflammatory program; no clear inconsistencies detected.

program_44.description: The program represents a robust NF-κB–driven, pro-inflammatory “M1-like” activation state typical of monocytes/macrophages (and, more broadly, innate immune or stromal cells responding to acute inflammatory cues). Evidence: • CXCL2, CXCL3, CXCL8 (IL-8) – canonical neutrophil-recruiting chemokines transcriptionally induced in M1-polarized macrophages after LPS/TNF-α stimulation. • CCL2 (MCP-1) – hallmark chemokine released by activated monocytes/macrophages to attract additional CCR2⁺ monocytes. • IL6 – classic pro-inflammatory cytokine secreted by M1 macrophages downstream of NF-κB and STAT3 signaling; frequently co-expressed with the above chemokines during acute activation. Inconsistencies: • Program lacks lineage-defining macrophage markers (e.g., CD68, LYZ) and could also be elicited in inflamed fibroblasts or endothelial cells; thus cell-type attribution relies mainly on the inflammatory chemokine profile rather than definitive lineage genes.

program_45.description: The gene set most consistently fits a hypoxia-responsive, extracellular-matrix–producing fibroblast (i.e., an activated or cancer-associated fibroblast) program characterized by collagen synthesis and reactive-oxygen/oxidative stress signaling. Evidence: • COL1A1 – canonical marker of fibroblasts and fibrosis; high expression denotes active collagen deposition. • HILPDA – HIF-1 target induced in low O₂ and lipid-droplet accumulation, frequently up-regulated in hypoxic cancer-associated fibroblasts. • NCF2 – component of the NADPH-oxidase complex, linking inflammatory/ROS production pathways that are elevated in activated fibroblasts exposed to cytokines or hypoxia. • PTRH1, SEC11C – broadly expressed housekeeping genes that do not contradict a fibroblast identity but likely reflect general translational and secretory activity typical of ECM-secreting cells. Inconsistencies: • NCF2 is classically myeloid-restricted (neutrophils/monocytes); its presence could indicate a fibrocyte (monocyte-derived collagen-producing cell) or an inflammatory fibroblast subset rather than a “pure” fibroblast population.

program_46.description: The gene set represents a general “heat-shock” or proteotoxic-stress response state, characterized by induction of HSF1-dependent chaperones, rather than a lineage-specific cell identity. Evidence: • HSPA1A, HSPA1B, HSPA6 – Inducible HSP70 family chaperones classically up-regulated within minutes of heat shock; canonical HSF1 targets. • HSP90AA1 – Cytosolic HSP90 isoform co-induced with HSP70 to stabilize and refold denatured proteins under thermal or chemical stress. • DNAJB1 – HSP40 co-chaperone that partners with HSP70s during stress to prevent protein aggregation. • Mutual up-regulation of multiple HSP70/HSP90/DNAJ genes and absence of lineage markers together typify a broad cytosolic heat-shock program observed across diverse cell types. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are core components of the conserved heat-shock response.

program_47.description: The gene set reflects an immediate-early, cytokine- and stress-responsive activation program commonly observed in immune cells (e.g., monocytes, macrophages, T cells) shortly after stimulation, rather than defining a stable lineage identity. Evidence: • JUNB and EGR1 – classic AP-1 and zinc-finger immediate-early transcription factors rapidly induced by mitogens, T-cell receptor signaling, and inflammatory cytokines. • GADD45B – NF-κB/STAT-inducible stress gene promoting MAPK signaling during acute immune activation. • SOCS3 – feedback inhibitor of JAK-STAT signaling up-regulated within minutes of IL-6, IFN-γ, or LPS exposure in myeloid and lymphoid cells. • RGS16 – G-protein signaling attenuator elevated after chemokine or antigen stimulation, modulating leukocyte migration. Inconsistencies: • No notable inconsistencies; all listed genes concordantly participate in early activation / inflammatory signaling.

program_48.description: The gene set represents a SREBP-driven de-novo cholesterol/unsaturated-fatty-acid biosynthesis program, a metabolic state commonly up-regulated in rapidly proliferating or metabolically activated cells across diverse lineages (e.g., cycling tumor cells, regenerating hepatocytes, activated immune cells). Evidence: • HMGCS1, FDPS, FDFT1, MSMO1 – sequential enzymes of the mevalonate → squalene → cholesterol pathway, a canonical SREBP-2 target set induced when cells need new membrane sterols. • FADS2 – introduces double bonds into fatty-acyl chains, complementing sterol synthesis to provide unsaturated lipids for membrane expansion; co-regulated by SREBP-1. Inconsistencies: • None noted (no negatively associated genes supplied).

program_49.description: The program most strongly fits an epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) / activated-fibroblast–like state in which epithelial cells lose keratin identity and acquire motile, stress-responsive, secretory features. Evidence: • Gain of mesenchymal/motility markers – S100A4 (FSP1) and TMSB4X are classic EMT and fibroblast genes promoting actin remodeling and migration. • Stress- and secretory-response gene – XBP1 drives the unfolded-protein response and is frequently up-regulated during EMT and in activated stromal fibroblasts coping with high secretory load. • Metabolic re-programming – SAT1 is induced by MYC and ER stress, supporting polyamine turnover during proliferative, remodeling states such as EMT. • Loss of epithelial identity – negative loading of KRT15 (a basal epithelial keratin) indicates down-regulation of epithelial structural programs, a defining step of EMT. Inconsistencies: • XBP1 is also characteristic of highly secretory immune cells (e.g., plasma cells); the absence of other B-cell/plasma markers (e.g., MZB1, JCHAIN) argues that its presence here likely reflects ER-stress during EMT rather than a lymphoid identity.

program_0.description: The gene set defines an endothelial-cell program characteristic of actively sprouting / remodeling micro-vasculature (“angiogenic endothelium”). Transcripts encoding canonical endothelial structural molecules are strongly enriched together with multiple VEGF, Notch and guidance-pathway regulators of tip- and stalk-cell behaviour, extracellular-matrix remodelers and caveolar components, indicating endothelial cells that are not quiescent but engaged in vessel growth and patterning. Evidence: • Core endothelial identity – CDH5 (VE-cadherin), EMCN, ESAM, ICAM2, OCLN, PODXL, CD93, RASIP1, CAV2/CAVIN1-3, HEG1, PECAM-associated genes. • Angiogenic/tip-cell regulators – CLEC14A, TM4SF1, ADGRL4 (ELTD1), EFNB2, NOTCH4, HES1, ETS1, ID1/3, PDGFB, CCN2, RAMP2/3 (adrenomedullin receptor), FLT1 and KDR (VEGFR1/2), FOXF1, GATA2. • Matrix/vascular basement-membrane remodeling – ADAMTS1/9, COL4A2, COL8A1, COL18A1, LAMA5/LAMB2, SPARC, DCN. • Signalling receptors typical of activated endothelium – BMPR2, TGFBR3, FGFR1, EFNB1, EDNRB, NPR3, LEPR. • Negatively loaded genes are largely housekeeping or T-cell enzymes (e.g., CTSW), supporting a shift away from non-endothelial programs rather than contradicting endothelial identity. Inconsistencies: • Moderate expression of lymphoid-associated genes (GIMAP6/7/8, IL15RA, CD69, CTSW down-weighted) suggests minor T-cell contamination or endothelial uptake of immune transcripts. • No strong contradiction from other lineages; overall pattern overwhelmingly supports an angiogenic endothelial state.

program_1.description: The program is characteristic of vascular endothelial cells that are in an activated, pro-angiogenic and inflammatory state, with hints of partial endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndoMT). Evidence: • Core endothelial identity – high expression of canonical endothelial markers PECAM1, CDH5, KDR/FLT1, EMCN, ESAM, CLEC14A, HEG1, RAMP2/3, ICAM1/4, ACKR1 and HSPG2. • Angiogenic / tip- or sprouting-cell signals – ADGRL4 (ELTD1), DLL1-NOTCH4, TEAD1, CXCL2, PGIS (PTGIS), CAVIN1/2, RAMP2/3, EFNA1, FLT1, VEGF-responsive genes (KDR, NR2F2), together with matrix-remodelling factors ADAMTS1/9, MMP-related TIMP1, CCN1/CYR61 and CCN2/CTGF. • Inflammatory activation – chemokines CCL2, CCL23, IL6, SOCS2; adhesion molecules ICAM1, ICAM4; ACKR1 (venular/inflammatory EC); GAS6, SELE-like response genes. • EndoMT / contractile shift – induction of smooth-muscle–associated cytoskeletal genes TAGLN, MYL9, CNN3, LIMCH1 and ABLIM1 along with ECM components COL4A2, COL8A1, LAMB2, DCN and FBN1. • Negative loadings for immune genes (CLEC4A, IL2RG, EMP3) underscore a non-immune, endothelial identity. Inconsistencies: • Epithelial/alveolar markers SFTPC, SCGB3A1 and SCGB3A2 appear, suggesting occasional epithelial doublets or ambient RNA. • Lymphatic markers LYVE1, CCL21 and SPNS2 are present without PROX1 or FLT4, indicating either mixed vascular subtypes or partial lymphatic gene leakage. • Smooth-muscle genes (TAGLN, MYL9) could reflect true EndoMT or contamination from pericytes/smooth-muscle cells.

program_2.description: The gene set describes monocytes/macrophages that have switched into a glucocorticoid- and p53-driven anti-inflammatory/stress state, typified by up-regulation of glucocorticoid/p53 response genes and simultaneous down-regulation of classical macrophage/MHC-II, phagocytic and inflammatory genes. Evidence: • Glucocorticoid response / anti-inflammatory regulators up: TSC22D3 (GILZ), KLF2, KLF4, DDIT4, CXCR4, ZBTB16, SPRY1, NR1D2 – all induced by glucocorticoids and known to dampen myeloid activation. • p53 / cellular-stress genes up: MDM2, CDKN1A (p21), GADD45A, BBC3 (PUMA), CCNG1, WEE1, NUPR1, SAT1 – coherent with a DNA-damage/oxidative-stress program frequently co-activated by glucocorticoids. • Metabolic re-wiring genes up: ASNS, PSAT1, MTHFD2, PDK4, LETMD1, IMPDH2 – typical of stress-adaptive, quiescent myeloid cells. • Core macrophage identity genes down: CD68, MRC1, MSR1, TYROBP, FCGR3A, FCGR2A, LST1, VSIG4 – loss of scavenger and Fc-receptor expression seen after glucocorticoid exposure. • Antigen presentation machinery strongly repressed: HLA-DRA, ‑DPA1, ‑DPB1, ‑DQB1/2, HLA-DMA, CD74 – hallmark of glucocorticoid-treated or tolerogenic macrophages. • Additional inflammatory mediators diminished: ALOX5AP, CYBA, C1QB/C, AIF1, TREM2, CCL17/18/13 – consistent with an anti-inflammatory phenotype. Inconsistencies: • Presence of epithelial/structural genes (KRT10, PKP2, CFAP68, SDC2) is atypical for myeloid cells and may reflect low-level contamination or multiplet cells. • Up-regulation of some proliferation-associated translation factors (e.g., EIF and ribosomal genes) contrasts with the growth-arrest signals but can accompany generalized stress responses.

program_3.description: The gene set represents a generic “cycling-cell” program characteristic of cells in late-S, G2 and M phases, i.e. actively proliferating cells irrespective of lineage. Evidence: • DNA replication/S-phase: high expression of MCM2-7, PCNA, ORC6, CDT1, TYMS, DHFR, RRM1, PRIM1, FEN1 and SLBP. • G2/M transition and mitosis: strong loading of CDK1, CCNB1/2, WEE1, AURKB, BUB1, MAD2L1, PRC1, KIF11, NUSAP1, TPX2, CENPA/P/M/PW, CENPF, CENPE, CENPU, CKS1B/2, UBE2C/S, ANLN, MKI67, BIRC5 and ASPM. • DNA damage repair and replication stress responders often co-induced in proliferating cells: BRCA1/2, RAD51AP1, FANCI, BRIP1, CLSPN, CHEK1, HELLS, DNMT1, UHRF1. • Chromatin and epigenetic modifiers up-regulated during replication: EZH2, PHF19, ATAD2, RBBP7, NASP, H2AZ1/2, HMGB1/2/3. • Negative loadings of myeloid/iron-storage genes (FTH1, TYROBP) highlight repression of lineage-specific functions while cells are in cycle. Inconsistencies: • A few lineage or stress-related genes (e.g., VIM, ANXA2, HLA-E) are not specific to the cell-cycle program but are frequently retained in many cycling cell types; their presence does not contradict a proliferative signature. • METTL1, typically elevated in some cycling cells, is negatively loaded, but this single exception does not outweigh the large, coherent proliferation module.

program_4.description: The gene set is most consistent with a type I-interferon– and TNF-driven inflammatory program in monocyte-derived macrophages/dendritic cells (an “M1-like” activated myeloid state characterized by heightened antigen presentation and Fc-receptor-mediated phagocytosis). Evidence: • Interferon-stimulated genes up-regulated: IFI27, OASL, IFIH1, MX2, EIF2AK2, STAT1, CXCL10 → hallmark of type I IFN activation. • Pro-inflammatory cytokines/chemokines: TNF, CXCL10, CXCL5 together with transcriptional stress genes (HMOX1, NUPR1, DUSP10) point to a classical inflammatory response. • Antigen-presentation machinery: MHC-I genes HLA-A/B/C/E and MHC-II gene HLA-DPB1 are positively loaded, supporting an activated professional APC identity. • Myeloid/phagocytic markers: LYZ, CTSL/CTSZ/CTSH, FCGR2A (CD32), FCGR3A (CD16), ITGB2, LCP1 and SERPING1 (complement regulator) typify macrophages/monocytes engaged in microbicidal activity. • Suppression of steady-state myeloid inhibitors: ITGAM (CD11b), LAIR1, BCL2A1 are negatively loaded, consistent with transition from a homeostatic to an activated state. Inconsistencies: • ECM/mesenchymal genes (COL6A1, COL6A2, FBN1, TAGLN, PCOLCE2, RSPO3) and epithelial keratin KRT18 suggest some fibroblast/epithelial signal contamination. • T-cell–associated transcripts (CD4, ICOS) and neutrophil-skewed genes (S100A9, CAMP) are present but represent a minority of the positively loaded genes.

program_5.description: The gene expression pattern is most consistent with alternatively activated / immunoregulatory macrophages—closely resembling the TREM2⁺ APOE⁺ lipid-associated or tumor-associated macrophage (TAM) state that displays an anti-inflammatory, tissue-remodeling M2-like program. Evidence: • Core macrophage markers: CD14, ITGAM (CD11b), CSF1R, FCGR3A, FCGR2B, C3AR1 confirm myeloid identity. • M2 / immunoregulatory signature: MRC1 (CD206), CD163, VSIG4, FOLR2, MERTK, STAB1, TIMP1, SERPINF1, IL10, CCL18, CCL17, ABCA1, NR1H3, APOE, SELENOP, CH25H, MAF indicate alternative activation and lipid handling. • TREM2–APOE axis: TREM2, APOE, GPNMB, SPP1, LILRB2, TMEM176A/B typify lipid-associated and tumor-associated macrophages reported in human tumors and metabolic tissues. • Tissue-remodeling / fibrosis genes: VCAN, ADAMTS2, OSM, CLEC11A, DCN, FGL2, SDC2 align with extracellular-matrix interaction seen in TAMs. • Anti-inflammatory regulators: IL1R2, PLA2G7, NR4A2, ZFP36, BTG1 dampen pro-inflammatory signaling, matching an immunosuppressive state. • Negative loading of complement/innate inflammatory genes (SERPING1, C1QB) and the lymphoid marker CD52 is compatible with a shift away from classical inflammatory monocytes toward this suppressive macrophage program. Inconsistencies: • Pro-inflammatory or “classical” monocyte genes (S100A9, VCAN, CCL2, CCL3) remain positively loaded, suggesting either partial activation or admixture of inflammatory signals. • MSR1, typically enriched—not depleted—in M2/TAMs, is negatively loaded. • CLEC10A and CD1D are more characteristic of certain dendritic-cell subsets, indicating some overlap with dendritic programs.

program_6.description: The gene set is most consistent with a lipid-handling, TREM2⁺/TYROBP⁺ tissue macrophage program often referred to as “lipid-associated macrophages” (LAM) or “disease-associated microglia” (DAM): cells that up-regulate phagolysosomal, antigen-presentation and cholesterol / fatty-acid–handling modules while dampening acute stress– and NF-κB–driven inflammatory genes. Evidence: • Core macrophage / microglia identity – ITGAM (CD11B), CD36, CYBB, LY96, CSF1, SLAMF8 together with broad MHC-II genes (HLA-DPA1, HLA-DRB5, HLA-DMA) and scavenger receptors (CD163, CD47, TREM2). • LAM / DAM lipid-metabolism module – TREM2, TYROBP, APOC1, LPL, LIPA, CHIT1, GPNMB, ABI3, CH25H, FABP3, CFH: well-described signature in lipid-laden macrophages and neurodegenerative microglia. • Enhanced phagolysosomal / oxidative machinery – CSTB, CST3, DNASE2B, LTA4H, CYBB, GPX1, PRDX1 indicate active debris clearance and redox control. • Anti-inflammatory or alternative activation cues – CD163, CCL18, AREG, ACE, FOLR3, CFH mark an M2-like, tissue-repair orientation. • Negative loadings suppress acute stress & classical activation – JUN, NFKBIA, HSPA8, HMOX1, ISG15, DDIT4, LYZ and FCGR2A are hallmarks of immediate-early, interferon or pro-inflammatory states, supporting a shift toward a lipid-handling, less inflammatory phenotype. Inconsistencies: • Epithelial / non-myeloid transcripts (SFTPC, GPRC5A, FN1, COL8A2) and neuronal/astrocytic markers (PVALB, SLC1A3) may reflect ambient RNA or phagocytosed material rather than true expression. • Immediate-early genes FOS and DUSP1 are positively loaded despite overall suppression of other stress genes, suggesting some concurrent transient activation.

program_7.description: The gene set represents an acutely stimulated, pro-inflammatory (M1-like) activation program in classical monocytes / macrophages, driven by NF-κB– and AP-1–dependent signaling, with strong heat-shock/stress responses and a concurrent suppression of MHC-II antigen-presentation genes. Evidence: • Pro-inflammatory effector molecules – TNF, IL1A, IL1B, CXCL1, CXCL5, CXCL8, PTGS2, ADM: hallmark cytokines/chemokines produced by activated monocytes/macrophages. • NF-κB pathway components/targets – REL, NFKBIA, TNFAIP3, NFKBIZ, GADD45B/G, SQSTM1, KDM6B: indicate canonical NF-κB activation. • Immediate-early/AP-1 transcription factors – JUN, JUND, FOSB, ATF3, EGR1/3, KLF2/4/6/10: classical rapid-response genes induced by TLR/LPS stimulation. • Lineage markers – LYZ, FCGR2A (CD32), MAFB, IFI30, CD83, SEMA4A, AOC3: enriched in monocytes/macrophages. • Stress/heat-shock machinery – HSPA1A/B/L, HSP90AB1, DNAJB1/4, HSPD1, HMOX1, DDIT3: reflects cellular stress that accompanies strong inflammatory activation. • Negative loadings of antigen-presentation and inhibitory genes – HLA-DQA2, HLA-DRB5, LAIR1, LAIR2, APOC1: mirrors the well-described NF-κB-driven repression of MHC-II and inhibitory receptors during M1 polarization. Inconsistencies: • NKG7 (cytotoxic lymphocyte granule protein) is atypical for monocytes, though occasionally expressed in inflammatory monocytic subsets. • BCL6, mainly linked to B-cell/T-FH biology, is not characteristic of monocytes. • FOS appears negatively loaded despite other AP-1 members being positive, suggesting stimulus-timing or technical variation.

program_8.description: The gene set reflects an acutely NF-κB–activated, “classical/M1-like” human monocyte–macrophage state, such as elicited by LPS or TNF stimulation. Cells in this state up-regulate immediate-early NF-κB targets, pro-inflammatory cytokines/chemokines and antigen-presentation/co-stimulatory molecules, while genes typical of tissue-resident or M2-like macrophages are relatively repressed. Evidence: • NF-κB signalling & immediate-early response: NFKBIA, TNFAIP3, REL, NFKB2, IER2/3, EGR1, JUNB, KDM6B, DUSP2, BTG1/2. • Pro-inflammatory cytokines/chemokines (M1 profile): TNF, IL1A/B, CXCL1/2/3/5/8, CCL2/3/4/20, CXCL5, IL1RN, VEGFA, PTGS2, NLRP3. • Monocyte/macrophage identity: CD14, MAFB, C5AR1, ICAM1, VCAN, SRGN, NAMPT, G0S2, GPR84, S100A9, LGALS3BP. • Co-stimulation/antigen presentation & surface activation markers: CD83, CD55, CD44, CD69, IL1R2, CCRL2, CD300E. • Negative loadings for M2/tissue-resident or anti-inflammatory genes: APOC1, GPNMB, ALOX5AP, CSF1, TXNIP, BCL2A1—consistent with a shift away from alternative/M2 or homeostatic macrophage programs. Inconsistencies: • NKG7 and CTSW (cytotoxic lymphocyte markers) appear, but are few and may reflect minor contamination or low-level expression. • ITGA10, ADAMTS9 (mesenchymal/chondrocyte-associated) are not typical of monocytes but are sporadically expressed in activated myeloid cells.

program_9.description: The gene set is characteristic of classical/inflammatory monocytes recently recruited to tissues and transitioning toward monocyte-derived macrophages.
