The program combines strong expression of canonical FCN1/VCAN/S100A8/S100A9 inflammatory-monocyte markers, immediate-early response genes (FOS, JUNB, NR4A2), and cytokine / tissue-remodelling factors (OSM, THBS1, VEGFA, AREG), while genes typical of resident C1QC macrophages (C1QB) and lymphocytes (CD52) are negatively loaded. Evidence: • Classical/inflammatory-monocyte core: FCN1, VCAN, S100A8, S100A9, S100A12, MS4A6A, CD14, C5AR1, LILRB2, GPR183, MAFB, CEBPD, RIPOR2. • Activation / immediate-early response: FOS, JUNB, FOSL2, NR4A2, CREM, ZFP36, ZFP36L1, RGS2, MAP3K8, DUSP4. • Cytokine / chemokine and tissue-remodelling signals typical of activated monocytes: OSM, IL10, VEGFA, AREG, EREG, TIMP1, PLAUR, SERPINB2, THBS1, NLRP3, APOBEC3A. • Monocyte-derived macrophage differentiation markers: MCL1, ETS2, MEF2C, STAB1, LYVE1, ABI3BP. • Negatively loaded C1QB plus CD52 and FTL highlight down-weighting of resident C1QC macrophage and lymphoid programs, reinforcing a monocyte-biased identity. Inconsistencies: • LYVE1 and STAB1 are more typical of resident, anti-inflammatory macrophages. • NKG7 and IL2RG are usually associated with cytotoxic lymphocytes. • SFTPA1 is an alveolar epithelial gene. These outliers are few and likely reflect minor contaminating transcripts or partial state transitions rather than the primary program.

program_10.description: The gene set is most consistent with vascular endothelial cells that are actively remodeling and showing early endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndMT) features, typical of capillary/venous or lymphatic endothelium engaged in angiogenesis or tissue repair. Evidence: • Canonical endothelial markers – CLEC14A, RAMP2/3, ACKR1, LYVE1, ENTPD1, CAV2, CAVIN1/2, RBP7, CX3CL1, EMP2. • Angiogenic/activation regulators – FOXC1, ID1, ID3, BMPR2, EFNA1, ATOH8, SRPX, PRSS23, ZFP36. • Vascular basement-membrane / ECM genes – COL18A1, COL4A2, COL8A1, ELN, MGP, GPX3, COL8A1, CLEC3B. • EndMT / contractile cytoskeleton shift – TAGLN, MYL9, CALD1, NEDD9, SHROOM1, AFAP1L1, FLNB, RIPOR1. • Lymphatic–venous bias – LYVE1, ACKR1, CX3CL1, IGFBP4, GPX3 (markers enriched in sinusoidal, lymphatic or venous EC). • Only one negatively loaded gene, ECSIT, is a myeloid/mitochondrial signaling gene, supporting low macrophage contamination. Inconsistencies: • Lymphocyte‐associated GIMAP6/7, IL2RG and BCL6B, and airway secretoglobin SCGB3A2 are atypical for endothelium and may reflect minor contaminating transcripts or ambient RNA. • UTY (Y-linked) is not cell-type specific.

program_11.description: The gene constellation is most consistent with distal lung secretory epithelium—predominantly alveolar type II (AT2) cells engaged in surfactant and lipid biosynthesis, with a minor airway/club-cell flavor that may reflect an AT2-to-AT1 or club/AT2 hybrid “transitional” state frequently captured after injury or during regeneration. Evidence: • Surfactant machinery (hallmark of AT2): SFTPC, SFTPA1, SFTPB, SFTPA2, SFTA2, NAPSA, LPCAT1, PGC • Lipid/cholesterol synthesis required for surfactant lipids: FASN, HMGCS1, SQLE, DHCR7, DHCR24, MSMO1, LDLR, PLAAT4 • General epithelial/secretory markers: KRT8, KRT18, MUC1, CYB5A, BMP1, HOPX (also appears in AT1-primed transitional cells) • Club/airway secretory genes often co-expressed in distal hybrid cells: SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1, SCGB3A2 • Stress-resistance and antioxidant components typical of AT2 cells: PRDX2, SELENOP • Negative loadings lack a cohesive alternate lineage signature, supporting the positive-gene interpretation. Inconsistencies: • SCGB genes could point to proximal airway club cells rather than pure AT2 identity. • CCL21 is more typical of lymphatic endothelium or fibroblasts. • SELENOP and LRRK2 are not AT2-specific but are broadly expressed metabolic/stress genes.

program_12.description: The program is most consistent with an activated, PLZF-expressing innate-like T-cell subset (e.g. NKT or MAIT cells) that is simultaneously engaging ER-/metabolic-stress pathways and cytoskeletal remodeling needed for migration and effector function. Evidence: • Innate-like T-cell identity/activation: ZBTB16 (PLZF; canonical for NKT/MAIT cells), LTB (lymphotoxin-β, produced by activated T/B lymphocytes), PPP3CA (calcineurin catalytic subunit driving NFAT signaling in activated T cells), DHX32 (up-regulated during T-cell activation), NKIRAS1 (modulates NF-κB in lymphocytes). • ER stress / metabolic rewiring typical of strongly stimulated lymphocytes: ERN1 (IRE1) and MBTPS1 (S1P) ‑ core unfolded-protein-response sensors/activators; SLC38A9 (lysosomal arginine sensor for mTORC1), MTERF4 & CLYBL (mitochondrial gene-expression/metabolism), THOC5 and FAM120B (stress-granule & mRNA-export factors). • Motility / adhesion changes seen after T-cell activation: ARHGEF5, ARAP2, PLOD2, PKD2 (Rho-, Arf- and Ca²⁺-regulated cytoskeletal or ECM-interacting proteins) support a migratory/trafficking state. Inconsistencies: • PLOD2 is more often highlighted in fibroblast or hypoxia programs, and its presence may reflect a generalized tissue-remodeling response rather than T-cell specificity. • The single negatively loaded gene LRRC61 lacks a clear link to T-cell biology, suggesting it may be noise or reflect repression of an unrelated pathway.

program_13.description: The gene set is most consistent with a GATA3-high lymphoid program characteristic of T helper-2 (Th2)–polarised or ILC2-like T cells that are metabolically primed and mildly proliferative. Evidence: • Lineage / survival markers – GATA3 (master regulator of Th2 and ILC2 fate) and GIMAP5 (T-cell survival GTPase) are jointly up-regulated. • Immunometabolic support – ACSL5, SLC38A9, USP30 and PMPCA encode mitochondrial or lysosomal proteins that feed fatty-acid or amino-acid fuel into mTORC1, a requirement for activated/Th2 T cells. • Mild proliferation / cell-cycle readiness – CCNC, POLA2, KIF2A, BIRC6, SEH1L and RBM39 are all expressed in dividing lymphocytes, fitting the modest cell-cycle component often seen in activated Th2 cells. • Cytoskeletal remodelling for immune synapse – SPECC1L, KIAA0586, EXOC6B, TPM2 and CCDC171 participate in microtubule or actin organisation needed for T-cell activation and cytokine secretion. • Negative loading – JMJD8, reported to restrict NF-κB/T-cell signalling, is down-regulated, consistent with an activated Th2/ILC2 state. Inconsistencies: • Several cilia-associated or broadly expressed structural genes (KIAA0586, CCDC171, EXOC6B, MAST4) and the muscle cytoskeletal gene TPM2 are not classically linked to T-cell biology, suggesting either pleiotropic roles in cytoskeletal dynamics or modest contamination from non-lymphoid transcripts.

program_14.description: The gene constellation is most consistent with a conventional myeloid dendritic cell (cDC) program enriched for antigen-processing/vesicle-trafficking functions and low-level inflammatory cytokine production. Evidence: • DC lineage markers – ZNF366 (DC-SCRIPT), a transcription factor highly selective for cDCs; PSMB10 (immunoproteasome β-subunit) induced in professional antigen-presenting cells. • Antigen processing / cross-presentation machinery – GABARAP (autophagosome formation), ATP6V0C (vacuolar ATPase required for endo-lysosomal acidification), PSMA6 (constitutive proteasome), TRAPPC5 & ARF5 (ER-to-Golgi/vesicle trafficking), RNASEK (clathrin-mediated endocytosis), GRINA and GSDME (phagosomal membrane proteins). • Cytokine / immunomodulatory genes typical of activated myeloid APCs – MIF (pro-inflammatory cytokine), TNFSF13/APRIL (DC-derived B-cell survival factor), VEGFB (myeloid-derived angiogenic factor). • Metabolic & translational up-regulation supporting active antigen presentation – NME2, EEF1G, MRPS24, EIF4EBP3, MTHFS, CRAT, multiple proteasome subunits. Inconsistencies: • VEGFB and APOC4-APOC2 are more characteristic of endothelial or hepatic tissue, respectively, though low expression is reported in some myeloid cells. • House-keeping or widely expressed genes (e.g., POLD4, SPECC1L, ABCC10) provide little cell-type specificity but do not contradict a cDC identity.

program_15.description: The gene set is most consistent with a core T-lineage/innate-like lymphocyte program characteristic of naïve or early-stage T or NK-T cells, defined by expression of the common γ-chain cytokine receptor, proximal T-cell receptor (TCR) signalling adaptors and the pan-T marker CD7, without overt cytotoxic effector genes. Evidence: • T-lineage membrane/cytokine components – IL2RG (common γ-chain used by IL-2,-4,-7,-9,-15,-21 receptors), CD7 (pan-T/NK marker), HLA-E (ligand modulating NK/T interactions). • Proximal TCR-signalling machinery – LAT (critical adaptor in TCR signalling), PRKCB (PKC-β, activated downstream of TCR), RGS10 (modulates G-protein signalling in lymphocytes). • Additional genes often enriched in resting or developing lymphocytes – SGPL1 (regulates S1P-dependent lymphocyte egress), BMPR1A (reported in thymocyte maturation), NEURL1 and TPST2 (E3-ligase and tyrosyl-sulfotransferase implicated in T-cell development), consistent with an early/naïve state rather than effector cytotoxic cells. Inconsistencies: • S100B (classically glial), ASRGL1, PGS1, WDR45 and other housekeeping/metabolic genes are not T-cell–specific but are ubiquitously expressed; their presence likely reflects generic metabolic or housekeeping requirements rather than contradicting a T-cell identity.

program_16.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated/migratory T-cell program characterized by T-cell receptor signalling together with extensive cytoskeletal remodelling, metabolic rewiring and chromatin re-organisation. Evidence: • Canonical T-cell identity/activation genes – CD3D (TCR complex) and C1orf56/CARMIL2 (costimulatory scaffold required downstream of CD28) are strongly positively loaded. • Actin-myosin and polarity regulators supporting immune-synapse formation and motility – CDC42SE1, PPP1R12A (MYPT1), TPM4 and NRP2 are all induced during T-cell spreading and tissue egress. • Stress- and mTOR-linked metabolic modulators typical of recently activated or nutrient-challenged lymphocytes – DEPDC5 (GATOR1, mTORC1 inhibitor), TSC22D1 (glucocorticoid/TCR-inducible), ACAD8 and PHKG1 (adjust energy metabolism), GSTM3 (ROS detoxification). • Chromatin and transcriptional regulators up-regulated during T-cell activation – MTA2 (NuRD), KDM6A (UTX), CHD6 and NFYB, supporting large-scale transcriptional reprogramming. Inconsistencies: • PRX (periaxin, Schwann-cell myelin protein) and TMEM107 (cilia component) are not typical of T cells and may reflect low-level ambient RNA or technical cross-loading. • Muscle/neuronal-leaning metabolic genes such as PHKG1, SLC26A11 and ACAD8 are uncommon in lymphocytes but could mark broader metabolic adaptation or minor contamination.

program_17.description: The gene constellation most closely matches a stress-response program in cortical/excitatory neurons that are engaging autophagy, ER-stress relief and early pro-apoptotic signalling, rather than a pure lineage-identity signature. Evidence: • Neuronal identity – NRGN (hallmark of cortical pyramidal neurons), NCK2 and CHST7 (brain-enriched signalling/scaffold genes), and neurotrophic factor MANF support a neuronal context. • Autophagy/ER-stress – MAP1LC3A (LC3A, core autophagosome protein) and MANF (ER-stress inducible secreted factor) indicate activation of the autophagy/UPR axis. • DNA-damage / pro-apoptotic signalling – BID (BH3-only apoptosis mediator), NEIL2 and ENDOD1 (DNA-repair enzymes), TSC22D1 and PLAGL1 (p53/glucocorticoid-inducible stress transcription factors) together denote a damage-response state. • Metabolic adaptation – GMPR, SLC20A1 and TPST2 reflect nucleotide and phosphate homeostasis adjustments commonly seen under cellular stress. • Chromatin/cytoskeletal remodelling – HDAC3, NFYB, MACF1 and NEXN are typical of cells reorganising transcription and the cytoskeleton during injury or stress recovery. Inconsistencies: • LAT and PLCG2 are classically immune-cell signalling molecules, and NEXN is best known in muscle; their presence is atypical for neurons and may reflect low-level contamination or broader stress-inducible expression.

program_18.description: This gene set outlines a generic “nuclear gene-expression/RNA-processing” program rather than a lineage-restricted signature. Cells scoring highly for the program appear to be in a transcriptionally and post-transcriptionally active state characterized by enhanced chromatin remodeling, RNA-pol II transcription, mRNA splicing/processing, nuclear export and cytosolic translation, while mitochondrial ribosome assembly is relatively down-weighted. Evidence: • Transcription/chromatin remodeling – CHD3 (NuRD remodeler), CTDP1 (RNA-pol II CTD phosphatase), ATF1 and RUNX3 (sequence-specific transcription factors). • mRNA processing/export – CPSF1 (cleavage-polyadenylation), THOC5 (THO/TREX complex), DIS3L (exosome nuclease), MBNL3 (splicing regulator). • Translation machinery – EEF1AKMT1 (elongation factor methyltransferase) and HARS2 (mitochondrial His-tRNA synthetase) imply up-regulated protein synthesis. • Vesicle/trafficking support for elevated protein throughput – TRAPPC10, SNX12, ZFYVE1, DEF8. • Negative loading of MTERF4, a key factor in mitochondrial ribosome assembly, is consistent with the program emphasizing nuclear-encoded over mitochondrial translation. Inconsistencies: • HRH1 (histamine receptor), CEP41 (ciliogenesis/centrosome), DAG1 (dystroglycan cell-adhesion) are signaling or structural genes not directly linked to RNA processing; they may reflect cell-type-specific co-expression rather than the core program.

program_19.description: The gene set best matches a B-cell identity program, reflecting cells that express canonical B-lineage surface molecules and intracellular adaptors involved in B-cell-receptor (BCR) signalling, without strong indications of a specific maturation stage. Evidence: • CD22 and DAPP1 – classical, B-cell-restricted components of the BCR complex and downstream signalling. • BTN3A3 and RGS18 – immune-restricted regulators found in haematopoietic lineages, including B cells, further supporting an immune rather than neuronal/epithelial origin. • House-keeping or broadly expressed genes (NUP43, PIGA, NEIL1, SLC5A6, BCKDHB, etc.) are compatible with a generic cellular program layered on top of a B-cell backbone. Inconsistencies: • NRGN (neuronal) and SPA17 (testis/sperm) are atypical for B cells and may reflect low-level ambient RNA or doublet contamination.

program_20.description: The gene set most closely matches an erythroid‐lineage program characteristic of late erythroblasts / reticulocytes that are actively clearing organelles through autophagy while remodeling their cytoskeleton on the way to becoming mature red blood cells. Evidence: • Erythroid identity – ICAM4 (erythrocyte/reticulocyte surface protein), HDAC7 and KLF8 (transcription factors implicated in erythroid differentiation). • Organelle clearance via autophagy/mitophagy – MAP1LC3A (LC3, autophagosome marker), SLC38A9 (lysosomal nutrient-sensor linked to mTOR), RNF5 (ER-associated ubiquitin ligase promoting autophagy), CASP2 (stress-induced caspase involved in mitophagy), PDP1 and CLYBL (mitochondrial enzymes whose expression precedes mitochondrial removal). • Cytoskeletal and membrane remodeling needed for enucleation and shape change – CFL2 (muscle/erythroid actin depolymerizing factor), TEDC1 (centrosome component), ARHGEF10 (Rho-GTPase activator), SPAG1 (microtubule-associated). • Additional metabolic/glycosylation genes consistent with reticulocyte maturation – B3GALNT2 (surface glycan remodeling), CUTC (metal homeostasis important for heme metabolism). Inconsistencies: • SPAG1 (classically ciliary), ADCY7 (cAMP signaling in immune cells) and some broadly expressed transcriptional regulators (TADA2B, ZBTB22) are not erythroid-specific, yet their presence can reflect generic roles in cytoskeleton or transcription rather than a different lineage.

program_21.description: The gene set most closely reflects a mitochondrial biogenesis / oxidative-metabolism program that is typically up-regulated in highly metabolic, often proliferating, cells rather than marking a specific differentiated lineage. Evidence: • Multiple mitochondrial protein–import or ribosomal genes (TIMM23B, MRPS27, MTG2) point to increased mitochondrial translation and assembly. • Enzymes for key mitochondrial co-factor synthesis (FECH for heme; PDSS1 for coenzyme Q) support heightened oxidative phosphorylation capacity. • Additional mitochondrial or redox regulators (PDSS1, MTG2, MTF1) and general transcription/translation factors (GTF2F2, ARID2) fit a coordinated up-shift in mitochondrial activity. • KIF2A and RGL2 are commonly induced in cycling cells, consistent with the elevated metabolic demand of proliferation that often coincides with mitochondrial biogenesis. Inconsistencies: • UGDH (glycosaminoglycan precursor synthesis) and QSOX2 (secreted disulfide-forming enzyme) relate to extracellular matrix production rather than mitochondria. • POFUT1 (Notch receptor fucosylation) and VPS33B (vesicle trafficking) are not directly linked to mitochondrial function, suggesting some non-mitochondrial housekeeping genes are co-loaded with the program.

program_22.description: The gene set is most consistent with a quiescent common-lymphoid-progenitor (CLP)–like program that retains both early T-lineage (LAT) and early B-lineage (CD22) signaling components alongside chromatin-modifying and metabolic “stemness” factors, indicating an undifferentiated lymphoid state poised for either B- or T-cell commitment. Evidence: • Dual lineage adaptors – LAT (obligate T-cell receptor scaffold) and CD22 (B-cell inhibitory co-receptor) co-expressed in early lymphoid progenitors before commitment. • Stem/progenitor maintenance and chromatin control – WDR5, CBX6, CCDC71L, SPTY2D1, TBC1D7 (TSC complex) and OGG1 support a quiescent, DNA-repair–competent progenitor profile. • Metabolic poise – PDK3 (glycolytic switch) and PRKAR2B/PRKCI (PKA/PKC signaling) help maintain low anabolic activity typical of resting progenitors. • Secretory vesicle/trafficking genes (SEC22A, CLCN3) and glycosaminoglycan enzyme CHPF2 are commonly elevated in early hematopoietic precursors. Inconsistencies: • NRGN (classically neuronal), ACRBP (testis-restricted cancer-testis antigen) and PLA2G12A (secreted phospholipase found in some epithelial tissues) are not typical lymphoid markers; their presence may reflect low-level promiscuous transcription or dataset-specific background.

program_23.description: The gene set is most consistent with an epithelial population that is actively assembling and maintaining a primary cilium (i.e., a “ciliogenesis” program often seen in differentiating or homeostatic ciliated epithelial cells such as kidney tubular, airway, or ependymal cells). Evidence: • Core ciliogenesis / centrosome genes – KIAA0586 (Talpid3), CCDC171 and KATNA1 are all required for centriole maturation or microtubule-based axoneme growth; PKD1 encodes the ciliary mechanosensor polycystin-1. • Additional coiled-coil or ankyrin-repeat proteins frequently enriched at the centrosome/ciliary transition zone – ANKRD36, UACA, LEMD3. • Supportive trafficking or ubiquitin-related factors frequently up-regulated during cilium assembly – USP31 (de-ubiquitinase), FBXL8 (SCF substrate adaptor), SLC39A13 (ZIP13; participates in TGF-β/BMP responses that are integrated at the cilium). • Presence of general microtubule/RNA-processing factors required for the high structural turnover that accompanies ciliogenesis – FASTKD3, SKIC3, BICRA, UVSSA. Inconsistencies: • Metabolic (PYGB), immune-regulatory (SIGIRR) and generic DNA-repair or mitochondrial genes (UVSSA, FASTKD3) are not specifically linked to ciliogenesis and may reflect housekeeping functions rather than the core program.

program_24.description: The gene combination is most consistent with an epithelial‐lineage program (marked by KRT8) that has up-regulated machinery for cytoskeletal remodeling, membrane trafficking and protein turnover, features typical of epithelial cells that are actively migrating or undergoing structural re-organization (e.g. wound-responsive or early epithelial-to-mesenchymal–like remodeling). Evidence: • Epithelial identity – KRT8 (canonical intermediate filament of simple epithelia). • Cytoskeletal rearrangement – TTLL5 (microtubule polyglutamylation), RIPOR1 (Rho-regulated polarity/migration protein), CFL2 (actin-severing), ADD3 (spectrin–actin junctions), DOCK10 (Rac/Cdc42 GEF for protrusive activity). • Membrane/Golgi–endosomal trafficking – GOLGA3, GANAB, NUS1, EPN1, NPLOC4, SLC38A9 (lysosomal transporter activating mTORC1), supporting heightened vesicle flow and turnover. • Proteostasis/turnover – FBXO32 (atrogin-1 E3 ligase), APEH (peptidase) indicate increased ubiquitin-proteasome activity often seen during remodeling or stress responses. Inconsistencies: • Muscle-biased genes CFL2 and FBXO32 are more typical of skeletal muscle atrophy programs but can be repurposed for actin turnover and protein degradation in non-muscle contexts, so their presence is not entirely specific to epithelia.

program_25.description: The gene set most plausibly represents a technical multiplet/doublet signature in which transcripts from airway secretory (“club”) epithelial cells are captured together with those from hematopoietic immune cells. The concomitant presence of strong lineage-restricted epithelial markers (SCGB1A1, CLDN7) and leukocyte-specific genes (ARHGAP15, PLCG2, CD2, LILRB1) – together with depletion of the alveolar type I marker AGER – is better explained by mixed-cell droplets than by a bona-fide physiological state of a single cell type. Evidence: • Club/airway secretory epithelial markers: SCGB1A1 (canonical club cell gene), CLDN7 (tight-junction protein enriched in airway/other epithelia). • Hematopoietic immune markers: – Myeloid: ARHGAP15 (neutrophil/monocyte), LILRB1 (monocytes, macrophages, DCs), PLCG2 (Fc-receptor and BCR signalling), RGS18 (megakaryo-platelet / myeloid). – Lymphoid: CD2 (T and NK cells). • House-keeping/ubiquitous genes (EXT1, PPP1R12A, MED11, WRAP53, RNF11, KIAA0586) provide little lineage information and are compatible with a mixed transcript pool. • Negative loading of AGER – a definitive alveolar type I cell marker – highlights that the epithelial component is not AT1, supporting the club-cell identity for the epithelial transcripts. Inconsistencies: • The simultaneous high expression of mutually exclusive lineage genes (SCGB1A1/CLDN7 vs. CD2/PLCG2/ARHGAP15) is inconsistent with any known single cell type or activation state. • Presence of the platelet-biased gene RGS18 alongside epithelial markers further supports a mixed-origin rather than a coherent biological program.

program_26.description: The program most strongly fits a pro-survival / stress-adapted state common in epithelial-derived (often malignant) cells, in which ubiquitin-mediated inhibition of apoptosis is coupled to heightened endosomal–autophagic trafficking and general detoxification processes. Evidence: • Anti-apoptotic / ubiquitin machinery: BIRC6 (IAP E2/E3 ligase that blocks caspase activation and promotes autophagy), ZNF217 (oncogenic transcription factor that suppresses apoptosis), USP31 (de-ubiquitinase that modulates NF-κB survival signalling), UACA (interacts with apoptosis regulators). • Vesicle / ESCRT / autophagy pathway: MVB12A (ESCRT-I), SYNJ1 (phosphoinositide phosphatase required for endocytosis and autophagosome maturation), SEH1L (nucleoporin that facilitates autophagy initiation), ARHGEF5 (Rho-GEF influencing actin-driven vesicle trafficking). • Stress-adaptation & detoxification: GSTM4 (glutathione S-transferase, oxidative-stress defence), MARK3 and TMEM164 (ER- and hypoxia-related stress responders), MFSD5 (putative redox/solute transporter). • General RNA / protein quality control: TSEN54 (tRNA splicing), CACTIN (spliceosomal factor), together with multiple ubiquitin-related genes, aligns with a proteostasis-oriented programme rather than lineage-specific differentiation. Inconsistencies: • CCDC171 (cilia-associated protein) and ANKRD36 have no clear role in stress-survival pathways but also do not strongly contradict the interpretation.

program_27.description: The gene set is most consistent with an alternatively-activated (M2-like), metabolically re-programmed macrophage that is engaged in phagosome trafficking/acidification and fatty-acid–supported oxidative metabolism, a state typical of tissue-resident or reparative macrophages rather than classically inflamed (M1) cells. Evidence: • Phagosome and trafficking machinery enriched in macrophages – RAB20 (promotes phagosome maturation), SLC4A7 (bicarbonate transporter required for phagosomal acidification), CBLB (E3 ligase highly expressed in myeloid/T-NK cells, tunes innate signalling). • Anti-inflammatory/NF-κB dampening components characteristic of M2 cells – NKIRAS1 (NF-κB inhibitor), CBLB, MOAP1 (BAX-associated apoptotic modulator, up-regulated during resolution phases). • Fatty-acid oxidation and mitochondrial/TCA enzymes that fuel M2 metabolism – EHHADH (peroxisomal FAO), IDH3A (TCA cycle), FN3K (protein deglycation linked to oxidative metabolism), RBKS (ribose salvage), DHX57/FIGNL1/BEX3 (stress-adaptation proteins often co-expressed with high OXPHOS). • Cytoskeletal/vesicular regulators supportive of phagocytic remodeling – PAK4 (actin dynamics), FIGNL1 (microtubule-associated AAA-ATPase). Inconsistencies: • PKD2 and SEL1L3 are more typical of renal/epithelial expression than of macrophages. • Canonical macrophage markers (e.g., CD68, CSF1R, MRC1) are absent; thus the program may capture a metabolic/vesicular module shared with other cell types, rather than a full macrophage identity.

program_28.description: The gene set best fits a generic “house-keeping / organelle‐ and ribosome-biogenesis” program that is up-regulated in metabolically active cells of many lineages rather than a lineage-restricted cell type or a specialized activation state. Evidence: • Ribosome / rRNA maturation – KRI1 and GTPBP8 (small-subunit assembly), PRRC2A (translation initiation partner) • RNA and chromatin regulation – CCAR2 (transcriptional co-activator), AEBP2 (PRC2 co-factor) • Nucleotide salvage – UCKL1 (uridine-cytidine kinase-like) • Membrane lipid signalling & endocytosis – PIP5K1A (PI(4,5)P₂ synthesis), EPN2 (clathrin-mediated endocytosis adaptor), MYO1E (actin-based vesicle traffic) • Organelle biogenesis – PEX3 (peroxisome membrane insertion), APOO & LZTFL1 (mitochondrial / ciliary trafficking) Together these genes point to increased translation, membrane turnover and organelle maintenance typical of cells with heightened basal metabolism or proliferation but do not specify a distinct immune, epithelial or stromal identity. Inconsistencies: • No strongly lineage-defining markers (e.g. CD3E for T cells, EPCAM for epithelia, COL1A1 for fibroblasts) are present; thus the program is unlikely to denote a dedicated cell type on its own.

program_29.description: The gene set is most consistent with a generic stress‐response program centered on autophagy-mediated organelle quality control (especially mitophagy) and vesicle/ER–Golgi trafficking rather than with any one differentiated cell type; it likely marks cells that have activated intracellular degradation pathways, for example during metabolic or hypoxic stress. Evidence: • Autophagy/mitophagy components – TECPR1 (selective autophagy receptor), SH3GLB2/Endophilin-B2 (autophagosome formation), USP30 and BRCC3 (mitochondrial‐outer-membrane de-ubiquitinases that regulate PINK1/Parkin-dependent mitophagy), SELENOO (mitochondrial stress sensor) all rise together. • Vesicle/ER–Golgi trafficking and membrane remodeling – SEC22A (ER–Golgi SNARE), SH3GLB2, KATNB1 (microtubule severing aiding autophagosome movement) support increased vesicular flux typical of active autophagy. • Ubiquitin pathway regulators – LZTR1 (CUL3 adaptor controlling Ras/ubiquitin signalling), USP30 and BRCC3 reinforce the heightened ubiquitin-dependent tagging and recycling that accompanies selective autophagy. • Stress/hypoxia signalling – ARNT (HIF-1β) is a key partner in hypoxia-induced transcription that often triggers mitophagy, aligning with the quality-control theme. Inconsistencies: • Several broadly expressed “house-keeping” or regulatory genes (CIR1, GPN1, MFSD5, CUTC, CCDC126) are not specifically linked to autophagy; their presence suggests some noise or a more generalized cellular stress program rather than a purely autophagic signature.

program_30.description: The gene set most closely fits a proteostasis/DNA-damage stress program that precedes or accompanies caspase-mediated apoptosis, rather than marking any one lineage; it is therefore indicative of cells—of various types—that are experiencing protein-folding or replication stress and are engaging ubiquitin-dependent degradation pathways together with executioner caspase activation. Evidence: • Ubiquitin/ER-associated degradation: UBA6 (E1 activating enzyme), FBXO38 and TRIM52 (E3 ligases), and ERLIN2 (ER-associated degradation scaffold) are jointly up-regulated when mis-folded proteins must be cleared. • Apoptotic execution: CASP7 is an executioner caspase activated downstream of mitochondrial or ER stress. • DNA-replication/repair stress: MMS22L (fork protection) and HDGFL3 (chromatin-associated) rise after genotoxic insult. • Metabolic adaptation to stress: GMPR shifts nucleotide pools during low-energy or DNA-repair conditions. • Additional stress-linked scaffolds/regulators: LEMD3 (nuclear envelope stress sensor), MPRIP (actin stress-fiber regulator), GPATCH1 and TTC38 (RNA-processing factors up-regulated in stress), CCDC88B (immune/stress signalling adaptor), collectively support a broad stress-response signature. Inconsistencies: • CDR2 (neuronal onconeural antigen) and CCDC88B (T-cell/innate-immune adaptor) are lineage-biased genes that are not directly tied to proteostasis stress, suggesting some cell-type heterogeneity or passenger loadings.

program_31.description: The gene set most consistently points to a receptor-tyrosine-kinase/RAS-MAPK signalling response program that accompanies growth-factor stimulation and associated transcriptional remodelling, rather than marking a single lineage; it is therefore indicative of cells in an activated, pro-proliferative signal-receiving state. Evidence: • RAS pathway components and modulators – LZTR1 (binds and ubiquitinates RAS), NKIRAS1 (NF-κB and RAS regulator), CBLB (E3 ligase that attenuates activated RTKs), GAB1 (scaffold that links EGFR/Met signalling to RAS–MAPK), MLLT6 (MYC/HOXA co-activator up-regulated by RAS). • Phosphoinositide and mTOR signalling support – IPMK (generates PIP3, feeds into AKT–mTOR), TRPT1 (NAD-linked RNA repair enzyme induced by growth signals). • Transcription-chromatin remodelling downstream of signalling – CHD3 (NuRD chromatin remodeler), CTDP1 (FCP1 phosphatase that reactivates Pol II), ZBTB20 (RAS-responsive zinc-finger transcription factor), EID2 (retinoblastoma/E2F co-repressor released on mitogenic cues). • Additional growth-support genes – NOA1 (mitochondrial GTPase that boosts oxidative metabolism), SLC23A2 (ascorbate transporter up-regulated in metabolically active cells), IFT46 (cilia/centrosome component often induced with proliferative signalling), CRYZL1 (oxidoreductase linked to redox homeostasis). Inconsistencies: • IFT46 is best known for ciliary assembly rather than classic RAS responses, and SLC23A2 is a vitamin-C transporter with broad tissue expression; their presence is not incompatible but less specifically tied to RTK/RAS signalling.

program_32.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated lymphoid-cell metabolic program, typical of T, NK or innate-lymphoid cells that have recently received γ-chain cytokine signals and are up-regulating mitochondrial biogenesis, autophagy and secretory/Golgi functions to support effector activity. Evidence: • Cytokine/γ-chain signalling – IL2RG (common γ-chain for IL-2, IL-7, IL-15, IL-21) is a core marker of T, NK and other innate lymphoid cells in an activated, cytokine-responsive state. • Organelle biogenesis & mitochondrial metabolism – CEP89, TIMM10B, BCKDHB and ABHD10 encode mitochondrial structural or metabolic proteins; their concerted up-regulation is typical of lymphocytes switching to increased oxidative metabolism after activation. • Autophagy / cellular remodelling – ATG4B (LC3-processing protease) supports the burst of autophagy that accompanies lymphocyte activation and metabolic rewiring. • Secretory/Golgi expansion – TPD52L2, GOLGA8B and NOMO1 participate in Golgi membrane trafficking, matching the need of activated lymphocytes to secrete cytokines and cytotoxic granules. • Redox and glycogen control – GSTM4 (glutathione transferase) and PPP1R3E (glycogen-associated phosphatase regulator) help buffer oxidative stress and regulate glycogen stores during intense metabolic activity. Inconsistencies: • IQCN and GFOD2 have more restricted or poorly characterised expression (testis or neuronal bias), and NAB2 is broadly expressed, so these transcripts are less specifically linked to lymphoid activation. • Absence of classic T/NK effector genes (e.g., GZMB, IFNG, CD3E) means the program captures the metabolic/organellar aspect of activation rather than the full effector transcriptome.

program_33.description: The gene combination most consistently reflects a broad “chromatin-remodelling / stress-adaptation” program—cells that have down-shifted proliferation and are engaging DNA-repair, unfolded-protein response and epigenetic re-wiring. It is not lineage-restricted and can be detected in many cell types that have entered a quiescent or early differentiation state after exposure to metabolic or genotoxic stress. Evidence: • Cell-cycle restraint – CDKN2D (p19^INK4d) enforces G1 arrest; absence of classic S-phase genes supports a non-proliferative state. • DNA-damage defence – NTHL1 (base-excision repair) is up-regulated when oxidative lesions accumulate. • Epigenetic/ transcriptional re-wiring – KAT2B (PCAF HAT), SETD5 (histone methyl-transferase), EID3 (CBP/p300 inhibitor) and POLR2D (RNAP II subunit) together signify active chromatin and transcriptional restructuring rather than lineage-specific effector functions. • Proteostasis / ER stress – DNAJC10 (ERdj5) is a canonical unfolded-protein-response chaperone. • General stress-associated signalling – S100A16 (calcium sensor in stressed cells), PRKX and ADCY7 (cAMP signalling), ARHGAP21 & EFNB1 (cytoskeleton / cell-contact remodelling) are commonly induced during adaptation to adverse cues. Inconsistencies: • EFNB1, PRKX, ARHGAP21 and TBCEL are also enriched in certain differentiated epithelia or endothelial cells, indicating the module is not entirely specific to a stress-quiescent state. • The set lacks classical p53 targets (e.g. CDKN1A, GADD45) and canonical UPR markers (e.g. ATF4, HSPA5), so the stress signature is partial rather than full-blown.

program_34.description: The gene set most strongly points to an unfolded-protein response/secretory activation program frequently seen in recently activated B-lineage cells transitioning toward a plasmablast/plasma-cell fate. The genes encode ER stress sensors, glycosylation and proteolytic enzymes, vesicle-trafficking factors and the canonical activation marker CD38, together indicating a cell that is ramping up endoplasmic-reticulum and Golgi capacity to sustain high-level protein secretion. Evidence: • ER stress & UPR: ERN1 (IRE1, central UPR sensor), NFYB (transcription factor that drives ER-stress genes), SRSF1 & SKIC3 (enhanced mRNA splicing/exosome activity during UPR). • Secretory/Golgi expansion: PCSK7 (pro-protein convertase in trans-Golgi), ST6GALNAC3 (sialyl-transferase), TPD52 and WASHC2C (vesicle/endomembrane trafficking), SUN1 (nuclear-envelope re-organisation during secretory differentiation). • Activated lymphoid identity: CD38 (high on plasmablasts/activated B and T cells), RGS16 (induced in activated B/T cells and regulates chemotaxis during plasma-cell egress). • Metabolic/cytoskeletal support for secretion: CKB (ATP buffering), ADD3 (actin–spectrin junctions needed for vesicle movement), BEX3 (stress-response adaptor). Inconsistencies: • No immunoglobulin (IGH, JCHAIN) or plasma-cell master regulators (PRDM1, XBP1); therefore the program may represent an early secretory/UPR state shared with other highly secretory or stressed cells rather than fully committed plasma cells. • House-keeping genes such as CKB, ADD3 and SUN1 are broadly expressed and not specific to lymphoid secretion, introducing some general cellular-activity signal into the program.

program_35.description: The gene constellation is most consistent with an antigen-receptor/NF-κB signalling program characteristic of recently activated lymphocytes (T or B cells) that is accompanied by heightened RNA-processing and mitochondrial activity. Evidence: • Antigen-receptor → NF-κB axis: MALT1 (paracaspase in the CARMA1–BCL10–MALT1 complex), MAP3K21 (MAP3K acting downstream of TCR/BCR), and GAB1 (adapter amplifying cytokine and receptor-tyrosine-kinase signals) are all core components of lymphocyte activation pathways. • Lymphoid-biased factors: DHX32 (helicase enriched in T-cell compartments, regulates activation-induced apoptosis) and ZRSR2 (splice-factor frequently mutated in myeloid/lymphoid lineages) reinforce a haematolymphoid context. • Transcription/spliceosome up-shift seen during activation: SART3, ZRSR2, DHX32, PCGF6 and ZSCAN30 encode spliceosomal or chromatin-modifying proteins that are up-regulated when lymphocytes enter rapid proliferation. • Metabolic support for activation: AIFM1 (mitochondrial redox protein) and SLC25A38 (mitochondrial glycine transporter needed for heme/ATP synthesis) are typically induced during high metabolic demand. Inconsistencies: • PKD1 (polycystin-1, kidney epithelium), RCN1 and TMEM131L are broadly expressed ER proteins, and SLC25A38 is best known for erythroid cells; these housekeeping genes add non-specific metabolic flavour rather than clear lymphoid identity.

program_36.description: The gene constellation most consistently points to a generic “secretory / vesicle-trafficking and mitochondrial-translation” housekeeping program that is up-regulated in metabolically active, secretory epithelial cells rather than to a lineage-specific identity. Evidence: • Vesicle/Golgi and glycan-modifying machinery – PLEKHA8 (FAPP2, PI4P-dependent Golgi carrier formation), CASD1 (sialic-acid O-acetyltransferase), EXT2 (heparan-sulfate polymerase), MON1A and DNAJC13 (Rab7 activation and clathrin/endosome remodeling) together indicate boosted Golgi-to-endosome trafficking and glycosylation typical of cells actively secreting or recycling membrane proteins. • Cytoskeleton/actin dynamics needed for membrane remodeling – SSH1 (cofilin phosphatase) and SCLT1 (distal‐appendage protein required for ciliogenesis and vesicle docking) support a trafficking/ciliary interface. • Elevated translational and mitochondrial protein-synthesis capacity – EEF1AKMT2 (methylates eEF1A to enhance cytosolic translation), MRPS18A and the mitochondrial amino-acyl-tRNA synthetase YARS2 point to increased global and mitochondrial translation, a hallmark of high metabolic/secretory demand. • Secreted or metabolically active enzymes – RNLS (renalase) is a secreted flavoprotein whose expression rises in metabolically active epithelia (kidney, pancreas), aligning with an overall secretory phenotype. Inconsistencies: No strongly lineage-defining markers (e.g., nephron, airway, immune, stromal, neuronal) are present, so while the program fits a high secretory/trafficking state, it does not uniquely specify a single differentiated cell type.

program_37.description: The gene constellation most closely fits an “activated, cytokine-responsive T/NK-cell” program characterized by strong common γ-chain signaling capacity and expression of trafficking/activation molecules that enable these lymphocytes to home to inflamed tissue. Evidence: • IL2RG (common γ-chain) + TXK (TEC-family kinase driving IFN-γ/Th1 responses) – canonical for T cells, NK cells and other innate-like lymphocytes reliant on IL-2/IL-15 signaling. • CD38 – surface ectoenzyme strongly up-regulated on recently activated T and NK cells. • CXCR2 – chemokine receptor that, while best known in neutrophils, is induced on activated T/NK subsets to promote migration toward CXCL8-rich inflammatory sites. • PCSK7, SPINT2, PLAAT4, OSBP – protease regulators and lipid-handling genes frequently induced during lymphocyte activation and membrane remodeling, supporting cytokine/chemokine receptor turnover. • Broadly expressed cytoskeletal/transport genes (TPM4, DYNLT2B) and chromatin/cofactor components (RBBP7, DCAF8, CCDC71L) are typical of a metabolically active, proliferating immune cell state. Inconsistencies: • CXCR2 is classically neutrophil-specific; its presence suggests either a specialized CXCR2⁺ T/NK subset or possible admixture of granulocytic signals. • SELENOW and SPINT2 are more commonly described in epithelial or stromal contexts and are not quintessential lymphocyte markers, indicating that some genes in the program are more generic activation/stress responders rather than lineage-defining.

program_38.description: The gene set is most consistent with a generic “house-keeping / metabolic–proliferative” program that is up-regulated in cells entering an activated or cycling state, frequently observed across many immune cell types. Evidence: • RNA processing / translation → DDX23 (spliceosome), EEF1AKMT1 (elongation-factor methyltransferase), SFI1 (centrosome–duplication protein) all rise during cell-cycle entry and biosynthetic up-shift. • Mitochondrial biogenesis / energy production → TIMM22 (protein import into the inner mitochondrial membrane) and FDX2 (Fe-S cluster biogenesis) support increased oxidative metabolism typical of cycling cells. • Lipid and carbohydrate metabolism → OSBPL10 (cholesterol/oxysterol transport) and GALT (galactose metabolism) indicate broad metabolic re-wiring. • Cytoskeleton / Hippo pathway components associated with morphologic change during proliferation → PPP1R12B (myosin phosphatase targeting subunit) and WWC3 (Hippo regulator). • Immune-cell context → NR2F6 (nuclear receptor enriched in activated T and B lymphocytes) and CD300C (immunoglobulin super-family receptor on myeloid/B/NK cells) suggest the program is being executed in hematopoietic rather than parenchymal cells. Inconsistencies: • NR2F6 and CD300C are lineage-restricted immune genes not strictly required for a universal housekeeping program, implying some cell-type bias (lymphoid/myeloid) rather than a pure, lineage-agnostic proliferation module.

program_39.description: The gene constellation points to a generic “mitochondrial maintenance / oxidative-stress” program that is typically up-regulated in highly proliferative or metabolically stressed cells (e.g. cycling progenitors or tumor cells) that must expand mitochondrial mass, safeguard electron-transport activity and repair oxidative DNA damage while sustaining elevated RNA turnover. Evidence: • Mitochondrial biogenesis & quality control – FASTKD5 and DNAJC30 (mitochondrial RNA processing and complex-I repair), MTFR1 (mitochondrial fission/biogenesis), FAHD2A (mitochondrial hydrolase). • Elevated ribosome and mRNA handling – BYSL (40 S ribosome assembly), NCBP1 (nuclear cap-binding, mRNA export) consistent with high global transcription/translation that accompanies cell cycling. • Oxidative DNA repair – NEIL1 excises oxidized bases produced during intense respiration. • Proliferation / proteostasis regulators – DCUN1D5 (cullin neddylation, supports cell-cycle ubiquitin ligases), PRDM10 (transcriptional regulator), ZNF511 (zinc-finger TF), collectively linked to growth programs. • Cytoprotective transport & signaling – ABCC10 (xenobiotic/drug efflux), SH3KBP1 (CIN85 adaptor in receptor endocytosis) help resist stressors encountered by rapidly dividing cells. Inconsistencies: • No classic cell-cycle markers (MKI67, MCMs) or core OXPHOS structural genes are present, so the program appears focused on mitochondrial upkeep rather than full proliferative machinery. • SH3KBP1 and ABCC10 are not mitochondria-centric; they may reflect ancillary survival pathways rather than the core program.

program_40.description: The gene set most consistently reflects a stress-adaptation program characterized by activation of the endoplasmic-reticulum (ER) unfolded-protein response (UPR) together with lipid and cytoskeletal remodeling, a state commonly seen in highly secretory or otherwise stressed epithelial and immune cells rather than defining a unique lineage. Evidence: • ER stress / UPR core – ERN1 (IRE1) is the canonical ER-stress sensor that initiates the UPR. – MOGS encodes the first enzyme of N-linked glycan trimming in the ER, up-regulated during protein-folding load. – ADCK5 and RAI1 are induced by cellular stress and contribute to ER/mitochondrial adaptive signaling. • Lipid and metabolic remodeling accompanying secretory stress – ACSL5 activates long-chain fatty acids for phospholipid synthesis, supporting expansion of ER membranes. – GALK2 participates in galactose salvage for glycoprotein synthesis. • Cytoskeletal and trafficking changes typical of cells adapting to secretory demand or stress – SEPTIN8, ARHGEF1, and ARHGEF5 regulate Rho-GTPase–dependent actin dynamics and vesicle traffic. • Transcriptional regulators linked to stress responses – ZNF76, MYNN, and KBTBD4 are zinc-finger/B-TB proteins reported to modulate gene expression during differentiation or stress. Inconsistencies: • CHST7 (a glycosaminoglycan sulfotransferase enriched in cartilage/chondrocytes) and MYNN (muscle-associated) are not classical UPR markers, suggesting either broader metabolic remodeling or low-level contamination from other cell programs.

program_41.description: The gene set represents a generic “house-keeping / high biosynthetic activity” program rather than a lineage-restricted signature. It combines factors that support efficient transcription by RNA-pol II, co-transcriptional RNA processing, organelle (Golgi, endosome, mitochondrion) function and protein trafficking—features that rise together in cells that are globally transcriptionally active (e.g., metabolically active or proliferating cells of many lineages). Evidence: • RNA and chromatin handling – PRPF39 (pre-mRNA splicing), INTS11 (Integrator 3′-end processing), SRCAP (chromatin-remodelling), UVSSA (transcription-coupled repair) all rise with increased transcriptional throughput. • RNA/ribosome methylation – METTL2B (tRNA), METTL17 (mitochondrial rRNA) support elevated translation capacity. • Organelle and vesicle trafficking – AP3S2 (AP-3 complex), GOLGA1 (Golgi matrix), ZFYVE26 (FYVE-domain endosomal protein) are up-regulated when secretory/Golgi flux is high. • Mitochondrial maintenance – AFG1L (AAA-ATPase quality control) and METTL17 point to boosted mitochondrial biogenesis that accompanies high biosynthetic demand. • Signal-dependent transcription boost – STAT5B, a cytokine-activated TF, often accompanies growth-factor driven expansion and heightened metabolic programs. • Cytoskeletal remodeling – ARHGEF5 supports Rho-GTPase–mediated actin changes typical of motile or dividing cells. Inconsistencies: • The list lacks classical cell-cycle genes (MKI67, MCMs, TOP2A) and lacks lineage-defining markers; thus STAT5B’s immune association is not reinforced, suggesting it is contributing here mainly to generic growth-factor signalling rather than a specific immune identity.

program_42.description: The gene set most consistently reflects a generic genotoxic-stress / DNA-damage-repair and cell-survival program that is frequently seen in rapidly-proliferating or stressed tumor and stromal cells rather than a lineage-restricted identity. Evidence: • DNA-damage sensing & repair – PARG (poly-ADP ribose turnover after PARP activation), UBQLN4 (recruited to double-strand breaks; promotes homologous recombination), COPS7B and UBR3 (ubiquitin/COP9 signalosome components that modulate DNA-repair protein turnover). • Anti-apoptotic survival – BCL2L2 (Bcl-w) directly blocks intrinsic apoptosis, fitting a pro-survival stress program. • Biosynthetic/replicative support – NOL6 (ribosome biogenesis), POLR3E (RNA-pol III subunit), CNTROB (centrosome & S-phase progression) indicate heightened proliferation accompanying repair. • Proteostasis / lipid trafficking often up-regulated under stress – UBQLN4, OSBPL9, SLC45A4 support protein- and membrane-homeostasis needed during recovery from damage. • Microenvironmental adaptation – ANGPT4 (angiogenic growth factor) is frequently induced in hypoxic, DNA-damaged tumor regions, cohering with a stress/repair context. Inconsistencies: • ANGPT4 is most classical for endothelial or adipocyte secretion, not a core DNA-repair gene. • The set lacks canonical heat-shock or oxidative-stress transcripts (HSPA1A, DDIT3, etc.), so it may represent only one facet (DNA repair/pro-survival) of a broader stress response.

program_43.description: The program most closely reflects an early-activation state of T lymphocytes (CD7⁺, CD69⁺), consistent with metabolic and transcriptional re-wiring that accompanies recent antigen stimulation; it is antithetical to a microglial signature, as shown by strong negative loading of the microglia marker P2RY12. Evidence: • T-cell identity and activation – CD7 and the early activation/retention marker CD69 are both strongly positively loaded. • Immediate-early / activation-induced regulators – TSC22D1, DHX9, SRCAP and ZNF839 are transcriptional or chromatin-remodelling factors up-regulated upon lymphocyte stimulation. • Metabolic reprogramming typical of activated T cells – LPIN1 (lipid metabolism), ATP9A (phospholipid flippase) and APOO (mitochondrial lipid protein) rise as T cells switch to anabolic lipid synthesis after activation. • Anti-microglial bias – The canonical microglia purinergic receptor P2RY12 is negatively loaded, supporting that this program marks T cells rather than CNS-resident microglia. Inconsistencies: • Most remaining genes (e.g. PCSK7, CEP295, C1orf56) are broadly expressed and not T-cell-specific; while not contradictory, they are merely non-informative for cell identity.

program_44.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated mesenchymal / myofibroblast-like state characterized by cytoskeletal remodeling and increased protein-folding capacity, as seen in fibroblasts responding to profibrotic cues such as TGF-β. Evidence: • Cytoskeletal contractility and Rho-GTPase signaling typical of myofibroblasts – MPRIP, ARHGEF5, DTNA and INPP5B all regulate actin stress-fiber formation or phosphoinositide-controlled membrane dynamics. • Profibrotic/TGF-β axis – LEMD3 (MAN1) and LZTFL1 modulate TGF-β/SMAD and hedgehog pathways and are highly expressed in lung and dermal fibroblasts undergoing activation. • Enhanced secretory / protein-folding machinery found in matrix-producing fibroblasts – DNAJC10 (ER disulfide isomerase co-chaperone), GRPEL2 (mitochondrial chaperone), DNAJB2 (HSP40 family) and POLR3E (Pol III subunit supporting high transcriptional output). • Interferon-inducible GTPase IRGQ is frequently up-regulated in stromal cells during tissue injury, fitting an activated fibroblast response to inflammatory cytokines. Inconsistencies: • DNAJB2 and DTNA are best known for neuronal or muscle expression, and IRGQ is classically immune-associated; their presence is atypical but can occur in stressed or trans-differentiating fibroblasts.

program_45.description: The gene set captures a robust type I interferon–stimulated (antiviral) transcriptional program, reflecting cells in an “interferon-activated/viral-response” state rather than a specific lineage identity. Evidence: • Canonical ISGs: ISG15, MX1, IFIT1/2/3, IFI44L, RSAD2 (Viperin), LY6E, CMPK2 and HERC5 are well-established direct targets of type I IFN signaling and collectively define interferon activation across many cell types. • Antiviral restriction/apoptosis components: XAF1 (pro-apoptotic, IFN-inducible) and EPSTI1 (IFN-inducible adaptor promoting antiviral responses) reinforce an IFN-driven antiviral state. • Additional ISG support: NEXN has been reported to be up-regulated by IFN in multiple datasets, fitting the same program. Inconsistencies: • No strongly discordant genes are present; all listed genes are compatible with an interferon-stimulated antiviral program.

program_46.description: The gene set most closely matches a generic “organelle quality-control / autophagy” program that can be activated in many cell types when nutrient or oxidative stress increases the need for mitochondrial repair, endosomal trafficking and protein turnover; it is not lineage-specific but reflects a transient cell state centered on vesicle-mediated transport and proteostasis. Evidence: • Autophagy core: MAP1LC3A (LC3-I/II) is a canonical autophagosome membrane protein up-regulated when autophagy is induced. • Endosomal/vesicle trafficking: RIN1 (activator of RAB5), AP4B1 (adaptor-protein complex 4 subunit) and SUN1 (nuclear–cytoskeletal LINC component important for autophagosome–nucleus contacts) support enhanced membrane flow. • Proteostasis / ubiquitin pathway: RNF4 (SUMO-targeted ubiquitin ligase) and DNAJC30 (mitochondrial HSP40 co-chaperone) facilitate removal or refolding of damaged proteins. • Mitochondrial and metabolic support: ILVBL and DNAJC30 are mitochondrial; SLC20A1 (phosphate) and SLC26A11 (anion) transporters supply substrates for ATP synthesis and pH control during increased metabolic turnover. • Additional housekeeping/splicing factors (PRPF39, ZNF555, ANKMY1) are frequently co-expressed with stress‐responsive proteostasis genes, consistent with a broad “maintenance” program. Inconsistencies: • No strong lineage markers (e.g., EPCAM, CD3D, MBP) are present, so the program does not specify a particular cell type. • ZNF555 and ANKMY1 have poorly defined roles in autophagy or trafficking, but their presence does not conflict with the overall stress-response theme.

program_47.description: The gene set is most consistent with an epithelial cell program centered on primary-cilium/centrosome assembly and associated planar-cell-polarity signaling, a profile typical of kidney tubular and other ciliated epithelial cells that are metabolically active and undergoing organelle biogenesis. Evidence: • Ciliogenesis/centrosome genes – KIAA0586 (TALPID3), CCDC171 and CCDC71L are core centriolar-satellite factors required for primary-cilium formation; PKD1 encodes the ciliary membrane receptor polycystin-1 found in renal and other ciliated epithelia. • Polarity / Wnt interface – CCNY (Cyclin Y) activates CDK14 to promote Wnt/planar-cell-polarity signaling, a pathway tightly linked to ciliated epithelial differentiation. • Cytoskeleton & membrane remodeling needed for basal-body docking – ARHGAP15 (Rho-GAP) and PLEKHO1 (CKIP-1) regulate actin dynamics and membrane organization during ciliogenesis. • Biosynthetic support for organelle assembly – WDR18 and NOP14 (small-subunit processome) drive rRNA maturation, while SRCAP (chromatin remodeler) and PIGV (GPI-anchor synthesis) supply chromatin and membrane components, respectively, consistent with cells building new organelles. Inconsistencies: • CARD8 is best known as an inflammasome modulator in myeloid cells, and ARHGAP15 is enriched in neutrophils; their presence could reflect broader epithelial expression or low-level contamination. • Classic intraflagellar-transport genes (e.g., IFT family) are absent, so the program may represent only a partial ciliogenesis signature or a dataset with limited gene coverage.

program_48.description: The gene set chiefly represents a generic “housekeeping/ RNA-processing” program characteristic of metabolically active cells rather than of a specific lineage; it reflects enhanced ribosome biogenesis, RNA splicing, nucleocytoplasmic transport and ubiquitin-mediated protein quality control that many cell types switch on when they increase biosynthetic activity. Evidence: • Ribosome biogenesis / nucleolar: WDR3 (ribosome assembly), ERI2 (rRNA exonuclease). • RNA splicing machinery: GEMIN8 and ATXN7L3B (components of the SMN/SAGA complexes). • Nucleocytoplasmic transport: RANGAP1 (Ran-GTP cycle). • Ubiquitin–proteasome regulation: TRIM23 and ASB7 (E3 ubiquitin ligases) support heightened protein quality control. • Cytoskeleton remodeling often accompanying high biosynthetic states: CFL2 (actin-binding). • General metabolic/secretory support: PAM (peptidyl-glycine amidation in secretory pathway). These coordinated functions point to an overall increase in core cellular metabolism rather than to a lineage-restricted program. Inconsistencies: • CFL2 is classically muscle-enriched, DNAL1 is typical of motile-ciliated cells, and PAM is neuroendocrine-biased; their presence argues that the program is not confined to one differentiated lineage. • Lack of canonical markers for proliferation (e.g., MKI67, TOP2A) or for specific immune/epithelial/muscle pathways suggests that the signature is a broad housekeeping state rather than a defined cell type–specific program.

program_49.description: The gene set most consistently reflects a generalized genotoxic- and metabolic-stress response that is frequently observed in proliferating cells experiencing replication strain or oxidative damage. Core components of the program couple DNA replication/repair enzymes with mitochondrial RNA/energy–maintenance factors and pro-apoptotic signaling, indicating cells that are still cycling but are primed for DNA-damage repair and, if needed, apoptosis rather than a lineage-restricted differentiation state. Evidence: • DNA replication / repair: LIG1 (Okazaki-fragment ligation), TOP3A (resolves replication and recombination intermediates), MBTD1 (TIP60 complex member recruited to DNA double-strand breaks). • DNA-damage / stress signaling: DUSP8 (MAPK phosphatase induced by oxidative stress), STK35 (hypoxia-responsive kinase that arrests cell cycle under stress), BAK1 (p53-inducible, pro-apoptotic mitochondrial pore protein). • Mitochondrial homeostasis: FASTKD3 (mitochondrial RNA maturation), TOP3A mitochondrial isoform (mtDNA maintenance), TMEM63B (stress-activated cation channel affecting mitochondrial Ca2+), DDHD2 (phospholipase linked to mitochondrial lipid handling). • Protein quality / ubiquitin: MIB2 (E3 ligase modulating Notch/NF-κB during stress). Together these positively loaded genes point to cells mounting a coordinated replication-repair, mitochondrial-maintenance and apoptotic-priming program characteristic of replication or oxidative stress. Inconsistencies: • DPCD (cilia assembly factor) and ZNF865 (poorly characterized zinc-finger) are not obviously linked to DNA-damage or mitochondrial stress and may reflect cell-type–specific background expression rather than the core program.

program_50.description: The gene set is most consistent with a generic “chromatin-remodeling/G1-S transition” program that marks cells preparing for or undergoing DNA replication, a state commonly observed in cycling progenitors of many lineages rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. Evidence: • Cell-cycle entry / S-phase preparation: USP37 (de-ubiquitinates CDT1 to license DNA replication), replication-dependent linker histones H1-3 and H1-4, and the chromatin remodeler BICRA together indicate heightened chromatin assembly that accompanies S-phase. • Broad chromatin regulation: KDM5C (H3K4 demethylase controlling transcription of proliferation genes) and GTF3C1 (Pol III transcription factor) are hallmarks of cells with active chromatin remodeling and ribosomal/transcriptional up-scaling. • Cytoskeletal and metabolic support for division: MPRIP (actin/myosin phosphoregulation) and PREPL (amino-peptidase linked to energy metabolism) often rise in proliferating cells. Inconsistencies: • Immune-enriched genes such as FGD2 (myeloid GEF), PLAAT4 (IFN-inducible phospholipase), and FKBP11 (ER stress chaperone enriched in plasma/secretory cells) are not classical cell-cycle markers, suggesting either mixed cell populations or secondary signaling superimposed on the proliferative program.

program_51.description: The gene set best fits a neuronal-specific signaling and metabolic program characteristic of mature, relatively quiescent neurons that are poised for cAMP/PKA-dependent plasticity and ephrin-mediated cell-cell communication while showing low mitochondrial protein-import activity. Evidence: • Neuronal cAMP/PKA axis – PRKAR2B (brain-enriched PKA regulatory subunit) and PQBP1 (synapse-associated transcriptional co-activator) are both strongly expressed in differentiated neurons. • Synaptic/axon guidance components – EFNB1 (Ephrin-B1 ligand guiding axons and dendritic spine formation) and NEURL4 (E3 ligase family member implicated in neural development) point to a neuronal communication context. • Metabolic enzymes with documented neuroprotective roles – GDPGP1 (regulates neuronal glycogen to preserve energy under stress) and ACAD8 (mitochondrial branched-chain fatty-acid oxidation supporting neuronal energy demands). • Membrane remodeling needed for neurotransmission – ATP11C (phosphatidyl-serine flippase active in neurons) and ARAP2 (Arf/Rho GAP that modulates actin cytoskeleton at synapses). • Epigenetic plasticity – HDAC3 participates in activity-dependent chromatin remodeling in neurons. • Negative loading of TIMM10B, a key component of the mitochondrial inner-membrane translocase, is consistent with neurons that are not actively expanding their mitochondrial import capacity, fitting a relatively quiescent but mature state. Inconsistencies: • ACAD8 and ATP11C are not strictly neuron-restricted and can be expressed in metabolically active non-neuronal tissues (e.g., liver, B cells). • The program lacks classic neuronal structural genes (e.g., MAP2, NEFL); thus, while supportive, the evidence is not exclusively neuronal.

program_52.description: The gene set most closely matches a vesicle-trafficking / antigen-presentation program commonly seen in professional antigen-presenting myeloid cells (dendritic cells and macrophages) preparing or sustaining MHC-II presentation and cytokine/JAK-STAT signaling rather than marking a lineage-restricted cell type per se. Evidence: • ARL14EP – myeloid-restricted effector that tethers MHC-II-containing late endosomes in dendritic cells and macrophages. • RBSN and AP1G2 – core endosomal/Golgi adaptors that control cargo sorting to late endosomes, a step required for peptide loading onto MHC-II. • MAP4K2 (GCK) and SH2B1 – kinases/adaptors activated downstream of TNF-α, B-cell or cytokine receptors, pathways typically heightened in activated APCs. • CDIP1 – p53-inducible pro-apoptotic factor frequently co-expressed with immune activation/stress programs. • General trafficking and translational-regulatory genes (TARBP2, ARL14EP, RBSN, AP1G2, APEH, HYPK) together point to an intracellular remodeling rather than a lineage-specific housekeeping signature. Inconsistencies: • MXRA7 (matrix-remodeling protein) and PER3 (circadian clock component) are not APC-specific and may reflect tissue context or circadian variation. • Most genes are broadly expressed; absence of canonical APC markers (e.g., HLA-DRA, CD74, CIITA) limits specificity, so the program could also represent a more generic endosomal/secretory stress response.

program_53.description: The gene set most consistently points to a generic proliferative program enriched for centrosome/centriole biogenesis and late-G2/M cell-cycle activity rather than to a specialized differentiated cell type. Evidence: • Centrosome and spindle assembly – CEP192 and SFI1 are core structural regulators of centriole maturation and mitotic spindle formation, hallmarks of G2/M-phase cells. • Cell-cycle/ubiquitin control – AREL1 (an E3 ubiquitin ligase) and CDKN2AIPNL (interacts with the p21 pathway) participate in regulating progression through mitosis. • Bioenergetic support – COQ8B (coenzyme-Q biosynthesis) and GALT (galactose metabolism) supply mitochondrial electron transport and glycolytic precursors needed for dividing cells. • Ancillary stress-/DNA-associated genes – HMBOX1 (chromatin/telomere binding) and ARMC5 (tumor-suppressor linked to proliferation control) are commonly up-regulated in actively cycling cells. Inconsistencies: • EDRF1 (erythroid transcriptional regulator) suggests erythroid lineage, and CD300C (immune receptor) suggests myeloid/B-cell identity; these lineage-biased genes are not obviously related to the core mitotic program. • CAPN15 (neuronal calpain) and the adrenal tumor-suppressor ARMC5 are less frequently linked to cell-cycle signatures, indicating some gene-list noise or mixed lineage expression.

program_54.description: The gene set reflects a ciliogenesis/microtubule-Golgi organization program characteristic of ciliated epithelial cells (e.g., airway or ependymal cells) or cells actively assembling/maintaining a primary or motile cilium. Evidence: • Core cilia machinery – IFT22 (intraflagellar transport B sub-complex), CCDC28B (Bardet–Biedl syndrome–associated centrosomal protein), HTT (scaffold that promotes basal-body docking and cilium elongation). • Microtubule stabilization needed for axoneme growth – EML4 (microtubule-binding), ARHGEF5 (Rho GEF coordinating actin–microtubule interactions during basal-body migration). • Golgi/vesicle trafficking that supplies membrane to the growing cilium – GORASP2 (Golgi stacking/re-assembly), FHIP2B (endosome–Golgi tether). • Organelle and protein-quality support frequently up-regulated in ciliogenesis – PMPCA (mitochondrial protein processing), USP13 (de-ubiquitination, mitophagy), WDR77/MEP50 (PRMT5 co-factor regulating ciliogenesis genes). • Transcriptional/regulatory component – ZNF496 likely coordinates expression of parts of the program. Inconsistencies: • The program lacks classic multiciliated markers such as FOXJ1 or DNAH genes; thus it may represent an early or partial ciliogenesis state, or a primary-cilium program rather than fully differentiated multiciliated cells. • Several genes (e.g., USP13, ZNF496) are broadly expressed and not cilia-restricted, though their supporting roles do not conflict with a ciliogenesis signature.

program_55.description: The gene set most parsimoniously fits a generic “biosynthetic / proteostasis” program seen in cells that have ramped-up ribosome biogenesis, mitochondrial translation, ER chaperoning and vesicle trafficking—features common to highly active, cytokine-stimulated cells (e.g., proliferating or secretory epithelial / immune cells) rather than to a lineage-restricted identity. Evidence: • Ribosome biogenesis – WDR12 (PeBoW complex), BMT2/BUD23 (18S-rRNA methyltransferase) and MRPS9 (mitochondrial small-subunit protein) together signal increased production of cytosolic and mitochondrial ribosomes. • Protein folding / quality control – DNAJB9 (ERdj4, UPR chaperone), UBR3 (N-end–rule E3 ligase) and MVB12A (ESCRT-I component) point to elevated ER stress handling and protein turnover. • Cytokine-driven growth signalling – STAT5B is a canonical effector of IL-2/IL-7/growth-hormone pathways that typically accompanies heightened biosynthetic demand. • Ancillary support for a high metabolic state – ZNF736 (nuclear zinc-finger), TCTN1 (cilia/hedgehog interface) and RNLS (secreted oxidase) are frequently co-expressed in metabolically active tissues. • Negative loading of DCAF10 (CUL4 adaptor) suggests selective dampening of a subset of ubiquitin-mediated degradation, consistent with a shift toward net protein accumulation. Inconsistencies: • RNLS (renalase) and TCTN1 (cilia protein) are not directly tied to ribosome or UPR pathways and may reflect tissue-specific background expression. • The program lacks classic lineage markers, indicating it represents a state (high biosynthetic load) rather than a distinct cell type.

program_56.description: The gene set best fits a generic “biosynthetic/secretory up-regulation” program that accompanies metabolically active, often cycling or recently activated cells across multiple lineages rather than pointing to a single differentiated cell type. The coordinated increase in RNA-modifying/translation factors, ER–Golgi trafficking components, lipid-metabolic enzymes and mitochondrial chaperones suggests cells that are boosting protein synthesis and vesicular transport—features typically seen in progenitor cells entering the cell cycle or in immune and other cells after activation. Evidence: • METTL1, EIF2D – tRNA m^7G methyltransferase and translation-initiation factor that rise when global protein synthesis is elevated. • GBF1, SMPD2, CC2D1A – core ER/Golgi and endosomal regulators that expand during increased secretory-pathway flux. • DNAJC30 – mitochondrial chaperone needed for oxidative phosphorylation up-shift that accompanies high anabolic demand. • PPP2R5D – PP2A B-subunit modulating cell-cycle and growth-factor signalling. • IGSF8 – tetraspanin-associated adhesion/exosome protein often enriched when vesicle production and membrane remodelling increase. • DHRS11, NIPAL3, ZNF84 – metabolic and transcriptional modifiers frequently co-expressed in high-metabolic-rate states. Inconsistencies: • Lack of classical proliferation markers (e.g., MKI67, TOP2A) or lineage-defining transcripts means the program is not uniquely tied to a specific cell type or a fully committed cell-cycle module. • No clear stress-response genes (e.g., ATF4, HSPA5) that would define an unfolded-protein or ER-stress signature, so the program may represent routine rather than stress-induced biosynthetic activity.

program_57.description: The gene set is most consistent with a “centrosome / early ciliogenesis” program that becomes prominent in proliferating epithelial progenitors preparing to assemble a primary cilium (e.g., cycling airway or neuroepithelial precursors). The enrichment of multiple basal-body and centrosomal scaffold components together with genes that support membrane trafficking, transcriptional drive and mitochondrial energy production suggests cells poised to exit mitosis and build a ciliary axoneme, rather than a lineage-specific differentiated state. Evidence: • Centrosome & basal-body assembly – CCDC171, KIAA0586/TALPID3 and CEP43 are core structural proteins required for centriole cohesion and docking that initiate primary cilium formation. • Cell-cycle/transcriptional support – CCNC (Cyclin C) drives G1 progression and enhances Mediator-dependent transcription, a common feature of proliferating progenitors before ciliogenesis. • Membrane trafficking for cilium extension – DENND4B is a RAB10 GEF implicated in polarized vesicle delivery to the plasma membrane/ciliary pocket. • Metabolic supply – SUCLA2 (TCA cycle) and DHDDS (dolichol pathway for glycoprotein synthesis) provide ATP and lipid precursors needed for building the ciliary membrane. • RNA surveillance/antiviral stress that often accompanies epithelial progenitors – SKIC3 (WDR61) and SHFL are interferon-inducible genes frequently co-expressed in ciliated epithelium. Inconsistencies: • DTNA (dystrobrevin α) is classically enriched in muscle sarcolemma, not centrosome biology. • SHFL is an antiviral effector rather than a structural ciliary protein, suggesting a parallel interferon response rather than pure ciliogenesis. • The program lacks canonical multiciliogenesis regulators (e.g., FOXJ1, MCIDAS), indicating it represents early primary-cilium assembly rather than terminally differentiated multiciliated cells.

program_58.description: The gene set most closely aligns with a generic “house-keeping / cellular homeostasis” program that is detected in many fully differentiated, non-proliferative cells. It reflects constitutive RNA processing, ER–Golgi and endosomal trafficking, basal proteolysis and cytoskeletal maintenance rather than a lineage-restricted identity. Evidence: • RNA maturation/core transcription – CPSF4 (3′-end cleavage-polyadenylation), TCF3 (broad transcription factor), THAP6 (nuclear DNA-binding). • Organelle and vesicle trafficking – CREB3 (ER-stress/secretory pathway transcription factor), SNX19 and ENTR1 (endosomal sorting/recycling), CEP41 (centrosome–microtubule organisation). • Metabolic & proteolytic maintenance – OSGEPL1 (mitochondrial tRNA modification), THOP1 (cytosolic oligo-peptidase), MFSD11 (major facilitator transporter). • Cytoskeletal anchoring – DTNA (dystrobrevin, cytoskeleton–membrane scaffold). Inconsistencies: • DTNA and MFSD11 show highest expression in muscle/neuronal tissues, and CEP41 is cilia-associated, which could hint at a mild bias toward excitable cells; however, the majority of genes are ubiquitous, supporting a broad housekeeping rather than a cell-type-specific program.

program_59.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated innate-immune (monocyte / macrophage–like) program that couples inflammatory signalling with heightened mitochondrial activity and secretory/trafficking capacity. Evidence: • HPGDS – cytosolic prostaglandin-D synthase that is selectively induced in activated macrophages, dendritic cells and other myeloid cells to generate PGD2 during inflammation. • NKIRAS1, TRIM41, MAPKAPK5 – regulators of NF-κB or p38-MAPK cascades that are typically up-regulated during myeloid cell activation. • RIPOR1 – Rho-GTPase effector controlling polarity and migration of neutrophils and macrophages, supporting a motile/activated state. • MTERF4, TRMT10B, TIMM23B – mitochondrial transcription, tRNA methylation and protein-import factors, indicating boosted mitochondrial biogenesis/oxidative metabolism seen in activated macrophages. • STX3, INPP5K, EPM2AIP1 – components of vesicle trafficking, phosphoinositide and glycogen metabolism that facilitate cytokine secretion and energy supply in stimulated myeloid cells. Inconsistencies: • Classical macrophage markers (e.g., LYZ, CSF1R) or mast-cell proteases are absent, making the precise myeloid subset uncertain. • Several genes (e.g., STX3, INPP5K) are broadly expressed and could reflect a generic stress-mitochondrial response rather than a strictly lineage-specific program.

program_60.description: The gene set most closely matches an activated cytotoxic-lymphocyte (natural killer cell / cytotoxic CD8⁺ T cell) program characterized by assembly and polarized trafficking of lytic granules. Evidence: • NKG7 – canonical marker of NK cells and cytotoxic CD8⁺ T cells; encodes a membrane protein of lytic granules. • SCRIB, COG1, ARFGAP1, TOR4A, AAAS – proteins involved in cell polarity (SCRIB) and Golgi/ER vesicle budding, coatomer function or nuclear pore transport (COG1, ARFGAP1, TOR4A, AAAS), all prerequisites for directed granule biogenesis and exocytosis during target-cell killing. • EFCAB2, PUSL1 – calcium-binding/enzymatic modifiers that are broadly expressed but up-regulated in secretory states, consistent with heightened vesicle processing. Inconsistencies: • B9D2 (cilia/centrosome protein) and the general transcription factor ZNF266 lack a clear link to cytotoxic lymphocytes; their presence may reflect housekeeping or technical noise rather than lineage specificity.

program_61.description: The program most consistently reflects a generic “house-keeping / high biosynthetic activity” state rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. The genes point to ribosome assembly, chromatin regulation, membrane-lipid synthesis and vesicle trafficking—features that rise when cells are metabolically active or preparing for division. Evidence: • Ribosome and nucleolar biogenesis – TSR1 (20 S rRNA maturation), NPM3 and HGH1 (nucleolar chaperones) • Chromatin / transcription regulation – HDAC7 (histone deacetylase active in proliferating cells), ZNF184 (KRAB-domain transcription factor) • Membrane-lipid and vesicle remodeling – PTDSS2 (phosphatidylserine synthesis), AAGAB and CHMP6 (clathrin- and ESCRT-mediated vesicle trafficking) • Cytoskeletal and junction dynamics – DOCK4 (Rac/Rap GEF controlling adherens-junction remodeling) • Miscellaneous biosynthetic support – ARMT1 (DNA-damage–responsive methyltransferase) Inconsistencies: • No strong contradictions; the list lacks canonical lineage markers or classic S/G2-M cell-cycle genes (e.g., MKI67, TOP2A), so the program likely represents a broad metabolic module rather than a specific differentiated state.

program_62.description: The gene set is most consistent with a metabolically active, WNT-secreting stromal / fibroblast-like state in which cells up-regulate fatty-acid β-oxidation and peroxisome biogenesis together with ubiquitin-mediated protein-quality control and translational capacity—features typical of “activated” niche fibroblasts that support neighbouring epithelia. Evidence: • Stromal signalling – WNT2B encodes a secreted Wnt ligand that marks niche-forming fibroblasts in intestine, lung and other tissues. • Lipid catabolism / peroxisome biogenesis – ACADSB (branched-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase) and PEX1 (peroxisomal AAA-ATPase) together point to active peroxisomal β-oxidation, a hallmark of metabolically primed fibroblasts. • Protein homeostasis – ZYG11B and RNF25 are substrate adaptors/E3 ligases for CUL2 and NF-κB pathways, indicating heightened ubiquitin-proteasome turnover; EEF1AKMT2 methylates eEF1A and rises when translational output increases. • Cytoskeletal remodelling / division – SEPTIN8 (septin filament component) and XRRA1 (radiation-responsive DNA-damage/cell-cycle gene) reflect the cytoskeletal and cell-cycle adjustments typical of activated, proliferating stromal cells. • Additional support – ANKRD36B and PROSER1 are broadly expressed in myeloid-stromal compartments and often co-vary with the genes above in scRNA-seq datasets of fibroblasts under stimulatory conditions. Inconsistencies: • Classical fibroblast extracellular-matrix markers (e.g., COL1A1, COL3A1, FN1) are absent, so the programme may represent a metabolic/secretory sub-state rather than the full fibroblast identity. • SEPTIN8 is also enriched in neurons, and its presence here is not lineage-specific.

program_63.description: The gene set most closely reflects an MRTFA-driven actin-cytoskeleton/mechanotransduction program typical of cells that have adopted a motile, mesenchymal-like state such as activated fibroblasts or epithelial cells undergoing epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT). Evidence: • MRTFA (MKL1) – SRF co-activator that is a canonical driver of fibroblast/myofibroblast differentiation and EMT via actin-regulated nuclear shuttling. • PDLIM2 – LIM-domain actin-binding protein that links actin stress fibres to signalling and is up-regulated in motile, mesenchymal cells. • ACAP3 – ARF6-GAP required for membrane trafficking and cell migration; enriched when cells acquire mesenchymal motility. • CNEP1R1 – regulator of nuclear-ER membrane lipid synthesis needed for cytoskeletal remodelling and cell spreading. • PPP5C, MAU2 – stress-response phosphatase and cohesin loader, respectively, which are commonly co-induced with cytoskeletal remodelling and proliferation in activated fibroblasts.
