Inconsistencies: • Classic mesenchymal structural genes (e.g., ACTA2, COL1A1, VIM) are absent, and several genes (TRMT10B, DHX34, MMAA, N4BP2) are generic RNA- or metabolic-processing factors with no clear link to a mesenchymal program, limiting cell-type specificity.

program_64.description: The program most closely matches an MHC-II–high, metabolically active myeloid antigen-presenting cell (monocyte-derived macrophage / dendritic cell) state, characterized by robust antigen presentation, reactive-oxygen-species machinery, and enhanced lipid handling. Evidence: • Antigen presentation: HLA-DRB5 and HLA-DQA2 are canonical MHC class-II genes selectively up-regulated in professional antigen-presenting cells (macrophages, dendritic cells, B cells). • Myeloid lineage / phagocyte markers: CYBB (gp91phox, NADPH oxidase component), IGSF6, and ACE are well-documented monocyte–macrophage genes; CYBB is required for respiratory burst in phagocytes. • Lipid catabolism typical of macrophages: LIPA (lysosomal acid lipase) and FABP-family member FABP3 support cholesterol ester hydrolysis and fatty-acid trafficking during foam-cell or inflammatory macrophage responses. • Immunomodulatory receptors: LAIR2 (soluble collagen receptor decoy) and GSN (gelsolin, actin-remodeling protein up-regulated during phagocytosis) are expressed in activated myeloid cells. • Metabolic re-programming: FBP1, although classically hepatic, is induced in tolerogenic or metabolically re-wired dendritic cells and macrophages to support gluconeogenic flux and redox balance. Inconsistencies: • FABP3 is more prominent in muscle and cardiomyocytes than in myeloid cells, though low-level expression has been reported in certain macrophage subsets. • LAIR2 is primarily secreted by activated T/NK cells; its presence could reflect paracrine capture rather than transcription in myeloid cells. • High FBP1 is not universal to all macrophages and may indicate a specialized metabolic subset or contaminating hepatocyte signature.

program_65.description: The gene constellation is most consistent with a generic “high-biosynthetic / proliferative” transcriptional program that accompanies cells entering or progressing through the cell cycle, rather than marking a specific lineage; it reflects coordinated up-regulation of chromatin-remodelling factors, phospholipid and vesicle biogenesis enzymes, and RNA-processing molecules required to duplicate cellular contents before division. Evidence: • Chromatin remodelling / transcriptional activation needed for S-phase entry – KDM5C (H3K4 demethylase active during DNA replication), INO80D (core INO80 complex subunit that promotes replication fork progression). • Membrane and vesicle production for daughter cells – CDS1 (rate-limiting for phosphatidylinositol synthesis), COPZ2 (COPI coatomer subunit for Golgi–ER trafficking). • Enhanced RNA handling and translation of growth-related mRNAs – PRRC2A (stress-granule/translation regulator), RC3H1 (Roquin-1, post-transcriptional regulator of proliferation-linked transcripts). • Cytoskeletal and junctional rearrangements typical of dividing epithelial or other adherent cells – ARHGAP17 (Cdc42 GAP regulating tight-junction dynamics), ZZEF1 (microtubule-associated RNA-binding protein). • Additional metabolic / protein-turnover support – UBR3 (E3 ubiquitin ligase), FAHD2A (mitochondrial hydrolase). Inconsistencies: No strongly lineage-restricted markers are present, and no negatively loaded genes were supplied; thus no major inconsistencies are evident, but the program lacks classical cell-cycle genes (e.g., MKI67, TOP2A), suggesting it captures the biosynthetic rather than mitotic arm of proliferation.

program_66.description: The gene set is most consistent with a generic “intrinsic-stress / apoptotic-priming” program that can be activated in diverse cell types rather than marking a specific lineage. Multiple genes encode regulators of mitochondrial function, sphingolipid signalling and Bax-mediated apoptosis, while others dampen cytokine signalling or remodel the cytoskeleton—changes typically observed during early intrinsic stress responses. Evidence: • MOAP1 (direct Bax activator) + FASTKD3 (mitochondrial RNA homeostasis under stress) + SGPL1 (terminates pro-survival S1P signalling) → core machinery that lowers the threshold for intrinsic/mitochondrial apoptosis. • SOCS7 (cytokine-signalling brake induced by DNA damage) and ARHGEF5 (Rho-GEF up-regulated during stress‐driven cytoskeletal remodelling) support a stress-response milieu. • PPP1R35 (centriole surveillance) often rises during DNA-damage checkpoints, fitting a stress context. • Program lacks canonical proliferation (MKI67, TOP2A) or lineage (e.g., CD3E for T cells, EPCAM for epithelia) markers, consistent with a state rather than a cell type. • UTY indicates the cells are of male origin but is not lineage-specific, aligning with a broadly deployable stress program. Inconsistencies: • TMEM184B (neuronal maintenance) and RELL2 (immune-receptor family) are not classical stress-response genes; their presence suggests either cell-type–specific flavouring of the program or residual expression unrelated to the core apoptotic/stress module.

program_67.description: The gene set is most consistent with a generic oxidative-stress / DNA-damage response program that can be transiently induced in many cell types rather than marking a particular lineage. The signature couples NADPH production and reactive-oxygen detoxification (G6PD) with multiple DNA repair factors (NTHL1, WRAP53, UBQLN4), mitochondrial and peroxisomal homeostasis (BOLA3, PXMP2), and stress-associated protein-kinase and ubiquitin signaling (PRKX, PELI3), together with actin remodeling (ARPC1A) frequently engaged during cellular stress. Evidence: • Oxidative-stress metabolism: G6PD (rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose-phosphate pathway supplying NADPH for ROS detoxification); PXMP2 (peroxisomal membrane channel involved in ROS metabolism). • DNA-damage sensing/repair: NTHL1 (base-excision repair of oxidative lesions), WRAP53 (recruits repair machinery to DNA breaks), UBQLN4 (coordinates homologous-recombination repair). • Mitochondrial stress support: BOLA3 (Fe-S cluster assembly, defects lead to mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress). • Stress-activated signaling/ubiquitination: PRKX (cAMP-dependent kinase enhancing survival under stress), PELI3 (E3 ubiquitin ligase in Toll-like/innate stress pathways). • Cytoskeletal remodeling often accompanying stress: ARPC1A (Arp2/3 actin nucleation). Inconsistencies: • EXT1 (heparan-sulfate polymerase) mainly functions in extracellular matrix synthesis rather than classical stress responses. • ARPC1A and EXT1 are broadly expressed housekeeping genes and may reflect general metabolic activity rather than specific oxidative-stress induction. • PELI3 links more to innate immune signaling than direct oxidative DNA-repair pathways, but can be co-induced in inflammatory oxidative stress contexts.

program_68.description: The program most closely fits an activated, proliferating epithelial/basal-like cell state characterized by enhanced extracellular-matrix (ECM) remodeling and high metabolic activity. Evidence: • Epithelial identity / surface protease – ST14 (matriptase) is a hallmark trans-membrane serine protease of keratinocytes, intestinal and other epithelial progenitors. • ECM remodeling – BMP1 encodes a secreted metalloprotease that processes procollagens and other ECM components, typical of epithelial cells undergoing tissue remodeling or wound repair. • Cell-cycle machinery – ZWILCH (kinetochore), together with chromatin modifiers KDM6A and MTA1, indicates active proliferation. • Heightened mitochondrial & metabolic activity – PCCB (propionyl-CoA carboxylase), MCU (mitochondrial Ca²⁺ uniporter) and GDPGP1 point to increased oxidative metabolism supporting growth. • Transcriptional co-regulation – ZMIZ2 (AR/SMAD co-activator) further supports a transcriptionally active, differentiating epithelial program. Inconsistencies: • Several genes (MCU, GDPGP1) are broadly expressed metabolic factors and do not on their own specify epithelium, but they do not contradict the overall interpretation.

program_69.description: The gene set most consistently points to a generic “centrosome-cilium/cell-cycle” program that is typically enriched in proliferating cells that are preparing centriole duplication and, in quiescent phases, can also support primary-cilium assembly. It does not specify a particular lineage; rather, it marks a transient cell-state associated with S–G2/M progression and centrosome–cilium dynamics. Evidence: • Centrosome & ciliogenesis genes – CEP192 (centrosome maturation), TCTN1 and KIAA1328/FAM92A (transition-zone proteins needed for primary-cilium assembly) jointly indicate activity around the centrosome–cilium axis. • Cell-cycle/chromatin regulators – PTPA (PP2A activator that promotes mitotic entry), TADA2B (SAGA histone-acetyltransferase subunit), and NACC1 (nuclear factor supporting embryonic-stem-cell proliferation) are typically up-regulated in dividing cells. • Replicative maintenance – ZBTB48/TZAP (telomere trimming) and OAZ2 (polyamine homeostasis, rises with growth) support a proliferative context. Inconsistencies: • Metabolic genes such as CLYBL and PREPL are housekeeping enzymes without a direct link to centrosome/cilium or cell-cycle control, implying some nonspecific background expression.

program_70.description: The gene set is most consistent with a motile-ciliated epithelial program (e.g., airway or ependymal multiciliated cells) in which core ciliogenesis factors are co-expressed with genes that bolster mitochondrial function and proteostasis needed to fuel axoneme assembly. Evidence: • Ciliogenesis / motile cilia regulators – RFX3: master transcription factor that drives expression of motile-cilia genes in airway and ependymal epithelia. – SPAG1: dynein-assembly factor required for formation and motility of cilia and flagella. • Energetic and protein-quality control support typical of highly ciliated cells – CLUH and USP30: coordinate mitochondrial biogenesis and mitophagy, respectively, ensuring the high mitochondrial output demanded by cilium beating. – SGTA and COPS7B: co-chaperone (SGTA) and COP9 signalosome subunit (COPS7B) that assist folding and turnover of membrane and ciliary proteins. • General biosynthetic capacity – NOL6 (ribosome biogenesis) and PIGS (GPI-anchor synthesis) point to elevated protein production and membrane trafficking, processes up-regulated during ciliogenesis. Inconsistencies: • Most remaining genes (e.g., ZNF268, SH3YL1) are broadly expressed regulatory or cytoskeletal factors without specific links to cilia, suggesting some housekeeping or stress-response signal is intermixed with the core ciliogenesis program.

program_71.description: The gene set points to a proliferative progenitor-like state, typical of actively cycling epithelial (basal) cells that are ramping up DNA-repair and metabolic rewiring rather than to a differentiated lineage identity. Evidence: • Pro-proliferative transcription factors – KLF5 and YES1 drive cell-cycle entry, growth-factor signalling and are characteristically high in basal epithelial stem/progenitor compartments. • Chromatin / DNA-repair machinery – PHF8 (histone demethylase promoting S/G2 progression) and FAAP100 (Fanconi-anemia core complex) are induced when cells replicate DNA and repair replication-associated damage. • Nuclear-envelope organisation – SUN1 and NPIPB family members participate in LINC/nuclear-pore functions that are up-regulated during rapid nuclear remodelling of dividing cells. • Metabolic shift genes – PDK1 (HIF1 target that diverts pyruvate from the TCA cycle) together with mitochondrial chaperone DNAJC30 support the glycolytic/oxidative balance typically seen in highly proliferative epithelial progenitors. • General vesicle-trafficking/coated-pit protein NECAP1 is often co-expressed in rapidly cycling cells to sustain elevated membrane turnover. Inconsistencies: • NECAP1 is classically brain-enriched, so its presence is not entirely aligned with an epithelial program. • The absence of canonical S-phase markers (e.g., MCMs, PCNA) suggests the program reflects preparatory growth/DNA-repair rather than full cell-cycle gene expression.

program_72.description: The program most closely fits a metabolically active, differentiating neuronal population—likely excitatory neurons engaging in membrane/lipid remodeling and glycosyl-glycan maturation rather than a lineage-neutral “housekeeping” module. Evidence: • DAGLA – key synthase of the endocannabinoid 2-AG, highly enriched in glutamatergic neurons and linked to synaptic plasticity. • RAI1 – neurodevelopmental transcription regulator whose high expression is characteristic of developing and mature neurons. • POMGNT2 and UGDH – enzymes that generate and transfer sugar donors for O-mannosyl and glucuronic acid–containing glycans, processes up-regulated during neuronal maturation and axon guidance. • AP1G2 – γ-adaptin subunit supporting trans-Golgi/endosomal vesicle trafficking required for synaptic-vesicle protein sorting. • PSMD9 and ACAD8 – proteasome component and mitochondrial branched-chain–fatty-acid dehydrogenase, respectively, meeting the elevated proteostatic and energy demands of active neurons. Inconsistencies: • HMBOX1 is more typically associated with immune/NK cell transcriptional programs. • Absence of classic neuronal structural genes (e.g., MAP2, SNAP25) means the assignment, while plausible, is not unequivocal.

program_73.description: The gene set is most consistent with a proliferative, G2/M-biased program seen in actively cycling epithelial or progenitor-like cells that couple mitotic machinery with enhanced mitochondrial/ER lipid metabolism. Evidence: • Cell-cycle/mitotic apparatus – ZWILCH (spindle-assembly checkpoint), CCDC7 (E2F-driven proliferation factor), KLC2 (kinesin involved in chromosome/vesicle transport) all rise during G2/M. • Metabolic support for division – MTG2/GTPBP5 (mitochondrial ribosome biogenesis), ACSL5 (long-chain fatty-acid activation for membrane synthesis), ERLIN2 (ER-associated degradation and lipid homeostasis) provide energy and membranes needed for cell division. • Progenitor/Wnt-Notch context – TLE1 is a corepressor enriched in cycling progenitors and cancers, fitting a proliferative state. • Cytokine-modulatory node – SOCS7 limits cytokine signaling and is often induced in dividing cells to temper STAT activity, seen in proliferating epithelia. Inconsistencies: • Absence of many canonical S-phase genes (e.g., MCMs, PCNA) suggests this program captures only part of the full cell-cycle signature. • PCED1A function is poorly characterized and not clearly linked to proliferation, and SOCS7 is more immunomodulatory than cell-cycle specific, but neither contradict the overall proliferative interpretation.

program_74.description: The gene set points to a broadly “secretory / organelle-remodeling” program, characteristic of metabolically active cells that are ramping up ER/Golgi glycosylation, lipid modification of membrane proteins, and lysosome trafficking—features observed in highly secretory states (e.g., activated immune or stromal cells and many tumor cells) rather than a lineage-restricted signature. Evidence: • ER/Golgi glycosylation – ALG1 (N-linked mannosyl-transferase) and POFUT1 (O-fucosyl-transferase for Notch and other EGF-like repeats) mark increased protein glycosylation capacity. • Lipid modification of cargo – ZDHHC18 encodes a palmitoyl-transferase that adds palmitate to membrane proteins, a step tightly coupled to secretory trafficking. • Vesicle and lysosome positioning – BORCS6 is a BORC-complex subunit required for anterograde lysosome transport and exocytosis. • Signaling / metabolic activation – MAP4K2 (MAPK pathway kinase) and PDIK1L (PIK-related kinase) support growth-related signaling; POLRMT indicates boosted mitochondrial transcription to meet energy demands; MFSD5 provides additional membrane transport capacity. • Generic transcriptional support – ZNF316 adds nuclear regulatory input typical of active, proliferating cells. Inconsistencies: • No classical ER-stress chaperones (e.g., HSPA5, XBP1) are present, so the signature is more “baseline secretory machinery” than an unfolded-protein-response program. • The list lacks lineage-defining markers, making the program cell-state rather than cell-type specific.

program_75.description: The gene set reflects a stress-induced mitochondrial quality-control and autophagy program rather than a particular lineage; it marks cells that are actively turning over damaged mitochondria and proteins via ubiquitin–proteasome, endosomal sorting, and macro-autophagy pathways. Evidence: • Autophagy core component – EPG5 is essential for autophagosome–lysosome fusion, a hallmark of macro-autophagy. • Mitophagy/ubiquitin regulators – MARCHF5 (mitochondrial E3 ligase controlling fission and Parkin-independent mitophagy) and ANKRD13C (endosomal ubiquitin-binding adaptor) support organelle turnover. • Cullin-RING ligase cofactor – DCAF17 links damaged-protein ubiquitylation to proteasomal degradation, frequently up-regulated during cellular stress. • Mitochondrial metabolism – CA5B encodes the mitochondrial carbonic anhydrase VB, typical of cells boosting mitochondrial activity while coordinating pH for oxidative metabolism. • Organelle/mRNA maturation factors – SPOUT1 (methyltransferase) and CIR1 (Notch-interacting corepressor) are commonly co-induced in general stress programs to remodel transcription and translation. Inconsistencies: • FGD6 (Cdc42 GEF) is primarily known for cytoskeletal remodeling in endothelial cells; its role here is indirect, possibly facilitating actin-dependent autophagosome movement. • LYSMD3 is a pattern-recognition receptor for peptidoglycan and not classically linked to mitophagy, though immunity-related stress pathways can co-activate autophagy genes.

program_76.description: The gene set is most consistent with a myeloid antigen-presenting cell program—typical of monocyte-derived dendritic cells or macrophages—that is skewed toward a tolerogenic/anti-inflammatory or cellular‐stress state marked by enhanced vesicle/endosomal trafficking and dampened Toll-like/IL-1 signalling. Evidence: • Negative regulation of innate signals – SIGIRR (TIR-8) is an established inhibitor of TLR/IL-1R pathways, enriched in monocytes, macrophages and dendritic cells adopting an anti-inflammatory profile. • Cytoskeleton/chemotaxis control typical of myeloid cells – ARHGAP9 is highly expressed in neutrophils and monocytes, directing actin re-organisation during chemotaxis. • Vesicle and antigen-processing machinery – ANKRD27 (VARP) and AP4B1 (AP-4 complex) regulate endosomal trafficking and MHC cross-presentation, functions prominent in dendritic cells/macrophages. • Stress/DNA-damage-linked MAPK signalling often up-regulated during myeloid activation – MAP3K21 (ASK2/TPL2-related) and TP53I13 (p53-inducible) cooperate with TELO2 (PIKK complex stabiliser) in stress-response signalling cascades observed in activated or tolerogenic myeloid cells. • Metabolic support – BPGM supplies 2,3-BPG for glycolytic flux; while classically erythroid, it is detectable in glycolytically active myeloid populations, fitting a metabolically reprogrammed antigen-presenting cell. Inconsistencies: • BPGM is classically restricted to erythroid lineage; its inclusion may reflect either glycolytic up-regulation in myeloid cells or minor erythroid contamination, so lineage assignment should be interpreted cautiously.

program_77.description: The gene set most coherently fits an interferon-driven, antiviral/metabolic activation program that is frequently observed in recently activated lymphocytes (e.g., CD4⁺/CD8⁺ T cells) or other immune cells responding to viral cues; it reflects heightened antiviral restriction (APOBEC3G) together with the increased nucleotide turnover, ribosome biogenesis and vesicle/lysosomal trafficking needed to sustain activation and proliferation. Evidence: • APOBEC3G – classical interferon-stimulated cytidine deaminase that restricts retroviruses; highly expressed in activated T cells and other antiviral immune states. • DCTPP1, PRUNE1 – enzymes of nucleotide metabolism whose expression rises in cycling/activated cells to maintain dNTP homeostasis. • MDN1 – AAA ATPase essential for large‐subunit ribosome maturation; up-regulated during ribosome biogenesis surge accompanying lymphocyte activation. • VPS18 – HOPS complex member; increased vesicle/lysosomal trafficking is characteristic of immune activation and autophagy during antiviral responses. • ZNF76, SMYD4 – chromatin/transcription regulators commonly induced by interferon signalling and needed to reprogram gene expression in activated immune cells. Inconsistencies: • Absence of hallmark proliferation markers (e.g., MKI67, TOP2A) and broader interferon signature genes (e.g., IFIT1/3, ISG15) weakens—but does not exclude—the interpretation of a full interferon/proliferative program. • FAM131A and ANKS3 have no well-defined link to interferon or lymphocyte activation, suggesting they may be passenger genes in the loadings.

program_78.description: The gene set is most consistent with a growth-factor/RAS–PI3K–RHO signalling program that typifies cells in early G1 poised for proliferation and cytoskeletal remodelling (a generic “mitogenic entry” state seen across many dividing epithelial and mesenchymal cell types). Evidence: • Mitogenic cell-cycle entry – CCND1 (G1 cyclin), RAD9A (DNA-damage checkpoint during G1/S), KDM5C (chromatin remodeller required for cell-cycle progression). • RAS/PI3K signalling – RIN1 (RAS effector), PIK3R4/VPS15 (class III PI3K regulatory subunit). • RHO/actomyosin rearrangement – MPRIP (myosin-phosphatase-Rho–interacting protein), ARHGAP21 (RhoGAP), UNC45A (myosin chaperone) together support stress-fibre assembly and cell-shape changes that accompany growth-factor stimulation. • Metabolic support – PYGB (glycogen phosphorylase) supplies rapid glucose for the increased energetic demand of proliferating cells. Inconsistencies: • No major conflicts; however, the absence of canonical S-phase (e.g., MCMs, PCNA) or G2/M genes suggests this program marks the pre-S-phase, signalling-driven entry state rather than full cell-cycle progression.

program_79.description: The gene set most consistently points to a generic “actively-dividing / G2-M–phase progenitor” program rather than to a lineage-restricted cell type. High expression of a core centrosomal regulator (CEP192) together with cytoskeleton– and vesicle-remodelling factors (ARHGEF10, EXOC6B, SCRN1), broad transcriptional regulators (PRDM10, HMBOX1, MYNN) and metabolic support genes (FECH) fits cells that are preparing for mitosis while maintaining secretory trafficking and heightened bioenergetic demand; TNFRSF10D contributes an anti-apoptotic edge often seen in proliferating or transformed cells. Evidence: • Centrosome/G2-M: CEP192 is essential for centrosome maturation and mitotic spindle assembly—classically up-regulated in G2-M–phase cells. • Cytoskeletal remodelling for mitosis/cytokinesis: ARHGEF10 (RhoA GEF) and EXOC6B (exocyst complex) coordinate actin and membrane dynamics required for cell division. • Secretory/vesicle support: SCRN1 and EXOC6B promote regulated exocytosis, a pathway frequently heightened in dividing progenitors or tumour cells. • Transcriptional “house-keeping” regulators: PRDM10, HMBOX1 and MYNN are ubiquitously expressed chromatin or DNA-binding factors whose levels rise with proliferation. • Metabolic support: FECH catalyses the final step in heme synthesis, boosting mitochondrial respiration needed for rapid cell growth. • Survival advantage: TNFRSF10D encodes the TRAIL decoy receptor, providing resistance to extrinsic apoptosis—common in highly proliferative or transformed states. • Absence of lineage-defining markers (no myeloid, lymphoid, epithelial or neuronal signature) supports a generic proliferative program rather than a specific differentiated cell identity. Inconsistencies: • FECH is most enriched in erythroid cells; its presence here is best explained by metabolic demand, but it slightly biases toward erythropoiesis. • TNFRSF10D’s anti-apoptotic role is not strictly proliferation-linked and may reflect stress- or tumour-specific adaptations rather than a universal cell-cycle program.

program_80.description: The gene ensemble most consistently points to a generic “house-keeping / proliferative” program typically seen in cycling epithelial or progenitor‐like cells that are actively replicating DNA, processing large amounts of RNA and sustaining high levels of microtubule-dependent organelle and vesicle traffic. Evidence: • DNA replication / repair: MMS22L supports homologous-recombination–mediated repair during S phase, a hallmark of cycling cells. • RNA biogenesis and turnover: PPIL1 (spliceosome component) and DCPS (mRNA decapping) mark elevated transcript processing characteristic of proliferative states. • One-carbon / nucleotide supply: SLC19A1 (reduced-folate carrier) is typically up-regulated in dividing cells to satisfy folate demand for nucleotide synthesis. • Microtubule-based trafficking: KIF1C (kinesin motor), RHOT2/MIRO2 (mitochondrial transport) and TBC1D13 (Rab-GAP for vesicular trafficking) together indicate heightened cytoskeletal transport activity, common in metabolically active cycling cells. • Centriole/transition-zone component: TCTN1 couples centrosome–cilium dynamics with the cell cycle, again pointing to cells preparing for or exiting mitosis. Inconsistencies: • ARRB1 is best known for GPCR signaling in neurons and immune cells and is not specifically linked to proliferation, so its presence is less diagnostic for a generic cycling program.

program_81.description: The gene constellation most strongly fits an early thymic, pre-T cell developmental program—specifically cycling double-negative (DN2–DN3) thymocytes that have initiated pre-TCRα (PTCRA) expression and display heightened RNA processing, membrane trafficking, and autophagy activity. Evidence: • PTCRA – lineage-defining marker of DN2/DN3 thymocytes expressing the pre-T-cell receptor. • PLEKHA1 and PLEKHA8 – PH-domain adaptors enriched in lymphocytes, supporting phosphoinositide-dependent signaling downstream of the pre-TCR. • EXOSC3, FRYL – components of the RNA-exosome/transcriptional machinery, consistent with the high biosynthetic demand of rapidly proliferating thymocytes after β-selection. • ATG9A – key autophagy membrane protein; autophagy is up-regulated during thymocyte proliferation and selection. • PDZD11 – scaffold for vesicular transport proteins, aligning with intense membrane trafficking in expanding thymocytes. Inconsistencies: • DPCD (cilia biogenesis) and, to a lesser extent, SMIM8 are more typical of epithelial/ciliated cells and are not classical thymocyte markers, implying either low-level background expression or a mixed signal.

program_82.description: The gene set is most consistent with a motile-ciliated epithelial cell program, enriched for factors that build and traffic the microtubule-based axoneme and its associated membranes. Evidence: • KIF9 – kinesin motor concentrated in axonemes of motile cilia/flagella and required for their beating. • TCHP (Trichoplein) – centriolar protein that regulates ciliogenesis and links the basal body to the cytoskeleton. • SPECC1L – microtubule/actin cross-linker that localises to centrosomes and supports epithelial morphogenesis, a common requirement during cilia formation. • VPS54 and BACE1 – components of retrograde Golgi/endosomal trafficking and membrane proteolysis, respectively, processes up-regulated during ciliary membrane biogenesis and turnover. • CRAT and NAT1 – metabolic enzymes providing acetyl- and acyl-groups needed for lipid synthesis, supporting the high membrane demand of ciliogenesis. Inconsistencies: • BACE1 is best known as a neuronal β-secretase; its presence is less typical for airway or ependymal cilia. • ZNF184 is a generic zinc-finger transcription factor with no established link to ciliogenesis. • NAT1 chiefly functions in xenobiotic metabolism and is not cilia-specific.

program_83.description: The program most closely matches a neuronal population that is simultaneously mounting an interferon-stimulated antiviral response and boosting primary-cilium/vesicle trafficking machinery – a state reported in stressed or virally challenged neurons. Evidence: • Neuronal identity/vesicle cycling – SYNJ1 (synaptic vesicle endocytosis phosphatase) together with the broadly expressed neuronal transcription factor BCLAF3. • Ciliogenesis/primary cilium components – IFT22 and TCTN1 are core intraflagellar-transport and transition-zone genes enriched in neurons that retain a primary cilium. • Nuclear and DNA metabolism associated with active or stressed neurons – TOP3A (mitochondrial & nuclear DNA topoisomerase) and NUP188 (nuclear-pore complex) support elevated nuclear trafficking/repair. • Interferon-stimulated antiviral program – USP18 is an archetypal ISG that attenuates type-I IFN signalling; its presence without other strong ISGs often marks neurons, which mount a restricted IFN response. • Extracellular remodelling consistent with neuronal stress – BMP1 can be induced in neurons/glia after injury and participates in ECM processing, fitting a stress-response context. Inconsistencies: • BMP1 is more typical of mesenchymal cells; its inclusion may reflect paracrine signalling or mixed cell capture rather than a pure neuronal signature. • CUTC (copper transporter) is ubiquitous rather than neuron-specific, providing little cell-type resolution.

program_84.description: The program most closely matches an anti-inflammatory, lipid-handling macrophage state (e.g. IL-10 / cholesterol-sensing macrophages) characterized by simultaneous regulation of innate-immune signaling and fatty-acid / cholesterol metabolism. Evidence: • Innate-immune modulators – PELI3 (TLR/IRAK adaptor) and SBNO2 (IL-10/STAT3-induced transcriptional regulator) are selectively induced in tolerized or anti-inflammatory macrophages. • Lipid uptake / cholesterol homeostasis – SLC27A1 (FATP1, long-chain fatty-acid transporter) and RNF145 (ER E3 ligase that targets HMG-CoA-reductase, SREBP-responsive) are enriched in lipid-laden or cholesterol-sensing macrophages. • Metabolic support – PPOX (heme biosynthesis, mitochondrial), MFSD3 (putative membrane transporter) and YIPF2 (ER-Golgi trafficking) provide the mitochondrial and secretory-pathway capacity typical of metabolically active macrophages. • Transcriptional/chromatin machinery – TADA2B (SAGA complex) and BRAT1 (DNA-damage/ATM activation) reflect heightened transcriptional activity seen during macrophage polarization. Inconsistencies: • PPOX is classically abundant in erythroid cells; its inclusion may indicate a broader metabolic demand rather than a strict macrophage marker. • Classic macrophage markers (e.g. CD68, LYZ, CSF1R) are absent, so assignment relies on functional rather than canonical surface genes.

program_85.description: The gene set most strongly reflects a generic “biosynthetic/house-keeping” program characteristic of cells that have increased ribosome biogenesis, mitochondrial metabolism and broad transcriptional activity, rather than a lineage-restricted signature. Evidence: • Ribosome/RNA biogenesis – BYSL (nucleolar factor for 40S ribosomal subunit assembly) and GPATCH3 (RNA-binding G-patch protein) point to enhanced ribosome and RNA processing. • Mitochondrial & energy metabolism – SLC25A51 encodes the main mitochondrial NAD⁺ transporter, supporting elevated oxidative metabolism; TMEM161A is a broadly expressed mitochondrial-associated membrane protein. • Membrane signalling/trafficking – PI4K2B (PI4-kinase) and MAST2 (microtubule-associated kinase) facilitate phosphoinositide turnover and cytoskeletal dynamics typical of metabolically active cells. • Global transcriptional regulation – SAP25 (Sin3A co-repressor component) and ZNF184 (zinc-finger TF) fit with widespread modulation of gene expression. • Lack of multiple lineage-specific markers argues against a dedicated immune, epithelial, or neuronal identity. Inconsistencies: • LILRA5 is an activating immunoglobulin-like receptor largely confined to myeloid cells (monocytes/microglia). Its presence is atypical for a pure housekeeping/proliferative program and may reflect mild myeloid enrichment or noise in the loading list.

program_86.description: The gene set is most consistent with a cytotoxic T-lymphocyte (CTL) program, i.e., mature CD3⁺ T cells that possess or are acquiring effector/cytotoxic function. Evidence: • Core T-cell identity: CD3D, CD3G, and CD2 encode components of the T-cell receptor complex and the co-receptor CD2, unequivocally marking T lymphocytes. • Cytotoxic specialization: CTSW (Cathepsin W) is selectively expressed in cytotoxic T cells and NK cells and is required for granule-mediated killing. • Secretory/processing capacity typical of activated CTLs: PCSK7 (pro-protein convertase) and GORASP2 (Golgi structural protein) support granule maturation and trafficking; TMEM41A is linked to autophagy and membrane remodeling, processes up-regulated during effector T-cell activation. • Metabolic activation: G6PD up-regulation supplies NADPH for reactive oxygen handling and biosynthesis, a common metabolic shift in activated CTLs. • Proliferative/epigenetic readiness: MPHOSPH8 (MPP8) participates in chromatin remodeling, consistent with active transcriptional reprogramming during T-cell activation. Inconsistencies: • No obvious conflicting markers were detected in the provided gene lists.

program_87.description: The gene set most consistently reflects a generic “house-keeping / high-metabolic-activity” program rather than a lineage-restricted signature. It marks cells that have up-regulated mitochondrial gene expression and RNA processing machinery—features commonly seen in metabolically active or recently activated cells across many tissues. Evidence: • Mitochondrial gene expression/biogenesis – MTERF2 (mitochondrial transcription termination), FAHD1 (mitochondrial enzyme involved in TCA regulation). • RNA processing machinery – DDX42 (RNA helicase), CPSF4 (cleavage-polyadenylation complex), FEM1A and ZNF682 (zinc-finger proteins often up-regulated with transcriptional activity). • Organelle/vesicle dynamics – SNX19 (sorting nexin, ER–endosome tether). • Presence of the cytokine IL16 fits with metabolically active immune cells that frequently show heightened RNA processing and mitochondrial programs. Inconsistencies: • DTNA (dystrobrevin α) is primarily a muscle structural protein and is atypical for a broad metabolic program. • IL16, while explainable by immune activation, is not a universal house-keeping gene and points to possible mixed cell populations or multifactor loading of the component.

program_88.description: The program most strongly reflects a housekeeping “nucleolar / ribosome-biogenesis” state that is typically up-regulated in metabolically active, growth-or cycling cells rather than pointing to a specific differentiated lineage. Evidence: • Ribosome-biogenesis/nucleolar machinery – MTG2 (mitochondrial large-subunit assembly), NVL (nucleolar AAA-ATPase for preribosome remodeling) and POLR1B (core RNA-polymerase I subunit that transcribes rRNA) are classical markers of enhanced rRNA synthesis and processing. • Chromatin/transcription co-activators that stimulate rDNA transcription – KAT2B (PCAF histone acetyl-transferase) and ZNF587 support increased transcriptional output. • Proteostasis and turnover factors that accompany high biosynthetic load – RNF126 (E3 ubiquitin ligase) and HIP1/SNX12 (clathrin-endosomal trafficking) are commonly co-expressed with ribosome programs in proliferating cells to maintain protein quality control and membrane trafficking. Inconsistencies: • No notable lineage-defining or cell-cycle genes (e.g., MKI67, MCMs) are present, so the program points to a generic high biosynthetic state rather than a specific cell type or a fully defined cell-cycle phase.

program_89.description: The gene set points to an interferon-stimulated, ubiquitin/endocytosis-rich activation program commonly observed in immune cells (both myeloid and lymphoid) rather than to a lineage-specific identity. Evidence: • HERC6 – canonical interferon-stimulated E3 ligase that conjugates ISG15 to target proteins; strong marker of type I interferon activation. • UBAP2 and SH3KBP1 (CIN85) – ubiquitin-binding/adaptor proteins that cooperate with CBL to remodel receptor complexes and drive clathrin-mediated endocytosis during immune-receptor signaling. • PIP5K1A – generates PI(4,5)P₂ required for T-cell receptor, Fc-receptor and phagocytic cup signaling; loss of function causes immunodeficiency. • TRPM4 – Ca²⁺-activated cation channel that limits Ca²⁺ influx and tunes activation thresholds in T cells, mast cells and macrophages. • ZNF512 and ZNF586 – interferon-responsive zinc-finger transcription factors reported to modulate antiviral gene expression. • Collectively, these genes converge on interferon induction, ubiquitin/ISGylation, phosphoinositide turnover and receptor internalization—hallmarks of an antiviral, activated immune state. Inconsistencies: • SLF1 (DNA-repair SMC5/6 loader) and FAM98A (RNA-processing factor) are housekeeping genes not specifically linked to interferon or immune signaling, but their broad expression does not contradict the activation program.

program_90.description: The program principally reflects an S-phase / DNA-damage-checkpoint cell-cycle state that can be seen in many proliferating cells; the co-expression of the immune-restricted cytokine receptor IL27RA suggests it most likely marks immune-lineage cells (e.g. activated T, NK or myeloid cells) that are actively cycling. Evidence: • DNA-replication and checkpoint machinery ― RAD9A (9-1-1 clamp), LIN54 (MuvB/DREAM complex controlling S/G2 genes), RMND5A (CTLH E3 ligase linked to cell-cycle progression) and SIN3A (HDAC co-repressor governing cell-cycle transcription) are all up-regulated during S phase or in response to replication stress. • Organelle duplication / mitotic preparation ― TEDC1 (centriole assembly) and STK25 (Ste20 kinase in Hippo/mitotic signalling) are induced as cells prepare for mitosis. • Heightened bioenergetic demand ― FASTKD5 supports mitochondrial translation, a feature of rapidly dividing cells. • Immune lineage context ― IL27RA is a cytokine receptor largely confined to lymphoid and myeloid cells, indicating the cycling program is operating within an immune cell background rather than generic epithelial or stromal cells. Inconsistencies: • IL27RA is not mechanistically tied to the cell-cycle genes above; its presence is consistent with an immune cellular context but is not itself a proliferation marker, so datasets dominated by non-immune proliferating cells would show weaker support for this interpretation.

program_91.description: The program most closely matches a conventional T-lymphocyte signature, skewed toward an activated or long-lived (memory-like) state that is prepared for sustained signalling and redox/DNA-damage management. Evidence: • T-cell identity – CD2 is a canonical pan-T (and minor NK) surface molecule required for TCR co-stimulation. • Leukocyte-specific signalling modulation – INPP5D (SHIP1) is highly expressed in T cells where it tempers PI3K activity after activation; ABTB1 and ARAF add further PI3K/MAPK pathway components, supporting an activation-competent state. • Stress-resilience features – TXNRD2 (mitochondrial thioredoxin reductase) and NTHL1 (base-excision repair glycosylase) provide antioxidant and DNA-repair capacity characteristic of long-lived or repeatedly stimulated T cells. • Readiness for transcriptional/cell-cycle re-entry – CCNL2 (splicing-associated cyclin) and PPIP5K1 (inositol-pyrophosphate kinase that modulates energetic signalling) are up-regulated during T-cell priming and memory maintenance. Inconsistencies: No strongly discordant genes are present in the current list.

program_92.description: The gene set most plausibly reflects a generalized “signal-transduction activation” program—cells that are responding to cytokine or GPCR input through concurrent JAK-STAT, cAMP and Rho-GTPase pathways rather than marking a specific lineage. Such a state is frequently observed in immune and epithelial cells undergoing growth-factor stimulation, motility changes or survival signaling. Evidence: • STAT5B – core JAK-STAT effector activated by many cytokines (IL-2, IL-7, growth hormone), hallmark of an acute cytokine-responsive state. • ADCY3 – membrane adenylate cyclase producing cAMP after GPCR stimulation; fits with broad second-messenger up-regulation. • ARHGEF5 – Rho GEF that links surface-receptor cues to actin remodeling and migration, typical of activated or motile cells. • TRAPPC8 (vesicle trafficking) and SLC26A11 (anion exchanger) – support increases in membrane trafficking and ion flux that accompany receptor signaling. • AIFM1 – mitochondrial redox/apoptosis regulator often induced alongside survival-versus-death signaling decisions. • Absence of lineage-defining markers and prevalence of intracellular signaling molecules indicate a transient activation state rather than a dedicated cell identity. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions; the list is small and largely composed of broadly expressed signaling genes, so lineage attribution remains ambiguous.

program_93.description: The program is most consistent with a polarized, differentiated epithelial cell—such as respiratory or gastric surface epithelium—that is engaged in active protein secretion and assembly/maintenance of primary or motile cilia. Evidence: • Ciliogenesis/centrosome: ALMS1 (centrosome-basal body protein mutated in ciliopathies), TTLL3 (tubulin polyglutamylase active on axonemal microtubules). • Vesicle and membrane trafficking needed for apical polarization: AP4E1 (AP-4 adaptor complex), MED16 (Mediator subunit facilitating high transcriptional output of secretory genes). • Secretory/ER processing: ENTPD5 (ER UDPase enhancing N-glycoprotein folding), VSIG10 (surface Ig super-family protein enriched in airway and gastric epithelium). • Cell-surface/ECM interaction typical of epithelial barriers: SDC3 (syndecan heparan-sulfate proteoglycan). • High biosynthetic demand: MYBBP1A (nucleolar factor for rRNA synthesis). Inconsistencies: • SDC3 is best known in neurons and endothelium, and its presence is less typical for mature airway/gastric epithelium. • MYBBP1A and MED16 are ubiquitous “housekeeping” regulators and add little cell-type specificity.

program_94.description: The gene set points to tissue-resident/innate macrophages that have up-regulated lysosomal, scavenger-receptor and Fc-receptor machinery while mounting a type I interferon response—hallmarks of an activated, phagocytic macrophage state such as alveolar or other resident macrophages responding to microbial stimuli. Evidence: • MARCO and APOE – canonical markers of tissue-resident scavenger macrophages (especially alveolar and other sessile macrophage populations). • FCGRT – neonatal Fc receptor that recycles IgG and supports antigen presentation in macrophages and dendritic cells. • CTSC, CTSA and CD63 – lysosomal proteases/trafficking proteins enriched in phagolysosome-active macrophages. • IFI6 – interferon-stimulated gene indicating type I IFN activation. • FAU negatively loaded – reduced ribosomal protein expression is typical of interferon-driven translational dampening accompanying macrophage activation. Inconsistencies: No strong contradictions; all listed genes fit an interferon-stimulated, lysosome-rich macrophage program.

program_95.description: The gene set most closely reflects a mitochondrial-maintenance/oxidative‐metabolism program that is prominent in resting (naïve) lymphocytes, characterised by high expression of leukocyte adhesion molecule ICAM3 together with multiple nuclear-encoded mitochondrial enzymes involved in protein import, tRNA maturation and fatty-acid/propionate catabolism. Evidence: • Mitochondrial housekeeping: MIX23 (inner-membrane translation factor), THG1L (mitochondrial tRNA-His guanylyltransferase), APOO (mitochondrial TIM22 complex component), MMUT (methyl-malonyl-CoA mutase), NEU4 (mitochondrial/lysosomal neuraminidase) collectively indicate enhanced mitochondrial function and oxidative metabolism. • Resting-lymphocyte marker: ICAM3 (CD50) is highly expressed on naïve T and B cells and is down-regulated after activation, consistent with a quiescent immune state. Inconsistencies: • IQSEC2 (ARF6 GEF, best known for neuronal synapse expression) and FBRSL1 lack clear links to lymphocytes or mitochondrial pathways; their inclusion may reflect broader housekeeping expression rather than the core program.

program_96.description: The gene constellation most coherently points to a neuronal-biased “intracellular transport & genome-maintenance” program that is commonly detected in mature or metabolically active neurons when they up-regulate microtubule-based trafficking, vesicle turnover and DNA-repair machinery (e.g. during heightened electrical activity or mild stress). Evidence: • Neuronal microtubule/trafficking – KIFC2 (neuron-restricted minus-end kinesin), ARHGAP1 (controls actin dynamics in neurite outgrowth). • Vesicle/secretory pathway – TPD52 promotes vesicle budding and exocytosis, frequently up-regulated in secretory neurons. • Mitochondrial supply for active processes – SLC25A45 transports acyl-carnitines across the mitochondrial membrane, supporting high neuronal energy demand. • Genome-maintenance & stress response – PARG (PAR turnover), TATDN2 (endonuclease), and ING3 (NuA4 complex; p53‐linked) are all induced by DNA-damage or oxidative stress, a situation encountered in active neurons. • TMEM102 encodes a brain-enriched transmembrane protein up-regulated in activated brain immune/neuronal interfaces, further supporting a nervous-system context. Inconsistencies: • TPD52 and ING3 are also described in proliferative epithelial or cancer cells, which is atypical for terminally differentiated neurons; however, both can be induced in neurons under stress, thus only mildly discordant.

program_97.description: The gene set is most consistent with a proliferative neural-crest–derived progenitor program (e.g. early melanoblasts, Schwann-cell precursors or pericyte precursors) characterized by endothelin (EDNRB) and Wnt/Cyclin-Y signalling, active cell cycling, controlled mTOR activity and cytoskeletal remodelling required for migration. Evidence: • EDNRB – canonical marker of migratory neural-crest cells, melanocyte lineage and Schwann-cell precursors; drives endothelin-guided migration. • CCNY (Cyclin-Y) – activates CDK14-dependent Wnt/β-catenin signalling and supports G1/S progression in neural progenitors. • H4C8 – replication-dependent histone, typical of actively cycling progenitors. • TBC1D7 – component of the TSC1/2/TBC1D7 complex that restrains mTOR, expressed in developing brain and perivascular cells, matching growth-controlled progenitors. • ARHGAP4 – Rho-GAP modulating cytoskeletal dynamics during cell motility; enriched in neural and glial lineages. • IER3IP1 – highly expressed in neuroectoderm; loss-of-function causes neurodevelopmental defects, supporting a neural progenitor context. Inconsistencies: • ARHGAP4 is also abundant in T-/NK-cells, so its presence is not unique to neural-crest derivatives. • SLC35E2B and ZNF587 have sparse functional or tissue-specific data, making their contribution to this program difficult to interpret.

program_98.description: The program most closely fits a proliferative, integrin-α5–high mesenchymal/activated-fibroblast state in which cells engage fibronectin-rich extracellular matrix while coordinating nuclear-centrosomal functions needed for division and mechanical signaling. Evidence: • ITGA5 – canonical fibronectin receptor highly expressed in fibroblasts, myofibroblasts and EMT-like tumor cells undergoing adhesion and migration. • NFYB, PARP1 – transcription factor and DNA-damage/repair enzyme that are up-regulated in cycling cells, supporting a proliferative component. • CEP68 (centrosome cohesion) and SUN1 (LINC-complex nuclear-envelope protein) – genes required for mitosis and for transmitting cytoskeletal forces to the nucleus, consistent with dividing, mechanically active mesenchymal cells. • FBRSL1 and LRRC61 – chromatin-regulatory and leucine-rich repeat proteins reported in proliferative or cytoskeleton-associated contexts, fitting the same theme. • Co-enrichment of adhesion (ITGA5) with nuclear/centrosomal and DNA-repair factors (NFYB, PARP1, CEP68, SUN1) is characteristic of activated fibroblasts or mesenchymal tumor cells preparing for migration and growth. Inconsistencies: • CNIH3 is best known as an AMPA-receptor trafficking factor in neurons and is not generally linked to fibroblast biology. • Classic fibroblast structural (e.g., COL1A1, PDGFRA) or high-stringency cell-cycle genes (e.g., MKI67, MCMs) are absent, so the assignment reflects a partial rather than full fibroblast/cell-cycle signature.

program_99.description: The gene constellation most consistently points to a skeletal-muscle / myocyte program, enriched for factors that support α-dystroglycan glycosylation, sarcolemmal remodeling and the high mitochondrial output typical of muscle fibres, with a sprinkling of more generic proliferation- or trafficking-related genes. Evidence: • FKTN – key glycosyltransferase required for proper α-dystroglycan modification; loss-of-function causes Fukuyama congenital muscular dystrophy, making it strongly muscle-biased. • FHL3 – LIM-domain co-factor highly expressed in skeletal and cardiac muscle where it modulates MyoD/MyoG-driven myogenic differentiation. • SNN – transcripts are highest in skeletal muscle and heart, fitting a muscle lineage signature. • UQCC6 – mitochondrial complex III assembly factor; high oxidative capacity is a hallmark of mature myofibres. • PIGH – GPI-anchor biosynthesis component; numerous muscle membrane proteins (e.g. contactin, sarcolemmal surface proteins) require GPI anchoring, supporting a membrane-focused muscle program. Inconsistencies: • RAB11FIP3 and CHTF8 are principally cytokinesis/replication factors and are not muscle-restricted, hinting at a possible proliferative (myoblast) contaminant rather than differentiated fibre. • TRIM65 is a broadly expressed E3 ligase mainly studied in innate immunity; its presence is not specifically informative for muscle identity.

program_100.description: The gene set most consistently fits a generic “house-keeping / homeostatic” program often seen in many metabolically active, non-proliferating cells, with a slight bias toward epithelial junctional maintenance. The genes encode core components of RNA synthesis, DNA repair, vesicle trafficking, prenylation and adherens-junction organization, indicating cells that are maintaining basic biosynthetic and membrane-turnover functions rather than engaging in a specialized immune, proliferative or stress response. Evidence: • Transcription / ribosome biogenesis – POLR1C (RNA-pol I/III subunit) supports high basal transcriptional activity typical of house-keeping programs. • Genome maintenance – MSH3 (DNA mismatch repair) implies routine DNA surveillance in cycling or recently divided cells without full proliferative signature. • Vesicle and endosomal trafficking – VPS53 (GARP complex) and VPS26B (retromer) point to active membrane recycling and protein sorting found in most healthy cells. • Protein prenylation – FNTB (farnesyltransferase β-subunit) is required for post-translational modification of many signaling proteins, a ubiquitous metabolic function. • Cytoskeleton / junctional stability – PLEKHA7 (zonula-adherens component) and TTLL5 (tubulin poly-glutamylase) suggest upkeep of microtubules and epithelial junctions, consistent with an epithelial homeostatic state rather than motile or mesenchymal cells. • Broadly expressed/poorly specialized genes – FAM131A is a widely expressed, incompletely characterized protein often captured in baseline transcriptional programs, reinforcing a general maintenance profile. Inconsistencies: • No clear proliferation markers (e.g., MKI67, PCNA) or epithelial-specific transcription factors (e.g., EPCAM, KRTs) are present, so the program lacks strong cell-type specificity and may arise in many cell categories undergoing routine metabolic upkeep.

program_101.description: The program most plausibly reflects activated, stress-responsive fibroblasts engaged in extracellular-matrix remodeling and heightened nuclear DNA-damage/replication control. Evidence: • BMP1 – secreted metalloprotease that cleaves procollagens; highly expressed in dermal and other tissue fibroblasts during matrix deposition and wound repair. • MAPK13 (p38δ) – stress-activated MAP kinase that promotes collagen production and myofibroblast activation; enriched in fibroblasts compared with most immune cells. • PIGG, ACTR8, EMSY, CSTPP1 – components of GPI-anchor synthesis (PIGG) and chromatin/DNA-repair complexes (INO80 subunit ACTR8, BRCA2-associated EMSY, CST-complex regulator CSTPP1); collectively consistent with proliferative, genome-maintenance activity seen in activated fibroblasts. • Absence of negatively loaded genes suggests the program is driven by coordinated up-regulation of the above factors rather than suppression of an alternative lineage. Inconsistencies: • Canonical fibroblast ECM genes (COL1A1, COL1A2, DCN, FAP, etc.) are not present, so the assignment relies on BMP1 and MAPK13 rather than a broader collagen signature. • Most nuclear/chromatin genes (ACTR8, EMSY, CSTPP1) are not fibroblast-specific and could arise in any dividing cell under genotoxic stress. • Limited gene set restricts definitive classification; osteogenic or epithelial stress responses could also feature BMP1 and MAPK13.

program_102.description: The program is most consistent with a proliferative, Wnt-active stem/progenitor state—such as intestinal crypt, neural, or fetal-like epithelial progenitors—characterized by heightened ubiquitin-proteasome/ER-associated degradation activity and intensive vesicle–cytoskeleton remodeling that supports rapid growth and self-renewal. Evidence: • Wnt/β-catenin stemness drivers – PLAGL2 (transcription factor that sustains stemness and amplifies Wnt signalling), FBXW11/β-TrCP2 (SCF-E3 ligase needed for regulated β-catenin turnover and NF-κB activation). • Ubiquitin-proteasome & ER-stress machinery – SYVN1/HRD1 (ER-associated‐degradation E3 ligase), FBXW11 (SCF complex component) indicate high protein quality-control load typical of rapidly dividing progenitors. • Vesicle trafficking/acidification – AP4B1 (AP-4 adaptor for TGN-to-endosome cargo), ATP6V0E2 (V-ATPase V0 subunit) reflect active endolysosomal flux in immature cells. • Cytoskeletal remodeling for mitosis and morphogenesis – KATNB1 (katanin p80, microtubule severing) and KLHDC3/Kaptin (actin-binding) support dynamic cytoskeleton needs of dividing or migrating progenitors. • Collectively these functions—Wnt signalling, protein turnover, vesicle traffic, and cytoskeletal dynamics—are canonical hallmarks of stem/progenitor states across multiple tissues. Inconsistencies: • Absence of classic proliferation markers (e.g., MKI67, PCNA) or definitive lineage-restricted stem markers (e.g., LGR5, SOX2) limits precise tissue assignment. • All listed genes are broadly expressed; thus the program may reflect a generic “high biosynthetic/proteostasis” state rather than a lineage-specific stem cell program.

program_103.description: The gene set is most consistent with a ciliated-sensory epithelial/neural program, such as that seen in photoreceptors or inner-ear hair cells, characterized by active ciliogenesis/stereociliogenesis and associated neuronal adaptor and DNA-repair machinery. Evidence: • TTC8 (BBS8) – core component of the BBSome required for intraflagellar transport and photoreceptor outer-segment formation; strongly marks ciliated sensory cells. • MYO15B – paralogue of MYO15A, an actin-based motor enriched in cochlear hair-cell stereocilia and other specialized sensory microvilli. • PARP3 – participates in centrosome integrity and primary-cilia dynamics in addition to DNA-damage repair, fitting a ciliogenesis program. • APBB2 (FE65-like) – neuronal adaptor protein highly expressed in developing neurons/photoreceptors, supporting a sensory-neural context. • Coordinated up-regulation of multiple ciliogenesis and neuronal-associated genes argues for a differentiated ciliated-sensory state. Inconsistencies: • IKBKE – kinase driving antiviral NF-κB/IFN signalling, more typical of immune activation than of sensory epithelial cells. • MZF1 – myeloid-lineage transcription factor seldom enriched in neuronal or epithelial sensory cells. • CDKN2AIPNL – poorly characterised; its relevance to ciliogenesis or sensory identity is unclear.

program_104.description: The gene set best fits a stress-responsive intracellular trafficking program, characteristic of cells experiencing endoplasmic-reticulum (ER) stress and activating autophagy rather than marking a specific lineage; it likely reflects a universal unfolded-protein-response (UPR)/autophagy state that many cell types can transiently enter. Evidence: • ERN1 (IRE1α) – canonical proximal sensor of the UPR, engaged upon ER stress. • STX17 – SNARE required for autophagosome maturation and fusion with lysosomes, typically induced alongside ER stress. • ARAP2, TMEM69, SLC35E2B – membrane-associated proteins that modulate Arf/Rho GTPase signaling or reside in ER/Golgi, fitting with membrane remodeling during UPR and autophagy. • EFNB1 – transmembrane ligand whose expression increases during stress and junctional remodeling, consistent with a cell attempting to adapt its surface contacts under ER stress. • CRAMP1 – cytoskeleton-associated/ARF-binding protein reported to cooperate with membrane trafficking, aligning with the above trafficking-oriented stress response. Inconsistencies: No strongly contradictory genes are present; EFNB1 is more commonly highlighted in developmental boundary formation, but its involvement in stress-induced junctional signaling does not conflict with an overall UPR/autophagy program.

program_105.description: The gene set is most consistent with a neuronal‐specific transcriptional program, characteristic of mature, synaptically active neurons (likely cortical or hippocampal excitatory neurons) rather than a hematopoietic or other lineage. Evidence: • Synaptic signaling/maintenance – IQSEC2 (postsynaptic density GEF essential for AMPA-receptor trafficking) and NEURL1 (E3 ubiquitin-ligase that promotes neurite outgrowth and synaptic plasticity). • Neuron-enriched signaling modulator – SOCS7 regulates actin dynamics and neurite extension in neurons. • Membrane trafficking/maintenance in neurons – ATP11C is a phospholipid flippase with high brain expression, sustaining neuronal membrane asymmetry. • Transcriptional regulators expressed in differentiating neurons – MLLT1 (ENL, part of the SEC/MLL chromatin-activation complex active in neuronal gene transcription) and ZNF441 (brain-expressed zinc-finger protein). • Cilia/axoneme component occasionally detected in ependymal and some neuronal subtypes – CFAP97 can be expressed in brain cells bearing primary cilia, consistent with neuronal lineage. Inconsistencies: • CFAP97 is better known for roles in motile cilia/flagella and is not universally expressed in all neurons. • ATP11C, SOCS7, and MLLT1 also have documented expression in hematopoietic cells; their presence alone is not neuron-specific, but in combination with strong synaptic genes they fit a neuronal program.

program_106.description: The gene set is most compatible with a neural‐lineage program—likely a developing or metabolically active neuron / glial state characterized by high membrane trafficking, mitochondrial co-factor synthesis and calcium-regulated proteolysis; however, the signal is modest and contains at least one gene (SLC26A6) more typical of epithelial cells, so the program may reflect a mixed or broadly expressed “neuronal-leaning” housekeeping module rather than a cell-type-defining signature. Evidence: • Neural development / function genes: SBF1 (MTMR5) is enriched in Schwann cells and axons; CAPN15 is a calcium-dependent protease required for brain and ocular development; ATRN encodes the “mahogany” glycoprotein highly expressed in brain parenchyma and microglia; KIAA1586 (CCDC9B) and ZC3H7B show broad but highest expression in neural tissues. • High mitochondrial demand typical of neurons: COQ6 supports coenzyme-Q biosynthesis, essential for neuronal oxidative metabolism. • Absence of negative loadings suggests these positively loaded genes jointly mark the program without an opposing gene set. Inconsistencies: • SLC26A6 is an anion exchanger classically abundant in renal proximal-tubule and pancreatic/intestinal epithelium, not in neural cells, indicating possible epithelial contamination or a more generic transport/housekeeping component.

program_107.description: The gene set most consistently points to an activated/secretory vascular endothelial-cell program characterized by heightened vesicle trafficking and Ca²⁺/cGMP-regulated exocytosis. Evidence: • STXBP5 – key negative regulator of Weibel-Palade body release; highly expressed in endothelial cells and controls vWF/P-selectin exocytosis. • BCAR3 – adaptor that promotes integrin- and Src-dependent signaling during endothelial migration and barrier regulation. • IRAG2 (IP₃-receptor-associated cGMP substrate 2) – paralogue of IRAG1, part of the IP₃R–PKG complex that mediates cGMP-dependent Ca²⁺ signaling in vascular endothelium and smooth muscle. • USP30, MTMR2 – membrane‐associated phosphatases/de-ubiquitinases that remodel mitochondria or endo-lysosomal membranes, fitting a broader vesicle/organelle-trafficking theme seen in secretory endothelial cells. • LZTFL1 – trafficking regulator first described in ciliary transport but also enriched in lung and vascular endothelium; contributes to cytoskeleton-dependent membrane dynamics. • Collectively, the genes converge on intracellular trafficking, Ca²⁺/cGMP signaling, and secretion—core features of endothelial cells preparing for or undergoing regulated exocytosis. Inconsistencies: • No classical endothelial markers such as PECAM1, VWF or KDR are present, so assignment relies on functional rather than canonical lineage genes. • USP30 and MTMR2 are not endothelial-restricted and are also linked to neuronal or general mitochondrial pathways, though still compatible with a trafficking-centric program.

program_108.description: The gene set most consistently represents a generic “house-keeping / cellular maintenance” program rather than a lineage-restricted signature; it is enriched for factors that sustain basic RNA processing, chromatin organization, membrane‐lipid and mitochondrial cofactor biosynthesis, processes that become up-regulated in metabolically active cells of many lineages. Evidence: • RNA processing GPATCH1 and DUS3L encode RNA-binding or tRNA-modifying enzymes that rise with heightened transcriptional/translation activity. • Chromatin architecture CTCF is a ubiquitous insulator protein that increases when genome organization and transcriptional regulation are active. • Bioenergetics COQ6 (ubiquinone biosynthesis) and PIGA (GPI-anchor synthesis) support mitochondrial respiration and membrane protein maturation required for high metabolic throughput. • Proteostasis CAPN3 encodes a Ca²⁺-dependent protease that can assist protein turnover during elevated metabolic or stress states. • Organelle trafficking LZTFL1 participates in vesicle/ciliary cargo release, another process that scales with global cellular activity. Inconsistencies: • CAPN3 is best known for skeletal-muscle specificity, and LZTFL1 is classically linked to ciliated epithelia; their presence suggests some mixed or low-level lineage contamination rather than a pure maintenance program.

program_109.description: The gene set is most consistent with a “retinoic-acid response / differentiation” program that is typically seen in epithelial (e.g., keratinocyte) or other RA-responsive cells as they exit proliferation and undergo maturation. Evidence: • PLAAT4 (also known as RARRES3/TIG3) – classical retinoic-acid receptor–responsive gene strongly induced by topical retinoids in keratinocytes and other epithelia; mediates growth arrest and differentiation. • RBP7 – cytosolic retinol-binding protein that regulates intracellular retinoid availability; commonly co-expressed with other RA-target genes during RA signalling. • CDR2 – reported among transcripts up-regulated after RA treatment in several neuronal and epithelial models; its presence fits an RA-inducible transcriptional profile. • RNF25 and SUPT7L – transcriptional/ubiquitin-ligase regulators that have documented RA-responsive promoters, supporting a coordinated RA transcriptional program. • Absence of canonical cell-cycle drivers and the enrichment of multiple RA-target genes together suggest a differentiation rather than proliferative state. Inconsistencies: • The list lacks classic epidermal structural markers (e.g., KRT1, IVL) or other highly specific lineage genes, so the exact cell lineage cannot be pinpointed beyond “RA-responsive epithelium.” • Several genes (TATDN2, CCDC97, SUPT7L) are broadly expressed housekeeping factors and do not themselves indicate RA signalling, though they are not contradictory to it.

program_110.description: The program most closely reflects a generic “protein-homeostasis / metabolic maintenance” state rather than a lineage-restricted cell identity. Its genes converge on regulation of ubiquitin-mediated protein turnover (COP9 signalosome), ADP-ribosylation repair, and nutrient-sensing pathways that are broadly active in many proliferative or metabolically active cells. Evidence: • COPS7B – core subunit of the COP9 signalosome that deneddylates cullins and tunes ubiquitin-proteasome–dependent protein degradation, a central feature of cellular protein-quality-control programs. • WDR6 – WD-repeat protein that binds S6K/TSC1 and suppresses autophagy under nutrient-replete conditions, linking growth signals to protein turnover. • MACROD1 – mitochondrial/ nuclear mono-ADP-ribosylhydrolase involved in removal of ADP-ribose from proteins after DNA- or oxidative-stress, fitting a proteostasis / stress-repair theme. • SBF1 – catalytically inactive myotubularin family member that modulates endosomal PI3P signaling and trafficking of membrane proteins scheduled for degradation. • FGGY – carbohydrate-kinase domain enzyme (glycerol/xylulose kinase) supporting central carbon metabolism needed to fuel biosynthetic demand associated with protein turnover. • ZNF808 – KRAB zinc-finger transcriptional repressor that can help enforce broad transcriptional programs, consistent with a regulatory component rather than lineage specificity. Inconsistencies: • PPP1R9B (spinophilin) is highly enriched in neurons and platelets due to its actin/synaptic scaffolding role and is less obviously tied to a general proteostasis module, suggesting some contribution from neural or cytoskeletal remodeling contexts that is not reinforced by the other genes.

program_111.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, proliferating T- or B-lymphocyte program that couples cell-cycle entry with cytoskeletal/vesicular remodeling typical of immune activation. Evidence: • Immune activation marker – SEMA4D (CD100) is strongly up-regulated on activated T and B cells and drives immune synapse formation. • Cell-cycle and mitotic regulators – ZC3HC1 (NIPA) controls G2/M transition; KATNB1 (katanin p80) and XPO5 are required for spindle organization and RNA export, respectively, supporting a cycling state. • Protection against replication stress – NUDT15 hydrolyzes oxidized nucleotides and is highly expressed in rapidly dividing hematopoietic cells. • Cytoskeleton/trafficking remodeling – FARP2 (Rho-GEF) and VPS39 (HOPS complex) mediate actin reorganization and lysosome–endosome fusion, processes enhanced during lymphocyte activation and effector-granule trafficking. Inconsistencies: • The list lacks classic lymphoid lineage genes (e.g., CD3E, CD79A) and canonical proliferation markers (MKI67, PCNA), so the program may represent a partial activation/proliferation module shared with other dividing cells. • VPS39 and FARP2 are ubiquitous and also enriched in non-immune cell types, which could indicate a more general vesicle–cytoskeleton remodeling program rather than lymphocyte-specific activation.

program_112.description: The program most strongly denotes a generic, growth-factor–responsive and stress-protective state that many proliferating somatic cells (e.g. cycling epithelial or immune cells) adopt rather than a lineage-restricted identity. It combines components of Hippo signalling (LATS1), receptor-tyrosine-kinase/PI3K scaffolding (GAB1), cAMP turnover (PDE8A), nuclear-pore and mTOR regulation (SEH1L), oxidative DNA-lesion repair (NEIL1) and attenuation of NF-κB activity (NKIRAS1), together characterising cells that are receiving mitogenic cues while simultaneously containing inflammatory signalling and repairing DNA damage. Evidence: • Hippo pathway / contact-inhibition control – LATS1 encodes the core Hippo kinase that restrains proliferation. • Growth-factor / PI3K signalling – GAB1 is an essential scaffold for EGFR, HGF-MET and many other RTKs driving PI3K–AKT activation in cycling cells. • cAMP homeostasis – PDE8A hydrolyses cAMP, modulating PKA activity downstream of multiple receptors during cell activation. • Nuclear-pore & mTOR interface – SEH1L (part of the NUP107-160 complex) supports nuclear-pore biogenesis and mTOR-mediated growth signalling. • Genome-protection – NEIL1 excises oxidised bases during S-phase, indicative of an active DNA-repair environment typical of dividing or stressed cells. • Anti-inflammatory feedback – NKIRAS1 interacts with IκB to dampen NF-κB, a common counter-regulatory mechanism during growth-factor stimulation. Inconsistencies: • The listed genes lack classical lineage markers (e.g. EPCAM for epithelium, PTPRC for leukocytes), so the program cannot be pinned to a single cell type with high confidence. • PDE8A shows enriched expression in T lymphocytes and macrophages, which may bias the program toward immune cells, yet the remaining genes are ubiquitous, making a purely immune interpretation uncertain.

program_113.description: The program most closely matches a barrier/airway epithelial cell state with features of ciliated and secretory activity—cells that must build or maintain motile/primary cilia, modify surface glycoconjugates, and expel xenobiotics. Evidence: • CEP41 – centrosomal protein required for tubulin glutamylation and proper cilia formation; strongly linked to ciliated epithelial and ependymal cells. • CASD1 – catalyzes 9-O-acetylation of sialic acids on mucins and glycolipids, a modification enriched on airway and other mucosal epithelia. • ABCC10 – apical ATP-binding cassette transporter conferring drug/xenobiotic efflux, commonly up-regulated in barrier epithelia such as airway and intestinal epithelium. • SH3GLB2 & LRCH3 – proteins involved in membrane trafficking and actin cytoskeleton organization, consistent with high vesicle turnover in secretory/ciliated epithelial cells. • Collective enrichment for ciliary assembly (CEP41), mucin modification (CASD1) and apical transport (ABCC10) coherently points to an epithelial program rather than mesenchymal, immune, or stromal lineages. Inconsistencies: • Classical core cilia genes (e.g., FOXJ1, DNAH11) and major secretory markers (e.g., MUC5AC) are absent, so the assignment relies on a limited gene set. • ZNF587B is poorly characterized and not known to be epithelial-specific, adding uncertainty.

program_114.description: The gene composition most closely reflects a generic “growth and division” program typical of actively cycling cells, marked by enhanced ribosome biogenesis, chromatin assembly and cytoskeletal re-organization that support proliferation across many lineages rather than a lineage-restricted identity. Evidence: • DHX33 – nucleolar RNA helicase that drives rRNA transcription and is indispensable for G1-S progression. • TBCC – tubulin-folding co-factor required for α/β-tubulin dimer formation and mitotic spindle assembly. • ARHGEF5 – Rho-GEF that coordinates actin/microtubule remodeling during cytokinesis and cell migration. • UBN1 – component of the HIRA histone H3.3 chaperone complex, facilitating replication-independent nucleosome assembly during rapid cell growth. • CDKN2AIP – p14ARF/p53-associated modulator of S-phase checkpoints, highlighting active regulation of cell-cycle transitions. • Combined up-regulation of nucleolar (DHX33), chromatin (UBN1), spindle (TBCC) and cytoskeleton (ARHGEF5) factors is characteristic of proliferative states observed in cycling progenitors, activated lymphocytes and many cancer cells. Inconsistencies: • ZNF587 lacks clear functional annotation; its contribution to proliferation is uncertain. • CDKN2AIP can mediate cell-cycle arrest under p53 activation, so its up-regulation may reflect checkpoint engagement rather than pure proliferative drive.

program_115.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated vascular endothelial cell state characterized by secretion of lipoprotein-modifying and immune-modulatory factors. Evidence: • RNASE1 – highly enriched in blood-vessel endothelial cells and widely used as an endothelial marker. • PLTP – secreted by endothelial cells to remodel circulating lipoproteins and HDL. • TNFSF13 (APRIL) – produced by endothelial cells under pro-inflammatory cues, supporting an “activated” rather than resting endothelium. • GABARAP, ATP6V0C – autophagy/vesicle acidification components that facilitate secretion; broadly expressed but up-regulated in secretory/activated endothelial states. • NME2 – nucleotide kinase linked to high metabolic and proliferative activity seen in stimulated endothelium. Inconsistencies: • TNFSF13 is also expressed in monocytes/B cells, and lack of canonical endothelial markers (e.g., PECAM1, KDR, VWF) limits specificity; however, the combined presence of RNASE1 and PLTP still favors an endothelial origin.

program_116.description: The gene set is most consistent with a mature neuronal program characterized by active synaptic‐vesicle cycling and lysosomal protein turnover. Evidence: • SYNGR1 (+) – presynaptic vesicle membrane protein highly selective for neurons and a hallmark of synapse-forming cells. • CTSF (+) – lysosomal cysteine protease enriched in neurons, supporting the high demand for protein degradation in active synapses. • CEP41 (+) – centrosomal/tubulin-modifying protein required for ciliary and axonal microtubule function, fitting the cytoskeletal needs of neurons. • SLC45A4 (+) – proton/sugar transporter with preferential brain expression, aiding neuronal energy demands. • ZNF224 and BIVM (+) – broadly expressed nuclear factors that participate in transcriptional regulation, frequently detected in neuronal nuclei. Inconsistencies: • CTSF is also expressed in macrophage/microglial lineages, and the absence of canonical neuronal markers (e.g., MAP2, RBFOX3) limits specificity.

program_117.description: The program is characteristic of activated mast cells, reflecting their canonical granule- and eicosanoid-producing machinery together with an early activation surface signature. Evidence: • TPSB2 – encodes β-tryptase, a mast-cell-specific granule protease and gold-standard marker for human mast cells. • HPGDS – hematopoietic prostaglandin-D synthase, highly enriched in mast cells and required for their secretion of PGD₂ during activation. • SYTL3 – vesicle-trafficking protein that interacts with Rab27 to regulate secretory granule exocytosis in mast cells. • CD69 – early activation antigen whose up-regulation marks recently activated mast cells in tissue. • Coordinated presence of granule (TPSB2), eicosanoid (HPGDS) and exocytosis (SYTL3) genes together with the activation marker CD69 supports an “activated mast cell” transcriptional state. Inconsistencies: • GSTM3 and HEBP2 are broadly expressed stress-response/housekeeping genes and do not specifically point to mast cells, but their presence is not incompatible with an activated state and does not contradict the overall mast-cell program.

program_118.description: The program reflects a generic “metallothionein-high” stress response state, not a specific lineage, seen when diverse cell types encounter heavy-metal exposure, oxidative stress, or pro-inflammatory cytokines. Up-regulation of multiple MT1 family members and MT2A suggests activation of metal ion buffering and reactive-oxygen-species detoxification pathways. Evidence: • MT1E, MT1F, MT1G, MT1H, MT1X, and MT2A encode cysteine-rich metallothioneins that sequester Zn²⁺/Cd²⁺ and are transcriptionally induced by MTF-1 in response to metal overload, ROS, and inflammatory mediators—canonical markers of a cellular metal-stress/oxidative-stress program. • Coordinated elevation of several MT1 isoforms together with MT2A is a well-described signature in scRNA-seq datasets of stressed epithelial, endothelial, immune, and tumor cells, supporting a state rather than a lineage identity. Inconsistencies: • None evident; all detected genes belong to the metallothionein family and coherently support the stress-response interpretation.

program_119.description: The gene set best fits a generic “house-keeping / organelle-biogenesis” transcriptional program rather than a lineage-restricted cell identity. The co-enrichment of a cilium assembly factor (TTC8/BBS8), an ER oligosaccharide flippase (RFT1), a vitamin-C importer important for redox balance (SLC23A2), and a peroxisomal NADH hydrolase (NUDT12) points to cells that are maintaining basic oxidative, glycosylation and ciliary functions—features common to many metabolically active epithelial and stromal cells rather than to a specific, well-defined cell type or activation state. Evidence: • Organelle biogenesis / protein processing – RFT1: essential ER flippase for N-linked glycosylation. – TTC8 (BBS8): basal body protein required for cilium assembly, a generic organelle function found in many differentiated cells. • Redox / metabolic homeostasis – SLC23A2: high-affinity vitamin-C transporter supplying ascorbate for anti-oxidant and collagen-modifying reactions. – NUDT12: peroxisomal NADH diphosphatase regulating redox status. • Broadly expressed “maintenance” factors – R3HCC1 and ZNF865 are ubiquitous nuclear proteins with no strong lineage restriction, fitting a housekeeping profile. Inconsistencies: No strongly lineage-specific markers (e.g., epithelial keratins, immune receptors, neuronal genes) are present; thus the program lacks features that would pin it to a single differentiated cell type.

program_120.description: The gene set most consistently aligns with a homeostatic/resting microglial (or closely related macrophage) program characterized by high secretory, lipid-handling and antigen-presentation activity and relatively low cytoskeletal remodeling.
