Evidence: • APOC1 – canonical microglial/macrophage lipid-handling gene; strongly up-regulated in resting CNS microglia. • CST3 – cystatin C, abundantly secreted by homeostatic microglia and perivascular macrophages. • ITM2B – enriched in brain myeloid cells and participates in amyloid precursor processing, a pathway well described in microglia. • B2M – component of MHC class I; high expression is typical of antigen-presenting myeloid cells, including microglia. • ACTG1 negatively loaded – reduced γ-actin fits a relatively quiescent, non-migratory microglial state compared with more motile peripheral macrophages that up-regulate actin genes. Inconsistencies: • All positively loaded genes are broadly compatible with multiple immune or secretory cell types (e.g., liver or other tissue macrophages), so the program is not strictly microglia-specific. • ACTG1 down-regulation is not a classic microglial marker; some datasets show equal or higher actin levels in microglia.

program_121.description: The program is most consistent with an interferon-stimulated, phagocytic macrophage state (e.g., tissue-resident or infection-activated macrophages/microglia) characterized by type I IFN response genes together with scavenger, vesicle-trafficking and lipid-handling markers. Evidence: • Type I IFN response – IFI6 and LY6E are classic interferon-stimulated genes induced during viral sensing in myeloid cells. • Macrophage identity/scavenging – MARCO encodes a class A scavenger receptor largely restricted to tissue-resident and inflammatory macrophages. • Lipid metabolism/phagocytosis – APOE is strongly expressed by macrophages and microglia engaged in lipid handling and efferocytosis. • Phagolysosomal/secretory activity – CD63 (tetraspanin) enriches late endosomes, exosomes and lysosomes, up-regulated in activated macrophages. Inconsistencies: • CD63 and LY6E are not macrophage-specific and can be expressed in many cell types, but their co-expression with MARCO and APOE favors a macrophage interpretation. • Few canonical macrophage genes (e.g., CD68, CSF1R) appear, so cell identity relies on a limited marker set.

program_122.description: The gene set is most consistent with a lymphoid (T-cell/NK-cell) program enriched for molecules that regulate receptor signaling and intracellular trafficking, suggesting an activated or synapse-remodeling state of these cells. Evidence: • CD2 – canonical surface adhesion/activation molecule of T cells and NK cells, rarely expressed outside lymphoid lineages. • ARHGAP27 – Rho-GTPase–activating protein that modulates actin dynamics and endocytosis following antigen-receptor engagement in lymphocytes. • VPS9D1 – Rab5 guanine-nucleotide-exchange factor domain-containing protein that promotes early endosomal trafficking; enriched in immune cells undergoing receptor internalization. • FBXO3 – F-box component of SCF E3 ubiquitin ligase complexes that fine-tunes cytokine signaling (e.g., TRAF regulation) during lymphocyte activation. • METTL1 – tRNA m7G methyltransferase up-regulated in proliferating or metabolically active immune cells, including activated T cells. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions detected; however, METTL1 and FBXO3 are broadly expressed housekeeping/ubiquitin genes and are not lymphoid-specific, so their presence alone does not confirm the program.

program_123.description: The gene set points to a mesenchymal / epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT)–like program characterized by enhanced cytoskeletal remodeling and branched-chain amino-acid (BCAA) catabolism, a state commonly seen in migratory fibroblasts or carcinoma cells acquiring motility. Evidence: • ARHGEF5 – Rho-GEF that activates RhoA to drive actin-stress-fiber formation and focal-adhesion turnover during cell migration and EMT. • ZNF322 – Oncogenic zinc-finger transcription factor that up-regulates AP-1 components (e.g., JUN) and MMPs, promoting invasion in lung and other carcinomas. • MGA – MAX-binding transcriptional regulator that modulates MYC-dependent transcription in proliferating, often de-differentiated, cells; its expression increases during EMT in some models. • BCKDHB – Mitochondrial E1β subunit of the BCKD complex; elevated BCAA oxidation supplies energy and NADH required for motile, proliferative mesenchymal cells. • TTC7B – Scaffolds the PI4KIIIα complex that generates PI4P at the plasma membrane, a lipid important for membrane dynamics and migratory signaling. Inconsistencies: • Absence of canonical EMT markers such as VIM, FN1, SNAI1 or ZEB1, and lack of epithelial gene repression, means the program may represent an early or partial EMT or a more generic mesenchymal activation rather than a full EMT signature. • Genes in the list are not uniquely restricted to mesenchymal cells; several (e.g., BCKDHB, MGA) are broadly expressed, so additional context would strengthen cell-type assignment.

program_124.description: The program most plausibly reflects epithelial-derived cells that have entered a proliferative, cytoskeleton-remodeling state characteristic of an early epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) or migratory activation, rather than marking a specific differentiated lineage. Evidence: • ARHGEF5 – Rho-GEF that activates RhoA/ROCK signalling, promotes actin re-organization and EMT-associated cell motility. • CDK10 – Cyclin-dependent kinase that drives cell-cycle progression and centrosome integrity, pointing to heightened proliferation. • FN3KRP – Metabolic stress-response/deglycation enzyme up-regulated in transformed or metabolically active cells, often concomitant with EMT programs. • Co-occurrence of cell-cycle (CDK10) and motility/actin-regulating (ARHGEF5) genes is typical of epithelial cells preparing for migration or invasion. Inconsistencies: • Canonical EMT markers (e.g., VIM, SNAI1/2, ZEB1) and epithelial markers (e.g., EPCAM, KRTs) are absent, so the assignment rests on indirect evidence. • TTC38 and LINC03051 have limited functional annotation, offering little specific support for EMT or a particular cell type.

program_125.description: The program most plausibly reflects a generic proliferative/house-keeping state seen in actively cycling progenitor or stem-like cells, characterised by heightened nuclear import, ubiquitin-mediated proteolysis and cytoskeletal remodelling rather than a lineage-restricted identity. Evidence: • TNPO2 – importin-β family member that mediates nuclear import of RNA-binding and splicing factors, up-regulated in dividing cells requiring high nucleo-cytoplasmic shuttling. • CUL4B and ASB7 – scaffold (CUL4B) and SOCS-box protein (ASB7) that assemble Cullin-RING E3 ubiquitin ligase complexes, supporting DNA-replication licensing and rapid protein turnover typical of cycling cells. • NR2C2 (TR4) – orphan nuclear receptor that partners with stem-cell factors (e.g., NANOG) and promotes self-renewal and metabolic adaptation in progenitors. • SPECC1L – actin–microtubule cross-linker involved in cytoskeletal reorganisation and cell migration, processes frequently up-regulated during proliferation and tissue remodelling. Inconsistencies: • Classic S/G2-M proliferation markers (e.g., MKI67, PCNA, MCMs) are absent, so the program may denote a more basal “growth/house-keeping” module rather than a high-mitotic burst.

program_126.description: The gene set represents an integrated stress response/unfolded-protein-response (ISR/UPR) program that is switched on when cells experience ER stress, amino-acid deprivation or other proteotoxic insults, rather than marking a particular lineage. Evidence: • DDIT3 (CHOP) – canonical effector of the PERK-eIF2α arm of the UPR, induced during ER stress. • ATF4 – master transcription factor of the ISR, drives genes involved in amino-acid biosynthesis, redox control and autophagy. • TRIB3 – direct ATF4/DDIT3 target that feeds back on Akt signalling during prolonged stress. • SLC3A2 (CD98hc) – amino-acid transporter subunit transcriptionally up-regulated by ATF4 to bolster nutrient import under starvation. • P2RX7 – purinergic receptor up-regulated in cells exposed to extracellular ATP released from damaged tissue, fitting a broader stress/inflammatory context. Inconsistencies: • None of the listed genes contradict an ISR/UPR program; P2RX7 is more typical of immune cells but is also stress-inducible, so it does not conflict with the overall interpretation.

program_127.description: The program is most consistent with cells undergoing ciliogenesis—such as differentiating motile-ciliated epithelial cells or spermatids—characterised by induction of intraflagellar transport machinery and heightened mitochondrial support for ciliary function. Evidence: • IFT74 – core intraflagellar transport B-complex component indispensable for axoneme elongation in motile and primary cilia; its up-regulation is a hallmark of ciliating cells. • COQ6 – catalyses a step in coenzyme-Q biosynthesis, supporting the elevated mitochondrial respiration that powers ciliary beating. • GCN1 – activator of the GCN2-eIF2α integrated-stress-response, reported to rise during ciliogenesis to modulate translational demand. • FAM234A and C10orf88 – although poorly characterised, publicly available single-cell atlases show enriched expression in airway multiciliated cells and testis, tissues rich in motile cilia, aligning them with the ciliogenic program. Inconsistencies: • Classical ciliogenesis regulators (e.g., FOXJ1, DNAH5, IFT88) are absent, so the program captures only a partial ciliogenic signature. • FAM234A has also been linked to erythroid traits, indicating it may not be exclusively ciliogenic.

program_128.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, proliferating lymphoid population (antigen-stimulated B or T cells) that is simultaneously experiencing an endoplasmic-reticulum stress/unfolded-protein-response (UPR). Evidence: • ZFAT – lymphoid-restricted transcription factor required for B- and T-cell development; strongly expressed in peripheral lymphocytes. • PPP3R1 – regulatory subunit of calcineurin; essential for Ca²⁺/NFAT signaling that is triggered immediately after antigen-receptor engagement in T and B cells, marking immune activation. • KNSTRN – kinetochore/mitotic-spindle protein expressed in G2/M, indicating that the cells are actively cycling following activation. • CRELD2 – ER-resident chaperone induced by ATF6/XBP1 during the UPR; up-regulated when lymphocytes boost secretory output (e.g., cytokines or immunoglobulin). • C22orf39 – enriched in hematopoietic tissues and reported to rise during immune activation in single-cell datasets, aligning with a lymphoid program. Inconsistencies: • No major contradictions within the limited gene list; all listed genes can be accommodated within an activated, cycling lymphocyte state.

program_129.description: This gene set reflects activation of the endoplasmic-reticulum (ER) unfolded-protein response (UPR)—a stress-induced transcriptional program common in highly secretory or acutely stressed cells rather than a lineage-specific signature. Evidence: • HSPA5 (BiP/GRP78) – master ER chaperone up-regulated by ATF6/IRE1/XBP1 during UPR. • HSP90B1 (GRP94) – ER-resident HSP90 family member induced by ER stress to assist immunoglobulin and other secretory protein folding. • CALR – ER Ca2+-binding chaperone that pairs with CALNEXIN in quality control; transcriptionally boosted in UPR. • PDIA3 (ERp57) – disulfide isomerase in the calnexin/calreticulin cycle; canonical UPR target. • MANF – cytoprotective ER-stress-inducible protein that limits PERK signaling. Inconsistencies: • None detected; all listed genes are classic UPR/ER-stress responders.

program_130.description: The program most closely fits an NF-κB–driven inflammatory activation state in innate myeloid cells (monocytes / macrophages or dendritic cells). Evidence: • CARD9 – adaptor almost exclusively expressed in myeloid lineage; couples C-type-lectin/NOD signaling to NF-κB cytokine production. • IKBIP – interacts with IκB-kinase complex, up-regulated by inflammatory cues and TGF-β, reinforcing NF-κB signalling during macrophage activation. • HSD11B1L – paralogue of HSD11B1, an enzyme enriched in macrophages that modulates local glucocorticoid tone and is induced during inflammation. • CRACR2B – Ca²⁺/calcineurin pathway component used by immune cells to sustain activation-dependent Ca²⁺ influx. • HDAC1 – chromatin modifier recruited to NF-κB target loci; increased activity is characteristic of pro-inflammatory macrophage polarization. Inconsistencies: • HDAC1 and CRACR2B are broadly expressed housekeeping/ signalling genes, so their presence alone is not strictly myeloid-specific; however, together with CARD9 and IKBIP they support a generic inflammatory programme rather than a unique cell identity.

program_131.description: The program reflects a generic proteostasis / stress-adaptation state rather than a specific lineage identity, marked by coordinated up-regulation of ER-associated degradation, mitochondrial ribosome assembly and a brake on innate-immune signaling—features commonly seen in diverse cell types that are resolving inflammatory or proteotoxic stress. Evidence: • NPLOC4 – core component of the VCP–UFD1L–NPLOC4 complex that extracts mis-folded proteins from the ER for degradation, a hallmark of ER-stress responses. • MTG2 – mitochondrial GTPase required for assembly of the large mitoribosomal subunit, supporting elevated mitochondrial translation often induced during recovery from stress. • CNNM2 – Mg²⁺ transporter; increased Mg²⁺ influx is needed for ATP-dependent protein-folding and refolding processes that accompany proteostasis programs. • TRAFD1 – interferon-inducible negative regulator of TLR/RIG-I signaling; its induction is characteristic of cells dampening innate-immune activation after an inflammatory hit. • RGL3 – guanine-nucleotide exchange factor that modulates small-GTPase trafficking pathways, facilitating ER/ Golgi vesicular transport during enhanced degradation or remodeling. Inconsistencies: No negatively loaded genes were supplied, and none of the positive genes conflict with the described stress-adaptation/proteostasis state.

program_132.description: The gene composition is most consistent with a stress-sensing, quiescent/poised state frequently observed in hematopoietic stem and early myeloid progenitor cells, characterized by cell-cycle restraint, heightened nucleic-acid surveillance and nutrient-sensing capacity. Evidence: • PLAGL1 – an imprinted tumor-suppressor transcription factor that enforces cell-cycle arrest and is repeatedly reported as elevated in quiescent hematopoietic and other adult stem cells. • DDX41 – DEAD-box helicase acting as a cytosolic DNA sensor and splicing factor; highly expressed in hematopoietic stem/progenitor compartments and up-regulated when these cells prime antiviral/interferon pathways. • SLC38A9 – lysosomal arginine transporter that couples amino-acid availability to mTORC1, a hallmark nutrient-sensing mechanism used by quiescent cells to balance growth versus dormancy. • CNPY4 – ER‐resident chaperone facilitating Toll-like receptor maturation, supporting a “ready” innate immune state typical of early myeloid lineages. • TSEN54 – component of the tRNA-splicing endonuclease complex, fitting a transcription/translation–maintenance program rather than active proliferation. Inconsistencies: • The gene set is small and lacks classical definitive HSC markers (e.g., PROM1, KIT, GATA2) or strong interferon signatures (e.g., IFITM, ISG15), so attribution to a specific stem/progenitor population is tentative.

program_133.description: The program reflects a macrophage‐lineage cell in a phagolysosomal/iron-handling (alternatively activated, tissue-resident) state, characterized by high expression of lysosomal proteases and iron-sequestration genes typical of red-pulp, Kupffer or disease-associated macrophages. Evidence: • Lysosomal proteases – CTSD (Cathepsin D) and LGMN (Legumain) are canonical lysosomal enzymes up-regulated during macrophage phagolysosome maturation. • GPNMB – marker of alternatively activated, tissue-resident and disease-associated macrophages/microglia that have heightened lysosomal and debris-clearance activity. • PLA2G7 – secreted phospholipase produced by macrophages that modulates inflammatory lipids and is enriched in foam-cell–like or anti-inflammatory macrophage states. • HAMP (Hepcidin) – iron-regulatory hormone induced in macrophages engaged in erythrophagocytosis or inflammatory iron sequestration, fitting an iron-handling resident macrophage program. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes support a lysosomal, iron-sequestering macrophage state.

program_134.description: The gene set represents a generic “immediate-early” activation program that is rapidly induced in many cell types after acute stimulation or tissue-dissociation stress, rather than marking a specific lineage; it reflects transient AP-1/MAPK signaling and accompanying negative-feedback regulators. Evidence: • AP-1 transcription factors FOS and FOSB are canonical immediate-early genes induced within minutes of MAPK or Ca²⁺ signaling. • ZFP36 (tristetraprolin) and DUSP1 are prototypical early feedback inhibitors downstream of the same pathways, curbing TNF-α mRNA stability and MAPK activity, respectively. • KLF4 is likewise a rapidly inducible transcription factor up-regulated by serum or cytokine exposure, often co-expressed with FOS in early-response gene clusters. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes coherently fit an immediate-early activation/stress-response program.

program_135.description: The program most parsimoniously reflects a generic stem- or progenitor-cell state characterized by active Notch signalling and Wnt/β-catenin–driven self-renewal, a profile commonly seen in undifferentiated epithelial, neural or hematopoietic precursors. Evidence: • POFUT1 – O-fucosylates Notch receptors; high expression is required for strong Notch signalling in multiple stem-cell compartments (intestinal crypts, hematopoietic and neural progenitors). • PLAGL2 – Transcription factor that boosts Wnt/β-catenin target gene expression and maintains stemness in intestinal, neural and hematopoietic stem cells. • HIVEP2 – Broad transcriptional regulator implicated in early developmental gene programs and hematopoietic stem-cell maintenance. • PEX13 – Peroxisome-import component; elevated in metabolically active, proliferating cells such as stem/progenitor populations. • KBTBD3 – BTB/kelch protein linked to cytoskeletal organization; up-regulated in dividing, undifferentiated cells. Inconsistencies: • The set is small and lacks classical lineage-specific stem markers (e.g., LGR5 for intestinal, NES/SOX2 for neural), so the precise tissue origin of the progenitor state cannot be resolved. • Several genes (PEX13, KBTBD3) are ubiquitous housekeeping or regulatory factors, not uniquely stem-cell-specific, so the program may partly reflect general proliferative metabolism rather than a dedicated stem signature.

program_136.description: The gene set is most consistent with a myeloid program characteristic of CD11b⁺ monocytes / macrophages that are in a motile, tissue-remodeling (M2-like or tumor-associated) activation state. Evidence: • ITGAM (CD11b) – canonical surface integrin of circulating monocytes, tissue macrophages and tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs). • S100A10 – forms the ANXA2/S100A10 plasminogen-receptor complex on alternatively activated macrophages, promoting extracellular matrix degradation and angiogenesis. • S100A4 – up-regulated in M2 macrophages and TAMs, linked to enhanced cell motility and matrix remodeling. • PFN1 – actin-binding protein that increases during macrophage spreading and chemotaxis, supporting a migratory phenotype. • SH3BGRL3 – adaptor protein reported to rise during macrophage activation and in inflammatory or tumor microenvironments. Inconsistencies: • PFN1 and S100A4 are not exclusive to macrophages (also found in fibroblasts and many other motile cells), so their presence alone is not definitive for myeloid identity, but they do not contradict the overall macrophage activation signature.

program_137.description: The program most consistently reflects a generic metabolic-stress/adaptive autophagy state that cells engage when nutrient or genotoxic stress requires increased NAD⁺ salvage, ubiquitin-mediated proteostasis and lysosome-dependent turnover rather than pointing to a specific lineage. Evidence: • NMNAT1 – nuclear NAD⁺‐salvage enzyme up-regulated during DNA-damage and oxidative stress responses. • RAB12 – GTPase induced by starvation that repositions lysosomes and promotes autophagy downstream of mTORC1 inhibition. • UBE2V1 – K63-linked ubiquitin E2 variant that partners with UBE2N to mark proteins for autophagic degradation and to activate NF-κB during cellular stress. • SH2B1 – adaptor that amplifies insulin/leptin/JAK–STAT signals, typically induced during metabolic adaptation. • KCTD3 – BTB/Kelch protein that binds cullin-3 ubiquitin ligase complexes, linking stress signaling to targeted protein turnover. Inconsistencies: • Lack of classical core ATG genes (e.g., ATG5, LC3B) means the program captures only part of the full autophagy module. • SH2B1 and KCTD3 are also enriched in neuronal tissues, so their presence could alternatively reflect neuronal identity, but remaining genes do not strongly support a neuron-specific program.

program_0.description: The gene set is most consistent with a serous-acinar secretory program typical of airway submucosal-gland or minor salivary-gland serous cells—an epithelial state specialized for production of antimicrobial, protein-rich fluid rather than the SCGB1A1-positive club-cell secretions. Evidence: • Antimicrobial/secreted serous proteins up-regulated: LYZ, LTF, BPIFA1, BPIFB1, SLPI, LPO, MUC7, STATH, PRR4, CRISP3, PIP and ODAM are canonical products of serous acinar cells in airway and salivary glands. • Fluid/ion secretion machinery up-regulated: SLC12A2 (NKCC1), KCNN4, KCNMA1, ANO1, AQP1 and ATP2A3 support the high anion / water flux characteristic of serous secretion. • Developmental/gland lineage TFs enriched: SOX9, ASCL2, FOXC1, ETV1, BARX2—factors implicated in airway gland and salivary-gland epithelial differentiation. • Negative loadings mark exclusion of alternative secretory states: strong depletion of club-cell genes SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1, SCNN1G and detoxification genes (GSTA1, GSTP1, AKR1C1), and of TACSTD2/KRT7-high simple epithelium, fits a serous rather than club or superficial epithelial identity. Inconsistencies: • Myeloid-associated CD14 and HP, and stress genes (FOS, HSPB1) appear but are few and could reflect ambient RNA or broad epithelial stress responses. • SOX10 and CRISP2 are more typical of salivary or other exocrine tissues, suggesting the program may encompass serous cells across multiple glandular sites rather than being strictly airway-restricted.

program_1.description: The gene set represents a motile multiciliated‐cell program characteristic of fully differentiated airway/ependymal/oviduct epithelial cells undergoing or having completed ciliogenesis and axonemal assembly. Evidence: • Core ciliogenesis and axonemal components: dozens of CFAP genes, DNAH5/6/7/9/10/11/12 (axonemal dynein heavy chains), DNALI1, DNAL1, DYNLT2B, DRC1/3 (dynein-regulatory complex), GAS8, HYDIN, SPAG17, KIF9, confirming motile cilium structure and beating machinery. • Transcriptional drivers of motile ciliation: FOXJ1 and RFX3 are master regulators of multiciliated lineage specification. • Basal body/centriole amplification and docking: CEP83, CC2D2A, CCDC65/78/146/181, FUZ, TTC21A, IFT22/25/140, TTLL7/9/10 (tubulin glutamylases) support active ciliogenesis. • Apical junction and planar polarity proteins typical of airway multiciliated cells: MPDZ, CDHR3, CDHR4, LRRC6/23/49, ANKS1A. • Secreted antioxidant GPX3 is negatively loaded, consistent with its enrichment in non-ciliated secretory (club/goblet) cells and repression in multiciliated cells. Inconsistencies: • CD4 (T-cell marker), GPC3, GRIN3B and a few neuronal/endocrine genes (SYT8, BAIAP3) appear positively loaded, suggesting minor contamination or low-level promiscuous expression not typical of multiciliated epithelia.

program_2.description: The program is most consistent with alveolar type II epithelial (AT2) cells that have entered an injury-associated, inflammatory “transitional” state on the way toward type I (AT1) differentiation. Classic surfactant and lipid-handling genes of AT2 cells are retained, while AT1/mesenchymal, IFN/NF-κB and cytokine response genes are simultaneously induced; airway secretory cell genes are specifically repressed. Evidence: • Canonical AT2 identity – surfactant/lipid genes SFTPA1/2, SFTPC, SFTPD, SLC34A2, ABCA3, LPCAT1, NAPSA, NKX2-1, MUC1-related AGR3 remain strongly positive. • Induction of AT1 or transitional markers – HOPX, AGER, CAV1/2, CAVIN2, TAGLN2, VIM, CLDN18 indicate partial acquisition of AT1/EMT features typical of damage-associated transitional cells. • Injury / inflammatory activation – IFITM1/2/3, NFKBIA, CXCL2, CCL2, CCL20, SERPING1, CD74, HLA-DRB5, LAMP3, CHI3L1, GDF15, SOCS2, CSF1/3R mark NF-κB, interferon and cytokine signalling seen after lung injury. • Stress–response / metabolic remodelling – GDF15, DAPK1/2, TIMP3, NNMT, RGS16, GDF15, CITED2, NNMT point to oxidative and metabolic stress characteristic of regenerating epithelium. • Negative loading of airway secretory/goblet genes – BPIFA1, BPIFB1, SLPI, TCN1, CLDN10, MSMB, XBP1 underscores suppression of proximal airway secretory identity and supports an alveolar, not bronchiolar, program. Inconsistencies: • Co-expression of both AT2 (SFTPC) and mature AT1 (AGER, HOPX) markers reflects an intermediate rather than pure cell state. • Occasional “off-target” genes (UPK3B, HPCAL1) are present but low in number and likely reflect ambient RNA or low-level noise rather than a conflicting cell identity.

program_3.description: The gene set is most consistent with an activated, mucus-secreting “goblet” airway epithelial program, characteristic of bronchial/bronchiolar goblet cells that arise during goblet-cell hyperplasia or metaplasia in inflamed airways. Evidence: • Goblet-cell/mucus machinery – high expression of MUC5AC, MUC16, AGR2, TFF3, WFDC2, CLCA2, LGALS3, SLC26A4 and FOXA3, all classical markers or regulators of airway goblet cells and mucus production. • Secretory epithelial identity – TACSTD2 (EpCAM), KRT19, ALCAM, ANXA2, PRSS23, TSPAN1/8, MDK, SPARCL1 and multiple SERPINB family genes mark non-ciliated secretory epithelium. • Oxidative / xenobiotic and inflammatory profile typical of inflamed goblet epithelium – CXCL1, CXCL6, LCN2, CYBA, DDIT4, metallothioneins (MT1E/X/G/F/H/M/3), GSTA1, TXN, UCP2. • Metabolic/secretory co-factors – ALDH1A1, GLUL, CP, SLC31A1, ABCA13 support high secretory and antioxidant activity seen in goblet cells. • Negative loading of canonical club-cell genes SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1, BPIFA1 and of the anti-inflammatory protease inhibitor TIMP3 indicates the program is inversely related to the club-cell state and thus reflects differentiation away from club toward goblet identity. Inconsistencies: • Club-cell xenobiotic enzymes CYP2F1, CYP4B1 and CYP2A13 are positively loaded, although club markers are otherwise suppressed. • ABCA13 and CD9 are more typical of alveolar type II cells. • UPK1B (urothelial) and immune genes CLEC12A, SLAMF7 appear sporadically and are not standard goblet-cell markers, suggesting some gene leakage or doublets.

program_4.description: The gene set outlines a highly secretory, luminal epithelial program most consistent with prostate gland secretory (NKX3-1⁺ / MSMB⁺) cells that are experiencing strong mucin production and endoplasmic-reticulum/Golgi activity. Evidence: • Prostate-restricted luminal markers: NKX3-1, MSMB, FOLH1 (PSMA), PSCA, KLK11, KLK12, TSPAN1 – canonical for differentiated prostate epithelium. • Secretory/goblet-like and mucin genes (supporting a high-output luminal state): MUC5B, MUC5AC, AGR2, TFF1, TFF3, FCGBP, BPIFB1/2, ITLN1, VSIG2, SPDEF. • ER/UPR and protein-processing machinery typical of cells under heavy secretory load: XBP1, CREB3L1/4, PDIA3/4, FKBP11, SEC62, HERPUD1, OST4. • Additional generic luminal/epithelial components: CLDN10/22, CD24, EPCAM-associated tetraspanins (CD9, CD63, TSPAN8/13), HLA-B/C. • Negative loading of endothelial/mesenchymal genes (RNASE1, SPARCL1, CYP4X1, A2M) further distinguishes this from vascular or stromal programs. Inconsistencies: • Airway-associated mucins and innate-defence genes (MUC5B/AC, BPIFB1/2, CXCL17) are not typical of prostate and may reflect either ectopic expression or contamination from other secretory epithelia. • Classic prostate kallikrein KLK3/ACPP are absent, indicating the program may represent a mucin-biased subset of prostate epithelium or a related glandular tissue rather than the full canonical prostate secretome.

program_5.description: The program is characteristic of epithelial cells that have recently been stimulated by pro-inflammatory cytokines (e.g. TNF-α / IL-1β), showing a rapid NF-κB / AP-1 “early-response” transcriptional state that drives chemokine and cytokine production. Evidence: • Epithelial structural genes – CLDN4, GPRC5A, TM4SF1, BCAM, ICAM1, SDC4, EZR point to an epithelial origin. • Immediate-early/AP-1 transcription factors – JUN, FOS, JUNB, FOSB, JUND, ATF3, EGR1/2, NR4A1/2, KLF2/6/10 are classic rapid-response genes induced minutes after cytokine or stress signalling. • NF-κB pathway activation – NFKBIA, NFKBIZ, TNFAIP3, ZC3H12A, SOCS3, DUSP1/2/5 are canonical NF-κB target genes and feedback inhibitors. • Secreted inflammatory mediators – IL6, CSF3, LIF, CXCL1/2/3/8, CCL2, CCL20, AREG, HBEGF, EDN1, CCN1/2, MMP7 reflect an epithelial cell actively recruiting and regulating immune cells and remodelling tissue. • Stress / apoptosis modulators – GADD45B, CDKN1A, PMAIP1, BBC3, GDF15 denote concurrent stress-response and survival pathways, typical of cytokine-challenged epithelium. • Negative loading of SLPI, a protease inhibitor normally high in resting mucosal epithelium, is consistent with its repression after TNF/IL-1 stimulation. Inconsistencies: • Low-level induction of MHC-II genes (HLA-DQA2, HLA-DRB5) is more typical of professional antigen-presenting cells, although epithelial cells can ectopically express them after IFN-γ exposure. • KLF2 is classically endothelial, but is also an early stress gene and can be transiently expressed in epithelium under shear or cytokine stress. Overall, the gene set most parsimoniously reflects an acutely inflamed, cytokine-stimulated epithelial state rather than a resting epithelial or immune cell phenotype.

program_6.description: The gene set describes an epithelial cell program characteristic of airway/alveolar secretory cells that have entered an acute inflammatory / stress-activated state (often termed KRT7/8⁺ “damage-associated transient progenitors” or inflammatory secretory epithelium). These cells retain epithelial/secretory features but up-regulate AP-1 and interferon–response genes, cytokines and MHC-II molecules, while canonical homeostatic secretory genes are concomitantly repressed. Evidence: • Epithelial/secretory identity – KRT7, CLDN4, SCGB3A2, FOLR1, GGT5, KLK10/13/14, TACR1, MMP7. • Stress & AP-1 activation – FOS, JUN, JUNB, IER2, ZFP36, DUSP1, EGR1, RHOB. • Interferon / innate antiviral response – IFITM1/2/3, RNASE1, CXCL2, CXCL3, IL6, SAA1, RARRES2. • Antigen presentation & immune crosstalk – HLA-DRB5, HLA-DQA1, CD74, UBD, NFKBIA, C1R/C1S. • Metabolic/remodeling factors seen in injured alveolar epithelium – HOPX, NNMT, SERPINA1, EGFL7, TIMP3. • Negative loadings highlight loss of normal secretory programmes – down-regulation of SLPI, PIGR, TFF3, DPP4, FAM3D, SLC12A2, CLDN22, FXYD3 that typify quiescent airway/gut secretory cells. Inconsistencies: • HLA class II expression (HLA-DRB5, DQA1, CD74) is more typical of professional antigen-presenting cells but can be induced in epithelium by IFN-γ. • SERPINA1 is classically hepatic, though it is reported in stressed alveolar epithelium.

program_7.description: This gene program is most consistent with lung-resident/alveolar macrophages (and closely related monocyte-derived macrophages) in an activated, lipid-handling state characterized by Fc-receptor/complement signaling, phagolysosomal activity, and surfactant-lipid metabolism. Evidence: • Myeloid/macrophage core: TYROBP, FCER1G, CD68, AIF1, LST1, MS4A7, SPI1, SLC11A1, LGALS1 – canonical markers of tissue macrophages. • Complement & opsonization: C1QA, C1QB, C1QC, VSIG4 – classic complement genes enriched in resident macrophages. • Alveolar/lipid metabolism signature: APOE, APOC1, FABP4, LPL, MARCO, OLR1, CYP27A1 – genes required for handling surfactant-derived lipids and cholesterol typical of alveolar macrophages. • Phagolysosomal & oxidative stress machinery: CTSD, CTSS, ACP5, PSAP, GPX1, PRDX1, ATP6V0C – supports active phagocytosis/antigen processing. • Activation cues: IL1B, AREG, CCL18, LTA4H, TNFRSF12A – mix of pro-inflammatory and alternatively activated (M2-like) transcripts often seen in lung macrophages responding to injury. • Negative loading of airway secretory cell genes BPIFA1 and BPIFB1 argues against epithelial identity and reinforces a distinct macrophage program. Inconsistencies: • SFTPC (type II alveolar epithelial), PECAM1 & RNASE1 (endothelial), TM4SF1 (stromal/endothelial) and GZMA (cytotoxic lymphocytes) may reflect ambient RNA or doublets. • FBP1 and FXYD5 are more typical of epithelial/hepatic contexts; their presence is atypical for macrophages but may represent low-level background transcription.

program_8.description: The gene set is most consistent with tissue-resident macrophages that have transitioned into an activated, antigen-presenting state (e.g., “MHC-II-high” or disease-associated macrophages/microglia). The program combines classical macrophage core genes, strong MHC class I/II expression, complement/apolipoprotein modules linked to phagocytosis and lipid handling, and receptors (TYROBP/FCER1G axis) characteristic of inflammatory activation. Evidence: • Core macrophage/microglia markers: TYROBP, FCER1G, CD68, AIF1 (IBA1), COTL1, LAPTM5, CST3, CD9 • Resident macrophage lipid/complement module: APOE, APOC1, FABP4, CLU, C1QA, C1QB, C1QC, OLR1, ALOX5AP • Phagocytic scavenger receptors enriched in tissue macrophages: MARCO, OLR1, APOE • Antigen-presentation machinery up-regulated (activated state): broad MHC-II panel (HLA-DRA, DRB1, DPA1, DPB1, DQA1/2, DQB1, DMA/B, DOA), MHC-I genes (HLA-A, ‑B, ‑C, ‑E, ‑F, ‑G), CD74, B2M • Signaling/adaptor genes seen in inflammatory macrophage programs: ALOX5AP, HCST, CORO1A, SERPINA1, IFITM3 Inconsistencies: • BANK1 and CD52 are typically lymphocyte-associated; their presence may reflect minor contamination or low-level expression. • FBP1 is a gluconeogenic enzyme usually linked to hepatic or renal cells but is sporadically detected in certain macrophage subsets under metabolic stress.

program_9.description: The program most closely matches an activated, inflammatory monocyte / macrophage state that engages in chemokine release and complement-mediated innate immune functions, typical of recently recruited or tissue-resident C1QC⁺ macrophages responding to pro-inflammatory cues. Evidence: • Classical myeloid / macrophage core: TYROBP, FCER1G, LAPTM5, ALOX5AP, ARHGDIB, ITGB2, CD37 – adaptor, phagosomal and integrin genes enriched in monocytes/macrophages. • C1QC module characteristic of C1QC⁺ inflammatory macrophages (often termed “TREM2/C1QC” in scRNA-seq studies): C1QC, APOC1, TYROBP, LGALS1. • Antigen presentation capacity: HLA-DPA1 plus accessory molecules (CD52, BTG1). • Chemokine/cytokine production typical of inflammatory macrophages: CCL3, CCL4, CCL4L2, CCL5, IL32. • Transcriptional/feedback regulators induced by inflammatory signals: NR4A2, TSC22D3, ZFP36L2, DUSP4, CREM. • Cytoskeletal and vesicular transport genes supporting phagocytosis and motility: ACTB, CORO1A, EVL, ACAP1, SYTL3. Inconsistencies: • GNLY and SRGN (lytic-granule proteins of cytotoxic T/NK cells). • HCST (DAP10) and CXCR4 are more typical of NK/lymphoid subsets. • KRT15 (epithelial keratin) and S100A4 (fibroblast/mesenchymal marker) likely reflect ambient RNA or doublets rather than the core macrophage program.

program_10.description: The program depicts a secretory mucosal/airway-type epithelial cell that is experiencing an interferon-driven activation of antigen-presentation pathways, consistent with an “IFN-stimulated secretory epithelial” state often seen during viral infection or inflammatory challenge. Evidence: • Secretory/mucosal epithelial identity – KRT19, AGR2, WFDC2 (HE4), BPIFB1, FAM3D, CXCL17, PRSS23, FXYD3, CLDN10, TSPAN1/8, CD9/CD63 all mark secretory or goblet/club epithelial cells of airways and other mucosae. • Active secretory/ER–Golgi machinery – SPCS2, TMED10, SSR4, LAPTM4A, PDIA3, FKBP11, NUCB2, ITM2B, TMBIM6 support high protein secretion typical of these cells. • Interferon/antigen-presentation response – IFI27, IFI44L, TNFSF10, PSMB9 plus strong up-regulation of MHC-I genes (HLA-A, ‑B, ‑C, ‑F, ‑G) and class-II component HLA-DMB indicate type-I/II IFN signalling and enhanced antigen processing. • Chemokine/immune recruitment – CXCL17 and LCN2 are epithelial-derived factors that attract myeloid cells during infection, aligning with an antiviral alert state. Inconsistencies: • UPK1B (uroplakin) is more typical of urothelial cells, and HLA-DMB expression is uncommon in resting epithelium but can be induced by IFN-γ, so both are explainable as context-dependent rather than contradictory.

program_11.description: The gene set most closely matches an epithelial cell undergoing a strong acute-phase/IL-1/IL-17/TNF-driven inflammatory response—a state often termed “inflammatory secretory epithelium.” These epithelial cells up-regulate antimicrobial peptides, chemokines that recruit neutrophils/monocytes, complement components and class II MHC, while retaining transport/secretory genes characteristic of differentiated airway, intestinal or glandular epithelium. Evidence: • Acute-phase / antimicrobial genes: SAA1, SAA2, SAA4, LCN2, DEFB4A, PI3, S100A8, S100A9, CP, CFB, CLU—classically induced in barrier epithelia exposed to IL-1β/TNF/IL-17. • Neutrophil-/monocyte-recruiting chemokines and cytokines: CXCL5, CCL20, CCL2, CSF3. • Antigen-presentation machinery up-regulated by IFN-γ in inflamed epithelium: HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DQA1, IDO1, KYNU. • Epithelial/secretory transporters and markers confirming epithelial origin: SLC26A4 (pendrin, airway/intestine), SLC5A5 (NIS, thyroid/mammary/airway), MUCL1, PROM1 (secretory & progenitor epithelium). • Stress-response and inflammation modulators typical of activated epithelium: SAT1, SOD2, TNIP3, CHI3L1. Inconsistencies: • PROM1 (stem/progenitor) and MUCL1/SLC5A5 are more typical of mammary/thyroid epithelium, and their presence suggests either a mixed epithelial population or broader induction of this program. • Classical neutrophil proteins (S100A8/A9) could point to contaminating myeloid cells, but accompanying epithelial transporters and MHC-II genes argue the program resides predominantly in inflamed epithelial cells rather than granulocytes.

program_12.description: The gene set is most consistent with a highly differentiated, mucin-secreting epithelial (goblet / foveolar-like) program found in airway and upper-gastrointestinal epithelia, characterized by abundant mucus production, secretory pathway activity and retinoic-acid–driven differentiation. Evidence: • Mucin and trefoil factors typical of goblet/foveolar cells: MUC5AC, TFF3, BPIFB1, PIGR, FOXA3. • Additional secretory-epithelium markers seen in gastric/airway cells: CEACAM5, WFDC2 (HE4), TSPAN8, VSIG2, PSCA, SCGB2A1. • Retinoic-acid metabolic genes that drive mucosal secretory differentiation: DHRS9, RDH10, STRA6. • ER/secretory-stress components indicating high protein export load: SEC62, CREB3L1, HERPUD1, GPX8. • General secretory or cytoskeletal support genes: GSN, CTSC, S100P. • Down-weighting of ubiquitous RNA-processing factors (HNRNPA1, BTF3) fits a terminally differentiated, low-proliferation secretory state. Inconsistencies: • MSMB and PSCA are better known from prostate epithelium, though both are also detected in gastric/airway secretory cells. • GJB1 (gap junction β-1) is classically glial but can be expressed in some epithelia. • IFI27 and SERPINB11 suggest an interferon/keratinocyte signature that is tangential to mucus secretion.

program_13.description: The gene set represents an interferon-stimulated, antigen-presenting inflammatory monocyte / macrophage state resembling classical “M1-like” activation. Evidence: • Interferon response: IFI27, IFI44L, GBP4, STAT1, WARS1, IDO1 strongly induced by type I/II IFNs. • Antigen presentation machinery: HLA-A, HLA-B (MHC-I) and HLA-DQA1, PSMB9 (immunoproteasome) characteristic of professional antigen-presenting myeloid cells after IFN-γ exposure. • Myeloid lineage / macrophage markers: FCER1G, AIF1 (IBA1), AIF1, S100A8, S100A11, S100A4, PI3, TNIP3 are enriched in activated monocytes/macrophages. • Classical inflammatory effectors: NOS2, DEFB4A, S100A8, PI3 encode nitric oxide synthase and antimicrobial peptides typical of M1 polarization. • Stress-response / cytoskeletal remodelling genes (TMSB10, TMSB4X, PRDX1) commonly rise in activated macrophages. Inconsistencies: • SLC26A4 (pendrin) and SIX3 are more typical of epithelial cells; PI3 and DEFB4A are also produced by epithelial and neutrophil lineages, suggesting some epithelial-related transcripts within the program. • S100A4 is often linked to fibroblasts and motile epithelial cells rather than myeloid cells. These discordant genes are a minority and do not outweigh the predominant interferon-activated myeloid signature.

program_14.description: The program is most consistent with a secretory serous/mesothelial-like epithelial state—an epithelial cell that produces and secretes proteins and displays strong MHC-I expression, a profile often seen in serous-lining epithelia and in serous ovarian, peritoneal or pancreatic duct–like cells. Evidence: • Epithelial structural markers – KRT19, CLDN7, TSPAN1, LGALS3, S100A2/A6/A11, ANXA1/2, GSN support an epithelial cytoskeletal and junctional identity. • Secretory/protease–protease-inhibitor module – AGR2 (ER chaperone for mucins), WFDC2 (HE4), SPINT2, PRSS23, KLK11, CST1, CFD indicate active protein secretion typical of serous/glandular epithelia. • Mesothelial/serous lineage genes – MSLN, UPK1B, PSCA, VSIG2 are characteristic of mesothelial or serous surface/ductal epithelia. • Antigen-presentation/immune-interaction – HLA-A, HLA-C and tetraspanins CD63/TSPAN1 imply high MHC-I display and vesicle trafficking, often up-regulated in inflamed or malignant serous epithelia. • Additional epithelial oxidoreductase/defence genes – CYBA, CYP4B1, CTSC fit with barrier cells exposed to xenobiotics. Inconsistencies: • CYP4B1 is more typical of airway epithelium, and PSCA is classically linked to prostate/bladder; their presence suggests some heterogeneity or a broad epithelial program rather than a purely mesothelial one.

program_15.description: The program represents a generic G2/M-phase cell-cycle module found in actively proliferating cells, independent of specific lineage identity. Evidence: • Mitotic regulators – CDK1, CKS2, PTTG1, CENPF, CENPW, ZWINT govern chromosome segregation, kinetochore formation and metaphase–anaphase transition. • DNA replication/repair factors – TK1 (dNTP synthesis), PCLAF (PCNA-associated), HMGB2, HMGN2, H2AZ1, H4C3 (histone variants) mark S–G2 progression and chromatin remodeling. • Cytoskeleton re-organization – STMN1, TUBB, TUBA1B encode microtubule components or regulators required for spindle assembly during mitosis. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes are canonical G2/M-phase or proliferation markers.

program_16.description: The gene set represents a ubiquitous “high-protein-synthesis / translational machinery” program that marks cells with elevated cytosolic translation—typically metabolically active or proliferating cells—rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. Evidence: • Translation elongation factors (EEF1A1, EEF1B2, EEF2) and the ribosome-associated scaffold RACK1 directly mediate peptide elongation on 80S ribosomes. • Ubiquitin-ribosomal fusion genes UBA52 (RPL40) and FAU (RPS30) are core components of the small ribosomal subunit and are classic markers of high ribosome biogenesis. • Nascent-chain-associated chaperones/co-factors NACA and BTF3 act at the ribosomal exit tunnel, supporting co-translational folding—further indicating active translation. • PABPC1 binds poly-A tails to promote initiation and stability of mRNAs undergoing active translation; TPT1 is a translationally controlled protein up-regulated when global protein synthesis is high. • H3-3A (histone H3.3) is enriched in transcriptionally active chromatin, consistent with the need to supply mRNA for robust protein synthesis. Inconsistencies: • COMMD6 is mainly known for NF-κB and copper‐ion signaling, not translation, though housekeeping genes often co-load with translational programs. • No lineage-defining markers are present, underscoring that this signature is functional (protein synthesis) rather than cell-type specific.

program_17.description: The gene set is most consistent with bronchiolar airway epithelial cells that are transitioning from secretory/club identity toward a multiciliated state and displaying a strong xenobiotic-metabolism/oxidative-stress program. Evidence: • Airway-restricted xenobiotic enzymes – CYP2F1 and CYP2A13 are classic markers of club (Clara) cells in human bronchioles and nasal epithelium. • Multiciliogenesis marker – CCNO is required for deuterosome-mediated centriole amplification during differentiation of multiciliated airway cells. • Pan-epithelial structural genes – KRT19 and TSPAN8 are broadly expressed in airway luminal epithelial populations, supporting an epithelial origin. • Detoxification/oxidative-stress genes – MT1F, MT1G and MT3 (metallothioneins) commonly rise in airway epithelium exposed to reactive oxygen species and xenobiotics. • Additional metabolic/secretory components – PRSS23 (serine protease enriched in airway epithelium), ADH1C (alcohol dehydrogenase found in lung secretory cells), and ATP6V1B1 (v-ATPase subunit contributing to airway surface liquid acidification) further support a secretory–luminal airway phenotype. Inconsistencies: • ADH1C is classically hepatic, and ATP6V1B1 is best known from renal intercalated cells; their presence is compatible with, but not specific to, airway epithelium. • Absence of canonical ciliogenesis transcription factors (e.g., FOXJ1) could indicate an early or partial ciliated differentiation state rather than fully mature multiciliated cells.

program_18.description: The gene set is most consistent with an airway mucous-secretory (goblet/submucosal gland) epithelial program characterized by high mucin production and an activated secretory pathway. Evidence: • Mucus production – MUC5B (major gel-forming mucin of airway goblet and submucosal-gland cells) and AGR2 (ER protein required for mucin folding) define mucous secretory identity. • Airway-restricted secreted proteins – BPIFB2 (LPLUNC2), an abundant product of upper-airway secretory cells, and ANG (angiogenin) are typical of serous/goblet secretions. • Secretory machinery – GOLM1 (Golgi membrane protein), FKBP11 (ER chaperone) and TIMP1 (secreted metalloproteinase inhibitor) support a high-output secretory state. • Epithelial barrier components – CLDN22 (tight-junction claudin) signals epithelial origin. • Metabolic and transcriptional support – HMGCS2 (ketogenic enzyme up-regulated in stressed airway epithelium) and the homeobox factor NKX3-1 (reported at low levels in some respiratory mucous cells) align with specialized glandular epithelium. Inconsistencies: • NKX3-1 is best known as a prostate luminal marker and is only sparsely reported in airway epithelium. • HMGCS2 and CLDN22 are more typical of intestinal/liver epithelium than airway, although they can be induced in stressed airway cells.

program_19.description: The gene set represents a ubiquitous “high-oxidative-phosphorylation / mitochondrial activity” program rather than a lineage-restricted signature. Cells expressing it are in a metabolically active state that relies on mitochondrial respiration, heightened protein import/folding, and overall biosynthetic output—features commonly seen in differentiated, energy-demanding cells (e.g., oxidative muscle fibers, neurons, memory lymphocytes) or any cell transitioning from a quiescent to an energetically active phase. Evidence: • Multiple electron-transport-chain subunits point to boosted OXPHOS: ATP5F1E and ATP5MG (ATP-synthase, Complex V); COX7C (Complex IV); UQCR11 (Complex III). • TOMM7 encodes a component of the mitochondrial outer-membrane translocase, supporting increased import of nuclear-encoded respiratory proteins. • SERF2, PFDN5 (prefoldin), and TMA7 participate in protein folding/translation, consistent with elevated proteostatic demand during high metabolic activity. • OST4 (core oligosaccharyl-transferase) and POLR2L (RNA-polymerase II subunit) mark enhanced ER processing and transcription, typical accompaniments of generalized metabolic up-shift. Inconsistencies: • No marked inconsistencies; non-mitochondrial housekeeping genes (OST4, POLR2L, PFDN5) are broadly compatible with an overall biosynthetic/metabolic activation program rather than contradicting it.

program_20.description: The gene set is most consistent with a polarized, secretory mucosal epithelial program characteristic of mature intestinal or airway epithelial cells that actively transcytose polymeric IgA/IgM and display heightened vesicular trafficking, glycosylation and ion-transport activity. Evidence: • PIGR – canonical marker of mucosal epithelial cells responsible for IgA/IgM transcytosis across gut and airway epithelia. • ATP1B1, CDC42SE1, CTNNB1 – components of ion transport, cell polarity and WNT/β-catenin signaling that are broadly enriched in differentiated epithelial layers. • B4GALT1 – Golgi β-1,4-galactosyltransferase required for glycosylation of secreted proteins, prominent in secretory/absorptive epithelia. • RIN2, CDC42SE1 – Rab/CDC42 effectors supporting endocytic and exocytic vesicle traffic in polarized epithelial cells. • INSR and PHKG1 – reflect metabolic responsiveness (insulin signaling, glycogen mobilization) typical of absorptive gut/airway epithelia exposed to fluctuating nutrient levels. Inconsistencies: • PHKG1 is classically described as a muscle-biased phosphorylase-kinase isoform; its presence in this set is less typical for epithelium. • The list lacks canonical epithelial structural genes (e.g., EPCAM, KRT8/18); their absence may reflect gene-selection limits rather than true biological exclusion.

program_21.description: The gene set points to a mucosal chemosensory “tuft” epithelial cell program, a specialized, rare lineage found in airway, intestinal and urothelial epithelia that expresses multiple Ly6-family surface proteins and secreted innate-immunity factors. Evidence: • Ly6/PLAUR-domain surface proteins typical of tuft cells – LYPD2, PSCA and LYNX1 – are key canonical markers used to identify human and mouse tuft cells. • ASRGL1 and HEBP2 are repeatedly reported as enriched transcripts in single-cell profiles of mature intestinal and airway tuft cells. • PI3 (elafin) is an antimicrobial protease inhibitor produced by barrier epithelia, including tuft cells, consistent with their role in sensing pathogens and releasing innate-immune mediators. Inconsistencies: • S100A4 is better known for expression in fibroblasts/EMT states; its presence could reflect minor contamination or an activated epithelial phenotype rather than a core tuft signature. • PI3, while found in tuft cells, is also broadly expressed by other secretory epithelial subtypes, so it is not uniquely specific to the tuft lineage.

program_22.description: The program most closely matches an airway/bronchiolar secretory (club‐cell-like) epithelial state that is experiencing immune or stress activation. The gene set points to classic xenobiotic-metabolising and protease-rich functions of club cells (CYP4B1, MGST1, KLK11, CTSC) together with an interferon-responsive signal (LY6E) and a secreted matricellular factor (SERPINF1) that is reported in activated airway epithelial cells. Evidence: • Xenobiotic metabolism typical of club cells: CYP4B1 and MGST1 are signature cytochrome-P450 and glutathione-transferase enzymes highly enriched in human and mouse club/secretory airway epithelium. • Secreted/activatable serine proteases of airway secretory cells: KLK11 (kallikrein-related protease) and CTSC (cathepsin C, the activator of neutrophil- and airway-associated serine proteases). • Interferon / viral response overlay: LY6E is a well-established interferon-stimulated gene broadly induced in epithelial cells during viral challenge, consistent with an “activated” rather than quiescent club-cell phenotype. • Secreted stress-associated factor: SERPINF1 (PEDF) is reported to be produced by airway secretory epithelium under inflammatory conditions and is co-expressed with detoxification genes in scRNA-seq profiles of activated club cells. • Lack of lineage-restrictive immune markers and the absence of collagen or smooth-muscle genes support an epithelial rather than fibroblast, macrophage or muscle identity. Inconsistencies: • SERPINF1 is more classically viewed as a fibroblast/pericyte product; its presence could indicate a mixed epithelial-mesenchymal stress program. • LY6E is not club-cell specific and could reflect a broader interferon response shared with neighbouring immune cells.

program_23.description: The gene set most strongly expresses canonical molecular chaperones (HSP90AA1, HSPH1, HSPD1, DNAJA4) that are transcriptional targets of HSF1, pointing to a proteotoxic-stress / cytosolic heat-shock response state rather than a lineage-restricted cell identity. Evidence: • HSP90AA1, HSPH1 (HSP105/110) – major HSF1-induced cytosolic heat-shock proteins that refold mis-folded proteins and buffer proteotoxic stress. • HSPD1 – mitochondrial chaperonin HSP60, co-induced with cytosolic HSPs during generalized heat-shock. • DNAJA4 – HSP40 family co-chaperone that delivers substrates to HSP70/90 during stress. • Coordinated up-regulation of multiple chaperone families is a core signature of the heat-shock transcriptional program observed across diverse cell types. • ANKRD36C and SPIRE2 are reported to rise after thermal or oxidative stress and cytoskeletal remodeling, respectively, consistent with a generalized stress response. Inconsistencies: • SPIRE2 is primarily an actin nucleation factor and not a classical heat-shock gene; its presence may reflect concurrent cytoskeletal adaptation rather than proteotoxic stress per se. • ANKRD36C is poorly characterized and not definitively linked to the heat-shock pathway.

program_24.description: The gene set is most compatible with an epithelial secretory program characteristic of serous acinar cells in exocrine glands (e.g., salivary or lacrimal gland) that rely on intense ion- and water transport and an active endoplasmic-reticulum/secretory machinery. Evidence: • AQP5 – canonical water channel of salivary, lacrimal and other serous acinar cells, enabling rapid fluid secretion. • CLDN10 – tight-junction claudin enriched in secretory gland epithelia and required for paracellular Na⁺ movement that drives fluid secretion. • FXYD3 – Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase regulatory subunit highly expressed in gastric and other secretory epithelia, supporting ion fluxes that accompany fluid release. • XBP1 – master transcription factor for unfolded-protein response and ER expansion in high-output secretory cells, including exocrine glands. • TMEM59 & the ubiquitous MHC-I component B2M – broadly expressed but both participate in membrane/secretory pathway and are commonly elevated in cells with heavy secretory traffic, consistent with the above program. Inconsistencies: • Lack of classic acinar digestive enzyme or antimicrobial genes (e.g., AMY1, PRSS, LYZ) means the program may capture the generic ion-/water-secretion and ER-stress module rather than the full, mature acinar transcriptome. • B2M is ubiquitous; its high loading does not specifically point to serous acinar identity but is not contradictory.

program_25.description: The gene set is characteristic of late-stage erythroid cells (reticulocytes/erythrocytes) undergoing hemoglobinization, reflecting a red-blood-cell program dominated by globin production and supporting cytoskeletal components. Evidence: • HBA2 (hemoglobin α2) and HBB (hemoglobin β) are the principal α- and β-globin chains, respectively; their co-expression is a canonical signature of maturing erythroblasts and reticulocytes. • ANKRD36, ANKRD36B and ANKRD36C encode ankyrin-repeat proteins reported to interact with cytoskeletal ankyrins that stabilize the erythrocyte membrane, and their transcripts are enriched in erythroid lineages alongside globin genes. • Absence of transcripts typical of other hematopoietic or stromal lineages further supports a highly specific erythroid/hemoglobin program. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes are compatible with an erythroid, hemoglobin-rich state.

program_26.description: The gene set represents a basal epithelial/keratinocyte progenitor program characteristic of the basal layer of stratified epithelia (e.g., epidermis or airway mucosa), marked by structural keratins and factors linked to barrier maintenance and stem-like potential. Evidence: • Basal keratin signature – KRT5, KRT15, and KRT17 are canonical intermediate filaments of basal epithelial cells and epidermal stem/progenitors. • Calcium-binding/stress response – S100A2 is enriched in basal keratinocytes and up-regulated during epidermal differentiation stress, fitting a basal, yet activated, state. • Barrier and hydration gene – AQP3, a glycerol/water channel localized to basal and suprabasal keratinocytes and airway basal cells, supports an epithelial barrier program. Inconsistencies: • No obvious conflicting genes were present in the list provided.

program_27.description: The gene set points to a generic cellular stress-response program, marked by metallothionein-mediated metal/oxidative detoxification and mTOR suppression, rather than to a specific lineage; it is typically observed in cells experiencing heavy-metal exposure, hypoxia, or inflammatory oxidative stress. Evidence: • MT2A, MT1E, MT1X – classic metallothioneins induced by Zn²⁺/Cd²⁺ overload and reactive oxygen species, providing metal sequestration and antioxidant protection. • DDIT4 (REDD1) – canonical stress sensor activated by DNA damage, hypoxia, and ROS; inhibits mTORC1 to conserve energy under stress. • C19orf33 – up-regulated in genotoxic and oxidative stress conditions, often co-expressed with metallothioneins. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all loaded genes are compatible with a stress/metal-response program.

program_28.description: The program is most consistent with an activated SERPINF1-high fibroblast / perivascular stromal cell state that secretes anti-angiogenic and matrix-modifying factors, a profile frequently reported for adventitial fibroblasts and certain cancer-associated fibroblast (CAF) subsets. Evidence: • SERPINF1 (PEDF) – canonical secreted marker of fibroblasts, pericytes and SERPINF1+ CAFs; confers anti-angiogenic and matrix-modulating activity. • ITM2B – transmembrane protein enriched in mesenchymal/stromal cells and up-regulated in fibroblast activation and senescence. • EPHX1 – metabolic enzyme broadly expressed but notably high in fibroblasts and other stromal cells with active xenobiotic/oxidative detoxification. • CD9 – tetraspanin abundant on fibroblasts and CAFs, promotes extracellular vesicle release and cell–matrix interactions. • UBC – stress-responsive ubiquitin gene often elevated in highly secretory or proteostatically challenged stromal cells. Inconsistencies: • No strongly discordant genes are present; the list is limited and largely compatible with a fibroblast/perivascular stromal identity.

program_29.description: The program represents a universal acute heat-shock/stress response rather than a lineage-specific cell identity; it reflects cells experiencing proteotoxic stress and engaging the canonical HSF1-driven cytoprotective chaperone network. Evidence: • Strong up-regulation of major inducible HSP70 family members HSPA1A, HSPA1B and HSPA6, hallmark targets of heat-shock factor 1 (HSF1) during thermal or other proteotoxic stress. • Enrichment of DNAJB1 (HSP40 co-chaperone) that partners with HSP70s to refold misfolded proteins, typical of the heat-shock program. • Presence of HSP90AA1, another inducible chaperone coordinating protein folding and buffering damaged proteins under stress, commonly co-expressed with HSP70s during heat shock. • Absence of lineage-restricted markers and dominance of generalized chaperone genes support a stress state rather than a specific differentiated cell type. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all listed genes coherently fit a classical heat-shock/stress response program.

program_30.description: The program most closely matches a renal proximal‐tubule epithelial cell state distinguished by active amino-acid/creatine metabolism and secretion of glycoproteins. Evidence: • GATM – kidney-enriched mitochondrial enzyme catalyzing the first step of creatine biosynthesis; a canonical proximal-tubule marker. • GLYATL2 – acyl-transferase highly expressed in proximal-tubule epithelium, reflecting specialized amino-acid conjugation pathways present in this segment. • TF – transferrin transcripts are produced by proximal-tubule cells (in addition to hepatocytes) and participate in iron reabsorption in the nephron. • FGGY – carbohydrate kinase with strong expression in renal cortex/proximal-tubule tissue, fitting the high metabolic activity of these cells. • FCGBP – although best known in intestinal goblet cells, it is also reported in renal tubular epithelium and detected in human proximal-tubule single-cell datasets, consistent with a secretory, glycoprotein-rich apical surface. Inconsistencies: • FCGBP is more commonly associated with mucin-producing goblet cells; its presence requires noting but does not conflict strongly given documented renal expression.

program_31.description: The gene set strongly indicates a serous acinar cell program of the human parotid (and to a lesser extent submandibular) salivary gland, reflecting a highly secretory, saliva-producing state enriched for proline-rich salivary proteins. Evidence: • PRB1, PRB2, PRB3, PRB4 – Basic proline-rich salivary proteins synthesized almost exclusively by serous acinar cells of parotid and submandibular glands and secreted into saliva. • PRH2 – Histatin precursor gene, another salivary secretory product co-expressed with proline-rich proteins in serous acinar cells and absent from most other tissues. • Lack of negatively loaded genes further supports a focused secretory-acinar signature without opposing lineage markers. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes are canonical salivary secretory products.

program_0.description: The gene set depicts an alveolar type II (AT2) lung epithelial program that is acutely stressed, characterized by a strong heat-shock/unfolded-protein response and immediate-early transcriptional activation while being distinctly non-mast-cell. Evidence: • AT2 identity – high expression of surfactant genes SFTPA1, SFTPA2, SFTPB, SFTPC and the AT2/epithelial regulators GATA2 and HOPX. • Heat-shock / protein-folding stress – concerted up-regulation of chaperones HSPA1A, HSPA1B, HSP90AA1/AB1, HSPD1, HSPH1, HSPA6, DNAJ family members, HSPE1, BAG3. • Integrated stress / inflammatory signaling – PPP1R15A, DDIT4, SQSTM1, PTGS2, VEGFA, SGK1, MAFF, KLF2/KLF6, BTG2. • Immediate-early activation – transcription factors JUN, JUND, FOSB, EGR1/3, NR4A1/2/3, IER3/5, CREM indicating rapid stimulus-responsive state. • Negative loadings suppress mast-cell / myeloid markers (ALOX5AP, MS4A2, CPA3, IL1RL1) and vimentin (VIM), differentiating this program from stromal or mast-cell signatures. Inconsistencies: • Scattered immune genes (CD52, TNFRSF18, ACAP1, TMEM176B) are atypical for AT2 cells but can be induced by cytokine exposure. • FOS is negatively loaded whereas related AP-1 members (JUN, FOSB) are positive, suggesting selective regulation within the immediate-early network.

program_1.description: The gene set reflects an acutely activated, pro-inflammatory monocyte / macrophage state dominated by NF-κB and immediate-early response signaling, in which cytokine/chemokine production is up-regulated while MHC-II antigen-presentation genes are concurrently suppressed. Evidence: • NF-κB pathway activation – strong positive loading of canonical targets and regulators (NFKB1, NFKB2, REL, NFKBIA, NFKBID, NFKBIZ, TNFAIP3, BIRC3). • Inflammatory effector genes typical of LPS/TNF-stimulated monocytes (PTGS2/COX2, CSF1, CCL4/CCL4L2, AREG, PLAUR, ICAM1, BCL2A1, MCL1). • Immediate-early / stress-response transcription factors induced by TLR signaling (JUNB, JUND, FOSL2, EGR3, NR4A1/2/3, KDM6B, BATF, CREM, ID2, DDIT4, SOCS3, DUSP2/6). • Myeloid-lineage or granule constituents (SRGN, CTSG, SELENOK, FTH1, ANXA1) supporting a monocytic origin. • Negative loadings of antigen-presentation genes (HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, CD74, B2M) are characteristic of classical monocytes after TLR stimulation, which transiently down-regulate MHC-II. • Additional negative loading of mast-cell proteases (TPSB2, TPSD1) and TXNIP underscores a shift away from resting or alternative myeloid programs. Inconsistencies: • Presence of some T-cell activation markers (CD69, BATF, SRGN) and neutrophil granule enzyme CTSG could reflect minor contamination or shared early-response genes, but they are also inducible in activated monocytes and thus only partially discordant.

program_2.description: The gene set best fits a program active in classically activated (M1-like) inflammatory monocytes / monocyte-derived macrophages that are simultaneously experiencing a cellular-stress (heat-shock) response. Evidence: • Inflammatory monocyte/macrophage identity – S100A8, S100A9, IL1B, CXCL8, CXCL2, CXCL3, CCL3, CCL20, RETN: hallmark pro-inflammatory mediators of classical (M1) monocytes. – C1QA, C1QB, C1QC, AIF1 (IBA1): complement and cytoplasmic markers enriched in macrophages. – HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1/5, HLA-DPA1/B1, CD74: high MHC-II presentation typical of antigen-presenting monocytes/macrophages. – FABP4 is negatively loaded; its absence distinguishes infiltrating / inflammatory monocytes from resident FABP4-high alveolar macrophages and adipocytes. • Stress/heat-shock component – HSPA1A, HSPA1B, HSP90AA1, HSPE1, DNAJB1, SOD2, IFITM3, ATF3, JUN/JUND, KLF2/4/6: canonical heat-shock / oxidative-stress and immediate-early response genes frequently co-induced in acutely activated myeloid cells. Inconsistencies: • Cytotoxic lymphocyte genes GNLY, NKG7, GZMA, GZMH could reflect minor NK/T-cell contamination or shared IFN-driven transcripts. • ACKR1 (endothelial) and matrix genes DCN, MGP may derive from ambient RNA or doublets with stromal cells.

program_3.description: The gene set reflects an activated cytotoxic T-cell program—most consistent with effector/early memory CD8⁺ T cells that are releasing lytic granules and inflammatory chemokines, while explicitly excluding mast-cell identity. Evidence: • Cytotoxic machinery: GNLY, PRF1, NKG7, GZMA, GZMB, GZMH → canonical perforin/granzyme arsenal of cytotoxic T and NK cells. • T-cell lineage: CD3D, CD2, CD7, ACAP1, DOK2, CYTIP → define bona fide T cells (not NK). • Activation / effector cytokines‐chemokines: CCL3, CCL4, CCL5, IL32, CD69, JUN, ATF3 → hallmarks of recently activated effector or tissue-resident memory T cells. • Antigen-presentation and interferon response: HLA-A/B/C/F, B2M, IFIT2 → typical up-regulation in activated CD8⁺ T cells. • Stress-response / chaperones (HSPA1A/B, HSPB1, HSPA8) and transcriptional regulators (BTG1, ZFP36L2, KLF6) → frequently induced during T-cell activation and proliferation. • Negative loadings for mast-cell granule proteases TPSAB1, TPSB2, CPA3 and the vesicle marker CD63 → rule out mast-cell identity, reinforcing a T-cell–specific program. Inconsistencies: • CXCR4 is more typical of central-memory or bone-marrow–homing T cells, slightly less common in terminal effector CD8⁺ cells, but still compatible with early effector or tissue-resident states. • No NK-exclusive markers (e.g., KLRC1, FCGR3A) are present, supporting a T rather than NK program, but their absence could also reflect dataset coverage.

program_4.description: The program most strongly matches an “immediate-early activation” signature seen in antigen-presenting myeloid cells (monocyte-derived dendritic cells / inflammatory macrophages) that have just sensed an external stimulus (e.g. TLR ligands, cytokines, hypoxia). It is characterized by rapid AP-1/NF-κB transcriptional induction, metabolic re-wiring and classic early surface activation molecules, while genes typical of terminally secretory/ER-expanded plasma cells (e.g. SDF2L1) are repressed. Evidence: • Immediate-early transcription factors: FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB, EGR1, BTG2, ZFP36, DUSP1, IER2 – hallmark of acute stimulus response. • NF-κB / NR4A activation pathway: NFKBIZ, NFKBID, NR4A1, NR4A2, BHLHE40 – induced in activated monocytes/DCs. • Myeloid/APC surface or lineage genes: ITGAX (CD11c), PLAUR, GATA2, SYTL3 – enriched in dendritic cells / inflammatory macrophages. • Early activation marker CD69 – rapidly up-regulated upon immune cell stimulation. • Metabolic–stress components: SLC2A3 (GLUT3), DDIT4, HSPA5, HSP90B1, MAT2A – reflect glycolytic shift and unfolded-protein response accompanying activation. • Down-regulated SDF2L1 – a chaperone highly expressed in antibody-secreting plasma cells, fitting with a myeloid rather than B-cell state. Inconsistencies: • TPSD1 (mast-cell tryptase) and GATA2 are mast-cell associated; their presence without other mast-cell genes (KIT, TPSAB1, CPA3) suggests either low-level cross-lineage expression or mixed cell capture. • Lack of strong monocyte markers (LYZ, S100A8/A9) and of T-cell receptor genes (CD3D/E) means the exact lineage cannot be pinned to a single myeloid subset, but the overall activation program remains most consistent with recently stimulated antigen-presenting myeloid cells.

program_5.description: The program is characteristic of KIT-positive, connective-tissue mast cells in a relatively quiescent/de-granulated state distinguished by high expression of the mast-cell lineage transcription factor GATA2 and granule enzymes TPSD1 and CPA3, together with metabolic/chaperone genes that support secretory granule biogenesis, while simultaneously showing low levels of the alternative mast-cell tryptase TPSB2 and the de-granulation/lysosomal marker CD63. Evidence: • Lineage/identity – KIT, GATA2, SIGLEC6, IL1RL1, LCP1: canonical surface and regulatory genes of mast cells. • Granule enzymes – TPSD1 and CPA3 are mast-cell-specific proteases that define connective-tissue mast cells; ATP6V0C, RNASEK, ACTB/G contribute to acidified secretory granules. • Secretory-ER support – HSPA5, PDIA3, EEF1G, AHNAK, ACTB/G, MYH9 indicate high protein synthesis and vesicle traffic typical of granule-rich mast cells. • Negative loading – Reduced TPSB2 and CD63 suggests these cells favor the TPSD1+ subset and are not in an actively degranulating/lysosome-rich state; down-regulation of B2M and NDUFB8 is consistent with low MHC-I display and relatively low mitochondrial activity often seen in resting mast cells. Inconsistencies: • TPSB2 (a common mast-cell tryptase) is negatively loaded, implying suppression of a usual mast-cell marker; this may reflect a specific TPSD1-dominant mast-cell subset or maturation stage. • TMSB4X, UBB, BIRC3 are broadly expressed housekeeping or stress-response genes whose negative loading is not mast-cell–specific and may reflect general transcriptional repression rather than lineage identity.

program_6.description: The program is characteristic of airway secretory (club/Clara) epithelial cells in an innate-defense–activated state, as reflected by high expression of multiple secretoglobins and antimicrobial proteins typically produced by these cells. Evidence: • Club/secretory cell markers – SCGB1A1 (canonical club cell protein CC10) and SCGB3A1 are hallmark genes of non-ciliated secretory epithelium in bronchioles. • Upper and distal airway secretory products – BPIFB1 (PLUNC) and WFDC2 are abundantly expressed by airway secretory cells and contribute to airway surface fluid and host defense. • Innate antimicrobial/anti-protease factors – SLPI and LCN2 are inducible in airway epithelial cells during inflammatory or microbial challenge, consistent with an activated defensive state of club cells. Inconsistencies: • LCN2 is also produced by neutrophils; its presence could reflect either epithelial induction or minor neutrophil contamination, but it is reported to be epithelial-derived in inflamed airways and therefore partly compatible with the proposed state.

program_0.description: Gene expression pattern indicates epithelial cells that have switched from a quiescent, differentiated state to an acutely “activated / inflammatory” state driven by NF-κB and AP-1 signaling, as seen after TNF-α or IL-1β exposure, tissue damage, or early wound-healing. Evidence: • NF-κB target and feedback genes (NFKBIA, NFKB2, NFKBIZ, TNFAIP3, BIRC3, ICAM1, CXCL2, CXCL3, CCL2, IL32, PTGS2, SOCS2/3) mark canonical NF-κB activation. • Immediate-early/AP-1 transcription factors (FOS, FOSB, JUN, JUNB, ATF3, EGR1) and stress sensors (ZFP36, DUSP1, GADD45A/B) reflect rapid transcriptional activation. • Wound/repair-associated ligands and receptors (HBEGF, AREG, EDN1, ANGPTL4, TNFRSF12A, PLAUR, CCN1) align with epithelial regeneration programs. • Cytoprotective and oxidative-stress genes (HSPB1, HSP90AA1/AB1, HSPH1, DNAJB1, metallothioneins MT1E/MT2A/MT1X/MT1G/MT1F, SOD2) support a stress-response state. • Epithelial identity retained by keratins and junction genes (KRT7/8/18/19, CLDN4/7, LAMC2, SDC4, ITGA2), indicating the program is a state change within epithelial cells rather than a lineage switch. • Negative loading of mature/quiescent epithelial markers (HOPX, SFTA2, CEACAM6, GSTP1, S100A6) is consistent with loss of differentiated features during activation. Inconsistencies: • Very few; the core set coherently reflects an activated epithelial program. A small number of broadly expressed “house-keeping” or cytoskeletal genes (e.g., ACTB, ACTG1) contribute but do not contradict the interpretation.

program_1.description: The program most consistent with a lung alveolar type-II (AT2) epithelial cell that is experiencing an acute stress / inflammatory stimulus. Core AT2 lineage transcripts (SLC34A2, NAPSA, AGR2) are retained, while a broad heat-shock / immediate-early–gene cascade and modest interferon–antigen-presentation module are strongly induced, and markers of alveolar type-I cells and contractile mesenchyme are concurrently repressed. Evidence: • AT2 lineage/secretory genes up: SLC34A2, NAPSA, AGR2, CLDN4 (injury-induced AT2/transitional marker) • Stress/heat-shock chaperones up: HSPA1A/B, HSP90AA1/AB1, HSPB1, HSPH1, HSPD1, DNAJB1/4, BAG3, SERPINH1 • Immediate-early response up: JUN, FOS, JUNB, FOSB, ATF3, DUSP1, EGR1, IER2, GADD45A/B, BTG1/2 • Inflammatory / interferon & antigen presentation up: IFITM2/3, IL32, HLA-E, CD74, TSC22D3, SQSTM1 • Genes characteristic of alveolar type-I and mesenchymal cells down: AGER and CAV1 (ATI markers), TAGLN & MYL9 (smooth-muscle/fibroblast), ALDH1A1 (club cell), GSTP1, S100A4 Inconsistencies: • NDNF, IGFBP7 and SRGN are not classical AT2 genes and may reflect paracrine signaling or low-level contamination. • Lack of KRT8/KRT17 induction, often seen in reported AT2-to-ATI “transitional” states, suggests the program is more generic stress activation than full transdifferentiation.

program_2.description: The gene set is most consistent with a lung alveolar type II-derived epithelial program that has lost key mature surfactant genes and instead expresses a broad secretory/inflammatory signature typical of lung adenocarcinoma or an injury-induced “transitional” (de-differentiated) AT2 state. Evidence: • Alveolar/adenocarcinoma lineage markers (positive loadings): NAPSA, SFTPB, ABCA3, SLC34A2, MSLN, CEACAM6, MUC1, WFDC2, ALPP – all frequently seen in AT2-derived lung tumors and transitional AT2 cells. • General epithelial and secretory proteins: CST3, S100A10, IGFBP7, AQP5, AQP1, DUOX1, SLPI support an epithelial secretory identity. • Interferon-stimulated and stress/inflammatory genes: IFI27, IFI6, IFITM2/3, LCN2, MIF, GSTP1, MGST1 indicate an activated/injured state common in malignant or regenerating epithelium. • Negative loadings for canonical mature AT2 genes (SFTPC, SFTPA1, SFTPA2) and the ER-stress marker DDIT3 denote loss of full AT2 differentiation, aligning with a de-differentiated or tumor phenotype. Inconsistencies: • Residual AT2 components (ABCA3, SFTPB) remain positively loaded despite loss of SFTPC/A1/A2, suggesting the cells are not fully de-differentiated; this is, however, frequently observed in both transitional AT2 cells and lung adenocarcinoma where partial lineage programs persist.

program_3.description: The gene set most closely matches an alveolar type I (AT1) epithelial-cell program in human lung that is accompanied by mild interferon activation and extracellular-matrix remodeling. Evidence: • Core AT1/epithelial markers up-regulated: AGER, CLDN18, UPK3B, CYP4B1, RTKN2, EPCAM, TACSTD2/TROP2, CD151, CD9, CAV1 all characterize differentiated alveolar type I cells. • Surfactant-producing AT2 genes are selectively down-weighted: SFTPA1, SFTPA2 (and chaperones HSP90AA1, DNAJB1 that serve the secretory pathway) are negatively loaded, consistent with an AT1 rather than AT2 identity. • Interferon/MHC class-I activation within epithelium: IFI6, IFI27, HLA-A/B/C/E up-regulated, indicating an interferon-stimulated AT1 state often seen during viral sensing or inflammatory stress. • Matrix/adhesion remodeling genes enriched: SPARC, IGFBP7, CCN1, GAS6, S100A4/S100A6 and tetraspanins (TSPAN13, CD151) are typical of AT1 cells engaged in basement-membrane interaction and wound repair. • Additional epithelial and secretory factors (SLPI, SUSD2, CLDN18, SELENOP) further support a lung epithelial phenotype. Inconsistencies: • SFTPB (a canonical AT2 surfactant gene) is positively loaded, suggesting some residual AT2 signature or mixed differentiation. • FLT3LG and MSLN are not typical of AT1 cells and may reflect low-level paracrine signaling or ambient RNA contamination.

program_4.description: The gene set is most consistent with an injury-induced, alveolar epithelial “transitional” program—cells that still retain some type-II (AT2) features but are beginning to acquire type-I (AT1) characteristics and a stress / interferon response (often referred to as pre-AT1 transitional cells or KRT8+ intermediates in lung repair).
