Evidence: • Residual AT2 identity – surfactant/secretory genes SFTPB, SFTA2, PPDPF, VAMP8 and GGT1 remain positively loaded. • Loss of mature AT2 markers – the canonical AT2 gene SLC34A2 is negatively loaded, indicating down-regulation as the program rises. • Early AT1 / differentiation markers – HOPX (early AT1), IFI27 and LGALS1 are positively loaded, while mature AT1 marker AGER is negatively loaded, matching a transitional, not fully AT1, state. • Stress / interferon and wound-healing signature typical of transitional cells – ISG15, BST2, FLT3LG, MIF, multiple S100 family members (S100A4/6/10/11), TAGLN2 and PRDX1 are enriched. • Aberrant basaloid / transitional epithelial markers common in lung injury and fibrosis – CEACAM6, MSLN, SUSD2 are positively loaded. Inconsistencies: • ICAM1 and CCN1, which can rise in some reparative epithelial states, are negatively loaded, and absence of classic KRT8/CLDN4 transitional markers may reflect dataset-specific expression thresholds rather than a fundamentally different program.

program_5.description: The gene pattern is most consistent with an antigen-presenting, pro-inflammatory monocyte / macrophage program (e.g., inflammatory tissue macrophages or recently-recruited monocytes) that displays strong MHC-II expression, complement activation and S100A8/A9-driven inflammatory activity, while lacking epithelial and endothelial signatures. Evidence: • Antigen presentation: very high loadings for multiple MHC-II genes (HLA-DRA, ‑DRB1/5, ‑DPB1, ‑DPA1, ‑DMA) and the invariant chain CD74. • Myeloid / macrophage identity: TYROBP (DAP12), C1QB, CYBA, APOE, APOC1, FABP4/5, SERPINA1, FTL/FTH1 and VIM are canonical macrophage or monocyte transcripts. • Inflammatory activation: S100A8, S100A9 and GPX1 are hallmark genes of inflammatory monocytes/macrophages. • Phagocytic / lipid-handling features: NPC2, FABP4/5, APOE, APOC1 support a macrophage engaged in lipid processing. • Negative loadings suppress epithelial / endothelial programs (AGER, EMP2, CAV1, COL4A3, AQP4, CCN1, ABCA1), reinforcing that the positive component represents non-epithelial myeloid cells. Inconsistencies: • CEACAM6 is more typical of epithelial cells or neutrophils but can be detected in some activated macrophages. • ABCA1, often abundant in lipid-laden macrophages, is negatively loaded. • HLA-B (class I) is negatively loaded despite most macrophages expressing it constitutively.

program_6.description: This program reflects a lung secretory-epithelial state dominated by mature, surfactant-producing alveolar type II (AT2) cells with contributions from club (Clara) cells, and it is characteristic of a homeostatic, non-inflamed condition (low MHC-II / interferon signaling). Evidence: • Surfactant machinery — SFTPC, SFTPA1, SFTPA2, CTSH, NPC2, PGC, RAB11FIP1: canonical markers of AT2 cells that synthesize, process, and recycle surfactant. • Club-cell secretory products — SCGB1A1, SCGB3A1, SCGB3A2, BPIFB1, CXCL17: hallmarks of airway club/secretory epithelial cells often co-expressed in AT2–club transitional states. • Lipid / vesicle trafficking needed for lamellar bodies — FABP5, PLCG2, VEGFA, RNF213, DENND3, RAB11FIP1 support surfactant-lipid handling typical of AT2 cells. • Basement-membrane/adhesion genes — COL4A3, DST, UTRN, AFDN stabilize the epithelial barrier in alveoli. • Negative loading of inflammatory/MHC-II genes — HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, CD74, IFITM2, IFITM3, IL32, SERPINA1 indicates suppression of interferon and antigen-presentation pathways, consistent with a quiescent, non-inflamed epithelial state. Inconsistencies: • Few genes (e.g., NKTR, VEGFA) are more typical of signaling/immune interaction or endothelial crosstalk, but they are occasionally expressed by AT2 cells and do not contradict the overall secretory-epithelial identity.

program_7.description: The gene set most strongly reflects an epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) / cytoskeletal contractility program seen in epithelial cells that are acquiring migratory, stress-fiber and smooth-muscle–like features (so-called “partial EMT” or “epithelial-myofibroblast” state). Evidence: • Contractile/stress-fiber machinery – MYL9, MYL6, MYL12A, TAGLN, ACTB, CALM2 and TMSB4X encode myosin light chains, actin-binding proteins, and calcium modulators that are prototypical of EMT-driven cytoskeletal re-organization and cell motility. • Plasma-membrane/cell adhesion remodelers – ANXA2 (focal adhesion turnover) and FXYD3 (ion-pump regulator up-regulated in metastatic carcinomas) are repeatedly described as EMT-induced genes. • EMT-linked epithelial markers – KRT19 often persists during partial EMT, while AGER and ADIRF are reported to rise in epithelium undergoing EMT in lung and breast cancer models, supporting a transitional epithelial origin rather than a fully differentiated smooth-muscle lineage. • Negative loading of NDNF, a neuro-angiocrine/endothelial factor not typically expressed in EMT programmes, is consistent with a shift away from a quiescent paracrine/endothelial-like state. Inconsistencies: • C1QB is a classical macrophage complement component and is not generally associated with EMT; it may represent low-level contamination or ambient RNA. • AGER is best known as an alveolar type-I marker; its presence may indicate that the programme is occurring in lung epithelium specifically rather than universally across epithelia.

program_8.description: The program represents a canonical SREBP-driven “cholesterogenic / lipogenic” state, characteristic of cells that are actively synthesizing membranes—e.g., cycling tumor cells, proliferating stem/progenitor populations, or metabolically activated hepatocytes—rather than marking a lineage-restricted cell type. Evidence: • Sterol-biosynthesis core: HMGCS1, MVD, MSMO1 and SQLE are sequential enzymes of the mevalonate–cholesterol pathway, classically up-regulated by SREBF2 in proliferating or lipid-depleted cells. • Fatty-acid synthesis arm: FASN couples de-novo fatty-acid production to sterol synthesis, a coordinated response governed by SREBF1 for membrane biogenesis. • Regulatory node: INSIG1 is an ER sensor that controls SREBP activation; its co-induction with the enzymatic genes is a hallmark of an engaged SREBP feedback loop. Inconsistencies: No obvious contradictions; all listed genes coherently belong to the same lipid/sterol biosynthetic program.

program_0.description: The gene set most closely matches an antigen-presenting, lipid-laden inflammatory alveolar macrophage (“foamy” alveolar macrophage) state that is common in the distal lung during injury or infection; abundant surfactant transcripts are likely derived from engulfed type II pneumocyte material or ambient RNA rather than indicating an epithelial identity. Evidence: • Core macrophage / myeloid markers: CD68, LYZ, CTSB, CTSD, FCER1G, TYROBP, ALOX5AP, C1QA/B/C, CST3. • High MHC-II antigen-presentation: HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DPA1 (class II up), supporting an antigen-presenting macrophage phenotype. • Lipid-handling “foamy” macrophage genes: APOE, APOC1, APOC1, FTL, FTH1, NBEAL1, S100A8/A9/A10/A11, DDIT4, consistent with surfactant/lipid uptake. • Inflammatory activation: S100A8, S100A9, DDIT4, IFITM3. • Negative load of HLA-C, B2M and IRF7 suggests reduced class I / interferon signaling, typical of certain lung tissue–resident macrophage states. Inconsistencies: • Strong surfactant genes (SFTPA1, SFTPA2, SFTPB, SFTPC) and epithelial factor AREG point to type II pneumocytes; their presence is likely due to engulfment or ambient RNA rather than true epithelial identity. • CD74 (invariant chain) is negatively loaded even though other MHC-II genes are positive, indicating some discordance within the antigen-presentation program.

program_1.description: The gene set is most consistent with activated antibody-secreting B cells—i.e., plasmablasts/plasma cells characterized by strong expansion of the endoplasmic-reticulum and secretory machinery required for high-rate immunoglobulin production. Evidence: • B-cell lineage markers: CD79A (BCR component), CD74 (invariant chain), CD27 and FCRL5 (post-germinal-center memory/plasma subsets). • Plasma-cell differentiation regulators: XBP1 (master UPR/plasma factor), MZB1, FKBP11, DERL3, PRDX4, ERLEC1 and SSR4—genes up-regulated during UPR-driven antibody secretion. • High secretory/ER processing components: SEC11C, SPCS1, LMAN1, TMED10, TMEM59, B2M, HLA-A/B/C, JCHAIN—classically elevated in plasmablasts producing multimeric IgA/IgM. • Activation marker CD38 and lysosomal/exosomal proteins (CD63, PSAP, NPC2) fit the high metabolic/secretory state. • Negatively loaded housekeeping/proliferation genes (EEF1A1, PPIA, HMGN2, PTMA) reflect the reduced cell-cycle/protein-synthesis signature typical once cells terminally differentiate into plasma cells. Inconsistencies: • MSMB (prostate secretory protein) and CRIP1 (often mesenchymal) are atypical for B lineage. • ICAM3 and LY96 are more broadly leukocyte/myeloid; their presence may reflect mixed regulation or ambient RNA rather than true expression.

program_2.description: The gene pattern is most compatible with an activated, metabolically-engaged T cell program in which cytosolic translation, glycolysis and immunoproteasome activity are up‐regulated while ER/secretory-pathway and plasma-cell-like genes are concomitantly suppressed. Evidence: • T-cell/adaptor genes up: LIME1 (T-cell receptor signalling adaptor), CORO1A and COTL1 (actin regulators enriched in lymphocytes) support a T-cell identity. • Metabolic/translation boost: glycolytic enzymes GAPDH, LDHA, TPI1 and elongation factors EEF1B2/EEF1G indicate high glycolytic flux and protein synthesis typical of activated T cells. • Proteostasis skewed to cytosol: immunoproteasome component PSME2, core proteasome PSMA6, ubiquitin genes UBA52/FAU and autophagy factor GABARAP point to enhanced cytosolic protein turnover seen after T-cell activation. • ER/secretory genes down: plasma-cell-linked JCHAIN, tetraspanin CD63 and multiple ERAD/UPR components (SSR4, HERPUD1, DNAJB9, FKBP2, SELENOK, SELENOS) have negative loadings, consistent with a non-secretory lymphocyte rather than an antibody-secreting cell. Inconsistencies: • Some ER chaperones (HSPA5, HSP90B1) are positively loaded despite the general suppression of ER/UPR genes, suggesting either basal ER stress handling or partial mixing of programs.

program_3.description: The program represents a generic acute-stress / immediate-early gene (IEG) response that many cell types display within minutes to hours of tissue dissociation, heat shock, cytokine, or MAPK activation. It is not lineage-restricted but instead marks a transient activated state characterized by AP-1 transcription factors, heat-shock proteins, stress-inducible phosphatases, and NF-κB modulators. Evidence: • AP-1 / IEG transcription factors: JUN, JUNB, JUND, FOS, FOSB, ATF3, EGR1, NR4A1, IER2, BTG2 – canonical markers of the rapid IEG burst after stress or mechanical dissociation. • Heat-shock / proteotoxic-stress chaperones: HSPA1A, HSPA1B, HSP90AA1, HSP90AB1, HSPH1, HSPB1, HSPE1, DNAJB1/4, DNAJA1 – hallmark of heat-shock and unfolded-protein responses. • Stress-induced MAPK inhibitors & phosphatases: DUSP1, DUSP2, DUSP5, PPP1R15A, GADD45B – negative feedback regulators induced by acute MAPK signaling. • NF-κB/STAT negative feedback: NFKBIA, SOCS3, TSC22D3 – rapidly induced inhibitors that curb inflammatory signaling following stimulation. • General stress/ubiquitin-proteasome & autophagy components: UBC, SQSTM1 – facilitate protein quality control during stress. • Cell-survival/anti-apoptotic factor: MCL1 – commonly up-regulated to preserve viability during acute stress. Inconsistencies: • ST6GAL1 (Golgi glycosyltransferase), EZR (cytoskeletal linker), and LMNA (nuclear lamina) are not classic IEGs; however, they can be secondarily elevated in some activated or mechanically stressed cells, so their presence is not strongly contradictory.

program_4.description: The gene set represents a universal “cell-cycle/proliferation” program characteristic of cells in late S-phase through G2/M, rather than a lineage-restricted cell type. Evidence: • Canonical proliferation markers – MKI67, BIRC5 (Survivin), PTTG1, PCLAF, CENPW, NUSAP1, MAD2L1 – are hallmarks of cells preparing for or undergoing mitosis. • DNA synthesis enzymes – RRM2, TYMS, TK1, DUT, DHFR – peak in S-phase and supply nucleotides for replication. • Microtubule and spindle components – TUBA1B, TUBB, STMN1, RAN – are required for spindle assembly in G2/M. • Chromatin/histone regulators – H2AZ1, H4C3, HMGB1/2, HMGN2, PTMA – facilitate DNA packaging and chromosome segregation in dividing cells. • Elevated metabolic/housekeeping genes – GAPDH, ACTB, TPI1, PPIA – typically rise with the high biosynthetic demand of cycling cells. Inconsistencies: No strongly discordant genes; “housekeeping” transcripts (e.g., GAPDH, ACTB) are not specific to proliferation but are commonly up-regulated in rapidly dividing cells, so they do not contradict the cell-cycle interpretation.

program_5.description: The gene set reflects a respiratory-epithelial secretory (club/goblet-like) program that endows airway lining cells with mucosal defense and secreted protein production, typical of club cells and related secretory progenitors in the bronchiolar epithelium. Evidence: • Secretoglobins SCGB1A1 (uteroglobin/CCSP) and SCGB3A1 are canonical markers of airway club/secretory cells. • BPIFB1 (LPLUNC1), SLPI and WFDC2 encode antimicrobial, protease-inhibitory proteins that are highly expressed and secreted by airway secretory and goblet cells to protect the mucosal surface. • Co-expression of KRT17 with the secretory factors is characteristic of a “secretory-progenitor” or stress-responsive subset of airway secretory cells that lies between basal and mature club cells, reinforcing an epithelial, secretory identity rather than another lineage. Inconsistencies: • KRT17 is more typical of basal/suprabasal or stress-induced epithelial states than of fully differentiated club cells, indicating the program may represent a transitional or injured secretory state rather than classic, quiescent club cells.

program_0.description: The program most strongly matches an airway (or other mucosal) secretory epithelial cell that has differentiated toward a goblet-like state and is simultaneously experiencing an interferon-driven inflammatory response; it is characterized by high mucin production and broad MHC-I up-regulation, while classical club-cell genes are repressed. Evidence: • Goblet / secretory epithelium – high expression of canonical mucins and supporting factors (MUC5AC, MUC16, MUC1, AGR2, WFDC2/HE4, BPIFB1, LCN2, CXCL17, SLPI, CLDN7, KRT19). • Goblet differentiation over club identity – strong negative loading of club-cell markers SCGB1A1 and SCGB3A1, together with positive loading of ALOX15 and CXCL17, proteins enriched in goblet cells. • Interferon / inflammatory activation – enrichment of IFI27, LY6E, HLA-A/B/C, B2M and antigen-presentation cofactor LGALS3, consistent with an epithelial antiviral response. • General secretory/metabolic support – presence of ALDH1A1, ALDH3A1, GSTP1, PRDX1, SAT1 and PLAAT4, enzymes commonly elevated in metabolically active airway secretory cells. Inconsistencies: • Detox enzymes more typical of club cells or hepatic tissue (ALDH1A1, AKR1C2, ADH1C) and prostate-associated MSMB are included, but these genes can be variably expressed in airway secretory/goblet cells and do not outweigh the dominant goblet/interferon signature.

program_1.description: The program reflects a differentiated, non-cycling secretory epithelial (goblet-/mucus-like) state characterized by high secretory-pathway activity and extracellular matrix/modulatory factor release, typical of mature intestinal or airway goblet cells or other trefoil-factor–producing luminal epithelia. Evidence: • Goblet/secretory epithelial products – TFF3 (classical goblet-cell trefoil factor), MS4A8 (murine colonic goblet marker; human homolog enriched in secretory epithelium), AZGP1 and LGALS3BP (secreted luminal proteins). • Secretory-pathway machinery – SEC11C, VAMP2, ICA1, EMC10, APP (signal peptidase, vesicle fusion and ER components) support heavy protein secretion. • Anti-proliferative/differentiation regulators – BTG1, CDKN2C, ID2, TIMP1, SERPINF1 indicate exit from cell cycle and mature phenotype. • Epithelial/immune surveillance context – HLA-A (MHC-I) expressed by differentiated epithelia engaged in antigen presentation. Inconsistencies: • Neuron-biased genes (BEX3/BEX4, SNRPN) and the neuronal v-SNARE VAMP2 are unusual for gut/airway epithelium, though they can be ectopically expressed in secretory tumors. • Lack of canonical mucins (e.g., MUC2) or transcription factor SPDEF leaves the goblet identity inferential rather than definitive.

program_2.description: The gene set represents an immediate-early activation/inflammatory response program, frequently seen when epithelial-derived cells (and many other somatic cell types) experience acute stimulation such as cytokine, growth-factor or stress signals. Evidence: • Canonical immediate-early transcription factors: FOS, JUN, JUNB, FOSB, EGR1, ATF3, NR4A1, IER2, KLF6 and BTG2 are hallmark “early response” genes rapidly induced without de-novo protein synthesis. • Negative feedback / signal-attenuating genes typical of this program: DUSP1 (MAPK phosphatase) and ZFP36 (tristetraprolin) dampen MAPK and cytokine mRNA stability, respectively. • Pro-inflammatory chemokines induced downstream of AP-1: CXCL8 (IL-8) and CXCL1 recruit neutrophils; CCN1 (CYR61) is a classic serum-response/AP-1 target. • CLDN4 and NCOA7 are often up-regulated in activated or injured epithelia, supporting an epithelial context for the stimulus-responsive program. Inconsistencies: • No strongly discordant genes; CLDN4 is a tight-junction component not universally induced in all cell types by stress, but its expression is common in epithelial cells and compatible with an epithelial activation state.

program_3.description: The expression pattern is most consistent with epithelial cells transitioning toward a multiciliated fate (the deuterosomal / early ciliogenesis state) and simultaneously up-regulating lysosome-autophagy and protein-synthesis machinery required for massive basal-body production. Evidence: • CDC20B––canonical deuterosomal marker induced just before the appearance of multiple motile cilia. • GABARAP, ATP6V0C, RNASEK––autophagy/endolysosomal components that are typically boosted during centriole amplification and organelle remodeling in ciliating airway and oviduct epithelium. • LRRC26––BK-channel auxiliary subunit enriched in airway and colonic secretory/ciliated epithelium, often co-expressed with ciliogenesis genes. • House-keeping biosynthetic genes (EEF1G, NME2) up-loaded, matching the high translational demand of ciliogenesis. • Negative loading of TMSB4X (actin-sequestering protein) and SAT1 (polyamine catabolism enzyme) aligns with their reported down-regulation as epithelial cells exit proliferation and reorganize the cytoskeleton for basal-body docking. Inconsistencies: • MIF is a broadly expressed cytokine and not specific to ciliating cells. • LRRC26 can also mark secretory (goblet) cells, so its presence alone is not uniquely cilia-specific.

program_4.description: The gene set reflects an inflammatory, interferon-γ–stimulated antigen-presenting myeloid cell (activated monocyte/macrophage or inflammatory dendritic cell) characterized by high MHC class II expression and concurrent acute-phase/innate immune protein production. Evidence: • Antigen presentation: Strong coordinated up-regulation of MHC-II genes HLA-DRA, HLA-DRB1, HLA-DPA1, HLA-DPB1, HLA-DMA together with the invariant chain CD74 is the canonical signature of professional APCs activated by IFN-γ. • Inflammatory/acute-phase response: LCN2 (lipocalin-2) and the serum amyloid genes SAA1 and SAA2 are induced in activated monocytes/macrophages and inflammatory dendritic cells during innate immune responses. Inconsistencies: • ZG16B is more commonly associated with secretory/goblet epithelial cells, making its presence atypical for myeloid APCs, although it can be detected in some inflamed tissues and secretory granules.

program_5.description: The gene constellation points to a generic “RNA- and DNA-damage stress” program that many cell types engage when they experience oxidative or genotoxic stress rather than to a lineage-restricted identity. The module couples (i) enhanced RNA splicing/quality-control and translational re-programming, (ii) ubiquitin-mediated protein turnover, (iii) DNA base-excision repair and (iv) intact mitochondrial respiration—features commonly up-regulated in proliferating or hypoxia-exposed cells, including tumor and activated immune cells. Evidence: • RNA processing / nonsense-mediated decay: SMG1 (master NMD kinase), SRSF6 and IWS1 (spliceosome/elongation factors), EIF4E2 (4EHP; switches translation toward stress-responsive mRNAs). • DNA damage / repair: NEIL1 (removes oxidized bases), USP34 (de-ubiquitinase active in WNT and DNA-damage checkpoints). • Mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation & ROS source: SDHD (succinate dehydrogenase subunit). • Stress-linked membrane trafficking / immune evasion: CMTM6 stabilises PD-L1, commonly induced by IFN and cellular stress pathways. • FAM221A, although poorly characterised, is co-expressed with proliferation- and stress-associated genes in several cancers, fitting the same context. Inconsistencies: • No conspicuous markers of a specific lineage (e.g., epithelial, lymphoid, myeloid) are present, underscoring that the program reflects a state (stress response) rather than a distinct cell type.

program_6.description: The gene set is most consistent with a motile-ciliated, secretory barrier epithelium found in the central nervous system—i.e., choroid-plexus/ependymal cells executing an oxidative- and xenobiotic-detoxification program. Evidence: • Ciliogenesis/ependymal marker – SNTN (Sentan) is a structural component of motile cilia, highly enriched in ependymal cells that line the ventricles. • Secretory/barrier factors – IGFBP2 and IGFBP7 are abundantly secreted by choroid-plexus and other barrier epithelia and modulate IGF signalling in cerebrospinal fluid. • Detoxification/antioxidant enzymes – GSTA1 (glutathione-S-transferase A1), CES1 (carboxylesterase 1) and PRDX5 (peroxiredoxin 5) form a canonical phase-II xenobiotic and reactive-oxygen-species defence module that is up-regulated in choroid-plexus epithelium exposed to blood-borne metabolites. • CNS context support – OMG (oligodendrocyte myelin glycoprotein) is a CNS-restricted glycoprotein that can be released into cerebrospinal fluid and is detected in choroid-plexus transcriptomes, aligning the program with a brain-resident cell type. Inconsistencies: • GSTA1 and CES1 are classically regarded as liver-enriched enzymes; their co-expression with ciliary genes is less typical and may reflect a heightened detox requirement rather than cell-identity per se. • OMG is primarily an oligodendrocyte product; its presence may derive from ambient myelin transcripts or phagocytosed material rather than active expression by ependymal cells.

program_7.description: The program most plausibly reflects a generally “activated/inflammatory” state typical of innate-immune cells (e.g. monocytes/macrophages) or recently stimulated T cells, characterized by NF-κB–dependent transcription and increased protein-synthesis capacity while oxidative-phosphorylation genes are relatively repressed. Evidence: • AKIRIN1 (+) – nuclear co-factor required for Toll-like-receptor / NF-κB transcriptional responses in macrophages and other innate-immune cells. • EIF4G1 (+) – core translation-initiation scaffold; its induction accompanies immune-cell activation and the burst of protein synthesis that follows stimulation. • SERINC3 (+) – up-regulated in activated lymphocytes and macrophages and contributes to anti-viral defence, further pointing to an immune activation context. • SDHD (–) – mitochondrial complex-II subunit; its down-regulation is seen during the metabolic shift from oxidative phosphorylation to glycolysis that accompanies pro-inflammatory activation (Warburg-like switch) in both macrophages and effector T cells. • CTDNEP1 (–) – phosphatase involved in lipid-metabolic and nuclear-envelope homeostasis; reduced expression has been reported upon inflammatory signalling and ER-stress, consistent with an activated state. Inconsistencies: • The gene set is small and lacks canonical cytokines or surface markers (e.g. IL1B, TNF, CD40) that would definitively pin down an immune lineage. • All positively loaded genes are broadly expressed “house-keeping” factors; thus, while their regulation fits an activation program, they are not exclusive to immune cells, leaving some ambiguity in cell-type assignment.

program_8.description: The gene set reflects a high-oxidative-phosphorylation (OXPHOS) metabolic program, characteristic of cells that rely heavily on mitochondrial respiration—for example actively respiring epithelial, neuronal or memory immune cells—rather than defining a specific lineage. Evidence: • COX7A2 and COX6C – nucleus-encoded subunits of cytochrome-c oxidase (complex IV), hallmark of enhanced electron-transport‐chain activity. • ATP5MK – F0 subunit of ATP synthase (complex V), up-regulated when mitochondrial ATP production is prioritized. • CHCHD2 – mitochondrial stress-response protein that boosts complex IV activity and supports oxidative metabolism. • H2AZ1 – histone variant that is induced during metabolic and chromatin remodeling programs accompanying elevated mitochondrial gene transcription. Inconsistencies: • None apparent; all detected genes align with an OXPHOS/mitochondrial up-regulation state.

program_9.description: The program most consistently fits an epithelial cell undergoing (or maintaining) a motile-ciliated state, characterised by apico-basal polarity, active RNA-processing machinery and elevated mitochondrial quality control. Evidence: • ODAD4 – core component of the outer dynein-arm docking complex; selectively expressed in motile cilia of airway, ependymal and oviduct epithelia, a definitive marker of ciliated epithelial differentiation. • LLGL2 – polarity protein of the Scribble/Lgl complex; required for establishment of apico-basal polarity in epithelial sheets, a prerequisite for correct positioning of the ciliary basal body. • FUS and RBM26 – multifunctional RNA-binding/splicing factors; high expression is typical of cells executing large transcriptomic remodelling such as ciliogenesis. • SPG7 – mitochondrial m-AAA protease; motile-ciliated cells rely on robust mitochondrial quality control to meet the ATP demand of ciliary beating, and SPG7 is up-regulated during such metabolic programmes. Inconsistencies: • Apart from ODAD4, the remaining genes are broadly expressed housekeeping factors; their presence alone does not uniquely specify ciliated epithelium and could reflect a generic RNA-processing/mitochondrial maintenance programme.

program_0.description: The gene set reflects a mature airway secretory (club/goblet) epithelial program characterized by high expression of secretoglobins and antimicrobial/secretory effector genes, with relative down-regulation of generic simple-epithelium keratins (KRT8/18) and other housekeeping transcripts—consistent with differentiated club cells responding to airway irritation or infection. Evidence: • Canonical club-cell markers SCGB1A1 (CC10) and SCGB3A1 (UGRP2) strongly enriched. • Secretory/antimicrobial genes typical of airway epithelium—SLPI, WFDC2, LCN2, AGR2, S100A11—are co-up-regulated. • Epithelial identity maintained via KRT19 and FXYD3, both abundant in airway secretory cells. • Negative loadings for KRT8 and KRT18 (often higher in less-specialized simple epithelium) and for CD9 and ATP6V0B suggest a shift away from a generic epithelial/housekeeping program toward a specialized secretory state. Inconsistencies: • LCN2 and S100A11 are also expressed by neutrophils and other cell types, but their presence in many secretory epithelial signatures makes this only a minor ambiguity. • H3-3B and SEC11C are ubiquitous housekeeping genes; their negative loading may simply reflect decreased relative expression rather than true absence.

program_1.description: The gene set is most consistent with a simple-/ductal-type epithelial program typified by cholangiocytes or other KRT19⁺ epithelial progenitors that are under a stress- or injury-responsive state (detoxification/repair). Evidence: • KRT19 – hallmark keratin of simple duct and biliary epithelium; widely used marker for cholangiocytes and epithelial progenitors. • LGALS3 (galectin-3) – strongly expressed by cholangiocytes and up-regulated during biliary injury and epithelial repair. • S100A6 – Ca²⁺-binding protein enriched in proliferative or regenerating biliary/ductal epithelium. • GSTP1 and CBR1 – phase II (GSTP1) and carbonyl detoxification (CBR1) enzymes that are characteristically high in cholangiocytes, reflecting their need to metabolize toxic bile constituents and oxidative stress. Inconsistencies: • LGALS3 and S100A6 are also found in activated macrophages/fibroblasts, but the simultaneous presence of the epithelial keratin KRT19 and detoxification enzymes favors a ductal epithelial rather than mesenchymal or immune identity.
